Their money is well earned.'b'MAX RAIMI'b'\nChicago, Dec. 28, 2013'b''b'The changing nature of politics has reshaped lobbying, not necessarily for the worse. Top dogs in Washington\xe2\x80\x99s influence industry are losing ground to a new breed.'b'The strategic adviser with clean hands, who stands aloof from the grunt work of cornering members of the House and Senate in Capitol hallways and the hassle of remembering committee secretaries by name, is now ascendant. Never mind those nightly fund-raisers.'b'If you look at the numbers, it may seem that lobbying is in decline, but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t; it\xe2\x80\x99s just taking different forms. What was once straightforward lobbying has become, in effect, a full service PR-advertising-social media operation, very little of which is covered by federal regulation.'b'In a field buffeted by the economic meltdown of 2008, the current legislative standstill on Capitol Hill, the emergence of high-tech competitors and the passage of the 'b'Honest Leadership and Open Government Act of 2007'b'  (which subjects registered lobbyists to a stringent regulatory regime including the threat of criminal sanctions and prison time), this shift in the influence industry poses a broader question. Are the days of the glad-handing lobbyist, carrying an envelope of PAC checks and the proposed wording of a client\xe2\x80\x99s legislative amendment, numbered?'b'Carter Eskew, a founding partner of 'b'the Glover Park Group'b', which lobbies and provides a host of other services to clients, raised this question in a conversation with me.'b'Looking to future sources of new revenue, Eskew has concluded that \xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98relationship lobbying\xe2\x80\x99 is dead, or at least not where the growth will be.\xe2\x80\x9d The traditional lobbyist, he argues, is no longer the \xc3\xa9minence grise of days past but instead has been reduced to serving as a conduit for campaign contributions from corporate and trade association PACs to candidates.'b'The action has shifted to what is known in the business as strategic advice: how to convince and mobilize voters and opinion elites in support of a client\xe2\x80\x99s agenda. According to Eskew, \xe2\x80\x9cMany years ago, members of Congress figured out what they really needed to worry about were their own constituent groups and their own voters.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So what does this new strategic adviser actually do? He or she can plan out a legislative campaign or a drive to affect the implementation of regulation, determine which officials and agencies must be dealt with, and propose potential coalition partners.'b'Interestingly, all this can be done without making direct contact with elected officials, congressional aides or top-ranked department and agency appointees and employees. This arms-length approach permits strategic advisers to avoid lobbying registration and reporting requirements.'b'Ed Gillespie, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee and a key adviser to George W. Bush, is the embodiment of the measured camouflage of top strategic operatives.'b'From 2000 to 2007, in partnership with Jack Quinn \xe2\x80\x94 a former chief of staff to Vice President Al Gore \xe2\x80\x94 Gillespie ran one of the most successful lobbying firms in Washington, Quinn-Gillespie. During that period, the firm\xe2\x80\x99s revenues 'b'more than doubled'b', from $7.6 million to $18 million.'b'Gillespie left the firm in 2007, initially to become 'b'counselor to President Bush'b'.  From that moment on, Gillespie disappeared from the ranks of registered lobbyists. In 2009 he formed 'b'Ed Gillespie Strategies'b'. The firm proudly declares:'b'None of these activities requires registration as a lobbyist or disclosure of fees.'b'In a 'b'question-and-answer session'b' on Oct. 30 with students at the University of Chicago, Gillespie said about his firm: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat we do mostly is just public relations and strategic communications advice and guidance for a lot of different clients, trade associations and corporate America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gillespie is by no means alone in his role as a strategic adviser not registered as a lobbyist. He and his colleagues are raking in large fees for performing similar services. Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, was paid 'b'$25,000 a month'b' for consulting and related services by Freddie Mac; Tom Daschle, the former Senate Democratic majority leader, is 'b'a senior policy adviser'b' at 'b'DLA Piper'b', \xe2\x80\x9cone of the largest business law firms in the world\xe2\x80\x9d; and Anita Dunn, former communications director in the Obama White House, is now 'b'a managing director'b' at 'b'SKDKnickerbocker'b', where she helps \xe2\x80\x9cNGOs, trade associations, Fortune 500 companies, and non-profit organizations to craft effective communications strategies.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Many formerly registered lobbyists have decided to deregister in order to avoid falling under the new reporting requirements in 2007\xe2\x80\x99s Honest Leadership Act.'b'Both academics and policy experts say that 'b'these reforms'b', adopted in the wake of 'b'the Jack Abramoff scandal'b', drove much of the work of manipulating legislative and regulatory processes underground.'b''b'A study by Dan Auble'b', a senior researcher at the Center for Responsive Politics, \xe2\x80\x9cLobbyists 2012: Out of the Game or Under the Radar?\xe2\x80\x9d contends that lobbyists are purposely changing their modus operandi:'b'Auble (see Figures 'b'1'b' and 'b'2'b') charts the decline in the number of Washington lobbyists from a 2007 high of 14,837 to 12,433 in 2012, and a drop in their disclosed compensation from a 2010 high of $3.55 billion to $3.31 billion in 2012.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt remains a challenging environment,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Lawrence F. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien III'b', a registered Democratic lobbyist, told me in a phone call. \xe2\x80\x9cFirst, courtesy of the great recession, and now there is a perception of dysfunction, nonproduction, that there\xe2\x80\x99s not a hell of a lot of action on the Hill that translates into truly serious legislation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not all. At the end of 2010, House Republicans, under pressure from the Tea Party, 'b'adopted rules prohibiting earmarks'b' \xe2\x80\x94 special provisions for individual members creating such local projects as roads, bridges, dams and federal buildings. Earmarks had been the bread and butter of firms that specialized in winning federal project grants for their clients.'b'For example, the lobbying firm Cassidy and Associates has paid 'b'a heavy price'b' for the earmark ban (see 'b'Figure 3'b'). Fees paid to Cassidy fell from $22.3 million in 2009 to $15.5 million in 2012.'b'Negative trends in reported fees mask some less visible but highly lucrative developments.'b'The legislative battles preceding the 2010 enactment of the Dodd-Frank finance industry reforms and the Affordable Care Act were the last two major moneymakers for publicly registered lobbyists.'b'Since then, however, there has been a 'b'huge amount'b' of 'b'unreported spending'b' on Washington lawyers, sometimes referred to as \xe2\x80\x9cshadow lobbyists,\xe2\x80\x9d who do not need to register or disclose fees, but who are attempting to influence the writing of regulations governing Dodd-Frank by such agencies as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.'b'In a 'b'November report'b' for the Sunlight Foundation, 'b'Tim LaPira'b', a political scientist at James Madison University, estimated that for every registered lobbyist there is at least one \xe2\x80\x9cshadow lobbyist\xe2\x80\x9d who is \xe2\x80\x9cgetting paid to influence public policy\xe2\x80\x9d without making any public disclosure of fees or clients. LaPira found a ratio of 52.3 to 47.7 of shadow lobbyists to registered lobbyists.'b'LaPira makes the working assumption that the shadow lobbyist collects the same amount in fees as the publicly registered lobbyist \xe2\x80\x93 an annual average of $270,000 per person. Using LaPira\xe2\x80\x99s reasoning, 'b'total spending'b' to influence legislative and regulatory outcomes in 2012 doubled from $3.1 billion to $6.7 billion.'b'Falling entirely outside the scope of regulation is what\xe2\x80\x99s known as 'b'grass-roots/AstroTurf'b' lobbying: mobilizing stockholders, suppliers, trade association members and members of any sympathetic constituency to write letters, call their Congressmen and send emails. This tactic has been around for decades, but every year it become more technically sophisticated.'b'For example, last March, Kate Ackley of Roll Call 'b'reported'b' that 'b'the DCI Group'b'  \xe2\x80\x94 which \xe2\x80\x9chelps corporations navigate their most challenging political, legislative and regulatory problems anywhere in the world\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 scheduled \xe2\x80\x9chundreds of Hill meetings and generated more than 31,500 constituent calls to congressional offices\xe2\x80\x9d on behalf of the Retail Industry Leaders Association, along with orchestrating \xe2\x80\x9c1,606 individualized contacts in target [Capitol Hill] offices from small business owners,\xe2\x80\x9d according to a \xe2\x80\x9ccase study\xe2\x80\x9d DCI used to persuade prospective clients hire the firm.'b'The DCI campaign helped win passage of legislation restricting the fees credit card companies could charge merchants.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe didn\xe2\x80\x99t come anywhere near the threshold for lobbying,\xe2\x80\x9d DCI Group spokesman Craig Stevens told Roll Call. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are very diligent to honor the letter and spirit of all the rules and regulations that Congress has set forth.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ed Rogers, who worked on the presidential campaigns of Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush, is currently a registered lobbyist and chairman of 'b'the BGR Group'b' (formerly Barbour Griffith &amp; Rogers). Now \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s essential to manage the Google hole, what\xe2\x80\x99s Google got about you, you have to inject content, enhance the good and dilute the bad.\xe2\x80\x9d The same assertive approach, Rogers argues, applies to YouTube videos and Wikipedia entries.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever let a negative go unanswered, if there is something bad on the web, you need to match it with something good. It\xe2\x80\x99s up to us to make it happen.'b'FOR years now, we\xe2\x80\x99ve heard the gripes by and about millennials, the offspring of the Great Recession, caught between childhood and adulthood. Their plight seems so very 21st century: the unstable careers, the confusion of technologies, the delayed romance, parenthood and maturity.'b'Many of the same concerns and challenges faced the children of the industrial revolution, as the booms and busts of America\xe2\x80\x99s wild 19th century tore apart the accepted order.'b'Each New Year\xe2\x80\x99s, young men and women filled their diaries with worries that seem very familiar today: They found living with their parents \xe2\x80\x9chumiliating indeed\xe2\x80\x9d and felt \xe2\x80\x9cqualified for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d Others moaned: \xe2\x80\x9cI am twenty-five and not in love yet.\xe2\x80\x9d Gathering over beer or cigars, they complained about how far they were from marriage, how often they switched jobs.'b'The idea that millennials are uniquely \xe2\x80\x9cstuck\xe2\x80\x9d is nonsense. Young Victorians grasped for maturity as well, embarrassed by the distance between their lives and society\xe2\x80\x99s expectations.'b'These Americans were born into an earthquake. During the 1800s America\xe2\x80\x99s population exploded from 5 million to 75 million. By 1900 nearly as many people lived in New York City as had lived in the entire country during the Revolution. The nation went from a rural backwater to an industrial behemoth \xe2\x80\x94 producing more than Britain, Germany and France combined \xe2\x80\x94 but every decade the economy crashed. America saw the kind of wild change we see today in China, and in a new society with little to stabilize it.'b'For rootless 20-somethings, each national shock felt intimate, rattling their love lives and careers. Many young adults could not accept that their personal struggles were just ripples of a large-scale social dislocation. So each New Year\xe2\x80\x99s, they blamed themselves. In a Jan. 1, 1859, entry in her journal, 19-year-old Mollie Dorsey, stuck on a Nebraska homestead in the middle of a recession, castigated herself for not being \xe2\x80\x9cany better than I was one year ago.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Romance worried them above all. Today some fret about the changing institution of marriage, but we are used to such adjustments; 19th-century Americans were blindsided when the average age of marriage rose precipitously, to 26 \xe2\x80\x94 a level America didn\xe2\x80\x99t return to until 1990. In a world where life expectancy hovered below age 50, delaying marriage until 26 was revolutionary.'b'Cities brimmed with bachelors and unmarried ladies in their mid-20s, once a rare sight. In their New Year\xe2\x80\x99s reflections, men and women noted that their parents had had children by their age. One typical Union Army soldier wrote home wondering, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I will be married before I am thirty?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This social change brought personal turmoil, especially for young women. Marriage meant love and family, but in a society that discouraged ladies from working, young women were dependent on their husbands. Remaining single meant economic and legal instability, and the perception of childishness. When the mother of one diarist, Emily Gillespie, scolded the Midwestern farm girl by saying, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are twenty years old and not married yet,\xe2\x80\x9d it hardly mattered that Emily was in line with her generation.'b'While some looked for love, others looked for jobs. Before the modern era, young people found work within family networks, laboring at home or on a farm, pausing for \xe2\x80\x9celevenses\xe2\x80\x9d (a late-morning whiskey break) or an afternoon nap. The industrial economy changed that.'b'The good news was that there were more jobs; the bad news was that they were isolating and temporary. Work now meant small factories or lumber camps or railroad crews of strangers. They were monitored like machines, with pressure to increase productivity replacing the slower pace of preindustrial labor.'b'For young people this meant chronic instability. A young man might brag about his new job one week and find himself begging for money from his father the next. Frustrated youths worried that their jobs did not reflect their age or ability: One brilliant young speaker complained about working in a cramped Philadelphia boot factory, nailing soles when he should have been climbing a soapbox.'b'While 19th-century young adults faced many of the anxieties that trouble 23-year-olds today, they found novel solutions. The first was to move. Young men and women were notoriously transient, heading out on \xe2\x80\x9cwander years\xe2\x80\x9d when life at home seemed stalled. In one Wisconsin county, 90 percent of those present in 1870 were gone by 1880. Most set out with no plan, few connections and a small carpetbag of personal possessions.'b'Another solution was to find like-minded young adults, to share, as one later put it in his memoir, their \xe2\x80\x9cbaffling discouragements and buoyant hopes.\xe2\x80\x9d Nineteenth-century young people were compulsive joiners. Political movements, literary societies, religious organizations, dancing clubs and even gangs proliferated. The men and women who joined cared about the stated cause, but also craved the community these groups created. They realized that while instability was inevitable, isolation was voluntary.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s young adults are constantly rebuked for not following the life cycle popular in 1960. But a quick look at earlier eras shows just how unusual mid-20th-century young people were. A society in which people married out of high school and held the same job for 50 years is the historical outlier. Some of that era\xe2\x80\x99s achievements were enviable, but they were not the norm.'b'The anxieties that 19th-century young people poured into their New Year\xe2\x80\x99s diary entries are more common. Americans considered young adulthood the most dangerous part of life, and struggled to find a path to maturity. Those who did best tended to accept change, not to berate themselves for breaking with tradition. Young adults might do the same today. Stop worrying about how they appear from the skewed perspective of the mid-20th century and find a new home, a new stability and a new community in the new year.'b'War, famine, pestilence and death \xe2\x80\x94 the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse \xe2\x80\x94 have been well represented in years ending in \xe2\x80\x9c4,\xe2\x80\x9d but probably not disproportionately so. A look at memorable moments in the last seven of these just might lead to optimism for the one that\xe2\x80\x99s upon us. Or not.'b''b'1944'b' Those of us who don\xe2\x80\x99t remember this year are lucky; a soldier cited in Rick Atkinson\xe2\x80\x99s brilliantly horrifying saga of the last two years of the war in Europe, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Guns at Last Light,\xe2\x80\x9d quotes King Lear: \xe2\x80\x9cThe worst is not, So long as we can say, \xe2\x80\x98This is the worst.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The end of the war was in sight; getting there was the trick, and millions were killed in the interval. Things have not been this bad since.'b''b'1954'b' If there was a golden era of United States foreign policy, it ended here, as Eisenhower warned against involvement in Vietnam while 'b'espousing the domino theory'b'. Good: Joe McCarthy\xe2\x80\x99s power began to ebb. Not good: The words \xe2\x80\x9cunder God\xe2\x80\x9d were added to the Pledge of Allegiance.'b''b'1964'b' The last year of the baby boom was mind-blowing. In the 28 months beginning that January, Bob Dylan made five of the best albums of the era \xe2\x80\x94 and there were the Beatles.'b'Nelson Mandela was sentenced to life in prison, and Lyndon Johnson single-handedly sent everyone into a tizzy by signing the Civil Rights Act, sending more \xe2\x80\x9cadvisers\xe2\x80\x9d to Vietnam, talking about bombing North Vietnam and 'b'proposing the Great Society'b'. Huh? The first anti-Vietnam War demonstrations and draft-card burnings took place. Pot smoking officially began. (Not really, but sorta.)'b'The civil-rights workers Schwerner, Goodman and Chaney 'b'were found dead'b'; just writing that gives me chills.'b''b'1974'b' The mid-70s were glum. We can gloat about Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s resignation, though don\xe2\x80\x99t forget he founded the Environmental Protection Agency. Gerald Ford gave his predecessor a better deal than he gave draft evaders. He also determined that we needed to 'b'Whip Inflation Now'b', as oil 'b'passed $10 a barrel'b'. Everyone made jokes about him, with reason.'b'Patty Hearst was kidnapped. Ted Bundy disappeared many people. Augusto Pinochet declared himself \xe2\x80\x9csupreme chief\xe2\x80\x9d of Chile and disappeared many more.'b'The high point may have been 'b'the Ramones\xe2\x80\x99 debut at CBGB'b'.\xc2\xa0'b''b'1984'b' Big Brother was not (yet) our biggest problem, but this was not a good year. President Reagan, presumably not yet stricken by Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s, remarked over an open mike that the bombing of Russia would begin \xe2\x80\x9cin five minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d Geraldine Ferraro became a vice-presidential candidate, and lost. Margaret Thatcher 'b'went to war with miners'b', and won. Indira Gandhi was assassinated and a Union Carbide leak in Bhopal 'b'killed untold thousands'b'.'b'The virus that causes AIDS 'b'was discovered'b'. People started smoking crack. And Marvin Gaye was shot and killed by his father.'b''b'1994'b' Whoa: Not only did Nelson Mandela not spend his life in jail, but he became president. The Brady Law 'b'went into effect'b', and Bill Clinton signed the assault weapons ban. (It expired in 2004.) O. J. Simpson 'b'spurred a national obsession'b'. Four bombers were convicted of the 1993 attack on the World Trade Center.'b'Reagan 'b'was implicated'b' in the Iran-contra cover-up, but it seemed more important to torture the Clintons over a 'b'bad real estate investment'b'. (Still, Paula Jones wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 fault, was she?) Clinton fired Joycelyn Elders for discussing masturbation.'b'The 'b'first credit default swap'b' was created. Nearly 'b'everyone in Rwanda'b' became either a killer or a victim, or so it seemed. And there was that messy thing in \xe2\x80\x9cthe former Yugoslavia.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Netscape Navigator was released.'b''b'2004'b' 'b'Barack Obama spoke'b' at the Democratic convention and there seemed reason for hope; then John Kerry 'b'went windsurfing'b' and W., incredibly, became president again (what were 62 million of us thinking?) several months after 'b'endorsing a constitutional amendment'b' banning same-sex marriage, which Massachusetts had 'b'already legalized'b'. (By 2013, 'b'even Utah'b' is on the right side of this issue.) W. also promised to improve education and access to health care; we all know how that worked out. Lance Armstrong won his sixth Tour de France; we all know how that worked out, too.'b'The Indian Ocean tsunami killed more than 230,000 people. Martha Stewart 'b'went to jail'b'. And Johnny Ramone (born 1948) 'b'died'b'.'b''b'2014'b' President Obama is calling this the \xe2\x80\x9cyear of action.\xe2\x80\x9d Here\xe2\x80\x99s hoping he\xe2\x80\x99s not bluffing and begins by demonstrating how popular progressive legislation is by circumventing Congress in areas of food, energy and climate change. The alternative could be a visit by the Four Horsemen.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94 A year ends, another begins, time for reminiscences and resolutions, regret and hope, best-of and worst-of lists, confessions and crystal-ball gazing \xe2\x80\x94 most of it pretty excruciating. It will take a nanosecond longer to scroll back to one\xe2\x80\x99s year of birth. So it goes.'b'I am not going to gripe about brilliant Twitter. I have nothing new to say about Miley Cyrus. But I am going to make one prediction for 2014. It is that, for all John Kerry\xe2\x80\x99s efforts, this will be another year in which peace is not reached in the Middle East. (And if I am wrong, I vow Sisyphean penance in eternity.)'b'Plenty of bad things have happened between Israelis and Palestinians of late. There has been a steady uptick in violence. Israel\xe2\x80\x99s freeing of 26 long-serving Palestinian prisoners was naturally greeted with joy in Ramallah, and by a wave of Israeli government tweets condemning the celebration of terrorists. Along with the release came word that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu\xe2\x80\x99s government will likely announce plans for 1,400 new housing units in the West Bank, just as Kerry arrives for his 10th peace-seeking visit. This has infuriated Palestinians. So, too, has an Israeli ministerial committee vote advancing legislation to annex settlements in the Jordan Valley. Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator, said the vote \xe2\x80\x9cfinishes all that is called the peace process.\xe2\x80\x9d Such contemptuous characterization of a negotiation from a leading protagonist is ill-advised and bodes ill.'b'Then there is the rebounding Israel-is-a-Jewish-state bugbear: Netanyahu wants Palestinians to recognize his nation as such. He has recently called it \xe2\x80\x9cthe real key to peace.\xe2\x80\x9d His argument is that this is the touchstone by which to judge whether Palestinians will accept \xe2\x80\x9cthe Jewish state in any border\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 whether, in other words, the Palestinian leadership would accept territorial compromise or is still set on reversal of 1948 and mass return to Haifa.'b'Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, says no; this \xe2\x80\x9cnyet\xe2\x80\x9d will endure. For Palestinians, such a form of recognition would amount to explicit acquiescence to second-class citizenship for the 1.6 million Arabs in Israel; undermine the rights of millions of Palestinian refugees; upend a national narrative of mass expulsion from land that was theirs; and demand of them something not demanded from Egypt or Jordan in peace agreements, nor of the Palestine Liberation Organization when, in 1993, Yasir Arafat wrote to Yitzhak Rabin that it recognizes the right of Israel \xe2\x80\x9cto exist\xc2\xa0in peace and security.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This issue is a waste of time, a complicating diversion when none is needed. As Shlomo Avineri, a leading Israeli political scientist, put it to me, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a tactical issue raised by Netanyahu in order to make negotiations more difficult.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Of course, any two-state peace agreement will have to be final and irreversible; it must ensure there are no further Palestinian claims on a secure Israel. It may well require some form of words saying the two states are the homelands of their respective peoples, a formula used by the Geneva Initiative. But that is for another day.'b'If Israel looks like a Jewish state and acts like a Jewish state, that is good enough for me \xe2\x80\x94 as long as it gets out of the corrosive business of occupation. Zionism, the one I identify with, forged a Jewish homeland in the name of restored Jewish pride in a democratic state of laws, not in the name of finicky insistence on a certain form of recognition, nor in the name of messianic religious Greater Israel nationalism.'b'When I spoke to him in Tel Aviv a few months ago, Yair Lapid, a top government minister, said: \xe2\x80\x9cThe fact that we demand from Palestinians a declaration that they recognize Israel as a Jewish state, I just think this is rubbish. I don\xe2\x80\x99t need that. The whole point of Israel was we came here saying we don\xe2\x80\x99t need anyone else to recognize us anymore because we can recognize ourselves. We are liberated.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s right. It\xe2\x80\x99s also true that Palestinian leaders, with zero democratic accountability, and through facile incitement, are not preparing their people for territorial compromise at or close to the 1967 lines. Then again, nothing in Israel\xe2\x80\x99s actions facilitates that. And on we go to more failure, more victories of narrative over normalcy.'b'A last word: This column is dedicated to Mike O\xe2\x80\x99Connor, fearless journalist, great Bosnia hand for The New York Times, vivid chronicler of the Israel-Palestine conflict over several years for NPR, and most recently representative of the Committee to Protect Journalists in Mexico, where saving press freedom is a daily struggle. Mike was an acute observer of the kind of human folly, fatuousness and self-interest that perpetuate the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It brought him to tears. Yet he always found a way to laugh. 'b'Mike died suddenly'b'\xc2\xa0on Sunday, age 67, in Mexico City. If nothing else, I hope Kerry and the rest prove me wrong for him.'b'Sometimes the New Year comes in feeling merely newish, a matter of changing months and not much else. But sometimes the New Year brings with it a powerful sense of regeneration, as if, like certain insects, you were entering a new stage of complete metamorphosis.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to know which kind of New Year is coming until it comes. Changing digits \xe2\x80\x94 from 2013 to 2014 \xe2\x80\x94 may be all the change you feel you need. Yet there are only so many New Years in any one life, and it never hurts to be ready for the eventful year, which, as Thoreau once wrote, will drown out all our muskrats. (Or, as the muskrats might say, the year which will drown out all our Thoreaus.)'b'There are no hymns to the New Year, and the only music most of us associate with this holiday is that dirge of the departing year, \xe2\x80\x9cAuld Lang Syne.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is no traditional ceremony either \xe2\x80\x94 everyone seems to celebrate the day in a different manner. And perhaps this is a holiday that defies both tradition and ceremony. Does it make sense, after all, to welcome the New Year in the Same Old Way? There is not much ritual in turning to a new page in the calendar. All the ritual lies within us, in the aspiration to live up to our highest hopes.'b'The dead of winter is not a natural season for rebirth. Yet all of nature, dormant now under the cover of cold and snow, is preparing for a re-emergence that always seems spectacular when it eventually comes. Meanwhile, we persist, as much like ourselves on Jan. 1 as we were on Dec. 31. The newness we hope for is something that is ours to construct day by day.'b'By all accounts, the standout entry in Wednesday\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Tournament of Roses Parade'b' in Pasadena, Calif., will surely be 'b'the marriage of two men'b', Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots, beaming amid the array of lavishly flowered floats to be viewed on national television and beyond.'b'This is a first \xe2\x80\x94 a newly married same-sex couple highlighting the grand parade. They\xe2\x80\x99ll do so like punctuation marks on the surprisingly rapid rise of same-sex marriage in America. In little more than a year, the number of states allowing same-sex marriage has tripled to 18, following a Federal District Court ruling in Utah.'b'Opponents of the single-gender nuptial display in the hallowed parade have dished heavy umbrage in petitions and blogs, calling it \xe2\x80\x9cunbiblical\xe2\x80\x9d and urging a boycott by onlookers. But the tournament executives have said they are pleased that love will triumph on a day when the tournament theme is \xe2\x80\x9cDreams Come True.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The vows are scheduled to take place aboard a float sponsored by the AIDS Healthcare Foundation to celebrate victories in the old year \xe2\x80\x94 that is, 2013 \xe2\x80\x94 including the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s upholding the repeal of California\xe2\x80\x99s Proposition 8 and striking down a basic part of the Defense of Marriage Act.'b'In 1890, as California was evolving as the cutting-edge state of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s future, little could local promoters foresee what the future might bring as they invented the Tournament of Roses to lure winter-hardened tourists to Pasadena\xe2\x80\x99s balmy climate. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s hold a festival to tell the world about our paradise,\xe2\x80\x9d they avowed. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t long before a football game was added to the fun.'b'And now, Danny and Aubrey saying I do. The new couple\xe2\x80\x99s float is titled, \xe2\x80\x9cLiving the Dream: Love Is the Best Protection.\xe2\x80\x9d It is hard to disagree as the new year parades forward.'b'The corporation that controls Sprint, the third-biggest cellphone company in the country after Verizon and AT&amp;T, is 'b'reportedly'b' planning to make an offer to buy the smaller rival T-Mobile in a move that would reduce competition in an important industry that already has too little of it.'b'Most Americans have a choice of just four national cellphone companies \xe2\x80\x94 Verizon, AT&amp;T, Sprint and T-Mobile \xe2\x80\x94 compared with six in 2003. The Federal Communications Commission recently described the industry as \xe2\x80\x9chighly concentrated\xe2\x80\x9d based on an index used by regulators to measure how competitive a market is. In 2011, the Department of Justice used a similar analysis to 'b'effectively block'b' AT&amp;T from acquiring T-Mobile.'b'Sprint, recently bought by the Japanese company SoftBank, appears to believe that regulators might look favorably on a proposal to purchase T-Mobile because the combined company would 'b'still be smaller'b' than AT&amp;T and Verizon in revenue and customers. Sprint would probably argue that the combined company would become a more effective competitor to the two larger companies.'b'Because T-Mobile uses a different wireless technology than Sprint, SoftBank could face significant technological hurdles in trying to integrate the two. But that\xe2\x80\x99s a separate issue; the main issue is whether consumers would benefit from the acquisition, and the evidence suggests they would not.'b'As an independent company, for instance, T-Mobile has recently cut prices aggressively and simplified its cellphone plans. Its phone plans are often much 'b'cheaper than'b' comparable packages offered by other cellphone companies. It no longer forces customers into 'b'two-year contracts'b'; its subscribers can switch to another wireless firm whenever they like. And it 'b'slashed the high international roaming charges'b' it levies on calls customers make when they are traveling abroad and eliminated roaming charges for text messages and Internet service.'b'As you would expect in a competitive environment, other companies like AT&amp;T 'b'have been forced'b' to respond to T-Mobile\xe2\x80\x99s price cuts and policy changes with similar moves. It is hard to imagine that any cellphone company would have been as aggressive as T-Mobile if the administration had allowed AT&amp;T to buy the company. The logic that the government used to step in still holds today, and antitrust regulators should look closely at any proposal that would reduce competition in the wireless business.'b'President Obama has done the predictable thing by 'b'sending more weapons to Iraq to counter an alarming rise in violence'b'. But arms alone will not solve a problem that has its roots in the political alienation of Sunnis and other minorities and the undermining of democratic processes, especially by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.'b'The bloodshed has reached catastrophic proportions. More than 8,000 Iraqis died in 2013, including 952 members of the Iraqi security forces. Over all, it is the highest death toll since 2008 and shatters a trend that in 2012 prompted a top administration official to assert that \xe2\x80\x9cIraq today is less violent\xe2\x80\x9d than \xe2\x80\x9cat any time in recent history.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The deadly surge is attributed to Al Qaeda\xe2\x80\x99s regional affiliate, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a Sunni group that is a potent force in northern and western Iraq. Its predecessor, Al Qaeda in Iraq, waged the insurgency that brought the country near civil war in 2006 and 2007 before suffering big defeats from Iraqi Sunni tribal groups and American forces. Since the United States withdrew at the end of 2011, the group has gained strength against Iraqi security forces that are incapable of fully protecting civilians, and it has taken in foreign fighters from neighboring Syria and the region. American officials say that Islamic State is deliberately trying to tear the country apart.'b'Mr. Maliki sought help from Mr. Obama at the White House in November, a turnabout after he failed to reach a deal to keep a small number of American troops in the country after 2011 for training and intelligence gathering.'b'Some 75 Hellfire air-to-ground missiles, to be fired at militant camps with the C.I.A. providing targeting assistance, were delivered to Iraq last week and 10 reconnaissance drones are expected to follow in March. The Obama administration also plans to provide 48 other reconnaissance drones and the first of an order of F-16 fighter jets. It is pushing a reluctant Congress to lease and eventually sell Apache helicopter gunships to Iraq.'b'The United States has a strategic interest in Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s stability, which is undoubtedly at risk, making increased counterterrorism cooperation and intelligence-sharing essential. But even the most lethal weapons will not have much positive effect if Mr. Maliki and other Iraqi leaders bicker rather than unite the country around shared goals through credible democratic processes. Mr. Maliki has been central to the disorder, wielding power in favor of his Shiite majority brethren at the expense of the minority Sunnis, stoking sectarian conflict and enabling a climate in which militants could gain traction.'b'American officials say Mr. Maliki and other Iraqi officials finally understand the dangers of the growing extremism and the fact that a security-only approach will not bring stability. They say that Iraqi security forces have lately been more successful against the militants and that Mr. Maliki and his government have shown more willingness to work cooperatively with Sunnis, resolve oil disputes with the Kurds and put in place a new agreement aimed at promoting civil and social peace. Given his authoritarian duplicity, it is hard to be optimistic. On Tuesday, more than 40 Sunni lawmakers submitted their resignations from Parliament and Sunni ministers threatened to withdraw from the Cabinet after Mr. Maliki\xe2\x80\x99s security forces dismantled a camp used by Sunnis protesting second-class treatment by the Shiite-led government.'b'As it doles out weapons, intelligence and advice, the Obama administration needs to press Mr. Maliki and other Iraqi leaders to do those things, to ensure that the election in April is free and fair and to commit finally to adopting laws that will address Sunni grievances. It also needs to be prepared to halt or withhold deliveries of weapons if they are misused or if Mr. Maliki continues to put his own interests over his country\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94  It may seem bizarre that two far-right, nationalist politicians \xe2\x80\x94 Marine Le Pen of France and Geert Wilders of the Netherlands \xe2\x80\x94 have reached across borders to form a Pan-European group dedicated to weakening the European Union. Their aim is a transnational political alliance that would compete in the May elections for the European Parliament; once in power, they would cooperate to try to rein in the power of Brussels.'b'Are these politicians, who share an opposition to immigration and a skepticism about the free flow of labor and capital across the Continent, simply hypocritical opportunists, as many Europeans of the left believe? Perhaps.'b'But in fact, since the early 20th century, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s far-right nationalists have often united in search of an \xe2\x80\x9cother\xe2\x80\x9d to oppose, exclude, resist, restrict or oppress \xe2\x80\x94 historically, minorities like Jews, homosexuals, the disabled, Roma, Marxists and, more recently, Arabs, Africans and Asians. What emerged after World War I was a philosophy that could be called Euro-fascist. The most extreme proponents, of course, were the Nazis: Notwithstanding their doctrine of racial supremacy, even they formed alliances with Mussolini\xe2\x80\x99s Italy and the militarists of Japan and found keen fascist collaborators in nations they invaded.'b'This vision did not die with the end of World War II. Transnational links among right-wing parties, based on common fears of minorities and immigrants, endured. The right-wingers, while speaking different languages, borrowed ideals, strategies, slogans and theorists from one another. The National Front in France, founded in 1972 by Ms. Le Pen\xe2\x80\x99s father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, imitated the symbol and political tactics of the original neo-Fascist party, the Italian Social Movement, which was formed in 1946 by admirers of Mussolini and, in 1979, coordinated with like-minded French and Spanish parties to compete (with little success) in the first popular elections for the European Parliament.'b'So when observers marvel about the \xe2\x80\x9cnew\xe2\x80\x9d nationalist parties of Europe, they are capturing only part of the truth. These right-wingers mistrust or even detest the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s core institutions \xe2\x80\x94 the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the European Parliament \xe2\x80\x94 but they are perfectly happy to join up with extremists in other countries to weaken those institutions.'b'Which raises a question: What makes the European Union so appealing as a target?'b'The answer may (and should) shock complacent left-leaning and center-right Europeans alike. \xe2\x80\x9cEurope,\xe2\x80\x9d as an idea and a community, has weakened. The European Union\xe2\x80\x99s byzantine governance makes it seem unaccountable. Its leaders \xe2\x80\x94 notably Jos\xc3\xa9 Manuel Barroso of Portugal, the president of the European Commission, the union\xe2\x80\x99s executive body; Herman van Rompuy of Belgium, the president of the European Council, which comprises the 28 heads of government; and Catherine Ashton, the union\xe2\x80\x99s top diplomat \xe2\x80\x94 are little known outside of elite circles.'b'Soaring youth unemployment, stringent fiscal policies, German-led monetary clout and the presence of Muslim immigrants have created a perfect target for the likes of Mr. Wilders and Ms. Le Pen, who blame outside forces like the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank and the European Union for their nations\xe2\x80\x99 woes. Conveniently, they overlook structural problems like the costs of social welfare and pension programs, declining birthrates, aging populations, stagnant labor productivity and intensifying competition from the economies of Asia and Latin America.'b'Surveys show that the anti-European Union forces may win more than 90 of the 751 seats to be contested in the May elections for the European Parliament. That might be enough to form an official parliamentary group \xe2\x80\x94 and to make them eligible, like the transnational alliances of socialists and center-right Christian democrats, for European Union financing and full political recognition. Even as a tiny, noisy voice within the European Parliament, this alliance could create a lot of trouble. Just think of the successes that Tea Party Republicans have had in impeding decision making in the United States.'b'The perception that bureaucrats in Brussels, bankers in Frankfurt and European lawmakers in Strasbourg, France, are haughty and indifferent has made it possible for demagogues to pose as populists who are alone in understanding \xe2\x80\x9cthe people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For example, in November, Lorenzo Fontana, an Italian member of the European Parliament from the right-wing Northern League, boasted \xe2\x80\x94 ahead of a gathering with leaders of the National Front and similarly oriented Swedish, Austrian and Flemish parties \xe2\x80\x94 that they spoke in the name of a \xe2\x80\x9cshared ideal of Europe, a Europe of people.\xe2\x80\x9d The League\xe2\x80\x99s newspaper, La Padania, on Nov. 14, put it this way: \xe2\x80\x9cIt will be up to the voters, but this time the troops, willing but disorganized, have the opportunity to unite in a single \xe2\x80\x98army\xe2\x80\x99 behind an able leader.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'How would these right-wingers reshape Europe? They say they would give power back to nations by dismantling the technocratic decision-making power amassed in Brussels and returning powers back to individual member states. They would pause, if not quite reverse, six decades of growing integration.'b'Tragically, in the face of this assault, calls for European solidarity are few. This is a sign of how far Europe has come from the dream that helped lift it from the ashes of war. It is a sign of the fading of the vision \xe2\x80\x94 common markets, democratic institutions and societal integration \xe2\x80\x94 promoted by the postwar founders of European integration: thinkers and statesmen like Konrad Adenauer, Winston Churchill, Jean Monnet, Robert Schuman and Altiero Spinelli.'b'The European Union must reclaim its reputation as a champion of the people. Its leaders should abandon their embrace of technocratic solutions, their support for the banking sector and their stoic austerity. Unless they deliver more jobs, and more of a sense that citizens are in charge, the far right will only keep growing.'b''b'\n'b'Andrea Mammone 'b' is a lecturer in modern European history at Royal Holloway, the University of London. 'b''b'A new organization called the Common Man Party shook India\xe2\x80\x99s political system in December when it took control of the government in the territory of Delhi, which includes the capital of New Delhi. Its rapid rise since its founding in 2012 suggests that many Indian voters are tiring of establishment politicians, especially members of the Indian National Congress Party, which has governed the country and Delhi longer than any other party but has lost favor in recent years because it has mismanaged the economy.'b'Common Man \xe2\x80\x94 its official Hindi name is Aam Aadmi Party \xe2\x80\x94 is led by Arvind Kejriwal, a former tax commissioner who helped lead a popular movement in 2011 that campaigned for the creation of a powerful federal anti-corruption agency. If it is able to maintain that momentum in next year\xe2\x80\x99s national election, Common Man could soon play an important role in Parliament as well.'b'Common Man must now show that it can govern. The party will also struggle to fulfill big promises like cutting electricity prices in half and providing free, clean drinking water to every Delhi household. But that it has come this far in such short order suggests a readiness among many Indians for change \xe2\x80\x94 and a willingness to use the democratic system to get it.'b'BEIRUT, Lebanon \xe2\x80\x94  The public health disaster in Syria has been a long time coming. In three years of violent conflict, 125,000 have been killed and millions displaced. The recent outbreak of polio has focused the world\xe2\x80\x99s attention, and the international response is welcome. Yet this crisis was both predictable and preventable.'b'The collapse of the health system and a lack of basic sanitation in opposition-held areas have created prime conditions for outbreaks of vaccine-preventable diseases. Syria eradicated polio 14 years ago; the fact that it has returned represents more than a breakdown of health care during civil war. It is symptomatic of how the international community, in its response to the crisis, has neglected public health.'b'Immunization coverage in what are now mainly opposition areas was already below accepted standards in 2011, but the situation has deteriorated. Data on routine immunization from the World Health Organization reveal that over the past two years a large proportion of the Syrian population has gone without vaccination.'b'Across Syria, coverage went down to 60 percent in 2012, and was as low as 50 percent in the embattled eastern city of Deir al-Zour, a front line between government and rebel forces. The latest W.H.O. figures from 2013 show that the level is now down to 36 percent in largely rebel-held Deir al-Zour Province, although it has remained at 100 percent in government-controlled areas such as the western stronghold of Tartus.'b'Given these conditions, it was no surprise to medical practitioners that a polio outbreak occurred. The question is why the international community did not prepare better for this eventuality. A disturbing part of the answer is that the United Nations itself has aggravated the situation.'b'Like other United Nations agencies, the World Health Organization works directly with the Syrian government. The W.H.O.\xe2\x80\x99s Syria office is in the Ministry of Health building in Damascus; many of its staff members are former ministry employees. A recent Reuters report on how the Assad government uses red tape and threats to prevent the provision of aid in opposition areas has raised doubts about the ability of the W.H.O. to act with impartiality.'b'The W.H.O., working with the Syrian government, excluded Deir al-Zour from a polio vaccination drive that began in December 2012. According to the W.H.O., the province \xe2\x80\x9cwas not included in the campaign as the majority of its residents have relocated to other areas in the country.\xe2\x80\x9d Ten months later, this was the province where polio re-emerged.'b'There is no evidence that most of the province\xe2\x80\x99s one million residents had, in fact, migrated. The United Nations World Food Program continued to distribute food there throughout 2012 and 2013 (with occasional interruptions because of worsening security conditions). In December 2012, the agency reached 69,000 people in Deir al-Zour.'b'Last month, an investigation by the German weekly newsmagazine Der Spiegel charged the W.H.O. with obstructing the testing of polio samples from the Deir al-Zour region. These samples had been presented by an agency working under the aegis of the Syrian National Coalition. It took nearly a month to get the test results \xe2\x80\x94 positive for poliomyelitis \xe2\x80\x94 and then only from an independent provider in Turkey. By that time, thousands of displaced people had moved within Syria or fled as refugees to neighboring countries, most likely spreading the disease.'b'The latest draft of a W.H.O. situation report for Syria reveals that it took three months for the W.H.O. and the Syrian Health Ministry to confirm a polio case detected in Aleppo in July 2013. It was then some weeks before a nationwide vaccination campaign began.'b'The consequences of these delays and failures now reach well beyond Syria\xe2\x80\x99s borders. Lebanon and Jordan, where a large proportion of Syrian refugees have fled, are particularly at risk. Their public health systems are already overloaded and underfunded. Unicef figures for immunization from the Lebanese Health Ministry indicate that only 77 percent of the population had been routinely covered for polio in recent years, placing thousands of Lebanese children at risk. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the Unicef figures are correct, then this would be far too low to keep an introduced infection at bay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Professor Martin Eichner, a disease expert at the University of T\xc3\xbcbingen, Germany. \xe2\x80\x9cWith 4,000 Syrian refugees a day leaving the country, and the majority entering Lebanon, the virus is already in Lebanon or they will get it sometime soon.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is also no discernible plan for delivering vaccination coverage to the hundreds of tented settlements that house as many as 200,000 Syrian refugees across Lebanon.'b'The emergency is not limited to polio. While Syria\xe2\x80\x99s polio outbreak has been making headlines, other communicable diseases like hepatitis A, the parasitic infection leishmaniasis, typhoid and measles have all been rising. Chronic and noncommunicable diseases such as diabetes, hypertension and cancer have also been silently killing Syrians by the tens of thousands. We know from previous crises that up to 80 percent of excess deaths are attributable to wider health conditions during and after a conflict.'b'The situation is extremely challenging, but humanitarian agencies in the region should be independent and transparent. There are very real challenges for United Nations staff members working in Syria, but the World Health Organization must respond to the claims that it refused to test the Deir al-Zour polio samples, explain why it took three months to confirm a suspected case in July 2013 and give a better account of why the area was excluded from its vaccination drive.'b'Anything short of this disclosure risks causing more preventable deaths, not just in Syria but across the entire region.'b''b'\n'b'Adam P. Coutts 'b' is a researcher at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. 'b'Fouad M. Fouad, 'b' a Syrian doctor, is an assistant research professor in the faculty of health sciences at the American University of Beirut.'b''b'HAIFA, Israel \xe2\x80\x94  Progress toward Israeli-Palestinian peace will help thwart Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear weapons ambitions.
