No halfway measures. Quitting is the only way.'b'The cold-turkey approach is deeply rooted in the United States, embraced by doctors, the multibillion-dollar treatment industry and popular culture. For nearly 80 years, our approach to drinking problems has been inspired by the 12 steps of Alcoholics Anonymous.'b'Developed in the 1930s by men who were \xe2\x80\x9cchronic inebriates,\xe2\x80\x9d the A.A. program offers a single path to recovery: abstinence, surrendering one\xe2\x80\x99s ego and accepting one\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cpowerlessness\xe2\x80\x9d over alcohol.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s not the only way to change your drinking habits.'b'Bankole Johnson, an alcohol researcher and consultant to pharmaceutical companies who is also the chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, puts it this way: \xe2\x80\x9cWe are wedded to the abstinence model as the goal, despite evidence that there can be many successful outcomes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Because of the promise of anonymity, A.A. doesn\xe2\x80\x99t track its members or conduct research. Some studies have found that many members find support for healthier habits from a like-minded group of nondrinkers. But a 'b'systematic review'b' found \xe2\x80\x9cno conclusive evidence to show that A.A. can help patients to achieve abstinence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Research shows that many problem drinkers \xe2\x80\x94 those who repeatedly drink more than they intend, sometimes have physical or psychological consequences from overdrinking, and may have difficulty controlling themselves \xe2\x80\x94 could benefit from 'b'brief interventions'b' and practical advice about how to set better limits and change their drinking by cutting back.'b'Women increasingly need help, as their drinking has escalated. Women are being stopped more for 'b'drunken driving'b' than they were two decades ago. They\xe2\x80\x99re also the biggest consumers of wine, buying the larger share of the 856 million gallons sold in the United States in 2012. These women are drinking partly because alcohol is a socially respectable way to slog through the smartphone-tethered universe of managing demanding careers, aging parents, kids\xe2\x80\x99 activities and relationships at once. And while it\xe2\x80\x99s not healthy to pour yourself a third or fourth glass every night, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean you\xe2\x80\x99re powerless to do anything about it.'b'Elsewhere in the developed world, doctors treat drinking problems with evidence-based tools that best match the client\xe2\x80\x99s needs. Many are prescribed drugs such as naltrexone, an opioid antagonist approved by the Food and Drug Administration in 1994 to treat alcohol use disorders. It blocks the signals released when consuming alcohol.'b'American doctors typically prescribe drugs with the goal of abstinence. Yet in Finland, the American psychologist John David Sinclair pioneered a radically different protocol for naltrexone: he instructs patients to take the drug \xe2\x80\x94 which is available generically \xe2\x80\x94 an hour before drinking. Mr. Sinclair calls his method \xe2\x80\x9cpharmacological extinction.\xe2\x80\x9d When people drink while taking naltrexone, the drug blocks the rewards produced by drinking and the cravings diminish. In published research, Mr. Sinclair has claimed a 'b'78 percent success rate'b' in reducing drinking. A drug similar to naltrexone, nalmefene, was recently approved in Europe to help heavy drinkers moderate their habits.'b'In reporting my book on women and drinking, I found that many women were successful in changing their drinking habits by using Moderation Management, a free nonprofit support group for nondependent problem drinkers who want to control their consumption. Using the techniques of cognitive behavioral therapy, M.M. encourages members to take \xe2\x80\x9cpersonal responsibility for choosing and maintaining their own path, whether 'b'moderation'b' or abstinence.\xe2\x80\x9d It instructs drinkers to abstain for 30 days, reintroduce alcohol while evaluating the effects of drinking, and then stick within limits (for women, that\xe2\x80\x99s nine drinks a week, no more than three on any day).'b'This approach isn\xe2\x80\x99t for severely dependent drinkers, for whom abstinence might be best. But it\xe2\x80\x99s been empirically shown to work for those on the more moderate end of the spectrum who outnumber dependent drinkers by about four to one \xe2\x80\x94 including the majority of women who drink too much. While the ratio of men to women in A.A. is roughly 2:1, that figure is reversed among users of an evidence-based Internet application at 'b'moderatedrinking.com'b'. The website helps drinkers set limits, self-monitor while they\xe2\x80\x99re drinking, get feedback on their progress and identify and manage triggers to overdrinking. Reid K. Hester, director of research at Behavior Therapy Associates, which designed the program, says heavy drinkers are more likely to be honest about their consumption when they know they won\xe2\x80\x99t be reproached.'b'Few master these skills overnight, Mr. Hester says, but most learn healthier habits within six months. And mistakes can be lessons, not failures.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t treat cancer, depression or asthma with the same tools we used in 1935. We need to get away from the one-size-fits-all approach to drinking problems.'b'PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 She was a 13-year-old girl who said she was beaten daily by strangers who forced her to work unpaid in their home, and she wanted to escape.'b'Marilaine was one of 200,000 or more Haitian children 'b'called restaveks'b', typically serving as unpaid maids in strangers\xe2\x80\x99 homes, working for room and board. It is a vast system of child trafficking that is often characterized as a modern form of slavery. I followed Marilaine for a week in Haiti as she tried to flee, find her parents and start life over \xe2\x80\x94 and this is her story.'b'Marilaine grew up in a remote village where no family planning or public schooling is available, one of 12 children to impoverished parents who later separated. As Marilaine tells the story, one day when she was 10 years old, she walked to her father\xe2\x80\x99s house to ask him to help pay her school fees. Instead, he dispatched her here to the capital to work as a restavek, a Creole term used to describe child laborers, without even telling her mother.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMy father didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to spend money on my school fees,\xe2\x80\x9d Marilaine explained.'b'As is common for restaveks, Marilaine slept on the floor and woke up at 5 each morning to clean the house, fetch water and wash dishes. She says she was beaten daily with electrical cords.'b'Marilaine was allowed no contact with her family. Once, she says, she tried to run away but was caught and beaten. At school, she often cried, and she had scars on her arms and legs from beatings.'b'Yet the restavek system isn\xe2\x80\x99t always slavery. Sometimes the child gets more food and education than would have been the case in her own family (two-thirds of restaveks are girls). Marilaine says that she was fed properly and that she was also allowed to attend a free afternoon school.'b'Many Haitian restaveks are treated much worse. One 12-year-old restavek I interviewed said that she rises at 4 each morning to get everything ready for \xe2\x80\x9cthe princesses,\xe2\x80\x9d as she calls the teenage girls in the house. Everyone in the house beats her, she says, and they refuse to let her see her mother for fear that she might run away.'b'An aid group called the 'b'Restavek Freedom Foundation'b' helped Marilaine escape her home and find refuge in a safe house for restaveks. The mood was festive in the beautiful home as the dozen girls living there cheered Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s arrival and hugged her.'b'Marilaine picked up a book, telling me that she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t allowed to touch books at her old house. She tried on new clothes. She slept in a bed.'b'But the family that Marilaine had been working for was furious. I visited the woman of the house, and she insisted that she had never beaten the girl and that Marilaine had in effect been kidnapped from her.'b'The leader of the neighborhood association, Junior Pataud, offered a conflicting defense. \xe2\x80\x9cIn Haitian culture, it\xe2\x80\x99s normal to beat a child,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s not the same as mistreatment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The next day, the neighbors gathered angrily outside the school Marilaine had attended, blaming it for the girl\xe2\x80\x99s escape and threatening to set fire to it unless Marilaine was returned. After hours of tense negotiations, the police averted a riot.'b'A few days later, I drove for several hours with the police and the Restavek Freedom Foundation to Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s village. When Marilaine stepped out of the car, family members and neighbors were stunned. They had assumed that she had died years ago.'b'Yet the reunion was a letdown. Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s mom didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem at all thrilled to see her daughter again, and Marilaine quickly made it clear that she wanted to return to the safe house in the capital so that she could attend a good school. The police told Marilaine that she would have to stay in the village with her family, and she burst into tears.'b'The authorities will probably eventually let Marilaine return to the Restavek Freedom Foundation safe house, but the episode was a reminder that helping people is a complex, uphill task \xe2\x80\x94 and that the underlying problem behind human trafficking is poverty.'b'One way to fight such human trafficking would be to provide free and accessible birth control, so that women like Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s mother don\xe2\x80\x99t end up with 12 children that they struggle to feed.'b'Another would be to provide free public education, so that parents don\xe2\x80\x99t feel that the only way to get schooling for their children is to send them off as restaveks.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why what\xe2\x80\x99s at stake in fighting global poverty isn\xe2\x80\x99t just poor people\xe2\x80\x99s incomes. It\xe2\x80\x99s also dignity and freedom \xe2\x80\x94 and the right of a girl to grow up in something better than quasi slavery.'b'My New Year\xe2\x80\x99s wish: May Marilaine in 2014 finally find freedom and an education.'b'Aided by a vast flow of corporate and right-wing money, Republicans have spent years persuading the public that the deficit is the nation\xe2\x80\x99s biggest financial problem and that austerity is the answer to it. Their success in making that argument \xe2\x80\x94 keeping taxes and government investment low \xe2\x80\x94 has helped increase American income inequality to crisis proportions: 95 percent of the income gains since 2009 have gone to the top 1 percent. The majority of the country has stagnated or lost ground, leaving the economy sluggish.'b'Democrats have largely been passive or defensive as all the wage increases flowed upward, but they have vowed to take a more aggressive stand this year. Last week, they announced 'b'a nationwide campaign in 2014 for a higher minimum wage'b', showing how it would help the economy and reduce inequality, while highlighting the cost of the adamant Republican opposition to the idea. They also plan to press for wage-increase referendums in states with crucial Congressional races this November.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s smart politics. 'b'More than three-quarters of Americans'b' support a wage higher than the current $7.25 an hour, and Republicans will be hard-pressed to explain why they oppose it. The issue might bring people to the polls who would otherwise be indifferent to midterm Congressional elections.'b'But more important, it\xe2\x80\x99s good economics, and it would benefit tens of millions of people. Raising the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour by 2016, as 'b'the current Democratic bill'b' would do, would directly or indirectly increase the take-home pay of 27.8 million workers, 'b'according to the Economic Policy Institute'b', adding $35 billion in greater wages through 2016. The resulting increase in gross domestic product would create 85,000 new jobs.'b'The minimum wage would still not go high enough, fast enough. If it had kept pace with inflation, 'b'it would now be $10.77 an hour.'b' But at least the Democratic bill, sponsored by Representative George Miller of California and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, would, for the first time, automatically index the wage to inflation each year after 2016.'b'Republicans have reflexively opposed any mandate that would force their business supporters to reward workers for the increased productivity. 'b'Some want to abolish the minimum wage'b' altogether. In March, every Republican in the House 'b'voted against a measure'b' to raise the minimum wage. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you raise the price of employment, guess what happens? You get less of it,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'said Speaker John Boehner'b' in February, espousing a party-line theory that most economists agree 'b'has been discredited'b'.'b'This campaign, if Democrats fully pursue it, could help demonstrate to voters how intransigent Republicans have been on the most fundamental and popular elements of a strong recovery. Most do not even acknowledge that the country has an inequality problem, and they have systematically worked to deny those at the bottom and in the middle from access to food stamps, health insurance and unemployment benefits. It\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that the only thing Republicans want to discuss are the stumbles of health care reform. An aggressive stand on inequality issues could knock them out of that loop.'b'As important as a minimum-wage increase would be, Democrats shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop there. It would be heartening to see the party give the same support to other aspects of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inequality agenda, including universal preschool, career and technical education, infrastructure investment and stronger collective-bargaining laws. But working toward a decent paycheck is a good place to start.'b'Seven months ago, the world began to learn 'b'the vast scope of the National Security Agency\xe2\x80\x99s reach into the lives of hundreds of millions of people'b' in the United States and around the globe, as it collects information about their phone calls, their email messages, their friends and contacts, how they spend their days and where they spend their nights. The public learned in great detail how the agency has exceeded its mandate and abused its authority, prompting outrage at kitchen tables and at the desks of Congress, which may finally begin to limit these practices.'b'The revelations have already prompted two federal judges to accuse the N.S.A. of violating the Constitution (although a third, unfortunately, 'b'found the dragnet surveillance to be legal'b'). A panel appointed by President Obama 'b'issued a powerful indictment'b' of the agency\xe2\x80\x99s invasions of privacy and called for a major overhaul of its operations.'b'All of this is entirely because of information provided to journalists by Edward Snowden, the former N.S.A. contractor who stole a trove of highly classified documents after he became disillusioned with the agency\xe2\x80\x99s voraciousness. Mr. Snowden is now living in Russia, on the run from American charges of espionage and theft, and he faces the prospect of spending the rest of his life looking over his shoulder.'b'Considering the enormous value of the information he has revealed, and the abuses he has exposed, Mr. Snowden deserves better than a life of permanent exile, fear and flight. He may have committed a crime to do so, but he has done his country a great service. It is time for the United States to offer Mr. Snowden a plea bargain or some form of clemency that would allow him to return home, face at least substantially reduced punishment in light of his role as a whistle-blower, and have the hope of a life advocating for greater privacy and far stronger oversight of the runaway intelligence community.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2'b'Mr. Snowden is currently charged 'b'in a criminal complaint'b' with two violations of the Espionage Act involving unauthorized communication of classified information, and a charge of theft of government property. Those three charges 'b'carry prison sentences of 10 years each'b', and when the case is presented to a grand jury for indictment, the government is virtually certain to add more charges, probably adding up to a life sentence that Mr. Snowden is understandably trying to avoid.'b''b'The president said in August'b' that Mr. Snowden should come home to face those charges in court and suggested that if Mr. Snowden had wanted to avoid criminal charges he could have simply told his superiors about the abuses, acting, in other words, as a whistle-blower.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf the concern was that somehow this was the only way to get this information out to the public, I signed an executive order well before Mr. Snowden leaked this information that provided whistle-blower protection to the intelligence community for the first time,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama said at a news conference. \xe2\x80\x9cSo there were other avenues available for somebody whose conscience was stirred and thought that they needed to question government actions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In fact, 'b'that executive order'b' did not apply to contractors, only to intelligence employees, rendering its protections useless to Mr. Snowden. More important, 'b'Mr. Snowden told The Washington Post earlier this month'b' that he did report his misgivings to two superiors at the agency, showing them the volume of data collected by the N.S.A., and that they took no action. (The N.S.A. says there is no evidence of this.) That\xe2\x80\x99s almost certainly because the agency and its leaders don\xe2\x80\x99t consider these collection programs to be an abuse and would never have acted on Mr. Snowden\xe2\x80\x99s concerns.'b'In retrospect, Mr. Snowden was clearly justified in believing that the only way to blow the whistle on this kind of intelligence-gathering was to expose it to the public and let the resulting furor do the work his superiors would not. Beyond the mass collection of phone and Internet data, consider just a few of the violations he revealed or the legal actions he provoked:'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 The N.S.A. broke federal privacy laws, or exceeded its authority, 'b'thousands of times per year'b', according to the agency\xe2\x80\x99s own internal auditor.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 The agency 'b'broke into the communications links'b' of major data centers around the world, allowing it to spy on hundreds of millions of user accounts and infuriating the Internet companies that own the centers. Many of those companies are now scrambling to install systems that the N.S.A. cannot yet penetrate.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 The N.S.A. systematically 'b'undermined the basic encryption systems of the Internet'b', making it impossible to know if sensitive banking or medical data is truly private, damaging businesses that depended on this trust.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 His leaks revealed that James Clapper Jr., the director of national intelligence,'b' lied to Congress 'b'when testifying in March that the N.S.A. was not collecting data on millions of Americans. (There has been no discussion of punishment for that lie.)'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court 'b'rebuked the N.S.A.'b' for repeatedly providing misleading information about its surveillance practices, according to a ruling made public because of the Snowden documents. One of the practices violated the Constitution, according to the chief judge of the court.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 A federal district judge 'b'ruled earlier this month'b' that the phone-records-collection program probably violates the Fourth Amendment of the Constitution. He called the program \xe2\x80\x9calmost Orwellian\xe2\x80\x9d and said there was no evidence that it stopped any imminent act of terror.'b'The shrill brigade of his critics say Mr. Snowden has done profound damage to intelligence operations of the United States, but none has presented the slightest proof that his disclosures really hurt the nation\xe2\x80\x99s security. Many of the mass-collection programs Mr. Snowden exposed would work just as well if they were reduced in scope and brought under strict outside oversight, as the presidential panel recommended.'b'When someone reveals that government officials have routinely and deliberately broken the law, that person should not face life in prison at the hands of the same government. That\xe2\x80\x99s why Rick Ledgett, who leads the N.S.A.\xe2\x80\x99s task force on the Snowden leaks, 'b'recently told CBS News'b' that he would consider amnesty if Mr. Snowden would stop any additional leaks. And it\xe2\x80\x99s why President Obama should tell his aides to begin finding a way to end Mr. Snowden\xe2\x80\x99s vilification and give him an incentive to return home.'b'LILONGWE, Malawi \xe2\x80\x94 Who is responsible when the trunks of government officials\xe2\x80\x99 cars are stuffed with bank notes while public hospitals are short on life-saving supplies?'b'In Malawi, a landlocked southern African state where more than half the population lives on a dollar a day, blame has fallen on the reformer: President Joyce Banda. Malawi is reeling from a $50 million corruption scandal that has seen Ms. Banda\xe2\x80\x99s budget director shot in the face (he survived) and her justice minister charged with attempted murder (he\xe2\x80\x99s out on bail).'b'Cashgate, as the affair is called, is dwarfed in size by the corruption of earlier administrations: Government investigators believe $500 million in donor money was lost to graft during the eight-year reign of Ms. Banda\xe2\x80\x99s predecessor. But the scam stands out for its brazenness and its violence.'b'It also stands out for the president\xe2\x80\x99s willingness to jail her own officials for their alleged involvement: Sixty-eight people have been arrested since the looting was discovered in September, Ms. Banda said in an interview with a group of foreign journalists, myself among them, at her official residence on Dec. 13.'b'The president is eager to convince Malawians that she is uniquely placed to battle her country\xe2\x80\x99s ills. But more than a year and a half into her tenure it looks like the system she talks of reforming may be her downfall.'b'Ms. Banda became president in April 2012 after the incumbent, Bingu wa Mutharika, died of a heart attack. In the eyes of Western governments, she was a dream successor: focused on health and development, untainted by corruption.'b'The daughter of a musician in the Malawi police band, Ms. Banda started a private girls\xe2\x80\x99 school and a charitable foundation before entering government as minister for gender and community services in 2004 and then serving as foreign minister. Mr. Mutharika used to rage against \xe2\x80\x9cimperialists\xe2\x80\x9d and persecute gays, and Malawi\xe2\x80\x99s G.D.P. dropped by nearly 15 percent during his second term. But Ms. Banda, who was elected vice president in 2009, talked of bringing down maternal mortality and improving education. She was embraced by President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton.'b'Then came Cashgate. A coterie of officials, senior bureaucrats and businessmen allegedly stole from the public treasury using a computerized system that allowed them to erase all record of the theft. Unlike past corruption, which typically involved over-invoicing and kickbacks, this was direct theft from government accounts. Soon Malawi\xe2\x80\x99s treasury felt a chill: Donor states started withholding aid, which makes up 40 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s budget.'b'Nothing seizes attention like a senior official with a bullet wound. But in Malawi political graft is just one facet of a broken administration: Corruption is both a product and a driver of poor governance; the looser the system, the easier it is to steal from it. According to two people familiar with the backdrop to Cashgate, Malawi\xe2\x80\x99s Finance Ministry had not attempted to balance the national checkbook for more than two years before the scandal was uncovered.'b'Penalties for corruption have traditionally been low, while the pressure on bureaucrats to profit illicitly has been intense. In a 2002 paper, the anthropologist Gerhard Anders described a stifling culture of corruption: \xe2\x80\x9cMany civil servants I have talked to emphasized the choking atmosphere of distrust, social control and strength of the unofficial code of conduct in the government\xe2\x80\x99s offices.\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Banda alluded to this in 'b'a November interview with The Daily Telegraph'b': \xe2\x80\x9cFor every one I have arrested,\xe2\x80\x9d she said of government crooks, \xe2\x80\x9cI have lost a whole village of votes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the public health sector, despite years of looting, Malawi only recently began work on a modern inventory-control system. In February the health minister admitted that Malawi\xe2\x80\x99s central medical stores held only 5 percent of the drugs they were supposed to stock.'b'Grace Chiudzu, chief of obstetrics at Kamuzu Central Hospital in the capital, recited a list of shortages to me during a visit last month. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m missing gloves; I\xe2\x80\x99m missing amoxicillin; I\xe2\x80\x99m missing augmentin; I\xe2\x80\x99m missing pethedine,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is the system.\xe2\x80\x9d The week before, she had watched a young woman die for want of a blood transfusion following complications from childbirth.'b'For this, Dr. Chiudzu blamed not corruption but an overcentralized state: The hospital is barred from buying supplies itself, yet the Health Ministry, which holds all the procurement power, is unable to meet needs.'b'Ms. Banda appeared to agree that poor governance was as lethal as corruption. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not about Cashgate,\xe2\x80\x9d she said during our December interview, referring to the underfunded health sector. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s about us, as a nation, getting our priorities right.\xe2\x80\x9d (Opposition leaders say that a recent government purchase of seven military patrol boats for Lake Malawi is one misplaced priority.)'b'A general election is scheduled for May. Ms. Banda\xe2\x80\x99s prospects are undermined by high inflation, a currency devaluation that has halved the value of Malawians\xe2\x80\x99 paychecks, and the stores of cash the biggest opposition party has at its disposal. And, of course, Cash-gate occurred on Ms. Banda\xe2\x80\x99s watch: Arrests and prosecutions notwithstanding, the scandal belongs to her.'b'Ms. Banda appears to be steeling herself for a noble defeat. \xe2\x80\x9cAll the ills of these 50 years that have drawn Malawians backward must be stopped,\xe2\x80\x9d she told my colleagues and me. \xe2\x80\x9cWhatever comes my way, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b' 'b'Dan Morrison 'b' is a journalist and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Black Nile.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'TOKYO \xe2\x80\x94 Last month the Diet passed the 'b'so-called Special Secrets Protection Bill'b'. The law does not define what a \xe2\x80\x9cspecial secret\xe2\x80\x9d is, but whoever leaks one may be imprisoned for up to 10 years. A journalist who merely tries to obtain information the government views as sensitive could be sentenced to five years in jail.'b'The law, which was proposed by the cabinet of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe only in August, has been widely criticized in Japan and abroad, sparking large protests in Tokyo.'b'Many of its opponents have noted that it recalls the infamous Peace Preservation Act of 1925, which the imperial government used to suppress dissent through World War II. The comparison is apt in more than one way. The Peace Preservation Act was passed when Japan was still reeling from the Great Kanto Earthquake of 1923, which had left Tokyo in ruins. Today, the country is still reeling from the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Tohoku, and the ensuing nuclear disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant.'b'Immediately after the secrets law was passed, people observed on Twitter and other social media that the Abe administration\xe2\x80\x99s move was a version of what Naomi Klein calls the \xe2\x80\x9cshock doctrine\xe2\x80\x9d: the practice among politicians and corporations of exploiting the fear and disorientation that follow natural disasters and other major \xe2\x80\x9cshocks\xe2\x80\x9d to push through controversial policies \xe2\x80\x94 giving a second, supposedly therapeutic shock to the system.'b'This, too, seems like a fairly accurate appraisal. At the same time, the secrecy bill is far from the only \xe2\x80\x9cshocking\xe2\x80\x9d news item to have surfaced in Japan since the triple disasters of 2011.'b'Ever since then the Japanese government has provided the media with a steady diet of major, almost all-consuming issues, and the media have obligingly lurched from one to the next. From May to August 2011, news coverage focused on the efforts of members of Prime Minister Naoto Kan\xe2\x80\x99s party to force him out of office after he ordered the shutdown of a nuclear power plant in Hamaoka. The rest of the year was dominated by news of the relocation of U.S. Marine Corps Air Station at Futenma, on Okinawa.'b'During the first half of 2012 the big issue was Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda\xe2\x80\x99s push to pass an unexpected increase in the sales tax. By August 2012, it was tensions between Japan and South Korea after President Lee Myung-bak\xe2\x80\x99s visit to islands that both countries claim as their own. The following month, relations with China soured, when the Japanese government announced its intention to purchase contested islands. And it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stopped: Just the other day, Mr. Abe created another crisis by 'b'visiting Yasukuni Shrine'b', becoming the first sitting prime minister to do so since 2006.'b'The adoption of the special secrets bill, in other words, is merely one in a series of supposedly pressing issues that have dominated national discourse in Japan. I say \xe2\x80\x9csupposedly pressing\xe2\x80\x9d because there was, in fact, no compelling reason for the government or the media to give these issues such prominence when they did. The sales tax could have been raised later. The territorial dispute with China could have been kept under wraps. No urgent matter of national security made it necessary to railroad the special secrets law through Parliament.'b'Meanwhile, the one problem that can\xe2\x80\x99t wait is being pushed into the background. Nearly three years have passed since the earthquake-tsunami-nuclear accident, and almost 280,000 evacuees from the contaminated areas of Fukushima \xe2\x80\x94 about 60 percent of the original number \xe2\x80\x94 are still living in temporary housing. Little progress has been made toward decommissioning units 1 through 4 at the Fukushima Daiichi plant; they continue to produce 400 tons of contaminated water every day, some of which is flowing into the sea.'b'The government\xe2\x80\x99s first priority should be to clean up the nuclear contamination and present Japanese voters with a long-term energy strategy and new economic vision. Anyone can see that these are the truly pressing issues \xe2\x80\x94 anyone, that is, who isn\xe2\x80\x99t looking away.'b'In this sense, describing what has been happening in Japan since 2011 as a version of Ms. Klein\xe2\x80\x99s shock doctrine is only half right. The Japanese government \xe2\x80\x94 first the Democratic Party of Japan, now the Liberal Democratic Party \xe2\x80\x94 may have been exploiting people\xe2\x80\x99s fears and disorientation to push through unpopular policies, but the media and society as a whole have been collaborating with it, even if unconsciously.'b'The French call this \xe2\x80\x9cla fuite en avant,\xe2\x80\x9d or the forward flight. Fleeing forward is what you are doing when you plunge from one issue to the next, constantly creating new emergencies in order to avoid confronting a more serious and intractable problem. It is what Japan is doing when it averts its eyes from the possibility that, as some have speculated, it may take 20 years and 200 trillion yen to recover fully from the damage of 2011.'b'Or maybe the recovery will take more time and more money. No one really knows, because the Japanese government has yet to release official estimates. It just keeps fleeing forward, with the media and society close behind.'b''b' 'b'Norihiro Kato 'b' is a literary scholar and a professor at Waseda University. This article was translated by Michael Emmerich from the Japanese.'b''b'MILAN \xe2\x80\x94  My father is 97 years old. Angelo Severgnini \xe2\x80\x94 Gino to his friends \xe2\x80\x94 was born during a world war, fought in another (first with the Germans, then against them) and witnessed the subsequent Italian civil war. He saw the coming and going of Fascism, Nazism and Communism.'b'And he adores the European Union. He has seen it bring former enemies together, create lasting peace across the Continent and enable his children and grandchildren to make friends abroad and move freely from Italy to Britain, the Netherlands and Poland.'b'Sadly, my father is in a minority these days.'b'Europe\xe2\x80\x99s narrative is in the hands of its foes. While the friends of Europe chat busily among themselves in the narrow circles of government, business and the media, anti-Europe parties are gathering momentum across the Continent.'b'The list is long: Beppe Grillo\xe2\x80\x99s Five Star Movement in Italy. Nigel Farage\xe2\x80\x99s U.K. Independence Party. Alternative for Germany. The Danish People\xe2\x80\x99s Party. True Finns. The Sweden Democrats. In the Netherlands, Geert Wilders\xe2\x80\x99s Party for Freedom. In France, Marine Le Pen\xe2\x80\x99s National Front.'b'Although sometimes lumped together as the \xe2\x80\x9cEuropean Tea Parties,\xe2\x80\x9d they make a somewhat motley political crew. But they share the conviction that the European Union must go.'b'Which would be a shame. The European Union may grind out far too many regulations, but it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t responsible for the current economic slump. And it has brought good things to its member countries. The \xe2\x80\x9cfour freedoms\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 free movement of goods, capital, services and people \xe2\x80\x94 help member economies, as Britain would soon find out if it left.'b'Without a common agriculture policy, Europe would be swamped by cheap imports, and farmers would go out of business. From competition to food safety, the environment, safety at work, the length of court proceedings and conditions in prisons, it is the European Union that sets the standards. Even soccer\xe2\x80\x99s Champions League would be a shade less exciting without the 1995 Bosman ruling, which allowed footballers, just like any other European worker, to move freely across the union.'b'Europe\xe2\x80\x99s voters take all this for granted. Instead, they blame the union for budget restrictions and austerity measures. Europe may be slowly sorting out its banking mess, but the European Union still gets the blame for youth unemployment. The European Commission\xe2\x80\x99s Eurobarometer, which has kept tabs on public opinion since 1973, shows that a record 60 percent of respondents \xe2\x80\x9ctend not to trust the E.U.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The European Commission is worried. Last April its president, Jos\xc3\xa9 Manuel Barroso, introduced \xe2\x80\x9cA New Narrative for Europe,\xe2\x80\x9d inviting the union\xe2\x80\x99s artists, intellectuals and scientists \xe2\x80\x9cto engage with and contribute to a reflection on the European \xe2\x80\x98story.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 Last month in Milan, Mr. Barroso said that Europe should again become \xe2\x80\x9can object of desire.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But rekindling enthusiasm for Europe with new banking regulations, which is where the big focus within the union lies today, is like attempting to boost libido by reading the instructions on a packet of condoms: possible, perhaps, but something of a challenge.'b'All bleak on the European front, then? Not necessarily. If a political storm is on its way, that is good news: Europe needs a good fright to find its courage. The European Union functions by transforming fear into energy. When things go quiet, Europeans tend to sit back and bellyache.'b'Over the last century, there have been four major, salutary scares, each of which has pushed Europe closer together.'b'The first followed World War II. Fearing another war might be possible, the former enemies linked together their coal and steel production, in 1951, and then their economies, with the 1957 Treaty of Rome.'b'A second scare followed the oil crisis and the economic slump of the 1970s. Brussels started to construct a single market, which was initiated in 1992 and has worked well ever since.'b'The third scare came with the fall of Communism from 1989 to 1991. Having no idea about what to do with all those new democracies on its eastern borders, the European Union panicked, as usual. Then it took a flier and significantly enlarged its membership.'b'The fourth scare followed the financial crisis of 2008-9. Many in London and the United States predicted the collapse of the euro, which didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen. New rules for national budgets avoided a major crisis. Today, banking and fiscal unification are on the way.'b'Now another Europe-bracing scare looms. Those Euroskeptic parties are likely to do well in European parliamentary elections in May, which will serve to concentrate minds. Do we care about Europe? Then let\xe2\x80\x99s say so, loud and clear.'b'The so-called Erasmus generation \xe2\x80\x94 the millions of young men and women who spent their 20s sharing offices, labs, lecture halls, apartments and beds across the European Union \xe2\x80\x94 is coming of age. They have a duty, and a privilege, to stand up for Europe.'b'It cannot be left to Ukrainians protesting in favor of integration with the West, or Africans risking their lives on rickety migrant boats, to tell us that Europe is a nice place to live because the rule of law is upheld and its welfare-protected citizens can enjoy agreeable cities set in lovely countryside. 'b''b'There is a last-minute rush by three advanced economies in East Asia to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade agreement that could be concluded this spring. Japan barely made the deadline to become a negotiating member last summer, while Taiwan and South Korea have announced interest in joining once a trade pact is established.'b'The trade talks began in 2010, and there are now 12 members: the United States, Canada, Mexico, Peru, Chile, New Zealand, Australia, Brunei, Singapore, Vietnam, Malaysia and Japan. They account for 40 percent of the world economy.'b'The interests of Japan, Taiwan and South Korea are not about reducing barriers to trade, which are already low. And South Korea, for one, will soon enjoy bilateral free trade agreements with all the economies in the Trans-Pacific Partnership except Japan and Mexico.'b'The partnership is of interest because it is more than a trade deal. Members will be asked to review and restructure the way their domestic economies function, with new rules covering intellectual property rights, regulatory coherence, environmental standards, labor practices and state-owned enterprises. It turns out, for instance, that Japan is eager to restructure the economically inefficient yet politically powerful agricultural sector, and hopes the new rules will help it do so. South Korea wants to use partnership to liberalize its economy, now dominated by 30 family-owned conglomerates, including Samsung and Hyundai, that generate 80 percent of its domestic product. Moreover, Japan, Taiwan and South Korea are mature societies, with older, traditional economic structure. The hope is that foreign pressure can accelerate the difficult task of restructuring and challenging vested interests.'b'For many of the same reasons, it would make sense for China to join the partnership. China recently announced that it would adopt more market mechanisms in an effort to reduce the economic distortions, inefficiencies and corruption of its economy dominated by monopolistic state-owned enterprises. And the partnership itself would make more sense with Chinese membership.'b'But there are pitfalls. Japan, Taiwan and South Korea want to ease rigid labor practices to make their economies more dynamic. There lies the danger of introducing income inequalities in what are now solidly middle-class societies.'b'Organic wine producers in the Burgundy region of France are facing prosecution for refusing to use pesticides. This move is perplexing given the Ministry of Agriculture\xe2\x80\x99s support for the organic wine industry and growing public alarm over pesticides in French wine.'b'The share of organically produced French wines rose from 2.6 percent in 2007 to 8.2 percent by the end of 2012. Despite this progress, France is still the third-highest user of pesticides in the world after the United States and Japan, and the highest user in Europe, applying 110,000 metric tons of pesticides per year.'b'A study in February that found pesticide residues in 90 percent of the French wines tested created an uproar. Pesticide residues were even found in organic wines, indicating contamination from neighboring vineyards or other sources. French vines are susceptible to a contagious bacterial disease, flavescence dor\xc3\xa9e, transmitted by a leafhopper. Treatment with pesticides is required by French law in several winegrowing regions, including Burgundy.'b'One organic producer in Burgundy has now been charged with breaking the law for refusing to use Pyrevert, a pyrethrin pesticide. He says there is no evidence that his vines are infected, and argues that Pyrevert, a neurotoxin, is nonspecific to leafhoppers and kills beneficial insects as well. He faces six months of prison time and a fine of 30,000 euros, or about $41,000. Another organic grower was fined 1 euro after he agreed to use pesticides.'b'France has pledged, under the 2007 Grenelle law on the environment, to reduce its pesticide consumption by 50 percent by 2018. Considering organic producers who refuse pre-emptive use of pesticides as criminals will not help France\xe2\x80\x99s transition to sustainable agricultural practices. The law requiring such use in Burgundy is not only bad policy, it is terrible publicity for French wine. I believe the preferred phrase is \xe2\x80\x9cterminated,\xe2\x80\x9d which is how my former employer, 'b'Byliner'b', a digital publishing company and subscription service in San Francisco, put it. I was informed that our \xe2\x80\x9cburn rate\xe2\x80\x9d was too high, that we needed to show investors that we were serious about reducing it, and that while my loss of a job was unfortunately going to be a part of that reduction, this had nothing to do with the quality of my work. Soon thereafter, an email arrived from the company\xe2\x80\x99s founder and chief executive saying how much he had enjoyed working with me.'b'Around the same time, a termination agreement pinged into my inbox. Much of it set forth standard-issue language resolving such matters as date of termination, the vesting of options, the release of all claims against the company, and the return of company property. I think I get to keep last year\xe2\x80\x99s Christmas gift of an iPad, and the previous year\xe2\x80\x99s bottle of wine has long been drunk, but I must send back any company files in my possession. So far, so good.'b'What brings me up short is clause No. 12: No Disparagement. \xe2\x80\x9cYou agree,\xe2\x80\x9d it reads, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you will never make any negative or disparaging statements (orally or in writing) about the Company or its stockholders, directors, officers, employees, products, services or business practices, except as required by law.\xe2\x80\x9d If I don\xe2\x80\x99t agree to this nondisparagement clause, I will not receive my severance \xe2\x80\x94 in this case, the equivalent of two weeks of pay. Two weeks? Must be hard times out in San Francisco, or otherwise why the dirt parachute \xe2\x80\x94 and by the way, is that the sort of remark I won\xe2\x80\x99t be allowed to make if I sign clause No. 12?'b'I would prefer not to, as Bartleby the Scrivener put it so succinctly in Herman Melville\xe2\x80\x99s classic tale of bureaucratic resistance. When I shared that inclination with one of my superiors at Byliner, the news traveled up the chain of command. And I was soon informed that the president wished to assure me that there is nothing unusual about such clauses, that media people like herself sign them all the time, and that Byliner might even agree to a mutual nondisparagement clause. That means that if I don\xe2\x80\x99t say anything mean about the company, its representatives won\xe2\x80\x99t say anything unkind about me.'b'You might say, what\xe2\x80\x99s the big deal? Sign the damn thing already! And indeed, it\xe2\x80\x99s true, as Byliner implied, that nondisparagement clauses prohibiting individuals from saying or writing anything that might have a negative effect on a corporation are increasingly common \xe2\x80\x94 used in most settlement agreements and about a quarter of executive employment agreements.'b'To make the choice of nondisparagement even easier for a prospective signee, there is no established body of law precisely defining \xe2\x80\x9cdisparagement.\xe2\x80\x9d Several state laws suggest that for former employees to violate a nondisparagement contract, their statements must be not only disparaging but also untrue. This means that it would probably be hard for a company to prove disparagement in the courts.'b'So if nondisparagement agreements are downright ordinary and at the same time difficult to enforce, why not sign and take the severance?'b'Because as quaint as this may seem, giving up the right to speak and write freely, even if that means speaking or writing negatively, strikes me as the unholiest of deals for a writer and an editor to accept. Though such clauses don\xe2\x80\x99t technically violate the First Amendment \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99d be explicitly agreeing to forfeit my right to speak freely if I signed clause No. 12 \xe2\x80\x94 such a contract has a paralyzing effect on the dissemination of the truth, with all of truth\xe2\x80\x99s caustically cleansing powers. To disparage is but one tool in a writer\xe2\x80\x99s kit, but it\xe2\x80\x99s an essential one. That a company would offer money for my silence, which is what this boils down to \xe2\x80\x94 well, I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen many a mob movie about exactly that exchange.'b'The increased prevalence of nondisparagement agreements is part of a corporate culture of risk management that would have us say nothing if we can\xe2\x80\x99t say anything nice. And yet it occurs to me that if a company isn\xe2\x80\x99t strong enough to be reproached, then it simply isn\xe2\x80\x99t strong enough, period.'b'Mind you, I\xe2\x80\x99m not looking to disparage Byliner. The company has made a few mistakes in my view (firing me perhaps being a relatively minor one), but what fledgling enterprise does not screw up from time to time during its shakedown phase? It\xe2\x80\x99s not that I necessarily want to disparage, but I want the freedom to do so, to be able to criticize, to attack, to carp, to excoriate, if need be. I want to tell the truth, even if it isn\xe2\x80\x99t pretty.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why I won\xe2\x80\x99t sign clause No. 12. Byliner can keep the money. I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep my self-respect.'b'CINCINNATI \xe2\x80\x94 THE N.F.L. playoffs start tomorrow. During the regular season, the conversation about traumatic brain injuries in sports among doctors, players, league officials, politicians and parents seemed to gain in volume and intensity with each passing week. New revelations from retired N.F.L. players who announced that they had the progressive neurodegenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., helped fuel these discussions.'b'The key to beating the concussion crisis lies in dealing with what\xe2\x80\x99s happening inside the skull, not outside of it. Because the brain doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fill the skull, there\xe2\x80\x99s room for it to rattle, be bruised or sheared, not just with every collision but with every sudden stop and even start \xe2\x80\x94 a phenomenon sometimes described as \xe2\x80\x9cbrain slosh.\xe2\x80\x9d For athletes in contact sports, brain slosh has long been seen as inherent and unavoidable. But to make progress against concussions, we have to give priority in future research to minimizing brain slosh during game play. This means that we need sports leagues, policy makers and health care providers to emphasize primary prevention instead of damage control.'b'At the 'b'National Conference on Youth Sports Safety in Washington 'b' in November, the approaches discussed were almost entirely focused on post-concussion management. The 'b'well-intentioned legislation'b' currently 'b'under consideration'b' in Congress is also too reactive. It should emphasize the critical role of primary prevention.'b'Newer helmets don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to make much of a difference, either. Studies appearing in the 'b'British Journal of Sports Medicine'b' and the 'b'American Academy of Pediatrics'b' found nearly identical rates of sports-related concussions among different helmet brands and models, including older helmets and new. Why? Think about shipping fragile porcelain \xe2\x80\x94 do we use steel or titanium containers, or Bubble Wrap?\xc2\xa0 The same principle applies when protecting the brain. Helmets fulfill their primary purpose of preventing skull fractures and lacerations, but they do not reduce concussions. It is the delicate brain within the skull that is damaged because it does not fit snugly. Athletes would benefit from a tighter fit for the brain \xe2\x80\x94 a Bubble Wrap effect \xe2\x80\x94 during play, but what are the factors within our control that might provide that effect? We have some leads.'b'At the 'b'Cincinnati Children\xe2\x80\x99s Hospital Medical Center'b', we released a 'b'study'b' that found that high school football players who played at higher altitudes sustained a 30 percent reduction in total concussion incidence. We hypothesized that higher altitude increased the volume in the cerebral venous system, a natural Bubble Wrap that surrounds the brain, and that this created a snugger fit inside the skull that protected the athletes from sustaining concussions. We are currently analyzing N.F.L. concussion data from the 2012 and 2013 regular seasons to see if this effect obtains among professionals.\xc2\xa0'b'There are also biomechanics in nature worth exploring for today\xe2\x80\x99s athletes.'b'Bighorn sheep ritually ram their heads into each other and woodpeckers slam their heads against trees thousands of times a day with neither species\xe2\x80\x99 sustaining concussions or even much of a headache, as far as we know. Meanwhile, much lesser forces result in a concussion, or worse, in humans. Our analysis suggests that both woodpeckers\xe2\x80\x99 and bighorns\xe2\x80\x99 brains are naturally protected with mechanisms that slow the return of blood from the head to the body \xe2\x80\x94 increasing blood volume that fills their brains\xe2\x80\x99 vascular tree, creating the Bubble Wrap effect.'b'We have observed that the woodpecker uses muscles to do this, while the sheep has hollow pneumatic horn cores attached to its respiratory system that allow it to re-breathe its air and thus increase carbon dioxide in its bloodstream, expanding its intracranial vascular tree and enhancing the Bubble Wrap effect.'b'Every week the lights come on over fields of competition around the world, brightening the lives of players and their fans. Unfortunately, every week the lights dim for too many athletes who suffer the effects of concussions despite rule changes and newer helmets. What\xe2\x80\x99s troubling for sports enthusiasts is that parents and politicians may be making the decision to limit or remove the opportunity for young people to participate in contact sports. Although we cannot play every game in Denver, the winning strategies for defeating the concussion crisis may come from research focused on recreating the safe biomechanics already in use in the animal kingdom.'b'Hurricane Sandy made a direct hit on New Jersey just over a year ago, killing 34 people and devastating much of the state\xe2\x80\x99s Atlantic coast. Now, communities that want to build sand dunes to provide protection when (not if) another storm hits are being thwarted by landowners who have refused to allow the dunes to be built on their property. Areas with dunes fared better in the storm than those without them.'b'As of last week, the state needed 2,889 property owners along the coast to agree to easements for the dunes. About one-fourth, more than 700, were holding out, many of them concerned about losing their views.'b'Because their resistance is likely to make conditions less safe for everyone, the state and some local communities are threatening to seize parts of their property \xe2\x80\x94 essentially part of their front yards \xe2\x80\x94 by eminent domain and build the dunes anyway; public safety is a legitimate reason to exercise eminent domain. It is unfair for a few to jeopardize the lives and property of so many others.'b'Gov. And once he made that decision, he put the full force of his office behind it. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are building these dunes, O.K.?\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Christie said at a meeting of homeowners last spring. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are building these dunes whether you consent or not.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There might have been more diplomatic ways to put it, but the governor was right. It\xe2\x80\x99s past time for the holdouts to do their part to protect lives and property, including their own.'b'The new year brings a positive change in the membership practices of the Boy Scouts of America. That overdue step toward inclusion went into effect on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day, a welcome \xe2\x80\x94 though incomplete \xe2\x80\x94 turn for an organization that until quite recently rejected any change in its discriminatory ways.'b'The Boy Scouts\xe2\x80\x99 reluctance to embrace gay equality has been painful to watch. But while the new membership policy caused some churches to end their sponsorship, no mass exodus has materialized. Mormon and Roman Catholic churches are continuing to participate.'b'Unfortunately, the organization still refuses to fully renounce discrimination, and will continue to prohibit gay and lesbian adults from serving as troop leaders. This will perpetuate the idea that gays are inferior and that being gay is inconsistent with the Boy Scout values of strong moral character and leadership. The audacious complaint in this case is against the requirement that such groups sign a short form certifying that they have religious objections to providing coverage for contraceptive services, a copy of which would go to their third-party insurance administrator. The nuns say that minor requirement infringes on religious exercise in violation of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.'b'Under that law, the federal government may not \xe2\x80\x9csubstantially burden a person\xe2\x80\x99s exercise of religion\xe2\x80\x9d unless the government demonstrates that the burden is the least restrictive means of furthering a compelling interest. The certification requirement, an accommodation fashioned by the Obama administration to bolster the protection of religious exercise without depriving women of an important benefit, does not rise to a substantial burden. A federal trial court denied a preliminary injunction on that basis and a federal court of appeals declined to issue an injunction pending appeal, though decisions in some similar cases have come out differently.'b'Adding a level of absurdity to the controversy, Little Sisters of the Poor\xe2\x80\x99s insurance plan qualifies as a self-insured \xe2\x80\x9cchurch plan\xe2\x80\x9d under an insurance statute known as Erisa. The Justice Department has conceded that it has no authority to compel a third-party administrator of such a plan to provide contraceptive coverage. But as he promises to take \xe2\x80\x9cdead aim\xe2\x80\x9d against problems as vast and daunting as inequality and injustice, he is boldly raising expectations for sweeping solutions he \xe2\x80\x94 like any mayor \xe2\x80\x94 has limited ability to deliver.'b'Mr. de Blasio, in a superb campaign, showed the keen judgment of a surfer who spots the swell before it becomes a cresting wave. The emphasis should be on \xe2\x80\x9clooking forward.\xe2\x80\x9d After, of course, he handles this week\xe2\x80\x99s snowstorm.'b'For a little while in my teenage years, my friends and I smoked marijuana. It was fun. I have some fond memories of us all being silly together. I think those moments of uninhibited frolic deepened our friendships.'b'But then we all sort of moved away from it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember any big group decision that we should give up weed. It just sort of petered out, and, before long, we were scarcely using it.'b'We didn\xe2\x80\x99t give it up for the obvious health reasons: that it is addictive in about one in six teenagers; that smoking and driving is a good way to get yourself killed; that young people who smoke go on to suffer I.Q. loss and perform worse on other cognitive tests.'b'I think we gave it up, first, because we each had had a few embarrassing incidents. Stoned people do stupid things (that\xe2\x80\x99s basically the point). I smoked one day during lunch and then had to give a presentation in English class. I stumbled through it, incapable of putting together simple phrases, feeling like a total loser. It is still one of those embarrassing memories that pop up unbidden at 4 in the morning.'b'We gave it up, second, I think, because one member of our clique became a full-on stoner. He may have been the smartest of us, but something sad happened to him as he sunk deeper into pothead life.'b'Third, most of us developed higher pleasures. Smoking was fun, for a bit, but it was kind of repetitive. Most of us figured out early on that smoking weed doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really make you funnier or more creative (academic studies more or less confirm this). We graduated to more satisfying pleasures. The deeper sources of happiness usually involve a state of going somewhere, becoming better at something, learning more about something, overcoming difficulty and experiencing a sense of satisfaction and accomplishment.'b'One close friend devoted himself to track. Others fell deeply in love and got thrills from the enlargements of the heart. A few developed passions for science or literature.'b'Finally, I think we had a vague sense that smoking weed was not exactly something you were proud of yourself for. It\xe2\x80\x99s not something people admire. We were in the stage, which I guess all of us are still in, of trying to become more integrated, coherent and responsible people. This process usually involves using the powers of reason, temperance and self-control \xe2\x80\x94 not qualities one associates with being high.'b'I think we had a sense, which all people have, or should have, that the actions you take change you inside, making you a little more or a little less coherent. Not smoking, or only smoking sporadically, gave you a better shot at becoming a little more integrated and interesting. Smoking all the time seemed likely to cumulatively fragment a person\xe2\x80\x99s deep center, or at least not do much to enhance it.'b'So, like the vast majority of people who try drugs, we aged out. We left marijuana behind. I don\xe2\x80\x99t have any problem with somebody who gets high from time to time, but I guess, on the whole, I think being stoned is not a particularly uplifting form of pleasure and should be discouraged more than encouraged.'b'We now have a couple states \xe2\x80\x94 Colorado and Washington \xe2\x80\x94 that have gone into the business of effectively encouraging drug use. By making weed legal, they are creating a situation in which the price will drop substantially. One RAND study suggests that prices could plummet by up to 90 percent, before taxes and such. As prices drop and legal fears go away, usage is bound to increase. This is simple economics, and it is confirmed by much research. Colorado and Washington, in other words, are producing more users.'b'The people who debate these policy changes usually cite the health risks users would face or the tax revenues the state might realize. Many people these days shy away from talk about the moral status of drug use because that would imply that one sort of life you might choose is better than another sort of life.'b'But, of course, these are the core questions: Laws profoundly mold culture, so what sort of community do we want our laws to nurture? What sort of individuals and behaviors do our governments want to encourage? I\xe2\x80\x99d say that in healthy societies government wants to subtly tip the scale to favor temperate, prudent, self-governing citizenship. In those societies, government subtly encourages the highest pleasures, like enjoying the arts or being in nature, and discourages lesser pleasures, like being stoned.'b'In legalizing weed, citizens of Colorado are, indeed, enhancing individual freedom. But they are also nurturing a moral ecology in which it is a bit harder to be the sort of person most of us want to be.'b'LAS VEGAS \xe2\x80\x94 IT\xe2\x80\x99S the time of year for resolutions. Lose 20 pounds, get to the gym, eat healthier, be more productive, whatever. But in a few months, many people will let these goals fall by the wayside, to be revived next year. I belong to a group who can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to make pledges we don\xe2\x80\x99t keep. I\xe2\x80\x99m an addict.'b'For addicts, discipline isn\xe2\x80\x99t something to strive for each new year; it\xe2\x80\x99s necessary for every moment. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to insult the sport by coming in out of shape, just fighting for a payday. That\xe2\x80\x99s when I became a full-on raging addict. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lifestyle focused on making moral choices and elevating the things that make life worth living to the forefront. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get me wrong. If I craved drugs or alcohol, I\xe2\x80\x99d still give in. I could never fight those cravings. Over the years, my conscience has saved me from descending into a life of total, selfish hedonistic abuse. At my lowest points, I\xe2\x80\x99d still be somewhat outside myself, thinking of the effect my actions had on other people.'b'Even with your conscience nagging at you, it\xe2\x80\x99s extremely difficult to develop a sober and moral consciousness without a good support system. There was no way I could win with people like that in my corner. I am now very fortunate to have a wonderful wife and children surrounding me.'b'In 2009, I vowed to get sober after the accidental death of my 4-year-old girl, Exodus. Recovery is a drawn-out process, and without the continued encouragement of my support system, it would be close to impossible.'b'Strangely, times of success are most dangerous for me. When people tell me, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re great\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cYour comeback is amazing\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re a god,\xe2\x80\x9d I could feed right into it and go get high. I\xe2\x80\x99m looking forward to a glorious 2014, when all of our best-intentioned resolutions become realities.'b'HOUSTON \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThe Circle,\xe2\x80\x9d Dave Eggers\xe2\x80\x99s runaway best seller, is a futuristic nightmare that seems to have touched a nerve. The Circle is a social networking firm with an Edenic campus and a totalitarian grip on its employees\xe2\x80\x99 lives; it forces them to socialize online at a dizzying pace, constantly messaging, friending, liking and answering surveys. In this novel, 21st-century capitalism has gone far beyond \xe2\x80\x9cMetropolis\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cModern Times.\xe2\x80\x9d The digital masters turn even personal lives into hard labor, and so all hours are suddenly working hours. Private space disappears as people make themselves \xe2\x80\x9ctransparent,\xe2\x80\x9d recording and posting their lives for thousands, even millions, of \xe2\x80\x9cfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In Eggers\xe2\x80\x99s hellish future world, anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s anyone measures her self-worth through the easily quantified markers supplied by social media networks: How many hits, how many thumbs-up, did you get today? Some of us are already living in this world, at least a good part of the time. Facebook, Google, Tumblr, Twitter, Instagram: The digital tsunami is absorbing, distracting and all-consuming \xe2\x80\x94 and increasingly it feels like work.  Staying up to the minute is a grind, not a pleasure.'b'The result of the cool-or-not criteria that social networks urge on us is a flattened, analog version of life. We connect with others by cheering for our favorite things, turning ourselves into simple fans and ignoring the many-leveled, ambivalent selves that we actually are. One of the Circle\xe2\x80\x99s disenchanted employees accuses the company of imposing an eternal adolescent immaturity on everyone: \xe2\x80\x9cI like stickers and unicorns\xe2\x80\x9d expanded to cover the whole human world. But a list of preferences is not a self, even though the Internet tells us to think of things that way.'b'The digital world offers us many advantages, but if we yield to that world too completely we may lose the privacy we need to develop a self. Activities that require time and careful attention, like serious reading, are at risk; we read less and skim more as the Internet occupies more of our lives. And there\xe2\x80\x99s a link between selfhood and reading slowly, rather than scanning for quick information, as the Web encourages us to do. Recent work in sociology and psychology suggests that reading books, a private experience, is an important aspect of coming to know who we are.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no accident that the click-happy online universe can sap our focus and make it harder for us to read a full-length book with rapt attention. But old-fashioned reading is still essential, because it teaches lessons about human identity that we can\xe2\x80\x99t get anywhere else. Making your way through a long, realist novel means taking a journey with another self; you look into people\xe2\x80\x99s inner lives as you could never do by watching a three-minute iPhone video.'b'The Circle works as a powerful warning to our culture. True, Eggers can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to create convincing characters, but this seems somehow right for his theme. Two things are missing in his novel: the private self and books. The two absences are linked, since books help us discover ourselves. It\xe2\x80\x99s telling that the library at the Circle is a gorgeous but unused relic: Being alone with a book is something antithetical to the plugged-in networking that preoccupies the company\xe2\x80\x99s workers.'b'After all the Internet\xe2\x80\x99s many diversions, people still yearn for the solitary refuge of reading, since a book provides a space for reflection, a private therapy that is hard to find online. Most of us remember from childhood the experience of being head-over-heels in a book, utterly absorbed. We entered into a strange, enchanted world and traveled with an author\xe2\x80\x99s characters; we lived their lives with them. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing in the online world that can fulfill the promise that we get in a work of fiction to give us a sustained picture of the self.'b'A few months ago, Scott Simon, a host on National Public Radio, tweeted his mother\xe2\x80\x99s last few days of life to his million-plus Twitter followers. Tenderly, tactfully, he shared his shocked realization that his mother was slipping away, and then gone. But I would bet that few of his followers lingered over the tweets for more than a few minutes; they won\xe2\x80\x99t want to reread them next year. Books offer something different, and more.'b'They give us the time and space we need to pursue a full picture of other people, and by extension ourselves. When we think of Anna Karenina\xe2\x80\x99s death, we remember Tolstoy\xe2\x80\x99s stunning, compassionate effort to give a complete image of her life over hundreds of pages. She is selfishly misguided, self-thwarting to the point of ruin, yet somehow she still has our sympathy. She interests us from first page to last, and each reader feels compelled to ponder why she has such a hold on us.'b'All of us deserve to be seen fully, in the way that Tolstoy makes us see Anna. When we read about Anna, we see what it might be like to imagine a self. That\xe2\x80\x99s why we reread Tolstoy, and why we read him slowly, drinking in every detail about Anna\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts and her emotions. This is the way to build a self, not through a collection of personal tastes and opinions, the likes and dislikes that the Internet trades in.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t yet live in Eggers\xe2\x80\x99s dystopian Circle, nor will we ever. These days especially we need to sound the alarm about reading, to practice shutting out distraction so we can have the time and space we need for books.'b'Young people are the ones in most danger from the electronic environment, but they are also just what they\xe2\x80\x99ve always been, the most fervent and loyal readers on the planet. LITT'b' General Counsel, Office of the Director of National Intelligence'b' Washington, Jan. 3, 2014'b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Hyperbole on both sides of the broadband deployment debate (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'U.S. Struggles to Keep Pace in Delivering Broadband Service'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Business Day, Dec. 30) obscures the important challenges digital communication networks face.'b'American consumers pay more than they should for broadband because of the combination of weak competition and lax regulation, but other factors also raise costs, including low population densities, geographic diversity and wide variation in local government requirements. There is a persistent digital divide in America that reflects income and lack of computer skills, not failure of infrastructure deployment.'b'The United States is not struggling in the digital economy. On the demand side, broadband subscriptions and use in this country are far higher than in the other major advanced industrial economies. On the supply side, the United States has a near-monopoly on the leading edge of innovation and production.'b'Utility-style regulation might help the demand side, but it could undermine the supply side. Failing to restrain abuse of market power will slow growth and cause a severe reaction abroad.'b'The hyperbole obscures the successful model of both the Internet and Wi-Fi communications protocols. Policy fostered decentralized communications and prevented abuse of telephone company market power, but regulators did not seek to dictate services and prices.'b'Innovators filled the space between the market and the state with open standards administered by voluntary agreement of the participants. The website\xe2\x80\x99s initial rollout will long stand as a monument to how badly technology contracting can go wrong. But the remarkable recovery also demonstrates what a determined response to such bungling can achieve.'b'Sadly, food stamp and Medicaid recipients can only look on in envy. Just as disaster-relief agencies keep track of hurricanes, floods and earthquakes, students of anti-poverty programs remember a litany of automation and contracting meltdowns \xe2\x80\x94 some of them prolonged, even epic. Florida, 1992-93. Michigan, 1998-99. Colorado, 1998-2002. Texas, 2006-7. Indiana, 2007-9. The Colorado Benefits Management System is particularly memorable: When first implemented, it reportedly refused food stamps to anyone who did not have a driver\xe2\x80\x99s license from Guam.'b'But finding parallels to the HealthCare.gov meltdown requires no memory at all. Just as HealthCare.gov was filling the headlines, a contractor for the Georgia Department of Human Services was neglecting to send renewal notices to the homes of some 66,000 food stamp recipients and about half that number of Medicaid beneficiaries. On Nov. 1, the state\xe2\x80\x99s computer system \xe2\x80\x94 which goes by the Orwellian acronym Success \xe2\x80\x94 automatically terminated benefits to all those affected for failure to cooperate with reviews they had never been told were underway.'b'In December, a Massachusetts contractor sent thousands of people new electronic food stamp benefit cards and immediately deactivated their old cards \xe2\x80\x94 without waiting to see if the new ones had arrived in the mail. Many had not. In mid-October, a contractor\xe2\x80\x99s glitch made food stamps inaccessible to recipients in 17 states.'b'The White House showed impressive alacrity in fixing 'b'HealthCare.gov'b'. But its response to technology failures affecting low-income people has been far more sluggish. The federal Department of Health and Human Services did eventually direct Georgia to reactivate the Medicaid benefits for those wrongfully terminated. The federal Department of Agriculture (which administers food stamps, now known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) brushed aside repeated pleas to tell Georgia to reinstate food assistance in time for Thanksgiving.'b'Instead, Georgia told its desperate people to reapply through a website, though it operated only intermittently. Wrongfully terminated households could call to request paper applications \xe2\x80\x94 but the call center answered fewer than 30 percent of the calls it received in September, and the lucky few who did get through had average waiting times of 34 minutes. They could go into a local food stamp office \xe2\x80\x94 but once there, they would only be directed to a terminal to try to get on the website or a phone to try to get through to the call center. Not just Orwell, but Kafka and Dickens come to mind.'b'Nor was this latest failure an isolated episode. In July 2012, a group of Atlanta eligibility workers told the federal Agriculture Department that case managers were \xe2\x80\x9cfalsely documenting\xe2\x80\x9d that they were calling customers and \xe2\x80\x9cgetting no answer\xe2\x80\x9d and using that excuse to justify denial of food-stamp assistance.'b'The Agriculture Department did not investigate these whistle-blowers\xe2\x80\x99 complaints. When my name appeared in an Atlanta news article about the food stamp debacle, a state employee called me to report a backlog of 12,000 applications waiting to be entered into the Success database.'b'All of this reflects a broader double standard for automation and contracting \xe2\x80\x94 and for government administration generally. An Indiana state judge described a familiar pattern in an earlier food stamp and Medicaid automation contracting fiasco: Officials implemented a \xe2\x80\x9csupersized\xe2\x80\x9d contract, an \xe2\x80\x9cuntested theoretical experiment,\xe2\x80\x9d that resulted in irremediable \xe2\x80\x9cpersonal suffering of needy Hoosiers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A few years ago, a former federal official, frustrated at frequent indifference to low-income Medicaid beneficiaries, joked darkly that the two big government health insurance programs should be called \xe2\x80\x9cMed-I-Care\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMed-I-Don\xe2\x80\x99t-Care.\xe2\x80\x9d (Elderly Medicare users are politically far more important than the poor and disabled customers of Medicaid.)'b'Properly supervised contractors can use technology to improve the delivery of government services. But attention, oversight and willingness to act decisively to remedy fiascoes seem to depend on the wealth and clout of those who are affected. As Obamacare regains its footing, that lesson shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be forgotten.'b'RIO DE JANEIRO \xe2\x80\x94 When I visited China in June, my trip happened to coincide with the discovery that Edward Snowden was hiding out 'b'in Hong Kong'b'.
