He also needs to crack down on the incitement of hatred against Israel in Palestinian schools, textbooks and government-controlled media.'b'As part of the negotiating process, Mr. Netanyahu agreed to release 104 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails over nine months rather than halt settlement construction. But when Mr. Abbas welcomed the latest group to the West Bank this week, Mr. Netanyahu accused him of embracing terrorists, even though Mr. Abbas never condoned the prisoners\xe2\x80\x99 crimes. If Mr. Netanyahu felt so strongly about the prisoner releases, he should have chosen instead to halt settlement construction.'b'Mr. Kerry is working to intensify the American role by offering ideas to bridge gaps between the two sides. His immediate aim is a framework accord that would define the principles of a comprehensive treaty, addressing borders, security, refugees, Jerusalem, mutual recognition and the end of conflict.'b'The framework must not become yet another interim agreement that leaves Palestinians with empty promises. To succeed, it will need to be embraced and defended by Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Abbas, who must acknowledge that neither society will be secure until both can learn to compromise and live as states, side by side.'b'At first glance, two recent crises to hit the White House \xe2\x80\x94 the revelations about unlawful surveillance and the botched health care rollout \xe2\x80\x94 have nothing in common. But each is a reminder of the increasing extent to which government work has been contracted out to private-sector companies. Currently, Washington spends about $500 billion a year on private-sector contracts, more than twice the amount in 2000.'b'It is hard to argue that Americans are getting their money\xe2\x80\x99s worth.'b'The ostensible purpose of using private contractors is to get jobs done cheaper and better. But that aim is often unmet. 'b'Companies bidding'b' for federal work have a financial incentive to overpromise. The complex procurement process gives big companies 'b'an edge'b' to win large, long-term contracts, even when the needed expertise, especially in technology, can often be found at smaller, more nimble companies. Federal rules intended to reduce conflicts of interest instead leave government officials with little authority to oversee or terminate contracts.'b'The result is delays, overruns and unmet public needs. Technological failures are not the only problem. A 'b'recent Senate report'b' found that federal contractors are among the worst violators of wage-and-safety laws, while a New York Times 'b'investigation'b' found that the government buys clothes from sweatshops in foreign countries.'b'It is legitimate to use contractors when the government does not possess the expertise, especially on specific projects, or for services that are tangential to core government functions. But the current practice of contracting out vast swaths of government work indefinitely \xe2\x80\x94 with little or no attempt to develop the needed technical and managerial expertise within the government or to enforce labor standards \xe2\x80\x94 has created a bloated federal-contractor sector in which the public good is often subservient to profit.'b'Several sensible proposals to reform federal contracting have been put forward, including bipartisan legislation to make a single person at each government agency responsible for technology projects. Some good-government groups have suggested that government analysts systematically evaluate whether contractors provide better value than federal employees and what it would take to develop in-house expertise. Legislators and some labor advocates say President Obama should require government agencies to consider a company\xe2\x80\x99s labor and performance record when awarding contracts.'b'But for all the 'b'research'b' and 'b'recommendations'b', nothing much is happening in Congress or the administration, in part because the status quo is lucrative for powerful corporations and big campaign donors, and is entrenched by the revolving door between government agencies and private-sector contractors. Reform will not be simply a technical exercise. It also will be a political battle, one that no one has taken up in earnest yet.'b'Rebuffed by Congress on stronger gun safety laws, President Obama is wisely using use his executive powers in a more focused attempt to bar mentally ill people from eluding federal watch lists and purchasing firearms. Two sensible changes proposed for the background check system would allow states and mental health providers more discretion than they have now in reporting information about potentially violent people.'b'The first would deal with longstanding complaints from law enforcement authorities about the narrow scope of a rule stipulating that a person cannot be denied the purchase of a firearm unless he or she has been \xe2\x80\x9ccommitted to a mental institution\xe2\x80\x9d in the past. This ignores whole categories of obviously risky citizens.'b'The proposed change would broaden the rule to include involuntary outpatient as well as inpatient commitments. Some of the shooters in cases of mass gun violence were found to have previously come to the attention of authorities but received psychiatric testing or care that fell short of orders of commitment. Including inpatient and outpatient care broadens the grounds for denying weapons.'b'The second proposal deals with privacy strictures in health insurance laws that states say prevent the passing on of relevant information about potentially violent people. After consultation with mental health professionals, the White House said health insurance organizations would be extended \xe2\x80\x9can express permission\xe2\x80\x9d to furnish to federal authorities \xe2\x80\x9cthe limited information necessary to help keep guns out of potentially dangerous hands.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Neither of these changes can fully solve the nation\xe2\x80\x99s gun safety problem, but both offer a promise of relief. Far more is needed, if Congress can ever disenthrall itself from the gun lobby to rein in the carnage.'b'The power to grant clemency is a critical function of the executive branch. It serves as a last, case-by-case resort to remedy an unjustly long sentence, erase a wrongful conviction or show forgiveness where it is merited. But New Yorkers seeking clemency from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, either from within prison or after their release, have found virtually no consolation during the three years of his tenure.'b'That fact was highlighted by Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'decision this week'b' to exercise his clemency power for the first time since taking office in 2011. When he finally took action, he did so with miserly caution, pardoning just 'b'three men'b' for relatively minor crimes committed long ago.'b'Seymour Hunter, 70, spent one day in jail 20 years ago for trying to sell drugs. Gerardo Alvarez was sentenced to three days\xe2\x80\x99 community service after cocaine was found in his car. Rocco Paciello was convicted of statutory rape for dating a 15-year-old girl when he was 22. He served eight days in jail; he and his girlfriend later married and have been together 21 years. Mr. Cuomo said that each of these men \xe2\x80\x9cpaid their debt to society long ago\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9care deserving of a second chance.\xe2\x80\x9d Surely that is true, particularly for Mr. Hunter and Mr. Alvarez, both of whom hope to become United States citizens. But there are still many more prisoners serving unfairly long sentences under the state\xe2\x80\x99s outdated and only partly reformed Rockefeller drug laws, or who have demonstrated that they, too, deserve a second chance. As a former attorney general who fought for the laws\xe2\x80\x99 reform, Mr. Cuomo can do better.'b'Part of the problem is that New York\xe2\x80\x99s clemency process is opaque, unpredictable and unproductive.'b'Some states have developed better processes to handle clemency requests with more regularity and transparency. In California, Gov. Jerry Brown 'b'issued 127 pardons'b' last month, and in Illinois, Gov. Pat Quinn has granted clemency 'b'more than 1,000 times'b' over four-plus years. Mr. Cuomo should show more courage on this issue and take the lead to improve New York\xe2\x80\x99s clemency process.'b'Laupheim, a small town in southern Germany, once boasted a large Jewish community and named a prominent street after one of its Jewish sons: Carl Laemmle, who went on to found Universal Studios. But all of that changed in the 1930s. By 1992, when I started fifth grade, Laemmle\xe2\x80\x99s name had long since been removed from the map, and my mother and I were the only Jews in town.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAllsbach, Lisa,\xe2\x80\x9d the teacher asked at the beginning of our first class. \xe2\x80\x9cProtestant or Catholic?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have to sign you up for either Catholic or Protestant religion classes. And I still didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what to say \xe2\x80\x94 in part out of an instinctive understanding that I would be marked out; in part because, not being religious, really, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know the right answer.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMounk, Yascha. Protestant or Catholic?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I guess I\xe2\x80\x99m sort of Jewish.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The class laughed. Uproariously.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cStop making things up,\xe2\x80\x9d Johannes Emmerle, a Protestant, shouted as the hilarity ebbed. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody knows that the Jews don\xe2\x80\x99t exist anymore!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Herr Weiss reprimanded Johannes. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk unless I call on you. We must have order. O.K., Yascha. You\xe2\x80\x99ll have a free period when the others take religion. There\xe2\x80\x99s a Turk in another class, I think. You two can keep each other company.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Then he added, as an afterthought: \xe2\x80\x9cAnd, Johannes, you are wrong, as a matter of fact. There are a few Jews. Again.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Johannes wasn\xe2\x80\x99t too far off the mark. Of the more than 500,000 Jews who lived in Germany when Hitler took power in 1933, only about 15,000 remained on German territory at war\xe2\x80\x99s end, and many of them planned to emigrate. German Jews, it seemed, would soon be extinct.'b'But that extinction never came to pass. Some Jews who had fled the Third Reich returned to build a new, better society. Others, liberated from the concentration camps but without a home to return to, temporarily settled in camps for \xe2\x80\x9cdisplaced persons.\xe2\x80\x9d Most of them soon made their way to Israel or the United States, but some got stuck for one reason or another, and never left. As West Germany rapidly grew, more Jews came to the country as businessmen, artists or refugees \xe2\x80\x94 especially after the fall of the Soviet Union, when tens of thousands were encouraged to relocate. All told, well over 100,000 Jews now live in the Federal Republic.'b'My family, too, came to West Germany as immigrants. Born in the shtetls of Eastern Europe, my grandparents embraced Communism as teenagers, leaving home to become political activists. They survived the Holocaust by fleeing to the Soviet Union and returned to Poland after the war, keen to put their ideals into practice at long last. But then the regime they had helped to build threw them out amid a large-scale anti-Semitic witch hunt. Out of options, my mother and her father sought refuge in West Germany.'b'Born in 1982 as the citizen of a peaceful, affluent and increasingly cosmopolitan country, I spent a mostly happy childhood in places like Munich, Freiburg and Karlsruhe. I was a fervent supporter of the national soccer team and dreamed of running for the Bundestag. German is, and will remain, the only language I speak without an accent.'b'My family\xe2\x80\x99s Jewish identity has never been strong. I had neither a bris nor a bar mitzvah. When I was young, my mother gave me Christmas presents so that I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t feel left out.'b'Even so, as I grew older, I felt more and more Jewish \xe2\x80\x94 and less and less German. Gradually, I concluded that staying in Germany was not for me.'b'The reaction of my classmates in Laupheim might suggest that ignorance or hatred \xe2\x80\x94 which have subsided since I was a child, but remain real problems \xe2\x80\x94 are why I left. But that\xe2\x80\x99s not quite true. If there was one thing that made me feel I would never truly belong, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t hostility: It was benevolence.'b'Starting in the 1960s, Germany began to break a silence of decades about the past. A new generation confronted its forefathers about what they had done during the Third Reich. The country embarked on the slow, painful process of facing up to the enormity of the Holocaust.'b'As Germany\xe2\x80\x99s understanding of its history changed, so did popular attitudes toward Jews. Especially in the country\xe2\x80\x99s hipper neighborhoods, Judaism was suddenly all the rage. Nary a literary reading failed to feature a Yiddish poem. Few were the gallery openings that lacked an ensemble of Aryans playing klezmer. Especially in the 1980s and early 1990s, it seemed as though the whole country had come down with a bout of philo-Semitism.'b'I first realized that I had become a flesh-and-blood object for this demonstrative good will when I moved from provincial Laupheim to cosmopolitan Munich. Suddenly, I found myself treated as a kind of celebrity \xe2\x80\x94 somebody to be admired for being different, but also to be handled with special care.'b'When I went to a party thrown by Franz, a high-school friend, I found him in a heated discussion about Woody Allen with a soft-spoken blonde.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFranz here thinks that Woody is creepy and that his movies are mediocre,\xe2\x80\x9d Marie, the girl, told me.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d Franz said, turning bright red. \xe2\x80\x9cI never said he was creepy or mediocre.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou just said he was creepy because he married Mia Farrow\xe2\x80\x99s daughter. And that he\xe2\x80\x99s not as serious as \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d Franz hedged, glancing at me, \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it quite like that. Sure, it\xe2\x80\x99s a little weird that he married his girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s daughter. But, you know, they were both adults and it\xe2\x80\x99s not illegal, so \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you being so strange?\xe2\x80\x9d Marie asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not being strange at all. It\xe2\x80\x99s just important to see both sides of the argument. You make it sound as though I had something against Woody Allen. I don\xe2\x80\x99t. He\xe2\x80\x99s a likable guy. As you said, his Jew humor is admirable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Marie turned to me, with a mocking smile. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be the reason for Franz\xe2\x80\x99s sudden transformation. What\xe2\x80\x99s the deal? Are you writing something about Woody Allen? Or are you related to him?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cRest assured that I have no particular horse in this race.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Franz mumbled, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, actually, yes, in a way, Yascha is re \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9d Helplessly, he petered out.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d Marie asked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou really are related to Woody Allen?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Franz stared at Marie, Marie stared at me, and I scanned the room for a desperately needed drink.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not at all,\xe2\x80\x9d I finally replied. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess what Franz meant to say is that I\xe2\x80\x99m Jewish.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Marie gasped. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, how exciting. A real Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Franz, meanwhile, set about telling me how great a work \xe2\x80\x9cDeconstructing Harry\xe2\x80\x9d was.'b'At first, I enjoyed the attention. After living in a place where my classmates had known so little about what it meant to be Jewish, it was nice to be treated with kid gloves. But my excitement did not last long. Increasingly, I realized that the mere mention of my heritage erected an invisible wall between my classmates and me. Back in Laupheim, there had at least been a kind of bravery in asserting my heritage. In Munich, I found myself increasingly circumspect about revealing my identity.'b'My experience of philo-Semitism had another effect. Until I moved to Munich, I had never doubted that I was a German. But now I realized that even my most well-intentioned compatriots saw me as a Jew first, and a German second. And so I, too, began to identify as more of a Jew than a German.'b'My feeling of not belonging only intensified as the philo-Semitic moment faded, and a new mood of \xe2\x80\x9cenough is enough\xe2\x80\x9d took hold. In 1998, the novelist Martin Walser argued that Germans had become unhealthily obsessed with the Third Reich, and that the memory of Auschwitz was increasingly being used to harm Germany. The country, he said, should draw a definitive \xe2\x80\x9cfinish line\xe2\x80\x9d underneath the past. Polls found that most Germans agreed.'b'Once again, Germany\xe2\x80\x99s changed understanding of its past manifested itself in ordinary interactions. One Saturday morning, for example, I went to Munich\xe2\x80\x99s Oktoberfest with a group of acquaintances. A jolly brass band in lederhosen was playing. We clinked our mugs in a traditional Bavarian toast.'b'Stephanie, a petite woman in her late 30s, was trying to make a joke. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you fit 200 Jews into a Volkswagen Beetle?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cKnock it off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hans, a big-boned, folksy friend of mine. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is not appropriate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I?\xe2\x80\x9d Stephanie shot back. \xe2\x80\x9cBecause you tell me to shut up? Because they tell me to shut up? Come on, it\xe2\x80\x99s just a joke!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI doubt it\xe2\x80\x99ll be funny,\xe2\x80\x9d Hans said.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNot funny? Have a sense of humor! Why can\xe2\x80\x99t a joke about the Jews be funny? It\xe2\x80\x99s 2006. The Holocaust happened 60 years ago. We should tell jokes about the Jews again!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLook,\xe2\x80\x9d Hans said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know as well as I do that Germans have a special responsibility to be sensi \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA special responsibility? I\xe2\x80\x99m not even 40! No, no. I won\xe2\x80\x99t stay silent any longer. Here\xe2\x80\x99s how you fit them in. You gas them. You incinerate them. You stuff them in the ashtray. That\xe2\x80\x99s how you do it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Stephanie\xe2\x80\x99s tasteless joke allowed me to put in words what had long made me uncomfortable even about less crass advocates of the \xe2\x80\x9cfinish line.\xe2\x80\x9d Clearly, there was something artificial about the ritualistic displays of historical contrition that had long been central to public life in Germany. But to assert that the time had come to move beyond the past, once and for all, was no less artificial. Normality cannot be decreed by fiat.'b'Both the ignorance I had encountered in Laupheim and the philo-Semitism I experienced in Munich had made me feel like an outsider \xe2\x80\x94 but each also made me more determined to help in the creation of a German-Jewish identity. Now that my very presence was enough to make some people resentful, however, I grew impatient with the endless complications of being a German Jew. I wanted nothing more than to be seen, finally, as an individual. And so, despite everything I loved about Germany, and unlike so many other German Jews, I decided to leave.'b'When I first moved to New York, as a graduate student, I hoped that living here would make it possible for me to choose who I wanted to be. In Germany, I always thought twice before mentioning that my ancestors were Jewish: I knew that, once I\xe2\x80\x99d pronounced that fateful word, I would, in the minds of many, be reduced to it. In New York, a city of more than a million Jews, I found that this hardly changed how others saw me.'b'Being free to construct my own identity has had an unexpected effect: I\xe2\x80\x99ve come to realize that being Jewish is not particularly important to me after all. Sure, I enjoy \xe2\x80\x9cSeinfeld\xe2\x80\x9d and a whitefish bagel. But is that enough to make me \xe2\x80\x9cculturally\xe2\x80\x9d a Jew? I\xe2\x80\x99m not convinced. I can see why many other secular, nonobservant Jews \xe2\x80\x94 who speak Hebrew, or grew up following Jewish ritual \xe2\x80\x94 feel that being Jewish defines them. But defining myself strongly as a Jew when I know so little about religion or ritual would, I believe, cheapen the tradition I would be claiming to invoke.'b'New York has given me the same liberty it has afforded generations of immigrants: the freedom to be true to myself. In an age of identity politics, we assume that this must mean the freedom to proclaim one\xe2\x80\x99s identity. But, for me, it has just as much to do with the liberty to shed an identity to which I\xe2\x80\x99d long been reduced.'b'A true New Yorker, E.B. White suggested, is one who has come to the city \xe2\x80\x9cin quest of something.\xe2\x80\x9d It is because New York is defined as much by its newcomers as by its natives that I hope to spend my life here. My identity is no longer that of a Jew or a German. It is that of a seeker who has found; that of a stranger who has come to be at home; that of, simply and immeasurably, a New Yorker.'b''b'\n'b'Yascha Mounk 'b' is a doctoral candidate in political theory at Harvard and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cStranger in My Own Country: A Jewish Family in Modern Germany.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'In the languid news week after Christmas, hungry media outlets swarmed over a report of piranhas attacking swimmers on a river in Argentina. \xe2\x80\x9cMassive Piranha Attack\xe2\x80\x9d cried The New York Post. \xe2\x80\x9c70 Christmas Day Bathers Are Savaged\xe2\x80\x9d added The Daily Mail, promising \xe2\x80\x9cthe truth about the fish with a bite more powerful than a  T. rex.\xe2\x80\x9d ABC News called it a \xe2\x80\x9cChristmas Day feeding frenzy.\xe2\x80\x9d In fact, the injuries ranged from minor cuts to at least one missing finger part \xe2\x80\x94 not exactly as newsworthy as, say, the 800,000 Americans who require medical treatment for dog bites each year.'b'Piranhas have always been among our favorite subjects for sheer, sputtering nonsense. Theodore Roosevelt, on a 1913 expedition in South America, called piranhas \xe2\x80\x9cthe most ferocious fish in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d More recently, multiple \xe2\x80\x9cPiranha\xe2\x80\x9d movies have ridden this hysteria to the bank.'b'This is an awful lot of hype for piranhas to live up to, and predictably, they disappoint. To test the colorful mythology of the ferocious piranha, I once climbed into a tank of hungry red-bellied piranhas at the Dallas World Aquarium. (They fled to the opposite corner.) In the Peruvian Amazon, I stood waist-deep in the Rio Napo while catching and releasing piranhas on a hook-and-line. (The nibbles were strictly of the usual kind.) In the flooded grasslands of Venezuela, I drove around tossing a chicken carcass into various bodies of water to time how long it took for the flesh-maddened swarms to strip it to feathers. (There was enough chicken left at the end of the day to feed a family of four.)'b'The point of this exercise, recounted in my book \xe2\x80\x9cSwimming With Piranhas at Feeding Time,\xe2\x80\x9d was that piranhas do that swarming, blood-crazed, flesh-ripping thing only in a couple of rare circumstances, both involving a highly concentrated food source: They will swarm around bird rookeries, where the fledglings leaving the nest often tumble straight down into the water. And they\xe2\x80\x99ll do it around docks where fishermen clean their catch and heave the guts into the water.'b'Otherwise, you can swim without fear.'b'I didn\xe2\x80\x99t worry about piranhas, for instance, when the only place to bathe, on a recent trip deep into the backcountry of Suriname, was the river running past our camp.'b'Then one day, sitting in a canoe, I watched the fish biologist on our expedition, Jan H. Mol of the University of Suriname, pull a 12-inch-long black piranha out of the same water where we took our daily baths. As this extremely toothy creature wriggled in his hands, Mr. Mol started talking, in his somewhat ponderous way, about a paper he had published on piranha-bite incidents, complete with color photos of amputated toes.'b'Like me, Mr. Mol believes the piranha threat is wildly exaggerated. He has spent more than 20 years wading in South American rivers and hauling up every imaginable fish without ever being injured by free-swimming piranhas. \xe2\x80\x9cFree-swimming\xe2\x80\x9d is, however, the operative phrase there: If you get careless while trying to untangle one from a net, or you let one flop around the bottom of the boat, things can get painful.'b'As he spoke, Mr. Mol was using the soft pad of his index finger to hold down the piranha\xe2\x80\x99s sharply serrated lower jaw and give me a better view. It was a formidable mouthful. But that index finger rather spoiled the effect of another recent study, in the journal Nature, which found that the black piranha\xe2\x80\x99s bite is more powerful, pound for pound, than that of a great white shark or a killer whale. Yes, yes, that article also mentioned T. rex, but \xe2\x80\x9cpound for pound\xe2\x80\x9d (or as the authors put it, \xe2\x80\x9cremoving the effects of body size\xe2\x80\x9d) turns out to be another of those pesky operative phrases.'b'We chatted briefly about the classic studies by the Brazilian researcher Ivan Sazima, who observed piranhas in the clear-water ponds and creeks of South America\xe2\x80\x99s vast Pantanal wetlands. Mr. Sazima found that these generally timid little fish mainly feed by nipping off fins and scales from passing fish, not by ripping their flesh. Mr. Sazima is also an author of a paper with the lovely title \xe2\x80\x9cScavenging on human corpses as a source for stories about man-eating piranhas.\xe2\x80\x9d It concluded that when human bodies turn up in the water with signs of piranha attack, it\xe2\x80\x99s almost certainly because the piranhas were scavenging on people who were already dead.'b'Even piranha specialists would struggle to come up with a dozen cases over the past half-century in which multiple living human victims were injured. In the two cases Mr. Mol investigated in northwestern Suriname, one in the 1950s and the other in the early 2000s, most of the victims suffered a single relatively minor bite on the feet or legs. He found that in each case, there was a factor that attracted piranhas to the area \xe2\x80\x94 fishermen gutting their catch nearby or holiday visitors spilling food in the river. Mr. Mol theorized that the piranhas bit humans by accident at first, and then, recognizing a newly abundant food source, began to take advantage of it. Other fish specialists I spoke to or emailed the other day argued that those incidents, and the more recent one in Rosario, Argentina, were all cases of defensive biting.'b'Christmas Day was unusually hot in Rosario \xe2\x80\x94 about 100 degrees Fahrenheit \xe2\x80\x94 and people were crowding into the river. It\xe2\x80\x99s also mating season for the three local piranha species. It\xe2\x80\x99s likely, said Prosanta Chakrabarty, a fish biologist at Louisiana State University, that bathers inadvertently wandered into male breeding territories, provoking a brief but hostile response.'b'None of the attacks escalated into a classic piranha swarm. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t, as The Daily Mail reported, \xe2\x80\x9clike a scene from a horror film\xe2\x80\x9d with swimmers being \xe2\x80\x9csavaged by shoals of the razor-toothed fish,\xe2\x80\x9d which ripped away \xe2\x80\x9cchunks of their naked and exposed flesh.\xe2\x80\x9d Victims were able to walk back to the beach without being attacked by other piranhas. Other beachgoers were back in the water a half-hour later.'b'So what\xe2\x80\x99s the bottom line on piranhas? \xe2\x80\x9cIf something is potentially dangerous to humans, it will be dangerous in certain conditions,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Mol told me, as we sat in the canoe that day in Suriname. But those conditions are extremely rare, and the danger tends to be highly limited.'b'We ate the piranha for dinner that night, and I continued to bathe in the river.'b'But \xe2\x80\x94 this is the thing about human nature \xe2\x80\x94 now and then I also paused to count my toes.'b''b'\n'b'Richard Conniff 'b' is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Species Seekers: Heroes, Fools, and the Mad Pursuit of Life on Earth.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S that time of year again. Maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s your waistline you\xe2\x80\x99re worried about, or maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s the smoking habit you just can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to kick. To improve your chances of keeping your New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolutions, we offer four tips inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health. We focus on health, but our suggestions should help with other goals, too.'b'First, make a concrete plan. When you do so, you both embed your intentions firmly in memory (which reduces forgetting) and make it harder to postpone good behavior, since doing so requires breaking an explicit commitment to yourself. In an experiment 'b'reported in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences'b', a team of researchers (including one of us) contacted thousands of individuals who needed 'b'flu'b' shots. Those individuals who were prompted to privately write down a plan specifying the date and time they would visit a clinic got shots at a 13 percent higher rate than members of a control group, who were also reminded about clinics but were not prompted to form a plan. This strategy, as the same team 'b'reported in the journal Preventive Medicine'b', also improved turnout for 'b'colonoscopies'b'.'b'Second, put something you value on the line. In 'b'an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association'b', a team of researchers (including one of us) reported that over the course of a 16-week study, individuals who were given the opportunity to set aside money for forfeiture if they failed to lose weight lost 14 pounds more than those in a control group. Similarly, 'b'an experiment in the American Economic Journal: Applied Economics'b' found that smokers hoping to quit were more likely to succeed if offered an opportunity to deposit funds in an account for six months that they would lose if they failed a urine test for 'b'nicotine'b' and cotinine. You can arrange to forfeit money if you don\xe2\x80\x99t achieve your goals at 'b'stickK.com'b', a website founded by behavioral economists. But putting money on the line isn\xe2\x80\x99t your only option: Making an appointment to 'b'exercise'b' with a friend may be effective, too, because you are much less likely to cancel on a friend than on yourself.'b'Third, bundle your temptations. This is one of our favorite strategies for tackling health goals, which we tested in an experiment described in 'b'a forthcoming paper in Management Science'b'. The idea is best illustrated with a scenario: Imagine you want to exercise more but struggle to drag yourself to the gym. Imagine you also have a fondness for trashy novels but feel guilty 'b'wasting'b' your time reading them. The solution is simple: Allow yourself to read those novels only while exercising at the gym. Our research demonstrates that when you leave your copy of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Hunger Games\xe2\x80\x9d (or such) at the gym, you exercise 56 percent more often (and 61 percent of people will even pay the gym to hold their book so it is only available when exercising).'b'Fourth, seek social support. You can achieve more by pursuing goals with the help of a mentor. In 'b'a study co-authored by one of us and reported in the Annals of Internal Medicine'b', patients with poorly controlled 'b'diabetes'b' were paired with patients who previously had poorly controlled diabetes but had since achieved mastery over their disease. The improvements in glycemic control achieved by those mentored in this study were larger than those produced by many leading drugs.'b'What if, despite our tips, you nonetheless fail to achieve your New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolutions? Fortunately, you will have plenty of other chances. In 'b'a paper forthcoming in Management Science'b', a team of researchers (including one of us) documents \xe2\x80\x9cthe fresh start effect.\xe2\x80\x9d We analyzed the frequency with which Americans searched for the term \xe2\x80\x9cdiet\xe2\x80\x9d on Google, students visited a university gym and people signed up to create goals on 'b'stickK.com'b'. We found that the beginnings of many cycles \xe2\x80\x94 including the start of a new week, month, year and semester (for students) \xe2\x80\x94 are associated with increased interest in dieting as well as increases in exercise and goal creation. People also intensify their pursuit of aspirations following birthdays and federal holidays.'b'So although many (in fact most) New Year\xe2\x80\x99s resolutions are unsuccessful, the good news is that if at first we don\xe2\x80\x99t succeed, there are many other \xe2\x80\x9cfresh starts\xe2\x80\x9d on the calendar when we can try again.'b'Readers react to a call for better coverage for psychiatric care.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'It has been a decade of tragedy. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports increasing suicide rates since 2000. News articles about mass shootings and extreme violence are routine.'b'The urgency for enhanced mental health services could not be more compelling. Congress responded with the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act of 2008, intended to end longstanding insurance practices that discriminated against people with mental illness and drug and alcohol addictions.'b'Beginning in 2014, the parity law\xe2\x80\x99s reach will become even broader as millions more Americans gain mental health coverage under the Affordable Care Act. But it won\xe2\x80\x99t be good enough. Many consumers will still face impossible barriers to getting needed mental health and substance abuse services.'b'Insurance programs can pick and choose which services to approve. A significant number don\xe2\x80\x99t cover residential services, partial hospitalization or intensive outpatient care for people who need it.'b'Not to mention that many outpatient psychiatrists do not even accept insurance, requiring patients to pay out of pocket, as your article \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Fewer Psychiatrists Seen Taking Health Insurance'b'\xe2\x80\x9d pointed out. It cites a study showing that a mere 55 percent of psychiatrists accept private insurance and Medicare, while only 43 percent accept Medicaid, far less than other doctors. This is not likely to change, as the demand for psychiatric care far exceeds the supply of physicians.'b'There are numerous reasons for this disparity, although they mostly boil down to the fact that insurance companies, with their poor psychiatric reimbursements and intrusive reviews, provide little incentive for solo practitioners to accept them.'b'To really improve access to mental health care, insurance companies need to reform their policies. Otherwise, millions of Americans will continue to go without a diagnosis and without treatment, leading to more decades of tragedy.'b'HELEN M. FARRELL'b' Boston, Dec. 30, 2013'b''b''b'The writer is a psychiatrist at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center and an instructor at Harvard Medical School.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Readers React'b''b'Dr. Farrell notes a number of barriers to mental health care, but does not acknowledge that much of the problem has been self-inflicted by psychiatry and the mental health profession, which have been co-opted by Big Pharma and its push to increase the diagnoses of both minor and major disorders to new heights.'b'This is the only explanation for a 40-fold increase in the diagnosis of bipolar disorder among youth and a doubling in adults. Rates of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder have tripled in some studies, while rates in Denmark have gone up fivefold. Naturally, these increases have resulted in an enormous increase in prescriptions for stimulants in both youth and adults. The evidence further suggests that psychiatrists are prescribing simply on the basis of symptoms rather than on formal diagnoses, which may or may not be a good development given our flawed manual of mental disorders, but nevertheless further opens the treatment floodgates.'b'CHARLES E. DEAN'b' Apple Valley, Minn., Jan. 1, 2014'b''b''b'The writer is a psychiatrist.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'While it is true that psychiatric services are poorly paid in general by insurance companies and particularly by Medicare and Medicaid, I am embarrassed by and disappointed in my colleagues who feel the solution is to accept only private-pay patients. SANDBERG'b' New York, Jan. 1, 2014'b''b''b'The writer is a psychoanalyst and a clinical associate professor of psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical Center.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'The letter by Dr. Farrell raises daunting questions, many of which I have been struggling with during 45 years in the private practice of psychiatry and on the inpatient services of Bellevue Hospital. GELLER'b' New York, Jan. 1, 2014'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'Pointing out the inadequacies within mental care policy evokes strong opinions, as it raises issues of necessity, fairness and responsibility.'b'Mental illness, as described by 19th-century doctors, was like a sphinx that defies anatomy. FARRELL'b' Boston, Jan. 2, 2014'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cTO read a novel is a difficult and complex art,\xe2\x80\x9d Virginia Woolf wrote in a 1925 essay, \xe2\x80\x9cHow to Read a Book.\xe2\x80\x9d Today, with our powers of concentration atrophied by the staccato communication of the Internet and attention easily diverted to addictive entertainment on our phones and tablets, book-length reading is harder still.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not just more difficult to find the time and focus that a book demands. Longstanding allies of the reader, professionals who have traditionally provided guidance for those picking up a book, are disappearing fast. The broad, inclusive conversation around interesting titles that such experts helped facilitate is likewise dissipating. Reading, always a solitary affair, is increasingly a lonely one.'b'A range of related factors have brought this to a head. Start with the publishing companies: Overall book sales have been anemic in recent years, declining 6 percent 'b'in the first half of 2013'b' alone. But the profits of publishers have remained largely intact; in the same period only one of what were then still the \xe2\x80\x9cbig six\xe2\x80\x9d trade houses 'b'reported a decline'b' on its bottom line. This is partly because of the higher margins on e-books. But it has also been achieved by publishers cutting costs, especially for mid-list titles.'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cmid-list\xe2\x80\x9d in trade publishing parlance is a bit like the middle class in American politics: Anything below it is rarely mentioned in polite company. It comprises pretty much all new titles that are not potential blockbusters. But it\xe2\x80\x99s the space where interesting things happen in the book world, where the obscure or the offbeat can spring to prominence, where new writers can make their mark.'b'Budgets have been trimmed in various ways: Author advances, except for the biggest names, have slumped sharply since the 2008 financial crash, declining by more than half, according to one recent survey. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine that the quality of manuscripts from writers who have been forced either to eat less or write faster isn\xe2\x80\x99t deteriorating. Meanwhile, spending on editing and promotion has also been pared away.'b'Things don\xe2\x80\x99t get better after the book leaves the publisher. Price cutting, led primarily by Amazon, has reduced many brick-and-mortar bookstores to rubble, depriving readers of direct interaction with booksellers. Despite some recent good news, the number of independents has been halved in the last two decades, and the chain stores that survive 'b'increasingly employ part-time, unskilled staff'b'.'b'The decline in libraries weakens another vital prop for readers. Librarians, described by the novelist Richard Powers as \xe2\x80\x9cgas attendant[s] of the mind,\xe2\x80\x9d saw a national decrease in their numbers of nearly 100,000 over the two decades to 2009. 'b'Two-thirds of public libraries'b' reported 'b'flat or decreasing budgets'b' in 2012.'b'Then there is today\xe2\x80\x99s increasingly rare bird, the professional book reviewer. Stand-alone book sections in major newspapers such as The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post have disappeared. The New York Times Book Review is now just 'b'a third of the length'b' it was in its 1970s heyday. Online reviews like The Los Angeles Review of Books and The New Inquiry are striving to fill the gap. But their rates of pay, predictably, do not rival those at the more established publications they are replacing. Cyril Connolly caustically described the book reviewer as having \xe2\x80\x9ca whole-time job with a half-time salary,\xe2\x80\x9d a job \xe2\x80\x9cin which the best in him is generally expended on the mediocre in others.\xe2\x80\x9d Today, it\xe2\x80\x99s more of a part-time job with no salary.'b'This variety of channels for the expert appraisal of books has been replaced with recommendations thrown up by online retailers\xe2\x80\x99 computers. But as with so much of the Internet, the nuance and enthusiasm of human encounters is poorly replicated by an algorithm. For more personal interactions, many have turned to social reading sites such as Goodreads or LibraryThing.'b'The growth of these sites has been phenomenal. Shortly after its purchase by Amazon in the spring of last year, Goodreads announced it had 20 million users. Whether this is an amelioration or a reflection of an increasingly atomized culture is a question that can be filed in the same drawer as Facebook friending or dating on 'b'Match.com'b'. Certainly the range of collective knowledge in pools of this size is incontestable. But it derives from self-selecting volunteers whose authority is hard to gauge. And though the overall network is vast, recommendations are generally exchanged within tight circles of friends. This results in another typical Internet characteristic: the \xe2\x80\x9cmirroring\xe2\x80\x9d of existing tastes at the expense of discovering anything new.'b'THERE are many who will not mourn the displacement of literary culture\xe2\x80\x99s traditional elite, dominated as it was by white, middle-aged men of comfortable means and conservative taste. Jeff Bezos, the C.E.O. of Amazon, aimed to exploit such disillusion with the old ways when announcing the launch of Kindle Direct. The self-publishing e-book program would, he claimed, produce \xe2\x80\x9ca more diverse book culture\xe2\x80\x9d with \xe2\x80\x9cno expert gatekeepers saying \xe2\x80\x98sorry, that will never work.\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d But to express discomfort at the attrition of expert opinion is not to defend the previous order\xe2\x80\x99s prerogatives. Nor is it elitist to suggest that making the values and personnel of such professional hierarchies more representative is preferable to dispensing with them.'b'On the desolate beach that is the lot of the contemporary book reader, the footprints of one companion can still be found. They belong to the writer, who needs the reader not just to pay her or his wages but also to give meaning to their words. As John Cheever put it: \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t write without a reader. It\xe2\x80\x99s precisely like a kiss \xe2\x80\x94 you can\xe2\x80\x99t do it alone.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The troubling thought occurs, however, that this last remaining cohabitant may also be about to depart the island. With falling advances, writing is evermore dominated by people who don\xe2\x80\x99t need it to earn a living: Tenured academics and celebrities spring to mind. For these groups, burnishing a r\xc3\xa9sum\xc3\xa9 or marketing a brand is often as important as satisfying the reader.'b'And then there are the hobbyists, those for whom writing is primarily an act of self-expression. This past November, National Novel Writing Month (Nanowrimo) encouraged more than 300,000 participants to produce a novel in 30 days. It would be churlish to gainsay the right of the legions taking up \xe2\x80\x9cnoveling,\xe2\x80\x9d as Nanowrimo describes it, to exercise their creative selves. But such endeavors are not much helping readers. Indeed, to the extent that they expand the mind-boggling proliferation of new titles being published (more than 300,000 in 2012), they are adding to the problem.'b'Faced with a dizzying array of choices and receiving little by way of expert help in making selections, book buyers today are deciding to play it safe, opting to join either the ever-larger audiences for blockbusters or the minuscule readerships of a vast range of specialist titles. In this bifurcation, the mid-list, publishing\xe2\x80\x99s experimental laboratory, is being abandoned.'b'THIS much can be said for Bill de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s inauguration, which featured a concentration of left-wing agitprop unseen since the last time Pete Seeger occupied a stage alone: If the waning years of Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s presidency are going to be defined by a liberal crusade against income inequality, there\xe2\x80\x99s no more fitting place to kick it off than New York City.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s fitting because a glance at New York\xe2\x80\x99s ever-richer 1 percent, its priced-out middle class and its majestic skyscrapers soaring above pockets of squalor makes it easy enough to understand left-wing populism\xe2\x80\x99s appeal.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s fitting, as well, because New York also illustrates the tensions that make the war on inequality hard to wage, and suggests reasons to question whether it\xe2\x80\x99s actually worth fighting in the first place.'b'Those tensions start with the fact that despite a run of non-Democratic mayors, the five boroughs have hardly been a laboratory for Social Darwinists in the last two decades. Instead, de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctale of two cities,\xe2\x80\x9d one ever-richer and one struggling to keep up, has been unspooling in a liberal metropolis in a liberal state surrounded by a mostly liberal region, where many obvious anti-inequality 'b'policy levers'b' are already 'b'being pulled'b'.'b'This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean inequality is immune to policy responses, especially when you leap to the national level \xe2\x80\x94 a leap, of course, that liberal populists want to see de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s message make.'b'But the new mayor\xe2\x80\x99s political coalition also provides a clue as to why a comprehensive policy response may never actually be tried. In his primary upset, de Blasio enjoyed strong backing from the city\xe2\x80\x99s college-educated upper middle class. He even did slightly better among voters making between $100,000 and $200,000 than he did among the poor.'b'In a way, this shows the potential breadth of populism\xe2\x80\x99s appeal. But while upper-middle-class voters are happy to support higher taxes on 1 percenters \xe2\x80\x94 not least because they\xe2\x80\x99re tired of trying to compete with them for schools and real estate \xe2\x80\x94 they don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily want a program that would require their own taxes to rise substantially.'b'And this is a problem for the populist left, because to build the kind of welfare state \xe2\x80\x94 European, Scandinavian \xe2\x80\x94 that seems to really level incomes, you need lots of tax dollars from the non-rich. Yet the current Democratic coalition has been built on a promise to never raise taxes on anyone making under $250,000 ... or maybe $400,000 ... or possibly $500,000, the threshold de Blasio chose.'b'That promise has made it safe for many well-off voters, in New York and elsewhere, to cast votes for liberal populism. But it\xe2\x80\x99s also made it impossible for the populist war on inequality to ever actually be won.'b'But should we even want that war to be fought? Here, too, New York\xe2\x80\x99s experience raises difficult questions for egalitarians. Of all the arguments for reducing inequality, the most potent is the claim that a more unequal society is one with fewer opportunities to rise, and that a hardening of class lines in America is intimately connected to growing fortunes at the top.'b'This makes some intuitive sense, and there is international data \xe2\x80\x94 dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cthe Great Gatsby curve\xe2\x80\x9d by the economist Alan Krueger \xe2\x80\x94 suggesting a link between inequality and immobility. But within the United States, that link turns out to be much less readily apparent.'b'Using data from an ambitious research project on social mobility, the Manhattan Institute\xe2\x80\x99s Scott Winship and the Heritage Foundation\xe2\x80\x99s Donald Schneider recently tried to recreate the \xe2\x80\x9cGatsby curve\xe2\x80\x9d for U.S. job markets. Instead, they found little-to-no correlation between inequality and mobility across different regions of the country.'b'And New York illustrates their point, because the city\xe2\x80\x99s extreme income inequality hasn\xe2\x80\x99t led to extreme immobility. In fact, compared with nationwide trends, New Yorkers born into poverty have an above-average chance of rising into the middle class. (And New Yorkers born into affluence have an above-average chance of dropping to the bottom.)'b'Now it\xe2\x80\x99s true that whatever the link between mobility and equality, there are potential policy moves \xe2\x80\x94 an expansion of housing stock, for instance, to make expensive cities more affordable \xe2\x80\x94 that would probably address both issues at once.'b'De Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s signature proposal, universal pre-K, is a more ambiguous case. 'b'Most research indicates'b' that early childhood education doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have the benefits to children\xe2\x80\x99s prospects that its advocates suggest. But it\xe2\x80\x99s possible the program could increase the 'b'mobility of parents'b', by lowering costs and stress for two-earner and single-parent households.'b'But there\xe2\x80\x99s also a pessimistic scenario, in which the growing cost of New York\xe2\x80\x99s existing welfare state means that de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s crusade ultimately just devolves into interest-group featherbedding, in which the rich are squeezed to benefit a well-compensated public sector and preserve bureaucracies that ought to be reformed.'b'And that outcome \xe2\x80\x94 a populism that marginally inconveniences the richest without meaningfully changing life for anyone else \xe2\x80\x94 would be less a model for the post-Obama Democrats than a cautionary tale.'b''b' 'b''b''b'Biometric scanners on smartphones and tablets will soon make answering security questions a thing of the past. It is amazing how many people violate that rule, but especially in Congress and especially among the Tea Party types, where calling someone a \xe2\x80\x9cdeal maker\xe2\x80\x9d is now the ultimate put down. What makes it crazier is that in American education, innovation and commerce today, \xe2\x80\x9ccollaboration\xe2\x80\x9d is being taught and rewarded as the best way to do anything big, important and complex. Indeed, in Silicon Valley, a \xe2\x80\x9ccollaborator\xe2\x80\x9d means someone with whom you\xe2\x80\x99re building something great. In D.C., it means someone committing political treason by working with the other party. And that is why Silicon Valley is now the turbo-engine of our economy and D.C. is the dead hand.'b'To be sure, in politics compromise is not a virtue in and of itself. There are questions of true principle \xe2\x80\x94 civil rights, for instance \xe2\x80\x94 where compromise might kill the principled choice. But there has been an inflation of \xe2\x80\x9cprinciples\xe2\x80\x9d lately that is inhibiting compromise. A certain tax rate or retirement age is not a principle. It\xe2\x80\x99s an interest that needs to be balanced against others. Today, we would be best served in meeting our biggest challenges by adopting a hybrid of the best ideas of left and right \xe2\x80\x94 and the fact that we can\xe2\x80\x99t is sapping our strength.'b'For instance, on the debt/spending issue, Congress should be borrowing money at these unusually low rates to invest in a 10-year upgrade of our crumbling infrastructure (roads, bridges, telecom, ports, airports and rail lines) and in a huge funding increase for our national laboratories, research universities and institutes of health, which are the gardens for so many start-ups. Together, such an investment would stimulate sustained employment, innovation and the wealth creation to pay for it.'b'But this near-term investment should be paired with long-term entitlement reductions, defense cuts and tax reform that would be phased in gradually as the economy improves, so we do not add to the already heavy fiscal burden on our children, deprive them of future investment resources or leave our economy vulnerable to unforeseen shocks, future recessions or the stresses that are sure to come when all the baby boomers retire. President Obama has favored such a hybrid, but it was shot down by the Tea Party wing, before we could see if he could really sell it to his base.'b'We should exploit our new natural gas bounty, but only by pairing it with the highest environmental extraction rules and a national, steadily rising, renewable energy portfolio standard that would ensure that natural gas replaces coal \xe2\x80\x94 not solar, wind or other renewables. That way shale gas becomes a bridge to a cleaner energy future, not just an addiction to a less dirty, climate-destabilizing fossil fuel.'b'In some cities, teachers\xe2\x80\x99 unions really are holding up education reform. But we need to stop blaming teachers alone. We also have a parent problem: parents who do not take an interest in their children\xe2\x80\x99s schooling or set high standards. And we have a student problem: students who do not understand the connection between their skills and their life opportunities and are unwilling to work to today\xe2\x80\x99s global standards. Reform requires a hybrid of both teacher reform and a sustained \xe2\x80\x94 not just one speech \xe2\x80\x94 national campaign to challenge parents and create a culture of respect and excitement for learning. Obama has failed to use his unique bully pulpit to lead such a campaign.'b'Finally, the merger of globalization and the information-technology revolution has shrunk the basis of the old middle class \xe2\x80\x94 the high-wage, middle-skilled job. Increasingly, there are only high-wage, high-skilled jobs. This merger of globalization and I.T. has put capitalism \xe2\x80\x94 and its core engine of creative destruction \xe2\x80\x94 on steroids. That\xe2\x80\x99s why Republicans are wrong when they oppose raising minimum wages and expanding national health care. These kinds of social safety nets make the free market possible; otherwise people won\xe2\x80\x99t put up with creative destruction on steroids.\xc2\xa0'b'But it is capitalism, start-ups, risk-taking and entrepreneurship that make these safety nets affordable, which is why we need more tax incentives for start-ups, the substitutions of carbon taxes for payroll and corporate taxes, and more cuts to regulations that burden business. Unfortunately, promotion of risk-taking and risk-takers is disappearing from the Democratic Party agenda. Its energy and excitement is focused much more today on wealth redistribution than wealth creation. On immigration, Senate Democrats and Republicans forged a sensible hybrid solution, but Tea Partiers in the House are blocking it.'b'These hybrid solutions are not how to split the difference. They\xe2\x80\x99re how to make a difference. But they only get forged if Republican leaders take on the Tea Party \xe2\x80\x94 which transformed the G.O.P. into a far-right party, uninterested in governing \xe2\x80\x94 and remake the G.O.P. into a center-right party again. If that happened, I\xe2\x80\x99m certain that a second-term Obama, who is much more center-left than the ridiculous G.O.P. caricatures, would meet them in the middle. Absent that, we\xe2\x80\x99re going to drift, unable to address effectively any of our biggest challenges or opportunities.'b'THOSE of us in the pundit world tend to blather on about what happened yesterday, while often ignoring what happens every day. We stir up topics already on the agenda, but we falter at calling attention to crucial-but-neglected issues.'b'So here\xe2\x80\x99s your chance to tell us what we\xe2\x80\x99re missing. I invite readers to suggest issues that deserve more attention in 2014. Make your suggestions on my blog, 'b'nytimes.com/ontheground'b'. I hope to quote from some of your ideas in a future column.'b'My own suggestion for a systematically neglected issue: mental health. One-quarter of American adults 'b'suffer from a diagnosable mental disorder'b', including depression, anorexia, post-traumatic stress disorder and more, according to the National Institutes of Health. Such disorders are the leading cause of disability in the United States and Canada, the N.I.H. says.'b'A parent with depression. A lover who is bipolar. A child with an eating disorder. A brother who returned from war with P.T.S.D. A sister who is suicidal.'b'All across America and the world, families struggle with these issues, but people are more likely to cry quietly in bed than speak out. These mental health issues pose a greater risk to our well-being than, say, the Afghan Taliban or Al Qaeda terrorists, yet in polite society there is still something of a code of silence around these topics.'b'We in the news business have devoted vast coverage to political battles over health care, deservedly, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t delve enough into underlying mental health issues that are crucial to national well-being.'b'Indeed, when the news media do cover mental health, we do so mostly in extreme situations such as a mass shooting. That leads the public to think of mental disorders as dangerous, stigmatizing those who are mentally ill and making it harder for them to find friends or get family support.'b'In fact, says 'b'an Institute of Medicine report'b', the danger is \xe2\x80\x9cgreatly exaggerated\xe2\x80\x9d in the public mind. The report concluded: \xe2\x80\x9calthough findings of many studies suggest a link between mental illnesses and violence, the contribution of people with mental illnesses to overall rates of violence is small.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Put simply, the great majority of people who are mentally ill are not violent and do not constitute a threat \xe2\x80\x94 except, sometimes, to themselves. Every year, 38,000 'b'Americans commit suicide'b', and 90 percent of them are said to suffer from mental illness.'b'One study found that 'b'anorexia is by far the most deadly psychiatric disorder'b', partly because of greatly elevated suicide risk.'b'Mental illness is also linked to narcotics and alcoholism, homelessness, parenting problems and cycles of poverty. 'b'One study found'b' that 55 percent of American infants in poverty are raised by mothers with symptoms of depression, which impairs child rearing.'b'So if we want to tackle a broad range of social pathologies and inequities, we as a society have to break taboos about mental health. There has been progress, and news organizations can help accelerate it. But too often our coverage just aggravates the stigma and thereby encourages more silence.'b'The truth is that mental illness is not hopeless, and people recover all the time. 'b'Consider John Nash'b', the Princeton University mathematics genius who after a brilliant early career then tumbled into delusions and involuntary hospitalization \xe2\x80\x94 captured by the book and movie \xe2\x80\x9cA Beautiful Mind.\xe2\x80\x9d Nash spent decades as an obscure, mumbling presence on the Princeton campus before regaining his mental health and winning the Nobel Prize for economics.'b'Although treatments are available, we often don\xe2\x80\x99t provide care, so the mentally ill disproportionately end up in prison or on the streets.'b'One example of a cost-effective approach employs a case worker to help mentally ill people leaving a hospital or shelter as they adjust to life in the outside world. Randomized trials have found that this support dramatically reduces subsequent homelessness and hospitalization.'b''b'Researchers found'b' that the $6,300 cost per person in the program was offset by $24,000 in savings because of reduced hospitalization. In short, the program more than paid for itself. But we as a society hugely underinvest in mental health services.'b'Children in particular don\xe2\x80\x99t get treated nearly often enough. 'b'The American Journal of Psychiatry reports'b' that of children ages 6 to 17 who need mental health services, 80 percent don\xe2\x80\x99t get help. Racial and ethnic minorities are even more underserved.'b'So mental health gets my vote as a major neglected issue meriting more attention. It\xe2\x80\x99s not sexy, and it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t involve Democrats and Republicans screaming at each other, but it is a source of incalculable suffering that can be remedied.'b'Now it\xe2\x80\x99s your turn to suggest neglected issues for coverage in 2014. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be back with a report.'b'Stephen Kellert is a social ecologist and senior research scholar at 'b'Yale University\xe2\x80\x99s School of Forestry and Environmental Studies'b'. He has written several books and produced a documentary about so-called biophilic design, which goes beyond sustainability to integrate and connect people with the natural world.'b''b'READING'b' 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Making of the Atomic Bomb\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Richard Rhodes is a terrible read \xe2\x80\x94 so long, boring and difficult to understand \xe2\x80\x94 but it\xe2\x80\x99s a profound book because it really does provide the incredible detail to make you realize here they were moving the boundaries of our understanding of the universe and they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t even see the thing they were studying.'b'Good design has an atomic quality. When things are organized in a coherent and integrated way you get these emergent properties so the whole is better than the sum of its parts. The 'b'wood thrush'b' has this beautiful fluting piccolo type sound, and each wood thrush\xe2\x80\x99s song is slightly different. It\xe2\x80\x99s subtle, but you begin to appreciate that individual variability.'b''b'WATCHING'b' I like to look at buildings and landscapes that reveal a pronounced and inspired connection to nature. Go to 'b'Grand Central Station'b' in New York City and you see people taking pictures. What is so appealing? Look closely and you will notice the natural materials, the constellations on the ceilings, even the fixtures and lights all have plantlike forms that look like leaves and ferns and vines. You can also see it in very well-designed spaces that aren\xe2\x80\x99t as well known. You see this fractal geometry, which you see in nature, that variation on a theme like a snowflake or seashell. They are recognizable and repeated time after time but not in the same way.'b''b'FOLLOWING'b' 'b'Children and Nature Network\xe2\x80\x99s website'b' is of great interest to me. They are called Baldies, which is a cross between an Angus and Hereford. As long as I\xe2\x80\x99m going to be a meat eater, I\xe2\x80\x99d much rather know where my meat is coming from and that the animals have been humanely raised or humanely shot. I don\xe2\x80\x99t mind telling people they are eating Strawberry, which is the name of the most recent steer we slaughtered. I have a picture of him in my mind and he was the sweetest, loveliest animal. He had a great life until it was over. He tasted great.'b'FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. \xe2\x80\x94 WE don\xe2\x80\x99t get any say about the kind of world we\xe2\x80\x99re born into \xe2\x80\x94 about whether it\xe2\x80\x99s prepared for the likes of us, whether it will open its arms. Hal Faulkner certainly didn\xe2\x80\x99t get the world he deserved. It was needlessly cruel to him, senselessly judgmental. For the most part, he made peace with that.'b'But over the last few months, with cancer spreading fast through his body and time running out, his thoughts turned to one aspect of that landscape that he could perhaps revisit, one wrinkle he might be able to revise, a wrong he had a chance of righting before his death.'b'Back in 1956, when he was 22, he was discharged from the Marines after more than three years of proud service. There were no real blots on his record. No complaints of incompetence or laziness or insubordination. There was only this: A man with whom Hal had spent some off-duty time informed Hal\xe2\x80\x99s commanding officer that Hal was gay. The commanding officer suspected that this was true and, on that basis, determined that Hal had to go. The discharge was classified as \xe2\x80\x9cother than honorable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt wrecked me,\xe2\x80\x9d Hal told me when I visited him on Friday at his home here on the 16th floor of a high-rise with a panoramic view of the Atlantic. The morning was gloriously sunny, but tears streamed down his cheeks. Although more than half a century has passed since that harsh judgment \xe2\x80\x94 he\xe2\x80\x99s 79 now \xe2\x80\x94 it has always stayed with him, a tight, stubborn knot of sadness and anger.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey gave up on me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, referring to the Marines. \xe2\x80\x9cI never forget it.\xe2\x80\x9d He was haunted in particular by those three words \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cother than honorable\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and wanted more than anything to have them excised from his epitaph. That became his dying wish: that those words not outlive him.'b'Before federal law was changed in 2011, more than 110,000 gay, lesbian and bisexual people were discharged from the United States military over time because of their sexual orientation. And until the 1990s, when the policy tweak known as \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Ask Don\xe2\x80\x99t Tell\xe2\x80\x9d vaguely softened the prohibition against gays in the armed services, it was common for such discharges to be dishonorable ones that barred gay veterans from receiving any benefits and sometimes disqualified them from civilian jobs they later sought.'b'But now that the military accepts gays, there is also a process that permits those who were dishonorably discharged to appeal for reclassifications of those dismissals as honorable. A military spokesman said last week that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how many veterans had sought to take advantage of it, or with what success. But Hal caught wind of it, and knew that he had to try.'b'He grew up on a cattle ranch in northern Florida, in a strict Southern Baptist family. He was one of eight children. His father died when he was 7, and his family struggled financially afterward. Although Hal (a nickname for Alfred) graduated from high school, college wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in the cards.'b'He enlisted in 1953 and attended boot camp in South Carolina from June to August, \xe2\x80\x9cthe hottest months of the year,\xe2\x80\x9d as he said in an email in September to OutServe-SLDN, an advocacy group for gay service members. He was telling them his story in the hopes of rallying them to his cause.'b'He rose in the Marines from private first class to corporal and then to sergeant, and he landed a plum assignment in the Philippines. \xe2\x80\x9cI would have ascended to the top,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be what I wanted to be.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He prospered nonetheless. In a company that sold heavy construction and road-making equipment, he worked his way up to an executive sales position. \xe2\x80\x9cI helped build Walt Disney World,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'But he grew increasingly conflicted about his hand in paving so much of Florida and switched courses, joining a firm that made tools and technology for guarding against environmental degradation.'b'He lived well: expensive cars, world travel, a collection of Native American art.'b'But the bigotry that ended his military career followed him beyond that point, and so did the fear of it. He lost another treasured job, he said, because of his sexual orientation. And from the 1950s through at least the 1970s, he felt that financial security and success hinged on a certain degree of secrecy. Had he been more open about being gay, he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be here today. I\xe2\x80\x99d probably be on the street.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t until 2005 that he finally brought Charles, his longtime partner and \xe2\x80\x9cthe love of my life,\xe2\x80\x9d to a big family gathering. A few years later, Charles died, and Hal now lives alone, with round-the-clock help from a home health care attendant.'b'When he received a diagnosis of cancer in his lungs, liver and adrenal glands a year ago, he was given about six months to live. He\xe2\x80\x99s at least 50 pounds thinner than he once was and moves through his apartment on a tiny scooter. He\xe2\x80\x99s almost deaf, his speech is labored and his thoughts are sometimes confused. To piece together his story, I relied heavily on two nieces who visit him regularly, Michelle and Deborah, and on Anne Brooksher-Yen, the New York lawyer who took on his discharge appeal.'b'The case came to her only two months ago, when doctors were saying that Hal might have only weeks left. It arrived in a letter in mid-December, and she traveled all the way to Fort Lauderdale for a gathering on Friday afternoon at which the letter was presented to Hal.'b'JOHN GILLESPIE, a member of OutServe-SLDN\xe2\x80\x99s board of directors, traveled here, too, from Mississippi, and he arranged for two local Marines, in uniform, to be on hand to congratulate Hal, who\xe2\x80\x99d been told what the letter said and would now get a special moment to savor it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe lived his entire adult life with this shame and this stain on his honor,\xe2\x80\x9d John said to me, explaining why he insisted on creating that moment. \xe2\x80\x9cThe world has changed so much that with the stroke of a pen, that stain and that shame are gone.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'At the gathering, in a penthouse apartment a few floors above Hal\xe2\x80\x99s, he was given a red Marine cap, but when he tried to put it on, he screamed. There are painful nodules on his scalp from the rapidly spreading cancer.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey hurt so bad,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to John, Anne, his two nieces and several friends from the building. He thanked his nieces. He thanked the Marines. He even thanked people in the room whom he had no reason to thank.'b'Someone went off to mix him a Scotch-and-soda, and he finally gave in. He sobbed.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s often said that a man doesn\xe2\x80\x99t cry,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a Marine and I am a man. So please forgive me.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His remarks hung there, because he\xe2\x80\x99d used the present tense. 'b'Am'b' a Marine. And because he was saying he was sorry, this veteran whose country owed him an apology for too long.'b'BILL BRATTON\xe2\x80\x99S biggest problem right now might not be stop-and-frisk.'b'It might be stop-and-sulk.'b'Given a new mayor who catapulted into office by castigating the police, given a City Council that passed two punitive bills related to the police and racial profiling, given the prospect of federal oversight on stop-and-frisk, given the overshadowing of the stunning drop in crime by the open sore of racial insensitivity, New York police may decide to engage in, as police call it, de-policing.'b'If morale sinks too low, one former New York City police official suggests, officers may not go after criminals \xe2\x80\x9cin the most aggressive fashion.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRight now, police in New York are not happy,\xe2\x80\x9d the new commissioner conceded in his conference room at police headquarters\xc2\xa0Friday\xc2\xa0evening, surrounded by walls of video screens tracking crime around the city. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re frustrated because their good work really did get banged around in the campaign.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There was a record decline in crime and\xc2\xa0a record increase in tourism, Bratton said, and \xe2\x80\x9ccops aren\xe2\x80\x99t feeling the residual benefit of that.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said \xe2\x80\x9cthe most angst\xe2\x80\x9d was being caused by a City Council bill expanding the ability to sue over racial profiling by officers, because police see it as a risk to themselves and their families.'b'He said New York has \xe2\x80\x9ca crisis of confidence on the part of the cops about what it is that we can do\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ca crisis of confidence in the public about what the cops have been doing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Bratton, always very popular with the police who work for him, has been through it before. I hesitate to describe it as intransigence because I really do believe that both Mayor Bloomberg and Commissioner Kelly, both good men, both committed to keeping this city safe, really deeply believed that the reason crime was going down, the reason there was less gun violence, the reason there were fewer guns being taken off the street, was because of the increasing numbers of stop-question-frisk.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd eventually because of that unwillingness to step back from that posture, it became a rallying cry for a number of the mayoral candidates, including Mayor de Blasio, who was able to most successfully use it as a platform.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Police, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cneed clear guidelines, clear guardrails, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t have that right now.\xe2\x80\x9d They are comfortable re-engaging, he said, when they have those guardrails.'b'In Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s final years as mayor, Bratton said, \xe2\x80\x9cCops themselves felt that they were in a\xc2\xa0no-win position.\xc2\xa0They had an administration, Mayor Bloomberg, Commissioner Kelly, who were demanding more and more and more.\xc2\xa0And the cops themselves felt, you know, it\xe2\x80\x99s too much. And the community was saying it\xe2\x80\x99s too much. It\xe2\x80\x99s like a doctor giving too much chemotherapy: \xe2\x80\x98Doctor I\xe2\x80\x99m feeling better but you\xe2\x80\x99re giving me all this chemo and I\xe2\x80\x99m feeling worse again.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'In L.A. in 2002, Bratton faced a crisis where morale was low after a corruption scandal and after the city was crowned the murder capital of America, and an inspector general was on hand for oversight. \xe2\x80\x9cWe got the cops out of their cars,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey got back to making arrests. Now his mission is to back off \xe2\x80\x94 to rein in the force enough so that minorities do not feel hounded. The last time he was Top Cop, his boss was Mr. Law and Order, and Bratton was the tip of Rudy Giuliani\xe2\x80\x99s spear. This time, he\xe2\x80\x99s working for a liberal populist mayor who got elected thrashing the excesses of stop-and-frisk, and he\xe2\x80\x99s supervising police officers who are trepidatious about working for a man who won office by stoking the fires of public opinion against them. (Dante de Blasio did a potent ad for his father noting that he might be a likely candidate for stop-and-frisk.)'b'Trying to help Christine Quinn (tepidly) and stop de Blasio during the mayoral primary, Michael Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s aides fed the paranoia that under de Blasio, New York would flame into \xe2\x80\x9cBonfire of the Vanities.\xe2\x80\x9d Bratton must be the affirmative answer to all the jittery New Yorkers asking \xe2\x80\x9cIs it safe?,\xe2\x80\x9d fearing that fiends are going to start climbing out of manholes if the new mayor goes all flower power on crime. Skeptics on both sides of the spectrum, from Al Sharpton to former Mayor Bloomberg, suggest the changes on stop-and-frisk may be cosmetic.'b'On the eve of leaving office, Bloomberg, defensive about the scar on his legacy, noted to Capital New York that in L.A. Bratton \xe2\x80\x94 considered the godfather of the sort of aggressive policing tools that have come under fire \xe2\x80\x94 was just as much a proponent of stop-and-frisk as Kelly was. \xe2\x80\x9cBratton did more stop and frisks per capita than Kelly did,\xe2\x80\x9d Bloomberg said. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll call it \xe2\x80\x98frisk and stop\xe2\x80\x99 instead of stop-and-frisk.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Bratton mulled that his specialty had been coming in to lead police departments \xe2\x80\x9cin total crisis\xe2\x80\x9d and, in a way, he violated his own philosophy by following someone so successful.'b'But he believes he can resolve the problems with stop-and-frisk and shaky morale. \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t come back to New York to fail,\xe2\x80\x9d he said flatly, dapper as ever in a Herm\xc3\xa8s tie with elephants and a blue Rolex watch his wife gave him.'b'Bratton said he wants to bring in a language expert, as he did back in 1994, to train police on the best ways to use language to \xe2\x80\x9ccalm down incidents\xe2\x80\x9d by being respectful rather than ratchet them up by being confrontational.'b'Noting that you have to use stop-and-frisk \xe2\x80\x9cwith skill,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9cWe have an expression in policing that it\xe2\x80\x99s not the use of force that gets cops in trouble, it\xe2\x80\x99s the use of language.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said an officer who says, \xe2\x80\x9cSir, can I speak to you?,\xe2\x80\x9d rather than \xe2\x80\x9cHey, you, get over here,\xe2\x80\x9d will be more productive.
