JACOBSON'b'\nExecutive Director, Center for'b'\nScience in the Public Interest'b'\nWashington, Dec. 31, 2013'b''b''b''b'FOR all the talk of New York\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctale of two cities\xe2\x80\x9d economic divide, last week Mayor Bill de Blasio took charge of a local economy that has far outperformed the rest of the country since the financial collapse \xe2\x80\x94 and not just in a small corner of Manhattan, but across the city. Driven by the expansion of the technology and information sector, New York City today has more private-sector jobs than during the 2007-8 peak of the finance-driven boom years.'b'New York has, over the last decade, become a tech city to rival San Francisco, Boston and Seattle. And it has done so by moving away from its old reliance on the finance and legal sectors, and the industries like hospitality that rely on them. The challenge for Mr. de Blasio is continuing that trend, and making sure all New Yorkers benefit from it.'b'Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, can justifiably boast about New York\xe2\x80\x99s rise to prominence as a \xe2\x80\x9cdigital city.\xe2\x80\x9d On his watch, the technology and information sector has become the city\xe2\x80\x99s second-most-powerful economic engine, after financial services. New York now has 10 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s jobs in the \xe2\x80\x9cInternet publishing and web search portal\xe2\x80\x9d industry, up from just over 6 percent in 2007.'b'Surprisingly, over the past couple of years, the city\xe2\x80\x99s minority populations have been among the main beneficiaries of this boom. Since 2010, the number of blacks working in computer and mathematical occupations \xe2\x80\x94 the Census Bureau\xe2\x80\x99s term for tech-related jobs \xe2\x80\x94 in the city has risen by 19.7 percent, based on a preliminary analysis of new census data.'b'Over the same stretch, the number of Hispanics in such occupations in New York City has risen by 25.4 percent. By comparison, non-Hispanic whites in computer and mathematical occupations experienced just a 6.4 percent gain since 2010.'b'The rapid growth of minorities in New York tech jobs reflects, in part, the soaring number of tech degrees earned by minorities in recent years. For example, bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degrees in computer and information sciences granted to Hispanic students have risen by more than 40 percent nationally over the past three years, according to data from the National Center for Education Statistics. That supply is then sucked up by the tightness of the city\xe2\x80\x99s technology and information labor markets, which has forced local employers to reach out beyond the usual sources.'b'The boom has also produced benefits across all five boroughs: Private-sector jobs in the outlying boroughs rose by 9 percent from mid-2008 to mid-2013, while private-sector jobs in Manhattan are up only 3 percent over the same stretch. This pattern is the reverse of the financial boom years, when Manhattan generated jobs at a much faster pace than the rest of the city.'b'Moreover, despite worries that the city has not yet spawned a Google or a Microsoft, New York\xe2\x80\x99s strength as a digital city continues to grow. Based on data from the Conference Board, an analysis by the Progressive Policy Institute shows that ads for computer and mathematical jobs in New York rose by 6.8 percent in the first 11 months of 2013 compared with a year earlier, and compared with just 4.0 percent nationwide.'b'Instead, the true weakness in the city\xe2\x80\x99s economy right now lies in the leisure and hospitality industry, which employs almost 400,000 workers in the city. The number of jobs has been rising, but real pay has fallen, perhaps because of continuing weakness in the financial and legal sector, which generates so much demand for hotels and restaurants. These real wage declines undercut gains in the rest of the local economy.'b'What lessons does this have for the new mayor? New York\xe2\x80\x99s gains came, in part, from the aggressive efforts of the Bloomberg administration to stimulate the technology and information sector. These included funding tech incubators; the \xe2\x80\x9cMade in NY\xe2\x80\x9d marketing campaign to support small tech companies; the rapid extension of broadband access across the city; the city\xe2\x80\x99s broad-reaching Open Data initiative, which makes city data available to the public and software developers; and the selection of Cornell and Technion, the Israel Institute of Technology, to open a huge new campus on Roosevelt Island.'b'To achieve the laudable objectives laid out in his inaugural speech, most notably narrowing the income gap, Mr. de Blasio should continue these policies. The technology and information boom needs to be encouraged: It is creating jobs for all corners of the city and helping to reduce the excessive dependence on finance and real estate. That should make the city\xe2\x80\x99s economy \xe2\x80\x94 and tax revenues \xe2\x80\x94 less volatile in the future.'b'In his inaugural address, Mr. de Blasio correctly pointed to the need for better education for all New York children. That, too, needs to be part of a continued tech-centric agenda: to improve schools and maintain the city\xe2\x80\x99s tech advantage, the new mayor also must ramp up the attention to tech and related fields in the city\xe2\x80\x99s schools.'b'The main path to reducing inequality and broadening the city\xe2\x80\x99s prosperity will be better education and training to help New Yorkers prepare for the jobs of the future, and if Mr. de Blasio successfully addresses that issue, his legacy as a great mayor will be secure.'b'For a while he didn\xe2\x80\x99t move. And it\xe2\x80\x99s no little bug.'b'In the age of rail, luxury hotels mimicked European palaces. When rich people arrived at their destination, they wanted to be treated like nobility.'b'Then in the age of the jet, a new sort of hotel emerged, sleek Hiltons and Sheratons. These hotels offered the comfort of familiarity. You could go around the world and the hotels were largely the same. They were efficient and bland, offering quality service and ease of movement. A business traveler could stay in one of these hotels for days and barely notice anything about the place.'b'The computer age has brought yet another new kind of hotel: the mass boutique.'b'Boutique hotels started in the early 1980s in London, with Blakes, and in San Francisco, with the Bedford. These hotels had entirely different goals than the big hotels at the time. Instead of offering familiarity, they offered difference. Instead of offering beige, they offered edginess, art, emotion and a dollop of pretension.'b'The first boutique hotels were founded by entrepreneurs who seemed more like rock producers or psych professors than corporate executives. Chip Conley founded Joie de Vivre Hospitality in the Bay Area when he was 26. He designed his hotel Phoenix around the personality of Rolling Stone magazine. He later organized his business strategy around Abraham Maslow\xe2\x80\x99s hierarchy of needs.'b'At the bottom of the pyramid, Conley\xe2\x80\x99s hotels offer a comfortable bed, but at the top of the pyramid, Conley says that his hotels offer \xe2\x80\x9cidentity refreshment\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmass therapy.\xe2\x80\x9d As he writes in his book \xe2\x80\x9cPeak,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIf we get it right at our boutique hotels, we don\xe2\x80\x99t just satisfy our guests\xe2\x80\x99 physiological, safety, social and esteem needs: We bring them an awareness of self-actualization.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Boutiques cater to the sort of affluent consumer who is produced by the information economy, which rewards education with money. This is a consumer who is prouder of his cultural discernment than his corporate success; who feels interested in, rather than intimidated by, a hotel room stuffed with cultural signifiers \xe2\x80\x94 cerulean sofas or Steichen photos. Boutique hotels hold up a flattering mirror. When guests arrive, they are supposed to feel like they are entering an edgy community of unconventional, discerning people like themselves.'b'In an age when Hotels.com and Travelocity turn hotel rooms into commodities, these are customers who are willing to pay extra, sometimes a lot extra, for a hotel with sensibility. The boutique Soho Grand in New York is currently offering rooms at $339 a night. The Hilton Garden Inn, a very adequate hotel a couple of blocks away, is charging $139.'b'Painfully hip boutique hotels used to seem like a fad, but they\xe2\x80\x99ve spread and spread. Over the past few years, they have gone mass. Starwood has planted large, boutiquey W hotels on five continents. Hyatt has Andaz. And 'b'as Brooks Barnes reported'b' in The Times\xe2\x80\x99s most recent Sunday Business section, Marriott is creating a chain of mass boutiques, called Edition. When Marriott enters the boutique business, everybody has entered the boutique business.'b'It seems as if there is an endless supply of middle-class consumers who have boutique identities and aspirations, especially among people in their 20s. Consumers now use hotels differently. They bring their laptops down to the lobby rather than working in their rooms. Fewer people bother to unpack their bags. Therefore, room desks and closets are less important, but having a happening lobby scene is more important. People need a civic space where they can have their contiguous but individualized iPad experiences.'b'Boutique hotels are, on one level, kind of ridiculous. They are almost invariably too dark throughout, making it hard to read. The bed is often too low. The bathroom door is sometimes a flimsy sliding shutter, sacrificing privacy for style.'b'But they do exemplify a shift in the consumer market, which you might call the shift from the lima bean economy to the edamame economy. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to forget how much more boring the marketplace was a few decades ago \xe2\x80\x94 more boring cuisine, more boring restaurants, more boring hotels. Recently, there\xe2\x80\x99s been a creative brand explosion, to go along with nichification and segmentation. Companies are much more interested in creating emotional arousal. Hotels, sneakers, iced tea and even ice cream is now marketed to people on the basis of psychographic profiles and the result is a profusion of unusual products and distinctive experiences. Consumers have been educated by the market and now the median level of cultural competence is much higher.'b'A basic rule of happiness is don\xe2\x80\x99t buy things; buy experiences. The market has taken one commodity product after another and turned it into an emotional experience \xe2\x80\x94 even hotel stays. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how you measure how much better off we are because of that, but we are significantly better off. The world\xe2\x80\x99s a sweeter place when, for an extra 200 bucks a night, you can lodge like Afrojack.'b'On Wednesday, New York City Council members are expected to choose a speaker to lead them and, when necessary, unite them as a counterweight and an alternative voice to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s. Andrew Cuomo of New York is set to use his executive powers to loosen restrictions on the use of marijuana for medical purposes. The Legislature, where medical marijuana bills have stalled repeatedly in the State Senate, ought to expand and strengthen the governor\xe2\x80\x99s effort through appropriate legislation.'b'As 'b'reported by The Times'b' on Sunday, Mr. Cuomo, who had long resisted legalizing medical marijuana, is planning to announce a policy on Wednesday that would allow marijuana to be used to treat severe illnesses, like cancer, glaucoma and other serious diseases to be identified by the State Health Department.'b'In many cancer patients, marijuana can alleviate the nausea caused by chemotherapy. The drug is also potentially useful in patients suffering from multiple sclerosis, pediatric brain seizures, and AIDS, among other debilitating illnesses. It would be available in only 20 hospitals across the state.'b'Some 20 states and the District of Columbia already allow medical uses of marijuana, so New York, long a holdout, would be joining a national trend.'b'One concern about Mr. Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s plan is that it may be too restrictive. Twenty hospitals, yet to be designated but scattered around this large state, may not provide sufficient access to patients who need the therapy. And the strains of marijuana that can be used may not be best for many patients.'b'A bill introduced in the Assembly by Richard Gottfried, of Manhattan, and in the Senate by Diane Savino, of Staten Island, both Democrats, would allow a wider range of organizations to grow, process and dispense medical marijuana, under monitoring by the State Health Department, for patients certified as eligible. It would also allow the use of strains specifically designed for the needs and conditions of particular patients. Mr. Cuomo ought to support this legislation.'b'The Federal Communications Commission ended a grave injustice last fall when it prohibited price-gouging by the private companies that provide interstate telephone service for prison and jail inmates. Thanks to the F.C.C. order, which takes effect next month, poor families no longer have to choose between paying for basic essentials and speaking to a relative behind bars. The commission now needs to be on the lookout for \xe2\x80\x94 and crack down on, if necessary \xe2\x80\x94 similar abuses involving newer communication technologies like person-to-person video chat, email and voice mail.'b'Research shows that inmates who keep in touch with their families have a better chance of fitting in back home once released. Before the recent ruling, a 15-minute interstate telephone call from prison could easily cost a family as much as $17. The cost was partly driven by a \xe2\x80\x9ccommission\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a legalized kickback \xe2\x80\x94 that telephone companies paid to state corrections departments. The commissions were calculated as a percentage of telephone revenue, or a fixed upfront fee, or a combination of both.'b'State prison officials and phone companies said the extra charges were necessary to pay for security screening. But this argument was discredited years ago in New York State, which has outlawed the kickback system and requires its prison phone company to provide service at the lowest possible cost to inmates and their families. Federal prisons also allow inmates to place calls cheaply to a preregistered, approved list of phone numbers.'b'The F.C.C. ruled that rates and fees may not include the \xe2\x80\x9ccommission\xe2\x80\x9d payments that providers pay to prisons. It also set a cap for interstate calls: 25 cents a minute for collect calls and 21 cents a minute for prepaid and debit calls. And it required the companies to base charges on the actual costs of providing service.'b''b'An analysis'b' provided last month to the commission by the Prison Policy Initiative, a Massachusetts research group, urged similar rules for video visitation, email, voice mail and other systems. It said that for-profit video visitation systems (allowing families and inmates to talk using, in some instances, personal computers outside the prison and video terminals inside) are being \xe2\x80\x9cdriven by the same perverse incentives that caused market failure in the correctional telephone industry.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Absent regulation, prisons and phone companies will simply use the video chats to get around the price caps on interstate calls.'b'Whatever the technology, gouging prison inmates and their families is both unfair and counterproductive, weakening family ties that could be critical to an inmate\xe2\x80\x99s adjustment to the world beyond bars.'b'The most important book I read in 2013 was Jaron Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Who Owns the Future?'b'\xe2\x80\x9d Though it was published in May, I came to it late in the year. But this turned out to be fortuitous timing. With unemployment seemingly stalled out at around 7 percent in the aftermath of the Great Recession, with the leak of thousands of National Security Agency documents making news almost daily, with the continuing stories about the erosion of privacy in the digital economy, \xe2\x80\x9cWho Owns the Future?\xe2\x80\x9d puts forth a kind of universal theory that ties all these things together. It also puts forth some provocative, unconventional ideas for ensuring that the inevitable dominance of software in every corner of society will be healthy instead of harmful.'b'Lanier has an unusual authority to criticize the digital economy: He was there, more or less, at the creation. Among (many) other things, he founded the first company to sell virtual reality products. Another of his start-ups was sold to Google. As a consultant, he has had assignments with \xe2\x80\x9cWal-Mart, Fannie Mae, major banks and hedge funds,\xe2\x80\x9d as he notes in \xe2\x80\x9cWho Owns the Future?\xe2\x80\x9d But unlike most of his fellow technologists, he eventually came to feel that the rise of digital networks was no panacea.'b'On the contrary: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat I came away with from having access to these varied worlds was a realization that they were all remarkably similar,\xe2\x80\x9d he writes. \xe2\x80\x9cThe big players often gained benefits from digital networks to an amazing degree, but they were also constrained, even imprisoned, by the same dynamics.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Over time, the same network efficiencies that had given them their great advantages would become the instrument of their failures. In the financial services industry, it led to the financial crisis. In the case of Wal-Mart, its adoption of technology to manage its supply chain at first reaped great benefits, but over time it cost competitors and suppliers hundreds of thousands of jobs, thus \xe2\x80\x9cgradually impoverishing its own customer base,\xe2\x80\x9d as Lanier put it to me.'b'The N.S.A.? It developed computer technology that could monitor the entire world \xe2\x80\x94 and, in the process, lost control of the contractors it employed. As for Facebook, Google, Twitter, Amazon et al., well, in Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s view, it\xe2\x80\x99s only a matter of time before their advantages, too, disintegrate.'b'There are two additional components to Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s thesis. The first is that the digital economy has done as much as any single thing to hollow out the middle class. (When I asked him about the effect of globalization, he said that globalization was \xe2\x80\x9cjust one form of network efficiency.\xe2\x80\x9d See what I mean about a universal theory?) His great example here is Kodak and Instagram. At its height, writes Lanier \xe2\x80\x9cKodak employed more than 140,000 people.\xe2\x80\x9d Yes, Kodak made plenty of mistakes, but look at what is replacing it: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen Instagram was sold to Facebook for a billion dollars in 2012, 'b'it employed only 13 people'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Which leads nicely to Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s final big point: that the value of these new companies comes from us. \xe2\x80\x9cInstagram isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth a billion dollars just because those 13 employees are extraordinary,\xe2\x80\x9d he writes. \xe2\x80\x9cInstead, its value comes from the millions of users who contribute to the network without being paid for it.\xe2\x80\x9d He adds, \xe2\x80\x9cNetworks need a great number of people to participate in them to generate significant value. But when they have them, only a small number of people get paid. This has the net effect of centralizing wealth and limiting overall economic growth.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus, in Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s view, is income inequality also partly a consequence of the digital economy.'b'It is Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s radical idea that 'b'people should get paid'b' whenever their information is used. He envisions a different kind of digital economy, in which creators of content \xe2\x80\x94 whether a blog post or a Facebook photograph \xe2\x80\x94 would receive micropayments whenever that content was used. A digital economy that appears to give things away for free \xe2\x80\x94 in return for being able to invade the privacy of its customers for commercial gain \xe2\x80\x94 isn\xe2\x80\x99t free at all, he argues.'b'Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s ideas raise as many questions as they answer, and he makes no pretense to having it all figured out. \xe2\x80\x9cI know some of this will turn out to be wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I just don\xe2\x80\x99t know which part.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Still his ideas about reformulating the economy \xe2\x80\x94 creating what he calls a \xe2\x80\x9chumanistic economy\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 offer much food for thought. Lanier wants to create a dynamic where digital networks expand the pie rather than shrink it, and rebuild the middle class instead of destroying it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf Google and Facebook were smart,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthey would want to enrich their own customers.\xe2\x80\x9d So far, he adds, Silicon Valley has made \xe2\x80\x9cthe stupid choice\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 to grow their businesses at the expense of their own customers.'b'Lanier\xe2\x80\x99s message is that it can\xe2\x80\x99t last. And it won\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94  Nigeria is arguably the worst run of the world\xe2\x80\x99s seven most populated countries. Despite earning hundreds of billions of dollars in oil revenue over the past decade, it is expected by 2015, by some calculations, to have the second-most destitute people in the world after India. But its largest city, Lagos, which until recently was known as one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most difficult cities to govern, seems to have turned a corner.'b'Even though it remains a slum-ridden and largely impoverished metropolis, with an exploding population estimated at 21 million (of Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s 170 million people), it has seen steady improvement in its governance for over a decade. The government has enhanced public transportation, cleaned up streets, upgraded the business environment and bettered the lives of its inhabitants.'b'So Nigeria, of all places, may be pointing the way to a strategy by which fragile states might begin to succeed: Devolve more power to cities from their corrupt and overcentralized national governments. At least in democracies, the cities have promise because their elected politicians face pressure to deliver specific services to their constituents. In the central governments, which are more remote, there is too much power and wealth to be grabbed by dysfunctional politicians and their cronies, and too little direct accountability.'b'The emergence of fragile states is one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most pressing problems. Such states, which include Nigeria, Iraq and Yemen, contain a rising number of the world\xe2\x80\x99s poor (half of the world\xe2\x80\x99s people who live on less than $1.25 a day will be in fragile states by 2015, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) and contribute disproportionately to the world\xe2\x80\x99s instability and terrorism. They have become a major focus of international aid efforts, but it has proved very difficult to improve governance there.'b'The turnaround in Lagos can be traced to 1999, when Nigeria returned to democracy and the city began holding regular elections. For the first time since independence, Lagos was able to re-elect its own leaders, or turn them out of office. And while national elections became a mud fight between elites to control the state\xe2\x80\x99s enormous oil wealth, local contests forced candidates to show pragmatism and competence.'b'Citizens in densely populated cities find it easier to organize themselves. And in an ethnically and religiously diverse metropolis like Lagos, politicians could not afford to pit ethnic and religious groups against one another, a problem that has long bedeviled Nigeria. Simple geography also helped the city administration. The powerful and wealthy classes are more likely to insist on better governance when their own neighborhoods are affected.'b'And unlike national politicians, local leaders know that the better they perform, the more money their city nets. The better its roads, schools and business environment, the more likely companies will pay taxes, and individuals will buy goods and services, which also contribute to the tax base. At the national level, by contrast, the great majority of the central government\xe2\x80\x99s income has little to do with government\xe2\x80\x99s performance, since about 75 percent of the national budget comes from the $50 billion a year that Nigeria collects in oil revenue.'b'Can Lagos really save Nigeria? Alone, it\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely \xe2\x80\x94 one factor is that the country\xe2\x80\x99s population is expected to continue mushrooming to 400 million by mid-century \xe2\x80\x94 but Lagos can now be the model for transferring more authority to other cities, such as Ibadan, Kano and Benin City. And they, in turn, could help to shift the polarized national politics that produce the same cadre of unaccountable elites year after year.'b'For example, if local politicians were better able to raise and regulate local taxes, they would find themselves more accountable to the population. And they would presumably establish a more welcoming local environment for business to flourish, and perhaps start a nationwide chain reaction unleashing the country\xe2\x80\x99s famous entrepreneurialism. If income levels rose, education and a rising middle class might follow. Greater affluence and aspiration, in turn, tend to act as a useful brake on population growth.'b'Elsewhere, other cities offer a similar lesson. In Medell\xc3\xadn, Colombia, the city government outshone the national government in the late 1990s by setting up a network of publicly funded business support centers, investing strategically in transportation and security, and introducing its own program of cash grants to help the poor. Cities such as Chennai and Hyderabad in India have similarly outperformed India\xe2\x80\x99s national government in promoting growth, educating children and reducing crime and poverty.'b'Can this model hold out hope for other fragile states? Countries such as the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan and Kenya all suffer from weak and dysfunctional governments, but have cities that could be the basis for a similar model of development. Regular local elections could spur significant changes in Kinshasa, Karachi and Nairobi, respectively, if the cities were granted more autonomy and the tax base was broadened to make government more dependent on local citizens and companies.'b'Almost half of the developing world\xe2\x80\x99s population now lives in cities, and rapid urbanization is expected to increase this proportion to two-thirds within a few decades, according to the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. The city is now the main driver of growth and stability across Africa, the Middle East and South Asia. And the example of Lagos shows that countries can begin to work better when their cities are well governed and thriving.'b'In other words, cities can help save countries.'b''b'\n'b'Seth D. Kaplan, 'b' a professorial lecturer in the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayed: Politics, Power and Prosperity.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b' 'b' 'b' 'b'\n'b''b'Moscow \xe2\x80\x94  Russians tend to think about politics in terms of weather-report jargon. In late December, for example, when President Vladimir Putin began to set his prisoners free, many people began asking: Is this a thaw?'b'The conclusion to that question \xe2\x80\x94 discussed over holiday dinner tables and on social networks \xe2\x80\x94 was nearly unanimous: It is not. Opinions differed only in the degree and the timing of the next big freeze.'b'This is strange, considering the formidable list of those who were granted amnesty: the former oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky; two members of the punk band Pussy Riot, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova; the 30 Greenpeace activists arrested in September during a protest against drilling in the Barents Sea; four of the young people held in detention since the May 2012 clashes between protesters and the police (the so-called Bolotnaya Case); the teacher Ilya Farber, charged with bribery; and thousands of less-known people, including minors, war veterans, pregnant women and mothers, who are now being granted amnesty.'b'The charges could have been dropped in a more consistent fashion, critics say, but the scale of the pardons is too great to dismiss. Many people, most of them held for political reasons, are free. Nothing like this had ever happened during Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s years in power. Even if his only motivation was to avoid being lectured by world leaders during the winter Olympics next month in Sochi, the December amnesties may prove highly significant, sending a message of moderation to the police, prosecutors and judges.'b'But whether the massive flood of amnesties amounts to a sea change is still in doubt. Everyone understands that the pardons were a one-off event, not a systemic reform. The freeing of high-profile prisoners matters little by itself. The fact that the legal system has been getting consistently tougher despite the release of some prominent prisoners does not leave me with much optimism, at least for the near future.'b'As president, Dmitri Medvedev, now prime minister, took steps to humanize the criminal code, but those efforts have been largely reversed. Legislative changes over the past year have granted greater power to law enforcement structures, not reformed them. Huge fines are now levied for illegal street protests, libel \xe2\x80\x94 decriminalized under Mr. Medvedev\xe2\x80\x99s presidency \xe2\x80\x94 is once again a criminal offense, and the government has banned so-called gay propaganda.'b'The police and the Investigative Committee \xe2\x80\x94 the main investigative authority in Russia \xe2\x80\x94 remain systemically corrupt, the courts are not independent of the Kremlin, and the penitentiary system remains a Stalinist institution.'b'Before Mr. Medvedev\xe2\x80\x99s reforms, law enforcement agencies used their power to put pressure on entrepreneurs, extracting bribes and taking stakes in business ventures. Under President Medvedev, the authority to open criminal cases for tax evasion was taken away from the Investigative Committee and given to the more professional Federal Taxation Service. President Putin give it back to the committee.'b'Despite these reversals, there remains in Russia an important minority that may yet prove a barometer for systemic change. This minority, impossible to define in ethnic, religious or demographic terms, is beyond Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s influence. It is an amorphous group of professional people, middle class workers, small business owners, intellectuals, artists, writers and assorted bohemians.'b'Yuri Pivovarov, a historian of Russia, has a term for those who have not been ground down by the regime. They are Russia\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cspare individuals,\xe2\x80\x9d neither part of the power mechanism, nor of the unquestioning population. Their one common feature is that they are independent of the sources of income controlled by the government.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easier to say what this group does not do than what it does. Its identity lies in the fact that it does not accept the regime\xe2\x80\x99s rules. Mr. Khodorkovsky said in a recent interview that Mr. Putin aspires to be the Deng Xiaoping of Russian politics \xe2\x80\x94 the wise arbiter between actors and groups. \xe2\x80\x9cBut once he realized that there was a part of the Russian society that did not accept his refereeing,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Khodorkovsky said, \xe2\x80\x9che simply factored that part out of his political scheme.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Putin and his associates realized that they could not win the big cities. So they tried to demonstrate that they could afford to discard their critics as politically negligible. They began to emphasize the \xe2\x80\x9croot\xe2\x80\x9d of the Russian people, those living outside major urban centers, as their power base. In practical terms, that meant leaving out Moscow, St. Petersburg and other big cities. After all what is Moscow? In the words of Sergei Ivanov, Mr. Putin\xe2\x80\x99s chief of staff, \xe2\x80\x9cit consists of street cleaners, car drivers, office plankton, journalists and bloggers who don\xe2\x80\x99t produce anything.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Derided and dismissed by officials, this minority of \xe2\x80\x9cspare individuals\xe2\x80\x9d is in fact of great political importance. True, they cannot unite, but that is only natural: These people are independent and different, they are not supposed to be united. Although they are not represented by any political party, the fact remains that most of the Kremlin\xe2\x80\x99s policies \xe2\x80\x94 alternatively toughening and relaxing the system \xe2\x80\x94 have been in response to their actions.'b'In 2011, angry \xe2\x80\x9ccubicle dwellers\xe2\x80\x9d poured into the streets, refusing to accept the official results of parliamentary elections widely believed to have been rigged. In 2012, the Kremlin had to end the practice of appointing regional governors and restore gubernatorial elections, and also relaxed the rules for the registration of political parties. The following year, it even allowed an election that seemed reasonably fair \xe2\x80\x94 the Moscow mayoral race.'b'A few days ago, Mr. Putin eased a ban on public protest in Sochi, the venue of the Olympic Games. Apparently, now that most of the celebrity prisoners are free, the Kremlin no longer sees reasons why anyone would protest. The issue has been addressed, not in a systemic fashion, but it has been addressed. The independent minority has been the ultimate cause.'b'The word for \xe2\x80\x9cspare\xe2\x80\x9d in Russian (lishniy) also can be translated as superfluous, excessive, odd or unneeded. But in fact, \xe2\x80\x9cspare individuals\xe2\x80\x9d are none of these things \xe2\x80\x94 they are indispensable: When they act, the Kremlin reacts. They raise an issue, the Kremlin responds, and amid the game of alternate thaw and freeze, one can recognize a warming trend. Will this work forever? It is hard to say. Predicting politics in Russia is as tricky as trying to predict the weather.'b''b'\n'b'Maxim Trudolyubov 'b' is the opinion page editor of the business newspaper Vedomosti. 'b''b'On Dec. 17, the European Union drafted important legislation to cut hydrofluorocarbons, or HFCs, by 79 percent by 2030. This is the most concrete move yet to rein in HFCs, which are potent greenhouse gases used in refrigerators and air-conditioners. In June, the United States and China reached an agreement to reduce these gases, and in September leaders of the Group of 20 nations pledged to do their share. With Europe\xe2\x80\x99s move, the goal of a global agreement on the gases is closer than ever.'b'Global support has been growing for tackling HFCs through the Montreal Protocol \xe2\x80\x94 which phased out chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, that were destroying the ozone layer \xe2\x80\x94 rather than through the broader and more cumbersome United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. While HFCs, developed to replace CFCs in refrigeration and air-conditioning, do not harm the ozone layer, they are fast becoming a significant contributor to global warming.'b'The United Nations Environment Program projects that HFCs, only 1 percent of greenhouse gases today, will make up 20 percent by 2030 if nothing is done. Eliminating HFCs would be the equivalent of taking 100 billion tons of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere. HFCs have higher global warming potential than carbon dioxide, but they disappear from the atmosphere much more quickly. Global negotiations on limiting more persistent greenhouse gases must continue, but eliminating HFCs will help.'b'New technologies exist to replace HFCs. The European legislation proposes phasing out consumer refrigerators using HFCs in 2015 and imposing additional bans on a range of commercial refrigeration and air-conditioning products that use the most potent HFCs in 2020 and 2022.'b'With this breakthrough in Europe, India, one of the fastest-growing markets for coolants, is now the last big holdout on reduction of HFCs. Despite joining the G-20 pledge, India has reiterated its opposition to tackling HFCs through the Montreal Protocol. The United States and India should continue bilateral talks to address concerns about costs so that India can join the international effort. The European Union should move quickly now to pass into law the draft legislation to give industry a clear timeline to begin the necessary transition.'b'Most Asian nations have been expanding their military budgets and capabilities in recent years. Now there is a new rush by Southeast Asian countries to acquire submarines because they have the money to pay for them.'b'On Jan. 1, Vietnam received its first of six Russian Kilo-class submarines. The last one is expected to be delivered in 2016. Myanmar intends to create a submarine force by 2015. Thailand plans to include the purchase of submarines in its soon-to-be-announced 10 -year armed forces development proposal. Thai officers are already enrolled at submarine training schools in Germany and South Korea, two potential submarine suppliers.'b'Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia have submarine fleets and plan to procure more. Malaysia paid a Franco-Spanish consortium $1.1 billion for two submarines in 2007 and 2009. Indonesia expects to replace its two aging submarines and expand its fleet to 12 with submarines from South Korea and possibly Russia by 2020. Only the Philippines, among the big nations, has not acquired new submarines yet.'b'These countries are not arming against each other. The arms expansion is a reaction to increasing uncertainty about the distribution of power in the region, caused largely by the extension of Chinese naval power into the South China Sea and Indian Ocean. But Chinese naval expansion is not likely to be halted by these submarine fleets. China will simply augment its anti-submarine capability. Each expansion only adds to regional suspicion and tension.'b'It is not at all clear that China would be more restrained with its aggressive claim if these nations possessed more military power. Japan\xe2\x80\x99s substantial military power, including an advanced submarine fleet, has not stopped China from acting on its territorial claim against Japan in the East China Sea. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations needs to act collectively to negotiate with China to prevent further destabilization, instead of each country dealing separately with China.'b'Much of this arms competition is propelled by growing wealth in Southeast Asia, which is tied to the 21st-century global economy. These countries and China should realize that increasing their armaments can only undermine their security as well as the stability that nurtures their economies.'b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9cA girl\xe2\x80\x99s escape\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 3):  I was pleased to read Nicholas Kristof\xe2\x80\x99s article about Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s escape from restavek slavery in Haiti. Her story sheds light on this disturbing system of child labor and inspires hope to end it.'b'Mr. Kristof aptly points to poverty, lack of family planning and no access to education as root causes of restavek slavery. The vulnerability and lack of awareness within rural, impoverished communities are at the heart of the system. Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s family reunion may have been a letdown not because her family did not want her, but because they were unaware of all that had happened to her and had wanted her to have better opportunities.'b'My organization, Free the Slaves, works with grass-roots NGO partners to empower remote communities to take a stand against this type of slavery. Through in-depth rights education and community organizing, residents like Marilaine\xe2\x80\x99s parents would learn to recognize the harmful effects of restavek slavery and identify ways to address it. We have seen parents succeed in bringing their children home, and community members preventing other children from being sent into this system.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s essential to bring all children like Marilaine out of situations of slavery. But there are only so many resources for safe houses. Ending the restavek system for good in Haiti requires the buy-in and determination of those most affected.'b''b'Christy Gillmore,  Washington'b''b'The writer is program manager  of Free the Slaves.'b''b''b''b'Marijuana and legalization'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9cBuyers rush to Colorado as marijuana sales begin\xe2\x80\x9d (News, Jan. 2): The euphoria that Colorado\xe2\x80\x99s legalization of recreational marijuana aroused has reached even Germany, where the issue has been debated for years. Just to be clear: I am not against marijuana. I am a supporter of medical marijuana, a scientifically proven way to help people with certain ailments. But recreational marijuana is different. Aside from its psychological and physical effects on adults, marijuana is also highly dangerous for teenagers, all the more that they will consume it with alcohol and cigarettes. So is it worthwhile to legalize a new way to ruin our health? I think we already have enough ways of doing that.'b''b'Yannik Hausmann  Namborn, Germany'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9cWeed: Been there. Done that.\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 4): David Brooks is a terrific thinker and writer, and practically everything in his column rang true for me, having survived a not-too-misspent youth in the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s in the United States. But he falters at the end by seeming to imply his disapproval of legalization. Society nudges us toward good behavior in many ways. With tobacco, for example, we have high \xe2\x80\x9csin taxes,\xe2\x80\x9d labeling, ad campaigns, restrictions on where smoking is allowed and so on. All these work to some extent.'b'Why not do the same for marijuana?  In that way we could send the right message: Marijuana is not great for you, but it would be worse to continue to prohibit it. At the very least, legalizing marijuana would dramatically reduce the hypocrisy index in our society.'b''b'Myrna Walton,  Paris'b''b''b''b''b'No consensus on G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s 'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9cLonely quest for facts on modified crops\xe2\x80\x9d (News, Jan. 6) by Amy Harmon: This article refers to the view that there exists a \xe2\x80\x9cglobal scientific consensus, which holds that existing genetically engineered crops are no riskier than others.\xe2\x80\x9d The reality is that there is no scientific consensus on this issue \xe2\x80\x94 nor has there been since the first genetically modified organisms were released around 20 years ago. The claim of a global consensus on the safety of G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s has no scientific basis, is misleading and misrepresents available scientific evidence and a broad diversity of opinion among scientists. Moreover, the claim encourages a climate of complacency that could lead to a lack of regulatory and scientific rigor, potentially endangering the health of humans, animals and the environment.'b'In contrast to the misleading claims of consensus on the safety of G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s, the scientific evidence is diverse, nuanced and ambiguous, with numerous studies providing evidence of concern that call for careful follow-up studies. This is partly due to the fact that there exists little independent biosafety science, as access to corporate-owned research material is controlled by corporations, which also control the questions and if and how the results are published.'b''b'Angelika Hilbeck, Berlin 'b''b'The writer is chairwoman of the European Network of Scientists for Social and Environmental Responsibility.'b'BEIJING \xe2\x80\x94  Anywhere in the world it can be a challenge to sort fact from fiction on the Internet, but in China the problem has a unique dimension, given the relative absence of reliable information, especially on issues involving the government.'b'In recent years, all too often the Chinese authorities have issued false statements in an effort to conceal the truth about matters of public concern, with the result that rumors thrive as people grope for clues about what really happened. As official lies and popular rumors vie for supremacy, it becomes all the harder to distinguish between fact and fiction, especially on the Internet.'b'A key factor in this are the microblogs, which during the last four years have claimed a hold over Chinese society and are shaping people\xe2\x80\x99s judgments. As a popular saying has it, \xe2\x80\x9cWhile truth is still tying its shoelaces, rumor has already run a whole lap around China.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But microblogs are simply a tool that makes it easy for rumors to circulate. It\xe2\x80\x99s the falsehoods peddled for so long by the government that have fueled the rise of Internet gossip.'b'On Feb. 6, 2012, Wang Lijun, then Chongqing\xe2\x80\x99s police chief, sought refuge in the U.S. Consulate in Chengdu for a day. Officials in Chongqing cooked up a story that Mr. Wang was on sick leave, and rumors started to fly, one even announcing a coup d\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xa9tat in Beijing.'b'Government fabrications provoke people to search the Internet in an attempt to piece together the real story, and sometimes they find that things officials write off as rumor turn out to be true. For example, colorful details like Bo Xilai \xe2\x80\x94 Chongqing\xe2\x80\x99s former top official who is serving time in prison for corruption \xe2\x80\x94 slapping Mr. Wang in the face were later confirmed as fact, making more people put their faith in rumors.'b'Given the proliferation of rumors, and the speed at which they circulate online, the government realized that measures like deleting posts and shutting down microblog accounts had lost their effectiveness. So it began a campaign to prosecute bloggers. On Sept. 9, the Supreme People\xe2\x80\x99s Court and Supreme People\xe2\x80\x99s Procuratorate issued a ruling stipulating that defamatory reports, if reposted more than 500 times on the Internet, are a crime worthy of punishment.'b'A few days later, Yang Hui, a 16-year-old boy in Gansu Province in the northwest, became one of the first to fall afoul of this new rule. After challenging online the official explanation for a local man\xe2\x80\x99s death, he was detained for seven days on charges of stirring up trouble. Only after an outcry, mostly online, was he freed.'b'In fact, the crackdown began in August, before the ruling was even issued. According to local media reports from across the country, hundreds of bloggers may have been arrested and taken into custody. Some were given \xe2\x80\x9ceducational warnings\xe2\x80\x9d; some were jailed. It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to get exact numbers.'b'The policy of cracking down first and only later providing a legal justification seems not to have been questioned on the Internet, because the government has continued to delete posts, gag speech and shut down microblog accounts, making it impossible for critics to protest online.'b'The government campaign came to light on Aug. 21, when one story dominated the web: The Beijing police had closed down an \xe2\x80\x9cInternet rumor company\xe2\x80\x9d and seized someone with the alias Qin Huohuo and five others.'b'The official media, in coordination with the Beijing police, reported in detail on Mr. Qin\xe2\x80\x99s many misdeeds. Prior to this I knew nothing about him, and after reading part of his microblog, it seemed to me that some of his posts were indeed just unsubstantiated rumors.'b'Even so, there were lots of people online who spoke up in his defense, finding weak spots in the official media\xe2\x80\x99s accusations. One of Mr. Qin\xe2\x80\x99s alleged crimes, for example, was that he disparaged Lei Feng \xe2\x80\x94 the young soldier exalted by Mao and his propagandists as an icon of patriotism and self-sacrifice \xe2\x80\x94 claiming in a post that Mr. Lei actually hankered after a life of luxury: \xe2\x80\x9cThe high-end apparel that Lei Feng bought for himself in 1959 \xe2\x80\x94 leather jacket, woolen pants, leather shoes \xe2\x80\x94 would have cost about 90 yuan at the time, but his pay was only 6 yuan a month.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some Internet commentators pointed out that at the end of 2012 the official Xinhua website had already reported Mr. Lei\xe2\x80\x99s purchase of a watch and a leather jacket, and they asked sarcastically why the police weren\xe2\x80\x99t taking Xinhua into custody.'b'Given all the online support for Mr. Qin, and for other well-known bloggers who have been shut down, I am doubtful that the government\xe2\x80\x99s use of punitive measures will achieve its goals.'b'Chinese people of my generation that grew up during the Mao era have long been accustomed to government mendacity: from the Great Leap Forward\xe2\x80\x99s grossly inflated claims about rice production to the recent fib about Mr. Wang\xe2\x80\x99s sick leave. The difference is that before the Internet and microblogs, popular rumors spread mouth to mouth, with very limited circulation, and official fairy tales enjoyed a virtual monopoly. But once the Internet and, more particularly, microblogs came onto the scene, the social reach of rumors soon eclipsed that of official media \xe2\x80\x94 and official mythmaking\xe2\x80\x99s monopoly was broken. That left the government to clamp down not on real violations but on what it labeled as Internet rumors.'b'The best way of putting an end to Internet rumors is for the government to stop disseminating lies. But the government will never do that, and so Internet rumors will continue to sprout and spread \xe2\x80\x94 even after the crackdown.'b''b'\n'b'Yu Hua 'b' is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cTo Live,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cChina in Ten Words\xe2\x80\x9d and other books. This article was translated by Allan H. Myer (Op-Ed, Jan. 3), notes that woodpeckers do not appear to sustain brain injuries from head banging. Certainly they are not found dead next to their trees.'b'The skeletal anatomy of the woodpecker\xe2\x80\x99s skull protects against brain damage from frontal impacts. The anatomy of the human skull is similar with its layers of facial bones, spaces and sinuses that help protect the human brain from direct frontal trauma.'b'This same protection is not present on the sides of our skulls. This is one reason that our brains are more vulnerable to blows from the side, which are more immediately brain destructive and more likely to cause rapid loss of consciousness and even death than frontal impacts. Side impacts must be more fully addressed to be able to develop safer helmets for children and adults.'b'MICHAEL M. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I enjoyed Bob Morris\xe2\x80\x99s surreal password control questions (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'How Insecure Is Your Password?'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Sunday Review, Jan. 5), but he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exaggerate much. When consumers cannot go to court but have to resolve their disputes before arbitrators who leave no tracks, all of us who depend on the law suffer.'b'THOMAS SCHNEIDER'b'\nMenlo Park, Calif., Dec. 31, 2013'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a retired federal administrative law judge.'b''b'Well, a major and venerable American brand has gone and announced that 'b'it contains no genetically modified organisms'b" (G.M.O.'s). Cheerios is G.M.O.-free! And will soon be labeled \xe2\x80\x9cNot Made With Genetically Modified Ingredients.\xe2\x80\x9d"b'Do we care? Should we? Is this a cynical marketing ploy or a huge deal or both? (It certainly isn\xe2\x80\x99t neither.)'b'Without question this could be the start of something big. That it has value to Cheerios and to 'b'anti-G.M.O. activists'b' is also undoubtedly true; the question is whether it matters to the rest of us. It does; but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it\xe2\x80\x99s a good thing.'b"First, let\xe2\x80\x99s get this straight. Taking the G.M.O.'s out of Cheerios is only a little bit harder than taking them out of oatmeal: "b'there are no G.M.O. oats'b', and Cheerios are, essentially, oats. (Well, hyper-processed oats.) They also contain small amounts of cornstarch and sugar, so its parent company, General Mills, has done little more than source non-G.M.O. cornstarch and cane rather than beet sugar to use in production. (There are G.M.O. beets, and almost all corn and soybeans grown in the United States use G.M.O. seeds, whose products find their way into most processed foods.) This is what they\xe2\x80\x99ve done for years 'b'in most of Europe'b", where products with G.M.O.'s are almost universally labeled as such."b"But it\xe2\x80\x99s not as if General Mills \xe2\x80\x94 which was among the funders of the opposition to G.M.O.-labeling efforts in California and Washington \xe2\x80\x94 has made a principled decision, or has suddenly seen some kind of light. (Other varieties of Cheerios, such as Apple Cinnamon and Multi Grain, will continue to be made with ingredients containing G.M.O.'s, including corn, corn syrup, beet sugar and others.) It could simply be that the company saw an opportunity to appease part of its market, and to test whether a minimal effort could lead to a labeling opportunity that would boost sales as would, say, a \xe2\x80\x9chigh-fiber\xe2\x80\x9d or cholesterol-reduction notice."b'But the label is only meaningless in terms of Cheerios\xe2\x80\x99 content. My guess is that General Mills is right: the G.M.O.-free label will appeal to consumers who, for whatever reasons \xe2\x80\x94 justified or not \xe2\x80\x94 would rather buy a G.M.O.-free product. Increased sales might come at the expense of other Cheerios products, but then again they might come at the expense of competitors\xe2\x80\x99 cereals that can\xe2\x80\x99t brag about their \xe2\x80\x9cpurity.\xe2\x80\x9d (Let\xe2\x80\x99s remember that few, if any, health-savvy breakfast-eating people would make Cheerios a frequent choice in any case\xe2\x80\x94 even if they are easy for toddlers to nibble on.)'b'All of this makes the announcement significant, because if it works, others will follow suit. And farmers could easily make the switch back to non-G.M.O. seeds (more are beginning to, as the benefits of G.M.O. seeds are increasingly outweighed by their costs), and processed food companies are \xe2\x80\x94 or at least should be \xe2\x80\x94 agnostic as to whether corn, for example, was grown with conventional or G.M.O. seeds.'b"Should we care? Yes. Much of the controversy over G.M.O.'s is being fought between those with a vested interest in their success and those who are willing to overstate the problems with the technology. Producing seeds containing G.M.O.'s is a valid scientific technique. The problem is that the benefits have accrued more to the seeds\xe2\x80\x99 producers than to farmers (who are spending many times more for seeds than they were previously) or consumers (who can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly tell the source of refined products in their processed foods) or to the environment. There\xe2\x80\x99s an argument that G.M.O. seeds increase yields and keep food costs down, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not a convincing one."b'There are three real issues here, and none of them is about whether there are teeny tiny G.M.O. ingredients in our food. One is that G.M.O. seeds have arguably done more harm than good, by making traditional farming 'b'more expensive for farmers'b" \xe2\x80\x94 not only here but internationally \xe2\x80\x94 and by retarding progress in combating weeds and bugs ecologically in industrial farming. Still, eliminating G.M.O.'s would not do much to remedy what\xe2\x80\x99s wrong with industrial agriculture; that\xe2\x80\x99s going to require a hard look at crop rotation, chemical applications and monoculture in general."b'Another issue, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve written about this before, is transparency. Increasingly, people want to know how and with what their food is being produced. ('b'Over 90 percent of Americans'b" are in favor of G.M.O. labeling.) Some of this may be for the wrong reason \xe2\x80\x94 fear of eating foods produced with G.M.O. seeds. (About half the population believes G.M.O.'s to be unsafe.) But the argument for labeling and transparency goes way beyond G.M.O.'s, and any labeling that provides more information should be seen as a victory for people who care about food quality."b'This brings us to the third issue, one about which I\xe2\x80\x99m not happy. If opportunistic marketers like those at General Mills can cash in by making insignificant changes in their products that lead to significant marketing benefits, what happens to people who\xe2\x80\x99ve actually put work into making their products significantly cleaner \xe2\x80\x94 that is, organic? Once you have an \xe2\x80\x9corganic\xe2\x80\x9d label, you are forbidden to put \xe2\x80\x9cNot Made With Genetically Modified Ingredients\xe2\x80\x9d on your package \xe2\x80\x94 that\xe2\x80\x99s theoretically understood, as are more important benefits, like antibiotic- and pesticide-free. But thanks to the way-too-loud G.M.O. screaming match, my guess is that it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to market food using a meaningless \xe2\x80\x9cG.M.O.-free\xe2\x80\x9d label than an organic label. That\xe2\x80\x99s not a cheery thought.'b'KANSAS, like every state, explicitly guarantees a free public education in its Constitution, affirming America\xe2\x80\x99s founding belief that only an educated citizenry can preserve democracy and safeguard individual liberty and freedom.'b'And yet in recent years Kansas has become the epicenter of a new battle over the states\xe2\x80\x99 obligation to adequately fund public education. Even though the state Constitution requires that it make \xe2\x80\x9csuitable provision\xe2\x80\x9d for financing public education, Gov. Sam Brownback and the Republican-led Legislature have made draconian cuts in school spending, leading to a 'b'lawsuit'b' that now sits before the state Supreme Court.'b'The outcome of that decision could resonate nationwide. Forty-five states have had lawsuits 'b'challenging the failure'b' of governors and legislators to provide essential resources for a constitutional education. Litigation is pending against 11 states that allegedly provide inadequate and unfair school funding, including New York, Florida, Texas and California.'b'Many of these lawsuits successfully forced elected officials to increase school funding overall and to deliver more resources to poor students and those with special needs. If the Kansas Supreme Court rules otherwise, students in those states may begin to see the tide of education cuts return.'b'Kansas\xe2\x80\x99 current constitutional crisis has its genesis in a series of cuts to school funding that began in 2009. The cuts were accelerated by a $1.1 billion tax break, which benefited mostly upper-income Kansans, proposed by Governor Brownback and enacted in 2012.'b'Overall, the Legislature 'b'slashed public education funding'b' to 16.5 percent below the 2008 level, triggering significant program reductions in schools across the state. Class sizes have increased, teachers and staff members have been laid off, and essential services for at-risk students were eliminated, even as the state implemented higher academic standards for college and career readiness.'b'Parents filed a lawsuit in the Kansas courts to challenge the cuts. In 'b'Gannon v. State of Kansas'b', a three-judge trial court ruled in January 2013 for the parents, finding that the cuts reduced per-pupil expenditures far below a level \xe2\x80\x9csuitable\xe2\x80\x9d to educate all children under Kansas\xe2\x80\x99 standards.'b'The judges also found that the Legislature was not meeting even the basic funding amounts set in its own education cost studies. The judges called the school funding cut \xe2\x80\x9cdestructive of our children\xe2\x80\x99s future.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To remedy the funding shortfall, the judges ordered that per-pupil expenditures be increased to $4,492 from $3,838, the level previously established as suitable.'b'Rather than comply, Governor Brownback appealed to the Kansas Supreme Court. A decision is expected this month.'b'A victory for the parents would be heartening, but if it comes, would Governor Brownback and legislative leaders uphold the right to education guaranteed to Kansas school children?'b'The signals thus far are not promising. If the Kansas Supreme Court orders restoration of the funding, legislators are threatening to amend the state\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution by removing the requirement for \xe2\x80\x9csuitable\xe2\x80\x9d school funding and to strip Kansas courts of jurisdiction to hear school finance cases altogether. And if the amendment fails, they have vowed to defy any court order for increased funding or, at the very least, take the money from higher education.'b'A court-stripping constitutional amendment, and defiance of a state Supreme Court order, would shred the very fabric of Kansas\xe2\x80\x99 government and send shock waves through state capitals across the nation. It would allow elected branches to avoid any responsibility to adhere to the language and interpretation of their state constitutions by the courts. It would gravely undermine judicial independence and shut the courthouse door to vulnerable children who, as a last resort, seek legal redress to vindicate their fundamental right to an education.'b'As the Gannon trial judges noted, matters such as education are placed in constitutions because they are \xe2\x80\x9cintended for permanence\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cto protect them from the vagaries of politics.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Kansans rightfully take pride in their strong public school system. But as Kansas goes, so may go the nation. The Kansas Constitution, like those in other states, demands that every child be given the educational opportunity to meet his or her promise. This requires, at a minimum, adequate and suitable school funding. Governor Brownback and legislators must meet the constitutional command and, by so doing, advance the core American value of equal opportunity for all.'b'When President Obama took office in 2009, he promised an \xe2\x80\x9cunprecedented level of openness in government.\xe2\x80\x9d In a 'b'memo'b' issued the day after his inauguration, he wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cThe government should not keep information confidential merely because public officials might be embarrassed by disclosure, because errors and failures might be revealed, or because of speculative or abstract fears.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the latest reminder that the Obama administration has failed to live up to that promise, the Justice Department last week 'b'won its fight'b' to keep secret a memo that outlines the supposed legal authority for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to collect Americans\xe2\x80\x99 telephone and financial records without a subpoena or court order.'b'The memo, issued in 2010 by the department\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Legal Counsel, approved of the bureau\xe2\x80\x99s use of what are known as exigent letters to obtain phone records without any legal process, and in the absence of any emergency. From 2003 to 2006, the bureau 'b'used these letters'b' to obtain phone records for 'b'more than 3,500 accounts'b'.'b'Last Friday, a unanimous panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit 'b'ruled'b' that the memo could be kept secret from the public because it was the product of internal agency deliberations and had not been formally adopted as department policy. (The F.B.I. has said it no longer uses exigent letters.)'b'Withholding the opinions of the Office of Legal Counsel, which provides legal advice to the president and executive agencies, is deeply troubling. The office\xe2\x80\x99s advice often serves as the final word on what the executive branch may legally do, and those who follow that advice are virtually assured that they will not face prosecution.'b'During the administration of George W. Bush, the opinions of the office gave 'b'legal cover'b' to officials who wanted to torture prisoners for terror-related intelligence and 'b'approved'b' the 'b'warrantless wiretapping'b' program that operated for years before being 'b'exposed'b' by The New York Times. Many other opinions remain hidden under the specious claim that they are only working drafts, not adopted policies, and that if officials must worry about operating \xe2\x80\x9cin a fishbowl,\xe2\x80\x9d they will avoid seeking legal advice altogether. This rationale is largely a pretext for putting an ever-expanding shroud over almost any controversial, and potentially illegal, government action.'b'In 2009, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. 'b'said'b', \xe2\x80\x9can agency should not withhold information simply because it may do so legally.\xe2\x80\x9d Those were encouraging words, but Mr. Holder\xe2\x80\x99s Justice Department fought the release of the memo. If the Obama administration continues to resist more transparency, Congress can amend the open-records law to require greater disclosure of the office\xe2\x80\x99s opinions.'b'Edward Snowden\xe2\x80\x99s unauthorized disclosures of secret mass surveillance programs have forever changed the public discussion about the relationship between national security and the protection of privacy and civil liberties. That debate is meaningful only if it is open. The public should not be left in the dark about the legal justifications for the most significant actions of its government.'b'Every day the headlines from the Arab world get worse: An Al Qaeda affiliate group, aided by foreign fighters, battles with seven different homegrown Syrian rebel groups for control of the region around Aleppo, Syria. The Iranian Embassy in Beirut is bombed. Mohamad Chatah, an enormously decent former Lebanese finance minister, is blown up after criticizing Hezbollah\xe2\x80\x99s brutish tactics. Another pro-Al Qaeda group takes control of Fallujah, Iraq. Explosions rock Egypt, where the army is now jailing Islamists and secular activists. Libya is a mess of competing militias.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s going on? Some say it\xe2\x80\x99s all because of the \xe2\x80\x9cpower vacuum\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 America has absented itself from the region. But this is not just about us. There\xe2\x80\x99s also a huge \xe2\x80\x9cvalues vacuum.\xe2\x80\x9d The Middle East is a highly pluralistic region \xe2\x80\x94 Shiites, Sunnis, Kurds, Christians, Druze and various tribes \xe2\x80\x94 that for centuries was held together from above by iron-fisted colonial powers, kings and dictators. But now that vertical control has broken down, before this pluralistic region has developed any true bottom-up pluralism \xe2\x80\x94 a broad ethic of tolerance \xe2\x80\x94 that might enable its people to live together as equal citizens, without an iron fist from above.'b'For the Arab awakening to have any future, the ideology that is most needed now is the one being promoted least: Pluralism. Until that changes, argues Marwan Muasher, in his extremely relevant new book \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThe Second Arab Awakening and the Battle for Pluralism\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 none of the Arab uprisings will succeed.'b'Again, President Obama could have done more to restrain leaders in Iraq, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Iran or Syria from going to extremes. But, ultimately, argues Muasher, this is the Arabs\xe2\x80\x99 fight for their political future. If 500,000 American troops in Iraq, and $1 trillion, could not implant lasting pluralism in the cultural soil there, no outsider can, said Muasher. There also has to be a will from within. Why is it that some 15,000 Arabs and Muslims have flocked to Syria to fight and die for jihadism and zero have flocked to Syria to fight and die for pluralism? Is it only because we didn\xe2\x80\x99t give the \xe2\x80\x9cgood guys\xe2\x80\x9d big enough guns?'b'As Muasher, a former Jordanian foreign minister and now a vice president at the Carnegie Endowment in Washington, put it in an interview: \xe2\x80\x9cThree years of the Arab uprising have shown the bankruptcy of all the old political forces in the Arab world.\xe2\x80\x9d The corrupt secular autocrats who failed to give their young people the tools to thrive \xe2\x80\x94 and, as a result, triggered these uprisings \xe2\x80\x94 are still locked in a struggle with Islamists, who also have no clue how to deliver jobs, services, security and economic growth. (Tunisia may be an exception.) \xe2\x80\x9cAs long as we\xe2\x80\x99re in the this zero-sum game, the sum will be zero,\xe2\x80\x9d says Muasher.\xc2\xa0'b'No sustainable progress will be possible, argues Muasher, without the ethic of pluralism permeating all aspects of Arab society \xe2\x80\x94 pluralism of thought, pluralism in gender opportunities, pluralism in respect to other religions, pluralism in education, pluralism toward minorities, pluralism of political parties rotating in power and pluralism in the sense of everyone\xe2\x80\x99s right to think differently from the collective.'b'The first Arab awakening in the 20th century was a fight for independence from colonial powers, says Muasher. It never continued as a fight for democracy and pluralism. That war of ideas, he insists, is what \xe2\x80\x9cthe second Arab awakening\xe2\x80\x9d has to be about. Neither the autocrats nor the Islamists can deliver progress. \xe2\x80\x9cPluralism is the operating system we need to solve all our problems, and as long as that operating system is not in place, we will not get there. This is an internal battle. Let\xe2\x80\x99s stop hoping for delivery from the outside.\xe2\x80\x9d This will take time.'b'Na\xc3\xafve? No. Na\xc3\xafve is thinking that everything is about the absence or presence of American power, and that the people of the region have no agency. That\xe2\x80\x99s wrong: Iraq is splintering because Prime Minister Maliki behaved like a Shiite militiaman, not an Iraqi Mandela. Arab youths took their future in their own hands, motivated largely by pluralistic impulses. But the old order proved to be too stubborn, yet these youth aspirations have not gone away, and will not.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Arab world will go through a period of turmoil in which exclusionist forces will attempt to dominate the landscape with absolute truths and new dictatorships,\xe2\x80\x9d writes Muasher. But \xe2\x80\x9cthese forces will also fade, because, in the end, the exclusionist, authoritarian discourses cannot answer the people\xe2\x80\x99s needs for better quality of life. ...\xc2\xa0 As history has demonstrated overwhelmingly, where there is respect for diversity, there is prosperity. Contrary to what Arab societies have been taught for decades by their governments to believe \xe2\x80\x94 that tolerance, acceptance of different points of view, and critical thinking are destructive to national unity and economic growth \xe2\x80\x94 experience proves that societies cannot keep renewing themselves and thereby thrive except through diversity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Muasher, who is returning to Jordan to participate in this struggle for diversity, dedicated his book to: \xe2\x80\x9cThe youth of the Arab World \xe2\x80\x94 who revolted, not against their parents, but on their behalf.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s top officials appear to be moving to address the risks posed by a fast-growing-but-shadowy part of the country\xe2\x80\x99s financial system. The Chinese cabinet is seeking to increase government oversight of lending by companies that currently face little or no supervision, according to 'b'news reports'b' based on an official document that was written last month.'b'Economists have long worried about China\xe2\x80\x99s so-called 'b'shadow banking system'b', in which banks and finance companies loan money to businesses and local governments at high interest rates outside the regulated financial system. Analysts worry that unregulated lenders, which themselves borrow money from regulated banks, have made too many dubious loans that could default and set off a broader financial crisis. In 'b'recent months'b', interest rates in China have surged from time to time in part because of the links between the unregulated and regulated parts of the financial system.'b'The shadow system has grown in recent years because the Chinese government has too tightly controlled traditional banking. It keeps the interest rates that conventional banks pay to depositors extremely low and gives out cheap loans to state-owned enterprises and favored companies that might not be able to repay the money.'b'The low rates, of course, have led savers to invest money in speculative real estate projects or dubious investments known as wealth management products offered by banks and finance companies that promise higher rates of return. Much of that money is then lent to private businesses and local governments, which cannot get conventional bank loans because regulated banks are required to give preferences to state-owned companies.'b'Chinese officials have to tread carefully in changing this system. The Chinese Academy of Social Sciences estimates that the size of the shadow sector is equal to 40 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s gross domestic product. If the government cracks down on shadow banking too hard and too quickly, it could cause a panic. If it does not move forcefully enough to curb unregulated lending, bad debts will proliferate and become harder to resolve later on.'b'That dilemma helps explain why the cabinet, which is known as the State Council, reportedly described shadow banking as \xe2\x80\x9cbeneficial\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cinevitable\xe2\x80\x9d in the document telling financial regulators to increase their oversight of unregulated lending.'b'It will take regulators years to reform the Chinese banking system and put it on more stable footing. Their success will be determined in large part by the willingness of the country\xe2\x80\x99s top leaders to end the flawed policies that encouraged the growth of the shadow banking system in the first place.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s going on with John Boehner, the speaker of the House?'b'On Dec. 12, Boehner 'b'broke with hard-line conservative groups'b', accusing them of \xe2\x80\x9cmisleading their followers\xe2\x80\x9d and charging that \xe2\x80\x9cthey have lost all credibility." He recently hired 'b'Rebecca Tallent'b', a former chief of staff for Senator John McCain, a strong backer of immigration reform, and he has encouraged aides to tell reporters that he is prepared to challenge the anti-immigration wing of his party.'b'There are several theories about Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s unexpected turn.'b'One explanation sees Boehner and centrist Republicans generally backing away from some of their more controversial stands in preparation for the 2014 election. 'b'David Brady'b', a political scientist at Stanford and deputy director of the Hoover Institution, said in an email: \xe2\x80\x9cTea Party threats to run their candidates against incumbents voting against them have lost credibility.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In close contests, the long-term unemployed, along with their families and their friends, have the power to determine the outcome in those 2014 elections in which a percentage point gained or lost can be decisive.
