A vote against restoring the benefits would create \xe2\x80\x9ca political vulnerability,\xe2\x80\x9d said John Feehery, a public relations executive who was once a top aide to Dennis Hastert, the former House speaker. \xe2\x80\x9cA lot of those folks on unemployment are swing voters. They dislike Obama but will vote their economic interests if they have to.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Alan Abramowitz, a political scientist at Emory, agreed:'b'Public Policy Polling, a Democratic firm, 'b'surveyed'b' voters in four competitive congressional districts currently held by Republican, as well as in Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s own district. The results showed that strong majorities back extension of unemployment benefits. Support for restoring benefits ranged from 63 to 68 percent in the five districts; Republicans approved of the idea by a 53.4-41.6 margin. The survey was informative, even though it was designed to poke a stick in Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s eye.'b'There is another clear reason for Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s shift towards the center: the economy has begun to improve. In 'b'Ben Bernanke\xe2\x80\x99s words'b', \xe2\x80\x9cThe combination of financial healing, greater balance in the housing market, less fiscal restraint, and, of course, continued monetary policy accommodation bodes well for U.S. economic growth in coming quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Why would an improving economy encourage John Boehner to be more receptive to extended unemployment benefits and liberalized immigration policies \xe2\x80\x93 and courageous enough to stiff-arm his party\xe2\x80\x99s right wing?'b'To answer that question requires a look at how favorable and unfavorable trends in the economy influence the political views of the electorate.'b'In 'b'recent columns'b', I have reported on studies demonstrating that conservatism often gains strength in downturns and that hard times tend to 'b'push the electorate to the right'b'.'b'There are those who dispute these trends, citing the sharp turn to the left during the 1930s. 'b'Steven Pinker'b', a professor of psychology at Harvard, wrote in response to my question about political responses to adversity:'b'It is, however, one of the ironies of political economy that support for the liberal agenda declines just when the needs of the needy are strongest. Conversely, when the economy begins to expand and the spending cuts sought by conservatives would be least painful, support for conservative belt-tightening drops.'b'One of the best explanations of this phenomenon was published two decades ago. The 'b'paper'b' focused on the differing responses of the right and left to scarcity and plenty, and was written by Linda J. Skitka, a professor of psychology at the University of Illinois-Chicago, and Philip E. Tetlock, a professor of psychology and management at the University of Pennsylvania.'b'Skitka and Tetlock conducted a survey assessing how liberals and conservatives would allocate three resources; azidothymidine (AZT) for AIDS patients; organs for would-be transplant recipients; and low-income housing for the poor \xe2\x80\x93 under conditions of plenty (\xe2\x80\x9cno scarcity\xe2\x80\x9d), low scarcity and high scarcity.'b'When participants in the experiments were told that resources were very scarce, liberals became less generous and began to make the same judgments as conservatives. Both left and right \xe2\x80\x9cdenied assistance to people they deemed personally responsible for their plight.\xe2\x80\x9d In other words, scarcity and a lack of resources made participants more conservative in their outlook.'b'But when participants were told there was \xe2\x80\x9cno scarcity,\xe2\x80\x9d liberals awarded benefits to everyone, and only conservatives made a distinction between giving to the \xe2\x80\x9cdeserving\xe2\x80\x9d and withholding from the \xe2\x80\x9cundeserving.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Skitka-Tetlock findings \xe2\x80\x93 and there are a number of other 'b'studies'b' and 'b'surveys'b' that 'b'confirm'b' the results \xe2\x80\x94 suggest that in the context of the improving economy, legislation extending unemployment benefits will pass the House with Boehner\xe2\x80\x99s support and the votes of a substantial number of Republicans.'b'President Obama knows he has Boehner and the Republican House on the defensive.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJust a few days after Christmas, more than one million of our fellow Americans lost a vital economic lifeline \xe2\x80\x93 the temporary insurance that helps folks make ends meet while they look for a job,\xe2\x80\x9d Obama declared in his weekly radio address on Jan. 4.'b'Hitting every note in the compassion playbook, the president said:'b'On Tuesday the Senate voted, with the support of six Republicans, to reject a filibuster and take up legislation that would extend long-term unemployment benefits for three months. A major sticking point remains: whether the legislation will be paid for by new revenues or by separate spending cuts as demanded by many Republicans.'b'John Boehner can read tea leaves as well as anyone, and he knows that in order to protect his members who are running in battleground districts, he cannot afford to let the compassion gap get too wide. The Tea Party is the loser in this calculus and the long-term unemployed are likely to be the winners.'b'TODAY, the anniversary of the shooting in Tucson that put a bullet through my head and killed six of my constituents, is when I make my annual resolutions.'b'Many may look at me and see mostly what I have lost. I struggle to speak, my eyesight\xe2\x80\x99s not great, my right arm and leg are paralyzed, and I left a job I loved representing southern Arizona in Congress.'b'But three years ago, dispatched to an almost certain death by an assassin\xe2\x80\x99s bullet, I was allowed the opportunity for a new life. I had planned to spend my 40s continuing my public service and starting a family. I thought that by fighting for the people I cared about and loving those close to me, I could leave the world a better place. And that would be enough.'b'Instead, I\xe2\x80\x99ve spent the past three years learning how to talk again, how to walk again. I had to learn to sign my name with my left hand. It\xe2\x80\x99s gritty, painful, frustrating work, every day. Rehab is endlessly repetitive. And it\xe2\x80\x99s never easy, because once you\xe2\x80\x99ve mastered some movement or action or word, no matter how small, you move on to the next. You never rest.'b'I asked myself, if simply completing a normal day requires so much work, how would I ever be able to fulfill a larger purpose? The killing of children at the school in Sandy Hook a little over a year ago gave me my answer. It shocked me, it motivated me, and frankly, it showed me a path. After that day, my husband and I pledged to make it our mission to change laws and reduce gun violence in a way that was consistent with our moderate beliefs and our identities as proud gun owners. We knew it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be easy, that special interests were arrayed against us, that congressional dysfunction was an enemy.'b'Predictably, Washington disappointed us during the first year of our work with the organization we began, 'b'Americans for Responsible Solutions'b'. Many of you were outraged at the failure of the Senate to pass the background checks bill, and so was I.'b'But I continue to be inspired by my fellow Americans. By any measure, they\xe2\x80\x99re with us. They know gun violence is a complex problem. No one law will make it go away.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99re not daunted. We know that the gun lobby, which makes money by preventing sensible change, relies on dramatic disappointments to wound us, reduce our power, push us back on our heels.'b'Our fight is a lot more like my rehab. Every day, we must wake up resolved and determined. We\xe2\x80\x99ll pay attention to the details; look for opportunities for progress, even when the pace is slow. Some progress may seem small, and we might wonder if the impact is enough, when the need is so urgent.'b'But every day we will recruit a few more allies, talk to a few more elected officials, convince a few more voters. Some days the steps will come easily; we\xe2\x80\x99ll feel the wind at our backs. Other times our knees will buckle. We\xe2\x80\x99ll tire of the burden. I know this feeling. But we\xe2\x80\x99ll persist.'b'We can get tough and win elections. We\xe2\x80\x99ll support our allies. And those who stood in the way will face a powerful advocacy community standing between them and re-election. I know that after the next elections, candidates won\xe2\x80\x99t wonder if common-sense gun policies can win elections; trust me, like Governor-elect Terry McAuliffe of Virginia, they\xe2\x80\x99ll know that the answer is yes.'b'We will seize on consensus where it exists, on solutions big or small. We will fight for every inch, because that means saving lives. I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen grit overcome paralysis. My resolution today is that Congress achieve the same. How? Step by step: Enhance enforcement by passing a law making gun trafficking a serious crime with stiff penalties. Make it illegal for all stalkers and all domestic abusers to buy guns. Extend mental health resources into schools and communities, so the dangerously mentally ill find it easier to receive treatment than to buy firearms. And even as we lay the groundwork for expanding background checks, pass strong incentives for states to ensure the background-check system contains the records of the most dangerous and violent among us.'b'This past year, I have achieved something big that I\xe2\x80\x99ve not spoken of until now. Countless hours of physical therapy \xe2\x80\x94 and the talents of the medical community \xe2\x80\x94 have brought me new movement in my right arm. It\xe2\x80\x99s fractional progress, and it took a long time, but my arm moves when I tell it to. Three years ago, I did not imagine my arm would move again. For so many days, it did not. I did exercise after exercise, day after day, until it did. I\xe2\x80\x99m committed to my rehab and I\xe2\x80\x99m committed to my country, and my resolution, standing with the vast majority of Americans who know we can and must be safer, is to cede no ground to those who would convince us the path is too steep, or we too weak.'b'In real life, Americans may keen about income inequality. But on TV, they\xe2\x80\x99re keen for it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey\xe2\x80\x9d continued its upward ascent with viewers Sunday night, a gushing embrace of class snobbery that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been seen since friends clustered across the country in 1981 \xe2\x80\x94 wearing black tie and clutching Teddy Bears and champagne glasses \xe2\x80\x94 to watch \xe2\x80\x9cBrideshead Revisited.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve resisted the \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey\xe2\x80\x9d fervor. Speaking of the grand lady of the house, Edgeworth wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cShe was a strict observer, for self and servants, of Lent, and all fast-days, but not holidays. One of the maids having fainted three times the last day of Lent, to keep soul and body together, we put a morsel of roast beef in her mouth, which came from Sir Murtagh\xe2\x80\x99s dinner, who never fasted, not he; but somehow or other it unfortunately reached my lady\xe2\x80\x99s ears, and the priest of the parish had a complaint made of it the next day, and the poor girl was forced, as soon as she could walk, to do penance for it, before she could get any peace or absolution, in the house or out of it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Niall O\xe2\x80\x99Dowd, the founder of The Irish Voice, IrishCentral.com and Irish America magazine, asserted: \xe2\x80\x9cFor this generation of Americans, the \xe2\x80\x98Downton Abbey\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Yes, m\xe2\x80\x99Lady\xe2\x80\x99 servants are the equivalent to the old minstrel shows on the Bowery. And the good ones instruct and nag their superiors into making the right moves in their royal lives, both personally and professionally. In Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s season premiere, Lady Mary frostily informed Carson the butler that he had overstepped the mark in urging her to move past her grief over her husband\xe2\x80\x99s death and get more involved in running the estate. But she soon humbly apologized for having the cheek to criticize Carson\xe2\x80\x99s cheek. The marble beauty in long black gloves melted into sobs in his arms and then bucked up to rejoin the world.'b'The butler did it.'b'By now, we all know that 'b'a polar vortex'b' is a cyclone of frigid air centered on the Arctic. A rogue sweep of that air moved south and pushed the temperature in Central Park in New York City to a 118-year low of 5 degrees on 'b'Tuesday morning'b'; records were similarly broken in scores of other American and Canadian cities; and flights were canceled across North America. Yet winter has barely begun, and, even before the icy cold of this week, it had already treated the eastern United States to snowstorms, southwest Britain to monster waves and northern Europe to unusually nasty weather.'b'Weather is changing in ways we cannot easily predict or understand. The polar vortex has had kinks before \xe2\x80\x94 most dramatically in March 1921, when temperatures in Central Park plummeted from 82 degrees to 26 degrees in 14 hours \xe2\x80\x94 just as there have been catastrophic floods, droughts, heat waves and blizzards all through recorded history. Experts say this week\xe2\x80\x99s kink in the polar vortex could be the result of warm air over Greenland and Alaska; some point out that changes to the polar vortex have become more common in recent years. 'b'British meteorologists said'b' the brutal storms in Britain since October could be the result of hot Sahara air that got stranded over the North Atlantic.'b'The point stressed by meteorologists the world over is that severe conditions that used to occur infrequently, say once a century, now happen more frequently, with greater and greater consequences. The threat of climate change is real, and our governments should prepare for the damage and dislocations caused by more extreme weather. Common sense would dictate that we attack all the risk factors that might make things worse next time.'b'ATHENS \xe2\x80\x94  The European Union\xe2\x80\x99s rotating presidency may be a symbolic gesture toward equality, but it does allow us to measure a country\xe2\x80\x99s fortunes each time it finds itself in the role. On Jan. 1, Greece took over the leadership at a crucial time for itself and for the union. The most troubled member, still dependent on loans from its partners and with its coalition government hanging on to power by a slim majority in Parliament, will represent the European Union for six months as its 28 members confront major questions on the group\xe2\x80\x99s identity and future.'b'This presidency will not be business as usual. Elections for the European Parliament in May are expected to result in significant gains by parties of the extreme right whose mission is to undermine European unification.'b'Greece\xe2\x80\x99s plight highlights the fact that European Union members are not equal, that some are grappling with debts while others are obliged to lend them money. This has allowed old prejudices to return, testing the limits of solidarity. But Greece, along with its partners and the bureaucrats at the European Union\xe2\x80\x99s headquarters in Brussels and at the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, has to make this presidency a success.'b'This is a make-or-break moment: The members have to show whether they will reinforce the union or let it drift. In terms of the economy, the union has allowed itself to be seen as being as weak as its weakest member. It cannot afford to do this at the political level.'b'The situation is awkward indeed. It is difficult to see how the government of a country that depends on foreign loans will meet the target, set out in the European Union\xe2\x80\x99s strategic framework adopted in December 2012, of strengthening \xe2\x80\x9cthe union\xe2\x80\x99s capacity to respond to the current economic, financial and social challenges.\xe2\x80\x9d Can Greece afford the cost, in treasure and human resources, when its economy has shrunk by roughly a quarter since 2008, with unemployment over 27 percent, with taxpayers groaning under the weight of ever higher taxes in return for fewer benefits, and with the civil service facing drastic cuts? These are questions posed not only by European editorial writers but also by Greek citizens, who wonder whether the money could be put to better use.'b'The issue, though, is not the 50 million euros that Greece expects to spend over the next six months as it hosts some 14 informal ministerial meetings and between 100 and 120 working groups on a range of issues. Rather, is Greece up to the task of being a competent member of the union, and can the union concentrate its resources and vision to make a success of the presidency?'b'The Greek prime minister will not be the European Union \xe2\x80\x9cpresident\xe2\x80\x9d in the White House sense, but rather will present for discussion objectives decided by the organization over a year ago, and his ministers will preside over meetings of their colleagues. The union sets out 18-month policy programs to be executed by the next three countries holding the rotating presidency. Greece is the third presiding country in this program (following Ireland and Lithuania) and a file of some 180 pending issues has been handed over to Athens. The presiding country, of course, is able to highlight some issues, delay others, perhaps even surprise us with an inspired idea (something that has been lacking during the crisis).'b'This is Greece\xe2\x80\x99s fifth presidency since it joined what was then the European Economic Community in 1981. It held the post in 1983, 1988, 1994 and 2003. At the start of its challenging last presidency, in January 2003, unity was threatened by some members (notably Britain and Spain) who aligned themselves with the United States as it prepared to invade Iraq; most members opposed the war. The Greek presidency helped cool things down and, toward the end of the semester, Athens\xe2\x80\x99s ancient agora hosted the signing of the accession treaties, by which 10 new members joined.'b'Of course, 2003 is a world away: Greece was booming and about to host a successful Summer Olympics. In the years that followed, public spending and debt flew out of control, leading to the crisis that made Greece the first country to ask its union partners for support.'b'If Greece\xe2\x80\x99s stewardship is deemed successful,  this may give the government in Athens a necessary push before May\xe2\x80\x99s elections for the European Parliament, which in Greece will coincide with elections for municipal and provincial governments. If the government does badly in those polls (especially in the European Parliament one, which in Greece has always been regarded as a referendum on government policies), Prime Minister Antonis Samaras\xe2\x80\x99s position will be untenable, forcing him to hold early national elections.'b'In the coming months, the European Union will be occupied with fostering economic growth and employment, reaching agreement on a banking union, simplifying procedures to boost competitiveness, and setting policy objectives in the areas of migration, security and justice. These issues are important for the future of the union and its members. Success will depend not as much on what Greece does as on the political will of union members to make tough decisions. As many of these imply handing over more national sovereignty in order to create a stronger union, the stakes are very high: Anything short of success will play into the hands of those who oppose unification, yet the fear of \xe2\x80\x9cEuroskeptic\xe2\x80\x9d parties makes governments wary of handing over more power to the union.'b'Greece will not be the only country to gain if progress is made. But if the European Union chooses to stagnate, more people will question its legitimacy, and all of its members will lose.'b''b'\n'b'Nikos Konstandaras 'b' is the managing editor and a columnist at the newspaper Kathimerini. 'b''b'CAIRO \xe2\x80\x94  Since the revolution of 2011, Egyptians have engaged in almost continuous debate over a critical question: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of country do we want?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This past December, I delivered an answer, on behalf of the Committee of 50 entrusted with amending Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution, to Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s acting president, Adly Mansour. Mr. Mansour recently confirmed that a two-day referendum on this draft will take place next Tuesday and Wednesday. We believe that this new charter, shaped over months of discussion and many drafts, reflects the needs and aspirations of all Egyptians, regardless of religious affiliation, gender, race, political views or economic status.'b'Contrary to what critics say, this document turns the page decisively on both the 2012 and 1971 Constitutions, and thus marks a historic step on our path to a government that is of, by and for the Egyptian people. The 2012 Constitution was rushed through by a single dominating political faction and answered only to its priorities. The 1971 Constitution failed to guarantee vital liberties. In short, both previous Constitutions failed because they denied Egyptians the dignity and freedom they deserve and demand; both those Constitutions have been popularly disavowed.'b'The revision process began in July, when our acting president named a committee of 10 judges, law professors and legal scholars to make amendments. Their recommendations were then transferred to the Committee of 50 to finish that job and produce a foundation for a democratic government.'b'The Committee of 50 gave everyone a seat at the table, including Egyptian feminists and young people. Talk that the process left out critical religious voices is inaccurate: An invitation was extended to all Islamic groups, including the Muslim Brotherhood. Of the parties of political Islam, only the Salafist Al Nour responded (the Muslim Brotherhood did not). All three denominations of our Christian community participated, as did representatives from the underdeveloped provinces of Nubia and Sinai.'b'This representation from across Egyptian society became all the more evident as the committee voted in view of television cameras: Each of the charter\xe2\x80\x99s more than 200 articles and provisions was approved with more than the required three-quarters majority, and the document was adopted unanimously. This year, a popularly elected civilian government will have the opportunity to write laws that improve on this foundation.'b'What I observed firsthand was a rare spirit of solidarity that created a draft constitution to transcend Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s current predicament. Chief among our concerns was to create an accountable system of governance, including, notably, for Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s military. Among other measures, this draft charter gives Parliament \xe2\x80\x94 for the first time in Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s history \xe2\x80\x94 the power to impeach the president, not just for criminal acts but also for violations of the Constitution. Unlike the 1971 charter, it also ensures a separation of powers and limits the elected president to two four-year terms.'b'New oversight will be brought to bear on the military through a National Defense Council that must include civilian and legislative officials alongside officers. The Constitution details those specific crimes committed by civilians that mandate trial in military courts, shielding civilians from the abusive interpretations of previous Constitutions. And for the first time, political parties can be dissolved only by a court ruling of the independent judiciary.'b'Unlike the 2012 Constitution, this draft version criminalizes torture and human trafficking, protects women from violence and commits the state to achieving equality between men and women. It provides greater protection for freedom of expression, press freedom, the pursuit of scientific knowledge and religious liberty, and provides equal protection under the law. Significantly, it places all international human rights treaties to which Egypt is a signatory above even national laws.'b'Constructing democratic institutions and political infrastructure  cannot be done overnight. Many countries over several centuries have embarked on similar journeys, and there are few examples of such momentous change occurring with rapidity and ease. Some of the world\xe2\x80\x99s oldest democracies struggle even now to run effective, pragmatic governments and respond to the will of diverse populations.'b'Egypt is still near the beginning of a crucial period in our storied history. And yet I am confident that we will emerge from this tumultuous transition stronger than before because we are willing to unite to create the political structures necessary for stability, prosperity and democracy to endure for generations.'b'Next week, Egyptians  will have the opportunity to vote on the constitution in the referendum. I know the people of Egypt will embrace this moment and I hope the world will as well. For a nation so infused with its past, Egypt is ready to move forward.'b''b'\n'b'Amr Moussa, 'b' a former minister of foreign affairs for Egypt and secretary general of the Arab League, is the president of the Committee of 50.'b''b'PHNOM PENH, Cambodia \xe2\x80\x94  On Dec. 29, more than 100,000 Cambodians \xe2\x80\x94 garment workers, teachers, farmers and students from all over the country \xe2\x80\x94 marched through the streets of the capital calling for Hun Sen, our long-serving prime minister-dictator, to step down or allow an independent investigation into the flawed national elections that took place in July.'b'The massive demonstration was the culmination of months of nonviolent rallies and marches led by the Cambodia National Rescue Party (C.N.R.P.). It was also the most significant challenge to Hun Sen\xe2\x80\x99s 28-year reign of exploitation and corruption.'b'And he could not tolerate it. He would sooner draw blood than enact real reform.'b'For almost three decades, Hun Sen \xe2\x80\x94 a Khmer Rouge defector who was put in power after Vietnam toppled Pol Pot\xe2\x80\x99s regime in 1979 \xe2\x80\x94 has convinced foreign governments to pour aid into the country, even while the ruling Cambodian People\xe2\x80\x99s Party has rigged elections, sold off our natural resources, imprisoned journalists, union leaders, opposition politicians and human rights activists. Some 250,000 people have been evicted because of land concessions that favor the rich and well-connected.'b'On July 28, vast swaths of the country \xe2\x80\x94 civil servants, indebted farmers, educated youth from both the cities and the countryside \xe2\x80\x94 tried to vote for change. But the election was neither free nor fair. A recent report by the Electoral Reform Alliance, a group of independent local and international nongovernmental organizations, describes massive irregularities, including fraudulent voter registries, which may have disenfranchised 1.25 million eligible voters.  So the peaceful protests began.'b'Factory workers joined the movement a few weeks ago. About 500,000 Cambodians are garment workers; most are employed by factories owned by foreigners with the backing of high-ranking Cambodian officials or the military and produce clothes for international brands like H&amp;M, Nike, Gap and Adidas. After the government refused to raise the minimum wage to $160 per month, some unions called for a general strike and workers started staging nonviolent sit-ins in front of the Labor Ministry and the Council of Ministers.'b'Then, last Friday, in an industrial area on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, hundreds of military policemen and municipal police forces  opened fire with AK-47\xe2\x80\x99s and handguns on a crowd of protesters.  At least four people were killed and over 29 were injured, most garment workers.  The human rights group Licadho called the shootings \xe2\x80\x9cthe worst state violence against civilians to hit Cambodia in 15 years.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The next day, police forces, municipal security guards  and thugs  wearing motorcycle helmets and red armbands stormed Democracy Square, a park the government had designated as a haven for peaceful protest. They evicted its occupants, wielding axes, hammers, metal pipes and wooden sticks. They then destroyed what had become, for the country\xe2\x80\x99s myriad marginalized citizens, a rare zone for free speech, a meeting place, a sanctuary. They tore down the stage and leveled a Buddhist altar. They smashed loudspeakers, metal donation boxes and first-aid tents.'b'Fear, and memories of past crackdowns, rapidly spread beyond Democracy Square that afternoon as thousands of security forces  patrolled Phnom Penh to break up public gatherings and threaten bystanders, while military helicopters, newly purchased from China, buzzed overhead.'b'That same day the Interior Ministry  revoked freedom of assembly. And the municipal court issued a summons for the C.N.R.P.\xe2\x80\x99s president, Sam Rainsy, the C.N.R.P.\xe2\x80\x99s vice president, Kem Sokha, and the head of the Cambodian Independent Teachers\xe2\x80\x99 Association, Rong Chhun, to appear next Tuesday for questioning about incitement of criminal acts and social disturbance.'b'Yet blame for the chaos and the violence lies with the government.'b'On Dec. 20, after the C.N.R.P. announced that it would call for sit-ins on main thoroughfares if the stalemate continued, Hun Sen issued this warning: \xe2\x80\x9cBlocking roads is blocking one\xe2\x80\x99s own blood vein.\xe2\x80\x9d The government, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cwould not allow action that would jeopardize national security, and I would urge precaution of the third hand,\xe2\x80\x9d a euphemism for government repression. It wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the first time if, last Friday, the authorities had sent in agents provocateurs  among the protesters in order to cause disturbances that could then justify the government\xe2\x80\x99s intervention.'b'Despite the government\xe2\x80\x99s attempt to scare them into silence, the Cambodian people remain strong and united in their desire to see their country move out of the shadow of the Khmer Rouge and into the light that is genuine democracy.'b'In this, they deserve more support than they have received. The international community, long content to take Cambodia\xe2\x80\x99s apparent economic and social stability at face value, must now recognize the brutality of this government\xe2\x80\x99s methods and help put an end to them and their underlying causes.'b'Foreign governments could provide technical and financial support for electoral reforms, including reform of the voter-registration system, so that a new election could be held within two years. An investigation must be conducted into the government\xe2\x80\x99s  use of lethal force against protesters, perhaps by the International Criminal Court itself.'b'Foreign companies also have a role to play, by easing the despair of underpaid factory workers: If they reduced their profit margins just slightly, the workers could be paid a living wage without jeopardizing Cambodia\xe2\x80\x99s long-term competitiveness in the garment sector. Gap, Adidas and other companies took a welcome step on Tuesday by condemning the use of force in an open letter to the government and calling for \xe2\x80\x9ca robust minimum wage review mechanism based on international good practices.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Democracy Square now stands empty, save for the military police who watch over it. Must it become a symbol of another dark day in Cambodia\xe2\x80\x99s history, made darker by those who watched and did nothing?'b''b'\n'b'Mu Sochua, 'b' a former minister of women\xe2\x80\x99s affairs, is a member-elect of the National Assembly for the Cambodia National Rescue Party.'b' 'b' 'b' 'b'\n'b''b'NAIROBI, Kenya \xe2\x80\x94  Terrorism is a global reality, and for me as a Kenyan, this struck close to home in September with the siege of the Westgate mall. Yet in many ways, growing up in Nairobi I was always in the midst of terror. As a boy living in extreme poverty in Kibera, one of Africa\xe2\x80\x99s largest slums, I learned early on that I was disposable, that human life is not equally valued. Life expectancy in Kibera is estimated at 30 years, compared with 64 in the rest of Kenya and 70 worldwide. In Kibera, people are desensitized to death. Living is understood to be the exception.'b'I am 29 years old \xe2\x80\x94 on the threshold of a new decade of life. All my close friends from childhood, save for two, were robbed of this experience. Some took risks to feed their families; for stealing bread or charcoal, they were shot by the police. Others, who worked for as little as $1 per day, fell from construction sites or burned in factory fires. Still others perished in the violence after the 2007 election. Violence and loss became part of day-to-day life.'b'These are more than singular tragedies; they contribute to the psyche of being poor. This psyche inculcates hopelessness, dispels a belief in the possibility of tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s being better than today, compels a resignation to the fact that you may suffer the same tragic fate as your peers, and fuels anger because there is no escape and you did not choose this \xe2\x80\x94 you simply drew life\xe2\x80\x99s short straw.'b'This, perhaps, is terrorism\xe2\x80\x99s fertile ground. Because if you grew up as I did, self-protection requires coming to terms with violence and terror. Violence becomes a vehicle of survival. My friend Boi was 16 when he joined a gang with the goal of supporting his mother and sister. If stealing or fighting was the only way, he was ready. In the end, he was shot dead.'b'An environment in which you cannot get a job despite ability, ambition and persistence fosters anger. My friend James and I used to leave the slum together each morning to look for work as day laborers. We always hoped we\xe2\x80\x99d be lucky, only to be told \xe2\x80\x9cnot today\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 day after day after day. Then one day, James and I got construction jobs. While carrying heavy stones, two of James\xe2\x80\x99s fingers were crushed. He was not compensated and was out of work for more than two years. Later, James caught another break and got a job as a security guard at an upper-class estate. The estate was robbed, and James was fired and never paid.'b'Something broke in James. In the constant degradation he saw that for people like us there was no justice. He joined a local group infamous for terrorizing the community, robbing and stealing. James was ready to die, willing to do anything to provide what he could for his family. Today, this world of violence and uncertainty remains his reality.'b'News reports inform us that Kenya\xe2\x80\x99s slums are ripe for terrorist recruitment. No one is born a terrorist. But being paid a reported $1,000 to undergo militant training in Somalia is more than enough financial incentive; the young people in Nairobi\xe2\x80\x99s slums are accustomed to taking risks that pay far less.'b'A 2011 study in the Journal of Peace Research found that the perpetuation of Islamist extremism was more significantly associated with urban poverty than with variables like religiosity, lack of education and income dissatisfaction. The urban poor are so close to the city\xe2\x80\x99s opportunities \xe2\x80\x94 but they always remain out of reach.'b'Given the link between urban poverty and terrorism, the best strategy to limit the power of militant groups to seduce recruits is to fight poverty, not terrorism. Instead of investing billions of dollars on drones, let\xe2\x80\x99s focus on augmenting economic opportunities and providing basic and essential services like health care and education.'b'Every day, more and more people arrive in Nairobi, drawn by the hope of a better life, only to settle in slums. More than half of those living in Africa\xe2\x80\x99s urban slums are between the ages of 15 and 24. Without access to education, this generation has little hope of escaping its straitened conditions. We must capture the potential of urban youth before they are led to believe that the path of violence is their only option.'b'Over the past few years, the Shabab, the Somali militant group that took credit for the Westgate massacre, has inflicted terror on the citizens of Kenya, throwing grenades into local bars, bus stations and villages near the border \xe2\x80\x94 places frequented by the poor and lower middle class. Only Westgate, however, garnered enormous international media attention. This was of course because of the scale of the tragedy, but also because of the affluent demographic it primarily affected.'b'Westgate was a place marked by economic prosperity, wholly inaccessible to so many, including those who might be recruited from Nairobi\xe2\x80\x99s slums to undertake similar acts. As we condemn those who have carried out these heinous acts, so too must we condemn the systems that perpetuate extremism. We must install new systems of urban promise.'b'If we pursue an antiterrorism strategy based on tactical strikes, it will only further a cycle of violence. The perpetual sense of anger experienced in urban poverty will ensure that there are always new terrorist leaders to replace those who are killed. The war on terror can be won only through education, promise and real opportunities.'b'It is time to give young men like my friends, and like those today living in urban slums, hope. That is the only way to end the violence that preys on our cities\xe2\x80\x99 most vulnerable.'b''b'\n'b'Kennedy Odede 'b' is the founder and chief executive of Shining Hope for Communities, a social services organization, and a 2013 New Voices fellow at the Aspen Institute. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'On Hawaii, a Lonely Quest for Fact'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 5):'b'Your article about genetically modified crops says that there is a \xe2\x80\x9cglobal scientific consensus\xe2\x80\x9d that they are safe, and suggests that opponents are driven by emotion, not fact.'b'As a medical research scientist, I disagree that there is any such consensus, and there is no evidence that any genetically modified product is safe. There is no required safety testing, no epidemiological study relating consumption to health.'b'Although the industry aggressively tries to discredit all studies showing potential harm, there are many showing toxicity in animals that predict serious medical consequences in humans from long-term exposure. Finally, contrary to industry claims, genetically modified crops have produced no increase in yield, have elevated the use of herbicides tenfold, and have resulted in no social or economic benefit except for the reduction of factory farm labor costs.'b'The public has every right to distrust what it is told about genetically modified food safety.'b'DAVID SCHUBERT'b'\nLa Jolla, Calif., Jan. 6, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a professor at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Your article about the struggle to ban genetically modified crops sadly demonstrates how belief without evidence is trumping science (belief based on evidence). There is not a shred of valid evidence that such crops pose any danger; all the worldwide evidence points to major benefits.'b'As a child, I often read of recurrent famines in places like India and China that caused millions to starve to death. These days we no longer hear of such famines. Why? Because of the Green Revolution. The Green Revolution has saved a billion lives. The use of genetically modified organisms, an extension of the Green Revolution, has increased agricultural yields and developed crops designed to combat specific nutritional deficiencies (\xe2\x80\x9cgolden rice\xe2\x80\x9d is an example). Do devotees of the anti-G.M.O. religion regret this?'b'Effective solutions to the many far-reaching problems of this world will be achieved only by the intelligent and wise application of science. Banning G.M.O. crops is an appalling step in the wrong direction.'b'MARVIN SCHISSEL'b'\nRoslyn Heights, N.Y., Jan. 5, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Your article about the Hawaii councilman and his \xe2\x80\x9clonely quest\xe2\x80\x9d for facts about genetically modified crops ignores the most fundamental problem associated with G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s: In most cases they are used to prop up an inherently fragile and profoundly destructive agricultural model that we ought to be figuring out how to replace.'b'Most of the problems that G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9csolve\xe2\x80\x9d are the inevitable consequence of industrial monoculture: a single species and often a single genome planted acre upon acre and sometimes county upon county.'b'There is a whole world of research, some of it mainstream, some of it small-scale and informal, on ways to grow diverse crops and raise livestock in ways that compromise little in the way of yields but that create natural barriers against disease, while building the soil instead of degrading it.'b'Although many G.M.O. opponents have taken the bait, it\xe2\x80\x99s in the interest of the companies and endowed institutions that promote G.M.O.\xe2\x80\x99s to let this issue degrade into a narrow debate about whether particular G.M.O. crops cause health problems in those who consume them. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'High-Speed Train in California Is Caught in a Political Storm'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 7):'b'The government has managed many large projects ranging from the Interstate highway system to the Apollo moon program. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The rules for election to the Baseball Hall of Fame state, \xe2\x80\x9cVoting shall be based upon the player\xe2\x80\x99s record, playing ability, integrity, sportsmanship, character and contributions to the game.\xe2\x80\x9d If Pete Rose gets his \xe2\x80\x9cshot\xe2\x80\x9d and is voted in, an emphasis on his playing abilities \xe2\x80\x94 at the expense of three of the listed criteria \xe2\x80\x94 will be required.'b'In that case, to offset the ensuing stir, voters would be well served to recall the words of the legendary baseball journalist Red Smith regarding another gifted player-manager still awaiting enshrinement: \xe2\x80\x9cIf votes are based, as the rule says, on the player\xe2\x80\x99s integrity, sportsmanship, and character, Gil Hodges will ride in. Those words were coined for him.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'MORT ZACHTER'b'\nPrinceton, N.J., Jan. 6, 2014'b''b''b'The writer is the author of a forthcoming book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Team Came First: A Biography of Gil Hodges.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'AMERICAN students are enrolling in college in record numbers, but they\xe2\x80\x99re also dropping out in droves. Barely half of those who start four-year colleges, and only a third of community college students, graduate. That\xe2\x80\x99s one of the worst records among developed nations, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a substantial drain on the economy. The American Institutes for Research estimates the cost of those dropouts, measured in lost earnings and taxes, at $4.5 billion. Incalculable are the lost opportunities for social mobility and the stillborn professional careers.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a remedy at hand, though, and it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty straightforward. Nationwide, universities need to give undergraduates the care and attention akin to what\xe2\x80\x99s lavished on students at elite institutions.'b'If that help is forthcoming, graduation rates more than double, according to several evaluations of an innovative program at the City University of New York\xe2\x80\x99s community colleges.'b'Over the past month, CUNY\xe2\x80\x99s Accelerated Study in Associate Programs (ASAP) has garnered hosannas in the media for its package of comprehensive financial resources, student support systems and impressive graduation rates. The social policy leader MDRC is conducting a multiyear random-assignment study of ASAP and, in a just-released 'b'report'b', describes it as \xe2\x80\x9cunparalleled in large-scale experimental evaluations of programs in higher education to date.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nearly 90 percent of students who attend a top-ranked university earn a bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree in four years. While these undergraduates may well be among the best and brightest, they also get kid-gloves treatment. If they run into trouble, an army of helpmates stands at the ready. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom moving day as a freshman through graduation and beyond,\xe2\x80\x9d Harvard assures its students, \xe2\x80\x9cour advisers are here to help and support you at every step.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The situation is entirely different for most undergraduates, especially poor and minority students. All too often they\xe2\x80\x99re steered to schools where they receive little if any support in mastering tough courses, decoding arcane requirements for a major, sorting out life problems or navigating the maze of institutional requirements. Graduation rates at these so-called dropout factories, especially those in urban areas that largely serve low-income, underprepared minority populations, are as abysmal as 5 percent.'b'Where a student goes makes all the difference. Consider a Chicago public high school graduate with a grade-point average of 3.5. If she enrolls at Chicago State University, a Washington Monthly 'b'investigation'b' shows, the odds against her finishing are high \xe2\x80\x94 the school\xe2\x80\x99s six-year graduation rate hovers at 20 percent. Her chances measurably improve if she attends the University of Illinois at Chicago, where the completion rate is 57 percent. And if she goes to Northwestern, just a few miles away, 93 percent of her classmates will graduate.'b'Six years ago, CUNY decided to confront the high dropout rate at its community colleges with the ASAP initiative. The results are stunning: 56 percent of the first two cohorts of more than 1,500 students have graduated, compared with just 23 percent of a comparable group that didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the same experience. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, most of those graduates are currently pursuing a bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree.'b'The program for community-college students addresses money issues, which are typically students\xe2\x80\x99 top concern, by covering tuition that\xe2\x80\x99s not paid for by federal and state grants, as well as paying for public transit and giving students free use of textbooks, saving them upward of $900 a year. To help balance the demands of college with work, life and family obligations, students take their classes in a consolidated course schedule (morning, afternoon or evening).'b'While the added dollars make a big difference, students consistently report in individual profiles found on the CUNY ASAP 'b'website'b' that the personal touch \xe2\x80\x94 biweekly seminars and one-on-one advising \xe2\x80\x94 is crucial. The ASAP adviser for 'b'Desiree Rivera'b', a LaGuardia student, became her life coach. \xe2\x80\x9cI am completely able to let my guard down around her and discuss both personal and academic struggles,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Rivera wrote on her profile. \xe2\x80\x9cHer support has played a major role in my success as an ASAP student.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'An 'b'evaluation'b' last year by the economist Henry M. Levin, a co-director of Teachers College, Columbia University\xe2\x80\x99s Center for Benefit-Cost Studies in Education, and Emma Garc\xc3\xada, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, D.C., concludes that although ASAP isn\xe2\x80\x99t cheap \xe2\x80\x94 the program costs, on average, $3,900 per student each year \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s a solid investment for New York City\xe2\x80\x99s taxpayers. Dr. Levin and Dr. Garc\xc3\xada calculate that the total lifetime benefits \xe2\x80\x94 from increased tax revenues as well as savings in crime, welfare and health costs \xe2\x80\x94 are a whopping $205,514 per associate degree graduate.'b'These results have persuaded CUNY to triple the size of the community college program to 4,000 students by fall 2014, and the system is considering expanding ASAP to its other schools. But this strategy merits a nationwide rollout, for it promises a significant increase in the number of educated workers that the nation badly needs.'b'Well, that didn\xe2\x80\x99t take long.'b'After wall-to-wall Obamacare disaster ruminations, the terrain of the political landscape is shifting, as it always does, and refocusing attention on some familiar themes.'b'The larger-than-life, straight-from-the-hip, quick-with-the-tongue paladin of the Palisades, Chris Christie, is beginning to emerge as small, petty and vindictive.'b'In September, several lanes of the George Washington Bridge were closed, grinding traffic to a halt in the town of Fort Lee, N.J., whose mayor just so happened to have refused to endorse Christie for re-election. Private sector hiring in December was reportedly higher than it had been since November 2012. According to The Wall Street Journal:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPrivate-sector payrolls increased by 238,000 positions in December, according to the national employment report compiled by payroll processor Automatic Data Processing Inc. and forecasting firm Moody\xe2\x80\x99s Analytics.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Democrats are pressing their income inequality message on several fronts, including moving to vote on extending long-term unemployment for three more months. It\xe2\x80\x99s by no means clear that the measure will pass, particularly not without budgetary offsets that some Republicans are demanding. But these income inequality issues do resonate with voters. And as we observed the 50th anniversary of the war on poverty, these issues take on added weight. A reader named Frank 'b'posted on my Facebook page'b': \xe2\x80\x9cAll the government aid/handouts in the world will not make people better parents. This is why the ideas from the left, although always made with the best of intentions, never work. ... In fact, the first lesson of the war on poverty is that we can make progress against poverty, but that it\xe2\x80\x99s an uphill slog.'b'The most accurate measures, using Census Bureau figures that take account of benefits, suggest that poverty rates have fallen by more than one-third since 1968. There\xe2\x80\x99s a consensus that without the war on poverty, other forces (such as mass incarceration, a rise in single mothers and the decline in trade unions) would have lifted poverty much higher.'b'A Columbia University study suggests that without government benefits, the poverty rate would have soared to 31 percent in 2012. Indeed, an average of 27 million people were lifted annually out of poverty by social programs between 1968 and 2012, 'b'according to the White House Council of Economic Advisers'b'.'b'The best example of how government antipoverty programs can succeed involves the elderly. In 1960, 'b'about 35 percent of older Americans were poor'b'. In 2012, 9 percent were. That\xe2\x80\x99s because senior citizens vote, so politicians listened to them and buttressed programs like Social Security and Medicare.'b'In contrast, children are voiceless, so they are the age group most likely to be poor today. That\xe2\x80\x99s a practical and moral failure.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t want anybody to be poor, but, if I have to choose, I\xe2\x80\x99d say it\xe2\x80\x99s more of a priority to help kids than seniors. In part, that\xe2\x80\x99s because when kids are deprived of opportunities, the consequences can include a lifetime of educational failure, crime and underemployment.'b'Research from neuroscience underscores why early interventions are so important. Early brain development turns out to have lifelong consequences, and research from human and animal studies alike suggests that a high-stress early childhood in poverty changes the physical brain in subtle ways that impair educational performance and life outcomes.'b'A careful review of antipoverty programs in a new book, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Legacies of the War on Poverty'b',\xe2\x80\x9d shows that many of them have a clear impact \xe2\x80\x94 albeit sometimes not as great an impact as advocates hoped.'b'For starters, one of the most basic social programs that works \xe2\x80\x94 indeed pays for itself many times over \xe2\x80\x94 is family-planning assistance for at-risk teenage girls. This has actually been one of America\xe2\x80\x99s most successful social programs in recent years. The 'b'teenage birthrate has fallen'b' by half over roughly the last 20 years.'b'Another hugely successful array of programs involved parent coaching to get pregnant women to drink and smoke less and to encourage at-risk moms to talk to their children more. Programs like Nurse-Family Partnership, Healthy Families America, Child First, Save the Children and Thirty Million Words Project all have had great success in helping parents do a better job with their kids.'b'Early education likewise has strong evidence of impact. Critics note that in Head Start, for example, gains in I.Q. seem to fade within a few years. That\xe2\x80\x99s true and disappointing. But in the last five years, robust studies from 'b'scholars like David Deming'b' have shown that graduates of Head Start also have improved life outcomes: higher high school graduation and college attendance rates, and less likely to be out of school and out of a job.'b'Another area of success: Programs that encourage jobs, especially for the most at-risk groups. The earned-income tax credit is a huge benefit to the working poor and to society.'b'Likewise, a program called Career Academies has had excellent results training at-risk teenagers in specialized careers and giving them practical work experience. Even eight years later, those young people randomly assigned to Career Academies are earning significantly more than those in control groups.'b'As that example suggests, we increasingly have first-rate research \xe2\x80\x94 randomized controlled trials, testing antipoverty programs as rigorously as if they were pharmaceuticals \xe2\x80\x94 that give us solid evidence of what works or doesn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'So let\xe2\x80\x99s drop the bombast and look at the evidence.'b'Critics are right that antipoverty work is difficult and that dependency can be a problem. But the premise of so much of today\xe2\x80\x99s opposition to food stamps and other benefits \xe2\x80\x94 that government assistance inevitably fails \xe2\x80\x94 is just wrong. And child poverty is as unconscionable in a rich nation today as it was half a century ago.'b'There was good news last week in Myanmar when President Thein Sein stated his support for changing the nation\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution to allow \xe2\x80\x9cany citizen,\xe2\x80\x9d including Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate, to run for the presidency in the 2015 elections.'b'Parliament is reviewing a 2008 constitutional provision that bars presidential candidates with close family members \xe2\x80\x9cwho owe allegiance to a foreign power.\xe2\x80\x9d Since Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi\xe2\x80\x99s sons are British citizens, that provision would prohibit her from entering the race. Never before have Europeans been more tired and disillusioned with the promises of the Brussels mandarins. In the run-up to the European parliamentary elections in May, the gap between what\xe2\x80\x99s economically necessary and what\xe2\x80\x99s politically justifiable is growing dangerously wide.'b'Europe has come through the last years of crisis with a new momentum, and yet the situation is reminiscent of how a star reaches its greatest density just before it explodes. If that is so, is there a remedy for what the analyst Roderick Parkes has called the \xe2\x80\x9csupernova moment\xe2\x80\x9d?'b'There is. But it would require Germany, the union\xe2\x80\x99s largest and most powerful driver, to support an idea that the country has always fiercely rejected: to activate the thrust reverser for certain parts of the unification project as a way to reduce the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s political stress. It would mean, more specifically, listening to the ideas being laid out by the British prime minister, David Cameron.'b'Integration, Mr. Cameron argues, should be cut back in a variety of policy-making realms \xe2\x80\x94 social and employment laws, for example, or environmental legislation \xe2\x80\x94 and shifted back to the individual countries. For the sake of Europe, she should think again.'b'Polls show anti-union forces gaining ground in core nations. Both parties have just agreed to join forces for the European elections. The very assembly that has always been a club of the European Union vanguard could turn into an arena of political rowdies, trying to destroy the body from within.'b'One wonders how many more warnings Ms. Merkel needs before she realizes that if Europe must be founded on democratic consent, its limits, for the moment, may have been reached. At nearly every opportunity in which voters were allowed to have their say about the form, speed and depth of integration, they said \xe2\x80\x9cstop.\xe2\x80\x9d But the architects of Europe never listened. Now they may have no choice.'b'In the past, integrationists have seen unification as proceeding in just one direction, with the only variable being the speed. But this critical point offers a unique possibility for a spring cleaning \xe2\x80\x94 not to retreat, but to remove those functions of the union that have proved less useful and more controversial than their creators expected.'b'A first move should be for Europe\xe2\x80\x99s leaders to admit that the history of the Continent\xe2\x80\x99s integration has not been a complete success. Everyone but them can admit that the European Union has grown far too big on the small issues, and remained far too small on the big issues; it has banned incandescent light bulbs, but it is unable to implement a common energy policy. It is too soft on the hard issues, and too hard on the soft issues; unable to pool its military capabilities, while being frenetically outspoken about the alleged foreign-policy mistakes of others.'b'Astonishingly, it is failing to deliver on the one promise it made above all others: to create a successful single-currency bloc. One reason for the euro\xe2\x80\x99s problems is that the commission is simply ignored by national governments when it comes to existential political questions.'b'Europe\xe2\x80\x99s leaders should also concede that the so-called euro-skeptics have often been right in the past, and that it was a mistake to tar them as primitive, reactionary heretics. And so it should be with the European Union.'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t fear Mr. Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s ideas. I am a skeptic because I am European.'b''b'\n'b'Jochen Bittner 'b' is a political editor for the weekly newspaper Die Zeit. 'b''b'NEW YORK \xe2\x80\x94  When I told my children we were moving from Russia to America, I promised them paradise, more or less. My parents had done the same when they brought me here 33 years ago, to escape anti-Semitic discrimination. Over the years we had spent waiting for our exit visas, they pored over Soviet \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s\xe2\x80\x99 letters by the yellow kitchen light and culled good news to use against me. Like when they said, in response to my repeated requests, that I could not have a pair of American jeans, which cost a month\xe2\x80\x99s salary on the black market in Moscow, because once we emigrated to America they could buy me jeans for $10.'b'As a young teenager I was equally concerned about not owning a pair of Levi\xe2\x80\x99s and about being Jewish; both circumstances made me a misfit. I was concerned that we were exchanging one country in which Jews were a minority for another. The \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s\xe2\x80\x99 letters contained little information on this: Unlike the price of jeans, ethnicity \xe2\x80\x94 we thought of our Jewishness as an ethnicity, not a religion \xe2\x80\x94 seemed to be a nonissue. I was skeptical, but I had no choice about following my parents out of the country.'b'In Boston, where I went to high school, I quickly learned the very peculiar fact that being Jewish meant being part of the majority \xe2\x80\x94 the white majority. Many Soviet \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s, buoyed by this discovery, adopted rabidly racist attitudes. This embarrassed their kids, the people of my generation, who, as they became American adults, usually moved steadily to the left of their parents.'b'I did that. I also became a journalist, went back to Moscow as an American correspondent in the early 1990s, stayed, restored my Russian citizenship, eventually started a Russian family, and then, a few weeks ago, found myself emigrating again \xe2\x80\x94 this time to escape the Kremlin\xe2\x80\x99s anti-gay campaign.'b'And, just like my parents before me, I found myself promising my children that America would feel different because, for the first time in their lives, they would not feel they were different. My oldest son, like me, looks distinctively non-Russian and has known this his whole life. All of our three children stand apart from the crowd because they are being raised by lesbians. I promised the kids that in America they would just be free to be themselves, unmarked. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t mention that life without labels, which they have never known, is always the prerogative of the majority.'b'We neighborhood-shopped and chose Harlem \xe2\x80\x94 among other reasons, because many people who are roughly my age and in roughly my field of work are moving to the neighborhood. Soon enough, I was speaking to one such woman. She mentioned she sometimes sensed resentment from Harlem\xe2\x80\x99s old-timers. She said she had been the target of \xe2\x80\x9cracist remarks.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I cringed. This woman was white, and the remarks had been made by people who were not. And I knew there was no such thing as \xe2\x80\x9creverse racism\xe2\x80\x9d: You cannot be the object of racial discrimination if you are a member of the powerful majority. I had learned this as an American before I became a Russian again.'b'The day after that conversation, my 12-year-old daughter took her toddler brother to a playground, only to return very soon and very shaken.'b'This park is Harlem in miniature. There are two playgrounds, less than 300 yards apart, an old basic one and a new shiny one. In the new playground, well-dressed toddlers of different races, most of them minded by dark-skinned nannies, played together. At the old one, a few black kids played while their older siblings kept reluctant watch. A couple of drunken men loitered nearby. Apparently, one of them had lashed out at my daughter, calling her a \xe2\x80\x9cwhite bitch.\xe2\x80\x9d He then collected his kids from the playground, making it clear this was done on her account.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIsn\xe2\x80\x99t this racism?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked me, shocked.'b'Somehow, my model, which denied the possibility of racism directed against the majority, could not account for the power dynamics involved in being a child being berated by an adult.'b'Back home, the first contender for the position of the toddler\xe2\x80\x99s nanny showed up for her interview. She was a Russian speaker who has lived in New York for many years, and as soon as she walked through the door, she started berating black and Latino nannies, who, she said, can\xe2\x80\x99t even take care of their own children. I ushered her out as soon as I could.'b'This kind of racism we were used to, and it was a good starting point for the complicated conversation I\xe2\x80\x99ll be having with my kids as we all learn to live in America.'b''b'\n'b'Masha Gessen\xe2\x80\x99s 'b' latest book is \xe2\x80\x9cWords Will Break Cement: The Passion of Pussy Riot.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Stanford, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94  As Iranian and Western diplomats continue to negotiate over Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program, the details will matter more and more. Obstinacy and obfuscation will return the two sides to deadlock. But there is hope for the long term if Iran and America are willing to break with the past.'b'Iran has very little to show for its 50 years of nuclear pursuit. It has only one commercial reactor ready for electricity production at Bushehr that was supplied by Russia without Iran learning much about the technologies needed for the manufacturing and construction of reactors. The country also has an aging 1960s-era American-supplied research reactor on its last legs of medical isotope production.'b'The heavy-water reactor Iran is building at Arak, ostensibly for medical isotope production, remains a major hurdle in negotiations. The current reactor design appears much better suited for producing bomb-grade plutonium than for civilian uses \xe2\x80\x94 and if producing plutonium were the goal, it would take several years for such production.'b'Iran\xe2\x80\x99s pride and joy, its uranium centrifuge program, can enrich in one year as much uranium as the European consortium, Urenco, can produce in about five hours. A ten-fold increase in Iran\xe2\x80\x99s centrifuge capacity would be required to enrich enough uranium fuel for its Bushehr reactor alone. And no matter how many more centrifuges Iran installs, it can never become self-sufficient because it does not possess adequate uranium ore reserves for a large-scale nuclear energy program. It could purchase enrichment services on the global marketplace just as it would have to buy the natural uranium to feed into the centrifuges.'b'All Iran has today is the capacity to produce small amounts of reactor fuel or, if it decides to, one or two bomb\xe2\x80\x99s worth of highly enriched uranium per year (which it would then need to weaponize).'b'Meanwhile, the direct costs of its nuclear pursuit have been enormous. And the indirect costs to the nation of keeping the nuclear weapons option open, in terms of political and scientific isolation plus economic sanctions, are staggering. If Iran\xe2\x80\x99s endgame really is a civilian nuclear power program, it will require a fundamentally different approach.'b'The best economic option for Tehran would simply be to get out of the nuclear fuel-cycle business altogether, but this is unlikely given Iran\xe2\x80\x99s insistence on its sovereign right to nuclear energy.'b'A second option would be to settle for a modest nuclear electricity program relying on the Bushehr reactor and construction of one or two more Russian-built reactors. Iran could maintain the current arrangement with Russia \xe2\x80\x94 that is, have Moscow supply the nuclear fuel and take back the spent fuel. Iran could then simply forgo all indigenous nuclear power development, including enrichment and the final disposal of spent fuel. It would not be doing so under pressure, but rather acting in its own best interest.'b'If Iran insists on a large and mostly indigenous nuclear electricity program, it can succeed only through international cooperation, not isolation. Like South Korea and Japan, Iran can never become fully independent because it lacks large indigenous uranium resources. It takes decades for countries without an established industrial and regulatory nuclear infrastructure to produce large amounts of nuclear electricity and requires close cooperation with established nuclear suppliers.'b'The lesson for Iran, based on other nations\xe2\x80\x99 experiences, is that it should concentrate on developing the capability to fabricate reactor fuel elements and reactor components, and learning how to build nuclear power plants. Japan and South Korea became leading global reactor vendors by doing so. This could constitute a pragmatic and honorable choice. Domestic enrichment would be abandoned because it isn\xe2\x80\x99t economical. And Iran would forgo the reprocessing of spent fuel because it isn\xe2\x80\x99t cost effective.'b'Such a solution offers the best opportunities for technical and industrial development with greatest economic gain and least danger of proliferation.'b'For the Arak reactor, Iran can still make technical changes that would reduce the proliferation risk and agree to send spent fuel out of the country to eliminate concerns about plutonium production.'b'A radical but even better solution would be to cooperate with other countries that sell and build reactors and tailor the design for medical and research applications in order to limit fears of proliferation. Such reactors are typically operated as international facilities. One is being constructed by South Korea in Jordan and an Argentine-built reactor has operated in Australia for the past six years. Such an arrangement would bring Iran into a cooperative relationship with the International Atomic Energy Agency instead of a confrontational one and integrate, rather than isolate, its nuclear program.'b'Sixty years after President Dwight D. Eisenhower announced the Atoms for Peace program, one lesson is clear: Civilian nuclear programs flourish only through cooperation and openness. Secrecy and isolation are typically signs of a nuclear weapons program.'b'If Iran accepts these pragmatic approaches to nuclear energy, it can resolve the nuclear stalemate in a manner that serves its people well and is acceptable to the international community.'b'Appropriately timed sanctions relief could then convince Tehran to implement the Additional Protocol of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which would provide the unprecedented transparency required to demonstrate the peaceful nature of its program.'b'A successful nuclear deal would also provide an enormous boost for beleaguered global nonproliferation efforts and possibly lead to a productive American-Iranian relationship that could deal with the many complex security problems impeding stability in the Middle East.'b''b'\n'b'Siegfried S.
