Both currently work at the Stanford University Center for International Security and Cooperation. 'b''b'Social media are playing an important new role in Indian democracy. A social media campaign by the Electoral Commission drew record levels of voter registration and turnout in elections held in four Indian states, including the capital, New Delhi, in November and December.'b'Of 790 million eligible Indian voters, about 160 million are first-time voters between the ages of 18 and 24 years old. Political parties are also embracing social media to reach voters, including cellphone messaging. Social media are credited with helping the new Common Man party and its candidate, Arvind Kejriwal, win a surprise victory in Delhi against the Congress and Bharatiya Janata parties.'b'But social media can also be subject to significant abuse. Some politicians have been accused of boosting their apparent popularity on social media with legions of followers who don\xe2\x80\x99t exist and of using social media to smear their opponents. Worse, social media have been used to fan violence against religious and ethnic groups; the dissemination of a fraudulent video may have helped spark deadly clashes between Hindus and Muslims in the city of Muzaffarnagar in September.'b'Meanwhile, the Indian government has used the 2008 Information Technology (Amendment) Act to increase monitoring and censorship of social media. In 2012, two women were arrested after posting a comment on Facebook that angered politicians in Mumbai. Journalists have had their Twitter accounts disabled, and cartoonists whose works poke fun at officials have had their social media accounts closed.'b'Last year, the government rolled out a Central Monitoring System with vast powers to monitor citizens\xe2\x80\x99 communications. Human Rights Watch called the new system \xe2\x80\x9cchilling\xe2\x80\x9d in its scope. According to Freedom House, India had the steepest decline in Internet freedom of any country in the year ending in April 2013.'b'The Electoral Commission of India has asked social media providers to monitor their sites for fraud in the run-up to the general elections in April this year. That would be helpful. But Indian voters must also demand that their government bring transparency and accountability to electronic surveillance.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 Twenty years ago this Saturday, the commander of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Rwanda wrote a 'b'coded cable 'b'to his superiors in New York that has come to be known as the \xe2\x80\x9cgenocide fax.\xe2\x80\x9d Citing inside information from a \xe2\x80\x9ctop-level trainer\xe2\x80\x9d for a pro-regime militia group, Brig. Gen. Rom\xc3\xa9o Dallaire warned of an \xe2\x80\x9canti-Tutsi extermination\xe2\x80\x9d plot.'b'The refusal by United Nations officials to approve the general\xe2\x80\x99s plan for raids on suspected arms caches has been widely condemned as paving the way for one of the worst genocides since the Holocaust. But evidence submitted to the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, some of it still under seal, reveals a murkier, more complicated situation than has often been portrayed.'b''b'New details'b' about the mysterious informant known to General Dallaire as \xe2\x80\x9cJean-Pierre\xe2\x80\x9d serve as a reminder that history can take a long time to reveal its secrets. Important documents that could shed light on the unresolved mysteries and ambiguities of the Rwanda genocide remain under lock and key.'b'It is now commonly recognized that the international community failed miserably in its efforts to protect the people of Rwanda. But even 20 years later, there is still much to learn. While the new evidence does not absolve the United Nations and Western governments for failing to take timely action, Jean-Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s story illustrates the challenges that continue to vex decision-makers struggling to make sense of unfolding crises in countries like the Central African Republic or South Sudan.'b'The immediate trigger for the Rwandan genocide was the shooting down of a plane carrying President Juvenal Habyarimana on April 6, 1994. Over the next hundred days, Hutu militia groups murdered at least half a million members of the Tutsi minority, along with tens of thousands of \xe2\x80\x9cmoderate\xe2\x80\x9d Hutus. These massacres took place against the backdrop of a war that pitted the Hutu-dominated regime against Tutsi-led insurgents who had invaded Rwanda from neighboring Uganda.'b'Whether the genocide was planned, and was thus foreseeable, has been hotly debated by scholars, politicians and lawyers. The \xe2\x80\x9cgenocide fax\xe2\x80\x9d has been a key part of this debate. Controversy has surrounded Jean-Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s motives for cooperating with General Dallaire, the reliability of his information, and his fate after his request for protection was rejected by the United Nations.'b'We now know a lot more about Jean-Pierre Abubakar Turatsinze (his full name was established by the war crimes tribunal). Half-Hutu and half-Tutsi, he operated on both sides of Rwanda\xe2\x80\x99s political and ethnic divide. While his prediction of mass murder of Tutsis by Hutu militia groups proved chillingly accurate, he misled United Nations peacekeepers on some key points.'b'Important details about his background and eventual fate are contained in a 2003 'b'interview'b' with his wife by tribunal investigators that has never been officially released but is now available. At the time of his marriage, in 1990, he worked as a driver for a senior Rwandan official. In the turmoil following the rebel invasion, Jean-Pierre used his connections to become an intermediary to the Interahamwe militia, whose principal goal was to defend the Hutu-dominated regime.'b'Curiously, the fact that he was married to a Tutsi and was the product of a mixed Tutsi-Hutu marriage does not seem to have affected his advancement in the Interahamwe, at least until the end of 1993. Around this time, he told his wife that he might have to kill her because the ruling party was planning to carry out \xe2\x80\x9cmassacres.\xe2\x80\x9d As she told investigators, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause I am Tutsi and his mother was Tutsi, I understood this to mean that the massacres were going to be against the Tutsi population.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Jean-Pierre told General Dallaire\xe2\x80\x99s aides in January 1994 that he had been instructed to register \xe2\x80\x9call Tutsis\xe2\x80\x9d living in Kigali, apparently for \xe2\x80\x9ctheir extermination.\xe2\x80\x9d He also said that the Rwandan Army had been supplying the Interahamwe with weapons, and identified several arms caches, including one in the headquarters of the ruling party. The Interahamwe went on to commit many of the murders during the genocide.'b'The Arusha-based international tribunal has found that the Rwandan Army channeled weapons to the Interahamwe and provided military training to militia members. But tribunal judges were not convinced that the purpose of that training was the \xe2\x80\x9cextermination\xe2\x80\x9d of Tutsis, as Jean-Pierre claimed, rather than preparation for renewed hostilities with the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front. They found that the Interahamwe had drawn up lists of \xe2\x80\x9csuspected opponents of the regime,\xe2\x80\x9d but such lists were \xe2\x80\x9cnot focused exclusively on ethnicity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Evidence submitted to the tribunal showed that Jean-Pierre may have had other motives for seeking United Nations protection. He had fallen out with party leaders who suspected him of selling arms to rebels in Burundi. Some witnesses believe he might have been an agent of the Rwandan Patriotic Front assigned to penetrate the Interahamwe.'b'While there is no reliable evidence to back the claim that he was an R.P.F. agent in January 1994, it is clear that he had connections to opposition parties allied with the Tutsi-led rebels. According to United Nations cables, a Hutu opposition leader named Faustin Twagiramungu served as Jean-Pierre\xe2\x80\x99s conduit to General Dallaire. These connections caused French and Belgian analysts to suspect that Jean-Pierre might be spreading \xe2\x80\x9cdisinformation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In his 2003 memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cShake Hands With the Devil,\xe2\x80\x9d General Dallaire raised the possibility that his informant had \xe2\x80\x9csimply melted back into the Interahamwe, angry and disillusioned at our vacillation and ineffectiveness, and become a genocidaire.\xe2\x80\x9d Jean-Pierre told the general\xe2\x80\x99s aides at their final meeting in February 1994 that he was planning to go to Zaire, for \xe2\x80\x9ccommando training.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Instead, he went to Tanzania where he joined the R.P.F., according to his wife. In late March, two weeks before the president\xe2\x80\x99s assassination, he moved to a rebel-held enclave in northern Rwanda, where he was reported to be \xe2\x80\x9cin very good books with senior members of the R.P.F.\xe2\x80\x9d In late 1994, a minister in Rwanda\xe2\x80\x99s new Tutsi-led government informed the family that Jean-Pierre had been \xe2\x80\x9c'b'killed in battle'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The circumstances of his death remain a mystery. As his wife told investigators, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know how he died and where.\xe2\x80\x9d She was unable even to establish whether he was \xe2\x80\x9csurely dead.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'General Dallaire has told the tribunal that he operated on \xe2\x80\x9cinstinct\xe2\x80\x9d in sending the genocide fax, which was followed up by a series of warnings to New York in early 1994 that were rebuffed or ignored. He sensed that the peacekeeping force had to reassert its authority. But his superiors in New York needed something more than their field commander\xe2\x80\x99s instincts to justify aggressive action.'b'Newly released State Department records show that United Nations officials briefed the United States, Belgium and France on the emerging crisis, but there was zero enthusiasm in the Clinton administration following the \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Hawk Down\xe2\x80\x9d debacle in Somalia in October 1993. Much stronger intelligence would have been necessary to disrupt the passivity of senior decision makers.'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cJean-Pierre\xe2\x80\x9d revelations are a tantalizing indication of how much we still have to learn about the Rwandan genocide. HOPKINS'b'\nAtlanta, Jan. 6, 2014'b''b''b'The writer, a vice president of the Carter Center, is an expert on the eradication of diseases.'b''b'Fifty years have passed since Lyndon Johnson declared war on poverty. And a funny thing happened on the way to this anniversary. Suddenly, or so it seems, progressives have stopped apologizing for their efforts on behalf of the poor, and have started trumpeting them instead. And conservatives find themselves on the defensive.'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t supposed to be this way. For a long time, everyone knew \xe2\x80\x94 or, more accurately, \xe2\x80\x9cknew\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that the war on poverty had been an abject failure. And they knew why: It was the fault of the poor themselves. But what everyone knew wasn\xe2\x80\x99t true, and the public seems to have caught on.'b'The narrative went like this: Antipoverty programs hadn\xe2\x80\x99t actually reduced poverty, because poverty in America was basically a social problem \xe2\x80\x94 a problem of broken families, crime and a culture of dependence that was only reinforced by government aid. And because this narrative was so widely accepted, bashing the poor was good politics, enthusiastically embraced by Republicans and some Democrats, too.'b'Yet this view of poverty, which may have had some truth to it in the 1970s, bears no resemblance to anything that has happened since.'b'For one thing, the war on poverty has, in fact, achieved quite a lot. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that the standard measure of poverty hasn\xe2\x80\x99t fallen much. But this measure doesn\xe2\x80\x99t include the value of crucial public programs like food stamps and the earned-income tax credit. Once these programs are taken into account, 'b'the data show a significant decline in poverty'b', and a much larger decline in extreme poverty. Other evidence also points to a big improvement in the lives of America\xe2\x80\x99s poor: lower-income Americans are much healthier and better-nourished than they were in the 1960s.'b'Furthermore, there is strong evidence that antipoverty programs have 'b'long-term benefits'b', both to their recipients and to the nation as a whole. For example, children who had access to food stamps were healthier and had higher incomes in later life than people who didn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'And if progress against poverty has nonetheless been disappointingly slow \xe2\x80\x94 which it has \xe2\x80\x94 blame rests not with the poor but with a changing labor market, one that no longer offers good wages to ordinary workers. Wages used to rise along with worker productivity, but that linkage ended around 1980. The bottom third of the American work force has seen little or no rise in inflation-adjusted wages since the early 1970s; the bottom third of male workers has experienced a sharp wage decline. 'b'This wage stagnation'b', not social decay, is the reason poverty has proved so hard to eradicate.'b'Or to put it a different way, the problem of poverty has become part of the broader problem of rising income inequality, of an economy in which all the fruits of growth seem to go to a small elite, leaving everyone else behind.'b'So how should we respond to this reality?'b'The conservative position, essentially, is that we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t respond. Conservatives are committed to the view that government is always the problem, never the solution; they treat every beneficiary of a safety-net program as if he or she were \xe2\x80\x9ca Cadillac-driving welfare queen.\xe2\x80\x9d And why not? After all, for decades their position was a political winner, because middle-class Americans saw \xe2\x80\x9cwelfare\xe2\x80\x9d as something that Those People got but they didn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'But that was then. At this point, the rise of the 1 percent at the expense of everyone else is so obvious that it\xe2\x80\x99s no longer possible to shut down any discussion of rising inequality with cries of \xe2\x80\x9cclass warfare.\xe2\x80\x9d Meanwhile, hard times have forced many more Americans to turn to safety-net programs. And as conservatives have responded by defining an ever-growing fraction of the population as morally unworthy \xe2\x80\x9ctakers\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a quarter, a third, 47 percent, whatever \xe2\x80\x94 they have made themselves look callous and meanspirited.'b'You can see the new political dynamics at work in 'b'the fight over aid to the unemployed'b'. Republicans are still opposed to extended benefits, despite high long-term unemployment. But they have, revealingly, changed their arguments. Suddenly, it\xe2\x80\x99s not about forcing those lazy bums to find jobs; it\xe2\x80\x99s about fiscal responsibility. And nobody believes a word of it.'b'Meanwhile, progressives are on offense. They have decided that inequality is a winning political issue. They see war-on-poverty programs like food stamps, Medicaid, and the earned-income tax credit as success stories, initiatives that have helped Americans in need \xe2\x80\x94 especially during the slump since 2007 \xe2\x80\x94 and should be expanded. And if these programs enroll a growing number of Americans, rather than being narrowly targeted on the poor, so what?'b'So guess what: On its 50th birthday, the war on poverty no longer looks like a failure. It looks, instead, like a template for a rising, increasingly confident progressive movement.'b'If you just listened to Republican politicians, you\xe2\x80\x99d have almost no sense that conservative thinking has changed much since Barack Obama beat Mitt Romney over a year ago. But if you hang around the conservative policy wonks, and read certain conservative magazines, the picture is quite different.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99d invite you, for example, to cast your eye over the new issue of 'b'National Affairs'b', the right-leaning policy journal edited by Yuval Levin. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find nine different articles that hang together coherently around what could well be the dominant style of conservatism of the coming years. This is the conservatism of skeptical reform.'b'This conservatism is oriented, first, around social problems, not government. For many years, conservatives spoke as if runaway government was the only major threat facing the country. Defining themselves against government, Republican politicians had no governing agenda for people facing concrete needs.'b'But the emerging conservatives begin their analysis by looking at concrete problems: how to help the unemployed move to where they can find jobs; how to help gifted students from poor families reach their potential. If you start by looking at these specific matters, then even conservatives conclude that, in properly limited ways, government can be a useful tool. Government is not the only solution, but it is also not the only problem.'b'In the lead essay of the issue, 'b'Michael R. Strain looks at broken labor markets'b'. Strain embraces some traditional conservative ideas, like streamlining regulations, but also some ideas that use government power: public investments in infrastructure, more aggressive monetary policy, wage subsidies, cash bonuses for people who get off unemployment insurance and find jobs, relocation subsidies to help the unemployed move.'b'Second, this conservatism is populist about ends but not means. Over the past decade, many Republican politicians have spread the message that the country\xe2\x80\x99s problems would be easily solved if only the nefarious elites would get out of the way and allow the common people to take over. Members of this conservatism are more likely to conclude that, in fact, problems are complex and there are no easy answers, but there is room for policy expertise, and perhaps philosophical rigor, even if it comes from Washington.'b'But these experts should focus on specific needs and desires of working-class Americans, not gripes and obsessions of the Republican donor community. \xe2\x80\x9cModern conservatives have tended to discount the moral value of the average person, focusing instead on extolling the moral superiority of the great.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Henry Olsen of the Ethics and Public Policy Center writes'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cHow many times in recent years have conservative leaders told us about the virtuous entrepreneur?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Third, this conservatism supports effective government, not technocratic government. Like all proper conservatism, it begins with a sense of epistemological modesty, a sense that the world is too complicated to be centrally planned. Therefore, it opposes the style of government embodied in Obamacare, where officials in the center define insurance products and then compel people to buy them.'b'This conservatism knows that central decision-makers, even conservative ones, are no match for complex reality. Therefore, they favor market mechanisms, which take advantage of dispersed knowledge. They prefer simple programs to complex ones. In National Affairs, 'b'Eli Lehrer and Lori Sanders argue'b' that a carefully structured income support grant could replace the morass of existing welfare programs for the poor.'b'Fourth, this conservatism is skeptical in temper, especially about itself. Recently, conservatives have been filled with fervor and conviction, and regarded compromise as selling out. Some recent conservatives have ideologized the Constitution, turning it into a rigid system that answers every political question for us. But the founders constructed a constitutional order that left room for different policy approaches; that was humble before the evolving needs of the future; and that required compromise and coalition building. The founders did not believe in concentrating power in the hands of any group of highly fallible individuals.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s emerging conservatives embrace that constitutional mind-set, embodied both by Madison and Hamilton. Moreover, the National Affairs authors understand that most policy programs, like most businesses, fail. Conservative programs like urban enterprise zones failed to produce measurable results. Liberal programs like Head Start scarcely produce identifiable long-term gains. Therefore, it is best to approach government in a mood of skeptical reformism: Engage in a constant process of gradual concrete reform even as you are aware that most of your efforts will not pan out.'b'The Republican style of recent years has produced a vacuum where concrete proposals should be. The emerging conservatives won\xe2\x80\x99t have to argue with or defeat the more populist factions on the right; they can just fill the vacuum. Republican politicians, when they are asked to come up with specific programs, will find there is no other game in town.'b'IN New Jersey, we like our politicians to be entertaining.'b'Watching Chris Christie writhe for what seemed like hours yesterday, denying he knew anything about what has become known as Bridgegate, might have given joy to the \xe2\x80\x9cjust desserts\xe2\x80\x9d crowd. If they were incompetents, they were his handpicked incompetents, with whom he was perfectly content until the heat rose on his personal backside.'b'As my friend Tom O\xe2\x80\x99Neil, who has been watching the parade of Jersey pols for decades, put it, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why there are no-show jobs, so the clowns who got you elected don\xe2\x80\x99t mess things up by going to work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s funny.'b'In recent years, it has become increasingly clear that no prominent banker would be prosecuted for fraud in the run-up to the financial crisis. In 'b'the current issue of The New York Review of Books'b', 'b'Judge Jed Rakoff'b' of the Federal District Court in Manhattan asks why.'b'The comforting answer \xe2\x80\x94 that no fraud was committed \xe2\x80\x94 is possible, but implausible. \xe2\x80\x9cWhile officials of the Department of Justice have been more circumspect in describing the roots of the financial crisis than have the various commissions of inquiry and other government agencies,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen nothing to indicate their disagreement with the widespread conclusion that fraud at every level permeated the bubble in mortgage-backed securities.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So why no high-level prosecutions? According to Judge Rakoff, evidence of fraud without prosecution of fraud indicates prosecutorial weaknesses.'b'This is not the first time Judge Rakoff has weighed in on the prosecutorial response to the financial crisis. In 2011, 'b'he rejected a settlement'b' between Citigroup and the Securities and Exchange Commission because it did not require the bank to admit wrongdoing.'b'His insights on financial-crisis cases also apply to cases that have emerged since then, like JPMorgan Chase\xe2\x80\x99s settlement with the government 'b'this week'b' over the bank\xe2\x80\x99s role in Bernard Madoff\xe2\x80\x99s Ponzi scheme.'b'Under the deal, JPMorgan Chase, which served as Mr. Madoff\xe2\x80\x99s primary bank for more than two decades, must pay a $1.7 billion penalty, essentially for turning a blind eye to Mr. Madoff\xe2\x80\x99s fraud. It must also take steps to improve its anti-money-laundering controls. And it had to acknowledge, among other facts, that shortly before the fraud was revealed, the bank withdrew nearly $300 million of its money from Madoff-related funds.'b'By adhering to the settlement terms, the bank will avoid criminal indictment on two felony violations of the Bank Secrecy Act. No individuals were named or charged.'b'And that is the problem. Until relatively recently, it was rare for corporations to face criminal charges without the simultaneous prosecution of managers or executives. That changed over the past three decades, as prosecutors shifted their focus away from individuals and toward corporations, as if fault resides not in executives, but in corporate culture.'b'That shift, in Judge Rakoff\xe2\x80\x99s view, largely explains the lack of banker prosecutions from the financial crisis. It also explains the JPMorgan Chase settlement in the Madoff case. A likely consequence of this approach is more wrongdoing, since, as Judge Rakoff argues, imposing compliance measures that are often just window-dressing is far less potent than \xe2\x80\x9cthe future deterrent value of successfully prosecuting individuals.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Even worse is the distortion of justice. In the financial crisis, prosecutors not only took a hands-off approach to bankers, but to banks as well for fear that indicting a big bank could harm the economy.'b'The JPMorgan Chase settlement in the Madoff case also sidesteps justice by relying on \xe2\x80\x9cdeferred prosecution.\xe2\x80\x9d That tactic, wrote Judge Rakoff, makes prosecutors happy because they tell themselves that the threat of prosecution will deter future crime; it makes corporations happy because they avoid indictment; and happiest of all are the executives or former executives responsible for the misconduct who are left untouched.'b'In addition, he explains, deferred prosecution is \xe2\x80\x9ctechnically suspect\xe2\x80\x9d because, under the law, prosecutors should not threaten to indict a company unless they can prove that some company manager committed the alleged crime, and if that can be proved, why not indict the manager? He also finds it \xe2\x80\x9cmorally suspect\xe2\x80\x9d because it punishes innocent shareholders and employees for wrongdoing committed by unprosecuted individuals.'b'As the myriad cases against JPMorgan Chase and other banks demonstrate, misconduct was not limited to the mortgage bubble. But unless prosecutorial weaknesses are remedied, justice will continue to prove elusive.'b'Fifty years ago this Saturday, on Jan. 11, 1964, a myth-shattering surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report on smoking and health brushed aside years of obfuscation by tobacco companies and asserted, based on 7,000 scientific articles, that smoking caused lung cancer and was linked to other serious diseases. Those findings expanded as more data was gathered.'b'Research since then has shown that tobacco can cause or exacerbate a wide range of diseases, including heart disease, stroke, multiple kinds of cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, emphysema, asthma and diabetes, and can injure nonsmokers who breathe in the toxic fumes secondhand. The death toll from tobacco remains stubbornly high but can be driven down by using a range of new and proven tactics.'b'By some measures, the 50-year campaign to rein in tobacco use has been an enormous success. The percentage of American adults who smoke dropped from 42 percent in 1965 to 18 percent in 2012. A 'b'study published'b' in the Journal of the American Medical Association this week estimated that tobacco control measures adopted since 1964 have saved eight million Americans from premature death and extended their lives by an average of almost 20 years.'b'Experts attribute the gains to vigorous campaigns to educate people about the dangers of smoking; increases in cigarette taxes; state and local laws that protect half the nation\xe2\x80\x99s population from tobacco fumes in workplaces, bars and restaurants; restrictions on advertising; prohibition of sales to minors; and various prevention and cessation programs financed by states or private insurance.'b'Despite these gains, nearly 44 million American adults still smoke, more than 440,000 Americans die every year from smoking, and eight million Americans live with at least one serious chronic disease from smoking. Medical costs connected to smoking are nearly $96 billion a year, with an additional $97 billion lost in productivity because of illness.'b'On Wednesday, several health organizations, including the American Heart Association, the American Lung Association, the American Cancer Society, the American Academy of Pediatrics, and the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids 'b'called for a new national commitment'b' to drive smoking among adults down to less than 10 percent over the next decade; protect all Americans from secondhand smoke within five years by having every state enact laws against smoking in all workplaces, bars and restaurants; and ultimately eliminate death and disease caused by tobacco.'b'It won\xe2\x80\x99t be easy. The tobacco industry spends more than $8 billion a year to market cigarettes and other tobacco products in this country, with much of its marketing slyly aimed at young people.'b'The industry is also invading foreign markets, often in less developed countries, in an effort to make addicts of millions more customers to replace those in industrialized nations. In the last two years, seven countries have forsaken their uranium and plutonium stockpiles, bringing the number of nations still possessing appreciable quantities of nuclear fuel usable for bomb-making down to 25. In 1991, the number was 52.'b'The data comes from the Nuclear Threat Initiative, a private advocacy group that promotes the safekeeping of nuclear materials. Following up on its first report in 2012, the group surveyed the precautions each country had in place and ranked nations based on their security practices. The report issued on Wednesday covered factors like national laws, regulations, participation in international treaties and physical security, including whether a state has armed guards protecting its facilities.'b'The countries deserving special praise \xe2\x80\x94 Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Mexico, Sweden, Ukraine and Vietnam \xe2\x80\x94 effectively gave up their bomb-making capability and now have less than one kilogram (2.2 pounds) of material that can fuel nuclear weapons.'b'Of the countries that still have weapons-usable nuclear material, Australia placed first on the security ranking, because it reduced its supply of nuclear materials and ratified a treaty that commits countries to criminalize acts of nuclear terrorism and bring nuclear criminals to justice. The United States fell to 11th in part because it failed to ratify two nuclear accords.'b'Despite progress, the challenges ahead are daunting. At the bottom of the security rankings were North Korea (25), which is continuing to expand its nuclear weapons program, and Iran (24), which is in negotiations with the United States and other world powers on an agreement to freeze and roll back its program.'b'Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s rank rose to 22, up slightly from two years ago and ahead of India (23), because the Pakistani government took steps to update its nuclear security regulations. Still, both countries are nuclear-armed, have weak safety and security ratings, and are still increasing their nuclear fuel stockpiles for military and civilian purposes.'b'The world is already awash in 2,000 metric tons of weapons-usable nuclear material spread across hundreds of sites around the globe. According to the International Atomic Energy Agency, 100 incidents of theft and other unauthorized activities involving nuclear and radioactive material are reported to the organization every year.'b'There are many steps the international community can take to prevent nuclear fuel from falling into terrorists\xe2\x80\x99 hands, including developing a system of global standards for securing the material and persuading nations to ratify nuclear security treaties. World leaders should push this agenda forward when they meet in The Hague for their third nuclear summit meeting this March.'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S not every day that your family photo appears on a 15-foot storefront sign in the Brazilian Amazon.'b'But for at least the last year, a larger-than-life version of the Massachusetts-Maryland-New York Kugels has stared down at passers-by on Sebasti\xc3\xa3o Diniz Avenue in Boa Vista, the low-slung capital of 'b'Roraima'b', Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s least populous state. The business, Credir\xc3\xa1pido Solicita\xc3\xa7\xc3\xb5es de Empr\xc3\xa9stimos, makes personal loans so the people of Roraima can buy cars or homes or take their kids to Disney World.'b'I had no idea the sign existed until December, when a Brazilian friend from S\xc3\xa3o Paulo \xe2\x80\x94 where I had lived for a few years \xe2\x80\x94 went to spend Christmas at her parents\xe2\x80\x99 home in Boa Vista. She spotted my face from the car, forced her dad to stop, snapped a picture and emailed it to me.'b'Needless to say, I was flabbergasted. I paused to make sure I was awake, and looked again. Yep, still us \xe2\x80\x94 my parents, my brother, my sister-in-law and my nephews posing in front of a mountain I didn\xe2\x80\x99t recognize.'b'That may sound creepy, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t take our privacy too seriously in the Kugel family. My father is a regular character in my mother\xe2\x80\x99s very personal 'b'blog'b'. If my brother, Jeremy, had his way he\xe2\x80\x99d be a game show host. My picture appears 24 hours a day on the online Travel section of The Times, and both nephews have starred in my articles, with no objections from my sister-in-law.'b'So I did what any self-respecting 21st-century human would do: I posted it on Facebook. I waited a few minutes, then called Jeremy to make sure he\xe2\x80\x99d seen it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCredir\xc3\xa1pido, how can I help you?\xe2\x80\x9d he answered. So that was a yes. He had called my parents already. My sister-in-law reposted it with the caption \xe2\x80\x9cI want royalties!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We easily figured out which photo the sign came from: the 2011 version of the annual Kugel family Thanksgiving Day picture, taken near my parents\xe2\x80\x99 home in Cambridge, Mass. But the background had been Photoshopped, an American football cropped out and the image flipped horizontally.'b'Still, several mysteries remained. How had this happened? Could it be legal? Were we on just one sign or Credir\xc3\xa1pido\xe2\x80\x99s nationwide models? And in a Brazilian state where a census report listed 73.6 percent of the population as nonwhite (and where 0.0 percent of the population wear winter coats), why us?'b'I began to investigate.'b'Credir\xc3\xa1pido, it turns out, is an Amazon-region enterprise (owned by a nationwide financial services company, Grupo BMG) that is part of the booming credit business in Brazil. Their specialty, payroll loans repaid directly from the borrowers\xe2\x80\x99 paychecks or pension checks, now makes up more than half of all personal credit in Brazil.'b'I called the number on the sign and spoke to a man named Francinei. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only sign we have is a banner of a family at the beach,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. But I insisted, and he went outside to check. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, the photo\xe2\x80\x99s there.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'They would look into who had produced the ad, and I should call back.'b'Then I had a revelation. Until 2012, I wrote a travel column for a Brazilian website, 'b'IG,'b' and had used that very photo for an 'b'article'b' about what to do if you visit the United States during Thanksgiving. (Top choice: weasel an invite to a family dinner.)'b'I pulled out my old contract: It permitted IG to \xe2\x80\x9ccommercialize\xe2\x80\x9d my photos. Whoa, so maybe this was all above board? But I wrote to them, and they said they had never sold the rights.'b'By the time I called Credir\xc3\xa1pido back, a manager, Cristiane Souza, had figured things out. The sign \xe2\x80\x94 there was only one \xe2\x80\x94 had been commissioned from a local company, Eduart Comunica\xc3\xa7\xc3\xa3o Visual. It had gone out of business a year ago, but she gave me the phone numbers of two former employees.'b'Neither remembered the sign, but both were frank about where the company got images: from Google searches.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s 100 percent illegal,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ronaldo Lemos, director of the Institute for Technology and Society in Rio de Janeiro. \xe2\x80\x9cIn Brazil, you need a whole set of authorizations to use a person\xe2\x80\x99s image, especially for commercial purposes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s not that simple, he added. There are two coexisting spheres in Brazil, the official and unofficial. He used the example of favelas, shantytowns where residents historically have no title to the land, state presence is minimal and \xe2\x80\x9claws\xe2\x80\x9d are created and enforced within the community. \xe2\x80\x9cThe same thing applies to intellectual property,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cA large portion of the Brazilian population lives in such a level of informality they don\xe2\x80\x99t even think about it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Eduart employees may simply not have entirely absorbed the news that Brazil had joined the World Trade Organization in 1995 (which requires adherence to an international agreement on intellectual property) and overhauled its copyright laws in 1998.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt reminds me of the old days,\xe2\x80\x9d said Vitor Knijnik, a friend who started working in Brazilian advertising in the late 1980s. \xe2\x80\x9cWe used photos right out of foreign magazines, because the probability of anyone catching us was small.\xe2\x80\x9d These days, he said, big firms go by the book.'b'Which leaves one last question: why us? I wrote to my friend Alessandra Ribeiro, a black Brazilian journalist. \xe2\x80\x9cWith all due respect,\xe2\x80\x9d she responded, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would be what advertisers call a \xe2\x80\x98margarine family\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 in other words, the kind of lily-white family you\xe2\x80\x99d see in margarine commercials.'b'Maria Helena Machado, a social historian at the University of S\xc3\xa3o Paulo, took it further.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re obviously white, and dressed in winter clothes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich in Roraima would be absolutely impossible. That captures the imagination of Brazilians from the region about what successful capitalism is about: white people, successful, with an age hierarchy and a sense of order.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ms. Ribeiro said the idea that fake white families were the best salespeople was slowly changing in Brazil. I hope that\xe2\x80\x99s true and that soon, even in Roraima, advertisers choose images of success that look a lot more Brazilian \xe2\x80\x94 and do it legally. Well, with one exception.'b'During our conversation, Ms. Souza of Credir\xc3\xa1pido had asked if I wanted the sign taken down. What, and end our 15 feet of fame?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact, I want the opposite,\xe2\x80\x9d I told her. \xe2\x80\x9cLeave it up there forever.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'ISTANBUL \xe2\x80\x94 For the past month, Turkey has been plagued by an all-out political war between the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and certain elements within the judiciary and the police. No one knows how it will end, but its meaning for Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s troubled democracy is already clear: There is little rule of law here, and \xe2\x80\x9cjustice\xe2\x80\x9d easily falls victim to power.'b'This is a problem with deep historical roots. When Mustafa Kemal Ataturk founded the modern Turkish Republic in 1923, he devised the legal system as the protector of his \xe2\x80\x9crevolution\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 rather than citizens\xe2\x80\x99 rights. His politically motivated \xe2\x80\x9cIndependence Courts\xe2\x80\x9d executed or imprisoned many dissidents. Soon, Turkey imported its penal code from Mussolini\xe2\x80\x99s Fascist Italy, where the law simply served the state, not the citizens. (\xe2\x80\x9cWesternization\xe2\x80\x9d does not always do wonders.)'b'Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s hawkish generals, the self-declared \xe2\x80\x9cguardians\xe2\x80\x9d of Ataturk\xe2\x80\x99s revolution, passionately continued this bad tradition. When they overthrew Adnan Menderes, Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s most popular leader ever, in a coup in 1960, he was subjected to a show trial. When Mr. Menderes asked at the court why he was not given a fair trial, the judge\xe2\x80\x99s answer was telling: \xe2\x80\x9cBecause that is how the power that put you here wishes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For decades, Turkey\xe2\x80\x99s religious conservatives condemned this cynical \xe2\x80\x9cjustice\xe2\x80\x9d and for good reason: They were often its victims. But when those same conservatives rose to power after 2000, with the ascendance of Mr. Erdogan\xe2\x80\x99s Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., they did not abolish the old logic; they just adopted it for their advantage. Now justice was the handmaiden of counterrevolution.'b'This became most evident during the various \xe2\x80\x9ccoup cases\xe2\x80\x9d of 2007-2011 that imprisoned hundreds of military officers and their alleged civilian allies. In these cases, there were certainly some military figures responsible for extrajudicial killings or possible coup attempts. Yet many other suspects were only \xe2\x80\x9ccriminal\xe2\x80\x9d in the ideological sense. As Gareth Jenkins, the only Western journalist who read the colossal indictments in full, observed, the hunt on the coup-makers was blown out of proportion due to a \xe2\x80\x9cconspiratorial worldview\xe2\x80\x9d and through \xe2\x80\x9ccreative interpretation and occasional apparent manipulation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Back then, these coup-hunting conservatives within the judiciary were wholeheartedly supported by Mr. Erdogan, but many whispered that they belonged to a specific religious community: The followers of Fethullah Gulen, a moderate Islamic scholar who lives in Pennsylvania and whose teachings have inspired millions in Turkey and beyond.'b'This Erdogan-Gulen alliance, as many people called it, ultimately won the war against the military old guard, but they could not keep the peace between themselves. Their growing political tension turned into an open political war on Dec. 17, with an unexpected corruption probe that involved four ministers in Mr. Erdogan\xe2\x80\x99s government. The prime minister soon accepted the resignation of those ministers, but also condemned the investigation as a \xe2\x80\x9ccoup attempt.\xe2\x80\x9d He blamed a \xe2\x80\x9csecret organization\xe2\x80\x9d within the judiciary and the police, a conspiratorial cabal directed by the Gulen movement that serves \xe2\x80\x9cforeign powers\xe2\x80\x9d such as the United States and Israel.'b'Since then, in just a month, Mr. Erdogan has pursued a huge purge within the police force, reassigning a staggering 2,500 officers and taking steps to make the judiciary subservient to the executive (such as his new proposal to place the relatively autonomous High Council of Judges and Prosecutors fully under the justice minister), in a reversal of the European Union reforms that his own government had introduced.'b'Last Wednesday, the prosecutor who launched the corruption probe, Zekeriya Oz, once Mr. Erdogan\xe2\x80\x99s favorite due to his leading role in prosecuting military leaders, declared that the prime minister had sent emissaries conveying threats. Mr. Erdogan denied this charge, while the pro-Erdogan media insisted that Mr. Oz himself is corrupt.'b'Objectively speaking, there are good reasons to believe that the corruption probe against the government is politically motivated. After all, it came immediately after the burst of the A.K.P.-Gulen conflict; it is passionately supported by the Gulen movement; and it may influence important local elections in March. But should the political motivations of a prosecutor devalue the evidence he finds? If yes, why was this not an issue during the \xe2\x80\x9ccoup\xe2\x80\x9d cases against the military? And if those cases were really based on manipulated evidence, should we trust the findings of the same prosecutors now?'b'Such questions must be asked in Turkey, but few are asking all of them together. Rather, the warring political camps are focusing only on what benefits their own interests. Some within the secular opposition who once condemned prosecutors such as Mr. Oz as \xe2\x80\x9cthe enemy of the Turkish military\xe2\x80\x9d now praise him for challenging Mr. Erdogan. Meanwhile, some supporters of Mr. Erdogan are arguing, surprisingly, that the Turkish military suffered from a similar judicial \xe2\x80\x9cplot,\xe2\x80\x9d debunking the very cases they once passionately defended.'b'Deep down, this crisis exposes the tragedy of Turkish justice. All political camps seem to believe that justice will only be served when the right people \xe2\x80\x94 their people \xe2\x80\x94 control the judiciary. Moreover, their similarly conspiratorial mind-sets demonize all political opponents as enemies within who need to be cornered and crushed. The result is an endless series of vendettas. Whoever manages to capture state power uses it aggressively, while the victims only grind their teeth and wait for their turn.'b'The only way out is to restructure the Turkish judiciary to make it both independent and nonpartisan, so that it protects the rights of all citizens and rule of law. The current crisis is unlikely to yield any good outcomes soon, but if it can convince more Turks that they really need such a structural, long-lasting solution instead of cosmetic reforms, that will be a significant step forward.'b''b'\n'b'Mustafa Akyol 'b' is a columnist and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cIslam Without Extremes: A Muslim Case for Liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'MONTREAL \xe2\x80\x94 Angela Merkel deemed multiculturalism \xe2\x80\x94 the idea that social harmony is best achieved through celebrating our differences \xe2\x80\x94 a complete failure in Germany. David Cameron claimed it facilitated the rise of radical Islam in Britain and called for \xe2\x80\x9cstronger societies and identities at home,\xe2\x80\x9d along with a \xe2\x80\x9cmuch more active, muscular liberalism\xe2\x80\x9d that \xe2\x80\x9cbelieves in certain values and actively promotes them.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Last fall, the European backlash against multiculturalism crossed the Atlantic and landed in Quebec, when the governing Parti Qu\xc3\xa9b\xc3\xa9cois proposed the 'b'Charter of Values'b', which sets out a vision of government that breaks sharply with Canada\xe2\x80\x99s broader multicultural ethos.'b'Quebec, of course, with its distinctive religious history, feminist bent and linguistically diverse metropolis of Montreal, has never been reluctant to go against the Canadian grain. In 1977, the province passed the French Language Charter, which made French its sole official language and required immigrants to attend French public schools (about 80 percent of Quebecers are native French speakers). Not content to use clean hydroelectric power as its primary energy source, it ratified the Kyoto Accord \xe2\x80\x94 an agreement Canada itself reneged on \xe2\x80\x94 and teamed up with California last year to introduce North America\xe2\x80\x99s first carbon-trading market. And this year, all of its public sector workers and most private ones will be required to adhere to equal-compensation laws, the strongest in North America, that ensure men and women are paid on a par.'b'Quebecers\xe2\x80\x99 dissent from the rest of Canada extends as deep as the country\xe2\x80\x99s Constitution. In 1982, a clause stating the need for the \xe2\x80\x9cpreservation and enhancement of the multicultural heritage of Canadians\xe2\x80\x9d was written into a new Constitution. It is one important reason Quebec, where a quarter of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s people live, has refused to ratify this text that nonetheless holds de facto authority over the province.'b'The Charter of Values is the latest expression of Quebec\xe2\x80\x99s dim view of multiculturalism. Among other things, the bill affirms the secular nature of Quebec\xe2\x80\x99s government and denies religious requests for accommodations of dress in public sector employment: After a transition period, government workers would have to refrain from wearing conspicuous religious symbols \xe2\x80\x94 for instance, the Muslim hijab, the Sikh turban or the Christian cross \xe2\x80\x94 while on the job.'b'As usual, though, when Quebec veers from the Canadian path, controversy breaks out. The Ottawan government has even vowed to challenge the charter in the national courts if it passes. Critics are claiming that the bill infringes on the liberties of Muslims and other minorities. Oddly, though, they do not balk at the current ban, for all government workers, on the expression of other social or political beliefs through their attire.'b'For no clear reason, multiculturalists seem to think some personal preferences are more permissibly expressed by government workers than others. In any case, a truly secular state should not permit the symbols of any religion, whether of the majority or a minority, to breach the wall between church and state advocated by no less than Thomas Jefferson; hence the Parti Qu\xc3\xa9b\xc3\xa9cois\xe2\x80\x99 decision to remove the crucifix that famously hangs in the legislature.'b'The charter is actually just the next logical step along the path of secularization. Until 1960, when its authority began to dip, the Roman Catholic Church held much sway in Quebec. It was only 20 years ago that Christian school boards were secularized and only 10 that Catholic and Protestant classes were moved out of the schools and into the churches. Members of the Catholic Church in Quebec used to wear religious gear in the public sector, but gradually shed it in the \xe2\x80\x9960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s. So the return of religious vestments in the public sector can be seen as a regression.'b'Interestingly, women in Quebec are especially likely to see it so. And indeed, the defense of gender equality is a pillar of the charter. It states that no one, man or woman, can work for the state with face covered \xe2\x80\x94 for instance, by the facial veils of the Muslim burqa and niqab \xe2\x80\x94 because such an act would imply inequality and segregation. The bill also clearly signals that no one can refuse to be served by a female public worker.'b'Quebec\xe2\x80\x99s approach to the separation of church and state is thus rigorous, progressive and modern. It is, in fact, in cosmopolitan Montreal, not in more homogeneous French regions of Quebec, that one finds the strongest supporters of the religious neutrality of state employees\xe2\x80\x99 attire: 61 percent of the Francophone majority living in the city. (Admittedly, Montreal\xe2\x80\x99s Anglophone minority is very much opposed, five to one.)'b'But anyone familiar with Quebec knows its distinctive mix of European (especially French) and American values. That European courts have granted considerable legal leeway to implement measures that promote state neutrality and gender equality is significant to Quebecers. And the ban on public employees\xe2\x80\x99 wearing religious and other symbols has actually been on the books in France for about a century: Christian professors, Jewish doctors and Muslim judges know that, from 9 to 5, they work in a neutral zone where such symbols are out of place.'b'If the charter does pass \xe2\x80\x94 a vote is expected in the spring \xe2\x80\x94 the very federal Constitution that Quebec has never approved might be invoked to strike it down. But the Canadian Supreme Court has a history of surprising governments in its major rulings, and it has become less enamored with multiculturalism in recent decisions. In fact, throughout the country, multiculturalists have been increasingly on the defensive in recent years, not least because of the concern over the multiplication of ethnic enclaves. Around 40 percent of Canadians outside Quebec support the Quebec Charter.'b'In a very real sense, the debate over Quebec\xe2\x80\x99s charter may be the last stand of Canada\xe2\x80\x99s multiculturalist experiment. Whatever the immediate outcome, it may be only a matter of time until Canadian multiculturalism finds itself buried alongside its European siblings.'b''b' 'b'Jean-Fran\xc3\xa7ois Lis\xc3\xa9e 'b' is Quebec minister for the Montreal area and for international affairs. 'b''b'DUBLIN \xe2\x80\x94  I was talking just before Christmas to a young man who sells shoes in a department store in Dublin. He told me that a television news crew had filmed interviews in the store the previous day. They wanted to know if sales were picking up during the vital holiday period, indicating that the battered Irish economy was, after five grim years, on the rise at last.'b'Most of his colleagues said that, actually, sales were rather sluggish. One was more hopeful and said that there were signs of improvement. When the young man watched the TV news that night, he was not entirely surprised to find that the only interview that had made the cut was the one with the optimist.'b'Everyone wants Ireland to be a good-news story, proof that a willingness to take the pain of prolonged austerity will be rewarded in the end. Ordinary citizens are hungry for some hope. The government, in the words of Deputy Prime Minister Eamon Gilmore, was \xe2\x80\x9cdetermined that Ireland would be Europe\xe2\x80\x99s success story.\xe2\x80\x9d An influential board member of the European Central Bank, J\xc3\xb6rg Asmussen, says, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Irish program is a success story.\xe2\x80\x9d Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany praised Ireland as an example of how crisis countries could turn themselves around.'b'The only problem is that, for most of us who actually live here, Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s success story feels less like \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shawshank Redemption\xe2\x80\x9d and more like \xe2\x80\x9cRocky.\xe2\x80\x9d We haven\xe2\x80\x99t been joyously liberated; we\xe2\x80\x99ve just withstood a lot of blows. We\xe2\x80\x99re still standing, but we\xe2\x80\x99ve taken so many punches that it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see straight.'b'Yes, things are finally looking up, but the hopeful vision is clouded by two nagging questions. Did they need to be so bleak for so long? And has the harsh medicine actually cured Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s ills?'b'For conservatives, in particular, Ireland is the Tyra Banks of nations: a model country. The only problem is that they can\xe2\x80\x99t quite decide what Ireland is a model of.'b'For a long time, when Ireland was booming, it was the perfect face of light regulation and low taxes. (With impeccably bad timing, Senator John McCain cited Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s low corporate taxes as a model for the United States in his presidential election debates with Senator Barack Obama in 2008 \xe2\x80\x94 just as Ireland was sliding into crisis.) Now, with Ireland tentatively emerging from its long slump, it is being cited as the great exemplar of the virtues of austerity.'b'As the German finance minister, Wolfgang Sch\xc3\xa4uble, a fiscal hawk, put it in October: \xe2\x80\x9cIreland did what Ireland had to do. And now everything is fine.\xe2\x80\x9d Ireland was a success story when it was partying wildly and it is a success story when it is the Grim Reaper of international economics. Binge or purge, we can do no wrong.'b'We Irish are eternal optimists, but Mr. Sch\xc3\xa4uble\xe2\x80\x99s belief that everything is fine is a rare example of a German outdoing us in irrational exuberance. It is certainly true that, if you were to walk around the rebuilt Dublin docklands, with their shiny European headquarter offices for Google, Twitter, Facebook and Yahoo, and their slick cafes and hotels, you might conclude that if this is what an Irish crisis looks like, an Irish boom must be quite something to behold.'b'The supercool new Marker Hotel and apartment complex, which opened its doors in April and cost 120 million euros ($163 million), could be in Los Angeles or Dubai. It looks down on the buoyant American architecture of Martha Schwartz\xe2\x80\x99s Grand Canal Square and a plush Daniel Libeskind theater. In a country wrecked by a spectacular property bubble, house prices in Dublin have begun to soar again, rising 13 percent in the last year.'b'But Ireland has two economies: a global one dominated by American high-tech companies, and a domestic one in which most Irish workers have to make their living. The first is indeed booming. Not least because of those low corporate taxes, large global corporations find Dublin convivial for reasons other than its pubs and night life. The sheer scale of Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s dependence on this kind of investment for its exports can be judged by the fact that Irish gross domestic product took a serious hit in 2013 when Viagra (which is made by Pfizer in County Cork) went off patent in Europe. Broadly speaking, however, the global side of the Irish economy has remained robust.'b'But home is where the heartache is: in the domestic economy outside the gated community of high-tech multinationals. Outside Dublin, property prices are still falling. Wages for most workers have dropped sharply. Unemployment remains very high at 12.8 percent \xe2\x80\x94 and that figure would be higher if not for emigration. There\xe2\x80\x99s always been a simple way to measure how well Ireland is doing: Go to the ports and airports after the Christmas vacation and count the young people waving goodbye to their parents as they head off to the United States, Canada, Australia or Britain, where they have gone to find work and opportunity.'b'Other people protest in bad times; the Irish leave. And they\xe2\x80\x99ve been doing so in numbers that haven\xe2\x80\x99t been recorded since the 1980s. Nearly 90,000 people emigrated between April 2012 and April 2013 and close to 400,000 have left since the 2008 crisis. For a country with a population about the size of Kentucky\xe2\x80\x99s (about 4.5 million), that\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of people.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s no great mystery about why they\xe2\x80\x99re going: They don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in the success story. A major study by University College Cork found that most of the emigrants are graduates and that almost half of them left full-time jobs in Ireland to go abroad. These are not desperate refugees; they\xe2\x80\x99re bright young people who have lost faith in the idea that Ireland can give them the opportunities they want. They just don\xe2\x80\x99t buy into the narrative of a triumphant rebound.'b'When the International Monetary Fund, the European Commission and the European Central Bank \xe2\x80\x94 the so-called troika \xe2\x80\x94 took over Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s fiscal governance in December 2010, they somehow convinced themselves that sharp cuts in public spending and reductions in wages would go hand in hand with economic growth. The I.M.F., for example, told us that the Irish economy would grow by 5.25 percent between 2011 and 2013. In fact, it grew at around half that rate.'b'Common sense would have suggested that in an economy in which private investment had dried up (Irish investment rates are now about half the average for the euro zone), there might be a problem with slashing public investment as well. After five years of austerity, it is shocking but hardly surprising that one in four Irish children are growing up in households in which no one at all is in paid employment.'b'Nor is it surprising that the departure of the troika at the end of 2013 and some modest signs of economic recovery have not been greeted by Riverdancing on the rooftops. Irish people were prepared to take some punishment; there\xe2\x80\x99s enough Catholic guilt still around for a story of sin and atonement to have considerable psychological purchase. People do look back ruefully on the Celtic Tiger years and admit that we deserved a whipping for thinking we could get rich by selling one another million-dollar houses. But they are not convinced that the cruel scale of the punishment was necessary or that the nasty medicine has, in fact, worked.'b'Behind both of these propositions looms the great contradiction in the supposed success story of Irish austerity. It was austerity only for citizens.'b'Running parallel to all the cuts in public spending and all the calls for fiscal responsibility has been a program of spending so lavish that it makes a drunken sailor look stingy. One part of the troika program was to cut wages, welfare, health care and education. The other was to insist that Ireland continue to put vast resources into its teetering banks, including the notorious, now liquidated, Anglo Irish Bank.'b'The policy of No Bondholder Left Behind, on which the European Central Bank insisted, has been staggeringly expensive. To put it in perspective, the European Union has just agreed to create a fund of $75 billion to deal with all future banking crises in its member states. Tiny Ireland has spent $85 billion bailing out its own banks.'b'Particularly galling to most Irish people is that there is now an almost casual admission that this was a pretty crazy idea. Olli Rehn, the European Union\xe2\x80\x99s economic affairs commissioner and one of the chief architects of Irish strategy since the crash, now says, \xe2\x80\x9cIn retrospect, I think it is quite easy to spot some mistakes like the blanket guarantee for banks.\xe2\x80\x9d This admission, though, does not imply any change of policy. \xe2\x80\x9cBut that is now water under the bridge,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on to say, \xe2\x80\x9cand now we have redirected the river.\xe2\x80\x9d Ireland, Mr. Rehn reassured us, is in \xe2\x80\x9ca better place for the moment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But the river has not been redirected: A torrent of debt continues to flow from the catastrophic decision to save bad banks at all costs. Hopes that Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s debts might be alleviated by its European partners in recognition of the country\xe2\x80\x99s role in saving the euro are now fading.'b'Little Ireland took one for the team. In return, it gets a pat on the head and the dubious pleasure of being called a success story.'b'This is why, in the end, the austerity program has not succeeded even in its basic aim of bringing down Ireland\xe2\x80\x99s sovereign debt, which actually rose sharply over the last five years. In 2009, it was 64 percent of G.D.P. Last year, it peaked at 125 percent. The debt has doubled while public spending has been slashed.'b'In this, Ireland may be a model indeed: suffering to maintain an unreal image of slimmed-down perfection.'b''b'\n'b'Fintan O\xe2\x80\x99Toole, 'b' a columnist for The Irish Times, is a visiting lecturer at Princeton. 'b''b'Every weekend in 1979, Ooi Cheng Ghee took his Leica camera out to the docks of Penang, an island off the west coast of peninsular Malaysia. Mr. Ooi, a local physician of Chinese descent, roamed the working-class district of Georgetown to document life in the harbor. By year\xe2\x80\x99s end, he had taken 4,000 portraits, mostly of first-and second-generation migrants from India.'b'The photographs chronicle a vanishing world. You can see it in the sad but defiant eyes of an old man hauling jute sacks of betel nuts, an ancient trade that was fading away. By then, Mr. Ooi said, the Indian enclave of Penang \xe2\x80\x9cgave off a feeling of having been abandoned.\xe2\x80\x9d Modernization had eclipsed the commercial and social patterns of earlier waves of globalization.'b'Many coastal cities across Southeast Asia gained prominence in the 15th century, as power ebbed from ancient upland capitals like Angkor and Bagan, which had become riven by conflict and were weakened by the collapse of agricultural production. Ports developed as ocean trade grew. Textiles from Gujarat and the Coromandel Coast of India were exchanged for staple goods like rice or spices and medicinal products from across Southeast Asia. The Chinese market was the most lucrative of all.'b'Malacca, situated at the junction of the Indian Ocean and the South China Sea, emerged in the 1400s as the greatest trading emporium in the region, perhaps even the world. Many smaller ports also thrived, including Aceh, Banten and Manila.'b'Most were small principalities ruled by Muslim families, but their populations were multiethnic. The important political office of harbormaster was often occupied by foreigners, often Indians. Alongside Chinese, Indian and Arab merchants, the port towns relied on a workforce of local peoples and slaves from South and Southeast Asia. When the Portuguese conquered Malacca in 1511, the apothecary Tom\xc3\xa9 Pires claimed to hear 84 languages spoken in its marketplace.'b'After the Portuguese, it was the Dutch who came, then the British and the French, setting up coastal footholds around the Indian Ocean. A British colony was founded in Penang, a strategic location on the Strait of Malacca, by the East India Company in 1786 as a trading and military base. As the British expanded into Malaya in the 1870s and established plantations, Penang prospered. By the early 20th century, Malaya was the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest producer of rubber and Penang among the most culturally diverse cities on earth.'b'Some migrants moved in search of fortune; others were forced to relocate by colonial authorities, labor recruiters or difficult circumstances at home. The Chinese went to all parts of Southeast Asia; Indians stayed mostly within the British Empire, concentrating in the Malay Peninsula, Sri Lanka and the area then known as Burma.'b'But the ports\xe2\x80\x99 fortunes were always precarious, contingent on the fluctuations of global trade. The Great Depression hit them hard, forcing many migrant workers to head back home. Singapore and Malaysia introduced immigration controls for the first time.'b'World War II severed already-strained trading links. After decolonization in the late 1940s and 1950s, newly independent governments favored industrialization over the export of basic goods, and the old port cities suffered. India\xe2\x80\x99s drive for self-sufficiency in food \xe2\x80\x94 supplemented as necessary by aid from the United States and bilateral deals \xe2\x80\x94 brought a decline in the Bay of Bengal\xe2\x80\x99s traditional free trade in rice.'b'By the second half of the 20th century, nearly all of the old ports of the eastern Indian Ocean had been eclipsed by investment in new facilities as part of national development plans: Penang lost out to Port Klang, closer to Malaysia\xe2\x80\x99s capital, Kuala Lumpur; Calcutta gave way to Visakhapatnam. Singapore is the great exception. With few natural resources and, after  independence from Malaysia in 1965, a limited domestic market, it  adapted by investing in a state-of-the-art container port. The old docks at Collyer Quay and Clarke Quay have long since been turned into commercial and entertainment districts.'b'Even the new ports that are built on very old sites \xe2\x80\x94 Hambantota in Sri Lanka was visited by Arab dhows centuries ago \xe2\x80\x94 are unmistakably modern creations: huge industrial facilities that are self-contained and divorced from their surroundings. Inhuman in size, these mega-harbors are built for an economy of scale.'b'If the harbors of the past were set up to make the most of a site\xe2\x80\x99s natural advantages \xe2\x80\x94 like the sheltering shape of a bay \xe2\x80\x94 the new ports remake coastlines according to their own needs, dredging waters and reclaiming land. Fishing communities are relocated. Beaches disappear. Erosion accelerates. There is one plan to spend $60 billion by 2020 in order to build a port every 32 kilometers or so along the coast of India.'b'In comparison, the old port cities are a picture of quaint cosmopolitanism; no wonder they are now looked upon with nostalgia. In 2008, Unesco declared Penang\xe2\x80\x99s Georgetown area a World Heritage Site for bearing \xe2\x80\x9ctestimony to a living multicultural heritage and tradition of Asia, where many religions and cultures met and coexisted.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The designation has brought a heritage boom. Chinese shophouses have been converted into boutique hotels, with the attendant coffee shops and art festivals. Thanks to this trend, a book of Mr. Ooi\xe2\x80\x99s photographs was published in 2011, after his work drew little attention for many years.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a revivalism mostly for tourist consumption, but it has also spawned an unprecedented interest in family history among locals. Small community-led museums have opened in Penang, Singapore and elsewhere in the region, and more are planned. They tap memories long kept dormant because the assertion of ethnic identities, particularly migrant origins, raises uncomfortable questions about relations between peoples, and entitlements such as citizenship.'b'But even these restoration efforts can produce a romanticized rendering of the past; they airbrush the ugly realities of Asia\xe2\x80\x99s earlier globalization. The old port cities boomed on the back of an underclass with few rights, poorly paid migrants who worked desperately to improve their lot.'b'Mr. Ooi points out that in his photographs of Penang, \xe2\x80\x9cThere were no curtains on any of the windows\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a sign, in his view, that people \xe2\x80\x9cknew they weren\xe2\x80\x99t staying.\xe2\x80\x9d These societies were multiethnic because they had to be; their cacophony of languages and competing gods made them messy, sometimes violent, places of rough-and-ready compromise.'b'Such hardships endure today. The dormitory settlements of South Asian migrant workers who toil from Dubai to Singapore are often out of view and far from the container ports they service. By dint of the size of these harbors, the connections between the jobs and their human cost are perhaps less immediate than they were centuries ago or even when Mr. Ooi photographed the docks of Penang. But they are no less real.'b'And we know it. That\xe2\x80\x99s why we recoil at these mammoth creations and look back on the past with longing. And that\xe2\x80\x99s why when we see in the past the origins of the modern behemoths, we look away again.'b''b'\n'b'Sunil S. Amrith 'b' teaches history at Birkbeck College, London. He is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cCrossing the Bay of Bengal: The Furies of Nature and the Fortunes of Migrants.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Security at the Winter Olympics might be a little tighter than usual.'b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c \xe2\x80\x98'b'Very Sad\xe2\x80\x99 Christie Extends Apology in Bridge Scandal'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 10):'b'As an independent, I look at the politically engineered traffic jam in Fort Lee, N.J., as a product of the partisan political culture. AUGUSTO'b'\nPresident and Chief Executive'b'\nAmerican Foundation for the Blind'b'\nNew York, Jan. 7, 2014'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Rwanda\xe2\x80\x99s Shrouded Nightmare'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Jan. 10):'b'Michael Dobbs contends that the possibility of intervention by the United States in the 1994 Rwanda genocide was hampered by an absence of \xe2\x80\x9cstronger intelligence\xe2\x80\x9d about the killings and the challenges of trying to \xe2\x80\x9cmake sense\xe2\x80\x9d of what was happening in Africa.'b'Samantha Power suggested otherwise in her Pulitzer Prize-winning book, \xe2\x80\x9cA Problem From Hell.\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Power, now the United States ambassador to the United Nations, reported that within weeks after the mass murder began, the Clinton administration \xe2\x80\x94 and the public \xe2\x80\x94 had ample information about it. Wyman'b'\nInstitute for Holocaust Studies'b'\nWashington, Jan. 10, 2014'b''b''b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 PRESIDENT OBAMA has assured American workers that he won\xe2\x80\x99t let Congress keep him from lending a hand during these tough economic times. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not allow gridlock, inaction or willful indifference to get in our way,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in a speech last year. \xe2\x80\x9cWhatever executive authority I have to help the middle class, I\xe2\x80\x99ll use it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The problem is that most presidential actions that could help significant numbers of middle-class workers do require congressional participation. But here\xe2\x80\x99s one that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t: raising the salary threshold for the exemption to the overtime rules of the 'b'Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938'b'.'b'The act establishes that most workers, after 40 hours of weekly work, are entitled to be paid 1.5 times their regular wage \xe2\x80\x94 a.k.a., overtime. Hourly paid workers fall into this class, as do salaried workers who make less than a specified \xe2\x80\x9cthreshold\xe2\x80\x9d amount. The idea is that employees in higher-status positions (executives, administrators, professionals) ought to be exempt from receiving the overtime premium.'b'But as with the minimum wage, which is not automatically adjusted for inflation and tends to lose real value unless it is raised, the overtime exemption threshold generally languishes. That means that many people who once would have been paid 1.5 times their wage when working overtime are not, violating the spirit of the law.'b'For decades, the Department of Labor periodically updated the overtime salary threshold. But today\xe2\x80\x99s threshold, at $455 a week, is far below historical levels in real terms. And at just $2 a week more than a poverty-level income for a family of four, it is indefensibly low. I propose that President Obama raise the threshold to $970, equal in today\xe2\x80\x99s dollars to the 1975 level of $250.'b'In keeping with the original purpose of the overtime rules, this increase would make overtime pay more expensive, creating an incentive for employers to spread work among other workers (an important goal in today\xe2\x80\x99s low-job-creation environment). It would also more fairly compensate those who do work more than 40 hours.'b'Why do I suggest an updated 1975 value of $970? Because it would restore the proper relationship between the overtime salary threshold and today\xe2\x80\x99s median wage. When the Ford administration raised the threshold in 1975, it was 1.6 times the median wage. Today\xe2\x80\x99s median wage for 40 hours of work is about $670. Were we to update that value by the same 1.6 ratio that prevailed in the mid-1970s, we\xe2\x80\x99d end up with a threshold above $1,000, suggesting that $970 is, if anything, on the low side.'b'At the same time, an updated 1975 value would still leave higher-status positions exempt from the overtime protection. According to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the median weekly earnings for manager-supervisors in various occupations range from $1,520 to $3,995, well above my proposed threshold.'b'You might worry that raising the overtime salary threshold would dampen hiring by creating higher labor costs. But there are good reasons not to expect this outcome. Research suggests that employers have a rough idea of how much overtime they will need from a given hire and adjust the base wage down accordingly. This means that at least some part of the burden of an increased overtime premium falls on the worker. But more important, if employers want to avoid paying overtime, they have an easy way to do so: Hire new workers to do the extra work at the standard wage. (This, again, was one of the objectives of the original law.)'b'The overtime provision of the Fair Labor Standards Act is still a vital contributor to the well-being of millions of American workers, but it needs updating to live up to its potential. At the same time, for President Obama to carry out his pledge to help working people with or without Congress\xe2\x80\x99s participation, he needs policy reforms that make a difference but don\xe2\x80\x99t require legislative approval. Raising the overtime salary threshold would be a simple solution to both problems.'b'Let us count the ways that this week\xe2\x80\x99s traffic-jam scandal is actually 'b'good'b' for Chris Christie\xe2\x80\x99s presidential prospects.'b'First of all, he proved that he could definitely handle an international crisis that required apologizing when the United States did something really stupid. Like \xe2\x80\x94 let\xe2\x80\x99s see. What if the secretary of commerce, in a fit of pique over a Chinese official\xe2\x80\x99s refusal to endorse American seafood products, sent a flotilla of cargo planes to dump tons of surplus mackerel on a Beijing highway? President Christie would be terrific! He could apologize profusely while making it clear that his administration actually had nothing to do with the incident whatsoever and, in fact, was itself a pathetic victim of betrayal by a double agent for the fish industry.'b'And Christie has stamina! On Thursday, he held a press conference on the George Washington Bridge traffic-jam fiasco and talked for nearly two hours. The historian Michael Beschloss says he can\xe2\x80\x99t think of any actual president who ever went on that long. It was even longer than the longest presidential Inaugural Address, which involved an hour and three-quarters of William Henry Harrison.'b'Of course, Harrison then died one month into office. But he did not have a personal trainer, and Chris Christie does. I must admit that I had a mixed reaction to the revelation about the trainer. Good for him on the healthy life front. But there really was something seductive about the idea of a chief executive without a physical fitness regimen. Four years bereft of jogging photo-ops or anecdotes from the pickup games in the White House gym.'b'Anyhow, there are lots of other ways that Christie\xe2\x80\x99s press conference could be viewed as presidential.'b'For instance, Richard Nixon had \xe2\x80\x9cI am not a crook.\xe2\x80\x9d Chris Christie gave us \xe2\x80\x9cI am not a bully.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Also, during Christie\xe2\x80\x99s press conference, he referred to \xe2\x80\x9cmistakes\xe2\x80\x9d 18 times. He seemed to be channeling Ronald Reagan, who famously said \xe2\x80\x9cmistakes were made\xe2\x80\x9d after his administration got caught secretly helping arm rebels in Central America with money made from selling weapons to Iran.'b'O.K., that was a bigger mistake. The buck that stopped at Christie\xe2\x80\x99s desk was not 'b'his'b' buck, just an errant piece of currency that wound up in the office because of treacherous fools over whom he had no actual control whatsoever.'b'So far, so good.'b'Among the critical qualities for a modern president is the ability to instantly cut off old friends and cast them adrift if they become political baggage.
