It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter, because Christie\xe2\x80\x99s example is much better.'b'The central figure in the traffic-jam scandal is a guy named David Wildstein, who is frequently described as a youthful chum of the governor\xe2\x80\x99s. The two were at high school together, and Wildstein later became mayor of Christie\xe2\x80\x99s hometown.'b'Asked about Wildstein \xe2\x80\x94 who spent Thursday pleading the Fifth at a legislative hearing \xe2\x80\x94 Christie expressed joy at having the opportunity to clear up the true parameters of their relationship. \xe2\x80\x9cDavid and I were not friends in high school. ... We didn\xe2\x80\x99t travel in the same circles in high school,\xe2\x80\x9d he said coolly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, I was the class president and athlete. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what David was doing during that period of time.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ouch.'b'The most fascinating part of the governor\xe2\x80\x99s talkathon was his explanation of what he did when he discovered \xe2\x80\x94 just as he was toweling down from a workout \xe2\x80\x94 that his deputy chief of staff had been involved in creating the bridge crisis.'b'Christie claimed he swiftly axed said aide, wasting no time in attempting to find out why she had done it, who she had conspired with, or why she imagined he would think it was a good idea.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m telling you that when I ask for an answer from a member of my staff and they lie ... they\xe2\x80\x99re gone. So I never had to get to the conduct, the underlying conduct,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'What do you think about that, people? Andrew Jackson-like decisiveness? Seems more like a really eerie lack of curiosity.'b'But then we have had presidents who were less inquisitive than a sidewalk. Look at George W. Bush. And he got elected twice.'b'There is often a simplistic, black-or-white, conservative vs. progressive discussion around the dissolution of the traditional family and high single-parent birthrates in America and what these trends may portend for us as a country.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t see the argument as completely binary or the problem as intractable. But, I do believe that we must focus more on complex areas of causation. We can\xe2\x80\x99t look longingly at the halcyon ideals of yore, where marriage held more primacy and premarital sex was considered more depraved.'b'Those days are gone. But there are ways for us to adjust to a new reality rather than simply bemoan it.'b'First, the parameters of the problems: 'b'According to the Guttmacher Institute'b', \xe2\x80\x9cabout half (51 percent) of the 6.6 million pregnancies in the United States each year (3.4 million) are unintended\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe U.S. unintended pregnancy rate is significantly higher than the rate in many other developed countries.\xe2\x80\x9d Among teenagers in high-income countries, those in the United States have the highest rates of pregnancy and some sexually transmitted infections, according to 'b'a report'b' released last year by the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine.'b'This, even though young Americans are not necessarily the most sexually active youth of developed countries, according to 'b'a previous Guttmacher report'b'. That report pointed out two important issues. First, \xe2\x80\x9cless contraceptive use and less use of hormonal methods are the primary reasons U.S. teenagers have the highest rates of pregnancy, childbearing and abortion.\xe2\x80\x9d Second, \xe2\x80\x9cmore sexual partners, a higher prevalence of infection and, probably, less condom use contribute to higher teenage sexually transmitted disease rates in the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Now there are things that I assume most Americans still agree on. Most think young people should delay sexual activity until they are mentally and emotionally capable of reasonably consenting and comprehending the consequences. Most want fewer children born to parents unwilling to provide for those children, or incapable of doing so, emotionally or financially. Most want fewer unplanned and unwanted pregnancies. And, most want fewer women to have to face the often wrenching decisions about what to do about such pregnancies.'b'There are some rather simple ways to move in this direction if we can agree to be less puritanical and more practical. We could, for example, begin teaching young people to value themselves in a way that contextualizes the initiation of sexual activity as a thing fully within their control and not so easily manipulated by peer and societal pressures. Abstinence can be honorable, but it won\xe2\x80\x99t be for everyone. Everyone can be affirmed, though, in the fact that they must love themselves enough emotionally to be in control of whom they allow to love them physically, and when.'b'Furthermore, we must provide thorough and unimpeded sex education \xe2\x80\x94 in the home and at school \xe2\x80\x94 about how to engage in sex safely and responsibly. And, we must provide a full range of reproductive services \xe2\x80\x94 prophylactic and contraceptive as well as post-pregnancy. Here we are moving in the wrong direction. 'b'A Guttmacher report'b' released last week found that more abortion restrictions were enacted in the last three years than in the previous decade.'b'Conservatives often stress marriage as a panacea for many of these problems, and indeed, marriage has its benefits. The fewer partners one engages sexually, the lower the risk of encountering disease. And, in terms of having a child, two adults in a home can often do twice as much as one. But, we must respect all family structures and encourage all parents to be active and engaged in child rearing regardless of living arrangements.'b'Furthermore, much of the discussion about single-parent families and births outside of marriage is focused too heavily on young women and is simply a form of sex shaming that blames them for not being proper guardians of chastity. The shaming itself is a shame, and often inflames the pathology of patriarchy in our culture.'b'We teach boys, overtly and implicitly, that sexual potency is a marker of masculinity and that empathy and emotional depth are purviews of a lesser sex. The ways we force boys to adhere to a perilously narrow reading of masculinity become a form of \xe2\x80\x9coppression all dressed up as awesomeness,\xe2\x80\x9d as Lisa Wade, an Occidental College sociology professor, 'b'put it last month'b' in Salon.'b'Boys are not taught to value themselves as fully human, but only as conquerors of everything \xe2\x80\x94 women, the workplace, the world. And men who are incapable of valuing their own humanity are incapable of fully valuing the humanity of a love interest.'b'We can address our societal problems, but to do so we must first address our societal issues.'b'This is certainly turning out to be quite the year for 50th anniversaries. Fifty years ago next month, 'b'the Beatles made their U.S. debut'b' on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Ed Sullivan Show.\xe2\x80\x9d In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson started the War on Poverty. And 50 years ago Saturday, the surgeon general of the United States issued the single most important report that would ever come out of that office. It 'b'linked cigarette smoking to illness and death'b'.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to remember now just how prevalent smoking used to be. In the mid-1960s, around half the men in the country smoked; for women, the number was 35 percent. People smoked in their offices, smoked in restaurants, smoked on airplanes. Indeed, Paul Billings of the American Lung Association recalls that the airlines often gave passengers small packets of cigarettes when they boarded the plane.'b'But by the 1950s, scientists were beginning to equate cigarettes with lung cancer and other fatal diseases, a linkage the tobacco industry vehemently denied. In 1962, the prestigious Royal College of Physicians in Britain 'b'issued a report connecting smoking and lung cancer'b'. After seeing that report, Dr. Luther Terry, who was then the surgeon general, put together an advisory board and asked it to report back to him on the potential dangers of cigarettes.'b'Did it ever: the advisory board\xe2\x80\x99s subsequent report not only linked smoking to lung cancer but also to emphysema and cardiovascular disease. It labeled cigarettes a health hazard. \xe2\x80\x9cIn general,\xe2\x80\x9d it concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cthe greater the number of cigarettes smoked daily, the higher the death rate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt was a landmark report,\xe2\x80\x9d says Scott Ballin, a longtime tobacco control and public health advocate. For the first time, the full weight of the federal government stood behind the notion that smoking killed. Antitobacco groups felt empowered and pressed for changes. In 1965, Congress passed legislation banning cigarette advertising on television \xe2\x80\x94 while also forcing the tobacco companies to put a surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s warning on every pack of cigarettes. The tobacco companies fought the legislation, while continuing to deny that cigarettes killed.'b'And so it went for the next 30 years. The surgeon general would issue reports on, say, nicotine addiction or secondhand smoke. The tobacco companies would deny the obvious. And antitobacco activists would push for change.'b'This culminated with the tobacco wars in the 1990s. With the activists continuing to push hard, and whistle-blowers 'b'leaking damning documents'b', attorneys general around the country sued the tobacco companies and 'b'wound up settling'b' for a staggering $246 billion over 25 years.'b'And all the while, as Americans learned more about the dangers of tobacco, cigarette smoking dropped, and dropped again. By 2005, the percentage of Americans who smoked was down to 21 percent, a remarkable achievement. But since then, the percentage drops have been much smaller; today, it is estimated that around 18 percent of the country smokes. \xe2\x80\x9cSeven out of 10 smokers say they want to quit,\xe2\x80\x9d says Billings at the lung association, but their addiction is too powerful. More than 400,000 Americans still die prematurely each year from smoking.'b'Today, thanks to a law passed in 2009, the Food and Drug Administration has the power to regulate tobacco. (Its first set of tobacco regulations has been sitting at the Office of Management and Budget since October.) It\xe2\x80\x99s a different environment now, not only because of F.D.A. regulation but because there are now \xe2\x80\x9charm reduction\xe2\x80\x9d products, like e-cigarettes, that potentially make it easier for people who want to quit.'b'Yet many in the public health community have pushed for 'b'e-cigarettes to be treated the same as combustible cigarettes'b'; when you have been fighting a war for nearly half a century, it is hard to put down your weapons. Instead of focusing on the potential for e-cigarettes to save lives, they worry instead that the new products will serve as a gateway to smoking \xe2\x80\x94 a fear that has yet to show up in any study.'b'In honor of the 50th anniversary of the surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report, the Journal of the American Medical Association devoted much of 'b'its current issue'b' to tobacco and tobacco control. It published a study showing that the report may have saved as many as eight million lives.'b'Another article in the current issue of the journal 'b'is by David Abrams'b', the executive director of the Schroeder Institute for Tobacco Research and Policy Studies. He had been among those who had fought in the tobacco wars, but, in recent years, he had come around to the idea that a new way was needed.'b'Yes, he wrote, there needed to be more science around e-cigarettes, and, yes, they should be kept away from minors, and, yes, their advertising shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t resemble the old tobacco come-ons. But, he concluded, with proper regulation, e-cigarettes \xe2\x80\x9chave the potential to make the combusting of tobacco obsolete.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Which was the whole point of the exercise back in 1964. Maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s time for another surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report.'b''b'Dear Readers: Some of you had trouble finding my most recent column, on alcoholism. From 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cgeomurshiva of copperstown, ny\xe2\x80\x9d'b':'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBeing a critical care nurse for a long time , I have seen what alcohol can do to anyone one of us. They become statistics only. Alas.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is nothing good to say about 'b'the December employment report'b', which showed that only 74,000 jobs were added last month. But dismal as it was, the report came at an opportune political moment. The new numbers rebut the Republican arguments that jobless benefits need not be renewed, and that the current minimum wage is adequate. At the same time, they underscore the need, only recently raised to the top of the political agenda, to combat poverty and inequality.'b'The report showed that average monthly job growth in 2013 was 182,000, basically unchanged from 2012. Even the decline in the jobless rate last month, from 7 percent in November to 6.7 percent, was a sign of weakness: It mainly reflects a shrinking labor force \xe2\x80\x94 not new hiring \xe2\x80\x94 as the share of workers employed or looking for work fell to the lowest level since 1978. That\xe2\x80\x99s a tragic waste of human capital. It would be comforting to ascribe the dwindling labor force mainly to retirements or other long-term changes, but most of the decline is due to weak job opportunities and weak labor demand since the Great Recession.'b'One result is that the share of jobless workers who have been unemployed for six months or longer has remained stubbornly high. In December, it was nearly 38 percent, still higher by far than at any time before the Great Recession, in records going back to 1948.'b'And yet, nearly 1.3 million of those long-term unemployed had their federal jobless benefits abruptly cut off at the end of last year, after Republicans refused to renew the federal unemployment program in the latest budget deal. Each week the program is not reinstated, another 72,000 jobless people who otherwise would have qualified for benefits will find there is no longer a federal program to turn to. Worse, in the Senate this week, after a show of willingness to discuss renewing the benefits, Republicans objected to a bill to do just that. They had demanded that a renewal be paid for, but they didn\xe2\x80\x99t like how Democrats proposed to do that \xe2\x80\x94 with spending cuts at the end of the budget window in 2024 in exchange for relief today.'b'There was no need to pay for the benefits, which have such a crucial and positive effect \xe2\x80\x94 on families, the economy and poverty \xe2\x80\x94 that it would be sound to renew them even if the government borrowed to do so. But Republicans would rather criticize President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s handling of the economy than help those left behind.'b'A similar dynamic is developing around the drive for a higher minimum wage. In the December jobs report, the average hourly wage for most workers was $20.35. That means that the minimum wage, at $7.25 an hour, is only one-third of the average, rather than one-half, as was the case historically. Raising the wage to $10.10 an hour, as Democrats have proposed, would help to restore the historical relationship. But even that would fall far short of the roughly $17 an hour that workers at the bottom of the wage scale would be earning if increased labor productivity were reflected in their pay, rather than in corporate profits, executive compensation and shareholder returns.'b'Republicans, however, are opposed to any increase, as if the numbers don\xe2\x80\x99t speak for themselves. Their stance also dismisses research, and common sense, which says that raising the wages of low- and moderate-income workers is essential for lessening both poverty and inequality.'b'Instead, in the past week, they have introduced ostensibly \xe2\x80\x9cantipoverty\xe2\x80\x9d ideas, most prominently Senator Marco Rubio\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'plan'b' to transform federal safety net programs into state block grants, another of the shopworn Republican ideas that also include privatizing federal services and slashing domestic spending. Block grants have allowed states to disregard the needs of the least fortunate. The proposal would set back the debate on wages, poverty and inequality.'b'The December jobs report is telling Congress what it needs to do. Unfortunately, that will not lead to action anytime soon.'b'Four years after the earthquake, Haiti is a fragile, largely forgotten country. It\xe2\x80\x99s possible that some natural or man-made crisis this year could push it back into the headlines. But sustained attention, with the kind of support from outside that Haiti still needs to rebuild and become more self-sufficient, is mostly gone.'b'The United Nations says as much in a 'b'recently published'b' Humanitarian Action Plan for Haiti that strives for an ambitious and hopeful tone but mostly sounds forlorn. It notes some positive changes. More than three-fourths of young children are now in primary school, up from about half. Cholera deaths are down, as is the number of homeless quake survivors. The population in the camps reportedly fell to 172,000 last year, from a peak of 1.5 million who were without shelter just after the quake in 2010.'b'But such hopeful signs are easily displaced by other dreary facts. Humanitarian aid is petering out as agencies leave and money dries up. The decline means Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s partners should be stepping up development efforts, to put the country on a sustainable recovery path, but that isn\xe2\x80\x99t happening. Meanwhile, Haiti still has half the world\xe2\x80\x99s cholera cases, as the United Nations \xe2\x80\x94 whose troops caused the epidemic \xe2\x80\x94 is battling it with an underfinanced eradication plan.'b'For all the talk \xe2\x80\x94 and the $14 billion pledged by governments the world over since Jan. 12, 2010 \xe2\x80\x94 what is there to show? The grand total of new homes built in four years since the quake is dismally low: 7,515. The signature American-led redevelopment project \xe2\x80\x94 an industrial park in Caracol, on Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s north coast, which was supposed to create as many as 60,000 jobs \xe2\x80\x94 had created 2,590 at the end of 2013. Workers\xe2\x80\x99 rights advocates reported last fall that garment factories at Caracol and elsewhere routinely violate Haitian minimum-wage laws and pay most workers too little to live on.'b'The new United Nations action plan lacks the loftiness of previous development proposals, but it focuses on four critical, and surely achievable, goals: housing the homeless, reducing cholera, feeding 600,000 \xe2\x80\x9cfood insecure\xe2\x80\x9d Haitians and strengthening national institutions. Financing it for one year will take $169 million.'b'The United States should stick to its commitments to Haiti, with a particular focus on building and repairing housing (permanent homes, not temporary shelters), supporting agriculture and building the capacity of the Haitian government and local businesses and organizations. Data from the United States Agency for International Development show that barely 5 percent of its financing for projects in Haiti in 2012 went to Haitian-led institutions; that is not good enough.'b'It would help, meanwhile, to have a better idea of what\xe2\x80\x99s going on. A bill, the 'b'Assessing Progress in Haiti Act'b', would require more detail and transparency from the State Department in reporting to Congress how humanitarian and development money is spent. The bill, sponsored by Representative Barbara Lee, a California Democrat, passed the House with bipartisan support; the Senate should follow suit.'b'The United Nations plan notes that \xe2\x80\x9cthe slightest shock\xe2\x80\x9d to Haiti could send it into another round of misery and death. It is a country still in the grips of an emergency, even though beyond its shores, nobody seems to remember.'b'There is some rare good news on the issue of securing and containing deadly nuclear materials. In the last two years, seven countries have forsaken their uranium and plutonium stockpiles, bringing the number of nations still possessing appreciable quantities of nuclear fuel usable for bomb-making down to 25. In 1991, the number was 52.'b'The data comes from the Nuclear Threat Initiative, a private advocacy group that promotes the safekeeping of nuclear materials. Following up on its first report in 2012, the group surveyed the precautions each country had in place and ranked nations based on their security practices. The report issued on Wednesday covered factors like national laws, regulations, participation in international treaties and physical security, including whether a state has armed guards protecting its facilities.'b'The countries deserving special praise \xe2\x80\x94 Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Mexico, Sweden, Ukraine and Vietnam \xe2\x80\x94 effectively gave up their bomb-making capability and now have less than one kilogram (2.2 pounds) of material that can fuel nuclear weapons.'b'Of the countries that still have weapons-usable nuclear material, Australia placed first on the security ranking, because it reduced its supply of nuclear materials and ratified a treaty that commits countries to criminalize acts of nuclear terrorism and bring nuclear criminals to justice. The United States fell to 11th in part because it failed to ratify two nuclear accords.'b'Despite progress, the challenges ahead are daunting. At the bottom of the security rankings were North Korea (25), which is continuing to expand its nuclear weapons program, and Iran (24), which is in negotiations with the United States and other world powers on an agreement to freeze and roll back its program.'b'Pakistan\xe2\x80\x99s rank rose to 22, up slightly from two years ago and ahead of India (23), because the Pakistani government took steps to update its nuclear security regulations. Still, both countries are nuclear-armed, have weak safety and security ratings, and are still increasing their nuclear fuel stockpiles for military and civilian purposes.'b'The world is already awash in 2,000 metric tons of weapons-usable nuclear material spread across hundreds of sites around the globe. According to the International Atomic Energy Agency, 100 incidents of theft and other unauthorized activities involving nuclear and radioactive material are reported to the organization every year.'b'There are many steps the international community can take to prevent nuclear fuel from falling into terrorists\xe2\x80\x99 hands, including developing a system of global standards for securing the material and persuading nations to ratify nuclear security treaties. World leaders should push this agenda forward when they meet in The Hague for their third nuclear summit meeting this March.'b'TEL AVIV \xe2\x80\x94 POLITICS, to Ariel Sharon, was like a Ferris wheel. But he didn\xe2\x80\x99t make do with just staying on the wheel; he did all he could to climb to the top and stay there.'b'Mr. Sharon exuded strength, authority, leadership and charisma. His briefings before missions were precise, clear and unequivocal, instilling in his men a sense of trust and confidence. His orders were delivered in a lighthearted, sometimes cynical tone, with a piercing sense of humor. And he fought at the front of his forces, taking great risks.'b'While he was still a young, relatively junior officer, Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion wrote in his diary about Mr. Sharon: \xe2\x80\x9can insightful young man, innovative; if he were to surmount his weakness of not telling the truth in his reports he could be an exemplary military leader.\xe2\x80\x9d He was right.'b'In 1982, when he was defense minister, Mr. Sharon lied to Prime Minister Menachem Begin and the cabinet by presenting a plan for a limited ground incursion to Lebanon with a strict time limit, while in fact ordering the army to conquer a large part of Lebanon, shattering the Palestine Liberation Organization\xe2\x80\x99s armed forces there and inflicting severe damage on the Syrian military presence. (All this was achieved, but the campaign was a political disaster.)'b'Mr. Sharon realized that shaping the historical narrative to present himself in a positive light would enable him to move up in the military and then the political hierarchy. Even though the operations of the counterterrorism unit he commanded back in the 1950s (known as Unit 101) never actually reduced the level of terrorist attacks, Mr. Sharon managed to shape the way it was portrayed as if he and his commandos had rescued the nation from chaos.'b'In 101\xe2\x80\x99s retaliation raids, many Arab civilians were killed. In one attack he commanded, the unit blew up 45 houses, killing some 65 of their inhabitants, men, women and children. He claimed that he thought the houses were empty.'b'Mr. Sharon devoted similar efforts to perpetuating the myth that it was he, as commander of an armored division, who saved Israel from sustaining a devastating defeat in 1973. He ordered the tapes of his division\xe2\x80\x99s radio messages hidden in a secret location so that he could speak about his feats without allowing others to examine the facts. And he conducted a successful struggle against the Israel Defense Forces\xe2\x80\x99 history department to prevent them from publishing the evidence of what had actually happened: how he had disobeyed many of the orders he received from the supreme command, how his division was only one element among many in the successful counterattack across the Suez Canal and how he had ignored calls for assistance from other forces.'b'Nine years later, Mr. Sharon didn\xe2\x80\x99t even try to find excuses for his disregard for the loss of life on his way to the top. He ordered the forces invading Lebanon \xe2\x80\x9cto finish off\xe2\x80\x9d southern Beirut, where the Palestinian refugee camps and P.L.O. bases were located, and \xe2\x80\x9craze it to the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d An Israeli weekly newspaper depicted him on the cover as a ruthless Viking trampling on Lebanon.'b'Mr. Sharon didn\xe2\x80\x99t like the analogy, but, like the Vikings, he made his goal the physical destruction of the enemy and, in this case, the elimination of its leader, Yasir Arafat. Mr. Sharon was ready to stop at nothing and to implicate himself and the Israeli army in war crimes against large numbers of civilians.'b'The entanglement in Lebanon and the ensuing public protests led to his removal from the defense ministry. Most Israelis believed Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s career was over.'b'Yet he remained on the Ferris wheel for years, as a Knesset member for the Likud Party and as a cabinet minister \xe2\x80\x94 until February 2001, when, with Israelis desperate for a strong leader who could stop the violence and terrorism of the second Intifada, he defeated the incumbent prime minister, Ehud Barak.'b'And then he changed. As long as he was striving for power, Mr. Sharon had been a wild man, a mega-intriguer. When he reached the top, in the midst of a wave of suicide attacks that were wreaking havoc, Mr. Sharon was the right leader at the right time. He ordered that all the resources the defense establishment had developed in preparation for the next war should now be diverted to fighting terrorism.'b'Mr. Sharon realized that without the consent and support of the United States, he would not be able to wage the aggressive war on terror that he envisaged. His closest counselor and chief of staff, Dov Weissglas, told him, \xe2\x80\x9cany warmth, support and friendship that you may earn from the U.S. government in your role as an antiterror warrior fades away when you put on your mega-settler cap.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In order to obtain America\xe2\x80\x99s consent, Mr. Sharon was prepared to sacrifice the project to which he had devoted years of effort: Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Later on, his readiness for concessions on settlements sprang also from a belief that, in the end, there would be no alternative to Israel withdrawing from most of the occupied territories to enable the establishment of an independent Palestinian state.'b'If Mr. Sharon had not had a stroke in 2006, which led, ultimately, to his death on Saturday, he would most likely have reached a peace agreement with the Palestinians. And he would have used his powerful personality and irresistible drive, as well as the widespread affection he had acquired among his people, to force the right-wing settler movement to accept it.'b'This time, I have no doubt, Mr. Sharon would indeed have saved Israel \xe2\x80\x94 mainly from itself.'b'WITHIN just over a year we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen the Newtown shootings, the bombing at the Boston Marathon and the rescue of the kidnapped women in Cleveland. But which details of these events will you remember in a year? In five years? Will you remember the names of the perpetrators or the victims, the places where they happened, or the month and the year?'b'It won\xe2\x80\x99t surprise you to learn that the very recent news events are the ones we remember best. The Japanese psychologist Terumasa Kogure found sharp drops in recollection at four years and eight years after an event, but sometimes we\xe2\x80\x99ll remember the details of far older news stories. Indeed, recent psychological research shows that our memory for news is not as straightforward as we might think \xe2\x80\x94 and the reasons offer insight into how the mind works.'b'Not surprisingly, your proximity to the story makes you remember it better: Two years after 9/11, a study by the cognitive psychologist Kathy Pezdek found that New Yorkers recalled more of the details than those living in California and Hawaii.'b'And the way you get the information matters, too. As an offshoot of research into a new test for amnesia, the Dutch psychologist Martijn Meeter began giving general populations around the world his Daily News Memory Test, asking them about recent news items. It\xe2\x80\x99s not easy. The average score is just 42 percent. What\xe2\x80\x99s striking is that a person\xe2\x80\x99s score is not best predicted by the amount of news they watch on TV, but whether or not they read a daily newspaper.'b'Likewise, whether you hear the news personally or learn it from the news media makes a difference. An individual is more likely to convey shock and genuine emotion, but not to include as much information as the news report.'b'The psychologist John Neil Bohannon asked a large group of contemporary college students how they heard about the Challenger shuttle disaster, while he tracked down alumni from the same college from 1942 to 1945 to ask them about Pearl Harbor. He found that in both sets, those who were told the news personally remembered more about what they were doing at the time, but if they heard it on the news or read it in a newspaper, they remembered more facts about the event.'b'Recalling the timing of an event is particularly tricky. In one experiment, Professor Kogure gave people a general description of a news event, like \xe2\x80\x9ca former member of the Beatles was shot,\xe2\x80\x9d and then asked for his name, the date and the place. People were more likely to recall the name than the date.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not surprising, but the reason is instructive: Working out the timing of events is something we find particularly difficult, partly because of a phenomenon known as telescoping, where you think that events happened more recently than they did. Who hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been shocked to hear that, for example, it has already been three years since the Chilean mine rescue, or 27 years since the disaster at Chernobyl?'b'Sometimes we can date a public event through reconstruction, linking it to other personal memories from that month or year. Two British psychologists, Alex Fradera and Jamie Ward, found that if people mapped out timelines of their own lives on a piece of paper, they were better at estimating the dates of news events because they linked them with their personal lives.'b'But occasionally we simply know the exact date of an event, without knowing why. One theory is that we create a memory that comes with some kind of time-tag attached, explaining why it happened. The neurologist Antonio Damasio has found that people with amnesia lose these time-tags, finding it impossible to distinguish which events happened in which decade.'b'And if we think that the years and months are hard to work out, the day of the week is even more difficult, particularly if it was a weekday. On Friday, Jan. 31, 1986, there was a mild earthquake in Mentor, Ohio. Everyone in town felt it. But when the psychologist William Friedman sent out questionnaires about it nine months later, he found that although most people recalled the time of day it occurred to within an hour, they couldn\xe2\x80\x99t name the day of the week.Sometimes it\xe2\x80\x99s not so much the details of the story itself that we remember well, but where we were when we heard about it. These so-called \xe2\x80\x9cflashbulb\xe2\x80\x9d memories mean that you get a vivid picture in your mind of exactly what you were doing.'b'I remember being awakened at 5 a.m. one Sunday morning by my husband\xe2\x80\x99s boss, a news editor, calling him to come straight to work to cover \xe2\x80\x9cthis Diana death thing.\xe2\x80\x9d Until we turned on the radio, we had no idea what he meant. (Flashbulb memories are hard to study because of course you can\xe2\x80\x99t induce them in a laboratory. You have to wait for the really big news events, like 9/11 or the shooting of John F. Kennedy.)'b'So in a decade\xe2\x80\x99s time you may or may not remember the details of the Newtown shooting, the Boston bombing and the Cleveland rescue. But it won\xe2\x80\x99t be because of the objective importance of the events. It will all depend on how you heard, where you were, what was going on in your life and how many newspapers you read.'b''b'Lise Funderburg, a journalist, interviewed Yael Ben-Zion, a photographer raised in Israel, about her new book, \xe2\x80\x9cIntermarried,\xe2\x80\x9d published by Kehrer,'b' 'b'which features families from the Washington Heights neighborhood where she lives with her French husband and 5-year-old twins.'b''b''b'Q.'b' What inspired this project?'b''b'A.'b' I saw an Israeli television campaign that showed faces on trees and bus stops, like missing children ads. A voice-over said, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen these people? Fifty percent of young Jewish people outside of Israel marry non-Jews. We are losing them.\xe2\x80\x9d I happen to be married to a person who is not Jewish. And, so for me it was, \xe2\x80\x9cAah, they\xe2\x80\x99re losing me.\xe2\x80\x9d I\xe2\x80\x99m not religious, but this campaign made me wonder more generally why people choose to live with someone who is not from their immediate social group, and what challenges they face.'b''b'Q.'b' How did you establish your taxonomy for what qualified as mixed?'b''b'A.'b' I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t going to go in the street and ask couples if they were mixed. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t grow up here; I didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know what terminology to use. But I live in a very diverse Manhattan community that has an online parent list with more than 2,000 families on it. I put up an ad saying I was looking for couples that define themselves as mixed. I said it could be different religion, ethnicity or social background. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t use the word race, because I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure how politically correct that was. All the couples who responded are either interfaith or interracial or both, but my goal from the beginning wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to create some statistical visual document. For example, I have hardly any Asian people, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think there are any Muslims, and the reason is that they didn\xe2\x80\x99t approach me.'b''b'Q.'b' Can you talk about how you chose to communicate the intermarriage experience?'b''b'A.'b' I could have done straight portraiture of people sitting on the couch who either had or did not have different skin color. For me, that would have been less engaging. When I create work, I look for something more complex: it\xe2\x80\x99s not the obvious Christmas tree next to the Hanukkah menorah. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to make it too easy.'b'Objects and spaces can say a lot about their inhabitants. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know if this is clich\xc3\xa9d, but in the end, for me, this book is about love. I wanted to describe the way these people live and I wanted to have things they struggle with hinted at but not necessarily in your face.'b''b'Q. 'b'In what ways is your own marriage an intermarriage?'b''b'A.'b' The obvious thing would be that I\xe2\x80\x99m Jewish and he\xe2\x80\x99s not. He does not define himself as Christian, but we celebrate Christmas as a cultural holiday. We had a Christmas tree. If you\xe2\x80\x99d asked me before the boys were born if I\xe2\x80\x99d ever have a Christmas tree in my home, as a good Jew I\xe2\x80\x99d have said no.'b'On paper, we cannot be more different. We come from different countries, religions and professional backgrounds, but there are many things that connect us. This is something that was repeated in my conversations with a lot of couples: When you have a relationship with someone not from your own group or where you expect there might be difficulties, you think of the difficult questions in advance. If there weren\xe2\x80\x99t values that were important to us both, we wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been together to begin with.'b'I speak to my kids only in Hebrew and Ugo speaks to them only in French. But it\xe2\x80\x99s still important to me not only that they speak Hebrew but that they read and write it.'b'In both Israel and France, if they aren\xe2\x80\x99t completely proficient in the language, they will be treated as outsiders and will have difficulties talking to families and friends. It\xe2\x80\x99s another challenge to deal with.'b''b'Q.'b' Do you have an agenda or hope for how viewers experience the project?'b''b'A.'b' I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to convince people of anything. I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying intermarriage is the right thing in every context. People make their own choices. You walk up the street in my neighborhood, and most people are intermarried in one way or another, but I would never feel comfortable to talk to them about this just out of the blue. When I show the work, though, I always end up in conversations I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have had any other way. I showed it in Santa Fe and this guy came over and told me he\xe2\x80\x99s a Jewish person married to a Native American and they had the first bris in Santa Fe Indian Hospital. The project creates an opportunity to talk about personal issues that are important, that are out there, and that people are dealing with.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 I HAVE learned two things covering politics.'b'One, first impressions are often right. John Edwards is slick. Hillary Clinton is expedient. W. was in over his head. Barack Obama is too much in his head. Chris Christie can be a bully.'b'Politicians are surrounded by spinners who work tirelessly to shape our perceptions of the characters of their bosses. Pols know how to polish scratches in their image with sin-and-redemption news conferences, TV confessionals and self-deprecating turns at hoary Washington press banquets. As Carter spokesman Jody Powell joked, if Hitler and Eva Braun came on stage at the Gridiron Dinner and mocked themselves in a song-and-dance routine, Washington chatterers would say, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, they\xe2\x80\x99re not so bad.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After being showered with spin, you say to yourself, maybe that first impression was wrong. But often it isn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Christie\xe2\x80\x99s two-hour \xe2\x80\x9cI am not a bully\xe2\x80\x9d news conference was operatic about an act of malice so petty it did not merit being called \xe2\x80\x9cauthentic Jersey corruption,\xe2\x80\x9d as New Jersey native Jon Stewart said, adding that it was unworthy of a state with a severed horse head on its flag.'b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re going to wage a vendetta, at least make it a well-thought-out one. How can Christie &amp; Co. run a national campaign when they can\xe2\x80\x99t even aim straight? How moronic to think the mayor of Fort Lee would get blamed for problems on a bridge that everyone knows is controlled by the Port Authority. If you want to be malicious, it would be so easy to put a project close to the mayor\xe2\x80\x99s heart on hold for a few months or redirect 60 state snowplows the night before a storm.'b'The governor groveled to New Jersey residents after his aides so gleefully burned them (even joking about children being late for the first day of school because of the orchestrated gridlock on the George Washington Bridge).'b'After zapping Obama for being so clueless that he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find \xe2\x80\x9cthe light switch of leadership\xe2\x80\x9d in a dark room, Christie is trying to salvage his once blazing career by claiming he was in a dark room, clueless to the bogus traffic study masking a revenge plan that top aides were executing in plain sight.'b'The epic news conference felt like a scene out of the governor\xe2\x80\x99s favorite movie, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Godfather\xe2\x80\x9d: Christie offering his tremulous, grandiose, self-pitying public apologia while in cross-cut scenes, his henchmen were getting rid of those who threatened his operation.'b'Calling his deputy chief of staff Bridget Anne Kelly \xe2\x80\x9cstupid\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdeceitful,\xe2\x80\x9d he threw her off the bridge, without talking to her himself or, as Niall O\xe2\x80\x99Dowd slyly wrote in IrishCentral.com, even extending the courtesy of the old Irish wedding night admonition: \xe2\x80\x9cBrace yourself, Bridget.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He also disappeared his two-time campaign manager, Bill Stepien. His cronies at the Port Authority, Bill Baroni and David Wildstein, fell on their swords last month.'b'Christie took a line straight out of the Robert DeNiro handbook, lamenting: \xe2\x80\x9cI am heartbroken that someone who I permitted to be in that circle of trust for the last five years betrayed my trust.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet we know workplaces are chameleon-like. I once had a publisher who loved the Audubon Society, so we ran a lot of bird stories. I had another boss who wore suspenders, so guys in the office started wearing suspenders.'b'Shades of Watergate: Since they were headed toward a landslide, you\xe2\x80\x99d think the Christie crew would have been in a more benevolent mood. But given the governor\xe2\x80\x99s past flashes of vindictive behavior, this was probably a wink-wink, nod-nod deal. Question: Who will rid me of this meddlesome mayor? Answer: The \xe2\x80\x9clittle Serbian\xe2\x80\x9d has been dealt with.'b'The second thing I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned from covering politics is that we can debate ad nauseam whether Christie was telling the truth, shading it or bluffing. But we can\xe2\x80\x99t gauge that from his impressive, marathon Trenton performance art.'b'No matter how jaded we feel in the news business, we are still suckers for the big lie. It\xe2\x80\x99s tough to wrap your head around a stunning level of duplicity.'b'I learned this lesson the hard way covering Paul Tsongas\xe2\x80\x99s presidential surge in 1992. When The Times\xe2\x80\x99s Dr. Larry Altman came on the campaign trail to interview Tsongas, he was skeptical about the candidate\xe2\x80\x99s claim that his lymphoma had not recurred. I told Altman it was impossible for me to believe that Tsongas, who prided himself on his honesty and who was so straightforward he was mocked as \xe2\x80\x9cSaint Paul\xe2\x80\x9d by Clinton aides, could lie about that \xe2\x80\x94 especially given the profound political consequences.'b'Dr. Altman was right, as Tsongas later admitted. The candidate and his doctors at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston repeatedly said he was cancer-free when he was not.'b'A cascade of subsequent outraged denials about transgressive behavior delivered with bravado and finger wagging, from Gary Hart to Bill Clinton to John Edwards to Anthony Weiner, has persuaded me that politicians \xe2\x80\x94 who are narcissists and, in essence, actors stuck in the same role \xe2\x80\x94 can persuasively tell the big lie if they believe their futures are on the line.'b'The Christie saga is still unraveling. Maybe he was a dupe in the dark. Maybe the man in the fleece jacket is fleecing us. Let\xe2\x80\x99s just say, I\xe2\x80\x99m not yet permitting him in my circle of trust.'b'THIS week 'b'Maria Shriver'b' brings together a star-studded cast of celebrities, from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Beyonc\xc3\xa9, to call attention to the economic plight of American women and demand that women\xe2\x80\x99s needs be put \xe2\x80\x9cat the center of policy making.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But is this really the time to focus on women? For nearly four decades, feminists have decried \xe2\x80\x9cthe feminization of poverty.\xe2\x80\x9d However, since the 1980s there has been a defeminization of poverty, as a growing proportion of men have fallen on hard times. In recent years men have experienced especially significant losses in income and job security.'b'Although women are still more likely to be poor than men, on average women\xe2\x80\x99s income and labor-force participation 'b'have been rising'b' since the 1970s. By contrast, between 1970 and 2010 the median earnings of men fell by 19 percent, and those of men with just a high school diploma by a stunning 'b'41 percent'b'. And while\xc2\xa0women have regained all the jobs they lost during the recession, men have regained just 75 percent.'b'Since about 1980 the percentage of men and women in middle-skill jobs has declined. But for women, nearly all of that decline was because of increased representation in higher-skill jobs. Women\xe2\x80\x99s employment in low-skill jobs increased by just 1 percent. By contrast, for men, half the decline in middle-skill jobs was a result of increases in low-skill jobs.'b'The most urgent issue facing working Americans today is not the glass ceiling. It is the sinking floor. So wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it make more sense to focus on gender-neutral economic policies?'b'Actually, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, because \xe2\x80\x9cgender-neutral\xe2\x80\x9d work practices and social policies were traditionally based on a masculine model. Employers assumed that there was no need to accommodate caregiving obligations because the \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d worker had a wife to do that. Policy makers assumed there was no need for universal programs such as family allowances and public child care because the \xe2\x80\x9cnormal\xe2\x80\x9d woman had a husband to support her and her children. Accordingly, most social benefits, such as Social Security and unemployment insurance, were tied to prior participation in the labor market. Welfare was a stigmatized and stingy backup for misfits who were not in a male-breadwinner family.'b'Social and economic policies constructed around the male breadwinner model have always disadvantaged women. But today they are dragging down millions of men as well. Paradoxically, putting gender equity issues at the center of social planning would now be in the interests of most men.'b'This was not so evident 40 or 50 years ago, when the struggle for gender equity threatened many male entitlements. In those days, men of every skill and income level had preferential access to jobs that provided security, benefits and rising wages. As the sociologist Erin Hatton shows, when employers needed cheap temporary workers, they turned to companies like Kelly Girl, whose ads bragged that unlike the gimme-gimme male worker, the Kelly Girl was a \xe2\x80\x9cNever-Never\xe2\x80\x9d employee: \xe2\x80\x9cNever costs you a dime for slack time. (When the workload drops, you drop her.) Never has a cold, slipped disk or loose tooth. (Not on your time anyway!)\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today, however, becoming a \xe2\x80\x9cnever-never\xe2\x80\x9d employee is increasingly a gender-neutral fate. Millions of men face working conditions that traditionally characterized women\xe2\x80\x99s lives: low wages, minimal benefits, part-time or temporary jobs, and periods of joblessness. Poverty is becoming defeminized because the working conditions of many men are becoming more feminized.'b'Whether they realize it or not, men now have a direct stake in policies that advance gender equity. Most of the wage gap between women and men is no longer a result of blatant male favoritism in pay and promotion. Much of it stems from general wage inequality in society at large.'b'IN most countries, women tend to be concentrated in lower-wage jobs. The United States actually has a higher proportion of skilled and highly paid female workers than countries like Sweden and Norway. Yet as a whole, Swedish and Norwegian women earn a higher proportion of the average male wage than American women because the gap between high and low wages is much smaller in those countries.'b'Establishing a \xe2\x80\x9clivable wage\xe2\x80\x9d floor would immediately reduce the gap in average pay between American women and men. But it would also boost the wages of millions of low-income male workers, who earn a much lower percentage of the average male wage than their counterparts in other wealthy countries. In 2009, one in every four American workers earned less than two-thirds of the national median hourly wage, the highest proportion of low-wage work in 19 Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, according to the economist John Schmitt of the Center for Economic and Policy Research.'b'Another source of the gender pay gap is the lack of reliable, affordable child care, which forces many mothers to stay home or work part time even when they need and want full-time work.'b'Prioritizing child care would not just be a boon for mothers but for millions of fathers as well. The highest proportion of stay-at-home moms is found among women married to men in the bottom 25 percent of the country\xe2\x80\x99s income distribution. Most of these women cannot afford to work because of the 'b'high cost of child care'b', even though their partners and children would benefit from the increased income.'b'Putting women first would mean strengthening America\xe2\x80\x99s social safety net, because a higher proportion of single-mother families live in poverty here than in any other wealthy country. But a stronger safety net would help single-father families and two-parent families, too, because these families also have higher poverty rates than their counterparts in other wealthy countries.'b'Putting women first would also mean changing unemployment insurance rules that leave many part-time workers ineligible for benefits and disqualify people who leave a job due to a family member\xe2\x80\x99s medical emergency. Women are especially affected by such rules, but the expansion of part-time and temporary jobs since the 1970s has left a growing number of male workers vulnerable as well. And a recent Pew poll found that almost 30 percent of fathers had reduced their work hours and 10 percent quit a job to care for a family member.'b'Putting women\xe2\x80\x99s traditional needs at the center of social planning is not reverse sexism. It\xe2\x80\x99s the best way to reverse the increasing economic vulnerability of men and women alike.'b'Given the increasing insecurity of many American men, they have good reason to back feminist policies. And if those policies alienate some women in the upper echelons, then maybe feminism isn\xe2\x80\x99t for every woman, and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to be.'b''b'Anthony Mandler'b' is a film director and photographer probably best known for the noir music videos he has created for pop artists such as Rihanna, Jay-Z, Beyonc\xc3\xa9, Eminem and Lana Del Rey.'b''b'READING'b' Right now I\xe2\x80\x99m into 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cShop Class as Soulcraft,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' by Matthew Crawford. He is guiding you, and you are giving yourself over to be affected and changed.'b''b'FOLLOWING'b' I look at 'b'Pinterest'b' every day. I have curated my own feed of things that inspire me. It\xe2\x80\x99s got a very archaic, European style. It will be brilliant or a total failure \xe2\x80\x94 my favorite sort of odds.'b'Most school officials try to apply disciplinary policies fairly and in compliance with federal laws that forbid racial discrimination. Even so, a large and troubling body of data \xe2\x80\x94 some if it gathered by the federal government \xe2\x80\x94 shows that black and Hispanic students are disproportionately and unjustifiably subjected to suspension, expulsion or even arrest for nonviolent offenses that should be dealt with in the principal\xe2\x80\x99s office.'b'As a result, minority children who are already at greater risk of dropping out are being ejected from school and denied the right to an effective public education.'b'Over the last several years, civil rights officials in the Obama administration have begun to focus on this problem, increasing civil rights investigations and forcing school districts to revise disciplinary policies that disproportionately affect minorities. The Department of Education\xe2\x80\x99s Office for Civil Rights, for example, has reached such agreements with school districts in Los Angeles; in Oakland, Calif.; and in Delaware.'b'Last week, the Department of Education\xe2\x80\x99s Office for Civil Rights and the Justice Department\xe2\x80\x99s Civil Rights Division took another welcome step. The agencies jointly 'b'issued'b' an extensive set of guidance documents, informing school districts of the law and showing them how to identify, avoid and remedy discriminatory disciplinary policies.'b'The guidance documents included striking data on racial inequities. For example, African-American students represent only 15 percent of public school students, but they make of 35 percent of students suspended once, 44 percent of those suspended more than once and 36 percent of those expelled. Statistical information does not in itself prove discrimination. But research has shown that black students do not engage in more serious or more frequent misbehavior than other students.'b'The treatment of disabled students should be a source of national shame: They represent 12 percent of students in the country, but they make up 25 percent of students receiving multiple out-of-school suspensions and 23 percent of students subjected to a school-related arrest.'b'Investigations in this area have found two kinds of discrimination: cases in which African-American students are treated more harshly and disciplined more frequently than white students who engage in similar misbehavior; and cases where policies \xe2\x80\x94 like mandatory suspension, expulsion or ticketing \xe2\x80\x94 are administered in a race-neutral manner but have a disproportionate and unjustified effect on students of a particular race.'b'To prevent bad practices, the new federal guidance urges schools to train teachers more intensively in classroom management; to ensure that teachers and administrators know they, rather than security or law-enforcement officers, are responsible for routine discipline; to collect data on disciplinary actions and monitor the actions of security officers; and to emphasize policies that reinforce positive behavior over tactics that drive students out of school.'b'Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. was on the mark last week when he said, \xe2\x80\x9cA routine school disciplinary infraction should land a student in the principal\xe2\x80\x99s office, not in a police precinct.\xe2\x80\x9d By making suspension and arrest a last resort, school districts can avoid federal civil rights sanctions and move away from destructive policies that seriously harm the most vulnerable students.'b'The Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'decision'b' to extend the international space station\xe2\x80\x99s time in orbit by at least four years makes good sense. Some $100 billion has been invested to build the station, which was completed less than three years ago. The plan had been to allow the station to plunge into the ocean in 2020.'b'Very little research was conducted during the 13 years the station was being built; research has only been going at a significant clip since 2011. Allowing the space station to operate to 2024, and possibly beyond, would provide more time for scientific and commercial experiments.'b'American space officials hope that other international partners, including the European Space Agency, Russia and Japan, will support the extension, but said that if necessary the United States will go it alone.'b'The move will not be cheap. Operating the space station currently costs the United States about $3 billion a year, a big chunk of the space agency\xe2\x80\x99s proposed $17 billion budget, and that cost could grow. Congress has yet to appropriate funds for specific agencies, so NASA\xe2\x80\x99s financial prospects for the coming year remain uncertain.'b'Administration officials listed several benefits of giving the station four more years of life. The extra time may encourage more scientists and more private companies to develop research proposals that often take years to plan and carry out. It would give commercial launching companies that carry cargo to the station, and will carry humans starting in 2017, a longer period to recoup their investments.'b'Perhaps most important, it will allow NASA to complete the research that is deemed necessary for preparing for long-duration flights beyond low-Earth orbit, including planned human missions to an asteroid by 2025 and to Mars in the 2030s. The research is looking for ways to mitigate many of the health hazards of long-duration flight and will test technologies that are needed to operate safely and productively in deep space.'b'Congress seems likely to support the extension because it will provide local jobs and contracts. The budgetary effect will be negligible through 2020. But eventually, Congress will need to decide whether to keep operating the station for as long as its key components last, possibly through 2028 or beyond, use the money for other manned and robotic space missions or supply enough money to do it all. The station ought to be kept in orbit as long as it yields important research findings, but it should not be allowed to cannibalize other important space activities.'b'NASA\xe2\x80\x99s budget is a tiny part of the trillions of dollars in annual federal spending. Congress ought to appropriate enough money to keep the United States at the forefront in all realms of space research and exploration.'b'Under the Constitution, the president nominates federal judges, cabinet members and officials for executive agencies, and the Senate votes on their confirmation. But what if the Senate isn\xe2\x80\x99t in session? The answer has always seemed clear: The Constitution 'b'gives the president the power'b' to fill \xe2\x80\x9call vacancies that may happen during the recess of the Senate.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'On Monday, for the first time in its history, the Supreme Court will hear oral arguments over the meaning of that clause. On one level, the debate is about language and history: What does \xe2\x80\x9cthe recess\xe2\x80\x9d refer to? What did the framers mean by \xe2\x80\x9chappen\xe2\x80\x9d? But this legalistic dispute should not obscure the larger issue at stake: The government needs to be able to function even when Congress can\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x94 or won\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x94 do its job.'b'The case, 'b'National Labor Relations Board v. Noel Canning'b', started as an ordinary labor dispute between a soft-drink bottling company in Washington State and the local union over a contractual pay raise. The N.L.R.B., a federal agency that hears such disputes every day, ruled for the union in February 2012. The company appealed, arguing that the decision was invalid because President Obama had 'b'wrongly used the recess-appointment power'b' to install three of the board\xe2\x80\x99s five members the previous month.'b'Without those three, the labor board did not have enough members to function, and in temporarily restaffing it, Mr. Obama was simply following long-established practice by both Democratic and Republican presidents faced with an intransigent Congress. Over the last 150 years, 'b'presidents have made'b' more than 600 such civilian appointments and thousands of military appointments. (A recess appointment expires at the end of the session unless Congress acts on it first.)'b'And yet in a 'b'remarkably myopic ruling'b' last January, the federal appeals court in Washington blocked out that reality and held, among other things, that the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s use of the words \xe2\x80\x9cthe recess\xe2\x80\x9d must mean there is only one, which falls between the end of one Congressional session and the start of the next.'b'There are historical arguments for why that reading may have made sense in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s early days, when travel times were long and recesses could last for months. But in the 21st century, senators come and go as they please, and recesses are short and frequent. What has not changed is a president\xe2\x80\x99s need to be able to staff the cabinets and federal agencies so that the government\xe2\x80\x99s work can be done.'b'Of course, a functioning N.L.R.B. is precisely what business-friendly Republicans want to prevent. They see the board as too pro-union, and are so intent on thwarting it and other agencies that they forced the Senate to hold phony \xe2\x80\x9cpro forma\xe2\x80\x9d sessions every three days during the January 2012 break \xe2\x80\x94 some of which lasted only a minute \xe2\x80\x94 just to prevent the president from using his recess-appointment power.'b'To be fair, Senate Democrats introduced this tactic in the last years of George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s presidency, but Republicans have blocked Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s appointments at a 'b'far higher rate'b'. They have made an art of avoiding up-or-down votes on judges, agency officials and even cabinet members.'b'Since the Senate finally voted last November 'b'to eliminate the filibuster'b' for most presidential nominees, Mr. Obama should have an easier time getting them confirmed. But there are still plenty of tricks senators can use to jam the system, from refusing to conduct hearings to placing holds on nominees. And if Republicans retake the Senate in November, they won\xe2\x80\x99t need a filibuster to keep Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s agencies from functioning.'b'The absurdity of the appeals court\xe2\x80\x99s ruling reaches not just into the future but into the past. If Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s recess appointments are ruled unconstitutional, thousands of other such appointments made over the years by other presidents would be called into question, not to mention 'b'more than 1,300 rulings'b' made by the \xe2\x80\x9cinvalid\xe2\x80\x9d labor board.'b'The Supreme Court should overturn the appellate ruling and reaffirm a longstanding practice that is consistent with both the language and the meaning of the Constitution, and that allows presidents to do their job.'b'Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay that said abolition of the tax would benefit workers.'b''b'To the Editor:'b' Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Abolish the Corporate Income Tax'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Laurence J. Kotlikoff (Op-Ed, Jan. 6):'b'For decades corporate income taxes have dropped without benefiting working and middle-class America. Chief executives now make 270 times more than the average American worker, whose real wages have fallen since their peak in the 1970s.'b'As most workers in America have seen their hours, wages and benefits shrink, corporate taxes have gone down, job creation and growth have gone down, and corporate profits and executive compensation have skyrocketed.'b'So why does Mr. Kotlikoff think that it will be different this time around? For whom does he think that it will be better? If the past predicts the future, it will not be the American workers or the middle class who benefit.'b'CARRIE GOLDWATER GOLKIN'b' New York, Jan. 7, 2014'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'To the Editor: 'b'Laurence J. Kotlikoff doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mention some key facts.'b'First, the personal income tax would have an enormous loophole for the rich if we didn\xe2\x80\x99t also have a corporate income tax. A corporation can hold on to its profits for years before paying them out as dividends. With no corporate income tax, rich people could create shell corporations to defer paying individual income taxes on much of their income indefinitely.'b'Second, even when corporate profits are paid out (as stock dividends), only a third are paid to individuals rather than to tax-exempt entities not subject to the personal income tax. If not for the corporate income tax, most corporate profits would never be taxed.'b'Third, the corporate income tax is ultimately borne by shareholders and is therefore a very progressive tax, which means that repealing it would result in a less progressive tax system. The Treasury Department concludes that 82 percent of the corporate tax is borne by the owners of stocks and business assets, who mostly have very high incomes.'b'ROBERT S.
