McGINLEY'b' Evanston, Ill., Jan. 8, 2014'b''b'MY favorite story in Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee\xe2\x80\x99s fascinating new book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Second Machine Age,\xe2\x80\x9d is when the Dutch chess grandmaster Jan Hein Donner was asked how he\xe2\x80\x99d prepare for a chess match against a computer, like I.B.M.\xe2\x80\x99s Deep Blue. Donner replied: \xe2\x80\x9cI would bring a hammer.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Donner isn\xe2\x80\x99t alone in fantasizing that he\xe2\x80\x99d like to smash some recent advances in software and automation \xe2\x80\x94 think self-driving cars, robotic factories and artificially intelligent reservationists \xe2\x80\x94 which are not only replacing blue-collar jobs at a faster rate, but now also white-collar skills, even grandmasters!'b'Something very, very big happened over the last decade. It is being felt in every job, factory and school. My own shorthand is that the world went from \xe2\x80\x9cconnected to hyperconnected\xe2\x80\x9d and, as a result, average is over, because employers now have so much easier, cheaper access to above-average software, automation and cheap genius from abroad. Brynjolfsson and McAfee, both at M.I.T., offer a more detailed explanation: We are at the start of\xc2\xa0 the Second Machine Age.'b'The First Machine Age, they argue, was the Industrial Revolution that was born along with the steam engine in the\xc2\xa0late 1700s. This period was \xe2\x80\x9call about power systems to augment human muscle,\xe2\x80\x9d explained McAfee in an interview, \xe2\x80\x9cand\xc2\xa0each successive invention in that age delivered more and more power. But they all required humans to make decisions about them.\xe2\x80\x9d Therefore, the inventions of this era actually made human control and labor \xe2\x80\x9cmore valuable and important.\xe2\x80\x9d Labor and machines were\xc2\xa0complementary.'b'\xc2\xa0In the Second Machine Age, though, argues Brynjolfsson, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are beginning to automate a lot more cognitive tasks, a lot more of the control systems that determine what to use that power for. In many cases today artificially intelligent machines can make better decisions than humans.\xe2\x80\x9d So humans and software-driven machines may increasingly be substitutes, not\xc2\xa0complements. What\xe2\x80\x99s making this possible, the authors argue, are\xc2\xa0three huge technological advances that just reached their tipping points, advances they describe as \xe2\x80\x9cexponential, digital and combinatorial.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To illustrate \xe2\x80\x9cexponential\xe2\x80\x9d they retell the story of the king who was so impressed with the man who invented chess that he offered him any reward. The inventor suggested rice to feed his family. He asked the king to simply place a grain of rice on the first square of a chessboard and then have each subsequent square receive twice as many grains as the previous. The emperor agreed until he realized that 63 instances of doubling yields a fantastically big number, even starting with one grain \xe2\x80\x94 like 18 quintillion grains of rice, once you finish the second half of the chess board.'b'The authors compare this second half of the chessboard to Moore\xe2\x80\x99s Law about the relentless doubling of digital computing power about every two years. Unlike the steam engine, which was physical and doubled in performance every 70 years, computers \xe2\x80\x9cget better, faster than anything else,\xc2\xa0ever,\xe2\x80\x9d says Brynjolfsson. Now that we\xe2\x80\x99re in the second half of the digital chessboard, you see cars that drive themselves in traffic, Jeopardy-champion supercomputers, flexible factory robots and pocket smartphones that are the equivalent of a supercomputer of just a generation ago.'b'Now add the spread of the Internet to both people and things \xe2\x80\x94 soon everyone on the planet will have a smartphone, and every cash register, airplane engine, student iPad and thermostat will be broadcasting digital data via the Internet. All this data means we can instantly discover and analyze patterns, instantly replicate what is working on a global scale and instantly improve what isn\xe2\x80\x99t working \xe2\x80\x94 whether it is eye surgery techniques, teaching fractions or how best to operate a G.E. engine at 30,000 feet. Suddenly, the speed and slope of improvement, they argue, gets very fast and steep.'b'Combinatorial advances mean you can take Google Maps and combine them with a smartphone app like Waze, through which drivers automatically transmit traffic conditions on their routes by just carrying their phone in their car, and meld both into a GPS system that not only tells you what the best route is to your destination but what the best route 'b'now'b' is because it also sees all the traffic everywhere. Instantly, you\xe2\x80\x99re the smartest driver in town.'b'\xc2\xa0Put all these advances together, say the authors, and you can see that our generation will have more power to improve (or destroy) the world than any before, relying on fewer people and more technology. But it also means that we need to rethink deeply our social contracts, because labor is so important to a person\xe2\x80\x99s identity and dignity and to societal stability. They suggest that we consider\xc2\xa0lowering\xc2\xa0taxes on human labor to make it cheaper relative to digital labor, that we reinvent education so more people can \xe2\x80\x9crace with machines\xe2\x80\x9d not against them, that we do much more to foster the entrepreneurship that invents new industries and jobs, and even consider guaranteeing every American a basic income. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got a lot of rethinking to do, they argue, because we\xe2\x80\x99re not only in a recession-induced employment slump. We\xe2\x80\x99re in a technological hurricane reshaping the workplace \xe2\x80\x94 and it just keeps doubling.'b'THE year is new, but we already have a candidate for the most troubling magazine essay of 2014: Amanda Hess on \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Why Women Aren\xe2\x80\x99t Welcome on the Interne'b't,\xe2\x80\x9d in the latest issue of Pacific Standard.'b'Hess takes a reality many people may be only dimly aware of \xe2\x80\x94 that female writers come in for an extraordinary amount of abuse online \xe2\x80\x94 and fleshes it out with detail, data and personal experience. The anecdotes, her own and others, range from the offensive to the terrifying, but there\xe2\x80\x99s also a thudding, soul-crushing sameness to them: graphic threats of sexual violence, rape and murder, intertwining and repeating.'b'Everyone who writes online comes in for abuse, but Hess\xe2\x80\x99s essay describes a form of intimate attack that few male journalists experience. We hear about it over drinks, we catch glimpses of it on Twitter, but it\xe2\x80\x99s easy for us to miss how radically different it makes our female peers\xe2\x80\x99 experience.'b'Hess\xe2\x80\x99s essay is mostly interested in solutions and responses: how women should deal with their harassers; how online forums should police abuse; how the laws surrounding stalking and discrimination might adapt to deal with online threats.'b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s also useful to think about root causes, and where all the hate and twisted fantasies are coming from. Is this misogyny always latent in a subset of the male population, or are there magnifying forces at work?'b'One potential magnifier, of course, is the Internet itself, which by its nature is a kind of unreal space for many users \xe2\x80\x94 a place where a range of impulses can be discussed, explored and acted out in what 'b'feels 'b'like a consequence-free zone.'b'There is some evidence that the emergence of this fantasy space has actually made the real world slightly safer for women: studies have shown 'b'correlations'b' between access to online pornography and lower rates of sexual assault. But the flip side is that many men who might have successfully regulated their darker impulses now have what seems like a green light to be \xe2\x80\x9cvirtually\xe2\x80\x9d abusive ... because they\xe2\x80\x99re just trying out a role, or because the woman on the receiving end seems no more real to them than a character in a pornographic film.'b'Another magnifier is ideology. Hess is a feminist who works in culture-war terrain, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no question that women writing from that perspective come in for more personal, sexualized abuse than women writing about, say, monetary policy. Where the personal is political, the political becomes personal more quickly, and the grotesque abuse that liberal, feminist writers can receive for being liberal feminists is a scandal that conservatives, especially, need to acknowledge and deplore.'b'But many 'b'conservative and libertarian women'b' also take a remarkable amount of sexual-political abuse. So it may be that the culture war cuts both ways, and a certain kind of left-wing narrative about gender \xe2\x80\x94 in which women are expected to hold liberal views just by virtue of being female \xe2\x80\x94 can become a license for allegedly progressive men to demean and dehumanize women who decline to play that part.'b'And then to further complicate matters, there is the phenomenon of intraliberal misogyny \xe2\x80\x94 like the flood of abuse, cited by Hess, that greeted the atheist writer Rebecca Watson when she 'b'wrote'b' about sexism and harassment at a skeptics\xe2\x80\x99 convention.'b'Cases like Watson\xe2\x80\x99s suggest that there\xe2\x80\x99s a chauvinist attitude in play here, a kind of crypto-ideology of sex and gender, that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t map neatly onto what we usually think of as culture-war divides. This attitude is \xe2\x80\x9cliberal\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0in that it regards sexual license as an unalloyed good, and treats any kind of social or religious conservatism as a dead letter. But at the same time it wants to rebel and lash out against the strictures it feels that feminism and political correctness have placed on male liberty, male rights.'b'Sometimes this rebellion is just coarse and libertine: think of lad magazines, or the world of pick-up artists, or Seth MacFarlane on Oscar night. But where it intersects with status anxieties, personal failure and sexual frustration, it can turn vicious \xe2\x80\x94 in effect, scapegoating women (those frigid castraters, those promiscuous teases) for the culture\xe2\x80\x99s failure to deliver a beer-commercial vision of male happiness.'b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t think either the left or the right quite understands this worldview: feminists tend to see it simply as a species of reaction, social conservatives as the dark fruit of sexual liberation, when it\xe2\x80\x99s really a combination of the two. And because it channels 'b'some legitimate male anxieties 'b'alongside its chauvinism and resentment, it probably can\xe2\x80\x99t be shamed or driven underground \xe2\x80\x94 or not, at least, without making its side effects for women that much more toxic.'b'Instead, it needs to be answered, somehow, with a more compelling vision of masculine goals, obligations and aspirations. Forging this vision is a project for both sexes. Living up to it, and cleansing the Internet of the worst misogyny, is ultimately a task for men.'b'POLITICS boils down to three pronouns: I, you, we. The politician who has them in balance goes a long way.'b'From the \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d comes the lust for attention necessary to face all the cameras, hear all the clamoring, weather all the commentary. From the \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d comes the yearning to be celebrated and, because celebration often hinges on accomplishment, the drive to get things done. Personal glory and public good dovetail. What we call narcissism overlaps with what we call altruism, neither of which is as tidy as we make it out to be.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x9d matters just as much in this transactional age. A politician must promise measurable improvement to each and every voter\xe2\x80\x99s life. That\xe2\x80\x99s what President Obama was trying to do with his pitch for the Affordable Care Act; he just went way too far. He became utterly fixated on the individual \xe2\x80\x9cyou,\xe2\x80\x9d when the best argument for universal health insurance was and is about the communal us.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x9d is essential. It must be in the mix. A politician who can cast his or her mission as 'b'our'b' mission not only finds the cloak in which self-regard is most fetchingly wrapped but also creates the sense of collective purpose that\xe2\x80\x99s vital to progress.'b'Can Chris Christie do that? Can he fit the \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x9d into me, me, me?'b'This question preceded the scandal that enveloped him last week. This question will also survive it, even if the public officials and reporters digging into his role in the 'b'lane closures'b' near the George Washington Bridge never find a smoking traffic cone. And that\xe2\x80\x99s because this question strikes to his overarching problem, which isn\xe2\x80\x99t an instance of gridlock but a pattern of grandiosity. While Christie sometimes seems to be fighting for you and for us, he almost always seems to have himself first and foremost in mind. There\xe2\x80\x99s too much \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d in the stew. Its flavor isn\xe2\x80\x99t sufficiently masked or muted.'b'In his news conference on Thursday he found a way to spell apology with a thousand I\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'Perhaps he nonetheless managed to assure voters that he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t directed the nightmare on Fort Lee\xe2\x80\x99s streets. His denials couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been more emphatic, unconditional or expansive. He spoke and spoke and spoke, which made some sense, in that he cast himself as someone volunteering information rather than running from the truth.'b'But as he spoke and spoke and spoke, the apology sprawled into an odd aria of self-congratulation, and he even praised his own penance.'b'The incident, he said, didn\xe2\x80\x99t reflect \xe2\x80\x9cthe environment I\xe2\x80\x99ve worked so hard to achieve.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cActions have consequences, and I\xe2\x80\x99m living up to that right now,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not a focus-group-tested, blow-dried candidate or governor.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am who I am.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not a bully.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the rare moment in this office when I raise my voice.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Self-pity crept in.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am humiliated.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt is heartbreaking to me that I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t told the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI am a very sad person.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayed me.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayed me.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayed me.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There was an abundance of self-fascination, a surfeit of \xe2\x80\x9cme.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Of course calling out politicians for being entranced with themselves is like calling out actuaries for being interested in math. Certain professions require certain temperaments. But the lesson of political success and failure is that egoism does best with checks and camouflage, lest one\xe2\x80\x99s career be shortened, one\xe2\x80\x99s ultimate goal unreached. Newt Gingrich didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to exit the House of Representatives as soon as he did, and his life\xe2\x80\x99s plan wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to wind up hosting \xe2\x80\x9cCrossfire.\xe2\x80\x9d An overblown \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x9d landed him there.'b'BILL CLINTON\xe2\x80\x99S appetite for adulation may have been almost as keen, but its expression took the form of groveling as often as it did grandstanding. That\xe2\x80\x99s long been his genius: to leaven the boastful with the solicitous. Did he, as a candidate and a president, really feel our pain, or did he just feel the need to have us believe that? It didn\xe2\x80\x99t matter. When that lower lip jutted out and those eyes misted, you wanted to give him a blanket, a binky and your support.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s interesting that the most frequently imagined presidential matchup for 2016 is Christie versus Hillary Clinton, because she\xe2\x80\x99s a textbook case in taming what the first President Bush, uncomfortable with the first-person singular, called \xe2\x80\x9cthe big I.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Back in 1993, shortly after she and Bill moved into the White House, she appeared in an angelic pose on the cover of this paper\xe2\x80\x99s magazine, for a profile titled 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSaint Hillary.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' It thrummed with self-satisfaction.'b'Then she fell. And then, as she picked herself up, she learned. In her bid for a Senate seat, she went on that famous \xe2\x80\x9clistening tour,\xe2\x80\x9d an exercise in self-effacement devoted to you, you, you. As secretary of state, she assiduously logged (and publicized) all those miles. It was a way of projecting a nose-to-the-grindstone humility, the appearance of which is a cornerstone of her sustained popularity.'b'Humility comes haltingly to Christie, if it comes at all. There wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a scintilla of it at the 2012 Republican convention. His keynote speech there was broadly 'b'disparaged'b' for the way the big I eclipsed the little mentions of Mitt Romney, in whose service it was supposedly being delivered. Chris Wallace, an anchor for Fox News, quipped, \xe2\x80\x9cFor a moment, I forgot who was the nominee of the party.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Humility was absent when Christie bragged to Dan Balz of The Washington Post about how many Republican luminaries 'b'pleaded with him'b' to get into the 2012 race and save the party. Humility doesn\xe2\x80\x99t factor into his habit, as governor, of 'b'having someone trail him'b' to collect video of his trademark confrontations with naysayers so that these exchanges can be uploaded onto YouTube, viral testaments to his vaunted truth telling.'b'When a politician\xe2\x80\x99s self-promotion scales the Olympian heights that his has scaled, a dangerous message goes out to aides, who assume that ascendance is everything and that victory vindicates anything: browbeating, rule-tweaking, a knot of traffic around the world\xe2\x80\x99s busiest bridge.'b'Something else happens, too. Or, rather, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t. Real friendships beyond a posse of loyalists aren\xe2\x80\x99t made, though they\xe2\x80\x99re essential. A politician needs not just acolytes and fair-weather allies but also peers who feel real admiration and deep affection and will be there when the storm comes.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s unclear, in the early days of this scandal, if Christie has that. Some Republican operatives have been strangely tepid in their assessments and defenses of him. Other Republican governors have been slow to rally around him.'b'Without enough \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwe,\xe2\x80\x9d a politician inevitably bumps up against a word that, unlike apology, is correctly spelled with an I.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s isolation.'b'SLEEP seems like a perfectly fine waste of time. Why would our bodies evolve to spend close to one-third of our lives completely out of it, when we could instead be doing something useful or exciting? Something that would, as an added bonus, be less likely to get us killed back when we were sleeping on the savanna?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSleep is such a dangerous thing to do, when you\xe2\x80\x99re out in the wild,\xe2\x80\x9d Maiken Nedergaard, a Danish biologist who has been leading research into sleep function at the University of Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s medical school, told me. \xe2\x80\x9cIt has to have a basic evolutional function. Otherwise it would have been eliminated.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve known for some time that sleep is essential for 'b'forming and consolidating'b' memories and that it plays a 'b'central role'b' in the formation of new neuronal connections and the pruning of old ones. But that hardly seems enough to risk death-by-leopard-in-the-night. \xe2\x80\x9cIf sleep was just to remember what you did yesterday, that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be important enough,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Nedergaard explains.'b'In a series of new studies, 'b'published'b' this fall in the journal Science, the Nedergaard lab may at last be shedding light on just what it is that would be important enough. Sleep, it turns out, may play a crucial role in our brain\xe2\x80\x99s physiological maintenance. As your body sleeps, your brain is quite actively playing the part of mental janitor: It\xe2\x80\x99s clearing out all of the junk that has accumulated as a result of your daily thinking.'b'Recall what happens to your body during exercise. You start off full of energy, but soon enough your breathing turns uneven, your muscles tire, and your stamina runs its course. What\xe2\x80\x99s happening internally is that your body isn\xe2\x80\x99t able to deliver oxygen quickly enough to each muscle that needs it and instead creates needed energy anaerobically. And while that process allows you to keep on going, a 'b'side effect'b' is the accumulation of toxic byproducts in your muscle cells. Those byproducts are cleared out by the body\xe2\x80\x99s lymphatic system, allowing you to resume normal function without any permanent damage.'b'The lymphatic system serves as the body\xe2\x80\x99s custodian: Whenever waste is formed, it sweeps it clean. The brain, however, is outside its reach \xe2\x80\x94 despite the fact that your brain uses up about 20 percent of your body\xe2\x80\x99s energy. How, then, does its waste \xe2\x80\x94 like beta-amyloid, a protein associated with Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s disease \xe2\x80\x94 get cleared? What happens to all the wrappers and leftovers that litter the room after any mental workout?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThink about a fish tank,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Nedergaard. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you have a tank and no filter, the fish will eventually die. So, how do the brain cells get rid of their waste? Where is their filter?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'UNTIL a few years ago, the prevailing model was based on recycling: The brain got rid of its own waste, not only beta-amyloid but other metabolites, by breaking it down and recycling it at an individual cell level. When that process eventually failed, the buildup would result in age-related cognitive decline and diseases like Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s. That \xe2\x80\x9cdidn\xe2\x80\x99t make sense\xe2\x80\x9d to Dr. Nedergaard, who says that \xe2\x80\x9cthe brain is too busy to recycle\xe2\x80\x9d all of its energy. Instead, she 'b'proposed'b' a brain equivalent of the lymphatic system, a network of channels that cleared out toxins with watery cerebrospinal fluid. She called it the glymphatic system, a nod to its dependence on glial cells (the supportive cells in the brain that work largely to maintain homeostasis and protect neurons) and its function as a sort of parallel lymphatic system.'b'She was hardly the first to think in those terms. \xe2\x80\x9cIt had been proposed about one hundred years ago, but they didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the tools to study it properly,\xe2\x80\x9d she says. Now, however, with advanced microscopes and dyeing techniques, her team discovered that the brain\xe2\x80\x99s interstitial space \xe2\x80\x94 the fluid-filled area between tissue cells that takes up about 20 percent of the brain\xe2\x80\x99s total volume \xe2\x80\x94 was mainly dedicated to physically removing the cells\xe2\x80\x99 daily waste.'b'When members of Dr. Nedergaard\xe2\x80\x99s team injected small fluorescent tracers into the cerebrospinal fluid of anesthetized mice, they found that the tracers quickly entered the brain \xe2\x80\x94 and, eventually, exited it \xe2\x80\x94 via specific, predictable routes.'b'The next step was to see how and when, exactly, the glymphatic system did its work. \xe2\x80\x9cWe thought this cleaning process would require tremendous energy,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Nedergaard says. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd so we asked, maybe this is something we do when we\xe2\x80\x99re sleeping, when the brain is really not processing information.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a series of new studies on mice, her team discovered exactly that: When the mouse brain is sleeping or under anesthesia, it\xe2\x80\x99s busy cleaning out the waste that accumulated while it was awake.'b'In a mouse brain, the interstitial space takes up less room than it does in ours, approximately 14 percent of the total volume. Dr. Nedergaard found that when the mice slept, it swelled to over 20 percent. As a result, the cerebrospinal fluid could not only flow more freely but it could also reach further into the brain. In an awake brain, it would flow only along the brain\xe2\x80\x99s surface. Indeed, the awake flow was a mere 5 percent of the sleep flow. In a sleeping brain, waste was being cleared two times faster. \xe2\x80\x9cWe saw almost no inflow of cerebrospinal fluid into the brain when the mice were awake, but then when we anesthetized them, it started flowing. It\xe2\x80\x99s such a big difference I kept being afraid something was wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Nedergaard.'b'Similar work in humans is still in the future. Dr. Nedergaard is currently awaiting board approval to begin the equivalent study in adult brains in collaboration with the anesthesiologist Helene Benveniste at Stony Brook University.'b'So far the glymphatic system has been identified as the neural housekeeper in baboons, dogs and goats. \xe2\x80\x9cIf anything,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Nedergaard says, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s more needed in a bigger brain.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'MODERN society is increasingly ill equipped to provide our brains with the requisite cleaning time. The figures are stark. Some 80 percent of working adults 'b'suffer'b' to some extent from sleep deprivation. According to the National Sleep Foundation, adults should sleep seven to nine hours. 'b'On average'b', we\xe2\x80\x99re getting one to two hours less sleep a night than we did 50 to 100 years ago and 38 minutes less on weeknights than we did as little as 10 years ago. Between 50 and 70 million people in the United States suffer from some form of chronic sleep disorder. When our sleep is disturbed, whatever the cause, our cleaning system breaks down. At the University of Pennsylvania\xe2\x80\x99s Center for Sleep and Circadian Neurobiology, Sigrid Veasey has been 'b'focusing'b' on precisely how restless nights disturb the brain\xe2\x80\x99s normal metabolism. What happens to our cognitive function when the trash piles up?'b'At the extreme end, the result could be the acceleration of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s and Parkinson\xe2\x80\x99s. While we don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether sleep loss causes the disease, or the disease itself leads to sleep loss \xe2\x80\x94 what Dr. Veasey calls a \xe2\x80\x9cclassic chicken-and-egg\xe2\x80\x9d problem \xe2\x80\x94 we do know that the two are closely connected. Along with the sleep disturbances that characterize neurodegenerative diseases, there is a buildup of the types of proteins that the glymphatic system normally clears out during regular sleep, like beta-amyloids and tau, both associated with Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s and other types of dementia.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo me,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Veasey, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s the most compelling part of the Nedergaard research. That the clearance for these is dramatically reduced from prolonged wakefulness.\xe2\x80\x9d If we don\xe2\x80\x99t sleep well, we may be allowing the very things that cause neural degeneration to pile up unchecked.'b'Even at the relatively more benign end \xe2\x80\x94 the all-nighter or the extra-stressful week when you caught only a few hours a night \xe2\x80\x94 sleep deprivation, as everyone who has experienced it knows, impedes our ability to concentrate, to pay attention to our environment and to analyze information creatively. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we\xe2\x80\x99re sleep-deprived, we can\xe2\x80\x99t integrate or put together facts,\xe2\x80\x9d as Dr. Veasey puts it.'b'But there is a difference between the kind of fleeting sleep loss we sometimes experience and the chronic deprivation that comes from shift work, insomnia and the like. In one set of studies, soon to be published in The Journal of Neuroscience, the Veasey lab found that while our brains can recover quite readily from short-term sleep loss, chronic prolonged wakefulness and sleep disruption stresses the brain\xe2\x80\x99s metabolism. The result is the degeneration of key neurons involved in alertness and proper cortical function and a buildup of proteins associated with aging and neural degeneration.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s like the difference between a snowstorm\xe2\x80\x99s disrupting a single day of trash pickup and a prolonged strike. No longer quite as easy to fix, and even when the strike is over, there\xe2\x80\x99s likely to be some stray debris floating around for quite some time yet. \xe2\x80\x9cRecovery from sleep loss is slower than we\xe2\x80\x99d thought,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Veasey notes. \xe2\x80\x9cWe used to think that after a bit of recovery sleep, you should be fine. But this work shows you\xe2\x80\x99re not.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If you put her own research together with the findings from the Nedergaard lab, Dr. Veasey says, it \xe2\x80\x9cvery clearly shows that there\xe2\x80\x99s impaired clearance in the awake brain. We\xe2\x80\x99re really starting to realize that when we skip sleep, we may be doing irreparable damage to the brain, prematurely aging it or setting it up for heightened vulnerability to other insults.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a society that is not only chronically sleep-deprived but also rapidly aging, that\xe2\x80\x99s bad news. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely that poor sleep as a child would actually cause Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s or Parkinson\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Veasey, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it\xe2\x80\x99s more likely that you may shift one of those diseases by a decade or so. That has profound health and economic implications.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a pernicious cycle. We work longer hours, become more stressed, sleep less, impair our brain\xe2\x80\x99s ability to clean up after all that hard work, and become even less able to sleep soundly. And if we reach for a sleeping pill to help us along? While work on the effects of sleeping aids on the glymphatic system remains to be done, the sleep researchers I spoke with agree that there\xe2\x80\x99s no evidence that aided sleep is as effective as natural sleep.'b'There is, however, reason to hope. If the main function of sleep is to take out our neural trash, that insight could eventually enable a new understanding of both neurodegenerative diseases and regular, age-related cognitive decline. By developing a diagnostic test to measure how well the glymphatic system functions, we could move one step closer to predicting someone\xe2\x80\x99s risk of developing conditions like Alzheimer\xe2\x80\x99s or other forms of dementia: The faster the fluids clear the decks, the more effectively the brain\xe2\x80\x99s metabolism is functioning.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a test could also be used in the emergency room after traumatic brain injury,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Nedergaard says, \xe2\x80\x9cto see who is at risk of developing decline in cognitive function.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We can also focus on developing earlier, more effective interventions to prevent cognitive decline. One approach would be to enable individuals who suffer from sleep loss to sleep more soundly \xe2\x80\x94 but how? Dr. Nedergaard\xe2\x80\x99s mice were able to clear their brain\xe2\x80\x99s waste almost as effectively under anesthesia as under normal sleeping conditions. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s really fascinating,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Veasey. Though current sleeping aids may not quite do the trick, and anesthetics are too dangerous for daily use, the results suggest that there may be better ways of improving sleep pharmacologically.'b'Now that we have a better understanding of why sleep is so important, a new generation of drug makers can work to create the best possible environment for the trash pickup to occur in the first place \xe2\x80\x94 to make certain that our brain\xe2\x80\x99s sleeping metabolism is as efficient as it can possibly be.'b'A second approach would take the opposite tack, by seeking to mimic the cleanup-promoting actions of sleep in the awake brain, which could make a full night of sound sleep less necessary. To date, the brain\xe2\x80\x99s metabolic process hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been targeted as such by the pharmaceutical industry. There simply wasn\xe2\x80\x99t enough evidence of its importance. In response to the evolving data, however, future drug interventions could focus directly on the glymphatic system, to promote the enhanced cleaning power of the sleeping brain in a brain that is fully awake. One day, scientists might be able to successfully mimic the expansion of the interstitial space that does the mental janitorial work so that we can achieve maximally efficient round-the-clock brain trash pickup.'b'If that day comes, they would be on their way to discovering that all-time miracle drug: one that, in Dr. Veasey\xe2\x80\x99s joking words, \xe2\x80\x9ccould mean we never have to sleep at all.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The first full week of the new year dutifully served up some of the themes likely to command attention in 2014.'b'The raising of Al Qaeda banners over the cities of Falluja and Ramadi, where some of the costliest battles of the American war in Iraq were fought, raised painful memories and renewed questioning about the efficacy of outside efforts to resolve the deep and bitter conflicts of the Middle East. As if to drive the point home, Afghanistan\xe2\x80\x99s United States-installed president, Hamid Karzai, infuriated the Obama administration by releasing dozens of prisoners accused of attacking Americans.'b'Then there was the \xe2\x80\x9cArctic vortex,\xe2\x80\x9d a meteorological phenomenon usually restricted to the top of the earth that became intimately familiar to millions when it sent a rogue southward loop of frigid air over all the states and provinces of North America. Temperatures abruptly plummeted to record lows, partially freezing Niagara Falls and even prompting Anana, the resident polar bear at Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s Lincoln Park Zoo, to take refuge indoors.\xc2\xa0The brutal cold raised the usual nyah-nyah chorus from climate-change deniers, but even as temperatures returned to seasonal norms, meteorologists and lots of other people anxiously wondered what other climactic quirks lay ahead.'b'And on the political front, the Republican who had seemed best positioned for a run for the White House, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, ran up against the conundrum of many ambitious politicians: Where does the buck stop?'b''b'The Pain of Falluja'b''b'The advances of Al Qaeda-backed Sunni insurgents in Falluja and Ramadi, the largest cities of Anbar Province, carried considerable dangers for Syria, Jordan and Saudi Arabia, countries that border on Anbar, and for the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose discriminatory policies against Sunnis have been at least partly responsible for the eruption of violence. The main insurgent group, which calls itself the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, has been increasingly active in Syria. Thousands of people have fled in anticipation of major fighting.'b'But outside Iraq, it was the symbolism of black insurgent flags over Falluja that struck painful chords. For many Americans, the images of destroyed buildings, burned-out vehicles, frightened Arabs and dusty Marines became the images of the war. Over two major operations, American Marines and soldiers did succeed in driving insurgents out or underground. But Sunni resentment continued to fester, waiting only for the Americans to pull out. One quote that surfaced several times over the past week was the conclusion of an 'b'analysis'b' of the battle in 2005 by Jonathan F. Keiler on Military.com: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Battle of Fallujah was not a defeat,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we cannot afford many more victories like it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In fact, Falluja was never really \xe2\x80\x9clost\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cwon.\xe2\x80\x9d A former Baathist stronghold that enjoyed a privileged status under Saddam Hussein, it has been rebellious ever since his fall. Mr. Maliki contributed to the problem by discriminating against Sunnis in government. The immediate trigger for the latest violence was a government dismantling of a Sunni protest camp. So the latest battle for Falluja will not be the last.'b'Still, the\xc2\xa0images of\xc2\xa0black flags and masked insurgents brandishing AK-47s in Falluja led to wrenching questions about how and why the United States got into Iraq \xe2\x80\x94 and how it got out. Like Khe Sanh or Hamburger Hill in the Vietnam War, bloody battlefields won at huge cost by American troops and abandoned soon after, Falluja has now assumed the burden of a bloody question mark over the entire American war in Iraq. Many veterans of the battle now wonder what their sacrifice, and that of their fallen comrades, was for. \xc2\xa0'b'The debates and finger-pointing are likely to continue, especially as conflicts in places like Afghanistan, Libya, Egypt and Syria continue to fester. \xc2\xa0But neither President Obama nor the public shows any inclination to return to Iraq. Perhaps that is why in Afghanistan, from which United States troops are preparing to leave by year\xe2\x80\x99s end, Mr. Karzai shows so little regard for American sentiments. In this part of the world, it is not the outsiders who determine the outcome.'b''b'Fun in New Jersey'b''b'The week\xe2\x80\x99s drama in New Jersey was more entertaining than wrenching for most of those who followed it \xe2\x80\x94 except of course for Governor Christie, who suddenly ran up against a major obstacle on his road to the White House. Until now, the going had been good: Mr. Christie easily won re-election in November in a historically Democratic state, and as the chairman of the Republican Governors Association, he had secured a nationwide lectern.'b'Then came the revelation that a deputy chief of staff, Bridget Anne Kelly, and other close aides had sent emails to friends on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which controls the George Washington Bridge, that it was \xe2\x80\x9ctime for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.\xe2\x80\x9d Fort Lee is on the New Jersey side of the bridge, and its mayor is a Democrat. 'b''b''b'NAIROBI, Kenya \xe2\x80\x94 SHE\xe2\x80\x99S a 4-year-old girl named Ida, fragile and shy, and when she was raped by a neighbor boy in September, her family tried to have the attacker arrested.'b'Yet the only interest the police showed was to ask for a bribe equivalent to $11.50 to make the arrest, the family says. The family didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the money, but perhaps the rapist did because the supposed police investigation stalled.'b'This kind of police indifference and corruption is a major factor in the impunity that leads to staggering levels of sexual violence in much of the world. 'b'A United Nations study released in September of 10,000 men in six countries'b' in Asia and the Pacific found that almost one-quarter acknowledged having raped a woman.'b'Other studies have reported similar findings. 'b'A 2011 study found'b' that 37 percent of men in part of South Africa acknowledged having raped women.'b'Often the victims, like Ida, are breathtakingly young. Ida lives in the vast, teeming Kibera slum in Nairobi, where she is being raised by a great-uncle and great-aunt, Stephen and Jane, after her parents largely abandoned her. Stephen and Jane are pillars of stability in a troubled area, and they have taken in three street children to raise along with four children of their own.'b'After Ida\xe2\x80\x99s rape, Jane closed her tiny restaurant for two weeks to get Ida surgery to repair internal injuries. Jane then made five trips to 'b'the Kilimani police station'b' that oversees the slum to try to get someone to make an arrest.'b'In this case, the evidence seemed strong: A neighbor had caught the alleged rapist in the house during the attack, and a police doctor had filled out forms documenting the rape and internal injuries.'b'Yet the police shrugged and did nothing. Stephen assumes that the perpetrator bribed the police.'b'After repeated inquiries, the police officers finally threatened to make an arrest in the rape case \xe2\x80\x94 not of the young man caught red-handed, but of Stephen and Jane for leaving the girl unattended and vulnerable.'b'The police station had the right physical infrastructure to deal with sexual violence. It had a separate counter for such cases, staffed by female officers. Posters denounced rape.'b'Yet Stephen and Jane tried to do the right thing \xe2\x80\x94 and then the police, in my presence, shouted at them and threatened to arrest them for their perseverance.'b'That was a terrifying threat, for who would look after Ida then? Stephen, a dignified man who was heartbroken at what happened to Ida, wilted. He seemed to have lost hope of justice.'b'What happened to Ida was no anomaly. I followed two other girls, a 13-year-old and a 14-year-old, who both said that they had been raped by a wealthier neighbor with H.I.V. Their families made eight visits to the Kilimani police station in Nairobi, waiting hours at a time, pleading for justice \xe2\x80\x94 but nothing ever happened. The families did spot the perpetrator\xe2\x80\x99s wife at the station, perhaps paying a bribe.'b'On each visit by the family, the police reported that some paper had mysteriously gone missing from the file. When a witness report was needed, the family brought the witness to the police station \xe2\x80\x94 and then the police charged her a fee for a piece of blank paper to write her statement on.'b'I tweeted a photo from the police station, saying the police wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take action. Soon after the tweet, the police officers\xe2\x80\x99 attitudes miraculously changed, and authorization for an arrest was given. Yet when the police went to make the arrest, the alleged rapist had obviously been tipped off somehow and had fled.'b'This breakdown in justice is common in much of the world. In many poor countries, the criminal justice system was set up decades ago to protect white colonial families and never really made the transition to serving the entire society. Salaries tend to be low, corruption high, accountability nonexistent \xe2\x80\x94 and, as a result, deterrence negligible.'b'In the United Nations survey, by far the most common reason men cited for raping women and girls was a sense of male entitlement, with explanations like \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted her.\xe2\x80\x9d Another factor was impunity, for more than two-thirds of men who acknowledged raping said that they had faced no legal consequences.'b'Attitudes like entitlement are hard to change. Reducing impunity is somewhat easier, and if we need evidence that imposing penalties can reduce the incidence of rape, just look at the United States.'b'Few people realize that rape has fallen by three-quarters over the last four decades in the United States, according to Justice Department statistics. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that underreporting makes the data not fully reliable, but underreporting is unlikely to be more serious now than in the 1970s.'b'The reason for the decline in American rape is simple. Most rapes are acquaintance rapes, and a generation ago police often shrugged. (\xe2\x80\x9cYou were drinking. You were making out with him. You still call it rape?\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'These attitudes still exist in America, rape kits often aren\xe2\x80\x99t tested even after evidence has been properly collected, and plenty of date rapists get away with their crimes. But punishment is still far more likely today than it once was \xe2\x80\x94 and that danger restrains men even when they\xe2\x80\x99re tipsy and lusting. If ending the impunity worked to reduce sexual violence in America, it can do the same in other countries.'b'That may be beginning to happen. After some horrifying rapes, India appears to be taking crimes of sexual violence more seriously in some cases. And here in Kenya, I was following Shining Hope for Communities, a slum-empowerment program in Kibera started by a remarkable young man, 'b'Kennedy Odede'b', who was once a homeless, uneducated street child in Kibera \xe2\x80\x94 and then taught himself to read and write, attended Wesleyan University, and now runs programs serving 43,000 slum residents.'b'Odede operates 'b'the Kibera School for Girls'b', an outstanding elementary school, and he soon found that many girls entering prekindergarten had been raped. To build a safer environment for the girls, he started a system of victim advocates to help push the police to do their jobs, and the group is winning support for its message that \xe2\x80\x9cno\xe2\x80\x9d means \xe2\x80\x9cno\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and that rapists should be punished.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s having an impact, offering a model for efforts to combat sexual violence worldwide. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you in my next column what happened to Ida\xe2\x80\x99s alleged attacker.'b'ON that early spring day in San Francisco, I walked out to buy local treats for my birthday party \xe2\x80\x94 country bread (sour, with walnuts) from Tartine bakery, tamales from the lady in front of my favorite produce shop, salted caramel ice cream from Bi-Rite and a tub of peanut curry ice cream from Humphry Slocombe\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'Since I was a teenager in art school scribbling recipes in my illustration notebook, my life has been about cooking, tasting and sharing stories about food. I\xe2\x80\x99m the former Roving Feast columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle and continue to write and appear on radio and TV. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had about two dozen cookbooks published, and now I\xe2\x80\x99m creating private supper clubs around the world.'b'Whenever I travel I tote back something delicious \xe2\x80\x94 miso-pickles from Japan; ripe Camembert from France; spicy salami from Calabria. Storefronts, billboards and leafy treetops floated slowly by, until my head hit the street and I was flung like a rag doll onto the pavement. I was racked with excruciating pain.'b'When I opened my eyes, emergency workers were asking if I knew who the president was. My arms were broken and I had a concussion. But the worst was just beginning.'b'That night, acrid smoke woke me. Nobody was smoking and no one else around me seemed to notice it.'b'My morning coffee was tasteless. Visitors brought delicacies to soothe me, but with each bite, I tasted dread. These well-chosen treats had no flavor, at least none that I recognized. Cinnamon drops, a childhood favorite, were bitter, horrible.\xc2\xa0Tamales were as bland as porridge. Bananas tasted like parsnips and smelled like nail polish remover.'b'It got no better as days went by. Gently saut\xc3\xa9ed mushrooms seemed like scorched bits of sponge. Red wine was just flat and sweet or unremittingly bitter.'b'I had lost my ability to taste and smell. It was like a musician losing her hearing. Fortunately, my senses weren\xe2\x80\x99t irretrievably destroyed. The nerve that transmits smell and taste to the brain had been injured but not severed, so, my neurologist reassured me, these senses could return. But when and how well? I felt desperate and terrified.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99d also lost all memories of tastes. Later, eating a bowl of ice cream, I murmured: \xe2\x80\x9cThis is delicious. What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d My first mouthful of bacon was \xe2\x80\x9cSo tasty!\xe2\x80\x9d But each encounter with bacon was like eating it for the first time. It might have been wonderful to be thrilled over and over again except that I felt incredibly stupid.'b'The awful phantom scents and distortions of actual smells \xe2\x80\x94 phantosmia and parosmia, respectively \xe2\x80\x94 continued: more smoke, moldering garbage, rotten fabric and worse.\xc2\xa0'b'To not smell the world around me, to not discern tastes, was horrifying. So, in the two years since the accident, I created a taste rehabilitation plan that gradually began to revive my senses of smell and taste.'b'After spitting out my first post-accident chocolate, I sampled as many types as I could. At first I could tolerate only the most insipid milk chocolate, but gradually I upped the cocoa level. Eventually I loved dark chocolate again.\xc2\xa0'b'COFFEE has been heartbreaking. As I sipped my way through San Francisco, New York and the cafe-bars of Naples, its flavor remained elusive. Looking into my cup was like looking at a soon-to-be-former lover. But I refused to just give up on the relationship. I signed up for a monthly delivery of selected beans and roasts from Britain\xe2\x80\x99s Union Roasters, each with their own tasting notes. I read the notes as I sipped: floral and sweet tones, caramel and chocolate and bitter and aromatic. I read and drank, read and drank, sniffed and sipped and drank. San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s Mission Chinese Food with its roller-coaster of flavors and textures was like a tasting lab. Perhaps, when it comes to death, it\xe2\x80\x99s better to live and let live.'b'Dennis Rodman helps Kim Jong-un score propaganda points.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94  Should gender segregation be allowed in Muslim public meetings? That question has created a surprising degree of political heat in Britain in recent weeks.'b'The controversy began after a number of hard-line Muslim student groups insisted that men and women must sit separately at their public meetings and lectures. Universities UK, the official voice of British universities, deemed such segregation to be acceptable so long as women were not forced to sit at the back of the room. The guidance caused an uproar, drawing the prime minister, David Cameron, into the debate, and leading an opposition spokesman, Chuka Umunna, to insist that \xe2\x80\x9ca future Labour government would not allow or tolerate segregation in our universities.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For some, the debate has been an expression of Islamophobia, singling out Muslim practices for criticism. For others, the attitude of Universities UK demonstrates how many in authority are willing to appease Islamist extremists, and to tolerate the intolerable so as not to offend minority groups.'b'It is true that many racists have seized on this controversy, as they have done with other issues, to foment hostility toward Muslims. But that only makes it more necessary for progressives to claim issues such as this, to bend them to progressive, rather than racist, purposes. To challenge specifically Islamic practices is not necessarily to be \xe2\x80\x9cIslamophobic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The problems revealed by the controversy are not only those of Islam: The storm over segregated meetings is merely the latest in a series of clashes. From questions of blasphemy to divisions over same-sex marriage, the fractiousness of such debates reflects growing tensions between some strands of religious thought and the changing demands of a secular society. It also reflects a deep-set confusion over what is meant by \xe2\x80\x9creligious freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Most Western societies have, for historical reasons, come to think of \xe2\x80\x9creligious freedom\xe2\x80\x9d as a special kind of liberty. The modern debate about tolerance and rights developed in Europe from the 17th century onward, primarily within a religious framework. Questions about what could be tolerated were, at heart, questions of how, and how far, the state and the established church should accommodate religious dissent.'b'Today we live in a different world. Religion is no longer the crucible in which political and intellectual disputes take place. Questions of freedom and tolerance are not about how the dominant religious establishment should respond to dissenting theological views, but about the degree to which society should tolerate, and the law permit, speech and activity that might be offensive or hateful, that might challenge the state or undermine national security.'b'From today\xe2\x80\x99s perspective, it is easier to see that religious freedom is not a special kind of liberty, but one expression of a broader set of freedoms of conscience, belief, assembly and action.'b'Whatever one\xe2\x80\x99s beliefs, secular or religious, there should be complete freedom to express them, short of inciting violence. Whatever one\xe2\x80\x99s beliefs, there should be freedom to assemble to promote them. And whatever one\xe2\x80\x99s beliefs, there should be freedom to act upon those beliefs, so long as, in so doing, one neither physically harms another individual nor transgresses that individual\xe2\x80\x99s rights in the public sphere. These should be the fundamental principles by which we judge the permissibility of any belief or act, religious or secular.'b'Many on both sides of the debate about religious freedom fail to grasp these principles. Many secularists, for instance, insist that religious views should be kept out of the public sphere. That cannot be right, any more than it would be right to bar the views of racists, conservatives, Communists or gay activists from the public sphere.'b'Many believers want to retain privileges for religion. As a society, we should tolerate as far as possible the desire of people, religious or secular, to live according to their consciences. But that tolerance ends when someone acting upon his or her conscience causes harm to another or infringes on another\xe2\x80\x99s rights.'b'So religions should have no right to prevent the publication of material believers deem offensive. Religious freedom requires that people of faith be allowed to speak or act in ways that might offend others; it does not require that others do not cause them offense.'b'There is nothing wrong with the American government\xe2\x80\x99s requiring Catholic-run hospitals to give employees health insurance that includes free contraception: Churches are not being forced to provide contraception. In their role as secular employers, they are being asked to provide benefits that all employers must provide. To exempt church-run organizations would be to deny those benefits to a particular group of employees.'b'A religious institution should be free to bar women from acting as clergy members or to segregate the sexes in religious services or private meetings. But enforced segregation in a public forum is a different matter and must be opposed.'b'All this is not, as many believers suggest, to enforce secular discrimination against religious belief. Many nonreligious groups \xe2\x80\x94 fascists, Communists, Greens \xe2\x80\x94 could claim that their beliefs mandated certain actions or practices. Yet, it would be illegal for a racist cafe owner to bar black people, or for Greens to destroy a farmer\xe2\x80\x99s field of legally grown genetically modified crops, however deep-set their particular beliefs.'b'There is a line, in other words, that cannot be crossed \xe2\x80\x94 even if conscience demands it. That line should be in the same place for religious believers as for nonbelievers.'b'Under pressure, Universities UK has withdrawn its advice on segregation, pending a review. Whether it has really understood the meaning of religious freedom in a modern society is a moot question. What seems certain, given continuing confusion about the relationship between the religious and the secular, is that we will see many more such controversies.'b''b'\n'b'Kenan Malik 'b' is a writer, lecturer, broadcaster and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cFrom Fatwa to Jihad: The Rushdie Affair and Its Aftermath.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94  A month after the execution of Jang Song-thaek, widely viewed as 'b'North Korea'b'\xe2\x80\x99s second-most-powerful leader, 'b'China'b' remains stymied in relations with its reclusive, defiant neighbor. This is not a new story. Though few in Beijing are prepared to admit it, China\xe2\x80\x99s policies toward North Korea have long been a conspicuous failure.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s official reactions to the North\xe2\x80\x99s internal power struggle have, thus far, been limited largely to formulaic calls for internal stability. Chinese leaders, including President Xi Jinping, voice periodic frustration with North Korea, but none seems able or willing to translate Pyongyang\xe2\x80\x99s ever increasing economic dependence on China into meaningful influence.'b'From the earliest years of China\xe2\x80\x99s reforms, under Deng Xiaoping, Beijing has repeatedly sought to coax North Korea toward gradual economic change, normal relations with the outside world and increased attentiveness to Chinese interests. Yet North Korea continues to exhibit its characteristic mix of demands and defiance, including repeated threats aimed at South Korea and accelerated development of 'b'nuclear weapons'b' and long-range ballistic missiles opposed by all outside powers, including China. Other than some modest steps toward informal marketization in the North, China\xe2\x80\x99s policy record on Pyongyang over three decades remains unblemished by success.'b'Mr. Jang was China\xe2\x80\x99s primary channel into the North. This did not make him Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s man, but he had far more extensive international experience than any other leader in Pyongyang. His control of various business interests in the North and responsibility for special economic zones along the Chinese border enabled him to amass substantial economic power.'b'Beijing probably calculated that Mr. Jang was prepared to open a limited window into the North. The Chinese may also have seen him as a potential advocate for stability \xe2\x80\x94 which they had long sought in North Korea but never found.'b'But Mr. Jang had undoubtedly acquired numerous enemies during decades of unforgiving political warfare in Pyongyang. There were mounting suspicions within ruling circles that he was too beholden to Chinese interests. Mr. Jang\xe2\x80\x99s accumulation of wealth and his economic links with China proved his undoing once Kim Jong-un, the third leader of the Kim dynasty, demanded a redistribution of the spoils.'b'North Korean officials linked to Mr. Jang now find themselves under suspicion; reportedly, others have also been purged or executed. Advocates of cooperation with China face greater risks as Mr. Kim consolidates his power and demands unquestioning loyalty from all subordinates. Without reliable allies in North Korea, China must deal with an impetuous and grandiose young leader who pays China very little heed.'b'Mr. Jang\xe2\x80\x99s fall from power is the latest in a long succession of Chinese policy failures in North Korea. Many analysts argue that North Korea is a buffer state for China, used by Beijing to insulate it from American pressure. But the reverse is more the case: China is a buffer state for North Korea, for Beijing continues to be Pyongyang\xe2\x80\x99s primary enabler.'b'Chinese foreign policy currently appears bold and assertive, but on the peninsula China\xe2\x80\x99s stance remains exceedingly risk-averse. The question is why Beijing continues to exhibit such caution, even outright timidity, toward the North.'b'Some argue that the legacy of the Korean War weighs heavily on the minds of more traditional constituencies within the Chinese Communist Party and army. But deeper, current anxieties also inhibit Beijing. China fears that extreme actions by an unpredictable, heavily armed neighbor with a xenophobic leadership could trigger a larger crisis on the peninsula that would quickly involve China. Lacking realistic options to control North Korean behavior, China prefers instead to avoid doing anything that might alienate Pyongyang.'b'While China insists that it wants normal state-to-state relations with North Korea, it is not prepared to impose conditions on its isolated, troublesome neighbor, much less undertake a larger reassessment of its policies. As a consequence, Mr. Kim sees little reason to follow China\xe2\x80\x99s advice, and he will continue to zealously guard against Chinese influence on the North.'b'The one exception to China\xe2\x80\x99s passivity toward the North is its promotion of closer ties with Seoul. South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s trade with China now exceeds $250 billion, more than the South\xe2\x80\x99s combined trade with Japan and the United States. (China\xe2\x80\x99s two-way trade with North Korea is worth approximately $6 billion.) South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s president, Park Geun-hye, has already been welcomed on a state visit to Beijing; there has been no equivalent welcome for Mr. Kim, and it is not even certain that he seeks one.'b'China exhibits ample unease about addressing the larger risks posed by North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s actions and goals. The purge of Mr. Jang serves only to underscore Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s lack of influence in Pyongyang. The United States and South Korea both hope for more from China, but Beijing seems paralyzed in policy indecision.'b'The failures of policy on the Korean Peninsula are not those of China alone, but Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s risk aversion bespeaks a larger absence of will and imagination on China\xe2\x80\x99s part. Without a more candid conversation among Beijing, Seoul and Washington, the latent risk of an acute threat on the peninsula remains uncomfortably high.'b'South Korea and the United States seem fully prepared for serious dialogue with China. Only Beijing seems unable to decide, leaving unaddressed the prospect of a severe crisis that cannot possibly be in China\xe2\x80\x99s interest.'b''b'\n'b'Jonathan D. Pollack'b' is the director of the John L. Thornton China Center at the Brookings Institution and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cNo Exit: North Korea, Nuclear Weapons and International Security.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b' 'b' 'b' 'b'\n'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Washington Memo, front page, Jan. 5) did not recognize the dramatic reduction in poverty made during President Lyndon B. Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s time in office.'b'When L.B.J. became president, more than a fifth of the American population was living in poverty. By the end of his term, the percentage had been cut to 12 from 20, the greatest one-time reduction in history.'b'The article also overlooked the broader milestone, the beginning of a period that proved transformative in our history, significant not only for what got done, but also for how President Johnson accomplished it. Fueled by his own experience and values, Johnson pushed hundreds of major pieces of legislation through Congress. More than any president since Franklin D. Roosevelt, Johnson got things done by following his creed: \xe2\x80\x9cDo it now. Not next week. Not tomorrow. Not later today. Now.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ultimately the War on Poverty was just the first in a roll call of achievements \xe2\x80\x94 civil rights, education, health care, immigration, the arts and humanities, the environment \xe2\x80\x94 that, taken together, equaled nothing less than a new American revolution of opportunity and equality.'b'MARK K.
