Where is the outrage?'b'FRANK DiMARCO'b'\nPortland, Ore., Jan. 8, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Can Upward Mobility Cost You Your Health?'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Gregory E. Miller, Edith Chen and Gene H. Brody (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Divide\xe2\x80\x9d series, Sunday Review, Jan. 5):'b'Recent 'b'work'b' from our research team at the Harvard School of Public Health regarding differences in short sleep duration by industry of employment and occupation between African-Americans and whites supports the article\xe2\x80\x99s findings that upward social mobility may occur at the expense of health.'b'We found that the greatest disparities between African-Americans and whites with regard to adequacy of sleep were among people in high professional and administrative roles. Our data suggested that high socioeconomic status is beneficial for healthy sleep among whites but negatively associated with sleep health among African-Americans.'b'The high prevalence of short sleep duration among professional African-Americans, who are often first-generation college graduates, can be attributed partly to limited professional and social networks that can provide financial and emotional support; discrimination or micro-aggressions experienced in the workplace; hypervigilance because of a perceived high work ethic needed to succeed; or greater levels of neighborhood and home stress.'b'Ultimately, sleep restriction may be a fundamental, modifiable source of health inequity that deserves more attention by many stakeholders in the community, including educators, employers and health care providers.'b'CHANDRA L. JACKSON'b'\nSUSAN REDLINE'b'\nFRANK HU'b'\nBoston, Jan. 10, 2014'b''b''b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writers are, respectively'b''b', a postdoctoral fellow, a professor of sleep medicine at Harvard Medical School and a professor of nutrition and epidemiology'b''b' at the Harvard School of Public Health.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Colorado River Drought Forces a Painful Reckoning for States'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 6), the major problem of drought in the Southwest is documented vis-\xc3\xa0-vis the availability of water for farming and for the population of Southern California and neighboring states dependent on the Colorado. The article mentions conservation efforts and potential alternative sources of water (San Diego\xe2\x80\x99s construction of a desalination plant).'b'However, as is typical of such news reports, the article does not directly deal with the elephant in the room \xe2\x80\x94 rapid population growth in the Southwest \xe2\x80\x94 except to take continued growth as given. It merely says \xe2\x80\x9c40 million people also depend on the river and its tributaries, and their numbers are rising rapidly.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Is it not appropriate to openly ask two questions: What is a sustainable population in the Southwest, considering its water resources, and what policies could eventually limit population growth there?'b'STAN BECKER'b'\nBaltimore, Jan. 7, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a professor in the department of population, family and reproductive health, Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.'b''b'ANDY INKSTER, a transgender man, had always wanted biological children. So when he embarked on the transition from female to male at age 18 \xe2\x80\x94 changing his name, taking testosterone and eventually undergoing surgery to remove his breasts \xe2\x80\x94 he left his female reproductive organs intact.'b'In his mid-20s, he decided it was time. He stopped taking testosterone and started trying to get pregnant. Eventually, in 2009, after beginning graduate school at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, he sought fertility treatment at Baystate Reproductive Medicine. Baystate was one of the few clinics in the country with an anti-discrimination policy for gender identity. And yet, it refused to treat him, arguing that it didn\xe2\x80\x99t have enough expertise to treat transgender patients. Mr. Inkster insisted there was no medical reason to deny him; his baby-making parts were the same as any woman\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'The more than 700,000 transgender people living in the United States have long faced discrimination by health care providers. Over the past 15 years, activists have fought to compel insurers to cover transgender-related health care \xe2\x80\x94 from hormone therapy to gender reassignment surgery \xe2\x80\x94 or at least be prevented from excluding transgender clients from buying policies for basic services. Finally, starting this month, thanks to the Affordable Care Act, \xe2\x80\x9ctranssexualism\xe2\x80\x9d can no longer be considered a pre-existing condition. What\xe2\x80\x99s been left out of the spotlight: having babies. Many Americans have come to accept gay parents; the transgender community is next in line for recognition.'b'Mr. Inkster eventually found another clinic that helped him conceive via in vitro fertilization and donor sperm, and in October 2010, he gave birth to a daughter, Elise. A month later, he sued Baystate for sexual discrimination.'b'According to court documents, he was denied treatment after failing to comply with a clinic counselor\xe2\x80\x99s request that he supply information from his current therapist that he was emotionally ready to handle pregnancy and parenting. Mr. Inkster argued that nontransgender patients weren\xe2\x80\x99t asked to do the same. This fall, the 'b'Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination'b' \xe2\x80\x94 the state\xe2\x80\x99s civil rights agency \xe2\x80\x94 found probable cause for Mr. Inkster. The case will next move on to a conciliation conference, and then to a possible settlement.'b'Admittedly, the idea of a \xe2\x80\x9cpregnant man\xe2\x80\x9d makes many people uncomfortable, and photos of Mr. Inkster caressing his bulging belly are startling. The issue is controversial even within the transgender community. \xe2\x80\x9cSome people believe if you\xe2\x80\x99re a trans man you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be wanting to bear kids,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Jamison Green'b', the author of \xe2\x80\x9cBecoming a Visible Man,\xe2\x80\x9d told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not something men do. Others think, If you have a body part that does something, why can\xe2\x80\x99t you use it? It\xe2\x80\x99s your body.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The issue brings up unprecedented questions: Do you use your genetic material to reproduce, and at what time during your transition? Before or after hormone therapy? Before undergoing reassignment surgery that will make you sterile? Should a transgender man like Mr. Inkster keep his breasts so he can nurse later? Is it generally psychologically healthier for someone like him to freeze his eggs and have them inseminated and the embryos transferred to a female partner or surrogate, rather than leave his female reproductive parts intact? How might years of estrogen or testosterone therapy affect eggs and sperm?'b'These questions matter. 'b'One study'b' published last year in the journal Human Reproduction of 90 transgender men in Belgium found that 54 percent wished to have children, and 38 percent would have considered freezing their eggs if the procedure had been available. Other 'b'research'b', published in 2002, by Belgian fertility doctors with Western European transgender women found that 40 percent wanted to have children, and 77 percent felt they should have the option to preserve their sperm before hormone treatment. As fertility technology improves and becomes more widely available, transgender people are realizing that they will have more options in the future.'b'Jennifer Hastings, a family care physician based in Santa Cruz, Calif., who specializes in transgender health care, says it\xe2\x80\x99s tricky to balance gender identity with family desires. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have preteens who come in and say, \xe2\x80\x98I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be a mom. I want to be a dad!\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d she says. \xe2\x80\x9cOn the other hand, there are youth who know they want to have biological kids from the outset and freeze sperm or eggs after going through puberty.\xe2\x80\x9d Since some doctors are concerned that letting transgender teenagers go through puberty in the gender they don\xe2\x80\x99t identify with may be deeply traumatic, they might administer puberty-blocking medications that delay adolescence until the teenagers can begin hormone therapy in their desired gender. But this means the patients may give up the option of having biological children later. \xe2\x80\x9cIt can be a painful choice for their parents to make,\xe2\x80\x9d says Dr. Hastings.'b'All these paths toward creating transgender families deserve careful study. Yet these issues aren\xe2\x80\x99t likely to get the attention they deserve until transgender people succeed in getting basic health care first.'b'Stories of transgender people in health care settings being gawked at, mocked or interrogated about their status abound. A disturbing 2011 study by the National Center for Transgender Equality and the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force of 6,450 transgender adults found that 19 percent reported having been refused treatment by a health care provider because of their gender identity, and 28 percent said they had postponed medical care because of discrimination. For those who had visited a doctor\xe2\x80\x99s office or hospital, 24 percent said they had been denied equal treatment, 25 percent reported having been harassed or disrespected, and 2 percent had been physically assaulted.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s understandable that doctors might be nervous about not having enough training to treat people who are under long-term hormone therapy. Medical schools need to make students more aware of transgender health needs, which in most cases aren\xe2\x80\x99t that different from everyone else\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cIf someone has a sore throat, they have a sore throat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dr. Hastings. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not because of their hormones.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The bigger challenge may be to get medical providers to overcome their bias. Discomfort over difference isn\xe2\x80\x99t an excuse to refuse compassionate care to a transgender person in an emergency room or a fertility clinic, or for insurance companies to refuse to cover that care. Gender identity has nothing to do with the desire to have children \xe2\x80\x94 or with who will make a good parent.'b'Suddenly it\xe2\x80\x99s O.K., even mandatory, for politicians with national ambitions to talk about helping the poor. This is easy for Democrats, who can go back to being the party of F.D.R. and L.B.J. It\xe2\x80\x99s much more difficult for Republicans, who are having a hard time shaking their reputation for reverse Robin-Hoodism, for being the party that takes from the poor and gives to the rich.'b'And the reason that reputation is so hard to shake is that it\xe2\x80\x99s justified. It\xe2\x80\x99s not much of an exaggeration to say that right now Republicans are doing all they can to hurt the poor, and they would have inflicted vast additional harm if they had won the 2012 election. Moreover, G.O.P. harshness toward the less fortunate isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a matter of spite (although that\xe2\x80\x99s part of it); it\xe2\x80\x99s deeply rooted in the party\xe2\x80\x99s ideology, which is why recent speeches by leading Republicans declaring that they do too care about the poor have been almost completely devoid of policy specifics.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s start with the recent Republican track record.'b'The most important current policy development in America is the rollout of the Affordable Care Act, a k a Obamacare. Most Republican-controlled states are, however, refusing to implement a key part of the act, the expansion of Medicaid, thereby'b' denying health coverage'b' to almost five million low-income Americans. And the amazing thing is that they\xe2\x80\x99re going to great lengths to block aid to the poor even though letting the aid through would cost almost nothing; nearly all the costs of Medicaid expansion would be paid by Washington.'b'Meanwhile, those Republican-controlled states are slashing unemployment benefits, 'b'education financing'b' and more. As I said, it\xe2\x80\x99s not much of an exaggeration to say that the G.O.P. is hurting the poor as much as it can.'b'What would Republicans have done if they had won the White House in 2012? Much more of the same. Bear in mind that every 'b'budget'b' the G.O.P. has offered since it took over the House in 2010 involves savage cuts in Medicaid, food stamps and other antipoverty programs.'b'Still, can\xe2\x80\x99t Republicans change their approach? The answer, I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry to say, is almost surely no.'b'First of all, they\xe2\x80\x99re deeply committed to the view that efforts to aid the poor are actually perpetuating poverty, by reducing incentives to work. And to be fair, this view isn\xe2\x80\x99t completely wrong.'b'True, it\xe2\x80\x99s total nonsense when applied to'b' unemployment insurance.'b' The notion that unemployment is high because we\xe2\x80\x99re \xe2\x80\x9cpaying people not to work\xe2\x80\x9d is a fallacy (no matter how desperate you make the unemployed, their desperation does nothing to create more jobs) wrapped in a falsehood (very few people are choosing to remain unemployed and keep collecting benefit checks).'b'But our patchwork, uncoordinated system of antipoverty programs does have the effect of penalizing efforts by lower-income households to improve their position: the more they earn, the fewer benefits they can collect. In effect, these households face very high marginal tax rates. A large fraction, in some cases 80 cents or more, of each additional dollar they earn is clawed back by the government.'b'The question is what we could do to reduce these high effective tax rates. We could simply slash benefits; this would reduce the disincentive to work, but only by intensifying the misery of the poor. And the poor would become less productive as well as more miserable; it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to take advantage of a low marginal tax rate when you\xe2\x80\x99re suffering from poor nutrition and inadequate health care.'b'Alternatively, we could reduce the rate at which benefits phase out. In fact, one of the unheralded virtues of Obamacare is that it does just that. That is, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t just improve the lot of the poor; it 'b'improves their incentives,'b' because the subsidies families receive for health care fade out gradually with higher income, instead of simply disappearing for anyone too affluent to receive Medicaid. But improving incentives this way means spending more, not less, on the safety net, and taxes on the affluent have to rise to pay for that spending. And it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine any leading Republican being willing to go down that road \xe2\x80\x94 or surviving the inevitable primary challenge if he did.'b'The point is that a party committed to small government and low taxes on the rich is, more or less necessarily, a party committed to hurting, not helping, the poor.'b'Will this ever change? Well, Republicans weren\xe2\x80\x99t always like this. In fact, all of our major antipoverty programs \xe2\x80\x94 Medicaid, food stamps, the earned-income tax credit \xe2\x80\x94 used to have bipartisan support. And maybe someday moderation will return to the G.O.P.'b'For now, however, Republicans are in a deep sense enemies of America\xe2\x80\x99s poor. And that will remain true no matter how hard the likes of Paul Ryan and Marco Rubio try to convince us otherwise.'b'LISA BONCHEK ADAMS has spent the last seven years in a fierce and very public cage fight with death. Since a mammogram detected the first toxic seeds of cancer in her left breast when she was 37, she has 'b'blogged and tweeted'b' copiously about her contest with the advancing disease. She has tweeted through morphine haze and radiation burn. Even by contemporary standards of social-media self-disclosure, she is a phenomenon. (Last week she tweeted her 165,000th tweet.) A rapt audience of several thousand follows her unsparing narrative of mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiation, biopsies and scans, pumps and drains and catheters, grueling drug trials and grim side effects, along with her posts on how to tell the children, potshots at the breast cancer lobby, poetry and resolute calls to \xe2\x80\x9cpersevere.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the last month or two, her broadcasts have changed tone slightly; her optimism has become a little less unassailable. As 2013 ended, the cancer that had colonized her lymph nodes, liver, lungs and bones had established a beachhead in her spine, the pathway to her (so far tumor-free) brain. She was deemed too sick to qualify for the latest drug trial. She is bedridden at New York\xe2\x80\x99s Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, which has embraced her as a research subject and proselytizer for the institution.'b'Lisa Adams is still alive, still blogging, and insists she is not dying, but the blog has become less about prolonging her survival and more about managing her excruciating pain. Her poetry has become darker.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe words of disease become words my brain gravitates to,\xe2\x80\x9d she pecked the other day after a blast of radiation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe ebb and flow of cancer, Of life. And so too, Inevitably, Of death.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In October 2012 I 'b'wrote'b' about my father-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s death from cancer in a British hospital. There, more routinely than in the United States, patients are offered the option of being unplugged from everything except pain killers and allowed to slip peacefully from life. His death seemed to me a humane and honorable alternative to the frantic medical trench warfare that often makes an expensive misery of death in America.'b'Among doctors here, there is a growing appreciation of palliative care that favors the quality of the remaining life rather than endless \xe2\x80\x9cheroic measures\xe2\x80\x9d that may or may not prolong life but assure the final days are clamorous, tense and painful. (And they often leave survivors bankrupt.) What Britain and other countries know, and my country is learning, is that every cancer need not be Verdun, a war of attrition waged regardless of the cost or the casualties. It seemed to me, and still does, that there is something enviable about going gently. One intriguing lung cancer 'b'study'b' even suggests that patients given early palliative care instead of the most aggressive chemotherapy not only have a better quality of life, they actually live a bit longer.'b'When my wife, who had her own brush with cancer and who 'b'has written'b' about Lisa Adams\xe2\x80\x99s case for The Guardian, introduced me to the cancer blog, my first thought was of my father-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s calm death. Lisa Adams\xe2\x80\x99s choice is in a sense the opposite. Her aim was to buy as much time as possible to watch her three children grow up. So she is all about heroic measures. She is constantly engaged in battlefield strategy with her medical team. There is always the prospect of another research trial to excite her hopes. She responds defiantly to any suggestion that the end is approaching.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am not on my deathbed,\xe2\x80\x9d she told me in an email from the hospital. \xe2\x80\x9cPeriods of cancer progression and stability are part of the natural course of this disease. I will be tweeting about my life and diagnosis for some time to come,\xe2\x80\x9d she predicted, and I hope she\xe2\x80\x99s right. In any case, I cannot imagine Lisa Adams reaching a point where resistance gives way to acceptance. That is entirely her choice, and deserving of our respect. But her decision to live her cancer onstage invites us to think about it, debate it, learn from it.'b'The first thing I would say is that her decision to treat her terminal disease as a military campaign has worked for her. Her relationship with the hospital provides her with intensive, premium medical care, including not just constant maintenance and aggressive treatment but such Sloan-Kettering amenities as the Caring Canines program, in which patients get a playful cuddle with visiting dogs. (Neither Adams nor Sloan-Kettering would tell me what all this costs or whether it is covered by insurance.)'b'Whether or not this excellent care has added months or years to her life, as she clearly believes, is a medical judgment, and her doctors, bound by privacy rules, won\xe2\x80\x99t say. Most trials of new drugs aim to determine safety and calibrate dosages, and make no promise of slowing the disease in the participants. But any reader can see that Adams\xe2\x80\x99s online omnipresence has given her a sense of purpose, a measure of control in a tumultuous time, and the comfort of a loyal, protective online community. Social media have become a kind of self-medication.'b'Lisa Adams\xe2\x80\x99s defiance has also been good for Memorial Sloan-Kettering. She has been an eager research subject, and those, I was surprised to learn, are in short supply. Scott Ramsey of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle cited a 'b'study'b' showing that only 3 percent of adult cancer patients who are eligible to enroll in clinical trials do so, and, he said, their reluctance has been \xe2\x80\x9ca huge bottleneck in cancer research.\xe2\x80\x9d Some 40 percent of clinical trials fail to get the minimum enrollment. Adams has been a cheerleader for cancer research in general and Memorial Sloan-Kettering in particular. In fact, she has implored followers to contribute to a research fund set up at the hospital in her name, and has raised about $50,000 so far. \xe2\x80\x9cWe love it!\xe2\x80\x9d the hospital tweeted last week about the Lisa Adams phenomenon. \xe2\x80\x9cAn important contribution to cancer patients, families, and clinicians! :)\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Beyond that, whether her campaign has been a public service is a more complicated question.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am public about this disease in order to shed light on the daily lives of women living with this diagnosis rather than hiding behind the pink party line that is the only one that gets the spotlight,\xe2\x80\x9d she told me in an email. (The ubiquitous pink-ribbon breast cancer campaigners have been 'b'faulted'b' for overselling the wonders of early detection and giving short shrift to research.)'b'Her digital presence is no doubt a comfort to many of her followers. On the other hand, as cancer experts I consulted pointed out, Adams is the standard-bearer for an approach to cancer that honors the warrior, that may raise false hopes, and that, implicitly, seems to peg patients like my father-in-law as failures.'b'Steven Goodman, an associate dean of the Stanford University School of Medicine, said he cringes at the combat metaphor, because it suggests that those who choose not to spend their final days in battle, using every weapon in the high-tech medical arsenal, lack character or willpower.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m the last person to second-guess what she did,\xe2\x80\x9d Goodman told me, after perusing Adams\xe2\x80\x99s blog. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure it has brought meaning, a deserved sense of accomplishment. But it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be unduly praised. Equal praise is due to those who accept an inevitable fate with grace and courage.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I was a college sophomore in April 1971, still mourning the death of Jimi Hendrix, when I learned that a campus organization to which I belonged was being spied on by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The news landed in the mailbox of the Black Student Union \xe2\x80\x94 at what is now known as Widener University, not far from Philadelphia \xe2\x80\x94 in an envelope stuffed with documents that had been stolen from an F.B.I. office in nearby Media, Pa.'b'The burglars referred to themselves as the Citizens Commission to Investigate the F.B.I. The streets were soon teeming with agents who tried in vain to find them. But the mailings continued, reaching news organizations, members of Congress and people like us who had been placed under surveillance.'b'A fledgling organization at the time, the Black Student Union was hardly a hotbed of revolutionary agitation. We sponsored cultural events, played a bit of a role in campus politics, recruited black students and threw the occasional party. We were flattered to find that the boogeyman of the era, J. Edgar Hoover, found us worthy of surveillance; it gave us more significance than we deserved and seemed to place us on the level of fearsome outfits like the Weathermen and the Black Panthers.'b'The excitement turned to chagrin as we read the documents. The F.B.I. described us as an incompetent and \xe2\x80\x9cbasically dormant\xe2\x80\x9d group that had displayed no \xe2\x80\x9cradical or militant ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d Based on that judgment, the bureau should have focused its attentions elsewhere. Instead, the Philadelphia office said that it would develop informants on the Black Student Union\xe2\x80\x99s leaders so that it could become \xe2\x80\x9caware of their identity and background.\xe2\x80\x9d In other words, innocence was no defense; people who came under unwarranted scrutiny might never escape it.'b'The F.B.I. agents on the Black Student Union case were either lazy or inept; they targeted the wrong people as purported \xe2\x80\x9cleaders\xe2\x80\x9d of our group. They could easily have learned who the actual leaders were from the local or campus newspapers. Instead, they relied on an informant who knew us only from a distance and who fingered two people so peripheral to the group that it was a stretch to call them members.'b'The woman they mistakenly designated a leader wore her hair in a spectacular Afro reminiscent of Angela Davis. The man \xe2\x80\x94 an amiable soul who had a brooding countenance and an impressive Afro of his own \xe2\x80\x94 was guilty of nothing more than looking the revolutionary part.'b'The burglary exposed a patently illegal domestic spying program that monitored the lives of innocent Americans with the help of an extensive network of informants. Cointelpro, for counterintelligence program, was created under Hoover in 1956, and by this time was aimed mainly at antiwar groups, civil rights organizations and black \xe2\x80\x9chate groups.\xe2\x80\x9d (In Hoover\xe2\x80\x99s world, the latter seemed to mean any organizations that used the words \xe2\x80\x9cblack\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cAfro\xe2\x80\x9d in their name.)'b'The portrait of the F.B.I. that began to emerge with the burglary, and was gradually filled in during the ensuing years, showed a voracious surveillance machine that hounded innocent people and tried to destroy their reputations. The Media burglars were never arrested and their identities were unknown to the general public until 'b'last week'b' when their story was told in a new book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Burglary: The Discovery of J. Edgar Hoover\xe2\x80\x99s Secret FBI,\xe2\x80\x9d by Betty Medsger, a former Washington Post reporter.'b'The Media burglary, the Watergate break-in and revelations that the Central Intelligence Agency was operating illegally inside the country led to a congressional investigation, conducted under the leadership of Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho. The Church committee\xe2\x80\x99s findings led to stronger oversight and the curtailment of F.B.I. powers.'b'Those safeguards were breached in the wake of 9/11, when Congress passed the Patriot Act. More recently, the stolen documents released last year by Edward Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor, showed that new technology has enabled government surveillance on a vast scale. Four decades after the Media burglary, Americans are, if anything, less protected from unjustified spying than they were during the tyrannical reign of J. Edgar Hoover.'b'President Obama has often issued executive orders to get around recalcitrant Republicans in Congress or to clarify existing policy. Yet there are some areas where the president has been too reticent. The start of a new year is a good moment to point out some matters ripe for executive action.'b'We begin with Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s baffling refusal to issue an executive order banning discrimination by federal contractors based on sexual orientation or gender identity. A long-sought measure to outlaw such discrimination by all employers'b' passed the Senate 'b'in November with Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s support, but it remains stalled in the House. Many federal contractors already have anti-discrimination policies in place. With a stroke of his pen, Mr. Obama could stop federal money from going to contractors that discriminate. There is no reason for further delay.'b'Mr. Obama should also use the government\xe2\x80\x99s contracting clout to combat sweatshops overseas. He could issue an executive order to develop and enforce a code of conduct for overseas factories that make uniforms and other clothing for the government. A recent investigation 'b'by The Times'b' found that many of these factories violate basic labor standards, by, for example, hiring underage workers. He should also issue an order directing officials to give preference to companies that offer good pay and benefits.'b'A proposal to do that was sidetracked in early 2010 amid objections from business groups and Republican lawmakers. But that was before Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s new focus on income inequality, and before protests by workers for companies that provide services at federal venues like the Smithsonian museums.'b'On guns, Mr. Obama has issued many executive orders and directives to combat illegal weapons and promote public safety. This month, for instance, he 'b'signed two executive orders'b' to strengthen gun background checks. The first clarified that states must submit notice of involuntary outpatient mental health treatment as well as inpatient commitments to the national database of disqualified gun purchasers. The other confirmed that sharing the information does not violate medical privacy.'b'But he should go further. He can encourage more submissions of eligible mental health records by instructing that Justice Department grants be withheld from the 15 states with egregiously poor compliance records.'b'On another front, Mr. Obama should use his executive authority to end a longstanding misinterpretation of the Helms amendment, which prohibits foreign aid money from being used to \xe2\x80\x9cpay for the performance of abortion as a method of family planning or to motivate or coerce any person to practice abortions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That language clearly excludes cases of life endangerment, incest and rape. Yet Republican and Democratic administrations, including Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s, have treated it as an absolute abortion ban. As a result, help is denied to women and girls subjected to rape in armed conflicts. Women with life-threatening pregnancies are denied assistance as well, thwarting efforts to reduce unsafe abortions around the world. The misreading of the Helms amendment has also deterred foreign-aid recipients from providing factual information about abortion to the public. It is time Mr. Obama set matters right.'b'Nearly three years after the fighting began, many of the most dire predictions about Syria\xe2\x80\x99s civil war have come true. The conflict has not only engulfed the country, killing more than 130,000 people and forcing more than nine million civilians out of their homes. Increasingly, it has metastasized across the region, destabilizing neighboring countries and serving as a magnet for militants, or would-be militants, including some from the United States.'b'The war has become exceedingly complicated, compounding the bitter rivalry between Saudi Arabia, a Sunni-majority state that is a major backer of Sunni rebels seeking to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad, and Shiite-led Iran, Mr. Assad\xe2\x80\x99s top supporter. And there is no indication that the United States or any other power has the influence to bring it to an end. The prospects for a peace conference planned for Jan. 22 in Switzerland are not encouraging. Just getting all sides to the table will not be enough, and even that looks doubtful.'b'One of the most alarming developments has been the extent to which better-equipped and better-trained Islamist and Qaeda-linked rebel groups have come to dominate the battlefield over more moderate, secular and Western-oriented opposition forces. These groups were outraged by ISIS, which wants to build an Islamist caliphate straddling Syria and Iraq, and its campaign to control the insurgency by brutalizing rebel-held areas, confiscating other rebels\xe2\x80\x99 weapons, arresting hundreds of Syrians, and executing those they say have violated Shariah law.'b'The fighting has reportedly forced ISIS to abandon some bases and towns it controlled; it would be good if Qaeda hard-liners were truly on the run. (The C.I.A. runs a separate covert program to arm and train the rebels.)'b'Administration officials are now 'b'considering resuming the nonlethal assistance'b', which is run by the State Department, after some of the Islamists fought alongside the Free Syrian Army against ISIS and the Islamic Front returned the warehouses and some of the contents. As one of Mr. Assad\xe2\x80\x99s main allies, Iran could go a long way toward persuading the world of its readiness to play a constructive international role by encouraging Mr. Assad to step aside in favor of a transitional government. But there is no sign of that, and it appears that Iran will not attend the peace conference, presuming it even takes place.'b'Both Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea are pushing to have high school history textbooks in their countries rewritten to reflect their political views.'b'Mr. Abe has instructed the Education Ministry to approve only textbooks that promote patriotism. What better way to win back lost voters than to demonize immigrants \xe2\x80\x94 even if that means conveniently putting aside the facts.'b'According to the migration research unit of University College London, \xe2\x80\x9cthe recent immigrants were 45 percent less likely to receive state benefits or tax credits than U.K. natives over the period 2000-11.\xe2\x80\x9d So much for benefit-grabbing Poles. As many of those asking \xe2\x80\x9cwhat if\xe2\x80\x9d believed, only Mr. Sharon, aptly nicknamed \xe2\x80\x9cthe bulldozer,\xe2\x80\x9d could have taken them down with such ease. No wonder many Israelis continue to pine for an alternate reality in which Mr. Sharon remains a vital presence.'b'Still, as we continue to ask \xe2\x80\x9cwhat if,\xe2\x80\x9d we must also recognize the ways that Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s decisions a decade ago continue to shape Israeli politics.'b'For one thing, they have defined the terms of Israeli-Palestinian talks today. \xe2\x80\x9cWe know what the issues are and the parameters,\xe2\x80\x9d the American secretary of state, John Kerry, recently declared. There\xe2\x80\x99s no deal in sight yet, but there is a sense, among both Israelis and Palestinians, that America means business.'b'Any such speculation around Mr. Kerry\xe2\x80\x99s efforts would have been unimaginable without Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s efforts a decade earlier. Mr. Kerry\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cissues and the parameters\xe2\x80\x9d are the very same that Mr. Sharon promoted during his premiership, in particular his acceptance of a deal enabling Israel to annex the large blocs of settlements close to the West Bank border in exchange for land now inside Israel.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn light of new realities on the ground,\xe2\x80\x9d President George W. Bush wrote in a historic 'b'2004 letter'b' to Mr. Sharon, \xe2\x80\x9cincluding already existing major Israeli population centers, it is unrealistic to expect that the outcome of final status negotiations will be a full and complete return to the armistice lines of 1949.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The formula in the letter, long haggled over with Israeli diplomats before publication, was now American policy. Following Israel\xe2\x80\x99s lead, it envisioned land swaps, with the Israelis keeping the large settlement blocs near the old border. Swapping land meant ceding land, and this was no less than heresy in pristine Likud doctrine.'b'But Mr. Sharon had made his choice, and not reluctantly. He wanted the blocs-plus-swaps scenario to be the preferred, pragmatic policy not only of the Israeli left and center, which were steadily sliding in his direction, but also of the rightist-religious coalition, which he had been vigorously involved in setting up.'b'Today, apart from the hardest core of settlers, their rabbis and their politician-supporters within the Likud, that consensus has indeed emerged \xe2\x80\x94 and makes the negotiations possible under another Likud prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu.'b'This was not a sudden whim on Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s part. The first significant indicator that he was finally maturing came soon after his election as prime minister, in 2001, with his relatively restrained use of the army and air force during the second intifada. His critics feared that the hawkish Mr. Sharon would send the army in full force against Palestinian terrorist groups, causing a blood bath in the West Bank.'b'It did not happen. \xe2\x80\x9cRestraint is strength,\xe2\x80\x9d he proclaimed, with a decisiveness that harked back to his role during the Yom Kippur War of 1973, when he led his division in a hard drive across the Suez Canal. Many officers and men who had no prior loyalty to him concluded that without his calm, steadfast command there would likely have been no Israeli crossing that October, nor ever.'b'But where did the \xe2\x80\x9crestraint\xe2\x80\x9d come from? Was it an upshot of his generalship during the 1982-1983 Lebanon War, including standing by while Christian militias slaughtered Palestinian and Lebanese Shiites, which brought obloquy on Israel, and especially on him? Perhaps: Despite his hard-boiled image, after weeks of war, it was hard for him to look into the eyes of bereaved Israeli parents of soldiers who were killed in Lebanon and persuade them their sacrifice was justified.'b'As prime minister, Mr. Sharon began using buzzwords like \xe2\x80\x9coccupation\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 once the sole province of the peace movement \xe2\x80\x94 in his speeches explaining Israel\xe2\x80\x99s strategic interest in Palestinian independence. Likud members feared that his secession from the party was imminent. They were right.'b'Above all, Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s resounding legacy is his confrontation with the settlers in Gaza who refused to leave in 2005, including many from the West Bank who infiltrated the Gaza settlements to \xe2\x80\x9cdefend\xe2\x80\x9d them. The disengagement was sad for the individual settler family, but on the national plane it was an anticlimax, thanks to Mr. Sharon\xe2\x80\x99s determination to neutralize the settlers \xe2\x80\x94 until recently his most loyal political allies.'b'Mr. Sharon had them forcibly removed, demonstrating that the government of a sovereign, democratic state had a monopoly on armed power over its citizenry.'b'I had the opportunity to ask him, before the disengagement, if he would go to Gaza himself and take command if the operation got bogged down. \xe2\x80\x9cYou worry too much,\xe2\x80\x9d was his self-assured answer, which turned out to be fully vindicated.'b''b' 'b'David Landau, 'b' the former editor in chief of Haaretz, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cArik: The Life of Ariel Sharon.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'As of late Monday afternoon, when I was finishing this column, the most frequently emailed story on The Times\xe2\x80\x99s website for the previous week wasn\xe2\x80\x99t about the polar vortex, Chris Christie or \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It was about cats.'b'I suppose that\xe2\x80\x99s no big shock. On blogs, on Facebook and all around the Internet, claws and clicks go hand in hand (or is that paw in paw?). While the meek may be inheriting the earth, the furry have already claimed cyberspace.'b'But what is surprising \xe2\x80\x94 and indicative of a new chapter in the interactions of Americans and the animals around us \xe2\x80\x94 is the 'b'focus of the cat story'b' in question.'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t about kittens doing the darnedest things. Under the headline \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Your Cat Is Thinking,\xe2\x80\x9d it examined the new book \xe2\x80\x9cCat Sense,\xe2\x80\x9d by a British biologist, John Bradshaw, who flags his seriousness of purpose with his subtitle, \xe2\x80\x9cHow the New Feline Science Can Make You a Better Friend to Your Pet.\xe2\x80\x9d Bradshaw means to get into the cat brain.'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s already plumbed its canine counterpart, in the 2011 book \xe2\x80\x9cDog Sense,\xe2\x80\x9d which was also grounded in research, not sentiment, and in the idea that pets have inner lives more complicated than we imagine. \xe2\x80\x9cDog Sense\xe2\x80\x9d was published just two years after the huge best seller \xe2\x80\x9cInside of a Dog,\xe2\x80\x9d by the psychology professor Alexandra Horowitz, which pivoted on the same notion.'b'It was \xe2\x80\x9cInside of a Dog\xe2\x80\x9d in particular that caught my friend Kerry Lauerman\xe2\x80\x99s attention, cluing him in to a quickly shifting human perspective on animals.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s this growing obsession with animal cognition,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Referring specifically to pets, he added: \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t want animals just for comfort. We really want to 'b'know 'b'them.\xe2\x80\x9d He mentioned another widely emailed story in The Times, from October, by a neuroeconomics professor who was doing M.R.I. scans of dogs\xe2\x80\x99 brains and finding suggestions of emotions like ours. Its telling headline: 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDogs Are People, Too.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Lauerman wasn\xe2\x80\x99t merely musing. He was explaining the rationale for a new website, 'b'The Dodo'b', that\xe2\x80\x99s dedicated to animal news and features and made its debut this week. He\xe2\x80\x99s its chief executive officer and editor in chief, and came to it from the influential online publication Salon, where he was the editor in chief from late 2010 to mid-2013.'b'One of The Dodo\xe2\x80\x99s principal financial backers is Ken Lerer, the current chairman of BuzzFeed and one of the founders of the Huffington Post. His daughter, Izzie Lerer, created and developed the site with Lauerman. Additionally, she\xe2\x80\x99s finishing up her doctorate in philosophy at Columbia University, where her research focuses on the evolving compact between people and animals.'b'The Dodo\xe2\x80\x99s pedigree speaks to a broadening, deepening concern about animals that\xe2\x80\x99s no longer sufficiently captured by the phrase \xe2\x80\x9canimal welfare.\xe2\x80\x9d An era of what might be called animal dignity is upon us. You see signs everywhere.'b'A story in The Wall Street Journal on Sunday reported a sharp rise over the last few years in the fraction of American dog and cat owners with provisions in their wills 'b'for their pets'b'. Nearly one in every 10 have made such arrangements.'b'One of the most fervently embraced documentaries of 2013 was \xe2\x80\x9cBlackfish,\xe2\x80\x9d shown over and over on CNN. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t just depict mistreatment of killer whales at SeaWorld; it makes the case that these glorious mammals have rich social and family connections and a profound capacity for grief.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s been extensive discussion lately of elephants\xe2\x80\x99 emotional lives, and Hillary Clinton, with her famously active political antenna, recently found time to narrate a documentary, \xe2\x80\x9cWhite Gold,\xe2\x80\x9d about the bloody wages of the ivory trade, and to speak at its premiere.'b'People who go on lion hunts encounter stern public shaming. (The Dodo recounts 'b'a recent example'b'.) Bill de Blasio has prioritized the retirement of Central Park\xe2\x80\x99s carriage horses. Several prominent retailers, including Gap and H&amp;M, stopped procuring angora last year after a widely shared video of the fur being yanked from rabbits\xe2\x80\x99 bodies. The movement to accord chimpanzees and some other kinds of apes legal rights is accelerating, and greater scrutiny of food production has prompted keener disgust over the fate of many farm animals, along with 'b'state legislation'b' to spare them florid suffering.'b'This is only going to build, because at the same time that scientific advances force us to gaze upon the animal kingdom with more respect, the proliferation of big and little cameras \xe2\x80\x94 of eyes everywhere \xe2\x80\x94 permits us to eavesdrop not just on animal play but also on animal persecution. It\xe2\x80\x99s all documented, it all goes viral, and we can\xe2\x80\x99t turn away, or claim ignorance, as easily as we once did.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThose creatures big and small that have fed, frightened, entertained, comforted and awed us are no longer just them,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Lauerman writes'b' in a letter to The Dodo\xe2\x80\x99s readers. \xe2\x80\x9cIncreasingly, they are us.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Why Everyone Seems to Have Cancer'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by George Johnson (Sunday Review, Jan. 5):'b'Although the \xe2\x80\x9cwar on cancer\xe2\x80\x9d nowadays more resembles a siege, presuming inevitable defeat seems a bit premature.
