In desperation, I called a counselor whom I had reluctantly seen a few times before and asked for help.'b'She helped me see that I was using alcohol and drugs to blunt the powerlessness I felt as a kid and suggested I give them up. That began some of the hardest months of my life. Without the alcohol and drugs in my system, I felt like my chest had been cracked open, exposing my heart to air. The counselor said that my abuse of drugs and alcohol was a symptom of an underlying problem \xe2\x80\x94 a \xe2\x80\x9cspiritual malady,\xe2\x80\x9d she called it. C.S.F.B. didn\xe2\x80\x99t offer me a full-time job, and I returned, distraught, to Columbia for senior year.'b'After graduation, I got a job at Bank of America, by the grace of a managing director willing to take a chance on a kid who had called him every day for three weeks. With a year of sobriety under my belt, I was sharp, cleareyed and hard-working. At the end of my first year I was thrilled to receive a $40,000 bonus. For the first time in my life, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t have to check my balance before I withdrew money. But a week later, a trader who was only four years my senior got hired away by C.S.F.B. for $900,000. After my initial envious shock \xe2\x80\x94 his haul was 22 times the size of my bonus \xe2\x80\x94 I grew excited at how much money was available.'b'Over the next few years I worked like a maniac and began to move up the Wall Street ladder. I became a bond and credit default swap trader, one of the more lucrative roles in the business. Just four years after I started at Bank of America, Citibank offered me a \xe2\x80\x9c1.75 by 2\xe2\x80\x9d which means $1.75 million per year for two years, and I used it to get a promotion. I started dating a pretty blonde and rented a loft apartment on Bond Street for $6,000 a month.'b'I felt so important. At 25, I could go to any restaurant in Manhattan \xe2\x80\x94 Per Se, Le Bernardin \xe2\x80\x94 just by picking up the phone and calling one of my brokers, who ingratiate themselves to traders by entertaining with unlimited expense accounts. I could be second row at the Knicks-Lakers game just by hinting to a broker I might be interested in going. The satisfaction wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just about the money. It was about the power. Because of how smart and successful I was, it was someone else\xe2\x80\x99s job to make me happy.'b'Still, I was nagged by envy. On a trading desk everyone sits together, from interns to managing directors. When the guy next to you makes $10 million, $1 million or $2 million doesn\xe2\x80\x99t look so sweet. She said I might be using money the same way I\xe2\x80\x99d used drugs and alcohol \xe2\x80\x94 to make myself feel powerful \xe2\x80\x94 and that maybe it would benefit me to stop focusing on accumulating more and instead focus on healing my inner wound. \xe2\x80\x9cInner wound\xe2\x80\x9d? I thought that was going a little far and went to work for a hedge fund.'b'Now, working elbow to elbow with billionaires, I was a giant fireball of greed. During the market crash in 2008, I\xe2\x80\x99d made a ton of money by shorting the derivatives of risky companies. As the world crumbled, I profited. I\xe2\x80\x99d seen the crash coming, but instead of trying to help the people it would hurt the most \xe2\x80\x94 people who didn\xe2\x80\x99t have a million dollars in the bank \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99d made money off it. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like who you\xe2\x80\x99ve become, my girlfriend had said years earlier. She was right then, and she was still right. Only now, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t like who I\xe2\x80\x99d become either.'b'Wealth addiction was described by the late sociologist and playwright Philip Slater in a 1980 book, but addiction researchers have paid the concept little attention. Like alcoholics driving drunk, wealth addiction imperils everyone. Wealth addicts are, more than anybody, specifically responsible for the ever widening rift that is tearing apart our once great country. Wealth addicts are responsible for the vast and toxic disparity between the rich and the poor and the annihilation of the middle class. Only a wealth addict would feel justified in receiving $14 million in compensation \xe2\x80\x94 including an $8.5 million bonus \xe2\x80\x94 as the McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s C.E.O., Don Thompson, did in 2012, while his company then published a brochure for its work force on how to survive on their low wages. I see Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s mantra \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re smarter and work harder than everyone else, so we deserve all this money\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 for what it is: the rationalization of addicts. From a distance I can see what I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t see then \xe2\x80\x94 that Wall Street is a toxic culture that encourages the grandiosity of people who are desperately trying to feel powerful.'b'I was lucky. Why not? Because our culture supports and even lauds the addiction. The money guy doing a job he complains about for yet another year so he can add $2 million to his $20 million bank account seems like an addict.'b'I recently got an email from a hedge-fund trader who said that though he was making millions every year, he felt trapped and empty, but couldn\xe2\x80\x99t summon the courage to leave. Together, maybe we can make a real contribution to the world.'b'HERE\xe2\x80\x99S a scary fact about America: We\xe2\x80\x99re much more likely to believe that there are signs that aliens have visited Earth (77 percent) than that humans are causing climate change (44 percent).'b'That comes to mind because a couple of weeks ago, 'b'I asked readers for suggestions'b' of \xe2\x80\x9cneglected topics\xe2\x80\x9d that we in the news business should cover more aggressively in 2014. 'b'Some 1,300 readers recommended'b' a broad range of issues, which I look forward to pilfering (with credit!) \xe2\x80\x94 and many made a particularly compelling case for climate change.'b'A reader from Virginia quoted James Hansen, the outspoken climate scientist: \xe2\x80\x9cImagine a giant asteroid on a direct collision course with Earth. That is the equivalent of what we face now.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another reader, Daria, acknowledged that the topic isn\xe2\x80\x99t sexy but added: \xe2\x80\x9cWhether we \xe2\x80\x98believe in it\xe2\x80\x99 or not, all species on Earth are being subject to frightening disruptions in our weather, food supply, land.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'You would think that we would be more attentive, with the federal government a few days ago declaring parts of 11 states disaster areas because of long-term drought. (Coverage did increase last year after a low in 2012.)'b'The proportion of Americans who say they believe that global warming is real has fallen since 2007 as well, and climate beliefs have fallen victim to political polarization. 'b'These days'b', 66 percent of Democrats say human activity is the main cause of global warming; 24 percent of Republicans say so.'b'My take is that when Democrats, led by Al Gore, championed climate change, Republicans instinctively grew suspicious. 'b'The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in September raised its confidence'b' that human activity is the main cause of warming from 90 percent probability to 95 percent or higher.'b'When we have this disjunction between scientific consensus and popular perception \xe2\x80\x94 well, that should light a fire under those of us in the news media.'b'An excellent basis for discussion is the new book \xe2\x80\x9cThe Climate Casino\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'by William Nordhaus'b', a Yale University economist. Professor Nordhaus is a moderate whose work has been cited by climate deniers, yet he concludes: \xe2\x80\x9cGlobal warming is a major threat to humans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nordhaus acknowledges uncertainty but sees that as a problem: \xe2\x80\x9cThe outcome will produce surprises, and some of them are likely to be perilous.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'For all the uncertainty, Nordhaus cites several areas of strong agreement among experts: Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere exceed those observed for at least the last 650,000 years; hurricanes will grow more intense; the Arctic will become ice free in summer; oceans will rise up to 23 inches by 2100 (more if there were major melting of ice sheets); and the global temperature will likely be 3.5 degrees to 7.5 degrees Fahrenheit higher in 2100 than in 1900.'b''b'A 7.5 degree difference in average temperature'b' may not sound like much. But it\xe2\x80\x99s about the differential by which Arizona is warmer than New Jersey.'b'Nordhaus warns that \xe2\x80\x9cthe pace of global warming will quicken over the decades to come and climate conditions will quickly pass beyond the range of recent historical experience.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Perhaps the greatest risk is various discontinuities and feedback loops that are difficult for climate models to account for. Melting of the Greenland ice sheet is typically predicted to add only a few inches to sea level rise by 2100, Nordhaus says. If the whole Greenland ice sheet disintegrated, that would raise sea level by 24 feet.'b'Climate change is hugely exacerbated by 'b'changing patterns of how we choose to live'b', often in danger zones such as extremely vulnerable coastal zones \xe2\x80\x94 from New Jersey to the Philippines. This enormously increases the economic and human costs of hurricanes, rising seas and changing weather patterns.'b'In politics and the military, we routinely deal with uncertainty. We can\xe2\x80\x99t be sure that someone is going to hijack a plane, but we still screen passengers.'b'So, readers, you\xe2\x80\x99re right! This is a neglected topic. MORGAN'b' Jersey City, Jan. 15, 2014'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Thanks, Mr. Bryant, for expressing so well what I have been feeling for years.'b'I am a staunch supporter of my local Republican Party. BRYANT'b' Hockessin, Del., Jan. 17, 2014'b''b'The latest 'b'surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report'b' on the health effects of smoking \xe2\x80\x94 issued at the 50th anniversary of the pathbreaking 1964 report \xe2\x80\x94 offers astonishing new evidence of just how much harm tobacco is causing. Despite the many gains in reducing risks over the past half-century, researchers keep finding new and insidious ways in which smoking is harming the smokers themselves and nonsmokers who breathe in toxic fumes.'b'The report, issued last Friday, finds that cigarette smoking kills even more Americans than previously estimated (about 480,000 a year, up from 443,000), and is a cause, though not necessarily the major cause, of even more diseases than previously recognized, including liver and colorectal cancers. These add to the long list of other cancers caused by smoking, as well as rheumatoid arthritis and other ailments. The report newly identifies exposure to secondhand smoke as a cause of strokes.'b'The report estimates that smoking costs the United States between $289 billion and $333 billion a year for medical care and lost productivity, well above the previous estimate of $193 billion.'b'Most shocking, the report finds that today\xe2\x80\x99s smokers have a much higher risk for lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease than smokers in 1964, despite smoking fewer cigarettes.'b'It reports that the risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the lung, the most common type of lung cancer, has increased substantially over the past several decades because of changes in the design and composition of cigarettes. These include ventilated filters that lead to more puffing of noxious materials and blended tobaccos that contain carcinogenic nitrosamines.'b'There is no doubt who is to blame for this mess, the report says. It is the tobacco industry, which \xe2\x80\x9caggressively markets and promotes lethal and addictive products,\xe2\x80\x9d continues to recruit youth and young adults as new customers, and has \xe2\x80\x9cdeliberately misled the public on the risks of smoking cigarettes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The new report rightly calls for more vigorous tobacco-control efforts, including an increase in cigarette taxes to drive up the average price of cigarettes to at least $10 a pack to prevent young people from starting to smoke; an antismoking mass media campaign by government agencies that would run year-round; and new rules extending smoke-free indoor protection to the entire population, double the current level. The goal is to reduce the smoking rate from the current 18 percent to less than 10 percent in 10 years.'b'There is an additional weapon that can be brought to bear. In mid-2009, Congress 'b'passed a law'b' that gave the Food and Drug Administration authority for the first time to regulate tobacco products. It should use those powers to reduce the addictiveness and harmfulness of smoking and reverse the design changes that have made cigarettes even more dangerous than they were in previous decades.'b'MORE than a decade into the 21st century, we would like to think that American parents have similar standards and similar dreams for their sons and daughters. But my study of anonymous, aggregate data from Google searches suggests that contemporary American parents are far more likely to want their boys smart and their girls skinny.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not that parents don\xe2\x80\x99t want their daughters to be bright or their sons to be in shape, but they are much more focused on the braininess of their sons and the waistlines of their daughters.'b'Start with intelligence. It\xe2\x80\x99s hardly surprising that parents of young children are often excited at the thought that their child may be gifted. In fact, of all Google searches starting \xe2\x80\x9cIs my 2-year-old,\xe2\x80\x9d the most common next word is \xe2\x80\x9cgifted.\xe2\x80\x9d But this question is not asked equally about young boys and young girls. Parents are two and a half times more likely to ask \xe2\x80\x9cIs my son gifted?\xe2\x80\x9d than \xe2\x80\x9cIs my daughter gifted?\xe2\x80\x9d Parents show a similar bias when using other phrases related to intelligence that they may shy away from saying aloud, like, \xe2\x80\x9cIs my son a genius?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Are parents picking up on legitimate differences between young girls and boys? Perhaps young boys are more likely than young girls to use big words or otherwise show objective signs of giftedness? Nope. If anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s the opposite. At young ages, when parents most often search about possible giftedness, girls have 'b'consistently been shown'b' to have larger vocabularies and use more complex sentences. In American schools, girls are 11 percent more likely than boys to be in gifted programs. Despite all this, parents looking around the dinner table appear to see more gifted boys than girls.'b'Parents were more likely to ask about sons rather than daughters on every matter that I tested related to intelligence, including its absence. There are more searches for \xe2\x80\x9cis my son behind\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cstupid\xe2\x80\x9d than comparable searches for daughters. Searches with negative words like \xe2\x80\x9cstupid\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cbehind,\xe2\x80\x9d however, are less skewed toward sons than searches with positive words.'b'What concerns do parents disproportionately have for their daughters? Primarily, anything related to appearance. Consider questions about a child\xe2\x80\x99s weight. Parents Google \xe2\x80\x9cIs my daughter overweight?\xe2\x80\x9d roughly twice as frequently as they Google \xe2\x80\x9cIs my son overweight?\xe2\x80\x9d Just as with giftedness, this gender bias is not grounded in reality. About 30 percent of girls are 'b'overweight'b', while 33 percent of boys are. Even though scales measure more overweight boys than girls, parents see \xe2\x80\x94 or worry about \xe2\x80\x94 overweight girls much more often than overweight boys.'b'Parents are about twice as likely to ask how to get their daughters to lose weight as they are to ask how to get their sons to do the same. Google search data also tell us that mothers and fathers are more likely to wonder whether their daughter is \xe2\x80\x9cbeautiful\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cugly.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Parents are one and a half times more likely to ask whether their daughter is beautiful than whether their son is, but they are nearly three times more likely to ask whether their daughter is ugly than whether their son is ugly. How Google is expected to know whether a child is beautiful or ugly is hard to say.'b'In general, parents seem more likely to use positive words in questions about sons. There is a larger bias toward asking whether sons are \xe2\x80\x9ctall\xe2\x80\x9d than \xe2\x80\x9cshort.\xe2\x80\x9d Parents are more likely to ask whether a son is \xe2\x80\x9chappy\xe2\x80\x9d and slightly more likely to ask whether a daughter is \xe2\x80\x9cdepressed.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Liberal readers may imagine that these biases are more common in conservative parts of the country. Not so. I did not find a significant relationship between any of the biases mentioned and the political or cultural makeup of a state. These biases appear to cut across ideological divisions. In fact, I was unable to find any demographics that significantly reduced the biases. Nor is there evidence that these biases have decreased since 2004, the year for which Google search data is first available.'b'This methodology can also be used to study gender preference before birth. Every year, Americans make hundreds of thousands of searches asking how to conceive a child of a particular sex. In searches with the words \xe2\x80\x9chow to conceive,\xe2\x80\x9d Americans are slightly more likely to include the word \xe2\x80\x9cboy\xe2\x80\x9d than \xe2\x80\x9cgirl.\xe2\x80\x9d Among the subset of Americans Googling for specific gender conception strategies, there is about a 10 percent preference for boys compared with girls.'b'This boy preference is surprising for two reasons. First, the top websites returned for these queries are overwhelmingly geared toward women, suggesting that women are most often making gender conception searches. Yet in surveys, women express a slight preference for having girls, not boys; men say they prefer sons. Second, many Americans are willing to admit a gender preference to even out a family. About 5 percent more boys are born than girls in the United States, so evening out a family would more often require having a girl, not a boy. Are men searching for conception advice in large numbers? Are women searching on their husbands\xe2\x80\x99 behalf? Or do some American women have a son preference that they are not comfortable admitting to surveys?'b'Other countries exhibit very large preferences in favor of boys. In India, for each search asking how to conceive a girl, there are three-and-a-half asking how to conceive a boy. With such an overwhelming preference for boys, it is not surprising that there are millions fewer women in India than population scientists would predict.'b'Clearly there is more to learn. Because this data make it easy to compare different countries over time, for example, we might examine whether these gender preferences change after a woman is elected to run a country.'b'The disturbing results outlined here leave us with many open questions, but the most poignant may be this one: How would American girls\xe2\x80\x99 lives be different if parents were half as concerned with their bodies and twice as intrigued by their minds?'b'WHAT would Marlise Munoz have made of all of this?'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ll never know. She can no longer form words. Can no longer form 'b'thoughts'b'. It\xe2\x80\x99s arguable that we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t even be referring to a \xe2\x80\x9cshe,\xe2\x80\x9d to a \xe2\x80\x9cher,\xe2\x80\x9d because if she\xe2\x80\x99s brain-dead, as her family has consistently said, then she meets the legal criteria for death in all 50 states, and what\xe2\x80\x99s been tethered to machines in a hospital in Fort Worth for the last seven weeks isn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly a mother. It\xe2\x80\x99s an artificially maintained ecosystem, an incubator for a fetus that has somehow been given precedence over all other concerns: the pain of Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s husband and parents; their wishes to put an end to this; their best guess about what her desires would have been; her transformation, without any possibility of her consent, into a mere vessel.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA host,\xe2\x80\x9d her father, Ernest Machado, called her in an interview 'b'with Manny Fernandez of The Times'b'. It seems to me that several lives are being devalued in the process, and that while there are no happy outcomes here, there\xe2\x80\x99s also no sense or dignity on the chilling road that this Texas hospital is taking us down.'b'In late November, Marlise, 33, was found unconscious on the kitchen floor by her husband, Erick. She had apparently suffered a pulmonary embolism. At the hospital, according to Erick\xe2\x80\x99s subsequent statements, it was determined that she was brain-dead, and he requested that she be disconnected from the machines that keep her vital organs functioning. He and she had both worked as paramedics and had discussed such end-of-life decisions, he said, and so he knew that she wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have wanted any extraordinary measures taken. The woman he loved was gone. It was time to come to bitter terms with that, and to say goodbye.'b'Hospital officials, supposedly acting on behalf of the state, won\xe2\x80\x99t let him. They went ahead with extraordinary measures, because Marlise was 14 weeks pregnant, and while that fell well within the window when abortion is legal, a Texas law compels hospitals to provide life support for terminally ill patients with fetuses developing inside them.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s considerable dispute about whether this law in fact covers Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s situation: about whether someone brain-dead qualifies as a patient and can be said to be receiving 'b'life'b' support. Lawyers representing him 'b'told CNN'b' on Friday that her medical records indeed document brain death.'b'But regardless of the law and whether it applies to Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s case, the treatment of her and her family isn\xe2\x80\x99t just or right, for many reasons.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not at all clear, for starters, that the fetus has a good chance of surviving inside the womb or of flourishing outside of it. 'b'In a study'b' of a few dozen cases of continued pregnancies inside brain-dead women, only one of the five fetuses that were between 13 and 15 weeks at the time of the mother\xe2\x80\x99s brain death was successfully delivered \xe2\x80\x94 by cesarean section \xe2\x80\x94 and kept alive, though the study tracked the boy only until 11 months after his birth.'b'I talked last week with two prominent obstetricians, both of whom said that it was impossible, until relatively late in a pregnancy, to get any real sense of how much neurological damage a fetus may have already suffered as a result of a maternal embolism and of any oxygen deprivation that occurred. They also said that a pregnancy dependent on artificial organ maintenance entails an array of dangers to the fetus beyond ordinary ones, including the mother\xe2\x80\x99s susceptibility to infections.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s extremely risky for fetal development,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mary D\xe2\x80\x99Alton, the head of obstetrics and gynecology at Columbia University Medical Center and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital. But, she added, \xe2\x80\x9cIf the family is willing and it\xe2\x80\x99s something they want, it\xe2\x80\x99s something I would attempt \xe2\x80\x94 and have attempted.\xe2\x80\x9d She said that she was involved in two such pregnancies. In one, the fetus died in utero at 27 weeks. In the other, a child was born, but with problems.'b'She dwelt on the part about the family\xe2\x80\x99s will, focusing on a simple truth that the Texas situation sweeps to the side. \xe2\x80\x9cThey will live with the impact,\xe2\x80\x9d D\xe2\x80\x99Alton said.'b'From what\xe2\x80\x99s been reported about Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s case, the hospital, executing the will of the state, has been making all of the calls about the care of the fetus, now about 21 weeks along. (The threshold for viability is generally considered to be 24 weeks.) But if there\xe2\x80\x99s a premature birth and quick death, Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s husband and parents will presumably be expected to deal with that.'b'And if a baby is born with severe and enduring ailments, Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s husband and parents will presumably inherit the effort to give that child a decent quality of life, which is a concept that goes strangely missing in too many disputes over the unborn.'b'In other words they\xe2\x80\x99ll possibly confront a slew of decisions \xe2\x80\x9cdownstream from a decision that they already made and that got overruled,\xe2\x80\x9d the one to remove her from machines, said Hyagriv Simhan, the chief of maternal-fetal medicine at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s quite complex.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s one word for it. Cruel is another.'b'Marlise apparently didn\xe2\x80\x99t leave any advance medical directive covering the particular scenario of artificial organ maintenance for a fetus well shy of viability. How many women do? In the absence of such instructions, her physicians should have done what they would have if there\xe2\x80\x99d been no fetus \xe2\x80\x94 looked to, and heeded, her obvious surrogates, her next of kin. How, then, can it prevent a family who speaks legitimately for her from taking that same step? Especially in a circumstance like this, so riddled with risks, questions and heartbreak? Marlise\xe2\x80\x99s husband and parents may not be able to ask her what she\xe2\x80\x99d make of it. But they\xe2\x80\x99re the ones left to behold and grieve over what\xe2\x80\x99s been made of her.'b'WHAT is happening in retirement communities, assisted living facilities and nursing homes? You might imagine quiet reading, crossword puzzles, bingo, maybe some shuffleboard. Think again. Think about sex \xe2\x80\x94 unsafe sex.'b'The Department of Health and Human Services released a little-noticed report on Medicare a few months ago that had this startling statistic: In 2011 and 2012, 2.2 million beneficiaries received free sexually transmitted disease screenings and counseling sessions. And more than 66,000 received free H.I.V. tests.'b'The number of Medicare enrollees who took advantage of free S.T.D. tests is about the same as the number who received free colonoscopies to screen for colon cancer, amounting to about 5 percent of all those on Medicare.'b'Numbers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show rapid increases in S.T.D.\xe2\x80\x99s among older people. Between 2007 and 2011, chlamydia infections among Americans 65 and over increased by 31 percent, and syphilis by 52 percent. Those numbers are similar to S.T.D. trends in the 20- to 24-year-old age group, where chlamydia increased by 35 percent and syphilis by 64 percent. Experts suggest there are four main factors contributing to the rise in S.T.D.\xe2\x80\x99s among older Americans.'b'First, retirement communities and assisted living facilities are becoming like college campuses. They cram a lot of similarly aged people together, and when they do, things naturally happen. I mentioned these numbers to a friend, and she was not surprised. When her father moved into an assisted-living facility, she said, three women came by to introduce themselves within 30 minutes. And it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to compare Medicare pharmacy plans and premiums.'b'Second, older people are living longer and are in better health. As a result, they are remaining sexually active much later into life. Several major surveys, including the National Social Life, Health and Aging Project and the National Survey of Sexual Health and Behavior, report that among people age 60 and older, more than half of men and 40 percent of women are sexually active.'b'But while they are having a lot of sex, seniors didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to get the safe sex memo, or when it came through they ignored it because they did not think it applied to them. They obviously don\xe2\x80\x99t have to worry about pregnancy. And they grew up before the safe sex era. So seniors might think they have no reason to use condoms. According to the 2010 National Survey of Sexual Health and Behavior, among college-age Americans, condoms are used in about 40 percent of sexual encounters, but only in about 6 percent of sexual encounters among those 61 and older. A study published in the Annals of Internal Medicine showed that older men who use Viagra and similar drugs are six times less likely to use condoms compared with men in their 20s.'b'Combine retirement communities, longer life, unfamiliarity with condoms and Viagra \xe2\x80\x94 and what do you get? You get an S.T.D. epidemic among the Social Security generation that rivals what we imagine is happening in those \xe2\x80\x9cAnimal House\xe2\x80\x9d fraternities.'b'These S.T.D. numbers demand that seniors take responsibility for their actions.'b'Clinicians must be aware of these trends and not overlook S.T.D. screenings when treating older patients. As you might expect, though, doctors are not very good at talking about sex in general and protected sex in particular \xe2\x80\x94 especially to the elderly. If doctors aren\xe2\x80\x99t having \xe2\x80\x9cthe talk,\xe2\x80\x9d we have to get safe sex counselors more involved at retirement communities and assisted living facilities. These facilities could also consider making condoms readily available, as they often are on college campuses.'b'We also need a big public health campaign on safe sex aimed not just at college students but at older people who are living independently. Maybe the AARP can push its constituents to be sexually responsible. Social Security could include some information on S.T.D.\xe2\x80\x99s and how to use a condom when it sends out checks. Come to think of it, these data mean there is an untapped market: over 40 million Americans who are unfamiliar with latex protection. Maybe Durex and Trojan can mail free condoms to every Social Security recipient?'b'IN 2009, shortly after Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s successful campaign for the White House, the McNally Jackson bookstore in Manhattan organized a display of about 50 books that Mr. Obama had read as a young man. The titles were eclectic, with a good number by African-American authors, including Ralph Ellison, James Baldwin and Toni Morrison.'b'As a candidate, Mr. Obama demonstrated a remarkable rhetorical ability to present himself as both inhabiting and escaping from the worlds created by these writers. He even modeled his much praised memoir, \xe2\x80\x9cDreams From My Father,\xe2\x80\x9d on Ellison\xe2\x80\x99s 1952 novel, \xe2\x80\x9cInvisible Man.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet where Ellison\xe2\x80\x99s young, idealistic black protagonist remains anonymous \xe2\x80\x94 the book ends with him alone in his underground apartment \xe2\x80\x94 Mr. Obama won the White House, inaugurating what many at the time hoped was a new, \xe2\x80\x9cpostracial\xe2\x80\x9d America.'b'That optimism turned out to be premature. Today, anti-Obama signs with racist language accompany Tea Party rallies; a Confederate flag is unfurled in front of the White House to protest the government shutdown.'b'Looking back, there was one book in the McNally Jackson display, overlooked at the time, that could have helped us anticipate all this. That book was \xe2\x80\x9cBenito Cereno,\xe2\x80\x9d a largely forgotten masterpiece by Herman Melville. In today\xe2\x80\x99s charged political environment, the message of Melville\xe2\x80\x99s story bears rehearing.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBenito Cereno\xe2\x80\x9d tells the story of Amasa Delano, a New England sea captain who, in the South Pacific, spends all day on a distressed Spanish ship carrying scores of West Africans who he thinks are slaves. They aren\xe2\x80\x99t. Unbeknown to Delano, they had earlier risen up, slaughtered most of the crew and demanded that the captain, Benito Cereno, return them home to Senegal. After Delano boards the ship (to offer his assistance), the West Africans keep their rebellion a secret by acting as if they are still slaves. Their leader, a man named Babo, pretends to be Cereno\xe2\x80\x99s loyal servant, while actually keeping a close eye on him.'b'Melville narrates the events from the perspective of the clueless Delano, who for most of the novella thinks Cereno is in charge. As the day progresses, Delano grows increasingly obsessed with Babo and the seeming affection with which the West African cares for the Spanish captain. The New Englander, liberal in his sentiments and opposed to slavery as a matter of course, fantasizes about being waited on by such a devoted and cheerful body servant.'b'Delano believes himself a free man, and he defines his freedom in opposition to the smiling, open-faced Babo, who he presumes has no interior life, no ideas or interests of his own. Delano sees what he wants to see. But when Delano ultimately discovers the truth \xe2\x80\x94 that Babo, in fact, is the one exercising masterly discipline over his inner thoughts, and that it is Delano who is enslaved to his illusions \xe2\x80\x94 he responds with savage violence.'b'Barack Obama may have avoided the fate of the protagonist of \xe2\x80\x9cInvisible Man,\xe2\x80\x9d but he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been able to escape the shadow of Babo. He is Babo, or at least he is to a significant part of the American population \xe2\x80\x94 including many of the white rank and file of the Republican Party and the Tea Party politicians they help elect.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBenito Cereno\xe2\x80\x9d is based on a true historical incident, which I started researching around the time Mr. Obama announced his first bid for the presidency. Since then, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been struck by the persistence of fears, which began even before his election, that Mr. Obama isn\xe2\x80\x99t what he seems: that instead of being a faithful public servant he is carrying out a leftist plot hatched decades ago to destroy America; or if not that, then he is a secret Muslim intent on supplanting the Constitution with Islamic law; or a Kenyan-born anti-colonialist out to avenge his native Africa.'b'No other American president has had to face, before even taking office, an opposition convinced of not just his political but his existential illegitimacy. In order to succeed as a politician, Mr. Obama had to cultivate what many have described as an almost preternatural dominion over his inner self. He had to become a \xe2\x80\x9cblank screen,\xe2\x80\x9d as Mr. Obama himself has put it, on which others could project their ideals \xe2\x80\x94 just as Babo is for Delano. Yet this intense self-control seems to be what drives the president\xe2\x80\x99s more feverish detractors into a frenzy; they fill that screen with hatreds drawn deep from America\xe2\x80\x99s historical subconscious.'b'Published in late 1855, as the United States moved toward the Civil War, \xe2\x80\x9cBenito Cereno\xe2\x80\x9d is one of the most despairing stories in American literature. Amasa Delano represents a new kind of racism, based not on theological or philosophical doctrine but rather on the emotional need to measure one\xe2\x80\x99s absolute freedom in inverse relation to another\xe2\x80\x99s absolute slavishness. This was a racism that was born in chattel slavery but didn\xe2\x80\x99t die with chattel slavery, instead evolving into today\xe2\x80\x99s cult of individual supremacy, which, try as it might, can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to shake off its white supremacist roots.'b'THIS helps explain those Confederate flags that appear at conservative rallies, as well as why Tea Party-backed politicians like Sarah Palin and Rand Paul insist on equating federal policies they don\xe2\x80\x99t like with chattel bondage. Believing in the \xe2\x80\x9cright to health care,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Paul once said, is \xe2\x80\x9cbasically saying you believe in slavery.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As for Mr. Obama, he continues to invoke fantasies that seem drawn straight from Melville\xe2\x80\x99s imagination. One Republican councilman, in Michigan, attended a protest carrying an image of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s decapitated head on a pike, which happens to be the very fate that befalls Babo once his ruse unravels. Another Republican ran for Congress in Florida with a commercial featuring Mr. Obama as the captain of a slave ship.'b'Over 60 years ago, Ralph Ellison began \xe2\x80\x9cInvisible Man\xe2\x80\x9d with an epigraph drawn from \xe2\x80\x9cBenito Cereno.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a pleading question that Delano asks Cereno after the revolt is put down and Babo is executed: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are saved: what has cast such a shadow upon you?\xe2\x80\x9d Though Ellison purposefully omitted it from his epigraph, in today\xe2\x80\x99s America it is still worth recalling Cereno\xe2\x80\x99s answer: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Negro.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'FOR most of my 20s I played in the indie rock band Sleater-Kinney. We wrote songs, we recorded them, we toured. In my 30s, though, things changed. I started spending most of my time writing or working on the TV show \xe2\x80\x9cPortlandia.\xe2\x80\x9d I haven\xe2\x80\x99t played many live shows in the past decade, but somehow I feel as if I\xe2\x80\x99m still on tour \xe2\x80\x94 not just with my bandmates, but with everyone. So I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d try writing a song again, so I\xe2\x80\x99d have something to play.'b'My song is prosaic. It tries to sound tossed-off, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not. It\xe2\x80\x99s overly considered. But soon I hit the sweet spot and \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s pithy. Whack. Thump. Head meets heart. My tune tells you where I am and what I\xe2\x80\x99m doing. It\xe2\x80\x99s report and rapport. Truth meets the unreliability of feeling. Fact meets friction. I play it all day long. Here\xe2\x80\x99s how it goes.'b'First verse: 'b'I texted to let you know that I woke up this morning. Otherwise I worried you might think, No word from her yet today \xe2\x80\x94 she must have died in her sleep.'b''b'We\xe2\x80\x99re living on a million tiny stages. Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Facebook, YouTube. Dinner plates are showcases for our food, beds become venues for our slumber, selfies are curtain calls for our faces. We put our activities on display, our feelings, our families, our skies. We\xe2\x80\x99re not quite sure if there is a point in doing anything anymore if it can\xe2\x80\x99t be documented, if no one is there to observe it. We long for favorites and likes and reposts, compulsively monitor these new forms of applause. The marquees of our lives say, special guest: ME! We play an encore, and then another. The quotidian one-man show never quite ends.'b'Second verse: same as the first. Except it\xe2\x80\x99s lunch. 'b'P'b''b'lease don\xe2\x80\x99t worry, I\xe2\x80\x99m eating. Here\xe2\x80\x99s proof. #nofilter.'b''b'All of these stages mean there is very little quiet. How can there be with so many exclamation points!!!? We shout as if everything from our breakfast scrambles to our dogs are tantamount to the \xe2\x80\x9cRocky\xe2\x80\x9d moment at the top of the stairs, or being on the bow of the ship like whatshisname in the movie \xe2\x80\x9cTitanic.\xe2\x80\x9d Never have we been so emphatic. If you want to elicit concern from a loved one, type a period at the end of a text message; it indicates a malaise, or worse, apathy. Apathy about that new sweater, apathy about 6 o\xe2\x80\x99clock. In fact, I\xe2\x80\x99ve never shown the hours of the day so much love as I have in the last few years. 5 p.m.!!!!!! I\xe2\x80\x99ve never meant YES!!! or NO!!! or O.K.!!! as much as I do now. And I\xe2\x80\x99ve never asked questions as intensely. RIGHT????'b'Third verse. 'b'I started a joke which started the whole Twitter-verse laughing. Oh, you\xe2\x80\x99re crying. I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry. Delete.'b''b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s be honest \xe2\x80\x94 if you\xe2\x80\x99re always on some ersatz stage, humming some endless song, then you can\xe2\x80\x99t merely mutter, \xe2\x80\x9cHello, Cleveland,\xe2\x80\x9d as if you\xe2\x80\x99re about to lecture to it, admonish it for not being some other city. Instead, you have to say, \xe2\x80\x9cHELLO, CLEVELAND!!!\xe2\x80\x9d Up onstage there is no place for the affectless \xe2\x80\x9cHow are you doing tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d That sounds like you might follow up with some dour, disheartening news, like, \xe2\x80\x9cWe have the results of your test\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s end this relationship.\xe2\x80\x9d Now the only option is, \xe2\x80\x9cHOW ARE YOU DOING TONIGHT?!!!!\xe2\x80\x9d [Applause]. [Like]. Relief.'b'Fourth verse: 'b'Traditionally there might be a bridge here. Here\xe2\x80\x99s a picture of one I drove over today on my way downtown.'b''b'A few years ago \xe2\x80\x94 mostly for the sake of talking about it \xe2\x80\x94 I quit Facebook. I went back only five times (O.K., maybe seven), but only to see how many people liked or commented on my status update saying that I was leaving. (Note to friends reading this: Please let me know if you\xe2\x80\x99ve recently died or had a birthday because I now have no way of knowing.) Seeing how many friends cared about my quitting Facebook was like getting to observe my own funeral. I think Facebook should advertise itself as a memorial service for the living. It makes the present feel as if it is instantaneously collecting dust. We\xe2\x80\x99ve become our own estate sales. But how can I put a price on my life if I\xe2\x80\x99m not really living it?'b'Fifth verse: Five verses and not a chorus in sight? I guess this is turning into a folk song or Don McLean\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Pie.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'I need to take my non-Chevy German luxury car to get repaired. Any recos? DM me.'b''b'When all of our information \xe2\x80\x94 images, art, news, modes of communication \xe2\x80\x94 is mediated through the same screen, the notion of value, of what is important and unimportant, even in a subjective, personal sense, becomes murky. Births, deaths, celebrity mug shots, piano-playing kittens, children we don\xe2\x80\x99t know engaging in wackiness, war, poverty, photos of salt shakers and table sets, tales of the mundane, puns: This is all funneled and flattened, much to our delight and convenience, of course. Everything is a headline, everything is front page.'b'Sixth verse: 'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m happy because you saw a squirrel and let everyone know. Also, my dad has cancer.'b''b'I don\xe2\x80\x99t miss a more monolithic age, where we all watched or heard the same moments through one of a few outlets, when what we witnessed was not overly diffuse or fractured, when the commentary and discussion were not as loud and concurrent as the event itself.'b'Sure, we rarely gather around a single moment anymore, at least not for long. But occasionally we join together to make a constellation that feels like a mass, something sturdy and important. Like maybe, right now. My song meets your song. Then piles upon piles of the mundane start to feel like days, like stories, like shapes, like songs, like lives.'b'Chorus: 'b'All together now. I\xe2\x80\x99ll listen if you will.'b''b'IN his opinion last month regarding the constitutionality of the National Security Agency\xe2\x80\x99s phone-data collection program, Judge Richard Leon wrote that \xe2\x80\x9cJames Madison, who cautioned us to beware of \xe2\x80\x98the abridgment of freedom of the people by gradual and silent encroachments by those in power,\xe2\x80\x99 would be aghast.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Judge Leon isn\xe2\x80\x99t the only legal mind these days to view Madison as a libertarian icon. Justice Antonin Scalia invoked Madison last spring in his memorable dissent from a Supreme Court opinion upholding the government\xe2\x80\x99s right to collect DNA swabs from suspects.'b'Expect to hear a lot more about Madison in the coming year, as the issues surrounding the N.S.A. move toward what Justice Scalia has said will be a likely review by the Supreme Court. For that reason, it is important to explore what Madison does and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t offer to this debate.'b'The apotheosis of Madison as an emblem for opposition to mass surveillance is welcome. But the reasoning behind his beliefs has been misunderstood. He believed that the preservation of people\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cdifferent and unequal faculties of acquiring property\xe2\x80\x9d was \xe2\x80\x9cthe first object of government,\xe2\x80\x9d but that a too-powerful government could undermine that goal. He was, therefore, more concerned with abuses of legislative and executive power than of unregulated commercial power.'b'As a result, the Bill of Rights, which he came to champion, constrains only government actors, not private ones. It applies to the government, not Google. Now that Google and AT&amp;T can track us more closely than any N.S.A. agent, it appears that the Madisonian Constitution may be inadequate to defend our privacy and dignity in the 21st century.'b'Soon after Judge Leon issued his ruling, Judge William H. Pauley III, a federal district judge in New York, reached the opposite conclusion, upholding the N.S.A. spying program in part by noting that the founders approved of secrecy.'b'The debate between Judge Leon and Judge Pauley echoes the one between Federalists and Anti-Federalists about the proper scope of government, one Madison, a moderate for his time, so effectively straddled.'b'In the revolutionary period, the galvanizing examples of government overreach were the \xe2\x80\x9cgeneral warrants\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwrits of assistance\xe2\x80\x9d that allowed the king\xe2\x80\x99s agents \xe2\x80\x9cto break open Doors, Chests, Trunks, and other Packages,\xe2\x80\x9d without specifying either the goods to be seized or the houses to be searched.'b'In a famous attack on such writs in 1761, the lawyer James Otis said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a power that places the liberty of every man in the hands of every petty officer.\xe2\x80\x9d To avoid the dangers of an overreaching central government, in 1777 the Continental Congress created a weak union governed by the Articles of Confederation.'b'Madison, a moderate Federalist, lamented the inability of the newly created government to curb the occasional excesses of economic populism, such as Shays\xe2\x80\x99 Rebellion in western Massachusetts, where debtors attempted to take over the local government.'b'Madison and others gathered in Philadelphia in 1787 to create a stronger, but still limited, federal government. In response to demands by Anti-Federalists for amendments that protect individual liberty against the government, Madison introduced the Bill of Rights in 1789.'b'Unable to foresee the Leviathan national security state, Madison, in his Bill of Rights, was more concerned with abuses by Congress than the executive branch. But he had an even greater blind spot for abuses by the private sector, because he was focused on protecting the property rights of the few against the tyranny of the many.'b'For example, economically populist Anti-Federalists, including Thomas Jefferson, backed an amendment to prohibit Congress from granting monopolies or setting up \xe2\x80\x9cany company with exclusive advantages of commerce.\xe2\x80\x9d Madison, who also mistrusted monopolies, was less convinced that they should be \xe2\x80\x9cwholly renounced.\xe2\x80\x9d He responded to Jefferson that \xe2\x80\x9cmonopolies are sacrifices of the many to the few,\xe2\x80\x9d and in America, where the power rested with the people, \xe2\x80\x9cit is much more to be dreaded that the few will be unnecessarily sacrificed to the many.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is, therefore, a tension in modern libertarian appreciations of Madison. They exaggerate his opposition to abuse of federal power and ignore his failure to anticipate abuse of corporate power.'b'Today, the foes of corporate monopoly power include those on the Tea Party Right and the Occupy Wall Street left. But on the right, the Madisonian devotion to property rights, and Jeffersonian suspicion of regulation, are so strong that the same principled libertarians who oppose N.S.A. data collection shrink from efforts to regulate Google or AT&amp;T.'b'In his speech on intelligence reform on Friday, President Obama called on Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to develop options for how the bulk telephone data collection program could continue without the metadata being held by the government itself. But telecom companies have resisted being the repository for the data, and an anti-regulatory Congress is unlikely to require them to do so or to impose meaningful limits on what they can do with the data they hold.'b'As a result, Internet service providers and telecoms are constrained neither by the Constitution nor, in meaningful ways, by federal privacy statutes. And they are free to engage in just the kind of intrusive surveillance that Judge Leon insisted was an unreasonable search and seizure when conducted by the N.S.A.'b'In practice, the neo-Madisonian distinction between surveillance by the government and surveillance by Google makes little sense. It is true that, as Judge Pauley concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cPeople voluntarily surrender personal and seemingly private information to trans-national corporations which exploit that data for profit. Few think twice about it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But why? Why is it O.K. for AT&amp;T to know about our political, religious and sexual associations, but not the government?'b'You might say there is a difference between political and cultural information. If the government knows you attended a Rand Paul rally, it could punish you by auditing your tax returns. But if AT&amp;T knows, it might send you an ad for a Tea Party Tax Day protest.'b'That distinction is unconvincing. Once data is collected by private parties, the government will inevitably demand access.'b'More fundamentally, continuously tracking my location, whether by the government or AT&amp;T, is an affront to my dignity. When every step I take on- and off-line is recorded, so an algorithm can predict if I am a potential terrorist or a potential customer, I am being objectified and stereotyped, rather than treated as an individual, worthy of equal concern and respect.'b'Justice Louis Brandeis, the greatest defender of privacy in the 20th century, recognized this when he equated \xe2\x80\x9cthe right to be let alone\xe2\x80\x9d with offenses against honor and dignity.'b'But he also lamented that American law, unlike European law, was not historically concerned with offenses against what the Romans called honor and what in more modern terms we call dignity. European laws constrain private companies from sharing and collecting personal data far more than American laws do, largely because of the legacy of Madisonian ideas of individual freedom, which focus on liberty rather than dignity.'b'What Americans may now need is a constitutional amendment to prohibit unreasonable searches and seizures of our persons and electronic effects, whether by the government or by private corporations like Google and AT&amp;T.'b'Perhaps even Madison, who unsuccessfully proposed a preamble to the Constitution declaring \xe2\x80\x9cthat all power is originally rested in, and consequently derived from the people,\xe2\x80\x9d and that all people have basic natural rights, including \xe2\x80\x9cthe enjoyment of life and liberty\xe2\x80\x9d and the right of \xe2\x80\x9cpursuing and obtaining happiness and safety,\xe2\x80\x9d might have realized that our rights to enjoy liberty, and to obtain happiness and safety at the same time, are threatened as much by corporate as government surveillance.'b'In any event, it is clear that, to keep us secure against the 21st-century version of the general warrants that so alarmed Madison and the other founders, America needs a robust debate about amending the Constitution to meet the exigencies of our electronic age.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s face it: For the world\xe2\x80\x99s media, nothing beats a good story about a French politician\xe2\x80\x99s love life. Forget Bill Clinton, Jacob Zuma and Silvio Berlusconi. For some reason, it\xe2\x80\x99s always more fun in Paris. Reporters from around the globe descend on the City of Light, baffled by the same old question: Why don\xe2\x80\x99t the French care about their politicians\xe2\x80\x99 affairs? Across the Channel, by contrast, anything goes. Even The Financial Times got carried away with this story and, to make up for it, then printed a letter from a reader scolding it for putting \xe2\x80\x9ca photo of an attractive woman\xe2\x80\x9d on half of its front page.'b'The attractive woman is, of course, the actress Julie Gayet, with whom, according to reports in the gossip magazine Closer, President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande has been secretly meeting in a private apartment not far from the \xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9e. Upon learning from the president about the magazine\xe2\x80\x99s disclosures, Val\xc3\xa9rie Trierweiler, the first lady and his partner, broke down and had to be admitted to the hospital for \xe2\x80\x9ctests and rest.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While the world\xe2\x80\x99s media have been concentrating on the collective \xe2\x80\x9cFrench shrug\xe2\x80\x9d over all this, the French themselves are trying to understand the president they elected 20 months ago. Sure enough, a poll showed that 77 percent of voters consider the alleged affair as part of his right to privacy. But this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean they don\xe2\x80\x99t care about it; it\xe2\x80\x99s just that the French are more concerned about other statistics: the unemployment rate which, at 10.9 percent, is twice as high as Germany\xe2\x80\x99s, or the government\xe2\x80\x99s abysmal approval ratings, stuck below 30 percent. Never before has a French president been so unpopular so early in his first term. Trust in political institutions is at an all-time low, and pessimism rules: 72 percent of the French fear their children will be worse off.'b'Which makes the lightness of Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande even more puzzling. The president who, as a candidate, promised that his behavior would be \xe2\x80\x9cexemplary\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 unlike that of his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy \xe2\x80\x94 in fact never intended his behavior to be perfect. In Mr. Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s mind, we now know, \xe2\x80\x9cexemplary\xe2\x80\x9d meant discreet; he merely assumed that he could resume the old tradition of President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand\xe2\x80\x99s secret double life. He just forgot that in the age of Twitter and WikiLeaks, secrets can\xe2\x80\x99t be kept for 20 years, let alone 20 months.'b'Perplexed by their president\xe2\x80\x99s economic indecisiveness since he took office, the French now learn that he is equally indecisive in his private life. And they have found out at the worst moment. After hesitating to address squarely the issue of radical economic reforms, after avoiding to cut public spending to reduce the fiscal deficit, after procrastinating on measures needed to restore the competitiveness of French companies, the president, having lost 20 months, finally decided that it was time to do all of the above.'b'This was the message he started to deliver to the nation in his traditional New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve address. Desperately aware of the sorry state of the economy \xe2\x80\x94 which, to be fair, this government inherited from the Sarkozy administration \xe2\x80\x94 the voters seemed to approve. One poll showed that three-quarters of the electorate was ready to go along with the proposal to cut taxes for companies if that would create more jobs.'b'The details of this major economic initiative were slated to be presented by the president at a press conference last Tuesday. Four days earlier, Closer struck. So what would Mr. Hollande do? At a packed press conference in the Salle des F\xc3\xaates at the \xc3\x89lys\xc3\xa9e, he switched from \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Normal\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Solemn,\xe2\x80\x9d acknowledged \xe2\x80\x9cpainful\xe2\x80\x9d moments in his private life but managed to elude six mild questions about it, and focused firmly on his plans for an economic turnaround. Which is not really a turnaround, we are told, but rather an \xe2\x80\x9cacceleration.\xe2\x80\x9d This president is not for turning; he does zigzags better.'b'Who is Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande? In a book out just last week in France aptly entitled \xe2\x80\x9cJusqu\xe2\x80\x99ici tout va mal\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cSo far, so bad\xe2\x80\x9d), the political reporter C\xc3\xa9cile Amar, who has covered Mr. Hollande for 10 years, points out that his son Thomas describes his father as \xe2\x80\x9celusive.\xe2\x80\x9d She also quotes a revealing answer the president made in May 2013, when asked whether he was a social-democratic reformer, as opposed to a classic socialist: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are asking me to say who I am. This is a tough question!\xe2\x80\x9d At last week\xe2\x80\x99s press conference, he finally came out, proclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a social democrat.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In one area, though, Mr. Hollande has shown decisiveness. Last year he chose to send troops to Mali when radical Islamists threatened to take over the capital, Bamako. And in December he again decided to intervene, under a United Nations mandate, to halt massacres in the Central African Republic.'b'People who have known Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande for a long time are amazed by his self-confidence and resilience. He is a man, they say, who even when in deep trouble always thinks that there is a way out. It is quite possible that he will again find a way out of this very public private crisis. There is no doubt that his image and personal credibility have suffered, but so far reactions to his press conference show that people have chosen not to be distracted from the work to be done on the economy.'b'I was Le Monde\xe2\x80\x99s correspondent in the United States during the Monica Lewinsky affair. It was a fantastic political story that kept us busy for a year. French readers loved it, as everywhere else. That year, in 1998, a little-known terrorist organization, Al Qaeda, headed by a little-known ex-mujahedeen, Osama bin Laden, attacked two United States embassies in Africa, but all eyes were turned on Washington\xe2\x80\x99s sordid battle. Don\xe2\x80\x99t blame the French for giving economic reforms priority over their politicians\xe2\x80\x99 pathetic private travails.'b''b'\n'b'Sylvie Kauffmann 'b' is the editorial director and a former editor in chief of Le Monde. 'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Critics Voice Objections to MoMA\xe2\x80\x99s Plan to Take Down Folk Art Museum'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Arts pages, Jan. 9):'b'The American Folk Art Museum in New York has one of the foremost folk art collections in the world. Three years ago, after the New York arts community failed to rescue the financially troubled museum, its magnificent building on West 53rd Street, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, was sold to its next-door neighbor, MoMA. In order to downsize and survive, the Folk Art Museum moved to modest, affordable and somewhat inadequate quarters on the West Side of Manhattan.'b'Now MoMA has decided to demolish the Folk Art Museum building and use the site as part of a seemingly pretentious and commercially driven plan to expand MoMA. Apparently that decision is irreversible. The American Folk Art building, particularly its facade, has been acclaimed by renowned architects and designers as an aesthetic gem, a brilliant and monumental work of art. Demolishing it is a cultural atrocity.'b'For not using their wealth, imagination, financial stamina and planning savvy to save the building, MoMA, New York\xe2\x80\x99s political leaders and arts-supporting philanthropists (many of whom buy multimillion-dollar works of art at the drop of a gavel) should collectively hang their heads in shame.'b'JULES L. It was 'b'one of the first of its kind 'b' \xe2\x80\x93 and there are now 'b'hundreds 'b' of treatment programs throughout China and 'b'South Korea'b'. (The first inpatient Internet addiction program in the United States recently 'b'opened in Pennsylvania'b'.)'b'The program featured in this video admits teenagers, usually male, whose parents typically take them there against their will. Once inside, the children are kept behind bars and guarded by soldiers. Treatment, which often lasts three to four months, includes medication and therapy, and sometimes includes parents. Patients undergo military-inspired physical training, and their sleep and diet are carefully regulated. These techniques (some of which are also used in China 'b'to treat other behavioral disorders'b') are intended to help the patients reconnect with reality.'b'Yet after four months of filming in this center (for our documentary \xe2\x80\x9cWeb Junkie\xe2\x80\x9d), some vital questions remained: Are the children being accurately evaluated? And is the treatment effective? In many cases, it seemed parents were blaming the Internet for complex social and behavioral issues that may defy such interventions. (For example, we noticed that some patients experienced difficult family relationships, social introversion and a lack of friends in the physical world.) Tao Ran, the center\xe2\x80\x99s director, claims a 70 percent success rate. If that\xe2\x80\x99s true, perhaps China\xe2\x80\x99s treatment model is something other nations should embrace, however disturbing it may seem to outsiders. There is still no real global consensus among experts about what constitutes addiction to the Internet, and whether the concept even exists, particularly in a strict medical sense.'b'What is clear is that this issue is not confined to China. With millions (if not billions) glued to screens and electronic devices, the overuse of technology is becoming a universal, transnational concern. While treatment methods may vary, one way or another, we will need to find effective ways to moderate our use of technology and provide help to those who need it.'b''b'This video is part of a series produced by independent filmmakers who have received support from the nonprofit Sundance Institute.'b''b'LOS ANGELES \xe2\x80\x94 IN 2009, I wrote a cover story for Wired magazine about the anti-vaccine movement and profiled Paul Offit, a leading proponent of vaccines for children. Dr. Offit is a man. I am a woman. That was sufficient grounds for things to get ugly.'b'In online comments and over email, I was called a prostitute and the C-word. J. B. Handley, a critic of childhood vaccination and the founder of the autism group Generation Rescue, affiliated with the actress Jenny McCarthy, sent me an essay titled, \xe2\x80\x9cPaul Offit Rapes (intellectually) Amy Wallace and Wired Magazine.\xe2\x80\x9d In it, he implied that my subject had slipped me a date-rape drug. Later, an anti-vaccine website Photoshopped my head onto the body of a woman in a strapless dress who sat next to Dr. Offit at a festive dinner table. The main course? A human baby.'b'I thought of this early this month, when I saw another Photoshop hack job. An advocacy group called Food Democracy Now was displeased by 'b'an article'b' in The New York Times about public hearings regarding a proposed ban on genetically modified organisms on Hawaii Island; the article pointed out that many of the anti-G.M.O. arguments ignored science. In response, FDN cut off the head of the article\xe2\x80\x99s author, Amy Harmon, and pasted it atop an image of a woman in a leopard-skin bathing suit.'b''b'The image'b', posted on FDN\xe2\x80\x99s Facebook page, showed a smiling Ms. Harmon on the beach, holding hands with the chief executive of Monsanto, the biotech and seed company. \xe2\x80\x9cNew York Times writer Amy Harmon travels to Hawaii ... falls in 'b'love'b' with GMOs,\xe2\x80\x9d the caption said.'b'Not long afterward, one commenter wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cEvil Bitchweed.\xe2\x80\x9d Another taunted, \xe2\x80\x9cHey Amy ... C U Next Tuesday,\xe2\x80\x9d an evocation of that C-word, again. When some commenters complained that the image of Ms. Harmon was inconsonant with the values of a group espousing progressive activism, FDN defended it as \xe2\x80\x9csatire, not sexism.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So a few journalists get heckled, you may be thinking. Why should we care? Here\xe2\x80\x99s why: This kind of vitriol is not designed to hold reporters accountable for the fairness and accuracy of their work. Instead, it seeks to intimidate and, ultimately, to silence female journalists who write about controversial topics. As often as not, even if they\xe2\x80\x99ve won two Pulitzers, as Ms. Harmon has, these women find their bodies \xe2\x80\x94 not their intellects \xe2\x80\x94 under attack.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I first saw it, I felt a flush of embarrassment \xe2\x80\x94 even though it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really my body, or my bathing suit,\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Harmon told me. She said colleagues of both genders commiserated. Many had received their own hate mail in the past: death threats, for example, or anti-Semitic missives. But for the men, at least, their bodies weren\xe2\x80\x99t part of the conversation. The FDN attack, Ms. Harmon said, was \xe2\x80\x9ca kind of visual shorthand that can\xe2\x80\x99t really be used in the same way to dismiss or demean a male reporter.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe intention is \xe2\x80\x98Shut up!\xe2\x80\x99 and it has a chilling effect,\xe2\x80\x9d says Joanna Pearlstein, deputy managing editor at Wired.
