It\xe2\x80\x99s a message the European Commission, which is debating whether to temper its clean energy goals, would do well to heed.'b'The commission is considering making renewable-energy targets nonbinding on individual nations, opting for less-onerous Europe-wide targets. It will announce its plan for Europe\xe2\x80\x99s renewable energy targets on Jan. 22.'b'Last October, the chief executives of 10 European energy companies urged the European Union to end subsidies for wind and solar power, claiming these have distorted the market, led to higher energy costs and put Europe\xe2\x80\x99s electricity grid at risk of a blackout. This was dreadful advice. Economic decisions have already caused a decline in investment in renewable energy in Europe. Investment fell in Spain, France, Italy and Germany in 2013, and only Britain managed to come close to matching 2012 investment levels in 2013. Worldwide, clean-energy investment fell 12 percent last year.'b'Binding targets have helped Europe become a global leader in reducing greenhouse gases. It is already nearing its target of reducing 1990-level greenhouse gas emissions by 20 percent by 2020. The European Commission is likely now to propose reducing greenhouse-gas emissions by 35 percent to 40 percent by 2030, and increasing the share of renewable energy to up to 27 percent. But these ambitious goals will not be met without continued incentives for renewable energy, the strongest of which are binding targets that individual countries cannot evade.'b'The United Nations report is clear: However hard it may be to move to renewable energy, it pales in comparison with the cost of not moving aggressively to reduce emissions. At current rates, carbon dioxide levels, now over 400 parts per million, will surpass 500 parts per million in a few decades, with devastating climate-change consequences.'b'The European Commission must not allow economic arguments from utility companies or individual governments to deter it from giving Europe the clearest possible blueprint for a renewable-energy future. The world cannot afford to have Europe abdicate its leading role on climate change now.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 DESPITE the last-minute diplomatic row over the cancellation of the United Nations\xe2\x80\x99 invitation to Iran, the \xe2\x80\x9cGeneva II\xe2\x80\x9d peace talks between the government of Bashar al-Assad and the Syrian opposition are scheduled to start today, with support from NATO members and Russia. But the process faces daunting challenges.'b'What is the likelihood of the Assad regime\xe2\x80\x99s negotiating its own departure, given its improved military position? And to what extent can opposition representatives act for the fragmented, even rival, forces fighting in Syria?'b'Since the beginning of the Syrian civil war, many observers have drawn parallels between Syria and Bosnia. The Geneva II talks echo efforts to resolve the conflict in the Balkans 20 years ago.'b'What are the lessons? If there is a general one from Bosnia for the parties meeting in Switzerland, it is the need for humility. As determined as the international community may be to resolve conflict, civil war is extraordinarily resistant to outside intervention. This has three important implications.'b'The first is that peace initiatives are often an unreliable lens through which to view a conflict. There is a tendency to assume that facts on the ground in places like Bosnia or Syria are primarily controlled by strategies and timetables devised by foreigners. They are not.'b'Conflict is embedded in the environment; peace plans come and go. The Dayton Accords that ended fighting in Bosnia in 1995 were preceded by four fruitless peace initiatives; the conflict in Syria has already generated its share.'b'Equally crucial is that we ask how our own efforts may interfere with conflict. In Bosnia in 1993, the effect of the unsuccessful Vance-Owen Peace Plan, which proposed new political entities divided along ethnic lines, was to intensify campaigns of ethnic cleansing as warring groups tried to strengthen their positions ahead of partition. We should expect plans discussed in Switzerland to have a similar impact in Syria. This may be unavoidable, but we may be able to predict how the pattern of violence will evolve and allocate resources better to meet humanitarian needs.'b'A second implication is the need to grasp the larger regional picture \xe2\x80\x94 as the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, showed during the diplomatic surge that led to Dayton. He secured the support of his European partners and Russia, and he brought the leaders of Bosnia\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors, Croatia and Yugoslavia (now Serbia), into the process.'b'The Dayton agreement was far from perfect, as Bosnia\xe2\x80\x99s current problems reveal, but Mr. Holbrooke\xe2\x80\x99s strategy did succeed in creating the conditions required to enforce a settlement. Russia, together with both the European Union and individual member states, played crucial roles in implementing Dayton, and the international community was able to rely on cooperation from Croatia and Serbia to help manage developments in Bosnia. This suggests that the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s effort to support the Geneva talks as part of a broad coalition that includes Russia is the right strategy \xe2\x80\x94 even if Iran\xe2\x80\x99s absence from the table proves a limiting factor.'b'Finally, Bosnia teaches us that war does not end when the weapons are put down. As the military theorist Carl von Clausewitz noted: \xe2\x80\x9cThe ultimate outcome of a war is not always to be regarded as final. The defeated state often considers the outcome merely as a transitory evil, for which a remedy may still be found in political conditions at some later date.\xe2\x80\x9d The experience of Bosnia is that wartime elites continue to pursue belligerent objectives even after the cessation of hostilities.'b'Instead of focusing exclusively on ending violence in the near term, negotiators should see any peace deal for Syria as a moment of transition when parties define the institutional and legal parameters under which they will pursue a conflict no longer under arms. Factions will not abandon their larger aspirations at the negotiating table. Diplomacy\xe2\x80\x99s power to steer conflict lies largely in its ability to shape future behavior through electoral and constitutional engineering.'b'The international community\xe2\x80\x99s undertaking to end Syria\xe2\x80\x99s civil war is highly ambitious. Even if Geneva II is successful in ending violence, foreign powers must expect that, as in Bosnia, some factions will seek to undermine the fragile settlement by other means. Insurgency is not a purely military phenomenon.'b'Our diplomacy must therefore be resilient, patient and humble as it guides the warring parties away from open strife. Winning the peace is never a short-term endeavor.'b''b'WHO\xe2\x80\x99s role in the Syrian crisis 'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Syria\xe2\x80\x99s raging health crisis'b'\xe2\x80\x9d by Adam P. Coutts and Fouad M. Fouad (Jan. 2): Although this opinion column spelled out the World Health Organization\xe2\x80\x99s apparent willingness to go along with the Assad government\xe2\x80\x99s obstruction of vaccination coverage in Deir al-Zour Province, there is nothing new in the acquiescent role that the World Health Organization seems to have played there. WHO representatives typically sit in a country\xe2\x80\x99s Health Ministry and are to a large extent a creature of the government; they are not prone to rocking the boat over health coverage issues. Over 20 years in dozens of countries, I saw WHO representatives sit tight and say nothing about cholera outbreaks and abysmal vaccination levels, fearful that the host government would be angered.'b'Contrary to what this article suggests, not all United Nations agencies are timid about risking the wrath of the host government if the facts justify it. The WHO shies away for a simple reason. Its director general is put in office by a vote of the world\xe2\x80\x99s health ministers. A director general looking for a smooth incumbency won\xe2\x80\x99t want his people on the ground to upset the electors.'b''b'Richard Reid, Istanbul'b''b'The writer directed Unicef\xe2\x80\x99s Middle East/North Africa region from 1986 to 1991, and its Former Soviet Republics Region from 1993 to 1995.'b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Pressing the fight against polio'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Eradicating polio everywhere'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Editorial, Jan. 15): I was dismayed to read that over the past year the number of new cases of polio and the number of countries in which they were reported has doubled. I am old enough to recall the years prior to the Salk and Sabin vaccines, when parents dreaded the possibility of epidemics of this disease, with its risk of severe and permanent paralysis. In my professional life I have also treated hundreds of such patients. The new outbreaks of this infection, which was close to being totally eradicated, are a reflection of local political instability in Africa, the Middle East and South Asia. The poliomyelitis virus does not distinguish between tribes, religious affiliations or political parties, and in order to prevent its further spread the involved nations need to rise above their differences. Polio should, like smallpox, become a part of mankind\xe2\x80\x99s past history.'b''b'Stanley F. Wainapel, New York 'b''b'The writer is Clinical Director of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at the Montefiore Medical Center.'b'The outstanding success of India\xe2\x80\x99s polio eradication stems from the untiring efforts of a committed government. These include the running of extensive awareness campaigns throughout the country, especially in rural areas where more than half of the target group lives, and the implementation of a nationwide program through which every child below the age of 5 receives two drops of the vaccine on a scheduled date right at their doorstep or at a nearby facility. Maintaining an unbroken cold-chain for the heat-sensitive vaccine is a daunting task in India; specially designed ice-lined refrigerators have been used to maintain the potency of the vaccine. Surely other countries could benefit from India\xe2\x80\x99s rich experience in this field.'b''b'Harish Chandran, Chennai, India'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Okinawans and the burden of bases'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Another step forward on Okinawa'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 7): Your editorial downplays the nature and reasons for Okinawans\xe2\x80\x99 opposition to the American military bases, as well as the significance, for the prefecture, of Governor Hirokazu Nakaima\xe2\x80\x99s decision to approve a landfill permit that will lead to a new base.'b'American military installations take up about 19 percent of Okinawa\xe2\x80\x99s main island. Many of these bases operate in the middle of heavily populated cities, and Okinawans are subjected to difficult living conditions: extraordinary noise pollution and a constant fear of military-related accidents, among other things.'b'The construction of the new base comes amid a raft of yet-unfulfilled promises over the years by Japanese and American governments to reduce the burden on Okinawans. 'b''b'The writer is assistant professor of history and international studies at the University of Richmond.'b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Putting the logic of 1914 to rest'b''b'As we commemorate the 100th anniversary of the outbreak of World War I, one basic question must be asked: Can 1914 repeat itself?'b'Every day we hear about wars being waged in nations from Central Africa to Central Asia. But this is only part of the picture. Basic thinking on international relations has changed dramatically in a century. While some nations still practice realpolitik, for many governments the personal well-being of the citizen is now the foundation of foreign policy. In Europe, we had a revolution in foreign affairs that replaced power politics with welfare thinking; a logic of war with a logic of values; a foreign policy based on the power of the state to serve the citizen.'b'After the terrible suffering of both world wars, the drive to build a welfare state, pioneered in Europe, is now the basis for legitimacy in international relations. While sovereignty remains important in relations between nations, ensuring the personal welfare of the individual citizen is the primary goal. The venues for this welfare-oriented foreign policy include international conferences, involving new classes of players, stakeholders like NGOs, the media and multinational companies. This has led to the globalization of the concept of human security and pushed a new social model onto the world stage.'b'The United Nations best embodies this transformation, with its special mandates in development, trade, the environment and the welfare of children. And since 1949 the Council of Europe has worked to help build a new international order; for the first time in history, citizens of the council\xe2\x80\x99s member states were granted the legal basis for pursuing their rights before an international body, the European Court of Human Rights. This is perhaps the most striking example of how the welfare of the citizen has superseded the power of the state.'b'War, in this context, has been rendered unthinkable to Europeans. For most of us in the West, when we discuss security, we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about social security and pension funds. While America may take an independent, traditional view on security issues, and go to war to defend its national interests, Europeans participate in military operations as international peacekeepers, in which the mission of the soldier is not about his country\xe2\x80\x99s foreign policy. American elections are won or lost by the promise to \xe2\x80\x9cmake America strong again\xe2\x80\x9d; in Austria and other European countries, elections are won by those who promise to develop the welfare state even further.'b'To be sure, with the United States the only remaining superpower, able to conduct its foreign policy in the classical sense, waging war and concluding peace at its discretion, power politics has not disappeared. Arms spending, the international weapons trade and the various current wars suggest that many countries remain determined to follow the realpolitik course to national glory. So we live in a very divided world.'b'Many countries still wage war at will. But many others live in a post-Westphalian world, dominated by the aspirations of millions to improve their daily lives. For these citizens, going to war again like in 1914 is simply not possible.'b''b'Wendelin Ettmayer, Vienna'b''b'The writer is a former Austrian ambassador to Finland, Canada and the Council of Europe.'b'ITHACA, N.Y. \xe2\x80\x94 Will China achieve technological dominance over the United States, surpassing us in scientific and engineering innovation?'b'A lot of people seem to think so. China\xe2\x80\x99s recent landing of an unmanned spacecraft on the Moon, its advances in renewable energies and high-speed rail, its increasing number of patent filings and its vast spending on research and development have contributed to a perception \xe2\x80\x94 held across much of the world, according to a Pew Research Center poll conducted last summer \xe2\x80\x94 that China is poised to overtake America as the world\xe2\x80\x99s leading power, if it hasn\xe2\x80\x99t already done so.'b'Concern that China \xe2\x80\x94 home of landmark innovations like printing and gunpowder \xe2\x80\x94 might reclaim its legacy as a land of invention is voiced at even the highest levels of the American government. In 2011, Steven Chu, the energy secretary at the time and a Nobel-winning physicist, remarked on China\xe2\x80\x99s dominance in the production of low-cost solar-energy cells, urging, \xe2\x80\x9cWe really can and should take back this technology lead.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Americans shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be so worried. Yes, China has demonstrated skill in moving to higher-value manufacturing, and excelled at improving existing technologies, while producing them more cheaply. But it has not excelled in true innovation. (The first modern solar cell was invented in the United States.)'b'No one knows this better than the Chinese themselves. Before he stepped down as president in 2012, Hu Jintao directed that vast sums be spent on supporting scientific innovation to \xe2\x80\x9cachieve the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But as a scientist who has taught in China, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe that China will lead in innovation anytime soon \xe2\x80\x94 or at least not until it moves its institutional culture away from suppression of dissent and toward freedom of expression and encouragement of critical thought.'b'Almost all the paradigm-shifting innovations over the past few hundred years \xe2\x80\x94 from Michael Faraday\xe2\x80\x99s generating electricity by moving a copper wire through a magnetic field in London in 1831 to the invention of the transistor at Bell Laboratories in New Jersey in the 1940s \xe2\x80\x94 have emerged in countries with relatively high levels of political and intellectual liberty. Why is this?'b'A first reason is cultural: Free societies encourage people to be skeptical and ask critical questions. When I was teaching at a university in Beijing in 2009, my students acknowledged that I frequently asked if they had any questions \xe2\x80\x94 and that they rarely did. After my last lecture, at their insistence, we discussed the reasons for their reticence.'b'Several students pointed out that, from childhood, they were not encouraged to ask questions. I knew that the Cultural Revolution had upturned higher education \xe2\x80\x94 and intellectual inquiry generally \xe2\x80\x94 during their parents\xe2\x80\x99 lifetimes, but as a guest I didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to get into a political discussion. Instead, I gently pointed out to my students that they were planning to be scientists, and that skepticism and critical questioning were essential for separating the wheat from the chaff in all scholarly endeavors.'b'A second reason is institutional: Much of American innovation started with the bright ideas of a few individuals, working in an industrial, government or university laboratory, or perhaps a garage in Silicon Valley. While government support for R&amp;D is essential, innovation is typically the product of a bottom-up approach. A classic example is the letter Albert Einstein wrote to President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1939, arguing that nuclear fission could be the basis of a powerful bomb, which led to the Manhattan Project.'b'In 2006, I led a group of scientists from Cornell to discuss possible collaborations on nanotechnology with colleagues at Tsinghua University in Beijing and Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Over meals, Chinese colleagues told me that scientific research was initiated in a top-down manner.'b'A third reason is political. Free societies attract foreign talent. England gave birth to the steam engine in the 18th century in part because of Denis Papin, a Huguenot who had fled France for greater religious tolerance in England. His idea of using steam and atmospheric pressure to do work, taken up by Thomas Newcomen and James Watt, powered the first Industrial Revolution.'b'During a trip to China last fall, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help but notice not only the lack of access to several Western news sources, but also the cynicism about the news in general. Those \xe2\x80\x9cin the know\xe2\x80\x9d distrusted what they were told by state news agencies like Xinhua and CCTV.'b'The case of Xia Yeliang, an associate professor of economics at Peking University, who was dismissed, supposedly for speaking out against one party rule, does not inspire confidence in academic freedom.'b'While in Beijing, my wife and I visited the 798 art district in the city\xe2\x80\x99s northeast. During our stroll of galleries and studios, I asked about the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei, whom we had met in Berkeley, Calif., in 2008. The woman I spoke with said that it was too dangerous to try to visit him, because there were so many police around his compound.'b'The significance of China\xe2\x80\x99s vast spending on R&amp;D cannot be overstated, particularly at a time when the United States has made short-sighted cuts to the budgets of the National Institutes of Health, the National Science Foundation and other agencies that finance research.'b'Perhaps I\xe2\x80\x99m wrong that political freedom is critical for scientific innovation. As a scientist, I have to be skeptical of my own conclusions. But sometime in this still-new century, we will see the results of this unfolding experiment. At the moment, I\xe2\x80\x99d still bet on America.'b''b' 'b'Stephen L. Sass,'b' professor emeritus of materials science and engineering at Cornell University, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Substance of Civilization: Materials and Human History from the Stone Age to the Age of Silicon.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'The Syria peace conference gets off to a bad start.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Asbestos Scam, Part 2'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Joe Nocera (column, Jan. 14), is an excellent explanation of the continuing fraud in asbestos litigation and why it hurts future asbestos victims, innocent companies and their employees, and the integrity of the American judicial system.'b'Companies have fought hard to expose this fraud but have found few listeners. Judge George Hodges, a federal bankruptcy judge, deserves credit for not accepting business as usual by allowing attorneys for Garlock Sealing Technologies to get access to asbestos bankruptcy trust records. Better yet, the Senate should take up the 'b'Furthering Asbestos Claim Transparency Act'b', passed by the House, which would require asbestos bankruptcy trusts to divulge information on all claims and prevent the kinds of \xe2\x80\x9cimpropriety\xe2\x80\x9d that Judge Hodges uncovered.'b'Plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 attorneys have lobbied hard to keep bankruptcy trust claims secret. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Administration Is Seen as Retreating on Environment in Talks on Pacific Trade'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 15):'b'While the article dismisses the environmental side agreement in the North American Free Trade Agreement as \xe2\x80\x9conly appendices,\xe2\x80\x9d the agreement has resulted in two decades of cooperation to raise environmental standards and practices, the latest example being nearly half a million dollars\xe2\x80\x99 worth of grants from the Environmental Protection Agency for environmental projects on both sides of the United States-Mexico border.'b'What made Nafta distinctive was an emphasis on partnership \xe2\x80\x94 rather than trade sanctions \xe2\x80\x94 to raise environmental standards. This integrated approach is highly cost-effective over a traditional removal and reconstruction in the operating room.'b'Mohs surgery exemplifies how medicine will be practiced in the future: It will be safe, effective, highly specialized and patient-centered.'b'SCOTT W. Now I hurt all over just thinking about my next visit to a doctor. Thanks a bunch for messing up my day.'b'KIRK NEVIN'b'\nCorvallis, Ore., Jan. 19, 2014'b''b'The relatively new notion that around a third or more of the world\xe2\x80\x99s population is badly (\xe2\x80\x9cmal\xe2\x80\x9d) nourished conflates hunger and diet-spawned illnesses like diabetes, both of which are preventable.'b'Both result from a lack of access to quality food, which in turn can result from a lack of money. No one with money starves, and the obesity-diabetes epidemic afflicts predominantly people on the low end of the income scale. With money comes good food, food that creates health and not \xe2\x80\x9cillth,\xe2\x80\x9d to use John Ruskin\xe2\x80\x99s word. With a lack of money comes either not enough food or so-called empty calories, calories that put on pounds but do not nourish.'b'This is made very clear in Oxfam\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGood Enough to Eat\xe2\x80\x9d'b' index, a snapshot of the state of eating in 125 countries released last week. The index attempts to determine the best and worst countries in which to eat, by measuring levels of undernourishment and underweight in children; asking \xe2\x80\x9cdo people have enough to eat?\xe2\x80\x9d; measuring costs of food versus other goods and services, to see whether food is affordable; looking at the diversity of people\xe2\x80\x99s diets and the availability of safe water; and monitoring diabetes and obesity levels to learn whether the diets are healthy.'b'The results for the United States make a fine case for American exceptionalism, though not in the way chauvinists will find pleasing.'b'We rank first in food affordability; food is cheap compared with other things we buy, and prices are relatively stable. We also rank highly (4th) in food \xe2\x80\x9cquality,\xe2\x80\x9d which is measured by (potential) diversity of diet, though access to good water is shockingly low (tied for 41st, about a third of the way down the list).'b'Then the hammer falls: When it comes to healthy eating as measured by diabetes and obesity rates, we\xe2\x80\x99re 120th: sixth from the bottom, better off only than Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Jordan, Fiji and our unlucky neighbor Mexico. (Canada fares a little better; it\xe2\x80\x99s 18th worst.) We\xe2\x80\x99re also in a tie (with Belarus and other powerhouses) for 35th in \xe2\x80\x9cenough to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d Really.'b'In fact, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine having a food supply as abundant as ours and doing a worse job with it. There are reasons for this:'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 Much of what\xe2\x80\x99s grown with the potential to become \xe2\x80\x9cfood\xe2\x80\x9d is actually turned into (as Michael Pollan dubbed them) 'b'edible foodlike substances'b' \xe2\x80\x94 in short, junk food \xe2\x80\x94 that produces the opposite of health. (About this there can barely be an argument any longer.) Some of what we grow is also turned into fuel for automobiles, doing no one but corn farmers any good. And much of it is fed to animals, in itself not a terrible thing, although the way we do it is damaging on many fronts.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 While we generally manage to keep the neediest quarter of our population from actually starving, we do not reach everyone who could use help; for example, only half of those Californians eligible for food stamps (officially known as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) actually get them, according to 'b'Roots of Change'b', a California nonprofit that focuses on food. And, of course, food stamps can be and often are used 'b'to buy junk'b', a pattern that causes as many problems as it alleviates.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 The budget for food education in the United States pales compared with the marketing budget for junk food, and much of that education is either unconvincing or ignored in the face of the barrage of \xe2\x80\x9cfun to eat\xe2\x80\x9d ads for the food that is worst for us. (These 'b'three charts,'b' gathered in one place by Tom Philpott, pretty much tell the story.) There is, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve complained before, no concerted effort to teach people how to cook, which cannot happen without simultaneously teaching people how to shop for real food.'b'There are also issues of economic justice and education, and all their complications, which is why talking about food and eating inevitably leads to talking about the structure of society.'b'Part of the problem lies in oversight. Although we have a first lady who cares about these issues (and presumably has the support of the president), we do not have an official government policy or agency responsible for coordinating and assuring that the nation\xe2\x80\x99s investment in food and agriculture is for a nourishing and healthful food supply. The Department of Agriculture partly fills that role, but it also has a clear conflict of interest, since its primary goal is to support what has become a system of industrial agriculture that cares more about production and marketing supports than about what happens to soil, water and air, or the health of consumers who buy its products. (One need look only at budgets to determine what any individual or agency cares about most.)'b'In the long run, what\xe2\x80\x99s needed is not a Farm Bill \xe2\x80\x94 that tangled mess that\xe2\x80\x99s been stalled in Congress since its expiration in 2012 \xe2\x80\x94 but a national food and health policy, one that sets goals 'b'first 'b'for healthful eating and only then determines how best to produce the food that will allow us to meet those goals. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make sense to tell people to eat vegetables and then produce junk; that leads only to bad health in the face of evident abundance. What\xe2\x80\x99s so great about that?'b'In the 1970s, I got both my bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s and master\xe2\x80\x99s degrees in modern Middle East studies, and I can assure you that at no time did environmental or climate issues appear anywhere in the syllabi of my courses. Today, you can\xe2\x80\x99t understand the Arab awakenings \xe2\x80\x94 or their solutions \xe2\x80\x94 without considering climate, environment and population stresses.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve been reporting on the connection between the Syrian drought and the uprising there for a Showtime documentary that will air in April, but recently our researchers came across a WikiLeaks cable that brilliantly foreshadowed how environmental stresses would fuel the uprising. Sent on Nov. 8, 2008, from the U.S. Embassy in Damascus to the State Department, the cable details how, in light of what was a devastating Syrian drought \xe2\x80\x94 it lasted from 2006-10 \xe2\x80\x94 Syria\xe2\x80\x99s U.N. food and agriculture representative, Abdullah bin Yehia, was seeking drought assistance from the U.N. and wanted the U.S. to contribute. Here are some key lines:'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 \xe2\x80\x9cThe U.N. Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs launched an appeal on September 29 requesting roughly $20.23 million to\xc2\xa0assist an estimated\xc2\xa0one million people impacted by what the U.N. describes\xc2\xa0as\xc2\xa0the country\xe2\x80\x99s worst drought in four decades.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 \xe2\x80\x9cYehia proposes to use money from the appeal to provide seed\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0technical assistance to 15,000 small-holding farmers in northeast Syria in an effort to preserve the\xc2\xa0social\xc2\xa0and economic\xc2\xa0fabric of this rural, agricultural community. If UNFAO efforts fail, Yehia predicts mass migration from the northeast, which could act as a multiplier on social and economic pressures already at play and undermine stability.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 \xe2\x80\x9cYehia does not believe that the [government of Bashar al-Assad] will allow any Syrian citizen to starve. ... However, Yehia told us that the Syrian minister of agriculture ... stated publicly that economic\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0social\xc2\xa0fallout from the drought was \xe2\x80\x98beyond our capacity as\xc2\xa0a country to deal with.\xe2\x80\x99 What the U.N. is trying to combat through this appeal, Yehia says, is the potential for \xe2\x80\x98social destruction\xe2\x80\x99 that would accompany erosion of the agricultural industry in rural Syria. This\xc2\xa0social\xc2\xa0destruction would lead to political instability.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 \xe2\x80\x9cWithout direct assistance, Yehia predicts that most of these 15,000 small-holding farmers would be forced to depart Al Hasakah Province to seek work in larger cities in western Syria. Approximately 100,000 dependents \xe2\x80\x94 women, children\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0the elderly or infirm \xe2\x80\x94 would be left behind to live in poverty, he said. Children would be likely to be pulled from school, he warned, in order to seek a source of income for families left behind. In addition, the migration of 15,000 unskilled laborers would add to the\xc2\xa0social\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0economic pressures presently at play in major Syrian cities. A system already burdened by a large Iraqi refugee population may not be able to absorb another influx of displaced persons, Yehia explained, particularly at this time of rising costs, growing dissatisfaction of the middle class,\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0a perceived weakening of the\xc2\xa0social fabric and\xc2\xa0security structures\xc2\xa0that Syrians have come to expect\xc2\xa0and \xe2\x80\x94 in some cases \xe2\x80\x94 rely\xc2\xa0on.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yehia was prophetic. By 2010, roughly one million Syrian farmers, herders and their families were forced off the land into already overpopulated and underserved cities. These climate refugees were crowded together with one million Iraqi war refugees. The Assad regime failed to effectively help any of them, so when the Arab awakenings erupted in Tunisia and Egypt, Syrian democrats followed suit and quickly found many willing recruits from all those dislocated by the drought.'b'But also consider this: Last May 9, The Times of Israel quoted Israeli geographer Arnon Soffer as observing that in the past 60 years, the population in the Middle East has twice doubled. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no example of this anywhere else on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And this: Last March, the International Journal of Climatology published a study, \xe2\x80\x9cChanges in extreme temperature and precipitation in the Arab region,\xe2\x80\x9d that found \xe2\x80\x9cconsistent warming trends since the middle of the 20th century across the region,\xe2\x80\x9d manifested in \xe2\x80\x9cincreasing frequencies of warm nights, fewer cool days and cool nights.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And then consider this: Syria\xe2\x80\x99s government couldn\xe2\x80\x99t respond to a prolonged drought 'b'when there was a Syrian government'b'. So imagine what could happen if Syria is faced by another drought after much of its infrastructure has been ravaged by civil war.'b'And, finally, consider this: \xe2\x80\x9cIn the future, who will help a country like Syria when it gets devastated by its next drought if we are in a world where everyone is dealing with something like a Superstorm Sandy,\xe2\x80\x9d which alone cost the U.S. $60 billion to clean up? asks Joe Romm, founder of 'b'ClimateProgress.org'b'.'b'So to Iran and Saudi Arabia, who are funding the proxy war in Syria between Sunnis and Shiites/Alawites, all I can say is that you\xe2\x80\x99re fighting for control of a potential human/ecological disaster zone. You need to be working together to rebuild Syria\xe2\x80\x99s resiliency, and its commons, not destroying it. I know that in saying this I am shouting into a dust storm. But there is nothing else worth saying.'b'Sarah, the subject of this Op-Doc video, lives in a rural town in western Missouri. She is in 10th grade. For generations almost no one in Sarah\xe2\x80\x99s family has finished high school. Sarah vows that she does not want to follow in those footsteps. But how will her life be different? She became pregnant at 15. Her son will be born in February.'b'Sarah has six siblings. Her father is estranged from the family and does not contribute financially. Sarah\xe2\x80\x99s mother, Dena Jewell Simental, is often away from home, cleaning houses and caring for the disabled. Supporting her seven children is Dena\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctop priority,\xe2\x80\x9d she says. It\xe2\x80\x99s never easy -- when the family has received food stamps, they often haven\xe2\x80\x99t lasted till the end of the month. Sometimes, when bills go unpaid, the electricity and water are shut off or Dena\xe2\x80\x99s phone service is interrupted. But Dena is proud to say, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are a good family.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is a myth in America: if you have a strong moral compass, work hard and make good choices, you will have equal opportunity. But after two years of listening to and documenting low-income families in rural America (for our forthcoming feature-length documentary \xe2\x80\x9cRich Hill\xe2\x80\x9d), we have witnessed a starkly unequal playing field.'b'Often, there is no social safety net. When a low-income family experiences a hardship or makes a misstep, the results can be devastating. Dena\xe2\x80\x99s family is uninsured, so when Sarah and her siblings need medical care, even for something as simple as a rash, it often means a trip to the emergency room.'b'Before Sarah\xe2\x80\x99s son is even born, so much is already stacked against him. What will it take for Sarah and her son to break out of this cycle of poverty?'b''b'This video is part of a series produced by independent filmmakers who have received support from the nonprofit Sundance Institute.'b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 AMID the coverage of the Christie controversy and the latest budget deal, it was easy to miss the news about last week\xe2\x80\x99s oral arguments before the Supreme Court in the case of National Labor Relations Board v. 'b'Noel Canning'b'. And yet the Canning case represents the biggest threat to presidential power in decades, and the stakes in the decision are extremely high.'b'The case grew from a challenge by the Noel Canning Corporation to President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s recess appointment of several nominees to the N.L.R.B., along with the head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Recess appointments are not unusual, but in this case, the Senate was away but still convening pro forma sessions \xe2\x80\x94 just five minutes or so at a time \xe2\x80\x94 because the House had not given permission to adjourn.'b'The challenge began narrowly, centered on the question of whether a president or the Senate gets to decide when the legislative body is in recess. But it was broadened dramatically last year by a panel of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, which ruled that virtually all recess appointments violated the direct language of the Constitution: Only those vacancies occurring during the recess between the two sessions of Congress, and only those filled during that recess, would be allowed. Because such recesses are very brief, the odds of a significant vacancy opening up during them are near zero.'b'The tenor of the oral argument suggested widespread skepticism by the justices about recess appointments in general, despite their frequent use by presidents for 200 years. The court might rule narrowly, simply outlawing the kinds of recess appointments made by Mr. Obama, leaving intact the accepted practices, and usual tugs of war, that have characterized nomination battles for many decades. But there is a strong chance that the Supreme Court will agree with the D.C. Circuit opinion, in essence erasing the recess appointment authority and capability of the president.'b'In the short run, this outcome would mean little. In recent years, presidents have used recess appointments to avoid Senate filibusters. But the Senate recently changed its filibuster rules, lowering the threshold for cloture on nominations from 60 to 50 (both the N.L.R.B. and C.F.P.B. slots in question were filled by Senate confirmation). With the new cloture rules, and a Democratic Senate, the president will have little difficulty filling executive and judicial vacancies.'b'But what happens when we have a president from one party and a Senate majority from the other? The justices, in the oral argument, focused on the \xe2\x80\x9coriginalist\xe2\x80\x9d fact that at the beginning of the republic, recess appointments were intended not to deal with political disputes between president and Senate but to enable presidents to fill positions when there were, as a practical matter, lengthy stretches without a Senate in session to confirm them.'b'But it is also true that at the beginning of the republic, there were no filibusters, and the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s framers believed that senators would use the \xe2\x80\x9cadvise and consent\xe2\x80\x9d power only rarely to block nominees, and even then only when senators judged them lacking in qualifications, temperament or ethical standards.'b'For most of American history, recess appointments were a safety valve for presidents when there were individual disputes over nominees, a modest weapon of the executive in the continuing struggle between the political branches.'b'The last decade or so, though, has been different. The party not holding the presidency has used the confirmation power not simply to vet presidential nominees but to veto them as a whole, regardless of qualifications, for partisan reasons, or has refused to confirm them in order to nullify laws by nullifying the agencies designated to enforce them.'b'That could be a disaster if that party controlled the Senate, where it could use its power to block nominees from even coming to a vote. In fact, the only thing that would keep a tribal party from acting to utterly foil a president from fulfilling his executive responsibilities would be the awareness that the other party would take its revenge later on.'b'Our contemporary politics make that kind of restraint unlikely. Without the possibility of a president being able to fall back on recess appointments, the temptation to foil the executive branch\xe2\x80\x99s entire agenda would be too great.'b'A president takes an oath to faithfully execute the laws; that requires having an executive branch led by presidential appointees. The inability to confirm those nominees would leave any president hamstrung to fill the most basic and core responsibilities of a chief executive.'b'To be sure, recess appointments are a limited tool, a modest safety valve to ameliorate the worst abuses of Senate power. But they are a necessary one to keep some check and balance in place. There is reason to fear that the Supreme Court will take that tool completely away \xe2\x80\x94 and make our dysfunctional politics and policy making much worse.'b'THERE\xe2\x80\x99S an old Italian saying, \xe2\x80\x9cA tavola non si invecchia,\xe2\x80\x9d which means: At the table, you don\xe2\x80\x99t grow old. All of us, of whatever age, need to socialize in public places to feel connected and alive.'b'That sense of shared conviviality was notably absent recently when 'b'police officers removed loiterers'b', many of them elderly Korean-Americans, from a McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s restaurant in Queens. The slew of comments that followed a report of the dispute were unsympathetic to those who whiled away their hours there.'b'One New York Times reader commented, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is only in the inner city that McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s and Starbucks are the gathering places for the unwashed, elderly, incompetent and infirm. I suppose this is the price for being a city dweller. These people ruin everything!\xe2\x80\x9d Others offered proposals to \xe2\x80\x9csolve\xe2\x80\x9d the problem by making the seating uncomfortable or removing it altogether, suing the elderly customers or playing blaring rap music to drive them away.'b'Older patrons may test the limits of public dawdling, but this phenomenon \xe2\x80\x94 call it loitering or community building \xe2\x80\x94 is essential for the survival of many people 65 and older. According to the last census, seniors constitute 12 percent of New York City\xe2\x80\x99s population. Many of them are single, sometimes far from family, and have lived in their localities for decades, their entire lives even. For the past four years, I have studied how neighborhood public places help older Manhattan residents avoid isolation and develop social ties that offer support, ranging from a sympathetic ear to a small emergency loan.'b'Like the teenagers who linger over sticky tabletops at Burger King and McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s, these older people have reached a time when their lives do not revolve around work and family. In the absence of those, these public places can anchor routines and provide a sense of structure and belonging.'b'A Manhattan bakery I observed had served as a de facto senior center for decades. The owner allowed customers to linger; many stopped in more than once a day. The bakery hummed with conversation: It felt more like a social club than a business, with a cup of coffee being the modest price of admission.'b'Yet the elderly are often now hindered by the loss of neighborhood places that have closed because of gentrification and rising retail rents. When that West Side bakery was shuttered, its patrons were forced to regroup in other neighborhood locales, including a nearby McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'For retirees on fixed incomes who may have difficulty walking more than a few blocks, McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s restaurants remain among the most democratic, freely accessible spaces. Much of the appeal lies in the fact that, as an elderly patron said to me, \xe2\x80\x9cyou can sit all day and nobody bothers you.\xe2\x80\x9d At the branch I observed, the tolerance for older New Yorkers also extended to the homeless, people who appeared mentally unstable and teenagers who congregated after school \xe2\x80\x94 even when they occasionally flung ice cubes at one another.'b'An afternoon at McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s opens up a world of people-watching opportunities. One elderly regular I observed sat an entire day and greeted a changing cast of passers-by, acquaintances and friends \xe2\x80\x94 a welcome alternative to sitting alone in her apartment with worsening dementia.'b'Ray Oldenburg, a professor emeritus of sociology at the University of West Florida, calls these gathering spots \xe2\x80\x9cthird places,\xe2\x80\x9d in contrast to the institutions of work and family that organize \xe2\x80\x9cfirst\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csecond\xe2\x80\x9d places. He sees bookstores, cafes and fast food joints as necessary yet endangered meeting points that foster community, often among diverse people. The Yale sociologist Elijah Anderson likens public settings such as Reading Terminal Market in Philadelphia to a \xe2\x80\x9ccosmopolitan canopy,\xe2\x80\x9d where people act with civility and converse with others to whom they might never otherwise speak.'b'The care-taking performed by such places extends to all kinds of groups. A professor of sociology at Princeton, Mitchell Duneier, has found a Chicago cafeteria that supports older working-class African-American men in this way. I have interviewed people who tell me they don\xe2\x80\x99t like senior centers because \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re depressing\xe2\x80\x9d; in these cafes, they can form emotional attachments with a wider mix of people.'b'Centers offer vital services, but McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s offers an alternative that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t segregate people from intergenerational contact. \xe2\x80\x9cI hate old people,\xe2\x80\x9d one 89-year-old man told me.'b'We should praise companies that allow loitering and devise public-private partnerships that benefit both older adults and business owners: I can imagine tax breaks for franchises that serve a high proportion of older adults and discounts to encourage patronage at off-peak hours. And we could replicate the 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCaf\xc3\xa9 Plus\xe2\x80\x9d'b' model of the Chicago nonprofit group Mather LifeWays in 30 American cities. These attractive coffee shops not only offer older customers who dislike traditional senior centers a 75-cent bottomless cup of coffee, but also welcome customers of all ages.'b'The 'b'Queens dispute has been settled'b', for now, by a compromise that allows the elderly Korean-American customers to linger, provided they vacate during the lunchtime rush. But in the looking-glass world of legal challenges to the federal government\xe2\x80\x99s terror watch lists, even people who succeed in showing that they were mistakenly included on such a list have no easy path around the walls of official secrecy and obstruction.'b'On Jan. 14, following a trial 'b'frequently conducted behind closed doors'b', a federal judge in San Francisco ruled that the Department of Homeland Security had to correct its erroneous inclusion of a Malaysian academic on the no-fly list. It is well past time to say \xe2\x80\x9cenough\xe2\x80\x9d to more civilian deaths \xe2\x80\x94 and exactly the right time for a cease-fire and secure deliveries of humanitarian supplies.'b'It is hard to imagine a country more miserable than the Central African Republic, a potentially wealthy land that for much of its short history has been looted by its presidents, emperor and warlords and battered by rebellions and sectarian wars, the latest of which has been raging since March. The European Union force is sorely needed, especially to secure the airport so that humanitarian aid can start arriving.'b'But Europe also demonstrated that it remains far from enthusiastic about international peacekeeping operations. Some major European military powers \xe2\x80\x94 Britain, Germany and Italy \xe2\x80\x94 declined to participate, and tiny Estonia took the lead by committing 55 soldiers to the force. At another meeting in Brussels, the European Union pledged nearly $500 million in humanitarian aid, while the United States announced that it would be providing nearly $30 million in additional help, on top of $15 million previously pledged.'b'Whether the money and the troops are enough to restore order in a country in \xe2\x80\x9cfree fall,\xe2\x80\x9d as the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, described it, is far from certain. So far, the foreign peacekeepers have been largely clustered in Bangui, while the far reaches of the country have been racked with violence, which has continued unabated. But at least the suffering country now has a head of state who is not part of the problem, as all her predecessors were, and the financial and military aid should at least give Ms. Samba-Panza some means and time to show that there is an alternative to chaos and violence.'b'The plight of migrant Roma squatters, harshly scapegoated and ostracized, is only getting worse in France, despite the election promises of President Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande to break with the strict policies of the past with a more humane approach. French government raids and evictions doubled last year at squatter camps, which are cobbled together out of necessity by the hard-pressed Roma, or Gypsies. Their nomadic search across Europe for economic and social opportunity worsened during the recession as local politicians stereotyped them as undeserving interlopers.'b'In France, nearly 20,000 Roma were evicted from camps last year and told to move on, most of them in the Paris region, according to investigators for the Human Rights League and the European Roma Rights Center. \xe2\x80\x9cForced evictions continued almost everywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d their report said.'b'Some nations, including Germany, Hungary and Serbia have announced special programs to help the Roma. But, so far, nothing progressive has been seen from the government of President Hollande as it maintains a hard-line policy of evictions and repatriations to Romania and Bulgaria. Mr. Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s tone was unyielding when he commented on the eviction report: \xe2\x80\x9cDo we have to be ashamed of what we have done? No.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His Socialist government\xe2\x80\x99s popular interior minister, Manuel Valls, has played to the nativist crowd in contending the Roma have little talent for adaptation in France and should be expelled. This prompted warnings from European Union officials that France must uphold its treaty commitments on human rights. But the approach from Mr. Valls, unfortunately, may play well in the French municipal elections this spring. It would be shameful for the Hollande government to pander to localized intolerance of the Roma.'b'BEIJING \xe2\x80\x94  In July 2013, two female traffic police officers in Tangshan in Hebei Province got into a fistfight and video footage of the scene went viral. The Tangshan public security bureau brushed off the incident, saying that the women were \xe2\x80\x9ctemporary traffic police officers.\xe2\x80\x9d The response was typical: Scandals in China are often blamed on lin shi gong, or \xe2\x80\x9ctemporary workers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In a much more disturbing case last July, officers of the urban management enforcement bureau beat an unlicensed watermelon vendor to death on a busy street in Linwu in Hunan Province. Following the attack, which was photographed by onlookers who circulated their pictures online, some of the assailants were dismissed by the local authorities as \xe2\x80\x9cauxiliary\xe2\x80\x9d urban management officers. Auxiliary officer is another name for a temporary worker.'b'Blaming'b' lin shi gong'b' has become so widespread in recent years that the practice has even been criticized by the government\xe2\x80\x99s own newspapers.'b'China Daily, a party newspaper, published an article in December 2010 under the headline \xe2\x80\x9cBlaming Temporary Workers?\xe2\x80\x9d declaring that \xe2\x80\x9cemployers, especially some government departments, should stop using temporary workers as an excuse to shirk their responsibilities in scandals such as forced demolition, and the government should expedite the process of improving the system of accountability to stop the abuse of power.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This temporary-worker ploy begs several questions: Who hired the workers? Whose orders were they following? Who was in charge? Did they receive adequate training before they began work?'b'Chinese businesses and government use temporary workers like much of the rest of the world to cut costs or to avoid red tape: Many are given jobs with lower pay and fewer benefits than regular staff. But whether the scapegoats are, in fact, temporary workers, or full-time staff members who are called temporary for political expediency, the logic of the situation is simple: Temporary workers are not formal government employees, so whatever goes wrong, the government need not assume responsibility.'b'In the past, the government would deny or write off its errors with outrageous lies. It claimed, for example, that the Great Famine of 1959-62 was caused by \xe2\x80\x9cthree years of natural disasters.\xe2\x80\x9d But in the Information Age, when the malfeasance of government agents is often caught on cellphone cameras and distributed online, denial is rarely an option. The government has had to find scapegoats.'b'The obsession with temporary workers is indicative of a larger failure: temporary governance.'b'In China, grandiose concepts like \xe2\x80\x9cfundamental national policies,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgoverning strategies\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cFive-Year Plan\xe2\x80\x9d appear constantly in the official media, but the government actually lacks long-term strategies or plans. Many policies, regulations and laws are shortsighted and the products of a knee-jerk approach to governance.'b'Perhaps the most damning effect of the government\xe2\x80\x99s temporary approach to governance is in the legal sphere. Mao once said, \xe2\x80\x9cAn editorial in the People\xe2\x80\x99s Daily can be carried out nationwide \xe2\x80\x94 what\xe2\x80\x99s the need for laws?\xe2\x80\x9d In the post-Mao era, the government promulgated a huge number of laws and regulations, in an effort to integrate with the rest of the world. But many of them have an obvious temporary flavor.'b'In 2007, a man in Sichuan Province was hit by a train and died. Acting in accordance with \xe2\x80\x9ctemporary regulations on handling railway accidents that involve other vehicles, as well as deaths and injury,\xe2\x80\x9d the Railways Ministry awarded his family a payment of 700 yuan (about $100), according to the Xinhua news agency. The temporary regulations were issued in 1979.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cRe-education through labor,\xe2\x80\x9d the notorious system for incarcerating people without court proceedings, is perhaps the best example. What in 1957 was supposed to be a temporary measure for punishing offenders for minor crimes stood as the law of the land for 56 years, until it was abandoned last year.'b'Three years ago a publisher used an article of mine without permission. Later I was sent a payment of 30 yuan, for 2,700 words. That payment was in accordance with the 1990 \xe2\x80\x9ctemporary regulations governing payment for authors,\xe2\x80\x9d which stipulates payment of 10 to 30 yuan per 1,000 characters. Two and a half decades after this regulation was issued, 30 yuan does not cover a taxi ride across Beijing.'b'Not only are personnel and laws often ephemeral, even government agencies are set up on a temporary basis. There are innumerable temporary \xe2\x80\x9coffices,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cleading groups\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccommittees\xe2\x80\x9d in China that have ill-defined powers, with no legal basis for operating.  Netizens have poured ridicule on peculiar government organizations like the \xe2\x80\x9cOffice for Prohibiting the Consumption of Alcohol During Lunchtime\xe2\x80\x9d in Henan Province and the \xe2\x80\x9cOffice for Immediate Action,\xe2\x80\x9d which is supposed to improve government efficiency, in Shangdong Province. The \xe2\x80\x9cOffice for Steamed-Bun Manufacturing and Marketing Management,\xe2\x80\x9d ostensibly started to regulate steamed-bun quality, was closed in 2001 after public complaints over its absurdity.'b'How effective is China\xe2\x80\x99s temporary governance? Some observers can point to the economic growth over the past 30 years as proof of Beijing\xe2\x80\x99s great achievements. But success is more than economic indicators. I am more concerned about the degrading quality of air, water and food, and about what the country\xe2\x80\x99s shaky political foundation means for the future of the country.'b'Over the past three decades, a once-blue sky has become a toxic smog, and political power has become a tool to make money and a weapon to kill. I have witnessed numerous preventable disasters, and the loss of countless lives.'b'This is the consequence of temporary governance, and the damage will be permanent. Yet no one takes responsibility for the country\xe2\x80\x99s failures because, after all, it is governed by temporary workers.'b''b'\n'b'Murong Xuecun 'b' is a novelist and blogger and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cLeave Me Alone: A Novel of Chengdu.\xe2\x80\x9d This article was translated by Jane Weizhen Pan and Martin Merz from the Chinese.'b''b'LAGOS, Nigeria \xe2\x80\x94  Growing up in my village in Nigeria, my friends and I had a favorite game. We called it Asesebhor \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cAre we there yet?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It was a game of trust. You picked a playmate to lead you to an undisclosed spot. You\xe2\x80\x99d close your eyes and, like a blind mendicant, rest both of your hands on his shoulders as he walked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAsesebhor?\xe2\x80\x9d you would keep asking. \xe2\x80\x9cAre we there yet?\xe2\x80\x9d To which he would respond, \xe2\x80\x9cEiyeh\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Others whom you passed would play along, chanting and hailing, without revealing your path or destination. When your guide stopped moving, you had arrived.'b'Often, you would open your eyes and be amused to find that you were in another part of the village. But sometimes, a rogue playmate would lead you into a bush of thorns or brush of poison ivy. So you learned to be on your guard. If your guide was in the habit of such tricks, you learned to slyly take a peek during the game. Though this ruined the fun of surprise, it kept you from getting hurt.'b'I cannot help but think that this is precisely the situation that the president of Nigeria, Goodluck Jonathan, has placed himself in now \xe2\x80\x94 playing a game of Asesebhor with the untrustworthy associates in his cabinet and in other positions of influence and power.'b'To a close observer of his administration, it is obvious that most of the ministers, special advisers, special assistants and a host of others are in his government only to bleed the country dry. And from all public indications, it would appear that our president is oblivious to their deceitful games.'b'That is the kindest interpretation I can put on Mr. Jonathan\xe2\x80\x99s inattention to the blatant corruption all around him. The alternative is that he is complicit in the corrupt actions that are clogging the wheels of progress in the country.'b'One thing is sure: Whatever trust the president stubbornly continues to hold in his cronies and kingmakers, whatever political debts they are collecting, whatever benefit he stands to reap by ignoring the deadwoods in his administration, it only hurts the ordinary Nigerians who voted him into power in 2011.'b'And whatever game he is playing with the voters\xe2\x80\x99 trust, he should stop now and systematically clean up his administration.'b'Mr. Jonathan is not incapable of making tough decisions. He recently fired five military commanders in one fell swoop, partly because of their failures in combating the Boko Haram insurgency and partly to consolidate his power in advance of next year\xe2\x80\x99s elections.'b'But in the area of corruption, the president has turned a blind eye.'b'In one recent scandal, Stella Oduah, the minister of aviation, was accused of spending 255 million naira \xe2\x80\x94 about $1.6 million \xe2\x80\x94 on the purchase of two armored cars that were worth perhaps one-quarter as much, as well as of falsifying an academic credential from an American college.'b'But the president has not yet acted against this minister. She continues in office while a report by a committee that was set up to investigate this case is gathering dust somewhere in the presidential offices, without having been made public.'b'The president\xe2\x80\x99s refusal to take action against her only lends credence to the widely held suspicion that some members of his administration are untouchable. No matter their offense, the president treats them as if he trusts them blindly, while he and his cronies engage in diversionary tactics.'b'A few weeks ago, for example, the president asked Sanusi Lamido Sanusi, the governor of the Central Bank of Nigeria, to resign from his post, a demand Mr. Sanusi has resisted. Mr. Sanusi had written a letter asking the president to look into a case of $49.8 billion in receipts from the Nigeria National Petroleum Corporation that are now unaccounted for.'b'Whereas a minister accused of misappropriating public funds is allowed to remain in office, a central bank governor has been hounded for seeking the president\xe2\x80\x99s intervention in a case that strongly suggests corrupt practices in a government-owned corporation.'b'When the president acts \xe2\x80\x94 or fails to act \xe2\x80\x94 in this manner, ordinary Nigerians wonder where just exactly he is  going, or where his advisers are leading him.'b'Recently, Mr. Jonathan signed into law a ban on same-sex marriage, even as another bill, which many Nigerians believe would curb corrupt practices in the oil and gas industry, suffered setback after setback in the Parliament.'b'The result: Nothing has been done to end corruption involving the single most important source of funds for the Nigerian government, but horror stories of gay-bashing by law enforcement officers have already become rife.'b'And gross failures in vital services like power supply, health care and education continue to get almost no effective attention.'b'In Nigeria, corrupt elected and appointed government officials typically do not resign from office unless they are forced out. So it is the duty of the commander in chief to clean a corrupt house.'b'Even Mr. Jonathan\xe2\x80\x99s mentor, former President Olusegun Obasanjo, who was behind Mr. Jonathan\xe2\x80\x99s rise to power, criticized him for tolerating corruption in the oil industry and other sectors and mismanaging the fight against Boko Haram. Mr. Jonathan rejected Mr. Obasanjo\xe2\x80\x99s attack in an open letter.'b'It is time for Mr. Jonathan to open his eyes, stop the dangerous game he is playing, and fire his corrupt playmates before the voters take the matter out of his hands in the general elections scheduled for next year.'b''b'\n'b'Victor Ehikhamenor, 'b' a Nigerian-American writer and artist, is the author of an essay collection, \xe2\x80\x9cExcuse Me! One Nigerian\xe2\x80\x99s Funny Outsized Reality.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'MADRID \xe2\x80\x94  You know a monarchy is in trouble when the queen is jeered at the Royal Theater, of all places, and by a classical music audience. This happened to Queen Sof\xc3\xada of 'b'Spain'b' last year in Madrid \xe2\x80\x94 a scene then repeated elsewhere with other members of the royal family.'b'A recent poll put support for the Spanish monarchy at a historic low: More than 60 percent of Spaniards want 'b'King Juan Carlos'b' to step down. And all this is happening amid a series of scandals involving the royal household, the most serious of which are corruption charges against the king\xe2\x80\x99s son-in-law, also involving the king\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, Princess Cristina.'b'What is astonishing about this turn of events is that the Spanish monarchy was once deemed rock-solid. King Juan Carlos was praised both inside and outside Spain as a model monarch; the man who in the 1970s steered the country\xe2\x80\x99s complicated transition from the military rule of Gen. Francisco Franco to parliamentary democracy; the king who stood up to an attempted military coup in 1981. He was said to be loved by his people, who were grateful for what he had done \xe2\x80\x94 and it was true.'b'What has changed? Not the king, but the country. Popular opinion has changed so fast and so dramatically that it is perhaps not surprising the monarchy has failed to keep pace.'b'Two things transform a people more than any other: war and economic hardship. War was what shaped the Spain that loved King Juan Carlos. It was the haunting memories of the 1936-39 civil war that won people over to the monarchy after Franco\xe2\x80\x99s death in 1975: Few were monarchists at heart, but the institution seemed to offer a safe path to stability.'b'Nearly four decades later, economic privation is creating a new Spain. The financial crisis hit the country hard, leaving a trail of home repossessions, draconian cutbacks to public services and low wages. Last year, there were fears of a complete meltdown of Spain\xe2\x80\x99s banking system, avoided only at the taxpayers\xe2\x80\x99 expense. The unemployment rate stands at a staggering 27 percent.'b'All this has made Spaniards angry at the establishment and hypersensitive to the misuse of public money. That\xe2\x80\x99s why, after they heard that the king\xe2\x80\x99s son-in-law was being investigated for fraud on a grand scale, their blood boiled. Public esteem for the monarchy started to decline.'b'The real disaster came in April 2012. The country learned that the king had broken his hip while hunting elephants in Botswana, reportedly as the guest of a Syrian-born Saudi magnate. He was also \xe2\x80\x94 unusually, for a private trip \xe2\x80\x94 unaccompanied by the queen. The affair opened a Pandora\xe2\x80\x99s box of awkward questions \xe2\x80\x94 from the state of the royal marriage to the nature of the king\xe2\x80\x99s business dealings.'b'Above all, people were livid at the insensitivity of his shooting of pachyderms while the country was reeling under harsh austerity. The fact that the king was also a patron of the World Wildlife Fund did not help. (Soon after, the conservation group unceremoniously sacked the monarch.) To this day, the mere mention of an elephant in Spain sends people into an uproar over the king.'b'The irony is that Juan Carlos had been hunting and doing business around the world all his life. Most people simply didn\xe2\x80\x99t know. The king and his family were shielded from criticism by an informal media covenant, their sources of income kept secret in part.'b'With hindsight, this proved to have been a mistake. The sudden contrast between image and reality only made disclosure all the more embarrassing. Now, thanks to the scandal, there is more transparency in the royal household, but probably not enough. Its official budget approved by Parliament is known to be around 8 million euros, but this is widely believed to represent a small part of the family\xe2\x80\x99s total worth.'b'To his credit, the king apologized for his ill-fated safari. Yet he lacked experience in apologizing \xe2\x80\x94 and his people, in forgiving. It was simply awkward, and it\xe2\x80\x99s become increasingly awkward as the king seeks to regain the favor of his subjects by multiplying his public appearances in spite of a series of surgeries from which he has not fully recovered.'b'As to the future, many believe that the appearance in court of Princess Cristina, regardless of the outcome, could be a cathartic moment that would allow a reset. That seems na\xc3\xafve. The king\xe2\x80\x99s men pin their hopes on an early end to the economic hardship and a shift in the general mood that would bring back the Spain of yore, more tolerant of housing bubbles and royal blunders.'b'That could well occur: Spaniards who change their minds are not unheard of. But others speak openly of Juan Carlos\xe2\x80\x99s abdication. They note that polls also show there is a chance that Crown Prince Felipe, young and untainted, could restore the monarchy\xe2\x80\x99s lost prestige.'b'Juan Carlos has made it clear he will not even consider stepping aside, but even on this, ill luck dogs him: The abdication last year of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, soon followed by King Albert II of Belgium renouncing the crown, renewed the pressure. Rather cruelly, even the pope stepped down. And yet, Juan Carlos remains adamant: He wants to be the king he was.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not the problem: He is the king he was. It\xe2\x80\x99s his kingdom that is no longer the same.'b''b'\n'b'Miguel-Anxo Murado 'b' is a Spanish author and journalist. 'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I was captivated by \xe2\x80\x9c'b'For the Love of Money'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Sam Polk (Sunday Review, Jan. 19).'b'During my career, I worked for more than 36 years, and lived and worked in six cities (including New York) on four continents. I was aware that in New York, there was a particularly strong obsession with excessive wealth, and that this obsession was culturally acceptable, even desirable and beneficial to society.'b'Mr. Polk has defined that obsession in a more compelling manner, as an addiction to excessive wealth. New York has always been a leader for the rest of the country, generally in a positive manner. But this addiction to wealth is destructive of society and our capitalistic economic system.'b'It is refreshing to see Mr. Polk acknowledge and break his addiction to the still-unregulated wealth and risk culture prevalent in our financial industry.'b'BILL STEWART'b'\nBloomfield Hills, Mich., Jan. 19, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'During more than 25 years as a wealth manager, I saw many clients who are caught up in the same mind-set as Sam Polk: that more money equals a better life. While he is an extreme example, I witnessed the pernicious effects of wealth addiction on so many people.'b'Although they were very wealthy, they were not happy and proved to me the fallacy of the accepted equation in our society that Money = Happiness. After witnessing setbacks in the lives of my clients and experiencing my own, I began to feel the same way.'b'I found that once you have a stable lifestyle there are three keys to your happiness: the quality of your most important relationships, being engaged in a meaningful activity, and making a difference in the lives of others.'b'DAVID GELLER'b'\nAtlanta, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cWealth and Happiness: Using Your Wealth to Create a Better Life.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Once upon a time, great wealth often produced great philanthropy and political intent for the common good of our country. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Inequality Problem'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (column, Jan. 17): In arguing that the problem of poverty is distinct from widening inequality, David Brooks overlooks what\xe2\x80\x99s happened to the middle class.'b'The median wage of the bottom 90 percent of Americans is lower today than it was three decades ago, adjusted for inflation, even though the economy is twice as large. Almost all the gains from that growth have gone to the top. As a result, the middle class doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have the buying power necessary for buoyant growth.'b'Slow growth and high unemployment hit the poor especially hard because they\xe2\x80\x99re the first to be fired, last to be hired and most likely to bear the brunt of declining wages and benefits.'b'Moreover, when the middle class is stressed, it has a harder time being generous to those in need.
