(By the way, I\xe2\x80\x99m 94.)'b'LEN ROSEN'b'\nBrooklyn, Jan. 22, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'After Years at War, the Army Adapts to Garrison Life'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 19):'b'Spec. Perez Brown Jr. is safely home from Afghanistan, but here at home, he says \xe2\x80\x9cthere are too many slow days.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is nothing like a pointless life for anyone, especially when you are young and energetic. These soldiers are looking for work so they can feel like useful members of society.'b'I can suggest a few projects: playing sports with children whose parents don\xe2\x80\x99t have time; delivering food to shut-ins; tutoring in schools or prisons; or perhaps road and bridge building.'b'Why not have our soldiers become a working army mitigating the dangers of neglect?'b'DIANA CAPLOW'b'\nChapel Hill, N.C., Jan. 19, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Afghanistan\xe2\x80\x99s Worsening, and Baffling, Hunger Crisis'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 5) correctly highlights the many challenges facing children, families and health professionals, although the information attributed to Unicef was provided nearly four months ago and is somewhat dated.'b'Under the leadership of the Afghan government, last year Unicef and partners treated some 185,000 children under 5 with acute malnutrition, of whom more than 61,000 were suffering from severe acute malnutrition, at more than 500 sites across Afghanistan. But the response is not just about providing specialist treatments.'b'There is also important work being undertaken to prevent malnutrition: promoting breast-feeding, the use of Vitamin A and micronutrient supplementation, and expanding access to health and nutrition services and education for the most vulnerable.'b'The results of a new nutrition survey are expected soon. Armed with these data, we will be able to do even more to reach more children and families. We all agree that more can and must be done to help the children of Afghanistan.'b'WERNER SCHULTINK'b'\nChief of Nutrition, Unicef'b'\nNew York, Jan. 10, 2014'b''b''b'PLEASANTON, Calif. \xe2\x80\x94 LAST year the private sector spent $67.2 billion on cybersecurity services. Nevertheless, according to a 'b'recent investigation'b' by Verizon, 60 percent of successful hacks were not detected until months after the attacks began. In the wake of recent high-profile hacker attacks against Target, Neiman Marcus and other retailers, the obvious question is: Why hasn\xe2\x80\x99t all that money done any good?'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not for lack of trying. Much of the money is well spent, paying for armies of technical engineers and state-of-the-art security applications.'b'The problem is not the resources, or the personnel, or the data. It\xe2\x80\x99s that many organizations simply don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to arrange the data to identify suspicious patterns and weaknesses, at least not fast enough. There\xe2\x80\x99s too much data, and not enough perspective.'b'What we need, then, is not necessarily more money or information, but a better way of knowing what it means \xe2\x80\x94 of interpreting the data to discover an unknown attack as it happens or, even better, anticipate the next attack.'b'The amount of security-related data that the typical enterprise manages today is staggering. A Fortune 500-size company could have over an exabyte (a billion gigabytes) of data scattered across thousands of servers and hundreds of thousands of software applications. All told, a detailed investigation of a complex, stealthy attack could involve trillions of discrete data points.'b'Most of those data points, even security-related points, are noise. Warnings are generated each time an easily blocked virus tries to gain access, or an employee enters the wrong password. Across a large company, that could mean thousands of warnings a day, all of which must be investigated. This noise makes the job of rapidly identifying serious attacks an overwhelming task.'b'The solution lies in finding a way to examine the data so that analysts can quickly identify suspicious patterns. Instead of programs to generate more data, we need different tools to understand them. And it turns out that the best tools are right in our heads: our eyes.'b'The fast-growing field of graph analytics involves the creation of a visual representation of \xe2\x80\x9cobjects\xe2\x80\x9d within an organization: people, devices, computers, applications. The relationships are displayed as lines linking objects. (My company, YarcData, develops graph-analytic platforms for a variety of applications.)'b'With this type of analysis, objects and their relationships uncover connections that are hidden in the numbers but obvious to the eye. It allows a user to see, immediately, the object\xe2\x80\x99s broader context. A failed attack on one computer might not raise a flag on its own \xe2\x80\x94 but it could if an analyst saw, simultaneously, that the target was connected to other critical targets, or that the attack was a modification of a recent failed attack.'b'Our brains conduct such contextual assessments every day, albeit on a much simpler, smaller scale. Think about when one hears a strange noise. Within a split second our mind connects the noise with its context. And we can ask creative questions, drawing on seemingly unrelated correlations that a computer program could never be robust enough to handle. Was it late at night? Is the family dog in that room? If it was in the middle of the day and the dog was in that room, we would react differently than if it was a strange noise late at night, with the dog asleep at our feet and no one else in the house.'b'Consider another example: My phone has just mysteriously connected to a website I have never visited, or intended to visit. Our minds ask the same sorts of contextual questions: Am I using the phone? What time of day is it? How many websites have I visited in the last five minutes? The last 30 minutes? Could a new app be connecting to sites to bump ad revenues?'b'All this information is already present in a company\xe2\x80\x99s data network. Graph analytics facilitates presentation in a visual fashion to allow our eyes, and brains, to do the top-level processing, enabling rapid understanding of all these events, then identifying the difference that would explain whether it was a malicious application or just a harmless bit of spam. Someone, somewhere, has to decide on a fast, accurate response.'b'Why hasn\xe2\x80\x99t this been done already? The industry has tried. But the speed and scope in computing power were not available until recently. And of course, with so much invested in traditional cybersecurity methods, many companies have been loath to try something new.'b'That must change soon. Target has pledged to make \xe2\x80\x9csignificant changes,\xe2\x80\x9d and it\xe2\x80\x99s likely that name-brand retailers around the globe will be undertaking security audits and taking measures to harden themselves against attacks and protect customer data.'b'Winning at cybersecurity today isn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily about collecting more data. It is about unleashing the information in the data that\xe2\x80\x99s already there \xe2\x80\x94 and doing so not in weeks, days and hours, but in minutes and seconds.'b'A generation ago, the Supreme Court was faced with deciding whether the police needed a warrant before installing a newfangled device at a telephone company switching office that could record the numbers dialed from a particular telephone. The answer the court gave was no.'b'After all, Justice Harry A. Blackmun explained in his 'b'majority opinion,'b' people know that the telephone company keeps track of the numbers they call -- they see their long-distance calls listed on their monthly bill. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is too much to believe,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cthat telephone subscribers, under these circumstances, harbor any general expectation that the numbers they dial will remain secret.\xe2\x80\x9d The absence of a \xe2\x80\x9clegitimate expectation of privacy\xe2\x80\x9d in information voluntarily conveyed to the phone company, the court concluded, meant that the use of the device, a \xe2\x80\x9cpen register,\xe2\x80\x9d was not even a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment\xe2\x80\x99s prohibition of unreasonable searches. Hence, no warrant was required.'b'This case, Smith v. Maryland, was no big deal in its day. (And the defendant in the garden-variety case that led to the decision was no criminal mastermind -- he was making harassing calls from his home phone.) The majority opinion was only 11 pages long. There were three dissenting votes, but the dissenting opinions lacked passion. After Justice Blackmun circulated his final draft in June 1979, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger responded by agreeing that \xe2\x80\x9cthe urge for privacy does not rise to the level of a constitutionally protected right.\xe2\x80\x9d The chief justice added that \xe2\x80\x9cCongress could require a warrant but the Constitution does not.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He ended his note with a lighthearted P.S.: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m going to use a public phone for my calls to my bookie.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Thirty-five years later, telephones and their users\xe2\x80\x99 privacy concerns are obviously no joking matter. They are the question of the hour. Constitutional challenges to the National Security Agency\xe2\x80\x99s bulk telephone data collection 'b'produced'b' 'b'opposing'b' Federal District Court rulings last month, and the issue appears destined for the Supreme Court.'b'Meanwhile, the justices last week 'b'accepted two cases'b' with less obvious national security implications but much greater relevance to many Americans: whether the police need a warrant in order to search the contents of a cellphone of a person they have just arrested. These cases, United States v. Wurie and Riley v. California, will probably be argued in April and decided in June.'b'All the cases will be dissected in minute detail in the coming months, but that\xe2\x80\x99s not my goal here. I\xe2\x80\x99m interested in the ultimate answers, of course, but what I find most intriguing at the moment is watching how judges respond to the challenge of figuring out how old precedents fit with new realities.'b'The fit is awkward at best; the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s description of a pen register -- \xe2\x80\x9ca mechanical device that records\xe2\x80\x9d on a paper tape \xe2\x80\x9cthe numbers dialed on a telephone by monitoring the electrical impulses caused when the dial on the telephone is released\xe2\x80\x9d -- reads like something from Alexander Graham Bell\xe2\x80\x99s laboratory. Differing conclusions about whether the old cases are even relevant, let alone controlling, have divided the lower courts, state as well as federal. For anyone interested in how the law develops in a system ostensibly governed by precedent, the progress of these cases promises to be the best show in town.'b'Take the N.S.A. cases. The government\xe2\x80\x99s constitutional defense relies heavily on the pen-register decision for the argument that anyone who voluntarily uses a phone yields up any reasonable privacy interest in the \xe2\x80\x9cbulk telephony metadata,\xe2\x80\x9d consisting of the numbers from which calls were made and received.'b'Judge Richard J. Leon of the Federal District Court in Washington was 'b'having none of it'b'. In the Smith case, he said, the Supreme Court \xe2\x80\x9cconsidered a one-time, targeted request for data regarding an individual suspect in a criminal investigation.\xe2\x80\x9d He suggested that the court that issued that decision would agree that it was of \xe2\x80\x9clittle value\xe2\x80\x9d in assessing the N.S.A. program: \xe2\x80\x9cThe notion that the government could collect similar data on hundreds of millions of people and retain that data for a five-year period, updating it with new data every day in perpetuity, was at best, in 1979, the stuff of science fiction.\xe2\x80\x9d Judge Leon ordered the government to stop collecting telephone data on the two plaintiffs in the case, Klayman v. Obama. He then granted a stay to permit the government to appeal.'b'But barely a week later, another federal district judge, William H. Pauley III of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, gave a 'b'very different reading'b" to Smith v. Maryland. He suggested that the pen register, aimed at a known individual, entailed a more direct invasion of personal privacy than does the N.S.A.'s collection of anonymous data: \xe2\x80\x9cSmith involved the investigation of a single crime and the collection of telephone call detail records collected by the telephone company at its central office, examined by the police, and related to the target of their investigation, a person identified previously by law enforcement.\xe2\x80\x9d If that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment, Judge Pauley concluded, then neither was the N.S.A.'s program. \xe2\x80\x9cClear precedent applies because Smith held that a subscriber has no legitimate expectation of privacy in telephony metadata created by third parties.\xe2\x80\x9d"b'In his opinion in A.C.L.U. v. Clapper, Judge Pauley took note of the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s own worries about adapting old cases to new technologies. Two years ago this week, in 'b'United States v. Jones,'b' the court ruled 9 to 0 that the placement by the police of a GPS device on a suspect\xe2\x80\x99s car in order to monitor his whereabouts over a period of weeks was a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.'b'Justice Antonin Scalia\xe2\x80\x99s majority opinion decided the case the old-fashioned way: that by attaching the device to the suspect\xe2\x80\x99s car, the police had committed a physical trespass. But five justices, in concurring opinions, warned that the deeper doctrinal implications of the case couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be so easily avoided. For one thing, many cars come already equipped with GPS systems, Justice Samuel A. Alito observed.'b'And Justice Sonia Sotomayor, in perhaps the best-known opinion of her tenure so far, wrote that \xe2\x80\x9cit may be necessary to reconsider the premise that an individual has no reasonable expectation of privacy in information voluntarily disclosed to third parties.\xe2\x80\x9d Citing Maryland v. Smith, she added, \xe2\x80\x9cThis approach is ill suited to the digital age, in which people reveal a great deal of information about themselves to third parties in the course of carrying out mundane tasks.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Still, as Judge Pauley noted in his opinion in the New York case, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Supreme Court did not overrule Smith.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The cellphone cases the court accepted last week challenge the applicability of another Fourth Amendment precedent from the 1970s. 'b'United States v. Robinson'b' applied a doctrine known as \xe2\x80\x9csearch incident to arrest\xe2\x80\x9d to uphold the warrantless search of a cigarette pack in the coat pocket of a man they had just arrested for driving without a license. Inside the pack were 14 capsules filled with heroin. Writing for the court, then-Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist said that as long as there was probable cause to make an arrest in the first place, \xe2\x80\x9ca full search of the person is not only an exception to the warrant requirement of the Fourth Amendment, but is also a \xe2\x80\x98reasonable\xe2\x80\x99 search under that Amendment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But a cellphone is much more revealing than a pack of cigarettes, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, said last May in one of the cases the Supreme Court has agreed to review. By a vote of 2 to 1, the appeals court suppressed the evidence -- drugs, a gun and ammunition -- the police found when they tracked the address of \xe2\x80\x9cmy house\xe2\x80\x9d from the call log of a cellphone belonging to a man they had just arrested after witnessing his involvement in an apparent drug sale.'b'Writing for the appeals court, Judge Norman H. Stahl 'b'criticized the government'b' for having \xe2\x80\x9chewed to a formalistic interpretation of the case law,\xe2\x80\x9d namely the \xe2\x80\x9csearch incident to arrest\xe2\x80\x9d doctrine of the Robinson case. \xe2\x80\x9cThe court, more than 35 years ago,\xe2\x80\x9d Judge Stahl wrote, \xe2\x80\x9ccould not have envisioned a world in which the vast majority of arrestees would be carrying on their person an item containing not physical evidence but a vast store of intangible data -- data that is not immediately destructible and poses no threat to the arresting officers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'On the other hand, the California Supreme Court in 2011 adopted the Robinson decision as part of its own interpretation of the Fourth Amendment, meaning that the police in California can routinely search the cellphones of the people they arrest. The California case the justices accepted is an appeal by a man who was arrested for having loaded weapons in his car and whose cellphone contained text and photographs suggesting involvement in a gang shooting.'b'Three years ago, the California Legislature passed a bill to require the police to obtain a warrant before searching a cellphone. But Gov. Jerry Brown vetoed the bill, saying that \xe2\x80\x9ccourts are better suited to resolve the complex and case-specific issues relating to constitutional search-and-seizure protections.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not every day that an elected official invites judges to legislate from the bench. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what the Supreme Court will do. But the justices surely know that they can\xe2\x80\x99t put the future on hold. It\xe2\x80\x99s here.'b'The first thing I can remember buying for myself, aside from candy, of course, was not a toy. It was a book.'b'It was a religious picture book about Job from the Bible, bought at Kmart.'b'It was on one of the rare occasions when my mother had enough money to give my brothers and me each a few dollars so that we could buy whatever we wanted.'b'We all made a beeline for the toy aisle, but that path led through the section of greeting cards and books. As I raced past the children\xe2\x80\x99s books, they stopped me. Books to me were things most special. Magical. Ideas eternalized.'b'Books were the things my brothers brought home from school before I was old enough to attend, the things that engrossed them late into the night as they did their homework. They were the things my mother brought home from her evening classes, which she attended after work, to earn her degree and teaching certificate.'b'Books, to me, were powerful and transformational.'b'So there, in the greeting card section of the store, I flipped through children\xe2\x80\x99s books until I found the one that I wanted, the one about Job. I thought the book fascinating in part because it was a tale of hardship, to which I could closely relate, and in part because it contained the first drawing I\xe2\x80\x99d even seen of God, who in those pages was a white man with a white beard and a long robe that looked like one of my mother\xe2\x80\x99s nightgowns.'b'I picked up the book, held it close to my chest and walked proudly to the checkout. I never made it to the toy aisle.'b'That was the beginning of a lifelong journey in which books would shape and change me, making me who I was to become.'b'We couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford many books. We had a small collection. They were kept on a homemade, rough-hewn bookcase about three feet tall with three shelves. One shelf held the encyclopedia, a gift from our uncle, books that provided my brothers and me a chance to see the world without leaving home.'b'The other shelves held a hodgepodge of books, most of which were giveaways my mother picked when school librarians thinned their collections at the end of the year. I read what we had and cherished the days that our class at school was allowed to go to the library \xe2\x80\x94 a space I approached the way most people approach religious buildings \xe2\x80\x94 and the days when the bookmobile came to our school from the regional library.'b'It is no exaggeration to say that those books saved me: from a life of poverty, stress, depression and isolation.'b'James Baldwin, one of the authors who most spoke to my spirit, once put it this way:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou think your pain and your heartbreak are unprecedented in the history of the world, but then you read. It was books that taught me that the things that tormented me the most were the very things that connected me with all the people who were alive, who had ever been alive.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is the inimitable power of literature, to give context and meaning to the trials and triumphs of living. That is why it was particularly distressing that The Atlantic\xe2\x80\x99s Jordan Weissmann 'b'pointed out Tuesday'b' that:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Pew Research Center 'b'reported'b' last week that nearly a quarter of American adults had not read a single book in the past year. As in, they hadn\xe2\x80\x99t cracked a paperback, fired up a Kindle, or even hit play on an audiobook while in the car. The number of non-book-readers has 'b'nearly tripled since 1978'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The details of the Pew report are quite interesting and somewhat counterintuitive. Among American adults, women were more likely to have read at least one book in the last 12 months than men. Blacks were more likely to have read a book than whites or Hispanics. People aged 18-29 were more likely to have read a book than those in any other age group. And there was little difference in readership among urban, suburban and rural population.'b'I understand that we are now inundated with information, and people\xe2\x80\x99s reading habits have become fragmented to some degree by bite-size nuggets of text messages and social media, and that takes up much of the time that could otherwise be devoted to long-form reading. I get it. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t take a troglodytic view of social media. I participate and enjoy it.'b'But reading texts is not the same as reading a 'b'text'b'.'b'There is no intellectual equivalent to allowing oneself the time and space to get lost in another person\xe2\x80\x99s mind, because in so doing we find ourselves.'b'Take it from me, the little boy walking to the Kmart checkout with the picture book pressed to his chest.'b'President Obama is going to visit the pope! He\xe2\x80\x99s been to the Vatican before, but not with 'b'this'b' pope, who is perhaps the only person in the world almost everybody likes.'b'Except Rush Limbaugh, which sort of makes it even better.'b'The president\xe2\x80\x99s visit, which is scheduled for March, comes at an interesting intersection in the two men\xe2\x80\x99s careers. Pope Francis can currently do no wrong, and Barack Obama can do no right. Recently, his administration decided to move its Vatican Embassy into a more secure building, and the outcry was so intense that you\xe2\x80\x99d think Obama had ordered a re-creation of the Sack of Rome.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cA slap in the face to the 78 million Catholics in the United States,\xe2\x80\x9d one congressman screeched.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy would our president close our Embassy to the Vatican?\xe2\x80\x9d twittered Jeb Bush. \xe2\x80\x9cHopefully, it is not retribution for Catholic organizations opposing Obamacare.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As political tweets go, this is a keeper on two counts. First, we can once again marvel at Republican politicians\xe2\x80\x99 ability to insert the Affordable Care Act into everything. (Coming soon: How the individual mandate robbed Oprah Winfrey of an Oscar nomination.)'b'Second, we can mark the official end of the former governor of Florida\xe2\x80\x99s career as the safe, sane fallback option in 2016.'b'But about the Vatican Embassy: the State Department has been trying to move it into a compound that includes the American Embassy to Italy. This will save money and improve security. Instantly, certain parties detected a plot.'b'Two former ambassadors to the Vatican, Ray Flynn (Clinton) and Jim Nicholson (Bush), penned a blistering op-ed for The Wall Street Journal in which they called the move \xe2\x80\x9ca colossal mistake\xe2\x80\x9d that would squish the Holy See\xe2\x80\x99s separate identity. Diplomatically, they attributed more intense feelings to others. (\xe2\x80\x9c... many have seen the move as a deliberate slap at the Catholic Church and the pope; some may even detect veiled anti-Catholicism.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'Fast-forward to many variations on the headline \xe2\x80\x9cObama Insults Catholics.\xe2\x80\x9d The State Department pointed out that the new quarters would be in an entirely different building, with an entirely different entrance than the Italian Embassy. And that while the new embassy will not be in the Vatican, neither is the current one. Or that of any other country. The Vatican is only two-tenths of a square mile, and more than half of that is gardens.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact, our new location is a tenth of a mile closer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Under Secretary of State Patrick Kennedy.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a clear diminishment of the importance of the Holy See post,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nicholson.'b'Cynics might wonder why we have an embassy for the Vatican in the first place. The total population is about 800 people, which is approximately one-eighth the seating capacity of Radio City Music Hall. It has virtually none of the attributes you find in an actual country. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even have a cuisine.'b'But, obviously, nobody is going to disrespect the Vatican while Pope Francis is around. He won the world\xe2\x80\x99s heart by quickly doing a few things that were so obvious, it\xe2\x80\x99s amazing no previous pontiff figured them out. Such as: if you are going to talk about the poor all the time, you should try to avoid gold furniture.'b'Without changing any of the Church\xe2\x80\x99s reactionary rules on contraception, homosexuality or abortion, Francis changed the tone just by saying that Catholics should stop obsessing about sex. I cannot imagine what the nuns who ran my old high school would have thought about that theory. Really, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to overestimate what an incredible time-saver this is.'b'And instead of just pleading for greater charity toward the poor, Francis decreed that the world needed to drop the idea that when the rich got richer, everybody eventually benefited. Trickle-down economics amounted to a \xe2\x80\x9ccrude and na\xc3\xafve trust in the goodness of those wielding economic power.\xe2\x80\x9d This would have been where he lost Rush Limbaugh.'b'Ken Langone, the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot, told Cardinal Timothy Dolan that a rich benefactor to a rebuilding project at St. Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s Cathedral in New York might hesitate to cough up his promised million-dollar donation because of the pope\xe2\x80\x99s attitude. Cardinal Dolan said he assured Langone that while the pope loves the poor, \xe2\x80\x9che also loves rich people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Republican budget guru Representative Paul Ryan said the pope\xe2\x80\x99s apparent lack of enthusiasm for the capitalist system was due to an unfortunate upbringing. \xe2\x80\x9cThe guy is from Argentina. They haven\xe2\x80\x99t had real capitalism in Argentina,\xe2\x80\x9d he told The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. Even if Francis was down on capitalism, no capitalists wanted to sound down on Francis. Meanwhile, President Obama has spent the last five years dodging calls for new taxes and protecting the insurance industry from health care reform. Stocks have been at an all-time high, and Wall Street hates him.'b'The moral is: It\xe2\x80\x99s way easier to be pope.'b'When I asked readers for \xe2\x80\x9cneglected topics\xe2\x80\x9d that journalists should cover more in 2014, one of the suggestions was a delicate but vital topic: family breakdown and the rise of single-parent households.'b'This is an issue that, frustratingly, the right has hijacked and the left has been reluctant to confront. Yet it\xe2\x80\x99s intimately related to poverty in our country.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt isn\xe2\x80\x99t politically correct to call attention to the effects of the increase in single women giving birth,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'wrote Colton'b', one reader who suggested the topic. \xe2\x80\x9cThree important effects are the greatly increased incidence of long-term poverty, poor development outcomes and poor educational achievement among the children.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur hesitancy to face the problem may result from fear of accusations of being moralists, racists, anti-woman, anti-freedom, supporting government decisions into personal decisions,\xe2\x80\x9d Lucinda noted.'b'Conservatives are, I think, correct to highlight family stability as a fundamental issue that goes to the welfare of children as much as food stamps or anything else. Children raised by a single parent are more than three times as likely to live in poverty as those raised by two parents, according to census data.'b'After Daniel Patrick Moynihan raised the issue in 1965 in the context of black families, he was condemned in liberal circles as intolerant if not racist. Over time, though, there has been a growing appreciation that he was ahead of his time, and 'b'as the Urban Institute notes'b', the percentage of white babies born to unwed mothers is now the same as it was for black babies when he sounded his alarm.'b'Yet if the issue is critical, it often emerges as part of a narrative that hectors the poor for their poverty. Republicans focus on \xe2\x80\x9cpersonal irresponsibility\xe2\x80\x9d or suggest that there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to be done about poverty until \xe2\x80\x9cthose people\xe2\x80\x9d stop having kids outside of marriage.'b'As I see it, conservatives are right in their diagnosis that the issue is critical in addressing poverty, but they are wrong in their prescriptions, while liberals are often too politically correct to address the issue at all.'b'First, the backdrop. At last count in the United States, 'b'almost 36 percent of births were to unmarried women'b', according to census data. The birthrate for unmarried women is up 80 percent since 1980.'b'Furthermore, census data show that a majority of high school dropouts having babies are unmarried; only 9 percent of college graduates are. Two-thirds of black women giving birth are unmarried; just over a quarter of white women are.'b'Of course, what matters isn\xe2\x80\x99t whether the parents have a marriage certificate but whether they are partners who are both committed to raising children they want and love. An Australian study 'b'found gay parenting had better outcomes'b' on average, apparently because gay couples don\xe2\x80\x99t have kids by accident.'b'Conservatives blame war-on-poverty welfare programs for undermining marriage. Academic studies indicate that this effect, while real, is small. The percentage of births to single mothers has been rising steadily in the United States (and other countries) since the 1940s.'b'Republicans tried \xe2\x80\x9cmarriage promotion\xe2\x80\x9d initiatives during the administration of George W. Bush, and these are worth testing, but, so far, 'b'they have failed the litmus test'b'. They didn\xe2\x80\x99t work. However, there are several steps that we could take:'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 First is to expand family planning so that teenagers and young adults don\xe2\x80\x99t have babies they don\xe2\x80\x99t want and are ill-prepared to care for. Four out of five teenage pregnancies are unintended, 'b'according to the Guttmacher Institute'b'. Family-planning initiatives save taxpayer money now spent on health care and the safety net, yet, after inflation, 'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s investment in Title X family planning has fallen'b' some 70 percent since 1980. That\xe2\x80\x99s crazy.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Second is to end America\xe2\x80\x99s disastrous experiment in mass incarceration. We quintupled incarceration rates since the 1970s, 'b'according to the Pew Center on the States'b', and, thus condemned millions of men \xe2\x80\x94 often men of color or with low incomes \xe2\x80\x94 to life at the margins and made them much less attractive as husbands. If the family has broken down, we helped break it.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Third is to back outreach efforts and job programs that give young people a lift and a stake in the future. Programs like 'b'Nurse-Family Partnership'b' that work with low-income mothers have a proven track record of keeping families together. Likewise, 'b'an evaluation'b' found that of young mothers in an Illinois outreach effort called Options for Youth, 97 percent delayed a subsequent pregnancy.'b'Talk about personal responsibility! It\xe2\x80\x99s irresponsible on our part to fail to take these steps.'b'So, readers, thanks for raising this issue. And let\xe2\x80\x99s address it not with platitudes but with proven policies that don\xe2\x80\x99t just hail the family but also strengthen it.'b'The standoff in Kiev, Ukraine, is now two months old, and it has 'b'claimed its first fatalities'b': two men who died of bullet wounds and a third who fell to his death. With tensions at a dangerous level, and Ukraine\xe2\x80\x99s citizens inflamed by both economic policy and new laws against public assembly, President Viktor Yanukovich met with the three most prominent opposition leaders: the popular boxer Vitali Klitschko, the former economics minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk, and the far-right nationalist Oleg Tyagnibok.'b'The meeting was a positive development, but it was difficult to see what agreement could end the standoff peacefully and properly. Neither bitter winter, nor Mr. Yanukovich\xe2\x80\x99s deal with Moscow for lower gas prices and a $15 billion loan, nor threatening laws and actions have deterred the protesters on Independence Square, known as the Maidan, and Mr. Yanukovich has shown no inclination to fire any members of his government or to resign.'b'The protesters, on their side, are divided, and the most radical nationalists among them have defied calls by Mr. Klitschko and other more moderate leaders to shun violence. An attempt by the government to clear the Maidan by force remains a strong possibility.'b'The United States and the European Union have made no secret that their sympathies are with the protesters, who poured out into Independence Square after Mr. Yanukovich abruptly announced in November that 'b'he would not sign a pact aligning Ukraine more closely'b' with the European Union. Russia, which was strongly opposed to the European pact, has predictably accused the West of egging on the demonstrators.'b'At this stage, however, the United States and Europe need to do more than hand out treats. It also must be prepared to follow through on its promise to consider \xe2\x80\x9cadditional steps in response to the use of violence by any actors.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A 'b'superb report released Wednesday by the Presidential Commission on Election Administration'b' can be summarized in one quick sentence: There are many ways to make voting easier in America. There shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be the slightest whiff of controversy or partisanship about that concept, or the important suggestions made in the report. But, of course, there is, and that makes the commission\xe2\x80\x99s persuasive logic and research all the more valuable.'b'President Obama appointed the commission last year 'b'to address the problem of long lines at the polls in 2012'b'. At a time when states were deliberately keeping people from voting with draconian ID requirements, that seemed a narrow goal, but members of the commission did far better than expected in showing the many ways that the nation\xe2\x80\x99s patchwork of state and local election laws has contributed to low turnouts.'b'Led by two election-law experts from opposing parties \xe2\x80\x94 Robert Bauer, a Democrat, and Benjamin Ginsberg, a Republican \xe2\x80\x94 the commission didn\xe2\x80\x99t get into politicized voter ID issues, though it did note that fraud is rare. It agreed, however, on a set of a principles that ought to be considered fundamental: No one should have to wait more than 30 minutes to vote. Ballots should be simple; registration efficient. Polling places should be well-organized and workers properly trained.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s an ideal experienced by few voters, who often stand in long lines caused by broken machines, confusing ballots, and useless poll workers. To fix the problems, the report makes several recommendations:'b''b'EARLY VOTING 'b'The report said early voting is one of the best ways to involve more people in the political process, allowing them to cast a ballot at their convenience and reducing Election Day congestion. Only 32 states allow some form of in-person early voting, and many Republican lawmakers have tried to cut back on it in the belief that it favors Democrats. The commission said every state should adopt the idea in some form, citing a bipartisan consensus of election administrators.'b''b'ONLINE REGISTRATION'b' The report says every state should move to online registration, which reduces the chances of errors, makes registration easy, and is far less expensive than paper systems. Registration has gone up significantly in states that have adopted these systems.'b''b'BETTER TECHNOLOGY 'b'The electronic and optical machines purchased with federal funds after the 2000 balloting disaster are wearing out, and there is no new money to replace them. The commission said the federal government needs to set clear national standards for new machines and certify the ones that work, replacing the federal Election Assistance Commission, which currently has no members thanks to Republican-led skirmishing in Congress. One suggestion made by the report is that voters be allowed to print out a ballot at home and fill it in before bringing it to the polling place for scanning.'b''b'POLL WORKERS 'b'States and cities should bring in more students and private-sector workers, and use fewer retirees. Colleges and employers should be encouraged to let students and workers volunteer. States should require far more training than the 2 to 4 hours that the average poll worker currently receives.'b'The most important idea in the report, endorsed by members of both parties on the panel, is that these are national problems requiring a national solution. It is no longer tenable for voting to be difficult in one state but easy next door. Republicans may continue to fight to keep large groups of minorities, low-income people and students from participating in the democratic process, but after the commission\xe2\x80\x99s report, there can no longer be any doubt that there are no legitimate reasons for their resistance.'b'Leave it to New York\xe2\x80\x99s top two political alpha males: Gov. Mr. de Blasio 'b'wants to offer'b' free, full-day prekindergarten to every 4-year-old in New York City and pay for it by raising taxes on wealthy residents. Mr. Cuomo 'b'is promising'b' to pay for full-day prekindergarten across the entire state, without any tax increase.'b'They are both right in purely pedagogical terms: expanding education for toddlers could make a real difference for thousands of New York\xe2\x80\x99s disadvantaged children, no matter how it\xe2\x80\x99s paid for. The question is whether they can come up with a way to turn this worthy goal into reality.'b'Mr. Cuomo told The Times on Wednesday that he would be willing to write what amounts to a blank check to Mr. de Blasio and other mayors in the state who wish to improve and expand their preschool programs. \xe2\x80\x9cAs fast as he can come up to speed, we will fund it,\xe2\x80\x9d the governor said.'b'Since prekindergarten was a major plank in Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s campaign platform last year, the governor\xe2\x80\x99s offer could be a big victory for him, even though it would not be financed in the way he had envisaged. He can, and undoubtedly will, continue to press for the tax increase. In the meantime, the smart thing is to accept the offer and declare political victory. Then he and his experts should quickly devise a prekindergarten program, one that could serve as a model for the state and the rest of the nation.'b'To make all this work, the governor must be generous. His promise of $1.5 billion over five years for universal, statewide preschool \xe2\x80\x94 $100 million in the first year, $200 million the next and then $400 million for the next three \xe2\x80\x94 is not enough. Mr. de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s price tag for the city alone is closer to $340 million a year. The mayor has also said that statewide financing could make the city vulnerable to year-to-year spending cuts, which is why he wants a dedicated revenue stream from the tax increase on residents making $500,000 a year or more.'b'Questions remain, too, about the strength of the governor\xe2\x80\x99s commitment. He told The Times that he now considers it \xe2\x80\x9cthe greatest single educational reform that we can make.\xe2\x80\x9d If he means it, he can also dramatically improve prekindergartens that now serve about 100,000 children around the state.'b'In addition, his administration will have to develop and require the highest educational standards so that preschool programs provide more than babysitting or day care. He must also help find the space and the talented teachers to make these programs really work.'b'These costs are one reason Mr. de Blasio wants what he calls his \xe2\x80\x9csmall soy latte tax\xe2\x80\x9d on the rich. But that tax has little chance of making it through the Legislature this election year, while the governor\xe2\x80\x99s new $135 billion budget would actually cut property, business and estate taxes in ways that would help more prosperous New Yorkers. How the governor can cut taxes by $2 billion and provide adequate services \xe2\x80\x94 including a new preschool program \xe2\x80\x94 is a mystery.'b'Mr. de Blasio is scheduled to testify at legislative budget hearings on Monday in Albany. He can use the occasion to defend his proposed tax increase. What he must also do is hold the governor to his promise to financing preschools, and to find enough money to do it right.'b'LONDON \xe2\x80\x94  \xe2\x80\x9cShakespeare,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote the American philosopher Allan Bloom, \xe2\x80\x9cwas an eminently political author.\xe2\x80\x9d On this matter, at least, the great controversialist was correct: As Mr. Bloom wrote 50 years ago in \xe2\x80\x9cShakespeare\xe2\x80\x99s Politics,\xe2\x80\x9d there was a time when \xe2\x80\x9cthe political man seemed to be the most interesting theme of poetry.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A new \xe2\x80\x9cKing Lear,\xe2\x80\x9d which opened at London\xe2\x80\x99s National Theater this month, restores this forgotten sense of priority. Already \xe2\x80\x94 deservedly \xe2\x80\x94 the hottest ticket in town, the director Sam Mendes\xe2\x80\x99s production presents the downfall of the aging monarch as much more than a study in human implosion, familial collapse and lyrical introspection. This \xe2\x80\x9cLear\xe2\x80\x9d deserves a Broadway transfer, and as wide a digital audience as the National Theater can muster.'b'Simon Russell Beale, shrunken, shriveled and broken, shows as convincingly as any actor I have ever seen what it is to lose everything (mind, children, kingdom). Yet his astonishing performance as Lear owes as much to an understanding of political dynamics as it does to the pathos of dementia. When we first meet him, he is a robust, impatient soldier-king, surrounded by an entourage of muscle. He divides his kingdom while seated \xe2\x80\x94 his back to the audience, oozing disdain through his very posture.'b'What is striking is the contemporary resonance of this production, the way in which it nags at the political subconscious and stirs our present anxieties. This is not the leaden \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical theater\xe2\x80\x9d of didacticism and finger-wagging. Rather, it uses the text of the early 17th century to illuminate the night terrors of the 21st, speaking directly to the pathologies of our time.'b'Mr. Mendes is right to claim that \xe2\x80\x9cit feels like a national play.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cKing Lear\xe2\x80\x9d was written in the infancy of what became the United Kingdom: Performed at Whitehall, London, in 1606 for King James I, who was also James VI of Scotland, it explores the fears of fragmentation and civil war that marked the declining years of the childless Queen Elizabeth I.'b'Now it returns to the stage only eight months before a referendum on Scotland\xe2\x80\x99s future. The polls suggest that independence will be rejected by the Scots on Sept. 18, but referendums are notoriously unpredictable.'b'Whatever the outcome, the fact that the question is being asked at all is unsettling for a union of nations such as the United Kingdom. Lear divides his kingdom to keep the peace; the outcome is precisely the opposite.'b'At a less literal level, there is an even stronger correspondence between \xe2\x80\x9cLear\xe2\x80\x9d and the spirit of the age. More than any other play in the language, it navigates the terrain between the personal and the political, the threads that connect decisions of state to the vulnerable individual. By stages, Lear is reduced from a mighty ruler to a naked vagrant, no better than a \xe2\x80\x9cpoor, bare, forked animal,\xe2\x80\x9d as he puts it to Poor Tom (the loyal Edgar, son of Gloucester, who is disguised and feigning madness).'b'This symbolic landscape is precisely where political battle is being waged in 2014. While the British economy is recovering, its resurgence has yet to translate into a sense of well-being. The fear of personal indigence remains deep. Austerity, insecurity and the cluster of social problems that Prime Minister David Cameron calls the \xe2\x80\x9cbroken society\xe2\x80\x9d continue to define the times.'b'No politician is more vulnerable than one who is not believed when he claims that things are getting better. Every regime is obsessed by what Lear calls \xe2\x80\x9ccourt news\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cWho loses and who wins, who\xe2\x80\x99s in, who\xe2\x80\x99s out.\xe2\x80\x9d But a coalition such as the Conservative-Liberal Democrat government headed by Mr. Cameron is conspicuously vulnerable to the charge of introspection and detachment.'b'The next general election, scheduled for May 2015, will be won by the party that persuasively connects the economic recovery to voters\xe2\x80\x99 personal circumstances. In one of the play\xe2\x80\x99s great moments of self-discovery, Lear considers the \xe2\x80\x9cpoor naked wretches\xe2\x80\x9d of his realm, helpless before \xe2\x80\x9cthe pelting of this pitiless storm.\xe2\x80\x9d He reproaches himself for his failure to help them when he could: \xe2\x80\x9cO, I have ta\xe2\x80\x99en / Too little care of this.\xe2\x80\x9d He tells \xe2\x80\x9cpomp\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 his own \xe2\x80\x94 to \xe2\x80\x9cExpose thyself to feel what wretches feel.\xe2\x80\x9d Never has the need for political empathy been so exquisitely expressed.'b'Herein lies the timeless demand made of those who govern on behalf of those with no apparent hope. As Conservative leader, Mr. Cameron has intermittently presented himself as the champion of the vulnerable. But his party is still associated in the eyes of the electorate with \xe2\x80\x9cpomp\xe2\x80\x9d and indifference to the \xe2\x80\x9cwretches\xe2\x80\x9d of our own time.'b'The twist is that, just as Lear was hailed for his strong kingship, so, too, the present prime minister is applauded when he is tough on welfare. Even as they reproach his party for its lack of compassion, voters demand crackdowns on benefit \xe2\x80\x9cscroungers\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 such is the great knotted dilemma at the heart of modern governance.'b'As Shakespeare knew, the practice of politics is governed not by straightforward rules but by a clutch of paradoxes. His plays are not manuals but mirrors held up to humanity. This is why Nelson Mandela and his fellow prisoners read and reread \xe2\x80\x9cJulius Caesar\xe2\x80\x9d on Robben Island, and why Abraham Lincoln turned to \xe2\x80\x9cMacbeth\xe2\x80\x9d as the truest portrait of tyranny and warning against it.'b'Every generation has its defining \xe2\x80\x9cKing Lear,\xe2\x80\x9d and I am sure this is ours. As Edgar says to his father, Gloucester, \xe2\x80\x9chow fearful / And dizzy \xe2\x80\x99tis to cast one\xe2\x80\x99s eyes so low.\xe2\x80\x9d Indeed, but how much worse is the politics of delusion.'b''b'\n'b'Matthew d\xe2\x80\x99Ancona 'b' is a political columnist for The Sunday Telegraph and The Evening Standard. 'b''b'BERLIN \xe2\x80\x94 From the bland figure of Fran\xc3\xa7ois Hollande, who rose to the pinnacle as Monsieur Normal, have cascaded of late some startling revelations, as if the French president had abruptly decided he was boring even himself.'b'First there was his love affair with the actress Julie Gayet. No real surprise there, but the images published by the tabloid Closer did seem to reduce the lofty presidency \xe2\x80\x94 De Gaulle\xe2\x80\x99s seat of French glory \xe2\x80\x94 to the level of a motorcycle courier service. A suitable caption for the helmeted gentleman en route to a tryst might have been: \xe2\x80\x9cI am more normal than you think.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When I asked Christine Ockrent, an acute observer of France, what she thought of the \xe2\x80\x9caffaire,\xe2\x80\x9d her immediate response was: \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a man. It\xe2\x80\x99s normal.\xe2\x80\x9d It would not damage Hollande for now, his popularity being so low anyway.'b'In matters of the heart the French shrug holds sway. This is healthy. \xe2\x80\x9cBof, c\xe2\x80\x99est normal,\xe2\x80\x9d a ubiquitous phrase, is the shrugging expression of a fierce realism about life in general and sex in particular. As Saul Bellow observes in his novel Ravelstein, \xe2\x80\x9cThe French were genuinely educated \xe2\x80\x94 or had been so once. They had taken a bad beating in this century. However, they had a real feeling for beautiful objects still, for leisure, for reading and conversation; they didn\xe2\x80\x99t despise creaturely needs \xe2\x80\x94 the human basics.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The French are indeed at home with creaturely needs. They do not squirm. They do not preach. It is safe enough to predict that Val\xc3\xa9rie Trierweiler, the first lady spurned, will not be at the White House with Hollande next month. She has been badly treated. Beyond that it is likely that the only consequence of Monsieur Normal\xe2\x80\x99s late-night forays will be the further demystification of the Fifth Republic\xe2\x80\x99s highest office, a process underway since Fran\xc3\xa7ois Mitterrand\xe2\x80\x99s death in 1996.'b'Bof, c\xe2\x80\x99est normal.'b'The second revelation about Hollande may be of greater consequence. It came at a recent press conference but, because of the affair, was scarcely noted. In the midst of a performance that was a tour de force he let drop a confession that was brave. \xe2\x80\x9cAm I a Social Democrat?\xe2\x80\x9d Hollande said. \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This may not seem a radical statement in the second decade of the 21st century, but it still is in France. Hollande, adhering to French socialist principle, had never previously ventured this far. To do so was to concede that his goal is to soften the harsh edges of capitalism rather than overturn it; to pursue social cohesion through compromise between capital and labor rather than class struggle; to suggest (heresy of heresies) that wealth must first be accumulated before it can be distributed; and to abandon the heady glory of the Popular Front for staid old German social democracy.'b'But, you may say, all this happened long ago \xe2\x80\x94 and you would be right. That, however, is not the point. The lexicon of political ideology is more important in France than anywhere. Hollande crossed a doctrinal line. This, in Paris, constitutes an event.'b'Hollande went further, proposing big business tax and budget cuts, even suggesting he was a supply-sider. A name doing the rounds in Paris is suddenly that of the last Social Democrat to lead Germany, Gerhard Schr\xc3\xb6der. During his time in office, a decade ago, reforms were passed that cut social benefits and changed the rules for receiving them in ways that meant it no longer made economic sense to remain unemployed rather than take a low-paying job. The German left partially dismantled the welfare state built by the German left. Unemployment fell, the economy boomed. Germany today is Germany and France is France.'b'This brings us to another troubled couple that once held hands, did big things and had big dreams \xe2\x80\x94 only to fall into a sulk. That would be France and Germany.'b'Because the war generation is gone, because the balance in the relationship was lost to German dominance, and because ever-closer union in Europe has withered as a political idea, the nations have been looking past each other. But there are stirrings. The return of the Social Democrats in a German grand coalition and Hollande\xe2\x80\x99s ideological pivot has led to talk of what Laurent Fabius, the French foreign minister, recently called \xe2\x80\x9ca new impulse to Franco-German cooperation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'With Britain consumed by anti-European rumblings, nothing is more important for the future of Europe than a reinvigorated French-German couple focused on political and budgetary integration, reignited growth, renewed democratic legitimacy and a revived European idea. In \xe2\x80\x9cla France profonde,\xe2\x80\x9d a diffuse populism is stirring. Reminiscent of America\xe2\x80\x99s Tea Party, this movement combines a nostalgic mind-set that everything \xe2\x80\x9cwas better before\xe2\x80\x9d with a radical aversion to taxes and a hostility toward the detested European bureaucracy.'b'According to a recent study, only 8 percent of French people espouse racial inequality, yet there is a palpable conviction that everything bad comes from outside: Brussels, globalization, immigration. It is not just Mr. M\xe2\x80\x99Bala M\xe2\x80\x99Bala who has flourished in this atmosphere; other comedians trot out the most hackneyed racial clich\xc3\xa9s.'b'The phenomenon cuts across social class. Take Alain Finkielkraut, a professor of philosophy at the elite \xc3\x89cole Polytechnique: He recently published \xe2\x80\x9cL\xe2\x80\x99identit\xc3\xa9 malheureuse,\xe2\x80\x9d a book bemoaning the dilution of an eternal France about to be defiled by swarthy barbarians threatening to plunge \xe2\x80\x9cEuropean civilization\xe2\x80\x9d into a multicultural bouillabaisse. Among the objects of his disgust: \xe2\x80\x9cHalal butcher shops and fast food.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Finkielkraut\xe2\x80\x99s sentiments echo those of Renaud Camus, a writer (not related to Albert Camus) who has denounced the \xe2\x80\x9cgreat replacement\xe2\x80\x9d of populations, which imposes on \xe2\x80\x9cthe true rooted French\xe2\x80\x9d those who are not. Mr. Camus makes no secret of his admiration for Marine Le Pen, daughter of Jean-Marie and current leader of the National Front. Such ideas have even found resonance in the media, thanks to commentators like the political journalist \xc3\x89ric Zemmour, who laments the fate of the \xe2\x80\x9cwhite proletariat,\xe2\x80\x9d helpless before the \xe2\x80\x9costentatious virility of their black and Arab competitors seducing numerous young white women.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The worst came last fall with a campaign against France\xe2\x80\x99s Roma people. The previous president, Nicolas Sarkozy, had already singled out this vulnerable population of 20,000 as a dangerous nuisance \xe2\x80\x94 despite the fact that the Roma constitute just 0.03 percent of the population. The interior minister, Mr. Valls, has now called for their expulsion. Well might we wonder about the integrity of a politician who defends Jews from Dieudonn\xc3\xa9\xe2\x80\x99s quenelle while deporting Gypsies.'b'The son of a white mother and a black father, Mr. M\xe2\x80\x99Bala M\xe2\x80\x99Bala will continue to surf a wave created by the \xe2\x80\x9ccompetition of victims\xe2\x80\x9d in a country that is historically \xe2\x80\x9cguilty\xe2\x80\x9d twice over: toward the Jews, for its participation in the collaborationist Vichy regime, and toward its black and Arab citizens, for its colonial past. By calling Jews \xe2\x80\x9cslave traders,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. M\xe2\x80\x99Bala M\xe2\x80\x99Bala plays a game of provoking the authorities\xe2\x80\x99 squeamishness about anti-Semitism, even as other expressions of racism get a pass. When Dieudonn\xc3\xa9 described Ms. Taubira as a \xe2\x80\x9ccheetah,\xe2\x80\x9d there was scarcely a stir.'b'Unless things change, this deplorable clown has a bright future.'b''b' 'b'Sylvain Cypel,'b' a former correspondent for Le Monde, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cWalled: Israeli Society at an Impasse.\xe2\x80\x9d This essay was translated by Edward Gauvin from the French. 'b''b'CALGARY, Alberta \xe2\x80\x94  New coils of razor wire top the fence around Melilla, one of two Spanish territories on North Africa\xe2\x80\x99s Mediterranean coast. Along with Ceuta, the enclaves share the European Union\xe2\x80\x99s only land borders with Africa and are targets for would-be migrants desperate to reach Europe. Spain has long maintained high-tech fencing systems around the enclaves in an attempt to keep the migrants out, but they had removed barbed wire from the top of Melilla\xe2\x80\x99s fence in 2007 after it inflicted serious injuries on those who dared to climb over.'b'Last November, though, in response to an increase of migrant assaults on the fence, the Spanish authorities restored the wire. The move angered human rights activists and religious leaders across Europe. In a letter to the Spanish interior minister, Bishop Santiago Agrelo Martinez wrote: \xe2\x80\x9cBarbed wire with blades on fences in Ceuta and Melilla is an attack on the physical integrity of immigrants: those blades cut, injure, [and] maim ... \xe2\x80\x9d The bishop appreciated the Spanish government\xe2\x80\x99s responsibility to secure the nation\xe2\x80\x99s borders, but he laid bare the fact that the \xe2\x80\x9cblades cause only pain and death.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The reinforcement of the fence around Melilla echoes the current building boom of border walls. According to Reece Jones, a University of Hawaii geographer, nearly 30 new border barriers have risen worldwide since 1998. There are new fences on America\xe2\x80\x99s border with Mexico and along Greece\xe2\x80\x99s border with Turkey. India erected barriers on its frontiers with both Pakistan and Bangladesh. Israel built a wall around Palestine and recently completed a fence along its Egyptian border.'b'Through technology, barriers to trade, travel and communication keep falling, and yet our world has never been more physically divided by the geometries of bricks, barbed wire and steel.'b'The political and economic ramifications of the walls are oft-discussed and well understood. So, too, is the psychological trauma suffered by those living in the shadow of the walls. In 1973,  an East German psychiatrist even coined a term for the disorder: Mauerkrankheit, or Wall Disease.'b'But Bishop Santiago\xe2\x80\x99s objections to Melilla\xe2\x80\x99s freshened barbed wire reveals something even more horribly intimate: In an attempt to control our borders, we\xe2\x80\x99ve designed systems to physically hurt those who defy them. The walls act upon the flesh.'b'In January 2011, the fencing along the India-Bangladesh border acted upon the flesh of Felani Khatun, 15. Felani\xe2\x80\x99s father, Nurul Islam, had arranged for her to be married to her Bangladeshi cousin. On the morning of her wedding, Nurul paid a pair of cattle smugglers to help him and Felani scale the fence into Bangladesh so they could walk to the village where the groom was waiting. Felani climbed the fence with a bamboo ladder the smugglers provided, but when the barbed wire snagged her blue skirt she panicked and started to scream. The noise alerted Indian border soldiers, who fired their rifles in the direction of the fence.'b'A single bullet pierced Felani\xe2\x80\x99s chest and she sagged, mortally wounded, on the wire. She begged for water for a half-hour before finally bleeding to death. Felani hung upside down, a memento mori fixed into place by the barbs, until morning sun burned away the fog and the border soldiers pulled her down. They tied her hands and feet to a bamboo pole and carried her away like a butchered animal.'b'Barbed wire also spins cruel calligraphy along the United States-Mexico frontier, but crossers have more to fear than just the violence of the barbs. Doctors at the University of Arizona Medical Center treat about 40 migrants each year for broken bones and spinal injuries suffered from falls off the border walls.'b'There are bullet wounds, too. According to a 2013 investigation by The Arizona Republic newspaper, American border patrol agents have killed 42 people since 2005. Some, like the teenager Jos\xc3\xa9 Antonio Elena Rodr\xc3\xadguez, were killed on the south side of the border by American agents shooting through the wall into Mexico.'b'Female migrants risk an even more intimate violence. Border activists speak about \xe2\x80\x9crape trees\xe2\x80\x9d in the borderlands of Arizona and California where human smugglers, many connected with Mexican drug cartels, pause their journey to rape their female charges. When they finish, the rapists hang their victims\xe2\x80\x99 bras and panties on the branches as a morbid accounting of their conquests.'b'Those granted passage through the walls must offer up their flesh in some way or another, too. Palestinian laborers press their bodies through steel chutes and turnstiles each morning to reach jobs in Israel. Elsewhere in the West Bank, farmers lift their shirts in front of young Israeli soldiers before receiving permission to work their own fields \xe2\x80\x94 their exposed midriffs proof they are not wired to explode.'b'Even when the walls don\xe2\x80\x99t cause the body pain, they demand, at least, some brief physical humiliation.'b'In 1876, a barbed wire salesman, John Gates, enclosed a few head of ferocious bulls within a barbed wire pen in San Antonio\xe2\x80\x99s central plaza. Reviel Netz writes about the scene in his book \xe2\x80\x9cBarbed Wire: An Ecology of Modernity.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Gates deliberately provoked the longhorns who then charged the fence, only to be repulsed by the barbs that tore into their flesh. \xe2\x80\x9cTheir wounds exacerbate their rage,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Netz writes. The bulls continued to throw themselves against the wire until their agony led to an instinctive withdrawal and resignation. Finally, they stopped trying to breach the fence.'b'The bloody spectacle proved that through the application of pain, even the fiercest beast can learn to respect a border. \xe2\x80\x9cOur skins,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Netz writes, \xe2\x80\x9cjust a little beneath the surface, are endowed with special nerves activated by pressure rising above rather low thresholds. You can use those nerves against us. By cutting through the boundary of our skins, you can act to protect the boundaries of your property, your prison, your border.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is also what our walls do. They exploit our bodies\xe2\x80\x99 low threshold for pain. Beneath the high-minded ideals of security and sovereignty lies the grim truth that we\xe2\x80\x99ve designed the walls to hurt people. We opt to control movement across sensitive geography by inflicting agony upon the flesh. We need to confront the inhumanity of how we choose to defend our lines and, like Bishop Santiago, see the barbarism in the barbed wire we uncoil.'b''b'\n'b'Marcello Di Cintio 'b' is the author, most recently, of \xe2\x80\x9cWalls: Travels Along the Barricades.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Singapore\xe2\x80\x99s tourism receipts doubled to $18 billion within two years of opening the Marina Bay Sands and Sentosa casino resorts in 2010, and visitor arrivals jumped nearly 50 percent. Lured by Singapore\xe2\x80\x99s success, the Taiwan Legislature could soon allow the opening of casinos. And Japan, with an official goal of tripling the number of foreign tourists in 20 years, is considering building casinos. Analysts believe that gambling in Japan could generate gross revenue of $15 billion annually.'b'But these countries should also pay attention to another aspect of Singapore\xe2\x80\x99s experience apart from revenue. Singapore has gone to considerable lengths to shield some of its most vulnerable people from the negative social consequences of gambling. Promoters naturally emphasize the positives of gambling, mainly how casinos attract foreigners and their money. But they say little about the negatives: addiction, broken families and criminal activities like loan-sharking, all of which fall heavily on local communities and on low-income groups. To dampen these effects, Singapore levies an $80 casino entrance fee on local residents, while foreigners enter free. After a 2011 survey showed an increasing proportion of low-income gamblers playing with ever-larger sums, the state decided to prohibit entry by the unemployed, people on welfare and people who have filed for bankruptcy protection.'b'As South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s experience shows, local residents generate lots of money. Of the country\xe2\x80\x99s 17 licensed casinos, only one, Kangwon Land Resort, in a remote mountain area more than 100 miles from Seoul, is open to locals. But its revenue, about $1 billion annually, exceeds that of the other 16 foreigners-only casinos combined.'b'Casino investments under consideration in Taiwan and Japan could total several billion dollars. The promoters, of course, advertise gambling as a revenue-producing leisure activity. But if these investments go forward, both countries need to consider the downside and, at the very least, seek ways to curb addictive and self-destructive behavior.'b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The \xe2\x80\x98How Are You?\xe2\x80\x99 Culture Clash'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Jan. 20):'b'Alina Simone illustrates a universal of cross-cultural communication: the tendency to take literally expressions that members of another culture use idiomatically. Greetings are prime examples because they are among the most ritualized expressions in any culture.'b'While Americans seem hypocritical to Russians because we ask \xe2\x80\x9chow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d when we don\xe2\x80\x99t want a medical report (and reply \xe2\x80\x9cfine\xe2\x80\x9d when we aren\xe2\x80\x99t), both Russians and Americans in Java or the Philippines might find it intrusive to be asked \xe2\x80\x9cwhere are you going?,\xe2\x80\x9d not recognizing the question as a formulaic greeting, the expected answer to which is \xe2\x80\x9cover there.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xc2\xa0And Burmese or Cambodians who ask \xe2\x80\x9chave you eaten yet?\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0(literally, \xe2\x80\x9chave you eaten rice?\xe2\x80\x9d)\xc2\xa0may be misheard by Westerners as issuing an invitation to lunch\xc2\xa0when they are simply saying hello.\xc2\xa0'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s sad is how ready we all are to draw negative conclusions about members of a different culture because they so clearly don\xe2\x80\x99t mean what they say, even as we ourselves are blithely using idioms and formulaic expressions without giving a thought to what a literal interpretation of their meaning would imply \xe2\x80\x94 or would lead outsiders to think about us.'b'DEBORAH TANNEN'b'\nWashington, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of linguistics at Georgetown.'b''b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'As a Briton born of Swedish parents and married to a Russian, I have complicated views on the casual use of \xe2\x80\x9chow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Alina Simone\xe2\x80\x99s Russian father was right to scoff at the suggestion that it was the Soviets who devalued \xe2\x80\x9cfine\xe2\x80\x9d as a reply.
