GREENE'b'\nHamden, Conn., Jan. 8, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is president-elect of the American Group Psychotherapy Association and on the clinical faculty of the Yale University department of psychiatry.'b''b'SEATTLE \xe2\x80\x94 My city is famous for its retail exports: coffee and Costco, Microsoft and Macklemore, Boeing\xe2\x80\x99s jetliners and Jeff Bezos\xe2\x80\x99s business model. This week, a boast by a man with number 25 on his chest turned all eyes to Seattle. But it should have been the claim by the city\xe2\x80\x99s most famous billionaire that got more attention.'b'The first gasconade was uttered by Richard Sherman, the Seattle Seahawks all-pro cornerback, who let his adrenaline speak for him after making a play that sent my hometown boys to the Super Bowl. Sherman is not just the best corner in the game \xe2\x80\x94 as he let the world know \xe2\x80\x94 but a thoughtful, generous, bright guy from Stanford by way of Compton\xe2\x80\x99s Dominguez High, where he ranked second in his class.'b'His postgame rant, one-part early Muhammad Ali and one-part pro-wrestling swagger, brought out a torrent of overt racism on the Internet \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cporch monkey\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthug\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cgangster\xe2\x80\x9d were the printable epithets. Most of this came on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday.'b'Thug, as Sherman noted Wednesday after apologizing for letting his words outshine his teammates, \xe2\x80\x9cseems like the accepted way of calling someone the n-word nowadays.\xe2\x80\x9d He shrugged it off with good humor, and asked people to look at the man outside the organized brutality of football.'b'The billionaire, Bill Gates \xe2\x80\x94 with a net worth of $72 billion, he was ranked by Forbes as the nation\xe2\x80\x99s richest person last year \xe2\x80\x94 made a far smaller splash with a far bigger pronouncement. His boast, more of a prediction, was that \xe2\x80\x9cby 2035, there will be almost no poor countries left in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy almost any measure, the world is better off than it has ever been,\xe2\x80\x9d Gates wrote. \xe2\x80\x9cPeople are living longer, healthier lives. Many nations that were aid recipients are now self-sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Like Sherman, Gates backed up his claim. And in his own monotonic, muss-haired way, the billionaire threw out a provocation on the eve of the Super Bowl of his class \xe2\x80\x94 the annual scrum of Big Picture Thinkers at Davos, Switzerland. His assertion arrived on the heels of an Oxfam report that just 85 billionaires controlled as much wealth as the world\xe2\x80\x99s poorest 3.5 billion people.'b'The idea that half the world\xe2\x80\x99s population is worth only as much as a gathering in a large Swiss chalet was designed to shock. But it shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be misinterpreted. Oxfam suggested closing tax loopholes and raising wages as solutions. These are fine ideas, but they aren\xe2\x80\x99t nearly as effective as the remedies outlined by Gates.'b'The Microsoft billionaire\xe2\x80\x99s prescriptions \xe2\x80\x94 titled \xe2\x80\x9cThree myths that block progress for the poor\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 were contained in 'b'the latest newsletter'b' of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, started 14 years ago with the intent of giving away the family fortune.'b'First, he debunks the notion that poor countries are doomed to stay poor. In the year that Gates was born, 1955, most countries in the world were poor. Since then, more than one billion people have risen out of extreme poverty. As he points out, that still leaves at least another billion at the very bottom. But progress has been so swift, he says, that within 21 years, there will be no poor nations left on earth except those held back by war, politics or geography (a big bunch of asterisks, to be sure).'b'Second, he takes on the hardened myth that foreign aid is a big waste. The United States spends less than 1 percent of its budget helping other countries. For that, we get a big bang for the buck. Since 2000, for example, a global effort by governments and philanthropies to eliminate malaria has saved 3.3 million lives.'b'The third point knocks down an old excuse used by the callous: that saving lives leads to overpopulation. The Malthusian myth is just that. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is that a laissez-faire approach to development \xe2\x80\x94 letting children die now so they won\xe2\x80\x99t starve later \xe2\x80\x94 doesn\xe2\x80\x99t actually work,\xe2\x80\x9d writes Melinda Gates. As people become better off and better educated, they have fewer children, and population stabilizes.'b"Money spent on relatively small, specific things can make the difference between life and death. The leading causes of mortality for children under 3, by far, are preventable diseases. Yes, preventable \xe2\x80\x94 with vaccines, early diagnoses, water purification. That\xe2\x80\x99s one reason the Gates Foundation has targeted disparities in health care. \xe2\x80\x9cA child\xe2\x80\x99s fate,\xe2\x80\x9d Bill Gates writes, \xe2\x80\x9cshould not be left to what Warren Buffett calls \xe2\x80\x98the ovarian lottery.'\xe2\x80\x9d"b'All of this is backed by the experience of Gates and like-minded rich people. Along with Mark Zuckerberg, T. Boone Pickens, Buffett and others, these billionaires have taken the Giving Pledge: a commitment to dedicate a majority of their wealth to philanthropy. (Conspicuously missing: the Koch Brothers, Charles and David, listed as the fourth wealthiest Americans by Forbes.) You can see the full list of giving pledgers 'b'here'b'.'b'If the 85 richest people on the planet took the pledge, it would hasten the audacious prediction of Bill Gates, whose life story is an example of how quickly things can change. Less than 20 years ago, Gates was called a high-tech robber baron, a predator, heartless. Few predicted that thousands of people would be alive today because Gates put his money to work in the right places.'b'Richard Sherman regularly goes back to Dominguez High with a message for kids trying to survive in a very tough neighborhood. Yes, football made him a star. But education got him out of Compton. His life story, like the prediction that Gates made this week, sends the same message: nothing is intractable.'b'OBSERVERS of our polarized democracy often blame party primaries for producing some of our most extreme politicians. It\xe2\x80\x99s well known that the most vociferous and partisan activists have a disproportionate influence in primaries.'b'Less well known is this: 44 states have \xe2\x80\x9csore loser\xe2\x80\x9d laws of one form or another. These laws effectively block a candidate who fails to win a party primary from appearing on the general election ballot, as either an independent or as the nominee of another party.'b'These laws deprive voters of a full array of choices. They are arguably even more insidious than partisan redistricting, which affects House races but not Senate ones.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s an example. In the 2012 Republican Senate primary in Texas, David Dewhurst, the relatively moderate lieutenant governor, won 46 percent of the vote, while the Tea Party favorite Ted Cruz, running an aggressively conservative campaign, won only 33 percent. In the primary runoff, Mr. Cruz beat Mr. Dewhurst \xe2\x80\x94 but with just 630,000 Republican votes, in a state of 26 million people.'b'Why didn\xe2\x80\x99t the popular Mr. Dewhurst, a proven vote-getter, simply challenge Mr. Cruz in the general election, when all Texans could vote? Under Texas\xe2\x80\x99 sore loser law, once Mr. Dewhurst lost the primary, he was no longer eligible to have his name on the ballot in November. Given that Texas is virtually a one-party state, Mr. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s relatively small vote total, combined with the sore-loser law, was all he needed to go to Washington and then orchestrate a shutdown of the federal government.'b'And Mr. Cruz\xe2\x80\x99s victory was a model of pure democracy compared to what happened in Utah two years earlier.'b'There, Republicans begin the nominating process with a convention of party activists. In the first round of voting for a Senate nominee, in 2010, the incumbent, Robert Bennett, finished third, about a hundred votes behind a conservative activist, Mike Lee. The top three finishers then went to a second round; again, Mr. Bennett came in third, this time trailing Mr. Lee by 320 votes. Mr. Bennett was eliminated and was not eligible to participate in the subsequent runoff primary, which Mr. Lee won.'b'There were a mere 3,500 people at this convention. Mr. Bennett would almost certainly have won a vote in which all Utah voters had been able to participate: the state\xe2\x80\x99s sore-loser law meant that 320 party activists effectively made a decision on behalf of the three million people of Utah.'b'Of course, sometimes victory by extremists backfires in the general election, particularly in states that are not dominated by one party (as Texas and Utah are). In 2010, Representative Michael N. Castle of Delaware, a respected moderate, 'b'lost'b' a low-turnout Republican primary to Christine O\xe2\x80\x99Donnell, who in turn went down in defeat in the general election over questions about her educational credentials, her ignorance of the Constitution and her fondness for witchcraft.'b'There is a better way. In 2006, liberal Democrats were determined to end the career of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman (their party\xe2\x80\x99s vice-presidential nominee in 2000) over his support for the Iraq war. He lost to Ned Lamont in a primary. But Connecticut is one of three states that have partisan primaries or caucuses, but no sore-loser law (Iowa and New York are the others). Mr. Lieberman was thus able to run \xe2\x80\x94 and win \xe2\x80\x94 in the general election, as an independent.'b'And in California, Louisiana and Washington, the primary election is open to candidates of any party, and the top two finishers advance to the general election, so parties cannot use election law to winnow the field.'b'Advocates of open primaries argue that letting all voters choose among all the candidates, regardless of party, forces candidates to make a broader appeal, resulting in more moderate or centrist candidates. The political scientists Barry C. Burden, Bradley Jones and Michael S. Kang 'b'found'b' that in states with sore-loser laws, congressional candidates were more ideologically distant from one another \xe2\x80\x94 that is, more polarized \xe2\x80\x94 than in states without them.'b'That may well be a sufficient reason for reformers to seek the repeal of sore-loser laws, but in my view, it\xe2\x80\x99s not the most important reason. For one thing, the political \xe2\x80\x9ccenter\xe2\x80\x9d is not always the right place to be (it certainly wasn\xe2\x80\x99t in the pursuit of civil rights and women\xe2\x80\x99s rights, or on issues like slavery and child labor). Compassion toward candidates who find their political prospects cut short is also of little interest to me.'b'What matters is the restoration of American democracy: giving voters the fullest range of choices when it comes to selecting their leaders. Under sore-loser laws, the real loser is the voters.'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe outstanding faults of the economic society in which we live are its failure to provide for full employment and its arbitrary and inequitable distribution of wealth and incomes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'John Maynard Keynes wrote that in 1936, but it applies to our own time, too. And, in a better world, our leaders would be doing all they could to address both faults.'b'Unfortunately, the world we actually live in falls far short of that ideal. In fact, we should count ourselves lucky when leaders confront even one of our two great economic failures. If, as has been widely reported, President Obama devotes much of his State of the Union address to inequality, everyone should be cheering him on.'b'They won\xe2\x80\x99t, of course. Instead, he will face two kinds of sniping. The usual suspects on the right will, as always when questions of income distribution comes up, shriek \xe2\x80\x9cClass warfare!\xe2\x80\x9d But there will also be seemingly more sober voices arguing that he has picked the wrong target, that jobs, not inequality, should be at the top of his agenda.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s why they\xe2\x80\x99re wrong.'b'First of all, jobs and inequality are closely linked if not identical issues. There\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty good although not ironclad case that 'b'soaring inequality helped set the stage for our economic crisis'b', and that the highly unequal distribution of income since the crisis has perpetuated the slump, especially by making it hard for families in debt to work their way out.'b'Moreover, there\xe2\x80\x99s an even stronger case to be made that high unemployment \xe2\x80\x94 by destroying workers\xe2\x80\x99 bargaining power \xe2\x80\x94 has become 'b'a major source of rising inequality and stagnating incomes'b' even for those lucky enough to have jobs.'b'Beyond that, as a political matter, inequality and macroeconomic policy are already inseparably linked. It has been obvious for a long time that the deficit obsession that has exerted such a destructive effect on policy these past few years isn\xe2\x80\x99t really driven by worries about the federal debt. It is, instead, mainly an effort to use debt fears to scare and bully the nation into slashing social programs \xe2\x80\x94 especially programs that help the poor. For example, 'b'two-thirds of the spending cuts proposed last year by Representative Paul Ryan'b', the chairman of the House Budget Committee, would have come at the expense of lower-income families.'b'The flip side of this attempt to use fiscal scare tactics to worsen inequality is that highlighting concerns about inequality can translate into pushback against job-destroying austerity, too.'b'But the most important reason for Mr. Obama to focus on inequality is political realism. Like it or not, the simple fact is that Americans \xe2\x80\x9cget\xe2\x80\x9d inequality; macroeconomics, not so much.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s an enduring myth among the punditocracy that populism doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sell, that Americans don\xe2\x80\x99t care about the gap between the rich and everyone else. It\xe2\x80\x99s not true. Yes, we\xe2\x80\x99re a nation that admires rather than resents success, but most people are nonetheless disturbed by the extreme disparities of our Second Gilded Age. 'b'A new Pew poll finds'b' an overwhelming majority of Americans \xe2\x80\x94 and 45 percent of Republicans! \xe2\x80\x94 supporting government action to reduce inequality, with a smaller but still substantial majority favoring taxing the rich to aid the poor. And this is true even though 'b'most Americans don\xe2\x80\x99t realize just how unequally wealth really is distributed'b'.'b'By contrast, it\xe2\x80\x99s very hard to communicate even the most basic truths of macroeconomics, like the need to run deficits to support employment in bad times. You can argue that Mr. Obama should have tried harder to get these ideas across; many economists cringed when he began echoing Republican rhetoric about the need for 'b'the federal government to tighten its belt along with America\xe2\x80\x99s families'b'. But, even if he had tried, it\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful that he would have succeeded.'b''b'Consider what happened in 1936'b'. F.D.R. had just won a smashing re-election victory, largely because of the success of his deficit-spending policies. It\xe2\x80\x99s often forgotten now, but his first term was marked by rapid economic recovery and sharply falling unemployment. But the public remained wedded to economic orthodoxy: by a more than 2-to-1 majority, voters surveyed by Gallup just after the election called for a balanced budget. And F.D.R., unfortunately, listened; his attempt to balance the budget soon plunged America back into recession.'b'The point is that of the two great problems facing the U.S. economy, inequality is the one on which Mr. Obama is most likely to connect with voters. And he should seek that connection with a clear conscience: There\xe2\x80\x99s no shame is acknowledging political reality, as long as you\xe2\x80\x99re trying to do the right thing.'b'So I hope we\xe2\x80\x99ll hear something about jobs Tuesday night, and some pushback against deficit hysteria. But if we mainly hear about inequality and social justice, that\xe2\x80\x99s O.K.'b'Rules issued in November to stop banks from emulating predatory payday lenders have yielded promising results. The rules, issued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, have led several banks to discontinue \xe2\x80\x9cdeposit advance\xe2\x80\x9d loans that are specifically designed to trap people in debt. But consumers will remain vulnerable to versions of the debt trap until another agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, issues rules of its own to protect consumers of small loans from excessive and unaffordable costs.'b'Payday lenders attract customers by promising small loans that can easily be repaid on the borrower\xe2\x80\x99s next payday \xe2\x80\x94 customarily in two weeks. Unfortunately, most borrowers are unable to repay on the agreed date and end up borrowing again and again, at ruinously high interest rates. Deposit advance loans work the same way, except the bank repays itself from an electronic deposit that comes into the borrowers account.'b'The rules from the F.D.I.C. and the O.C.C. attacked this vicious cycle by requiring the banks to determine if the borrowers could pay their debts, limited them to one loan per monthly statement cycle and said they could not grant a new loan until the previous one was paid off. Several big banks have since 'b'announced'b' that they are getting out of the deposit advance business.'b'But new forms of exploitation will invariably arise unless the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau writes broad affordability rules of its own. These rules, 'b'suggested by'b' The Pew Charitable Trusts\xe2\x80\x99 Safe Small-Dollar Loans Research Project, would limit monthly loan payments to 5 percent of the borrowers\xe2\x80\x99 pretax income, spread the costs of fees and interest over the life of the loan and require clear disclosure of all costs. Rules like these will give unsuspecting borrowers even more protection from being ambushed by debt.'b'It was a shock to learn from the latest surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report that, because of changes in the design and composition of cigarettes, smokers today face a higher risk of lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease than smokers in 1964, despite smoking fewer cigarettes. It is equally shocking to learn now that some of today\xe2\x80\x99s cigarettes may be more addictive than those smoked in past years, most likely because the manufacturers are designing them to deliver more nicotine to the lungs to induce and sustain addiction. That devious tactic requires a strong response by regulators.'b'A 'b'report'b' published last week in the journal Nicotine and Tobacco Research found that while the nicotine content of cigarettes has remained relatively stable for more than a decade, the amount of that nicotine delivered to the machines researchers use as surrogates for smokers has been rising. The researchers, from the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and the University of Massachusetts Medical School, analyzed data from four manufacturers as required by state law. The findings varied among the companies and brands, but the overall trend led the researchers to conclude that changes in cigarette design have increased the efficiency of delivering nicotine to a smoker\xe2\x80\x99s lungs. Young people who experiment with smoking may thus become addicted more easily and existing smokers may find it harder to quit.'b'Those provocative findings will need to be verified by other experts but are consistent with the 'b'surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report'b'. That report, issued on Jan. 17, found that some of today\xe2\x80\x99s cigarettes are more addictive than those from earlier decades, based on the findings of a Federal District Court judge in 2006 who had access to industry documents spelling out how cigarettes were designed to make them more addictive. The industry\xe2\x80\x99s tactics included designing filters and selecting cigarette paper to maximize the ingestion of nicotine and adding chemicals to make cigarettes taste less harsh and easier to inhale deeply.'b'Nicotine itself, in addition to its addictive qualities, has harmful effects on the human body. The surgeon general\xe2\x80\x99s report concluded that nicotine activates biological pathways that increase the risk for disease, adversely affects maternal and fetal health during pregnancy, and can have lasting adverse consequences for brain development in fetuses and adolescents. At high doses, nicotine is toxic and sometimes lethal. A rapid increase in nicotine blood levels can also raise heart rate and blood pressure and narrow arteries around the heart.'b'Still, the main problem is that nicotine addicts people to smoking, which exposes them to a host of toxic ingredients. Regulators will need to find ways to block the designs, ingredients and marketing strategies that increase the amount of nicotine taken in by smokers.'b'Mayor Bill de Blasio, swiftly delivering on a campaign promise, joined the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, last week in 'b'offering a bill'b' to revise New York City\xe2\x80\x99s law on paid sick leave. Their bill is broader than one that passed last year after much delay and political spatting. It\xe2\x80\x99s also better.'b'The existing law, set to take effect in April, requires companies with 20 or more workers to provide at least five paid sick days a year, eventually lowering the threshold to 15 workers. The new bill applies to companies with five or more workers, protecting an estimated 360,000 more people than the existing law. It eliminates the current law\xe2\x80\x99s 18-month phase-in period and a trigger to delay implementation if the economy lags.'b'Mr. de Blasio and Ms. Mark-Viverito unveiled the bill with a rally in Brooklyn, emphatically sending the message that the city\xe2\x80\x99s political center of gravity has shifted toward working families and the poor. A more cautious mayor might have been content to let the existing law take effect in April, wait to see how enforcement and compliance worked out and consult with the Council and business community on improving it. But the impatience of Mr. de Blasio and his allies is understandable after more than a decade of Republican mayors and sometimes tooth-and-nail battles over sensible laws like paid sick leave.'b'Mayor de Blasio, who essentially installed Ms. Mark-Viverito as his partner in progressivism, shares with her a mission to pursue an unabashedly liberal agenda in areas like jobs, health care and housing. It\xe2\x80\x99s clearly in his interest to show that the change he promised is on its way. Helping workers, especially single parents, to avoid that awful choice \xe2\x80\x94 dragging themselves to a job from a sickbed or losing a day\xe2\x80\x99s pay \xe2\x80\x94 is not just a potent symbolic gesture, but also good policy.'b'Once again, a thorough and independent analysis of the government\xe2\x80\x99s dragnet surveillance of Americans\xe2\x80\x99 phone records 'b'has found'b' the bulk data collection to be illegal and probably unconstitutional. Just as troubling, the program was found to be virtually useless at stopping terrorism, raising the obvious question: Why does President Obama insist on continuing a costly, legally dubious program when his own appointees repeatedly find that it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work?'b'In a 238-page report issued Thursday afternoon, the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, a five-member independent agency, called on the White House to end the phone-data collection program, for both constitutional and practical reasons. The board\xe2\x80\x99s report follows a 'b'Dec. 16 ruling'b' by Federal District Judge Richard Leon that 'b'the program'b' was \xe2\x80\x9calmost certainly\xe2\x80\x9d unconstitutional and that the government had not identified \xe2\x80\x9ca single instance\xe2\x80\x9d in which it \xe2\x80\x9cactually stopped an imminent attack.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Two days later, a panel of legal and intelligence experts convened by Mr. Obama after the disclosures by Edward Snowden 'b'echoed those conclusions'b' in its own comprehensive 'b'report'b', which said the data sweep \xe2\x80\x9cwas not essential to preventing attacks\xe2\x80\x9d and called for its end.'b'The growing agreement among those who have studied the program closely makes it imperative that the administration, along with the program\xe2\x80\x99s defenders in Congress, explain why such intrusive mass surveillance is necessary at all. If Mr. Obama knows something that contradicts what he has now been told by two panels, a federal judge and multiple members of Congress, he should tell the American people now. Otherwise, he is in essence asking for their blind faith, which is precisely what he warned against 'b'during his speech last week'b' on the future of government surveillance.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGiven the unique power of the state,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama said, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not enough for leaders to say: trust us, we won\xe2\x80\x99t abuse the data we collect. For history has too many examples when that trust has been breached.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The more likely reality is that the multiple analyses of recent weeks are correct, and that the phone-data sweeps have simply been ineffective. If they had assisted in the prevention of any terrorist attacks, it is safe to assume that we would know by now. Instead, despite 'b'repeated claims'b' that the bulk-data collection programs had a hand in thwarting 54 terrorist plots, the privacy board members write, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have not identified a single instance involving a threat to the United States in which the telephone records program made a concrete difference in the outcome of a counterterrorism investigation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That reiterates the findings of Judge Leon \xe2\x80\x94 who noted that even behind closed doors, the government provided \xe2\x80\x9cno proof\xe2\x80\x9d of the program\xe2\x80\x99s efficacy \xe2\x80\x94 as well as the conclusion of a 'b'report released this month by the New America Foundation'b' that the metadata program \xe2\x80\x9chad no discernible impact on preventing acts of terrorism and only the most marginal of impacts on preventing terrorist-related activity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'No one disputes that the threat of terrorism is real and unrelenting, or that our intelligence techniques must adapt to a rapidly changing world. It is equally clear that the dragnet collection of Americans\xe2\x80\x99 phone calls is not the answer.'b'Over the past decade we\xe2\x80\x99ve had a rich debate on how to expand opportunity for underprivileged children. But we\xe2\x80\x99ve probably made two mistakes.'b'First, we\xe2\x80\x99ve probably placed too much emphasis on early education. Don\xe2\x80\x99t get me wrong. What happens in the early years is crucial. But human capital development takes a generation. If you really want to make an impact, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to have a developmental strategy for all the learning stages, ages 0 to 25.'b'Second, we\xe2\x80\x99ve probably put too much weight on school reform. Again, reforming education is important. But getting the academics right is not going to get you far if millions of students can\xe2\x80\x99t control their impulses, can\xe2\x80\x99t form attachments, don\xe2\x80\x99t possess resilience and lack social and emotional skills.'b'So when President Obama talks about expanding opportunity in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping he\xe2\x80\x99ll widen the debate. I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping he\xe2\x80\x99ll sketch out a stage-by-stage developmental agenda to help poor children move from birth to the middle class.'b'Such an agenda would start before birth. First, children need parents who are ready to care for them. But right now roughly half-a-million children are born each year as a result of unintended pregnancies, often to unmarried women who are not on contraception or are trying to use contraceptives like condoms or the pill. As the University of Pennsylvania\xe2\x80\x99s Rebecca Maynard and Isabel Sawhill and Quentin Karpilow of the Brookings Institution have argued, if these women had free access to long-acting reversible contraceptives like I.U.D.\xe2\x80\x99s, then the number of unintended births might decline and the number of children with unready parents might fall, too.'b'Once born, children are generally better off if they grow up within a loving two-parent marriage. It would be great if we knew how to boost marriage rates, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'For the time being, we probably should spend less time thinking about marriage and more time thinking about parenting skills. As Richard Reeves, also of Brookings, points out, if we could teach the weakest parents to behave like average parents \xe2\x80\x94 by reading more to their kids, speaking more, using consistent, encouraging discipline \xe2\x80\x94 then millions of children might have more secure attachments, more structure and better shots at upwardly mobile careers. Programs like Nurse-Family Partnerships and the Baby College in the Harlem Children\xe2\x80\x99s Zone seem to be able to teach these parenting skills.'b'Once they get to elementary school, children need to learn how to read and write. But that can\xe2\x80\x99t happen in schools where 15 percent of the students are disruptive, where large numbers of students live with so much stress that it has stunted the development of the prefrontal cortexes, sent their cortisol levels surging, heightened their anxiety responses and generally made it hard for them to control themselves.'b'Therefore, we probably need more programs like Pamela Cantor\xe2\x80\x99s Turnaround for Children, which works in schools to help teachers and administrators create \xe2\x80\x9cfortified environments,\xe2\x80\x9d in which overstressed children can receive counseling and treatment, in which the psychic traumas that go with poverty are recognized and addressed.'b'According to work done by Sawhill and others, a significant number of kids stay on track through the early years, but then fall off the rails as teenagers. Sawhill set a pretty low bar for having a successful adolescence: graduate from high school with a 2.5 G.P.A., don\xe2\x80\x99t get convicted of a crime, don\xe2\x80\x99t get pregnant. Yet only 57 percent of American 19-year-olds get over that bar. Only one-third of children in the bottom fifth of family income do so.'b'Over the next few years, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to spend a lot more time and money figuring out how to help people from poorer families chart a course through the teenage years. There\xe2\x80\x99s evidence that Career Academies help adolescents navigate the teenage rapids. There\xe2\x80\x99s some evidence that New York\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9csmall schools of choice\xe2\x80\x9d yield measurable results. We as a nation have made awesome progress in reducing teenage pregnancies, so it is possible to change teenage behavior, even in the face of raging hormones.'b'But it is harder to find successful programs geared toward teenagers than it is to find successful programs geared toward younger children. It feels like less money has been raised to help teenagers, fewer innovative programs have been initiated.'b'Robert Putnam of Harvard argues that when we design early education programs, they need to be \xe2\x80\x9cwrap-around.\xe2\x80\x9d They need to have formal and informal programs that bring parents in and instill communal skills. With teenagers, we need more guidance counselors to help them become savvy, so they know how to work the system, and to respond when their needs aren\xe2\x80\x99t being met.'b'Putnam is emphasizing skills \xe2\x80\x94 for toddlers or teenagers \xe2\x80\x94 that are hard to see and measure. But that\xe2\x80\x99s the next frontier of human capital development: Building lifelong social and emotional development strategies from age 0 to 25. I\xe2\x80\x99m hoping President Obama goes there.'b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Bosnia\xe2\x80\x99s lessons for Syria'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Opinion, Jan. 22) by Philippe Leroux-Martin: There are certainly lessons to be learned from Bosnia for Syria. Alas, it seems few if any have been heeded.'b'It was not simply Richard C. Holbrooke\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cdiplomatic surge\xe2\x80\x9d that led to the Dayton peace talks: a NATO bombing campaign and a combined Bosnian-Croatian Army offensive were instrumental in creating the right frame of mind for the Bosnian Serbs and Serbia. For the first time, the Bosnian Serbs were losing \xe2\x80\x94 posing a threat to Slobodan Milosevic\xe2\x80\x99s rule should their lines break and forcing a wave of refugees toward Serbia, which occurred in August 1995 during Croatia\xe2\x80\x99s Operation Storm. This is no knock on diplomacy, but it contextualizes the environment in which it could succeed.'b'There is no parallel to the Geneva II talks. As recently as a year ago, Western military intervention \xe2\x80\x94 specifically striking Bashar al-Assad\xe2\x80\x99s air force and columns of ground forces on the major roads between fronts \xe2\x80\x94 could have created a parallel dynamic by limiting the overstretched Syrian Army\xe2\x80\x99s mobility and fighting effectiveness. Now, due to the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s unwillingness to act, the correlation of forces has shifted, making such an application of force less likely to achieve the desired result of forcing Mr. Assad from power or into negotiations from a position of weakness. Less savory opposition actors have also proliferated in the intervening year, also as a result of nonintervention.'b'Mr. Leroux-Martin mentions the Serbian and Croatian roles at Dayton. Yet Mr. Milosevic and Franjo Tudjman represented Bosnia\xe2\x80\x99s Serbs and Croats at the negotiations because they were effectively co-belligerents who could literally call the shots with their local allies. No external power exerts a parallel weight in Syria, though there is no doubt that Russia, Iran and the Gulf states have influence in the war.'b'I agree completely that diplomacy is effective in shaping \xe2\x80\x9cfuture behavior through electoral and constitutional engineering.\xe2\x80\x9d This is why I pray that the Syrians don\xe2\x80\x99t get saddled with a power-sharing deal anything like Dayton, which has preserved oligarchical warlord politics in Bosnia, albeit with a democratic veneer. Galbraith, Townshend, Vt.'b''b'The writer served as the deputy special representative of the United Nations in Afghanistan in 2009.'b'\xc2\xa0'b''b'Spain\xe2\x80\x99s regressive abortion bill 'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Spain\xe2\x80\x99s alarming abortion debate'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Editorial, Jan. 18): When a country severely restricts women\xe2\x80\x99s access to abortion, as Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy is proposing in Spain, it shames and stigmatizes all women who may need to end a pregnancy. 'b''b'Regarding \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Twitter-bashing bores'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 21): Roger Cohen\xe2\x80\x99s injunction \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt not complain about social media\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 ignores the fact that some laments are legitimate, like Philip Roth\xe2\x80\x99s observation that well-crafted prose is losing its audience. That generally beneficial trade has also generated huge emissions of pollutants like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides that are swiftly transported elsewhere by global winds \xe2\x80\x94 in addition, of course, to adding significantly to carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas.'b'According to the study, which was published\xc2\xa0in\xc2\xa0The Proceedings of the\xc2\xa0National Academy of Sciences, emissions linked to China\xe2\x80\x99s exports\xc2\xa0caused increases in surface sulfate concentrations (a combination of sulfur dioxide and other gases) of between 3 percent and 10 percent in the Western United States in 2006, as well as a smaller increase in ozone-producing pollutants. In Los Angeles, that increased pollution was responsible for causing at least one extra day of smog per year that exceeded federal ozone limits. The report also estimated that the outsourcing of production to China resulted in less pollution in the Eastern United States, because there were fewer emissions from upwind factories in the East and Midwest.'b'The study provides further evidence that Beijing could and should do more to reduce pollution, which ultimately hurts people in that country much more than it does Americans.\xc2\xa0The study, which was written by a team of American and Chinese researchers, estimates that China could cut its emissions of sulfur dioxide by up to 62 percent and nitrogen oxides by up to 22 percent by requiring factories to install energy-efficiency and emission-control technologies as effective as those used in the United States.'b'More broadly speaking, the report\xe2\x80\x99s findings demonstrate that trade and global pollution patterns inextricably link countries to one another. That means that world leaders must coordinate their efforts to successfully reduce harmful emissions of all kinds. Not nearly enough has been done to rein in carbon dioxide and other greenhouses gases, largely because of fundamental disagreements between rich and developing nations over who should be required to do more.'b'But the technology to control windblown pollutants like sulfur dioxide is readily available. What\xe2\x80\x99s needed is robust investment and political will on the local and regional levels.'b'The French National Assembly\xe2\x80\x99s approval on Jan. 22 of an amendment that frees women seeking an abortion during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy from having to justify their decision is a refreshing step forward for reproductive rights. The bill deletes language from a 1975 law that gave women the right to an abortion within 12 weeks if the pregnancy caused \xe2\x80\x9cdistress.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'France\xe2\x80\x99s minister for women\xe2\x80\x99s rights, Najat Vallaud-Belkacem, said that in light of the Spanish government\xe2\x80\x99s proposal to severely limit abortion, it was more important than ever for France to reject any presumed moral justification for depriving women of the freedom to manage their own bodies.'b'The amendment is part of a gender-equality bill that is the most comprehensive legislation on women\xe2\x80\x99s rights in the history of France. The bill seeks to give women parity with men by improving wages, strengthening laws against domestic violence and providing for equal representation in politics.'b'The bill also encourages fathers to seek parental leave to care for a new baby by offering six additional months of paid leave if taken by the second parent. In addition, it bans beauty pageants for girls under 13 and expands support for single mothers. Companies that do not show progress on workplace equality face monthly fines of up to 1 percent of their wage base. The bill enjoins the media from broadcasting sexist or demeaning images of women. The French Senate passed the bill last September.'b'Women in France earn, on average, 25 percent less than their male counterparts. They make up only 27 percent of the Assembly and 22 percent of the Senate. Only 3 percent of chief executives in France are women.'b'This bill puts France at the forefront of efforts to address persistent discrimination against women. Given threats to women\xe2\x80\x99s rights elsewhere in Europe and the world \xe2\x80\x94 including access to legal abortion \xe2\x80\x94 lawmakers\xe2\x80\x99 commitment to back pieties about equality with strong legislation is a welcome example of what governments can do to support equal rights and equal opportunities for women.'b'The European Union weighs in.'b'NEW DELHI \xe2\x80\x94 The Africans \xe2\x80\x94 Nigerians, Ghanaians, Ugandans \xe2\x80\x94 began leaving my neighborhood in New Delhi around December. Each week, more and more families exited. Some went to parts of Delhi considered more accepting of Africans; others to areas where the residents were thought to be less interfering in general. I have heard that some of the Ghanaian families had gone back to Africa, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know that for sure.'b'For years, they had been a part of the swirl of cultures, languages and races that makes up this part of the capital. The Nigerian women in their bright dresses out for evening strolls and the Cameroonian family with the curious-eyed baby at the ice-cream van had made a life for themselves alongside the Afghans, Tamils and Iranians.'b'On Oct. 31, about a month before the departures started, a Nigerian national, rumored to have been in the drug trade, was found dead in Goa. Nigerians in the coastal state protested his murder as an act of racism, while posters read: \xe2\x80\x9cWe want peace in Goa. Say no to Nigerians. Say no to drugs.\xe2\x80\x9d One state minister threatened to throw out Nigerians living illegally. Another equated them with a cancer. He later apologized, adding that he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t imagined there would be a \xe2\x80\x9cproblem\xe2\x80\x9d with his statement.'b'The controversy has reverberated across the country, including in Delhi, 1,200 miles away, where the tolerance of African neighbors has turned into suspicion and even hostility.'b'One night, a police constable rang my doorbell. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen any man from the Congo entering and leaving the building?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cAfrican man,\xe2\x80\x9d he clarified. He said he had received a report that a local resident was friendly with Africans, and he wanted to know, was this true? The question surprised me; neighborhood battles here are waged over water and parking spaces, not over ethnicity. Now neighbors had become nervous of neighbors.'b'Once the African communities had been singled out, complaints against them bubbled up like filthy water, in Jangpura, in Khirki Extension, in the alleyways off Paharganj, anywhere in Delhi they lived.'b'The fragile hospitality gave way to a familiar litany of intolerance: They were too loud, exuberant and dirty; the women were loose, the men looked you directly in the eye, they were drug takers and traffickers, and worse.'b'Residents of Khirki Extension, whose rambling lanes had seen an influx of artists, journalists and migrants, conducted their own investigation of their African neighbors, which they called the \xe2\x80\x9cblack beauty\xe2\x80\x9d sting.'b'Coinciding with the city\xe2\x80\x99s darkening mood, the newly elected Aam Aadmi Party in Delhi started a wave of cleanups as part of its mission to control \xe2\x80\x9clawlessness.\xe2\x80\x9d The city\xe2\x80\x99s law minister, Somnath Bharti, led a raid into Khirki Extension, claiming to be acting on residents\xe2\x80\x99 complaints that Nigerians and Ugandans were involved in prostitution and drug trafficking. Media reports suggest that on the night of Jan. 15, he entered Africans\xe2\x80\x99 homes with a group of vigilantes, without a warrant. In the fracas, a Ugandan woman was allegedly forced to give a urine sample, on the street, in the middle of the crowd. After she filed a complaint, Delhi\xe2\x80\x99s court ordered the Police Department to pursue her case against Mr. Bharti.'b'These recent events have awakened dormant prejudices against Africans in India, aggravated by our tendency to prize fair skin over dark. \xe2\x80\x9cHabshi,\xe2\x80\x9d derived from the word \xe2\x80\x9cAbyssinian,\xe2\x80\x9d has become a common epithet for people of African descent.'b'So, on one hand, the racist turn in Delhi and Goa is unsurprising. On the other hand, we have a long, and neglected, history of cross-migration with Africa. While Indians have been settling on that continent since at least the 15th century, African roots in India run even deeper. Africans were brought over in numbers around the 13th century as slaves, but also as generals, guards, merchants, bodyguards and craftsmen. Many never went back. Now tens of thousands are here to study, and others work as chefs and in the garment and textile businesses, among other industries.'b'Despite our close ties and the shared history of colonialism, Africa doesn\xe2\x80\x99t figure on the Indian map of curiosity and desire. Our admiration of China\xe2\x80\x99s economic prowess is commonplace and unabashed; we are obsessed with the West, in terms of education, ideals of beauty and economic might. But Africa is invisible. Racist views can be spouted without consequence. Africa simply doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.'b'There will be few repercussions for the Aam Aadmi Party if it continues with blanket policies against Africans. The party won on the promise of change, yet here it is, proving that it shares the same blindness as other, older parties.'b'These days, the Afghans and Indians stroll in my neighborhood park, enjoying the winter breeze. In our greed and foolishness, we destroy other species without a second thought (and set the stage for our own demise).'b'But at least we will have plenty of animal knickknacks to pass on to our great-grandchildren even if no animals remain in the wild.'b'NANCY FEINSTEIN'b'\nPawcatuck, Conn., Jan. 18, 2014'b''b'LAST week, the sports and pop culture website Grantland published a story called \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Dr. V\xe2\x80\x99s Magical Putter'b'\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 a piece of \xe2\x80\x9clong-form,\xe2\x80\x9d as we now call multi-thousand-word, narrative-driven reported articles \xe2\x80\x94 about a woman named Essay Anne Vanderbilt, who claimed to have invented a golf putter of unsurpassed excellence.'b'Over the course of 7,000-plus words, the writer, Caleb Hannan, devoted a lot of space to the contentious relationship he had developed with his subject. Ms. Vanderbilt, who was transgender but in the closet \xe2\x80\x94 and also probably a con artist \xe2\x80\x94 didn\xe2\x80\x99t like Mr. Hannan\xe2\x80\x99s digging into the details of her personal and professional life. In the final few paragraphs of the story, Mr. Hannan revealed some shocking news: Ms. Vanderbilt had killed herself.'b'The piece was initially met with praise from across the Internet. (\xe2\x80\x9cGreat read,\xe2\x80\x9d raved a typical Tweet. \xe2\x80\x9cFascinating, bizarre,\xe2\x80\x9d read another.) Then the criticism started. Mr. Hannan was accused of everything from being grossly insensitive to Ms. Vanderbilt\xe2\x80\x99s privacy to having played a role in her suicide. The controversy soon grew so intense that the editor of the site, Bill Simmons, felt compelled to address it in an apologetic, if defensive, 2,700-word post of his own. Mr. Simmons stressed that the decision to publish the piece had not been taken lightly and that somewhere between 13 and 15 people had read it before it was posted and had all been \xe2\x80\x9cblown away.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Well, institutions make mistakes. Even a group of smart people is capable of doing something dumb. The fact that Ms. Vanderbilt had killed herself \xe2\x80\x94 and that the writer may have been involved in her decision to do so \xe2\x80\x94 obviously could not be relegated to the status of a footnote. But to chalk up \xe2\x80\x9cDr. V\xe2\x80\x99s Magical Putter\xe2\x80\x9d simply to shoddy editing and bad judgment is to miss the bigger picture. Grantland\xe2\x80\x99s decision to publish the piece, like the initial burst of enthusiasm that greeted it, is also a product of the journalistic environment we\xe2\x80\x99re living in. Specifically, the power of the cult of long-form.'b'It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t so many years ago that people assumed the Internet would make long magazine-style stories obsolete. Paradoxically, it now seems to have revived this once threatened medium. Magazines may be disappearing, but that\xe2\x80\x99s O.K.; we still have \xe2\x80\x9clong-form.\xe2\x80\x9d What started as a Twitter signifier (#longreads or #longform), a way to get the attention of people who might be looking for a substantive read, has morphed into its own genre. In the process, a long magazine story went from being one part of a steady diet of journalistic consumption to something artisanal, a treat for connoisseurs.'b'Not only are there websites like Longreads and Longform devoted to curating the best \xe2\x80\x9clong-form\xe2\x80\x9d writing from around the Internet, but even high-metabolism sites like BuzzFeed and Politico are producing their own long-form content. The term confers respectability and connotes something special, something 'b'literary'b'. And sometimes, with the right headline and some breathless re-tweets, long-form can even drive traffic. (See the magazine Pacific Standard\xe2\x80\x99s recent and wildly popular 4,000-word feature on San Francisco\xe2\x80\x99s craze for high-end toast.)'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s behind this revival? Nostalgia, partly, for what only recently had seemed to be a dying art. And technology: High-resolution screens make it much more pleasant to read a long piece online than it was even a few years ago. Also the simple and honorable intention to preserve a particular kind of story, one that\xe2\x80\x99s much different from even a long newspaper feature, with scenes and characters and a narrative arc.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of excellent magazine-length journalism being done now, and Grantland publishes plenty of it. The problem is that long-form stories are too often celebrated simply because they exist. And are long. \xe2\x80\x9cLong-form, on the web, is in danger of meaning \xe2\x80\x98a lot of words,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d as James Bennet wrote recently in The Atlantic, the magazine he edits.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a familiar phenomenon: When you fetishize \xe2\x80\x94 as opposed to value \xe2\x80\x94 something, you wind up celebrating the idea of the thing rather than the thing itself. How many of those people who initially praised \xe2\x80\x9cDr. V\xe2\x80\x99s Magical Putter,\xe2\x80\x9d I wonder, even made it down to those final few paragraphs before taking to Twitter to associate themselves with this great journalistic achievement?'b'When we fetishize \xe2\x80\x9clong-form,\xe2\x80\x9d we are fetishizing the form and losing sight of its function. That\xe2\x80\x99s how a story with a troubled woman who commits suicide at its center gets told as a writer\xe2\x80\x99s quixotic quest to learn everything he can about the maker of a golf club that he stumbled across during a late-night Internet search for tips for his short game. In the 1960s, during the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, the federal government passed a series of laws designed to liberate the mentally ill from the acknowledged horrors of mental hospitals, where they were often confined for decades. The idea was that with the introduction of powerful new antipsychotic drugs, people with schizophrenia could live outside a mental hospital \xe2\x80\x94 and that hospital stays would be much shorter. The federal government gave money to communities to set up local mental health centers as well as housing for the mentally ill.'b'In 1975, this trend was affirmed by the Supreme Court, 'b'which ruled'b' that the mentally ill had a right \xe2\x80\x9cto live in the least restrictive setting necessary for their well-being,\xe2\x80\x9d as Sheehan writes. Some 67 percent of the admissions were people who had had previous stays at Creedmoor.'b'On the one hand, many mentally ill people were able to lead fuller, richer lives thanks to the deinstitutionalization movement. Yet there were no longer enough hospital beds for them, hence the need for hospitals to drug them up and move them out.'b'E.
