Many use the more formal term cannabis and refer to themselves loftily as \xe2\x80\x9cthe 420 community,\xe2\x80\x9d so intent on setting a good example they could be Shakers.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to use the word \xe2\x80\x98pot\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98weed\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98smoke\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98joint,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99 says a pretty 37-year-old event planner who uses the nom de pot Jane West (Mary Jane in the West) and owns a company called Edible Events. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we redefine it as consuming cannabis, then maybe people will be more open to that. There are only so many hoodie-wearing stoners in town. This needs to be opened up to other demographics.\xe2\x80\x9d West is especially interested in wooing women, getting them to equate cannabis with a glass of wine.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMany women think it\xe2\x80\x99s something that makes you dumb,\xe2\x80\x9d she says, arguing that women should leave the Valley of the Dolls \xe2\x80\x94 anti-anxiety pills and Ambien \xe2\x80\x94 and switch to \xe2\x80\x9cthe Napa Valley of cannabis.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'She wants to arrange corporate events, but concedes she may only attract cannabis corporations for a while. Her first big party, aptly held at the (nonsmoking) Space Gallery, was Friday night. Guests could \xe2\x80\x9cblaze,\xe2\x80\x9d as West put it, in a bus parked outside, which she had decorated with peacock feathers so it would look less \xe2\x80\x9ccheesy.\xe2\x80\x9d They could smoke, vape and nosh on savories soaked in sauce and cream to alleviate dry mouth. \xe2\x80\x9cMunchies for foodies,\xe2\x80\x9d she calls it.'b'At a warehouse under construction in a spot that used to be a bakery, Dixie Elixers is cooking up edible, drinkable and topical pot treats, trying to become the Coke of toking. With a big foil-covered Willy Wonka machine, they extract the THC from the plant and whip up products from chocolate truffles to bath soaks to massage oil, all in modern silvery packaging meant to scream \xe2\x80\x9csafe.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nonetheless, Denver is the Wild West of weed. And things will be confusing, evolving and dicey for some time. As Dixie Elixirs Chief Operating Officer Chuck Smith tells his team, \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re building the airplane while we\xe2\x80\x99re flying it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'BORDEAUX, France \xe2\x80\x94 WHEN the Bordeaux International Wine Institute, which offers business management training in the oenological arts, opened its doors in 2004, it had 20 students, mostly from domestic French wineries. Today it has 105.'b'What is most striking about this year\xe2\x80\x99s class isn\xe2\x80\x99t its size, but its composition. Though students come from places as diverse as India and Turkey, one group of foreigners stands out: Chinese students make up almost 30 percent, the largest group by nationality behind the French. Their American classmates comprise less than 4 percent.'b'Meanwhile, the Burgundy Business School in Dijon has also recorded a rise in Chinese students in its wine management programs. Between 2009 and 2012, Chinese students made up barely 10 percent of the graduate ranks; now, 33 of this year\xe2\x80\x99s 100 students hail from China.'b'Wine has always been an essential part of the French tradition, both culturally and economically, but the world\xe2\x80\x99s growing middle class has made it a global one: worldwide wine consumption is expected to grow almost 9 percent, to $182 billion, by 2016, with a large chunk of the demand coming from China.'b'Some in France, however, view this development with unease, which has at times exploded into violent xenophobia. In August a group of Frenchmen assaulted a group of Chinese oenology students at a wine school in nearby Sauternes, sending several to the hospital.'b'Along with a general fear of change within the centuries-old wine world, there is concern that China, with its huge population and geography, could someday eclipse France\xe2\x80\x99s place in wine production. Some even fear that these students could mark the first stage of a Chinese takeover of the French wine industry, buying up vineyards in the same way the country bought up huge tracts of Africa.'b'Such concerns are misplaced. Not only does the explosion in China\xe2\x80\x99s interest in wine bode well for the French economy, but the connections built between French vintners and their Chinese students will pay enormous cultural dividends for both countries.'b'Most people are surprised to learn that China already has a strong winemaking tradition. Indeed, many of the students at the French schools are working at the graduate level, having already completed undergraduate courses in oenology back home.'b'One student in Bordeaux, Zhang Xuan, began his wine studies in one of the new oenology programs at China\xe2\x80\x99s Northwest University of Agriculture and Forestry, in the central Chinese city of Yangling, and later interned with a Chinese winery before coming to France.'b'Others grew up working on their family\xe2\x80\x99s vineyards, or selling wine at a family-owned shop.'b'Whatever their background, most of them plan to return to China after their studies \xe2\x80\x94 and to take their new, French-inflected skills with them. Another Bordeaux student, Wu Zhaolong, discovered his passion for wine while working in the hotel and restaurant industry in Shanghai. He plans to go into restaurant management, integrating French food and wine styles with traditional Shanghainese dining.'b'As they move on, they will take along a respect for French culture, which they will later share with their co-workers and customers, in much the same way that the French winemaking know-how imported to California in the 1950s and \xe2\x80\x9960s helped initiate a new wave of interest in French cuisine and culture nationwide.'b'At the same time, these students will build strong binational business relationships: Zhu Qiyao, who ran a wine sales company in Hangzhou before coming to Bordeaux, wants to perfect her wine-negotiation skills and expand her business network before returning to China.'b'But the real benefit for France, and one that these students will help strengthen, is economic. French wine already accounts for 48 percent of Chinese wine imports, and Bordeaux\xe2\x80\x99s reds are a particular favorite of the Chinese elite.'b'And the Chinese market can only grow. A report presented last summer at Bordeaux\xe2\x80\x99s enormous VinExpo predicted that Chinese wine consumption would grow 40 percent from 2012 to 2016. And Chinese drinkers don\xe2\x80\x99t want plonk: While China ranks only 20th in per capita wine consumption, it ranks fourth in terms of the value of the wine it consumes.'b'A good bit of this demand will be met domestically, of course: China is already the fifth-largest wine-producing nation, and France\xe2\x80\x99s Center for Scientific Research recently predicted that it would double its production in five years.'b'Some in France fear that China\xe2\x80\x99s growing love of wine will drive wealthy Chinese investors to gobble up French vineyards. Chinese have been snatching up Bordeaux chateaus at roughly one a month. Last year a Chinese industrialist raised alarms in Bordeaux after buying a top-class, or grand cru, wine producer, Ch\xc3\xa2teau Bellefont-Belcier.'b'But such concerns are overblown. With upward of 8,000 properties, there are still plenty of French-owned vineyards. And there has been plenty of investment in the other direction.'b'In the last few years, many renowned French wine companies have rushed to open joint-venture vineyards and wineries in China. In July, Mo\xc3\xabt Hennessy\xe2\x80\x99s Chandon subsidiary opened its Ningxia Winery in central China, which will be dedicated to producing sparkling wine. Not far away, Pernod Ricard, a renowned wine producer, recently took over another large winery, Helan Mountain.'b'Globalization is reshaping every industry, even one as hidebound as French wine. But its partisans should be more optimistic. Far from destroying French wine traditions, forces of globalization, even one as large and powerful as China, can only help them.'b'And in any case, at least some in Bordeaux are keeping their prejudices closer to home. As one leading vintner said wryly, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care who buys these chateaus, as long as they are not from Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A SEEMINGLY un-American fact about America today is that for some groups, much more than others, upward mobility and the American dream are alive and well. It may be taboo to say it, but certain ethnic, religious and national-origin groups are doing strikingly better than Americans overall.'b'Indian-Americans earn almost double the national figure (roughly $90,000 per year in median household income versus $50,000). Iranian-, Lebanese- and Chinese-Americans are also top-earners. In the last 30 years, Mormons have become leaders of corporate America, holding top positions in many of America\xe2\x80\x99s most recognizable companies. These facts don\xe2\x80\x99t make some groups \xe2\x80\x9cbetter\xe2\x80\x9d than others, and material success cannot be equated with a well-lived life. But willful blindness to facts is never a good policy.'b'Jewish success is the most historically fraught and the most broad-based. Although Jews make up only about 2 percent of the United States\xe2\x80\x99 adult population, they account for a third of the current Supreme Court; over two-thirds of Tony Award-winning lyricists and composers; and about a third of American Nobel laureates.'b'The most comforting explanation of these facts is that they are mere artifacts of class \xe2\x80\x94 rich parents passing on advantages to their children \xe2\x80\x94 or of immigrants arriving in this country with high skill and education levels. Important as these factors are, they explain only a small part of the picture.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s wealthy Mormon businessmen often started from humble origins. Although India and China send the most immigrants to the United States through employment-based channels, almost half of all Indian immigrants and over half of Chinese immigrants do not enter the country under those criteria. Many are poor and poorly educated. Comprehensive data published by the Russell Sage Foundation in 2013 showed that the children of Chinese, Korean and Vietnamese immigrants experienced exceptional upward mobility regardless of their parents\xe2\x80\x99 socioeconomic or educational background.'b'Take New York City\xe2\x80\x99s selective public high schools like Stuyvesant and Bronx Science, which are major Ivy League feeders. For the 2013 school year, Stuyvesant High School offered admission, based solely on a standardized entrance exam, to nine black students, 24 Hispanics, 177 whites and 620 Asians. Among the Asians of Chinese origin, many are the children of restaurant workers and other working-class immigrants.'b'Merely stating the fact that certain groups do better than others \xe2\x80\x94 as measured by income, test scores and so on \xe2\x80\x94 is enough to provoke a firestorm in America today, and even charges of racism. The irony is that the facts actually debunk racial stereotypes.'b'There are some black and Hispanic groups in America that far outperform some white and Asian groups. Immigrants from many West Indian and African countries, such as Jamaica, Ghana, and Haiti, are climbing America\xe2\x80\x99s higher education ladder, but perhaps the most prominent are Nigerians. Nigerians make up less than 1 percent of the black population in the United States, yet in 2013 nearly one-quarter of the black students at Harvard Business School were of Nigerian ancestry; over a fourth of Nigerian-Americans have a graduate or professional degree, as compared with only about 11 percent of whites.'b'Cuban-Americans in Miami rose in one generation from widespread penury to relative affluence. By 1990, United States-born Cuban children \xe2\x80\x94 whose parents had arrived as exiles, many with practically nothing \xe2\x80\x94 were twice as likely as non-Hispanic whites to earn over $50,000 a year. All three Hispanic United States senators are Cuban-Americans.'b'Meanwhile, some Asian-American groups \xe2\x80\x94 Cambodian- and Hmong-Americans, for example \xe2\x80\x94 are among the poorest in the country, as are some predominantly white communities in central Appalachia.'b'MOST fundamentally, groups rise and fall over time. The fortunes of WASP elites have been declining for decades. In 1960, second-generation Greek-Americans reportedly had the second-highest income of any census-tracked group. Group success in America often tends to dissipate after two generations. Thus while Asian-American kids overall had SAT scores 143 points above average in 2012 \xe2\x80\x94 including a 63-point edge over whites \xe2\x80\x94 a 2005 study of over 20,000 adolescents found that third-generation Asian-American students performed no better academically than white students.'b'The fact that groups rise and fall this way punctures the whole idea of \xe2\x80\x9cmodel minorities\xe2\x80\x9d or that groups succeed because of innate, biological differences. Rather, there are cultural forces at work.'b'It turns out that for all their diversity, the strikingly successful groups in America today share three traits that, together, propel success. The first is a superiority complex \xe2\x80\x94 a deep-seated belief in their exceptionality. The second appears to be the opposite \xe2\x80\x94 insecurity, a feeling that you or what you\xe2\x80\x99ve done is not good enough. The third is impulse control.'b'Any individual, from any background, can have what we call this Triple Package of traits. But research shows that some groups are instilling them more frequently than others, and that they are enjoying greater success.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s odd to think of people feeling simultaneously superior and insecure. Yet it\xe2\x80\x99s precisely this unstable combination that generates drive: a chip on the shoulder, a goading need to prove oneself. Add impulse control \xe2\x80\x94 the ability to resist temptation \xe2\x80\x94 and the result is people who systematically sacrifice present gratification in pursuit of future attainment.'b'Ironically, each element of the Triple Package violates a core tenet of contemporary American thinking.'b'We know that group superiority claims are specious and dangerous, yet every one of America\xe2\x80\x99s most successful groups tells itself that it\xe2\x80\x99s exceptional in a deep sense. Mormons believe they are \xe2\x80\x9cgods in embryo\xe2\x80\x9d placed on earth to lead the world to salvation; they see themselves, in the historian Claudia L. Bushman\xe2\x80\x99s words, as \xe2\x80\x9can island of morality in a sea of moral decay.\xe2\x80\x9d Middle East experts and many Iranians explicitly refer to a Persian \xe2\x80\x9csuperiority complex.\xe2\x80\x9d At their first Passover Seders, most Jewish children hear that Jews are the \xe2\x80\x9cchosen\xe2\x80\x9d people; later they may be taught that Jews are a moral people, a people of law and intellect, a people of survivors.'b'That insecurity should be a lever of success is another anathema in American culture. Feelings of inadequacy are cause for concern or even therapy; parents deliberately instilling insecurity in their children is almost unthinkable. Yet insecurity runs deep in every one of America\xe2\x80\x99s rising groups; and consciously or unconsciously, they tend to instill it in their children.'b'A central finding in a study of more than 5,000 immigrants\xe2\x80\x99 children led by the sociologist Rub\xc3\xa9n G. Rumbaut was how frequently the kids felt \xe2\x80\x9cmotivated to achieve\xe2\x80\x9d because of an acute sense of obligation to redeem their parents\xe2\x80\x99 sacrifices. Numerous studies, including in-depth field work conducted by the Harvard sociologist Vivian S. Louie, reveal Chinese immigrant parents frequently imposing exorbitant academic expectations on their children (\xe2\x80\x9cWhy only a 99?\xe2\x80\x9d), making them feel that \xe2\x80\x9cfamily honor\xe2\x80\x9d depends on their success.'b'By contrast, white American parents have been found to be more focused on building children\xe2\x80\x99s social skills and self-esteem. There\xe2\x80\x99s an ocean of difference between \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re amazing. Mommy and Daddy never want you to worry about a thing\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t do well at school, you\xe2\x80\x99ll let down the family and end up a bum on the streets.\xe2\x80\x9d In a study of thousands of high school students, Asian-American students reported the lowest self-esteem of any racial group, even as they racked up the highest grades.'b'Moreover, being an outsider in a society \xe2\x80\x94 and America\xe2\x80\x99s most successful groups are all outsiders in one way or another \xe2\x80\x94 is a source of insecurity in itself. Immigrants worry about whether they can survive in a strange land, often communicating a sense of life\xe2\x80\x99s precariousness to their children. Hence the common credo: They can take away your home or business, but never your education, so study harder. Newcomers and religious minorities may face derision or hostility. Cubans fleeing to Miami after Fidel Castro\xe2\x80\x99s takeover reported seeing signs reading \xe2\x80\x9cNo dogs, no Cubans\xe2\x80\x9d on apartment buildings. During the 2012 election cycle, Mormons had to hear Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s clean-cut sons described as \xe2\x80\x9ccreepy\xe2\x80\x9d in the media. In combination with a superiority complex, the feeling of being underestimated or scorned can be a powerful motivator.'b'Finally, impulse control runs against the grain of contemporary culture as well. Countless books and feel-good movies extol the virtue of living in the here and now, and people who control their impulses don\xe2\x80\x99t live in the moment. The dominant culture is fearful of spoiling children\xe2\x80\x99s happiness with excessive restraints or demands. By contrast, every one of America\xe2\x80\x99s most successful groups takes a very different view of childhood, inculcating habits of discipline from a very early age \xe2\x80\x94 or at least they did so when they were on the rise.'b'In isolation, each of these three qualities would be insufficient. Alone, a superiority complex is a recipe for complacency; mere insecurity could be crippling; impulse control can produce asceticism. Only in combination do these qualities generate drive and what Tocqueville called the \xe2\x80\x9clonging to rise.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Needless to say, high-achieving groups don\xe2\x80\x99t instill these qualities in all their members. They don\xe2\x80\x99t have to. A culture producing, say, four high achievers out of 10 would attain wildly disproportionate success if the surrounding average was one out of 20.'b'But this success comes at a price. Each of the three traits has its own pathologies. Impulse control can undercut the ability to experience beauty, tranquillity and spontaneous joy. Insecure people feel like they\xe2\x80\x99re never good enough. \xe2\x80\x9cI grew up thinking that I would never, ever please my parents,\xe2\x80\x9d recalls the novelist Amy Tan. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a horrible feeling.\xe2\x80\x9d Recent studies suggest that Asian-American youth have greater rates of stress (but, despite media reports to the contrary, lower rates of suicide).'b'A superiority complex can be even more invidious. Group supremacy claims have been a source of oppression, war and genocide throughout history. To be sure, a group superiority complex somehow feels less ugly when it\xe2\x80\x99s used by an outsider minority as an armor against majority prejudices and hostility, but ethnic pride or religious zeal can turn all too easily into intolerance of its own.'b'Even when it functions relatively benignly as an engine of success, the combination of these three traits can still be imprisoning \xe2\x80\x94 precisely because of the kind of success it tends to promote. Individuals striving for material success can easily become too focused on prestige and money, too concerned with external measures of their own worth.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not easy for minority groups in America to maintain a superiority complex. For most of its history, America did pretty much everything a country could to impose a narrative of inferiority on its nonwhite minorities and especially its black population. Over and over, African-Americans have fought back against this narrative, but its legacy persists.'b'Black America is of course no one thing: \xe2\x80\x9cnot one or ten or ten thousand things,\xe2\x80\x9d as the poet and Yale professor Elizabeth Alexander has written. There are black families in the United States occupying every possible socioeconomic position. But Sean \xe2\x80\x9cDiddy\xe2\x80\x9d Combs \xe2\x80\x94 rapper, record producer and entrepreneur \xe2\x80\x94 undoubtedly spoke for many when he said: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you study black history, it\xe2\x80\x99s just so negative, you know. It\xe2\x80\x99s just like, O.K., we were slaves, and then we were whipped and sprayed with water hoses, and the civil rights movement, and we\xe2\x80\x99re American gangsters. I get motivated for us to be seen in our brilliance.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Culture is never all-determining. Individuals can defy the most dominant culture and write their own scripts, as Mr. Combs himself did. They can create narratives of pride that reject the master narratives of their society, or turn those narratives around. In any given family, an unusually strong parent, grandparent or even teacher can instill in children every one of the three crucial traits. It\xe2\x80\x99s just much harder when you have to do it on your own, when you can\xe2\x80\x99t draw on the cultural resources of a broader community, when you don\xe2\x80\x99t have role models or peer pressure on your side, and instead are bombarded daily with negative images of your group in the media.'b'But it would be ridiculous to suggest that the lack of an effective group superiority complex was the cause of disproportionate African-American poverty. The true causes barely require repeating: They include slavery, systematic discrimination, schools that fail to teach, employers who won\xe2\x80\x99t promote, single motherhood and the fact that roughly a third of young black men in this country are in jail, awaiting trial or on probation or parole. Nor does the lack of a group superiority narrative prevent any given individual African-American from succeeding. It simply creates an additional psychological and cultural hurdle that America\xe2\x80\x99s most successful groups don\xe2\x80\x99t have to overcome.'b'At the same time, if members of a group learn not to trust the system, if they don\xe2\x80\x99t think people like them can really make it, they will have little incentive to engage in impulse control. Researchers at the University of Rochester recently reran the famous marshmallow test with a new spin. Children initially subjected to a broken promise \xe2\x80\x94 adults promised them a new art set to play with, but never delivered \xe2\x80\x94 almost invariably \xe2\x80\x9cfailed\xe2\x80\x9d the test (snatching the first marshmallow instead of waiting 15 minutes for a promised second). By contrast, when the adults followed through on their promise, most kids passed the test.'b'The same factors that cause poverty \xe2\x80\x94 discrimination, prejudice, shrinking opportunity \xe2\x80\x94 can sap from a group the cultural forces that propel success. Once that happens, poverty becomes more entrenched. In these circumstances, it takes much more grit, more drive and perhaps a more exceptional individual to break out.'b'Of course a person born with the proverbial silver spoon can grow up to be wealthy without hard work, insecurity or discipline (although to the extent a group passes on its wealth that way, it\xe2\x80\x99s likely to be headed for decline). In a society with increasing class rigidity, parental wealth obviously contributes to the success of the next generation.'b'But one reason groups with the cultural package we\xe2\x80\x99ve described have such an advantage in the United States today lies in the very same factors that are shrinking opportunity for so many of America\xe2\x80\x99s poor. Disappearing blue-collar jobs and greater returns to increasingly competitive higher education give a tremendous edge to groups that disproportionately produce individuals driven, especially at a young age, to excel and to sacrifice present satisfactions for long-term gains.'b'THE good news is that it\xe2\x80\x99s not some magic gene generating these groups\xe2\x80\x99 disproportionate success. Nor is it some 5,000-year-old \xe2\x80\x9ceducation culture\xe2\x80\x9d that only they have access to. Instead their success is significantly propelled by three simple qualities open to anyone.'b'The way to develop this package of qualities \xe2\x80\x94 not that it\xe2\x80\x99s easy, or that everyone would want to \xe2\x80\x94 is through grit. It requires turning the ability to work hard, to persevere and to overcome adversity into a source of personal superiority. This kind of superiority complex isn\xe2\x80\x99t ethnically or religiously exclusive. It\xe2\x80\x99s the pride a person takes in his own strength of will.'b'Consider the story of Sonia Sotomayor, who was born to struggling Puerto Rican parents. Her father was an alcoholic, she writes in her moving autobiography, \xe2\x80\x9cMy Beloved World,\xe2\x80\x9d and her mother\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cway of coping was to avoid being at home\xe2\x80\x9d with him. But Justice Sotomayor, who gave herself painful insulin shots for diabetes starting around age 8, was \xe2\x80\x9cblessed\xe2\x80\x9d with a \xe2\x80\x9cstubborn perseverance.\xe2\x80\x9d Not originally a top student, she did \xe2\x80\x9csomething very unusual\xe2\x80\x9d in fifth grade, approaching one of the smartest girls in the class to \xe2\x80\x9cask her how to study.\xe2\x80\x9d Soon she was getting top marks, and a few years later she applied to Princeton \xe2\x80\x94 though her guidance counselor recommended \xe2\x80\x9cCatholic colleges.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The point of this example is not, \xe2\x80\x9cSee, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to climb out of poverty in America.\xe2\x80\x9d On the contrary, Justice Sotomayor\xe2\x80\x99s story illustrates just how extraordinary a person has to be to overcome the odds stacked against her.'b'But research shows that perseverance and motivation can be taught, especially to young children. This supports those who, like the Nobel Prize-winning economist James J. Heckman, argue that education dollars for the underprivileged are best spent on early childhood intervention, beginning at preschool age, when kids are most formable.'b'The United States itself was born a Triple Package nation, with an outsize belief in its own exceptionality, a goading desire to prove itself to aristocratic Europe (Thomas Jefferson sent a giant moose carcass to Paris to prove that America\xe2\x80\x99s animals were bigger than Europe\xe2\x80\x99s) and a Puritan inheritance of impulse control.'b'But prosperity and power had their predictable effect, eroding the insecurity and self-restraint that led to them. By 2000, all that remained was our superiority complex, which by itself is mere swagger, fueling a culture of entitlement and instant gratification. Thus the trials of recent years \xe2\x80\x94 the unwon wars, the financial collapse, the rise of China \xe2\x80\x94 have, perversely, had a beneficial effect: the return of insecurity.'b'Those who talk of America\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cdecline\xe2\x80\x9d miss this crucial point. America has always been at its best when it has had to overcome adversity and prove its mettle on the world stage. For better and worse, it has that opportunity again today.'b'Xi Jinping has vowed to end corruption among China\xe2\x80\x99s elite, but a report said that the country\xe2\x80\x99s wealthy are storing billions of dollars abroad.'b'BEIJING \xe2\x80\x94  On Jan. 12, Song Binbin, the daughter of a former prominent member of the Communist Party, created a stir on China\xe2\x80\x99s blogosphere when she joined some fellow former Red Guards at a Beijing high school and offered a public apology for her part in one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution. In August 1966, the school\xe2\x80\x99s vice principal, Bian Zhongyun, was tormented, beaten and left to die by students at the school. Ms. Song said she had tried to stop them but did not try hard enough. She said she did not participate in the beating.'b'The Cultural Revolution wreaked devastation on the lives of millions of Chinese people. Mao, who unleashed the movement by urging young people to rise up against their parents and teachers, was attempting to regain prominence after years of failed policies by purging the Communist Party of \xe2\x80\x9ccapitalists.\xe2\x80\x9d For 10 years, the nation was reduced to a state of barbarism.'b'Because Mao has continued to be revered by China\xe2\x80\x99s leaders since his death in 1976, genuine public reflection on the lessons of this disastrous time has been impossible. Attempts by intellectuals to publicly address the Cultural Revolution have been suppressed; only a smattering of research by state-funded scholars has seen the light of day. The result has been a gradual receding of memory. The economic surge of the past 30 years has even led some deluded souls to look back on the period with nostalgia. But given the authoritarian nature of today\xe2\x80\x99s leadership, many people fear the prospect of a return of the terror that marked the Cultural Revolution.'b'Still, a sort of \xe2\x80\x9capology compulsion\xe2\x80\x9d appears to have taken hold among people like Song Binbin who were lured into villainy during that tumultuous period. Wang Jiyu, haunted by a fatal beating he carried out in 1967 when he was 16 years old, published an article in a pro-reform journal, Yanhuang Chunqiu, in 2010, reflecting on his transgressions.'b'Wang Keming, who admitted to badly beating an older man during the Cultural Revolution, compiled a book of articles by people willing to tell their stories. He finished the book in 2013, but he could not find a publishing house willing to take on the project.'b'Perhaps the most prominent example is Chen Xiaolu, the son of a former foreign minister, Chen Yi, who created a storm late last year when he apologized for ordering teachers to line up in their school auditorium and wear dunce caps.'b'Among those who have apologized, Song Binbin and Chen Xiaolu do not appear to have committed very serious crimes. It is those who committed the greatest atrocities, such as the cannibals of the Guangxi region, or the people who actually killed Vice Principal Bian Zhongyun, who remain silent.'b'Yet the public reaction suggests that many Chinese people \xe2\x80\x94 especially the younger generation that is active online \xe2\x80\x94 consider Song Binbin\xe2\x80\x99s apology insincere. Many netizens accuse her of grandstanding; some argue that her apology is meaningless if she does not  say who killed the vice principal. Many doubt she was telling the whole truth. \xe2\x80\x9cNow she apologizes for her crime. Which of her words are true?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one anonymous commentator. Another wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cThe apology didn\xe2\x80\x99t have much meaning.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The truth is that we should not limit public reflection to the Cultural Revolution alone. China\xe2\x80\x99s history has been marked by an endless series of massacres and government-led persecutions \xe2\x80\x94 from the Great Famine right through to the more recent \xe2\x80\x9chard-strike\xe2\x80\x9d anti-crime campaigns, the Tiananmen Square massacre and the persecution of the Falun Gong spiritual movement, to name just a few.'b'But a public accounting of our tragedies will not come anytime soon. It is only because of the massive involvement of ordinary people in the Cultural Revolution that official suppression has failed to prevent some participants from spontaneously offering apologies.'b'Can China continue the momentum and create a framework for wider public acknowledgement? Are the Chinese people ready for such a mass reckoning?'b'Justice requires the application of legal principles, and a basic consideration for human feelings. In the case of the Cultural Revolution, an apology is the most important thing, more important than any punishment. More apologies should be encouraged \xe2\x80\x94 and accepted \xe2\x80\x94 even if they come 40 years late.'b'The concern is that those who might be willing to step forward will be discouraged from doing so for fear of facing excessive criticism, like Song Binbin. If those who publicly apologize are continually put through an online gauntlet, and are eventually subjected to absolute justice, the more reluctant perpetrators will certainly stay in the shadows.'b'We Chinese need to build an appropriate environment for the wrongdoers to come forward. First and foremost, this requires that people who were fortunate enough not to experience the Cultural Revolution put themselves in the place of the perpetrators. While they have a right to criticize perpetrators of past crimes, they should repress the impulse to harshly condemn those who come forward. We should not be making excessive demands on this process. Chinese people should try to consider what they themselves might have done under similar circumstances.'b'But as the vitriolic reaction to Song Binbin\xe2\x80\x99s apology shows, Chinese society is not ready for a public reckoning. There is simply not enough good will to accept the apologies of the Cultural Revolution\xe2\x80\x99s criminals.'b'The question remains whether society can come around before all of the victims have died, and the Cultural Revolution becomes yet another tragedy in our history that never receives the public airing it deserves.'b''b'\n'b'Xiao Han 'b' is an associate professor at China University of Political Science and Law. This article was translated by Stacy Mosher from the Chinese. 'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cGender\xe2\x80\x9d has been chosen as the 2013 word of the year in Poland. In making their selection, scholars from the University of Warsaw and the Polish Language Foundation passed over other buzzwords like \xe2\x80\x9cwiretapping\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEuromaidan.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Since the fall of Communism and integration into the West, gender has become an established concept in Poland, along with the feminist and L.G.B.T. movements. Many universities have Gender Studies programs, and numerous books on the subject have been published. And, as a European Union member, Poland is obligated to follow a policy of so-called gender mainstreaming.'b'In any case, the English word \xe2\x80\x9cgender\xe2\x80\x9d is hardly new to Poland. Academics have managed to make it standard in Polish humanities, and the country has had time to get used to it. Why, then, has gender suddenly become a hot topic?'b'The first sign that something strange was happening emerged this past summer at a debate I participated in with one of Poland\xe2\x80\x99s best-known bishops, Tadeusz Pieronek. We were at a summer culture festival at a resort in Swinoujscie, on the Baltic coast. All of a sudden, Bishop Pieronek blurted out, \xe2\x80\x9cI would like to add that the ideology of gender presents a threat worse than Nazism and Communism combined.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Bishop Pieronek, considered part of the liberal wing of Poland\xe2\x80\x99s Catholic Church, seemed to be reciting memorized talking points. In any case, he didn\xe2\x80\x99t have more to say about his statement, nor could he name any victims or give the number of people killed or maimed by the threat of gender. He did, however, repeat his statement, while adding that gender ideology is at odds with nature and natural law.'b'The clergy always protest that in vitro fertilization, abortion, civil unions for gays and teaching sex education are at odds with nature. Yet priests\xe2\x80\x99 lifestyles, namely their celibacy, are hardly a textbook product of the theory of evolution.'b'Because politicians in Poland fear the church, all of the above activities are either banned or heavily restricted by the law or, as in the case of compulsory sex education, ignored by the authorities. But exist they do, on more or less the same scale as in any Western country. In this way, freedom has been privatized in Poland, and access to it depends on social class, and therefore on the contents of one\xe2\x80\x99s wallet, level of education and place of residence.'b'Bishop Pieronek\xe2\x80\x99s statement touched off a series of ever more perplexing actions by the church hierarchy. Posters have appeared in schools proclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cProtect Your Child Against Gender.\xe2\x80\x9d (The newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported that young children have begun to ask their parents how they can be vaccinated.) Almost every day there are new pronouncements warning against gender ideology, for example, as when a priest commented in a talk in Poznan that \xe2\x80\x9cgender leads to the devastation of families\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cis associated with radical feminism, which advocates for abortion, the employment of women and the detention of children in preschools.\xe2\x80\x9d Lining up behind the church fight, conservative politicians have convened a parliamentary group, \xe2\x80\x9cStop Gender Ideology,\xe2\x80\x9d consisting of one woman and 15 men.'b'The bishops voiced their official opinion in a pastoral letter posted online entitled, \xe2\x80\x9cThreats to the Family Stemming from the Ideology of Gender,\xe2\x80\x9d which proclaimed that \xe2\x80\x9cthe aim of gender education is the sexualization of children and young people.\xe2\x80\x9d According to Poland\xe2\x80\x99s Catholic Church, the Council of Europe\xe2\x80\x99s Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence is promoting \xe2\x80\x9cnonstereotypical sexual roles\xe2\x80\x9d and is breaking down the educational system by requiring education on homosexuality and transsexuality.'b'In their letter the bishops also went after the World Health Organization, writing that it \xe2\x80\x9cpromotes, among other things, masturbation by preschool-aged children, encouraging them to seek joy and pleasure in touching their own bodies and those of their peers.\xe2\x80\x9d The bishops warned that \xe2\x80\x9cas a consequence of the education implemented by youth sexual educators, young people become regular customers of pharmaceutical, erotic, pornographic, pedophile and abortion enterprises.\xe2\x80\x9d The letter, perhaps not surprisingly, was replaced with a toned-down version less than two hours after it was published, according to Gazeta Wyborcza. Even so, the bishops announced that both versions were legitimate, but that the original was for pastoral use, and the second version for the laity.'b'The church hierarchy claims none are immune to the influence of gender. It might be that even the Polish Church itself is threatened. \xe2\x80\x9cChurch\xe2\x80\x9d was originally a feminine-declined noun (from the Greek \xe2\x80\x9cecclesia\xe2\x80\x9d). And it is traditionally personified by the image of a woman. In Polish, however, this same word is masculine. Is the Catholic Church also having gender issues?'b'A more serious question many in Poland are asking is, Why is this anti-gender paranoia happening now? If \xe2\x80\x9cgender ideology\xe2\x80\x9d were such an apocalyptical threat, it should have wiped out a significant part of the Polish population before our church\xe2\x80\x99s recent wake-up call.'b'For two decades, the church hierarchy exhibited no interest in the \xe2\x80\x9cideology of gender\xe2\x80\x9d until suddenly one day it began to speak of little else. The reasons behind such an orchestrated action might be found in the church\xe2\x80\x99s recent problems. Poles have been outraged by the large-scale financial fraud carried out by the commission tasked with the reprivatization of church property that had been seized by the Communist government. Poles also continue to be disturbed by increasingly common disclosures of pedophilia within the church.'b'In Poland, politics is the one area in which the church does not need any lessons. And in today\xe2\x80\x99s politics, when a party finds itself in trouble, its best bet is to change the subject with a media campaign. Necessity is the mother of invention, and thus arose the church\xe2\x80\x99s new invention, the \xe2\x80\x9cideology of gender.\xe2\x80\x9d This seems to be working wonderfully, since \xe2\x80\x9cgender\xe2\x80\x9d has become the word of the year, handily beating not just \xe2\x80\x9cwiretapping\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEuromaidan,\xe2\x80\x9d but also \xe2\x80\x9cpedophilia\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cproperty commission.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\n'b'Slawomir Sierakowski 'b' is a sociologist and a founder of the Krytyka Polityczna movement. This article was translated by Maria Blackwood from the Polish.'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'David Brooks\xe2\x80\x99s column about the tragedies endured by the Woodiwiss family, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Art of Presence'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 21), brought to mind my interviews with dozens of people who were ill, bereaved or coping with a loved one\xe2\x80\x99s distress.'b'Many of them reported astonishingly insensitive responses to their suffering, from the clich\xc3\xa9d, \xe2\x80\x9cGod only gives you as much as you can handle,\xe2\x80\x9d to the cringe-worthy, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you have to have a mastectomy, at least you\xe2\x80\x99re married.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Though Mr. Brooks correctly states, \xe2\x80\x9cThere are no uniformly right responses,\xe2\x80\x9d he draws other conclusions contradicted by my sample and my own experience as a breast cancer patient. Yes, \xe2\x80\x9cmost people need presence,\xe2\x80\x9d but they don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily need the presence of everyone who decides to show up, and they don\xe2\x80\x99t want unannounced visits.'b'Yes, a bathmat was a thoughtful gift for Catherine Woodiwiss when she was recovering from her bike accident, but if asked, she might have preferred something more creature-comforting, say a pint of ice cream or a gift certificate for a massage.'b'Over all, what my interviewees said they wished for, whether physically sick or sick at heart, was an etiquette of honesty \xe2\x80\x94 the freedom to tell their friends what\xe2\x80\x99s helpful and what\xe2\x80\x99s not, when they want to be alone and when they want company, what to bring and when to leave.'b'LETTY COTTIN POGREBIN'b'\nNew York, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer\xe2\x80\x99s most recent book is \xe2\x80\x9cHow to Be a Friend to a Friend Who\xe2\x80\x99s Sick.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The guidelines that David Brooks presents for reaching out to the bereaved are ethically intelligent. But how should the bereaved respond to friends who unwittingly violate these rules? It behooves the recipient to react with compassion and understanding.'b'Relationships are a two-way street. Those who are experiencing the types of trauma that Mr. Brooks describes are entitled to be treated with respect and sensitivity. Such people should also appreciate the limitations of friends with good intentions. The best response to anyone trying to help is a sincere \xe2\x80\x9cthank you.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'BRUCE WEINSTEIN'b'\nNew York, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cEthical Intelligence.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'May we humbly add several more suggestions for more helpful behavior in the presence of trauma and tragedy:'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Don\xe2\x80\x99t begin any sentence with the words, \xe2\x80\x9cAt least ...\xe2\x80\x9d (as in: \xe2\x80\x9cAt least the taxi didn\xe2\x80\x99t hit both children\xe2\x80\x9d).'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Don\xe2\x80\x99t say, \xe2\x80\x9cPlease call if you need anything.\xe2\x80\x9d That call rarely comes. Go and do. Wash the dishes. Take out the garbage. Do something practical, and then come back in a couple of days and do it again.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Bring real food, not cake or cookies.'b'\xe2\x96\xa0 Don\xe2\x80\x99t assume because a \xe2\x80\x9cperiod of mourning\xe2\x80\x9d has passed, that grief is over. Sorrow has no timetable. Your presence may well be most needed when the house is silent and empty, when all the company has left.'b'JUDITH TARGAN ABRAHAMSON'b'\nSHARON L. MOSENKIS'b'\nFair Lawn, N.J., Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I thank David Brooks for his eloquent account of what he learned by listening so carefully to the Woodiwiss family. His advice for helping those suffering: \xe2\x80\x9cLet them define meaning. Sit simply through moments of pain and uncomfortable darkness.\xe2\x80\x9d As the mother of a 23-year-old son who died in a mountain-climbing accident, I can say that nothing means more.'b'Almost 20 years later I still treasure those who were able to be with us in our grief, and to temper their own fears and need to \xe2\x80\x9chelp.\xe2\x80\x9d Being, not helping, is what allows survivors to gather strength and to recover their own lives.'b'One other thought: please don\xe2\x80\x99t use the word closure. Ever.'b'JUDITH LINGLE RYAN'b'\nNyack, N.Y., Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cJourney From Mount Rainier: A Mother\xe2\x80\x99s Chronicle of Grief and Hope.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'You Don\xe2\x80\x99t Have to Be Jewish to Love a Kosher Prison Meal'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 21) minimizes the struggles encountered by prisoners who are Jewish or of other faiths. Because prisoners are often denied congregate religious services and other forms of religious observance, their religious dietary restrictions become one of the few ways they can observe their faiths.'b'Recognizing prison officials\xe2\x80\x99 repeated interference with religious observance, Congress enacted the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act in 2000 to protect the rights of religious prisoners. Congress acknowledged that accommodating the religions of prisoners may sometimes cost money but made the judgment that protecting these fundamental rights was worth the price.'b'The price of kosher meals is a negligible fraction of Florida\xe2\x80\x99s $2 billion yearly prison budget. If the state really wants to save money on prisons, it should reform the criminal justice policies that have given it one of the highest incarceration rates in the country.'b'DAVID FATHI'b'\nDirector, National Prison Project'b'\nAmerican Civil Liberties Union'b'\nWashington, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'My grandfather Rabbi Abraham Burstein served as the senior Jewish chaplain of the New York City Board of Correction from 1935 to 1966, working with prisoners at Rikers Island. Learned in November of Photos Said to Show Torture in Syria'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 23):'b'A central tenet of the human rights advocacy movement has long been that information about human rights abuses, especially those occurring far away, will lead to action to halt them.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf only people knew, surely they would do something\xe2\x80\x9d has been the rallying cry from the Holocaust, to the Rwandan genocide, to Darfur, to the conflict in Syria.'b'In particular, photographic images have always been deemed crucial in mobilizing action to halt gross violations of human rights.'b'This conviction \xe2\x80\x94 that seeing gruesome pictures of distant atrocities will lead countries to finally take action \xe2\x80\x94 has sadly been proved to be nothing more than wishful thinking, a truism whose basis bears no resemblance to reality.'b'Human rights advocates are at a loss; their primary weapon \xe2\x80\x94 shock \xe2\x80\x94 has proved to be ultimately powerless. Shocking images could never compete with politics, which trumps human rights always and everywhere it appears.'b'TRISTAN ANNE BORER'b'\nWaterford, Conn., Jan. 23, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of human rights at Connecticut College and the editor of the book \xe2\x80\x9cMedia, Mobilization and Human Rights: Mediating Suffering.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'In Life and Business, Learning to Be Ethical'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Alina Tugend (Shortcuts column, Jan. 11), confirmed what our school has advocated since 1878 \xe2\x80\x94 ethics matter.'b'By integrating ethics into our curriculum from kindergarten through 12th grade, we prepare our students to analyze and understand moral dilemmas they will encounter in the world inside and outside our walls. Our mission thrives as our students pursue academic, social and emotional growth in tandem with moral development.'b'Ms. Tugend is correct in asserting that \xe2\x80\x9chow we teach ethics has to catch up with what we know about how the human mind works.\xe2\x80\x9d There are many ways to teach a child the habits of mind. But as to habits of the heart \xe2\x80\x94 well, that\xe2\x80\x99s a different story.'b'One can only hope that the newfound interest in ethics and behavioral economics will lead to a national conversation as to what should be the essential common core \xe2\x80\x94 ethics in action from pre-K onward. FERNANDEZ'b'\nHead of School'b'\nEthical Culture Fieldston School'b'\nNew York, Jan. 14, 2014'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Patients\xe2\x80\x99 Costs Skyrocket; Specialists\xe2\x80\x99 Incomes Soar'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cPaying Till It Hurts\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Jan. 19) is a disappointing representation of skin cancer surgery patients, the overwhelming majority of whom are satisfied with their outcomes, treatment options, care, and physician expertise and communication.'b'Diagnosis of cancer is a frightening experience. Patients are understandably worried about what will happen, the risk of recurrence, scarring, loss of function and disfigurement. When delivering care, dermatologic surgeons take into account the best interest of the patient, their needs and desires and carefully explain effective treatment options and offer comfort and reassurance while providing expert care.'b'While dermatologic surgeons perform skin cancer removal and reconstruction procedures more often than other specialists, sometimes a multi-physician approach is recommended because of patient needs or expectation. With research and clinical breakthroughs, we are able to offer many treatment options in an office setting to achieve the highest cure rates efficiently.'b'One in five Americans develops skin cancer over a lifetime. It is important to encourage patients to seek appropriate treatment.'b'MITCHEL P. GOLDMAN'b'\nSan Diego, Jan. 21, 2014'b''b''b' 'b''b''b'The writer is president of the American Society for Dermatologic Surgery, based in Rolling Meadows, Ill. 'b''b'IN recent years Americans have begun to wise up to the idea that our overstuffed prisons are a shameful waste of lives and money. Lawmakers have recoiled from the high price of mass incarceration (the annual per-inmate cost of prison approaches the tuition at a good college) and some have recognized that our prisons feed a pathological cycle of poverty, community dysfunction, crime and hopelessness. As crime rates have dropped, the public has 'b'registered support'b' for reforms that would have fewer nonviolent offenders languishing in prison. For three years in a row, the population of America\xe2\x80\x99s prisons has inched down; 13 states closed prisons last year. Efforts to fix the perpetual misery machine that is our criminal justice system have won support not only from progressives and academics but from 'b'conservatives'b' (both fiscal and evangelical), from enlightened law enforcement groups, from business and even from 'b'advocates for crime victims.'b''b'This emerging consensus is good news, since our prisons are an international scandal, and we can only hope the new attitude doesn\xe2\x80\x99t evaporate with the next Willie Horton-style rampage or spike in the crime rate. But it raises an important question: What is the alternative? How do we punish and deter criminals, protect the public and \xe2\x80\x94 the thing prisons do most abysmally \xe2\x80\x94 improve the chances that those caught up in the criminal justice system emerge with some hope of productive lives?'b'That has become about the hottest subject in criminal justice, the focus of a profusion of experiments in states and localities, and of researchers trying to determine what works. California alone, which is under a Supreme Court mandate to relieve its inhumanely congested prisons, is offering counties $1 billion a year to try out remedies. A 'b'study'b' released on Monday by the Urban Institute examined 17 states, red and blue, testing an approach called Justice Reinvestment \xe2\x80\x94 reducing prison costs and putting some of the savings into alternatives. Perhaps the most striking thing, said Nancy La Vigne, the principal investigator on the report, is the enthusiasm of law-and-order states that a few years ago might have shunned such programs as bleeding-heart liberalism.'b'In conversations with a wide range of criminal justice experts, I found several broad strategies that seem promising:'b''b'SENTENCING'b' America has long been more inclined than other developed countries to treat crime as a disposal problem; \xe2\x80\x9ctrail \xe2\x80\x99em, nail \xe2\x80\x99em and jail \xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d is our tough-on-crime slogan. Beginning in the \xe2\x80\x9870\xe2\x80\x99s, rising crime rates, compounded by the crack epidemic and the public fear it aroused, set off a binge of punitive sentencing laws. Three-strikes, mandatory minimum sentences and requirements that felons serve a minimum portion (often 85 percent) of their sentence lengthened the time offenders \xe2\x80\x94 especially drug offenders, and especially black men \xe2\x80\x94 spent in lockup. Restoring common sense to sentencing is the obvious first step in downsizing prisons. New York rolled back its notorious Rockefeller drug laws, California has softened its three-strikes law and several other states have tinkered with rigid sentencing laws. But there is stiff resistance from prosecutors, who use the threat of long sentences to compel cooperation or plea deals. Reformers concede that those draconian laws have had a modest effect on the crime rate, but because of them we are paying to imprison criminals long past the time they present any danger to society. \xe2\x80\x9cKeeping a 60-year-old in prison until he\xe2\x80\x99s 65 does close to zero for crime rates,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jeremy Travis, president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we\xe2\x80\x99re really seeing something deep going on here, the proof will be whether legislators have the political will to roll back sentencing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'SUPERVISION'b' For every inmate in our state and federal prisons, another two people are under the supervision of probation or parole. Caseworkers are often poorly paid and usually overwhelmed. About all they can do is keep count of an offender\xe2\x80\x99s violations until the system decides to kick that offender back to prison. A few jurisdictions have tried to make parole and probation less of a revolving door back to prison, with some encouraging results. They focus attention on offenders considered most likely to commit crimes. They send caseworkers out of the office and into the community. They use technology (ankle bracelets with GPS, A.T.M.-style check-in stations, Breathalyzer ignition locks to keep drinkers from driving) to enhance supervision. They employ a disciplinary approach called \xe2\x80\x9cswift and certain,\xe2\x80\x9d which responds promptly with a punishment for missing an interview or failing a drug test. The punishments start small, then escalate until the offender gets the message and changes his behavior \xe2\x80\x94 preferably before he has to be sent back to prison. Mark Kleiman, a U.C.L.A. public policy professor who is a champion of the technique, says, \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s basically applying the principles of parenting to probation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'DIVERSION'b' Many jurisdictions now send drug offenders to special courts that divert nonviolent drug abusers to treatment instead of prison. Adam Gelb, director of the Public Safety Performance Project at the Pew Charitable Trusts, said more than 2,000 drug courts have been created. The popularity of drug courts has spawned other specialized venues \xe2\x80\x94 veterans\xe2\x80\x99 courts, domestic violence courts \xe2\x80\x94 that aim to address problems rather than simply dispense punishment.'b''b'RE-ENTRY'b' We release more than 650,000 prisoners into society every year, often just dropping them on a curb to fend for themselves. Two-thirds of them are rearrested within three years. A number of programs aim to improve the odds that a released felon will have options besides unemployment, homelessness and a return to crime. Some feature prerelease counseling and enlist family members to assure a safe landing. \xe2\x80\x9cBan the box\xe2\x80\x9d initiatives encourage employers to eliminate the box on job applications that asks if you have ever been arrested. A criminal history can still count against you in hiring, but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t eliminate you from consideration. (Target is the biggest retailer to ban the box.) Sherrilyn Ifill, president of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, says another simple measure is to repeal rules that say a felon can\xe2\x80\x99t be licensed as a barber or beautician.'b''b'POLICING'b' It may seem counterintuitive, but sophisticated police work has helped reduce prison populations in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, New Orleans and other cities while also bringing down violent crime, 'b'according to'b' David Kennedy of John Jay. Instead of wholesale policing of \xe2\x80\x9cbad neighborhoods\xe2\x80\x9d and indiscriminately stopping and frisking residents, they target micro hot spots, such as drug corners, and small groups of violent actors, such as gang members. Police in these cities have become more selective about who gets arrested and put into the criminal justice system in the first place.'b'Although the government has stepped up evaluation of all these programs (see the National Institute of Justice\xe2\x80\x99s impressive 'b'CrimeSolutions.gov'b' 'b'website'b'), most of the evidence is still tentative. Joan Petersilia of the Stanford Criminal Justice Center, who is monitoring California\xe2\x80\x99s wild experiment in prison downsizing, says the reform movement has been hampered by a lack of rigorous science \xe2\x80\x94 and by public impatience. To know what works, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cWe have to stay the course, and we never do in criminal justice policy.\xe2\x80\x9d Sooner or later crime ticks back up, and, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen fear gets in the American public, they will pay anything for prisons.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The quest for safe and humane alternatives to lockup faces opposition from prosecutors protecting their leverage, from corrections employee unions protecting jobs and from a private prison industry protecting profits. (Private prison operators, who house about 9 percent of prison inmates, have a vested interest in keeping prisons full because they are paid based on occupancy.) Liberal skeptics, in turn, point out that these programs do not solve the root problems: communities, bereft of good schools, decent housing and jobs, that become cradles of crime. They are right, of course, but they remind me of critics who oppose charter schools because the real problem is poverty. I\xe2\x80\x99m all for reaching out to those trapped on the bottom. But in the meantime, why not try to save some lives?'b'Rising inequality has obvious economic costs: stagnant 'b'wages'b' despite rising productivity, rising debt that makes us more vulnerable to financial crisis. It also has big social and human costs. There is, for example, strong evidence that 'b'high inequality leads to worse health'b' and higher mortality.'b'But there\xe2\x80\x99s more. Extreme inequality, it turns out, creates a class of people who are alarmingly detached from reality \xe2\x80\x94 and simultaneously gives these people great power.'b'The example many are buzzing about right now is the billionaire investor Tom Perkins, a founding member of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield &amp; Byers. In a 'b'letter to the editor'b' of The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Perkins lamented public criticism of the \xe2\x80\x9cone percent\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and compared such criticism to Nazi attacks on the Jews, suggesting that we are on the road to another Kristallnacht.'b'You may say that this is just one crazy guy and wonder why The Journal would publish such a thing. But Mr. Perkins isn\xe2\x80\x99t that much of an outlier. He isn\xe2\x80\x99t even the first finance titan to compare advocates of progressive taxation to Nazis. Back in 2010 Stephen Schwarzman, the chairman and chief executive of the Blackstone Group, 'b'declared'b' that proposals to eliminate tax loopholes for hedge fund and private-equity managers were \xe2\x80\x9clike when Hitler invaded Poland in 1939.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And there are a number of other plutocrats who manage to keep Hitler out of their remarks but who nonetheless hold, and loudly express, political and economic views that combine paranoia and megalomania in equal measure.'b'I know that sounds strong. But look at all the speeches and opinion pieces by Wall Streeters accusing President Obama \xe2\x80\x94 who has never done anything more than say the obvious, that some bankers behaved badly \xe2\x80\x94 of 'b'demonizing'b' and 'b'persecuting'b' the rich. And look at how many of those making these accusations also made the ludicrously self-centered claim that their hurt feelings (as opposed to things like household debt and premature fiscal austerity) were the main thing holding the economy back.'b'Now, just to be clear, the very rich, and those on Wall Street in particular, are in fact doing worse under Mr. Obama than they would have if Mitt Romney had won in 2012. Between the partial rollback of the Bush tax cuts and the tax hike that partly pays for health reform, tax rates on the 1 percent have gone more or less back to 'b'pre-Reagan levels'b'. Also, financial reformers have 'b'won some surprising victories'b' over the past year, and this is 'b'bad news for wheeler-dealers'b' whose wealth comes largely from exploiting weak regulation. So you can make the case that the 1 percent have lost some important policy battles.'b'But every group finds itself facing criticism, and ends up on the losing side of policy disputes, somewhere along the way; that\xe2\x80\x99s democracy. The question is what happens next. Normal people take it in stride; even if they\xe2\x80\x99re angry and bitter over political setbacks, they don\xe2\x80\x99t cry persecution, compare their critics to Nazis and insist that the world revolves around their hurt feelings. But the rich are different from you and me.'b'And yes, that\xe2\x80\x99s partly because they have more money, and the power that goes with it. They can and all too often do surround themselves with courtiers who tell them what they want to hear and never, ever, tell them they\xe2\x80\x99re being foolish. They\xe2\x80\x99re accustomed to being treated with deference, not just by the people they hire but by politicians who want their campaign contributions. And so they are shocked to discover that money can\xe2\x80\x99t buy everything, can\xe2\x80\x99t insulate them from all adversity.'b'I also suspect that today\xe2\x80\x99s Masters of the Universe are insecure about the nature of their success. We\xe2\x80\x99re not talking captains of industry here, men who make stuff. We are, instead, talking about wheeler-dealers, men who push money around and get rich by skimming some off the top as it sloshes by. They may boast that they are job creators, the people who make the economy work, but are they really adding value? Many of us doubt it \xe2\x80\x94 and so, I suspect, do some of the wealthy themselves, a form of self-doubt that causes them to lash out even more furiously at their critics.'b'Anyway, we\xe2\x80\x99ve been here before. It\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to read screeds like those of Mr. Perkins or Mr. Schwarzman without thinking of F.D.R.\xe2\x80\x99s famous 1936 Madison Square Garden 'b'speech'b', in which he spoke of the hatred he faced from the forces of \xe2\x80\x9corganized money,\xe2\x80\x9d and declared, \xe2\x80\x9cI welcome their hatred.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama has not, unfortunately, done nearly as much as F.D.R. to earn the hatred of the undeserving rich. But he has done more than many progressives give him credit for \xe2\x80\x94 and like F.D.R., both he and progressives in general should welcome that hatred, because it\xe2\x80\x99s a sign that they\xe2\x80\x99re doing something right.'b'Republican leaders have chosen an odd way to try to win back female voters alienated by relentless G.O.P. attacks on women\xe2\x80\x99s health care and freedoms. Instead of backing off, they\xe2\x80\x99re digging in, clinging to an approach that gave President Obama a 12-point advantage among women in the 2012 election and provided the slim margin of victory for Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia, in 2013. On the national level and even in some red states, the party\xe2\x80\x99s stance on women\xe2\x80\x99s rights is plainly not helping it.'b'Yet the ideological tide rolls on. States dominated by Republicans continue to enact new abortion restriction. The Republican National Committee last week heard Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, 'b'suggest'b' that Democrats favor universal access to free contraception because they think women \xe2\x80\x9ccannot control their libido\xe2\x80\x9d without the help of \xe2\x80\x9cUncle Sugar.\xe2\x80\x9d And this week, the Republican-led House is expected to pass the deceptively named No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act.'b'Federal financing for abortion has been outlawed since 1976 by what\xe2\x80\x99s known as the Hyde Amendment, harming poor women and others who rely on the federal government for their health care. Now here comes the House with a new bill that would erect new obstacles to women who might seek an abortion. For instance, it would deny tax credits to small businesses that offer health plans including abortion coverage, as most such plans now do, thus discouraging businesses from offering such plans. The measure\xe2\x80\x99s treatment of tax benefits as the equivalent of public spending for abortion seems especially strange in a landscape where people are permitted to deduct donations to religious institutions despite the constitutional bar on government support of religion. Other insidious provisions would permanently codify the Hyde Amendment, now subject to annual approval, and a ban on the District of Columbia\xe2\x80\x99s use of locally raised revenue to provide abortion care.'b'The new measure is the latest iteration of a bill introduced by Representative Christopher Smith, a New Jersey Republican, in 2010 and passed by the House in 2011 after gaining notoriety because of wording (subsequently deleted amid broad public criticism) limiting the rape exception to \xe2\x80\x9cforcible\xe2\x80\x9d rapes.'b'As House Republicans well know, the measure stands no chance of being approved in the Senate. It is thus tempting to dismiss the coming vote as political theater of the absurd, staged to stoke up enthusiasm among the party\xe2\x80\x99s core supporters. But in forging ahead, as expected, to approve the bill, the House will lend it undeserved legitimacy, encouraging more states to pass copycat legislation. And it will reinforce the notion of the Republican party as insensitive to women at just the moment when the party \xe2\x80\x94 not to mention society at large \xe2\x80\x94 would profit from a more welcoming approach.'b'The heartening effects of the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'landmark ruling'b' last June striking down the core of the Defense of Marriage Act, or DOMA, continue to ripple outward. On Jan. 21, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that gays and lesbians 'b'may not be excluded from juries'b' on the basis of their sexual orientation.'b'In a 'b'strongly worded opinion'b', Judge Stephen Reinhardt, writing for a unanimous three-judge panel, explained that the reasoning of United States v. Windsor \xe2\x80\x94 in which the Supreme Court gutted DOMA, the spiteful 1996 law that denied federal benefits to married same-sex couples \xe2\x80\x94 compelled the Ninth Circuit\xe2\x80\x99s holding.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cJury service is one of the most important responsibilities of an American citizen,\xe2\x80\x9d Judge Reinhardt wrote. Although the Windsor case addressed only marriage, Judge Reinhardt added, the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s decision was premised on the idea of equal dignity for all, a dignity enhanced by \xe2\x80\x9cresponsibilities, as well as rights.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Ninth Circuit is just the latest court to rely on the Windsor decision to expand the equal treatment of gays and lesbians. In recent weeks, federal judges in 'b'Utah'b' and 'b'Oklahoma'b' have cited Windsor in striking down state bans on same-sex marriage, a federal judge in Ohio 'b'ordered that state'b' to recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere, and state courts in 'b'New Jersey'b' and 'b'New Mexico'b' have relied on the ruling to permit same-sex marriages there.'b'The Ninth Circuit case involved a dispute between two drug companies, SmithKline Beecham and Abbott Laboratories, over the marketing and pricing of certain H.I.V. medications. During jury selection in the trial, Abbott\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer eliminated a prospective juror who had made several references to his male partner. The lawyer relied on what is known as a peremptory challenge, which allows the striking of a limited number of potential jurors without explanation. The Supreme Court has prohibited the use of such strikes based on a juror\xe2\x80\x99s race or gender; after the Windsor case, the Ninth Circuit reasoned, that prohibition must extend to a juror\xe2\x80\x99s sexual orientation.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGays and lesbians have been systematically excluded from the most important institutions of self-governance\xe2\x80\x9d based on persistent prejudice, the court wrote.'b'Critics contend that the Windsor ruling is more properly understood to protect each state\xe2\x80\x99s right to decide its own marriage laws. But that misses Windsor\xe2\x80\x99s essence, which is that DOMA\xe2\x80\x99s central, impermissible purpose was \xe2\x80\x9cto impose inequality\xe2\x80\x9d on a class of individuals without legitimate justification.'b'In applying heightened judicial scrutiny to classifications based on sexual orientation, the Ninth Circuit used a standard the Windsor ruling never explicitly applied. But the impact of that scrutiny is likely to be felt throughout the Ninth Circuit\xe2\x80\x99s nine states, in cases involving public employment, family law and same-sex marriage itself.'b'While the Supreme Court has so far declined to decide whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage, it is increasingly clear that because of its holding in Windsor, the court will be confronted with that issue sooner rather than later. Seventeen states now permit same-sex marriage \xe2\x80\x94 not counting Utah and Oklahoma, where officials are challenging the recent judicial rulings \xe2\x80\x94 and that number is likely to grow in the next few years. The court has laid the groundwork for the recognition of equal rights for all. Now it must follow through on its own reasoning.'b'New York state test data to be released later this spring will include sobering news for Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new schools chancellor, Carmen Fari\xc3\xb1a. The data show that only one in four New York City students who started high school in 2009 and graduated in 2013 performed well enough on the Regents exams to meet the state definition of college readiness. Racial and ethnic breakdowns are not yet available. But they are likely to mirror last year\xe2\x80\x99s statistics, which showed striking racial disparities: Only about 11 percent of black and about 12 percent of Hispanic graduates were deemed college-ready.'b'Mr. de Blasio, who has had a field day bashing his predecessor over this problem, must now find a way to solve it by ramping up the quality of education for poor and minority children. For starters, the city must preserve, at least in part, the controversial school evaluation system that Michael Bloomberg introduced in 2006.'b'Mr. de Blasio has rightly decided to junk the simplistic, deeply unpopular A-through-F grading system that is used to rate schools. But there is much about the evaluation system that\xe2\x80\x99s worth preserving, including its tight focus on the issue of equity, which means holding schools accountable for how well they educate poor and minority children who are too often written off and left behind.'b'Historically, the rankings compared a school\xe2\x80\x99s test scores with those of the district as a whole. But under that system, demographics ruled the day; wealthy schools invariably were ranked at the top and poor schools at the bottom. Commendably, the Bloomberg administration devised a way to control for demographically driven differences that enabled it to reach the bedrock question of how much a given school actually improves student learning from year to year. Despite its imperfections, the system found that schools with similar populations of poor and minority children posted vastly dissimilar results. This, in turn, allowed officials and teachers to zero in on a school\xe2\x80\x99s weaknesses, with positive results. The data show that over the last two years, nearly 80 percent of the lowest-performing schools improved their ratings after receiving help in the areas where they were weak.'b'The A-through-F rating system has several deficiencies. First, it lacks transparency; many people find it hard to understand how reams of complex information are crunched down into a single grade. Second, when people think of letter grades, they think of an overall quality rating, not a rating based largely on special factors. As a result, parents, lawmakers and others were confused when a school at which the overwhelming majority of students were performing well received a mediocre rating because it saw less improvement than schools at which students were not doing as well. It would be better to do away with the overall grade and continue to report a separate rating for each relevant metric \xe2\x80\x94 say, one each for overall performance, success with disadvantaged students and so on.'b'The Bloomberg administration acknowledged shortcomings in the evaluation system, especially at the elementary and middle school levels, where too much weight had been given to testing and too little weight to nontest indicators of school performance (thus forcing weaker schools to spend far too much time teaching students how to take tests). The new evaluation system must give significant weight to how well schools are preparing students for the next level and keeping children on track for college readiness.'b'The report cards can be improved and revised. But their basic purpose \xe2\x80\x94 providing a plausible system for measuring student progress \xe2\x80\x94 cannot be abandoned. If it is, city officials will never know how well students are doing until, on graduation day, they find that too many of them do not have the skills they need to go to college.'b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 The majestic view at sunset from the terrace of President Vladimir V. For decades the gathering has been one of the most important places for the trans-Atlantic community to exchange ideas, find common ground and devise foreign and security policy.'b'But when politicians, military and business leaders, think tank experts and journalists gather this Friday in southern Germany, they won\xe2\x80\x99t be in the mood for much celebration.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s because, over the last year, the Western security community has seen a series of setbacks unprecedented since the end of the Cold War. Rumsfeld, exposing the deep rift that American war plans had created in the West.'b'Not long after, the German chancellor, Gerhard Schr\xc3\xb6der, and the French president, Jacques Chirac, took things a step further, calling for a multilateral world to replace the unilateral order imposed by the United States.'b'Now we have a classic case of \xe2\x80\x9cbeware what you wish for.\xe2\x80\x9d Eleven years and one global financial crisis later, we can see in Syria what such a world might look like, with rogue states, regional wannabes and nonstate actors filling the vacuum that America\xe2\x80\x99s absence has created.'b'To be sure, the United States remains an unrivaled power, with military resources and economic prowess that no other nation can match. The risk is not so much that another country might take its place; in a way, it is that no one will.'b'Syria is a cautionary tale. It shows that the leadership vacuum is not going to be filled by benign actors, as Mr. Schr\xc3\xb6der and Mr. Chirac hoped, but by rogue actors like Al Qaeda, Hezbollah and Iran \xe2\x80\x94 and not only in Syria.'b'Libya is becoming a hotbed of extremism; Al Qaeda and other groups are using the town of Derna, near Benghazi, as a new logistics hub in the region.
