He contends that capitalism\xe2\x80\x99s inherent dynamic propels powerful forces that threaten democratic societies.'b'Capitalism, according to Piketty, confronts both modern and modernizing countries with a dilemma: entrepreneurs become increasingly dominant over those who own only their own labor. In Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s view, while emerging economies can defeat this logic in the near term, in 'b'the long run'b', \xe2\x80\x9cwhen pay setters set their own pay, there\xe2\x80\x99s no limit,\xe2\x80\x9d unless \xe2\x80\x9cconfiscatory tax rates\xe2\x80\x9d are imposed.'b'Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s book \xe2\x80\x94 published four months ago in France and due out in English this March \xe2\x80\x94 suggests that traditional liberal government policies on spending, taxation and regulation will fail to diminish inequality. Piketty has also delivered and posted 'b'a series of lectures'b' in French and English outlining his argument.'b'Conservative readers will find that Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s book disputes the view that the free market, liberated from the distorting effects of government intervention, \xe2\x80\x9cdistributes,\xe2\x80\x9d as Milton Friedman famously 'b'put it'b', \xe2\x80\x9cthe fruits of economic progress among all people. That\xe2\x80\x99s the secret of the enormous improvements in the conditions of the working person over the past two centuries.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Piketty proposes'b' instead that the rise in inequality reflects markets working precisely as they should: \xe2\x80\x9cThis has nothing to do with a market imperfection: the more perfect the capital market, the higher\xe2\x80\x9d the rate of return on capital is in comparison to the rate of growth of the economy. The higher this ratio is, the greater inequality is.'b'In a 20-page 'b'review'b' for the June issue of the Journal of Economic Literature that has already caused a stir, Branko Milanovic, an economist in the World Bank\xe2\x80\x99s research department, declared:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am hesitant to call Thomas Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s new book Capital in the 21st Century one of the best books in economics written in the past several decades. Not that I do not believe it is, but I am careful because of the inflation of positive book reviews and because contemporaries are often poor judges of what may ultimately prove to be influential. With these two caveats, let me state that we are in the presence of one of the watershed books in economic thinking.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There are a number of key arguments in Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s book. One is that the six-decade period of growing equality in western nations \xe2\x80\x93 starting roughly with the onset of World War I and extending into the early 1970s \xe2\x80\x93 was unique and highly unlikely to be repeated. That period, Piketty suggests, represented an exception to the more deeply rooted pattern of growing inequality.'b'According to Piketty, those halcyon six decades were the result of two world wars and the Great Depression. The owners of capital \xe2\x80\x93 those at the top of the pyramid of wealth and income \xe2\x80\x93 absorbed a series of devastating blows. These included the loss of credibility and authority as markets crashed; physical destruction of capital throughout Europe in both World War I and World War II; the raising of tax rates, especially on high incomes, to finance the wars; high rates of inflation that eroded the assets of creditors; the nationalization of major industries in both England and France; and the appropriation of industries and property in post-colonial countries.'b'At the same time, the Great Depression produced the New Deal coalition in the United States, which empowered an insurgent labor movement. The postwar period saw huge gains in growth and productivity, the benefits of which were shared with workers who had strong backing from the trade union movement and from the dominant Democratic Party. Widespread support for liberal social and economic policy was so strong that even a Republican president who won easily twice, Dwight D. Eisenhower, recognized that an assault on the New Deal would be futile. In 'b'Eisenhower\xe2\x80\x99s words'b', \xe2\x80\x9cShould any political party attempt to abolish Social Security, unemployment insurance, and eliminate labor laws and farm programs, you would not hear from that party again in our political history.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The six decades between 1914 and 1973 stand out from the past and future, according to Piketty, because the rate of economic growth exceeded the after-tax rate of return on capital. Since then, the rate of growth of the economy has declined, while the return on capital is rising to its pre-World War I levels.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf the rate of return on capital remains permanently above the rate of growth of the economy \xe2\x80\x93 this is Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s key inequality relationship,\xe2\x80\x9d Milanovic writes 'b'in his review'b', it \xe2\x80\x9cgenerates a changing functional distribution of income in favor of capital and, if capital incomes are more concentrated than incomes from labor (a rather uncontroversial fact), personal income distribution will also get more unequal \xe2\x80\x94 which indeed is what we have witnessed in the past 30 years.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Piketty has 'b'produced the chart'b' at Figure 1 to illustrate his larger point.'b'The only way to halt this process, he argues, is to impose a global progressive tax on wealth \xe2\x80\x93 global in order to prevent (among other things) the transfer of assets to countries without such levies. A global tax, in this scheme, would restrict the concentration of wealth and limit the income flowing to capital.'b'Piketty would impose an annual graduated tax on stocks and bonds, property and other assets that are customarily not taxed until they are sold. He leaves open the rate and formula for distributing revenues.'b'The Piketty diagnosis helps explain the recent drop in the share of national income going to labor (see 'b'Figure 2'b') and a parallel increase in the share going to capital.'b'Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s analysis also sheds light on the worldwide growth in the number of the unemployed. The International Labor Organization, an agency of the United Nations, 'b'reported recently'b' that the number of unemployed grew by 5 million from 2012 to 2013, reaching nearly 202 million by the end of last year. It is projected to grow to 215 million by 2018.'b'Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s wealth tax solution runs directly counter to the principles of contemporary American conservatives who advocate antithetical public policies: cutting top rates and eliminating the estate tax. It would also run counter to the interests of those countries that have purposefully legislated low tax rates in order to attract investment. The very infeasibility of establishing a global wealth tax serves to reinforce Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s argument concerning the inevitability of increasing inequality.'b'Some liberals are none too happy with Piketty, either.'b''b'Dean Baker'b', one of the founders of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, wrote me in an email that he believes that Piketty \xe2\x80\x9cis far too pessimistic.\xe2\x80\x9d Baker contends that there are a host of far less ambitious actions that might help to ameliorate inequality:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIs it really implausible that we would ever see any sort of tax on finance in the U.S., either the financial transactions tax that I would favor or the financial activities tax advocated by the I.M.F.?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Baker also noted that \xe2\x80\x9cmuch of our capital is tied up in intellectual property\xe2\x80\x9d and that reform of patent laws could serve both to limit the value of drug and other patents and simultaneously lower consumer costs.'b''b'Lawrence Mishel'b', the president of the Economic Policy Institute, responded to my email asking for his take on Piketty:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99d take the perspective that this phenomenon is related to the suppression of wage growth so that policies which generate broad-based wage growth are an antidote. The political economy is such that the political power to enact those taxes also requires a mobilized citizenry and institutional power, such as a robust labor movement.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Daron Acemoglu'b', a more centrist economist at MIT, praised Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s careful acquisition of data, as well as his emphasis on the economic forces and political conflicts over distribution that shape inequality. In an email, Acemoglu went on to say:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPart of his interpretation I do not share. Piketty argues that there is a natural tendency for high inequality in \xe2\x80\x98capitalist\xe2\x80\x99 economies (the term capitalist is not my favorite) and that certain unusual events (world wars, the Great Depression and policy responses thereto) temporarily reduced inequality. Then both earnings inequality and inequality between capital and labor have been reverting back to their \xe2\x80\x98normal\xe2\x80\x99 levels. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think that the data allow us to reach this conclusion. All we see is this pattern of fall and rise, but so many other things are going on. It is consistent with what Piketty says, but it is also consistent with certain technological changes and discontinuities (or globalization) having created a surge in inequality which will then stabilize or even reverse in the next several decades. It is also consistent with the dynamics of political power changing and this being a major contributor to the rise in inequality in advanced economies. We may be seeing parts of several different trends underpinned by several different major shocks rather than the mean-reverting dynamics following the shocks that Piketty singles out.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is, however, significant liberal applause for Piketty.'b''b'Richard Freeman'b', an economist at Harvard who specializes in inequality, unions and employment patterns, wrote me by email:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am in 100 percent agreement with Piketty and would add that much of labor inequality comes because high earners got paid through stock options and capital ownership.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Freeman and two colleagues, Joseph Blasi and Douglas Kruse, professors at the School of Labor and Management Relations at Rutgers, contend in 'b'their 2013 book'b', \xe2\x80\x9cThe Citizen\xe2\x80\x99s Share: Putting Ownership Back into Democracy,\xe2\x80\x9d that they have an alternative to a global wealth tax. They argue that:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe way forward is to reform the structure of American business so that workers can supplement their wages with significant capital ownership stakes and meaningful capital income and profit shares.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In other words, let\xe2\x80\x99s turn everyone into a capitalist.'b'Piketty does not treat worker ownership as a solution, and he is generally dismissive of small-bore reforms, arguing that they will have only modest effects on economic growth worldwide, which he believes is very likely to be stuck at 1 to 1.5 percent through the rest of this century.'b'Piketty joins a number of scholars raising significant questions about how the global economic system will deal with such phenomena as 'b'robotics'b', the 'b'hollowing out'b' of the job market, 'b'outsourcing'b' and 'b'global competition'b'.'b'His prognosis is extremely bleak. Without what he acknowledges is a politically unrealistic global wealth tax, he sees the United States and the developed world on a path toward a degree of inequality that will reach levels likely to cause severe social disruption.'b'Final judgment on Piketty\xe2\x80\x99s work will come with time \xe2\x80\x93 a problem in and of itself, because if he is right, inequality will worsen, making it all the more difficult to take preemptive action.'b'Every winter since 2009, President Obama has stood at the podium of the House and pleaded for the cooperation of Congress. For the last three State of the Union speeches, he has largely been ignored. That has left a growing trail of unfinished business: background checks for gun buyers, immigration reform, a higher minimum wage, tax fairness, universal preschool.'b'This year was different. Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s speech on Tuesday night acknowledged the obvious: Congress has become a dead end for most of the big, muscular uses of government to redress income inequality and improve the economy for all, because of implacable Republican opposition. As a result, the remainder of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s presidency will be largely devoted to a series of smaller actions that the White House can perform on its own.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAmerica does not stand still, and neither will I,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cSo wherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Taking the offensive by veering around Congress 'b'isn\xe2\x80\x99t new'b' for the administration, but it is more important than ever. As the president forcefully described, inequality has deepened and upward mobility has stalled. If Republicans in Congress stymie the public\xe2\x80\x99s needs and desires, Mr. Obama should employ every tool in his box to bypass those barriers. The multistate tour that he plans in the coming days will give him a chance to be even more critical of Congress than he was in the House chamber.'b'Most of the executive actions in the speech have the potential to make a difference, though their diminished scope demonstrates the lost potential caused by political intransigence. 'b'Raising the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour for federal contract workers'b' might benefit only a few hundred-thousand people, but it increases the pressure on other businesses and, ultimately, Congress to raise the wage for everyone. (The $10.10 wage, however, provides an income too paltry to celebrate as a huge achievement.)'b'The increased focus on federal job-training efforts and manufacturing institutes could help reduce unemployment by improving job skills to match the market, as will a $100 million competition to goad high schools into 'b'improving science, technology and math learning'b'. Give America a raise.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One particularly promising request the president made of Congress was to expand the earned-income tax credit, which now benefits 15 million families a year, 'b'to workers without children'b'. As an Orthodox rabbi, one who advocates for a more open and inclusive Orthodoxy, I\xe2\x80\x99ve often attested to the Jewish status of congregants who wish to marry in Israel, as required by the Chief Rabbinate. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been doing so for 45 years, but in October, one of my letters was rejected. Suddenly, my judgment had been found unacceptable.'b'Eventually, protests about that rejection moved the Chief Rabbinate to change its mind and restore my ability to attest for candidates for marriage. But the episode has propelled me to raise a larger issue: the Chief Rabbinate\xe2\x80\x99s far-reaching and exclusive control in Israel over personal matters like marriage, and its intrusion into the affairs of the Diaspora. It is time to decentralize the Chief Rabbinate\xe2\x80\x99s power and to give Jewish communities greater say in what is acceptable for their members.'b'The modern institution of the Orthodox Chief Rabbinate was created for the Jewish community in Palestine by the British during the Mandate period and kept in place when the independent state of Israel was established in 1948. The Chief Rabbinate controls the foundations of Jewish life in Israel: conversion, marriage, burial, food and more.'b'In a democratic state like Israel, it might seem anomalous for a centralized body appointed by the government to be invested with so much power over individual affairs. For a time, the Chief Rabbinate was perceived to serve all the Jewish people. Today it is largely seen and experienced by many Jews in Israel and abroad as an intrusive and coercive religious body. Not only does it impose Orthodox religious law on all Jews, but it also demands ultra-strict standards in most areas it oversees.'b'The recent events are just one manifestation of this. Since there is no civil marriage for Jews in Israel, those wishing to marry must prove, to the satisfaction of the Chief Rabbinate, that they are Jewish. In the past, a statement provided by an Orthodox rabbi had been sufficient. Without warning, I and some other Orthodox rabbis found ourselves on a \xe2\x80\x9cblacklist\xe2\x80\x9d last October; our testimony was no longer considered reliable.'b'It would have been easier to remain quiet and avoid the embarrassment that rejection had caused me. I realized, however, that the issue had serious consequences for Jews in Israel and abroad. I therefore went public by challenging the Chief Rabbinate in the press in the hope that community awareness and involvement would lead to a solution. I was ready to bring the matter before the Israeli Supreme Court.'b'The Chief Rabbinate\xe2\x80\x99s reversal in my case, earlier this month, was an encouraging sign, but the issue is far from resolved. Systemic problems persist.'b'In the late \xe2\x80\x9990s, I published an essay articulating a vision of Open Orthodoxy. Those who identify with this vision believe in the divinity of the Torah and are committed to the detailed observance of the practices of Jewish law. But commitment does not have to mean rigidity. We believe in an Orthodoxy that empowers women to be more involved in Jewish ritual and spiritual leadership; invites religious questioning; promotes dialogue across the Jewish denominations; welcomes all people regardless of sexual orientation or level of religious observance; and looks outward, driven by a sense of responsibility to all people.'b'The Chief Rabbinate, in contrast, has been turning inward, taking religiously extreme positions, consolidating and extending its power. In 2008, in one sweeping move, it limited the right to participate in American conversions to a short list of handpicked rabbis and rabbinical courts. It did so by enlisting the full cooperation of a major American rabbinical association that ceded its autonomy and capitulated rather than stand up for all of its members in the field.'b'This was a major step backward. One of the most vibrant aspects of Orthodoxy in America has been its decentralization and proliferation of many voices. It would be particularly distressing for Orthodoxy in America to reverse course and adopt the stifling hierarchical model of the Israeli Rabbinate.'b'In a democratic Jewish state, options must be available. For example, an Orthodox group in Israel, Ne\xe2\x80\x99emanei Torah Va\xe2\x80\x99Avodah, has proposed that communities elect their own religious leadership and receive state funding. In matters like marriage and conversion, communal standards would be taken into consideration instead of dictates imposed from above.'b'This does not mean that individual Orthodox rabbis in Israel would be obliged to go against their conscience by accepting all conversions or marriages as valid. No rabbi should be asked to compromise personal standards of Jewish law. But Israel is a state for all the Jewish people. As such, it should allow for the option of secular as well as religious marriage.'b'Coercion and religion do not mix. Religious choice would benefit all. When choice is available, religion in general and Orthodoxy in particular will fare better because people will have the freedom to embrace faith willingly. An imposed religion is a disservice to the people and a disservice to religion.'b''b'\n'b'Avi Weiss,'b'an Orthodox rabbi, is the spiritual leader of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, in the Bronx. 'b''b'President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan seems to have decided that there is nothing lost, and maybe something to be gained, in destroying his relationship with the United States. He had just been cursed at and kicked by senior citizens for sitting in a seat designated for \xe2\x80\x9cthe elderly and the infirm.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The man, whom we know only by his surname of Kim, was sentenced on Jan. 14 by a Seoul court to one year and six months in prison. One news article reporting the results of his trial garnered more than 1,000 comments in just one day, most of which were from sympathetic younger people complaining about being forced to give up their seats on the subway to senior citizens. Mr. Kim is hardly young, but his frustration resonated with the younger generations.'b'The Seoul subway\xe2\x80\x99s designated-seating section has become a curious backdrop of intergenerational conflict in South Korea. In the 40 years or so since full-scale industrialization began, the social divide between generations has widened. Senior citizens grew up during Japanese occupation and the Korean War, and lived through the era of breakneck economic growth that followed, building a modern country from the ground up in just a few decades, most of the time under a military dictatorship. Most younger South Koreans have come of age in a time of relative affluence and freedom, and like many younger people in East Asia, have gradually become more independent-minded than their elders and less attached to the traditional Confucian values that have been the basis of Korean society for centuries.'b'In recent years, South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s economic woes have put strain on both groups, and frustrations are high. Older South Koreans are finding themselves financially unprepared for retirement, while younger people can\xe2\x80\x99t find jobs. The Seoul subway is a rare place where the generations cross paths \xe2\x80\x94 and the intergenerational tensions are playing out in the crowded trains.'b'South Korea is one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s most rapidly aging countries. It is expected to become an \xe2\x80\x9caged society,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the United Nations\xe2\x80\x99 definition of 14 percent of the population above age 65, in four years. South Korea also has the third lowest birthrate in the world.'b'The country\xe2\x80\x99s elderly spent their lives assuming their children would care for them in old age and did little to prepare for retirement. But their children don\xe2\x80\x99t appear to be fulfilling their end of the bargain \xe2\x80\x94 and now the elderly are not faring well economically. The relative poverty rate among senior citizens in South Korea is 49.3 percent, the highest of the industrialized countries. Public pensions tend to be small. And the suicide rate for senior citizens, surely an indicator of economic strain, is the highest among the industrialized countries, at about 80 for every 100,000 people.'b'Meanwhile, South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s younger people are facing unemployment not seen since the early 1980s. More than half of the country\xe2\x80\x99s college-educated youth in their 20s remains unemployed or has stopped searching for work.'b'The notoriously congested Seoul Metropolitan Subway, which opened in 1974 and covers a total of some 200 miles, transports an average of 7 million passengers per day, which is more than twice the daily average of London\xe2\x80\x99s Tube. For years, \xe2\x80\x9cpushmen\xe2\x80\x9d were employed at busy stations to stuff hundreds of extra passengers into each train. In 2008, the subway switched to employing \xe2\x80\x9ccutmen\xe2\x80\x9d instead, who prevent people from boarding cars once they are full.'b'At both ends of each subway car, 12 seats are set aside for \xe2\x80\x9cthe elderly and the infirm.\xe2\x80\x9d As the name suggests, these seats are intended for senior citizens as well as for the handicapped and pregnant women, but in practice they are mostly occupied by the elderly.'b'According to the Seoul Metropolitan Subway authorities, there was a sharp increase in the number of complaints over the seats, from 252 in 2009 to 536 in 2011 (the latest year for which statistics are available). Anecdotal evidence suggests the trend has continued.'b'About two years ago, I had unintentionally sat in one of the elderly-designated seats on the subway and was checking my email when I looked up to meet the eyes of a scowling elderly man. I got up right away. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t thank me, but continued to stare at me from across the train. There had been other free seats for him to use, but he pressured me to get up just to make the point that I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been sitting there.'b'All subway lines in South Korea are free for those over 65 years of age, so most elderly people use it whenever possible. There was a time when young people were happy to give up their seats for the elderly. And the elderly, fitting to tradition, have always assumed they had a right to a seat occupied by a younger person. But young people today are simply less deferential to their elders.'b'The fighting over seats mirrors a vast political gap outside the subway. A majority of older Koreans support President Park Geun-hye and the governing party, but the younger generation is strongly opposed to her leadership. Many older people feel nostalgia for the days of Park Chung-hee, the current president\xe2\x80\x99s father, when they were more prosperous and the country was in the throes of exciting development.'b'For now, South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s intergenerational conflict seems limited to the underground. But without a meaningful dialogue on how to help both our struggling elderly and disaffected young people, the tensions will find a way of rising to the surface.'b''b'\n'b'Young-ha Kim 'b' is a novelist and short-story writer. There is no law against that behavior in China?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The police officer stammered and said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, of course that is a crime.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So I continued, \xe2\x80\x9cBut because the man was my husband, it\xe2\x80\x99s O.K.? Being married makes it legal to beat a woman?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A female officer said to me, \xe2\x80\x9cYou and your husband are both good people, just calm down a little, go home, everything will be fine.\xe2\x80\x9d Barely able to see clearly, I pointed to my swelling forehead and said, \xe2\x80\x9cDoes this look fine to you?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I was trying to file a report against my husband for assaulting me, but as far as the police were concerned, no crime had occurred. After an afternoon of pressing the police to acknowledge the crime and failing, I went home and posted a picture on Weibo, a microblogging platform, showing only my injured forehead, hoping that some friends among my 23 followers would respond to a cry for help.'b'My photograph unleashed a torrent of pent-up frustration, agony and support from abused women across China. Within hours of my post, it was forwarded and commented on by more than 20,000 people. I was inspired by the reaction, and the next day went again to a police station and insisted on making an official report. The saga took more than a week and eventually the police officially acknowledged my husband\xe2\x80\x99s abuse.'b'My now ex-husband is a prominent Chinese businessman, famous for a chain of English-language schools that we built together. I\xe2\x80\x99m an American who has adopted China as my home. Our story was played out in the media, leading to widespread attention on us, and more importantly, on the cause of domestic abuse. In the two and a half years since the attack, I have partnered with the United Nations and a Beijing domestic violence organization to foster awareness of the problem and help victims.'b'The All-China Women\xe2\x80\x99s Federation reports that nearly 25 percent of married women in China have experienced domestic violence. But the abuse is far more prevalent than those numbers show: A large percentage of attacks go unreported. When women find the courage to go to the police, they most often meet the kind of resistance I did. Meanwhile, the legal system favors men \xe2\x80\x94 even abusive men \xe2\x80\x94 leaving desperate women few options.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve received countless messages from Chinese women describing a culture that denies there is a problem. One woman wrote to me in frustration: \xe2\x80\x9cI accompanied my injured mother to the police station, but the officers here didn\xe2\x80\x99t even know the term \xe2\x80\x98domestic violence.\xe2\x80\x99 They only say that this kind of \xe2\x80\x9cprivate matter\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cfamily problem\xe2\x80\x9d is common and there isn\xe2\x80\x99t anything they can do.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When abused women are ignored by the police, the last legal option is divorce in civil court. But divorce still carries a heavy stigma for Chinese women, and this is another strong deterrent for women to take action against abusive husbands. Those who pursue divorce have an uphill battle: Among all divorces filed on the grounds of domestic violence, about 3 percent are awarded on this basis alone. If the court fails to recognize the husband\xe2\x80\x99s violence but still grants the divorce, the result can be financially devastating for the woman. Even more horrifying, divorce puts the woman at risk of losing custody of her children, as the parent with the higher income is seen as the better caretaker.'b'Those who have never lived through domestic violence often wonder about the victim, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t she just leave?\xe2\x80\x9d The answers to this question are varied and complex, but for women in China there is a very practical answer to consider: There is no place to go. Support services are few and far between even in the largest cities, and there are no functioning shelters to speak of.'b'Faced with the prospect of a lengthy divorce that could end up costing a woman her home and her child, is it any wonder that prisons are full of women who attacked their husbands with axes and fruit knives rather than rely on the law to protect themselves? Surveys of some women\xe2\x80\x99s prisons have shown that more than 60 percent of inmates were sentenced for injuring or killing their husbands in retaliation for domestic violence. Many women convicted of killing their husbands serve life sentences, while most men who beat their wives to death serve only several years in prison.'b'In 2009, a 26-year-old Beijing woman, Dong Shanshan, reported her abusive partner to local police eight times, only to repeatedly have her bruises and complaints dismissed as \xe2\x80\x9cfamily problems.\xe2\x80\x9d She was later beaten to death by him. He received a sentence of six and a half years, for the crime of \xe2\x80\x9cmaltreatment.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'China needs better domestic violence laws. Only a smattering of local courts are able to issue protection orders against abusive husbands. A national anti-domestic violence law has been drafted and is under consideration by the government. The legislative process is too opaque to know where things stand. Its opponents say that \xe2\x80\x9cfamily matters cannot be legislated,\xe2\x80\x9d yet last year the national government passed a highly publicized law requiring grown children to visit their elderly parents.'b'It is heartening that some localities are pushing ahead with anti-domestic violence laws in the absence of a national law, but it is not enough. Only a national law can drastically raise awareness that domestic violence is in fact a crime. It would give women something to reference when turned away by the police or even to warn abusive husbands with.'b'In the aftermath of the publicity around my case, I was often asked by incredulous Chinese media why I, as an American, put up with my husband\xe2\x80\x99s violence. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think nationality makes a difference when it comes to the shame and fear women feel about speaking up. No woman is eager to say her family isn\xe2\x80\x99t happy. No woman is proud of the fact that the man she loves beats her. I\xe2\x80\x99m sure my nationality contributed to the amount of attention that my case received, but certainly no more than the fact that my Chinese ex-husband is a celebrity.'b'Domestic violence isn\xe2\x80\x99t a country-specific problem or a cultural phenomenon. It\xe2\x80\x99s a crime. Stopping it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t start with laws \xe2\x80\x94 though in some countries, like in China, new laws are necessary. It starts with voices willing to rise above geographic, political and linguistic barriers to shout out that domestic violence will not be tolerated, excused or ignored.'b''b'\n'b'Kim Lee 'b' is a childhood educator and an advocate for the rights of victims of domestic abuse. And his first song: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Star-Spangled Banner.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'HAROLD LANGUS'b'\nStaatsburg, N.Y., Jan. 29, 2014'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Afghanistan Exit Is Seen as Peril to Drone Mission'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 27), you report the concern of intelligence agencies that they will lose the bases from which to launch drone rocket strikes.'b'The Central Intelligence Agency should not be launching deadly military strikes. As the article reports, the troubling trend of a shrinking labor force, even while our working-age population is growing, signals a serious problem in our labor markets.'b'That problem is a lack of jobs. Unemployment insurance cuts will not solve that problem, and they are likely to make it worse.'b'ALEXANDRA SIROTA'b'\nDirector'b'\nNorth Carolina Budget and Tax Center'b'\nRaleigh, N.C., Jan. 23, 2014'b''b''b''b'WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 IN his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama focused on reversing the growth of economic inequality in the United States and restoring the American dream. At the same time, he also announced his support for fast track authority that would limit Congress\xe2\x80\x99s role in determining the content of trade agreements.'b'The president\xe2\x80\x99s call follows on legislation introduced earlier this month to grant him fast-track authority as a way of forcing Congress to speed up its consideration of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation pact with Latin American and Asian nations.'b'But Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s desire for fast-track authority on the T.P.P. and other agreements clashes with another priority in his speech: reducing income inequality.'b'This month is the 20th anniversary of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which significantly eliminated tariffs and other trade barriers across the continent and has been used as a model for the T.P.P. Anyone looking for evidence on what this new agreement will do to income inequality in America needs to consider Nafta\xe2\x80\x99s 20-year record.'b'While many analysts focus on the number of jobs lost from Nafta and similar pacts \xe2\x80\x94 and some estimates say upward of a million \xe2\x80\x94 the most significant effect has been a fundamental change in the composition of jobs available to the 63 percent of American workers without a college degree.'b'At Nafta\xe2\x80\x99s core \xe2\x80\x94 and proposed for the T.P.P. \xe2\x80\x94 are investor rights and privileges that eliminate many of the risks that make firms think twice about moving production to low-wage countries. Today, goods once made here are being produced in Mexico and exported here for sale. Indeed, American manufacturing exports to Mexico and Canada grew at less than half the rate after Nafta than in the years before it.'b'As a result, our trade deficit has ballooned. In 1993, before Nafta, the United States had a $2.5 billion trade surplus with Mexico and a $29 billion deficit with Canada. In 2012, the combined Nafta trade deficit was $181 billion, even as the share of that deficit made up of oil imports dropped 22 percent. The average annual growth of our trade deficit has been 45 percent higher with Mexico and Canada than with countries that are not party to a Nafta-style pact. The companies that took the most advantage of Nafta \xe2\x80\x94 big manufacturers like G.E., Caterpillar and Chrysler \xe2\x80\x94 promised they would create more jobs at their American factories if Nafta passed. Instead, they fired American workers and shifted production to Mexico.'b'The Labor Department\xe2\x80\x99s Trade Adjustment Assistance program, which documents this trend, reads like a funeral program for the middle class. More than 845,000 workers have been certified under this one narrow and hard-to-qualify-for program as having lost their jobs because of offshoring of factories to, and growing imports from, Mexico and Canada since Nafta.'b'The result is downward pressure on middle-class wages as manufacturing workers are forced to compete with imports made by poorly paid workers abroad. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, nearly two out of every three displaced manufacturing workers who were rehired in 2012 saw wage reductions, most losing more than 20 percent.'b'The shift in employment from high-paying manufacturing jobs to low-paying service jobs has contributed to overall wage stagnation. The average American wage has grown less than 1 percent annually in real terms since Nafta, even as productivity grew three times faster.'b'But the decline in the wages of workers who lost a job to Nafta is only part of the story. They joined the glut of workers competing for low-skill jobs that cannot be done offshore in industries like hospitality and food service, forcing down real wages in these sectors as well.'b'And, for America\xe2\x80\x99s remaining manufacturing workers, Nafta put downward pressure on wages by enabling employers to threaten to move jobs offshore during wage bargaining. A 1997 Cornell University study ordered by the Nafta Commission for Labor Cooperation found that as many as 62 percent of union drives faced employer threats to relocate abroad, and the factory shutdown rate following successful union certifications tripled after Nafta.'b'This is hardly news; in the early 1990s a spate of studies resulted in an academic consensus that trade flows contributed to between 10 and 40 percent of inequality increases. Indeed, since Nafta\xe2\x80\x99s implementation, the share of national income collected by the richest 10 percent has risen by 24 percent, while the top 1 percent\xe2\x80\x99s share has shot up by 58 percent.'b'Some advocates of Nafta-style pacts acknowledge that they will cause the loss of some jobs, but argue that workers will win over all by being able to purchase cheaper imported goods.'b'But when the Center for Economic and Policy Research applied the data to the theory, they found that reductions in consumer prices had not been sufficient to offset losses in wage levels. They found that American workers without college degrees had most likely lost more than 12 percent of their wages to Nafta-style trade, even accounting for the benefits of cheaper goods. This means a loss of more than $3,300 per year for a worker earning the median annual wage of $27,500.'b'The Nafta data poses a significant challenge for President Obama. As he said on Tuesday, he wants to battle the plague of income inequality and he wants to expand the Nafta model with T.P.P. But he cannot have it both ways.'b'WHEN New York City\xe2\x80\x99s mayor, Bill de Blasio, 'b'went to Albany'b' earlier this week to talk about his program for universal preschool, the discussion reportedly focused on funding, not on whether or how preschool would actually help children. President Obama seemed equally confident when he 'b'introduced his plan'b' for universal preschool last year, flatly stating, \xe2\x80\x9cWe know this works.\xe2\x80\x9d But the state of research is actually much murkier. And unless policy makers begin to design preschool programs in ways that can be evaluated later, the situation won\xe2\x80\x99t get any clearer.'b'A preschool that \xe2\x80\x9cworks\xe2\x80\x9d could mean different things. It might simply be a safe spot for kids to go. Or it could be a means to get poor kids ready to learn reading and math; they are currently eight to 10 months behind wealthy kids when they start kindergarten. Mayor de Blasio and the president are more ambitious: They think that preschool ought to change life trajectories, resulting in more high school graduates and fewer prison inmates. These plans have two precedents in particular, the Abecedarian and Perry preschool programs from the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s, whose students went farther in school and, decades later, had better jobs than children from similar backgrounds who did not attend those programs.'b'But large state programs differ from these model programs in two important ways. First, Perry and Abecedarian attendees were randomly selected from a large group of volunteers. The other kids served as the comparison group, which made it easy for researchers to assess the programs\xe2\x80\x99 impact. Large state programs seldom use random selection, so their effectiveness is more open to debate.'b'In addition, Perry and Abecedarian were expensive, intensive programs. Preschools in large state programs inevitably vary in what they do, and they show variable results. That\xe2\x80\x99s why advocates always solemnly intone that preschool must be \xe2\x80\x9chigh quality.\xe2\x80\x9d But what does that actually mean?'b'Researchers know what doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work. Preschools that focus mostly on social activities (as the federal 'b'Head Start'b' program does) show minimal academic benefits. But trying to teach primarily reading and math to 4-year-olds \xe2\x80\x94 essentially putting a kindergarten curriculum into preschool \xe2\x80\x94 doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work either.'b'The preschools that do work teach less well-prepared kids precursor skills, the kind that many wealthy kids learn at home, through activities that don\xe2\x80\x99t look especially academic. Songs and rhyming games, for example, help children hear that words are composed of individual sounds, making it easier to learn how to read letters. Kids gain knowledge about the world \xe2\x80\x94 important for reading comprehension in later elementary years \xe2\x80\x94 when they are read to by their parents and when they listen to them. Jigsaw puzzles and globes help kids develop spatial skills, which later help with math. Household rules teach children to learn to control their impulses, part of learning self-discipline.'b'Teaching these precursor skills in a preschool setting, rather than at home, is not easy. Teachers have just a few hours per day and many children to serve. But at present, it is not often a key objective.'b'So large state preschool programs have two problems: It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to guarantee quality at the outset, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to evaluate results once the program gets going. But both problems can be addressed.'b'First, we should capitalize on what we know. Small-scale studies indicate that some curriculums (like 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBuilding Blocks\xe2\x80\x9d'b' for mathematics) are effective. We know some features of preschools (like a warm emotional climate) are important. The federal government ought to ensure that states have access to concise research summaries of what does and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work. Such communication is currently not a priority, but it could increase the proportion of good schools pretty painlessly.'b'Second, high-quality evidence requires planning. Ideally, we would be able to compare kids with access to the program to kids without access. If all children gain access at the same time, we\xe2\x80\x99re stuck with less-optimal research methods and uncertain results. Policy makers could encourage states to randomly vary when and where new programs start \xe2\x80\x94 complications of pre-K implementation will probably make this necessary in any case. Yes, there\xe2\x80\x99s a moral bullet to be bitten in the short term because some families will gain access to preschool later than others. But gaining high-quality evidence for program effectiveness is the best strategy for the long term.'b'Third, comparing preschool programs is hard because quality depends not just on factors in the classroom like the curriculum and the teacher\xe2\x80\x99s skill, but also on how those factors interact with sleep, nutrition, parenting and other aspects of domestic life. Yet we know little about such interactions.'b'To understand them, we need a national study (enrolling perhaps 15,000 children) that would collect detailed information about the family and the preschool, beginning at age 3 and continuing through at least second grade.'b'Helping poor children succeed will not be easy, and we\xe2\x80\x99d be fools to think we\xe2\x80\x99ll get this right the first time. We need the tools of science to help plan course corrections, which means planning policies so that both scientists and teachers can learn on the job.'b'It was hard to watch President Obama during Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s State of the Union address and not see a man who has had his coat trimmed and his ambitions adjusted.'b'He touted his accomplishments, as he should have, but in laying out the parameters of his \xe2\x80\x9cyear of action\xe2\x80\x9d he outlined goals that didn\xe2\x80\x99t ask America to dream as much as adjust to the paralysis, abandoning big moves for smaller ones.'b'Republican lawmakers have made clear that they have no desire to work with him and that they have every intention of opposing him, even if that means the legislative branch passes almost no laws. And that\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what they\xe2\x80\x99ve done. In December, 'b'Politico put it this way'b': using \xe2\x80\x9cpublic laws passed\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbills passed\xe2\x80\x9d as the measurement, \xe2\x80\x9cthe 113th Congress has passed just 58 laws so far, the lowest since 1947.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So, the president pledged Tuesday that he would work with Congress where he could, but would move forward without Congress if necessary, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to do.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His plans were noble enough, and they were poll-friendly \xe2\x80\x94 raising the minimum wage, working for universal high-quality pre-K, equal pay for women, a new \xe2\x80\x9cMyRA\xe2\x80\x9d retirement savings plan \xe2\x80\x94 but they are not nearly large enough proposals to solve our most intractable problems.'b'There was only one line devoted to fixing our \xe2\x80\x9cupside-down tax code\xe2\x80\x9d for individuals, and that was in reference to the retirement account. Gone were the appeals to get Congress to have the wealthy pay their fair share.'b'Last year, the president put it this way:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t ask senior citizens and working families to shoulder the entire burden of deficit reduction while asking nothing more from the wealthiest and the most powerful.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He continued:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMost Americans \xe2\x80\x94 Democrats, Republicans and independents \xe2\x80\x94 understand that we can\xe2\x80\x99t just cut our way to prosperity. They know that broad-based economic growth requires a balanced approach to deficit reduction, with spending cuts and revenue, and with everybody doing their fair share.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Last year, on the issue of new gun control legislation, the president said:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt has been two months since Newtown. Overwhelming majorities of Americans \xe2\x80\x94 Americans who believe in the Second Amendment \xe2\x80\x94 have come together around common-sense reform, like background checks that will make it harder for criminals to get their hands on a gun.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This year, he mentioned gun violence only once, saying:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cCitizenship means standing up for the lives that gun violence steals from us each day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The only big proposal that even has a chance this year is comprehensive immigration reform, and its prospects are far from certain.'b'Last year, the president spoke extensively about passing immigration reform, repeating, \xe2\x80\x9cNow is the time to do it. Now is the time to get it done. Now is the time to get it done.\xe2\x80\x9d He spoke about stronger border security, a pathway to citizenship and decreasing waiting times for highly skilled immigrants.'b'This year, he spoke of immigration in a single passage, with no specifics other than to cite this: \xe2\x80\x9cIndependent economists say immigration reform will grow our economy and shrink our deficits by almost $1 trillion in the next two decades.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The president seems to have been reduced by the resistance. He seems to be concentrating on what can be done rather than on what should be done. This is a rational reaction, I suppose, to irrational opposition, but nonetheless it\xe2\x80\x99s a sad indictment of our politics.'b'The president has had failures and missteps, to be sure. Every administration has some. None are perfect. But the idea of grinding government to a halt in opposition to one leader \xe2\x80\x94 as Republicans have done \xe2\x80\x94 has been an extraordinary and infuriating thing to behold.'b'And it has been sad to watch a president full of hope and promise be stymied at nearly every turn and have to reframe his objectives.'b'In 'b'an article this week'b' in The New Yorker, Obama attempted to give context to his struggles and place his term in the long sweep of history:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I think America was very lucky that Abraham Lincoln was President when he was President. If he hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been, the course of history would be very different. But I also think that, despite being the greatest President, in my mind, in our history, it took another hundred and fifty years before African-Americans had anything approaching formal equality, much less real equality. I think that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t diminish Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s achievements, but it acknowledges that at the end of the day we\xe2\x80\x99re part of a long-running story. We just try to get our paragraph right.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The president who was fond of proclaiming that under his leadership, the country was beginning a \xe2\x80\x9cnew chapter\xe2\x80\x9d on everything from 'b'diplomacy'b' to 'b'climate change'b', is now just trying to get his paragraph right.'b'All of a sudden, early childhood education is really, really popular. Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s favorite. If early childhood education were an actor, it would be Tom Hanks or Meryl Streep. If it were a video game, it would be Candy Crush or Angry Birds, minus the spyware.'b'The other night at the State of the Union speech, President Obama mentioned \xe2\x80\x9chigh-quality early education\xe2\x80\x9d and John Boehner applauded. Boehner applauded early education! Paul Ryan likes it, too. Prekindergarten is so in, the guys on \xe2\x80\x9cDuck Dynasty\xe2\x80\x9d would probably have a good word for it.'b'Kudos, guys! We certainly don\xe2\x80\x99t want to complain about this. Early education is one of the best tools for breaking the poverty-to-poverty trap. Unfortunately, it only works if it\xe2\x80\x99s high quality, and high quality is expensive. Yet very little of this newfound enthusiasm comes with serious money attached.'b'Last year, in his State of the Union speech, President Obama called for universal preschool for 4-year-olds, to be paid for by a tobacco tax that would raise $78 billion over 10 years. The prekindergarten idea was hailed throughout the nation. The tax part did not go anywhere. To say it was dead on arrival at Congress is an insult to the word \xe2\x80\x9cdead.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEverybody seems to agree we need some sort of national effort to provide preschool education to our kids. What we don\xe2\x80\x99t have is any discussion about how to pay for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Senator Patty Murray who is, I am pretty sure, the first former preschool teacher ever to run the Senate Budget Committee.'b'When President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s detailed budget proposal comes out, he\xe2\x80\x99ll presumably include some way of paying for his universal preschool idea. Perhaps it will be the tobacco tax again. Perhaps you will never know because, in recent years, the presidential budget has all the traction and clout of a small mouse attempting to cross a frozen lake. During a windstorm. While wearing bedroom slippers.'b'Here in New York, we\xe2\x80\x99re having a political dispute that pits the let\xe2\x80\x99s-just-cheer camp against the pick-a-tax crowd. Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to pay for universal prekindergarten for New York City 4-year-olds with an increase in the income tax rate for high income city residents. He got elected on this issue, but he needs the state\xe2\x80\x99s permission.'b'Gov. Andrew Cuomo says he\xe2\x80\x99ll just give de Blasio some money out of the state budget. This is an election year, and Cuomo is definitely not targeting any taxpayers, even if the ones in question are jumping up and down and waving their arms to get attention.'b'The mayor wants money the city can count on to keep coming every year. It\xe2\x80\x99s a very interesting argument. If New York is lucky, the nation will find the debate so fascinating that everyone will forget about the fact that on Tuesday, shortly after Obama called for more quality prekindergarten classes, a congressman from New York City threatened to throw a reporter off the Capitol balcony. This had nothing to do with early childhood education, but you know how people talk.'b'Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s estimate of how much it would cost to do preschool for the entire state is lower than de Blasio\xe2\x80\x99s estimate for just New York City. Which is, on a per-pupil basis, much lower than the amount New Jersey spends on a much-praised prekindergarten program. (Cheers to New Jersey for your effort to provide quality early education to the state\xe2\x80\x99s poorest children. We are so impressed that we will leap right over the fact that you only did it because a judge made you.)'b'One way to dodge the responsibility for coming up with actual cash for a great leap in preschool financing is to argue, as Cuomo does, that you need to roll these things out slowly. \xe2\x80\x9cTo do it on a large scale is very difficult,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ron Haskins of the Brookings Institution, a former adviser to the Bush administration. But Haskins thinks poor children\xe2\x80\x99s needs are so great, and so immediate, that it\xe2\x80\x99s worth the risk. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re desperate. These kids are coming into school already a grade behind,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'A quarter of the youngest Americans are poor. We need to get to them quickly, and do the job right, well before they\xe2\x80\x99re 4. And while we should start with the neediest families, if the programs are good, middle-class parents are rightfully going to point out that they need help, too.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99ll be a huge number of kids, and the classes have to be really small. Also, the teachers have to get much better pay. They go into the business out of love, but when you are talking about median salaries of $27,000 a year, sometimes love is not enough. All in all, we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about a ton of money.'b'So here\xe2\x80\x99s the question: How much of the new enthusiasm for early childhood education is real, and how much is just an attempt to dodge the whole inequality debate? Maybe we could agree that no politician is allowed to mention pre-k without showing us the money.'b'Against all odds, prekindergarten is gaining ground.'b'President Obama called again 'b'in his State of the Union address'b' for Congress to support high-quality preschool for all, noting that 30 states are already moving ahead on this front (including New York).'b'\xe2\x80\x9cResearch shows that one of the best investments we can make in a child\xe2\x80\x99s life is high-quality early education,\xe2\x80\x9d Obama said. The House speaker, John Boehner, who sat stonily through most of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s speech, applauded that line. Congress also unexpectedly increased financing this year for early education.'b'Aside from apple pie, preschool may also be the only issue on which voters agree. 'b'A poll last year found'b' that 60 percent of Republicans and 84 percent of Democrats support expansion of prekindergarten. Republican-led states like Oklahoma have been leaders in early education for a simple reason: It works.'b'Yet one obstacle is the misperception that early education has been debunked by researchers \xe2\x80\x94 when, in fact, it\xe2\x80\x99s the opposite. With so many programs and billions of dollars at stake, let\xe2\x80\x99s carefully review the evidence.'b'Advocates focus on the stunning success of two tiny programs in the 1960s and 1970s, 'b'Perry Preschool'b' and 'b'Abecedarian'b'. Children from low-income families who participated in them were more likely to graduate from high school and get a job and less likely to end up on welfare.'b'Yet critics correctly note that programs often work when small but don\xe2\x80\x99t scale up. It\xe2\x80\x99s an open question whether those two programs would have an impact as great today if they were rolled out nationwide.'b'Republican critics focus on (and misunderstand) a major, well-designed project called 'b'the Head Start Impact Study'b'. It found that Head Start produces educational gains that fade away. By third grade, when the research ended, there was little detectable difference between those assigned to Head Start and those in control groups.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s disappointing. And that\xe2\x80\x99s why critics denounce Head Start as a waste of money.'b'Yet early education has always had an impact not through cognitive gains but through long-term improvements in life outcomes. With Perry, Abecedarian and other programs, educational gains fade, yet, mysteriously, there are often long-term improvements on things that matter even more, such as arrest rates and high school graduation rates. The Head Start Impact Study couldn\xe2\x80\x99t examine those outcomes.'b'Other researchers have, and their findings are almost unanimous. 'b'One rigorous study led by Eliana Garces'b', then of U.C.L.A., found that Head Start graduates were more likely to graduate from high school and attend college than their peers. 'b'David Deming of Harvard found'b' that children who attended Head Start were more likely to graduate from high school and less likely as young adults to be \xe2\x80\x9cidle\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 out of a job and out of school.'b'Jens Ludwig of University of Chicago found that Head Start reduced child mortality in elementary years, apparently because of screening and treatment referrals.'b'Beyond Head Start, a series of randomized trials of other early education initiatives repeatedly found the same result: Long-term outcomes improve.'b'When experts weigh these benefits against short-term costs, preschool for at-risk kids from low-income families more than pays for itself. (It\xe2\x80\x99s not as clear that this is as true for middle-class kids.) When we have kids growing up in poverty and homes without books, we end up paying one way or the other. We can invest 'b'in preschool today'b' (about $8,000 per child per year), or 'b'in juvenile detention tomorrow'b' (around $90,000 per child per year).'b'So where does this prekindergarten \xe2\x80\x9csleeper effect\xe2\x80\x9d come from? Nobody is quite sure. Maybe children learn self-discipline, patience or grit.'b'Or maybe parents do. Alexander Gelber of University of California, Berkeley, found that parents of children in Head Start are significantly more likely to read to them, and spend more time reading to them \xe2\x80\x94 even years later. Parents are more likely to take them to museums. Dads living apart spend an extra day a month with them.'b'The United States is an outlier in early education. 'b'We rank 28th out of 38 industrialized countries'b' in the share of 4-year-olds in preschool. In Shanghai, with one of the top-performing school systems in the world, nearly all preschoolers participate in early education programs.'b'Of course, what we need in America isn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cpre-k\xe2\x80\x9d narrowly but broad investment in young children, and that\xe2\x80\x99s what Obama proposes. Programs like Nurse-Family Partnership or Reach Out and Read that coach low-income parents on reading to their kids and other parenting skills seem to have a particularly powerful long-term impact.'b'One of the most consequential national debates this year will be about early education. The evidence that it builds opportunity is overwhelming. So the next time you hear people scoff that it\xe2\x80\x99s a failure, push back \xe2\x80\x94 and school them.'b'Few bills of real substance emerge from today\xe2\x80\x99s polarized Congress, and those that do tend to be misshapen lumps. They have enough useful provisions to win approval from Democrats, but are weighed down by the dangerous and occasionally bizarre demands of the many branches of the Republican Party.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s certainly the case with the $956 billion farm bill that 'b'passed the House on Wednesday'b' with bipartisan support. It seems headed for approval by the Senate and the White House in the next few days. It makes some of the most significant reforms to wasteful agriculture subsidies in many years, and it contains dozens of important provisions designed to increase employment in rural areas and save lives with farsighted crop research. It preserves some important environmental protections, while cutting others. And though its food-stamp provisions were saved from being much worse, they will still reduce benefits for too many poor people.'b'On balance, the bill is clearly worthy of support, particularly because it will prevent austerity fanatics in future Congresses from gutting food stamps for the next five years. It will save $16.6 billion over a decade, or $23 billion if you count existing budget cuts imposed in the last two years. But endorsing the bill also means acknowledging the low expectations for real progress in Washington.'b'The most important reform in the bill is the elimination of direct payments to farmers, which provided cash subsidies in good years and bad, whether crop prices were high or low. This program was one of the worst abuses in the federal budget, and negotiators in the House and Senate should be commended for overcoming intense lobbying to preserve it, thereby saving $19 billion over 10 years.'b'To protect farmers from disaster in bad years, the bill moves $7 billion of that savings into a beefed-up insurance subsidy program, which is a better way of reducing risk. But that program is still too generous to big farmers. As 'b'the Environmental Working Group argues'b', the subsidies should have been means-tested. Reducing the insurance program\xe2\x80\x99s size might have paid for more food stamps.'b'Negotiators took an important step by linking crop insurance subsidies to requirements that farms meet environmental standards, including soil conservation and wetlands protection. But a few smaller conservation programs were eliminated, and the overall amount spent on conservation was cut by $4 billion.'b'The bill also pays for research to improve crop yields and reduce plant disease that could have an important effect in developing countries, along with energy-efficiency programs and new manufacturing opportunities in agriculture-related businesses.'b'The most painful cut in the bill is the $8 billion reduction in food stamps over a decade. The effect of this is limited to 'b'4 percent of recipients'b', or 850,000 families, who would lose about $90 a month. Most of them live in the 16 states that have taken advantage of a loophole in a utility-assistance program, receiving benefits that Congress did not intend. That loophole should have been closed, but not in such a precipitous way for needy families.'b'Nonetheless, the bill\xe2\x80\x99s authors rejected the far worse cuts in the original House bill, which would have tossed 3.8 million people from the program. As the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities argues, rejecting the farm bill means rolling the dice that the next Congress will do a better job. In today\xe2\x80\x99s environment, that\xe2\x80\x99s a tough bet.'b'It is bad enough that the death penalty is barbaric, racist and arbitrary in its application, but it is also becoming less transparent as the dwindling number of death-penalty states work to hide the means by which they kill people.'b'The increased secrecy around lethal-injection drug protocols is only the latest tactic of pro-death-penalty legislators and corrections officials around the country. In Missouri, this secrecy was 'b'upheld last week'b' by a federal appeals court, which denied a condemned inmate\xe2\x80\x99s constitutional claim that he is entitled to basic information about the drugs that would be used to put him to death.'b'Herbert Smulls 'b'was executed late Wednesday'b' for the 1991 murder of a jewelry-store owner. Missouri refused to name the pharmacy or pharmacies involved in producing the execution drugs.'b'Missouri\xe2\x80\x99s secrecy, along with new legislation in states such as Georgia and Tennessee, is a response to a mounting \xe2\x80\x9ccrisis\xe2\x80\x9d in death-penalty states: Because many drug manufacturers now refuse to supply drugs for use in executions, states are scrambling to replenish their stocks. This often means turning to 'b'compounding pharmacies'b', which exist in a largely unregulated world.'b'In 2011, the Drug Enforcement Administration 'b'seized'b' Georgia\xe2\x80\x99s supply of one lethal-injection drug after concerns that it had been illegally imported from Britain. And last fall, Louisiana officials sought to buy drugs from an Oklahoma pharmacy, the Apothecary Shoppe, which 'b'was not licensed to provide drugs'b' in Louisiana.'b'There have been multiple reports of previously untested drug combinations leading to botched executions, which is a polite way of saying the condemned person suffered greatly while being put to death. (On Jan. 16, an Ohio man, Dennis McGuire, 'b'appeared'b' to gasp and choke after being administered a new combination of lethal-injection drugs.) States should simply admit that they don\xe2\x80\x99t really know how these drug protocols will work, but instead they have tried to hide almost all information about the drugs and who makes them \xe2\x80\x94 increasingly through legislation.'b'Some courts have had little patience for this behavior. In July, a Georgia judge issued a last-minute stay of execution to one inmate, reasoning that the state\xe2\x80\x99s secrecy law \xe2\x80\x9c'b'makes it impossible'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to show that the drug protocol violates the Eighth Amendment.'b'But, on Friday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit 'b'ruled'b' that Mr. Smulls had no constitutional claim against Missouri\xe2\x80\x99s practice because he had not demonstrated that the \xe2\x80\x9crisk of severe pain\xe2\x80\x9d from the state\xe2\x80\x99s intended drug protocol would be substantially greater than a readily available alternative. As the dissent argued, this \xe2\x80\x9cplaces an absurd burden on death row inmates,\xe2\x80\x9d who must identify \xe2\x80\x9ca readily available alternative method for their own executions,\xe2\x80\x9d even though the state won\xe2\x80\x99t let them see the method it plans to use.'b'Meanwhile, Missouri and other states race to execute inmates using new and untested drug protocols developed on the fly and under a cowardly shroud of secrecy. Mr. Smulls was the third inmate executed in Missouri since November. In some states, lawmakers have even proposed 'b'reintroducing older execution methods'b', such as the firing squad and electrocution, so as to avoid the escalating legal battles over lethal injection.'b'In the end, the argument over what is the most \xe2\x80\x9chumane\xe2\x80\x9d way to kill someone only obscures the larger point, which is that, in the 21st century, the United States has no business putting people to death by any means. Public support for capital punishment has reached a 40-year low, and virtually all other Western societies have rejected it. It will end here, too, but not until this despicable practice is dragged out into the open for all to see.'b'LAGOS, Nigeria \xe2\x80\x94  In the weeks since Jan. 7, when President Goodluck Jonathan signed the Same Sex Marriage Prohibition Act into law, nearly 40 purportedly gay men have been arrested in Bauchi State alone, with warrants out for the arrests of another 168 suspects, according to Dorothy Aken\xe2\x80\x99Ova, executive director of the International Center for Reproductive Health and Sexual Rights. So far, it seems that at least one man has been punished, with 20 lashes. No doubt much is happening that we are not hearing about. Many things go unreported in Nigeria for all sorts of reasons, not the least of them being a justice system that often contradicts itself.'b'Take the new law. It stipulates 14 years in prison for anyone who enters into a same-sex union, and 10 years for \xe2\x80\x9cany person who registers, operates or participates in gay clubs, societies and organizations or directly or indirectly makes public show of same-sex amorous relationship.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is assuming that English Common Law \xe2\x80\x94 which Nigeria inherited from Britain after independence \xe2\x80\x94 will be applied. However, in the years since military rule ended in 1999, and in defiance of the secular provisions of the Constitution, nine of the 19 northern states, including Bauchi, embraced Shariah, as did some parts of another three.'b'Those arrested in the north will be tried under Islamic law, where the punishment for sodomy is death. Their cases will be tried in the so-called Area Courts, which were summed up by a retired magistrate in a report by the Civil Liberties Organization. \xe2\x80\x9cEspecially in criminal matters,\xe2\x80\x9d he declared, there is \xe2\x80\x9ca general ignorance of applicable laws and procedure.\xe2\x80\x9d This was illustrated in 2002 in cases against two women who were sentenced to be stoned to death for adultery. But their sentences were overturned. No one in modern times has been executed that way in Nigeria, although at least one man did have his right hand amputated for stealing a cow.'b'The Islamic legal code is enforced by a special, state-funded force known as Hisbah, partly because some state governments don\xe2\x80\x99t believe the federal police are up to the job. While it is true that the federal police are understaffed and mired in corruption, it is also doubtful that they would want to spend their limited resources  arresting people on morals charges. The well-funded Hisbah, by contrast, are a zealous lot. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will go into every nook and cranny,\xe2\x80\x9d said Usman Nabahani, deputy head of the Hisbah in Kano State, to fully enforce \xe2\x80\x9cthe prohibition of prostitution, gay marriages and consumption of alcohol.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is absurd on several levels. State police forces are illegal under the Constitution, even though state governors say they are needed to fight crime. Moreover, homosexuality was already a criminal offense under federal law, so why bother with yet another statute, one that has drawn so much international protest?'b'Preserving national unity \xe2\x80\x94 or the illusion of it \xe2\x80\x94 is one reason. That was why Olusegun Obasanjo, president from 1999 to 2007, ignored the challenge to his authority when he turned a blind eye to the imposition of Shariah in the first place, declaring that it would soon \xe2\x80\x9cfizzle out.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Jonathan, a Christian and a southerner, also can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to offend Muslim sensibilities. Desperate to win re-election in February 2015, he knows his only real hurdle is among the majority Muslim northerners, many of whom consider him an interloper. When, as vice president, he succeeded his northern predecessor, President Umaru Yar\xe2\x80\x99Adua, who died in 2010, Mr. Jonathan repudiated an arrangement by his own People\xe2\x80\x99s Democratic Party stipulating that the north and the south would take turns holding Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s presidency for two, four-year terms. Now a powerful coalition of prominent northerners have agreed to  work to ensure his defeat.'b'Still, the anti-gay bill is popular throughout the country. Christian leaders, who wield much political as well as moral power, were full of praise. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the beliefs of most Nigerians, same sex marriage is offensive to us as a people,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pastor Ayo Oritsejafor, president of the Christian Association of Nigeria. \xe2\x80\x9cWhile we love all human beings created by God, we also believe that human beings must have restraint.\xe2\x80\x9d He added that individual countries should be free \xe2\x80\x9cto develop according to their cultures.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Behind these sentiments lie the widespread belief that homosexuality is somehow un-African, along with the idea that societies that permit such \xe2\x80\x9cungodly\xe2\x80\x9d acts (i.e. the West) are displaying their moral depravity.'b'So far, only a few prominent voices have spoken out against the law, notably Wole Soyinka, the Nobel laureate, who simply said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat people do in their bedrooms is no business of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Foreign objections  have come with threats to withdraw aid. This apparently worked with Uganda, which has backpedaled on its call to jail gay people for life. But, unlike Uganda, Nigeria is a major oil producer.  Britain has announced an increase in development aid from 200 million pounds ($332 million) to nearly \xc2\xa3270 million. The United States, which buys 70 percent of Nigeria\xe2\x80\x99s crude, is considering its options.'b'Though Nigeria has now joined 37 other African countries that outlaw homosexuality, there is some solace in the fact that 13 others \xe2\x80\x94 South Africa, Congo, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Central African Republic, Chad, Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso, Benin Republic, Ivory Coast, Guinea Bissau and Equatorial Guinea \xe2\x80\x94 have actively legislated to protect the rights of L.G.B.T. people.'b'Meanwhile, the Kenyan writer Binyavanga Wainaina has ratcheted up the debate by choosing to come out, asserting, among other things, that homosexuality in Africa actually \xe2\x80\x9ccame out of the box a long time ago\xe2\x80\x9d but that attacking it has been an easy tool for populists. He also belittled talk that it was somehow foreign. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a pan-Africanist,\xe2\x80\x9d he declared. \xe2\x80\x9cI belong to this continent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\n'b'Adewale Maja-Pearce'b' is a writer and critic, and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cRemembering Ken Saro-Wiwa, and Other Essays.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'In recent months, India has welcomed the Japanese emperor, then the defense minister, and last weekend, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, at national Republic Day celebrations. K. Shankar Bajpai, a former secretary of Indian external affairs, said: \xe2\x80\x9cIndia and Japan can honestly say that they are not building relations in hostility against China. But it is right for them to plan for the eventuality of Chinese hostility.\xe2\x80\x9d Between India and Japan, this is largely a marriage of convenience.'b'Both have territorial disputes with China.
